Body mass index may fall short as a reliable health predictor compared to body fat analysis, according to research published in the Annals of Family Medicine. The findings indicate body fat percentage offers superior accuracy for evaluating long-term death risk.

Research Methodology and Findings

Scientists employed bioelectrical impedance analysis to measure body fat in participants, using electrical currents to assess tissue resistance. Data came from 4,252 American adults in the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey.

Results demonstrated people with elevated body fat faced 1.6 times higher overall death risk over 15 years. Cardiovascular fatalities increased more than threefold among this group, while BMI proved wholly unreliable for predicting mortality during the same period.

Doctor measuring obese man's waist

BMI's Limitations Exposed

Dr. Frank Orlando, the study's senior author and medical director at UF Health Family Medicine, asserted BMI shouldn't be treated as a vital health indicator. "We use BMI to screen for body composition issues, but it lacks the accuracy of true vital signs," he explained. BMI categories classify individuals as underweight (below 18.5), normal weight (18.5-24.9), overweight (25-29.9), or obese (30+).

Man lifting weights

BMI's limitations become apparent in cases like bodybuilders, Orlando noted: "Their muscle mass can produce obesity-range BMI readings despite excellent health." Researcher Mainous emphasized BMI's entrenchment in medical culture, stating, "The study proves we should adopt alternatives that perform significantly better."

Future of Body Composition Assessment

While DEXA scans offer greater precision than BIA, their high cost and limited accessibility present barriers for widespread use. Unaffiliated physician Dr. Kate Vogel acknowledged BMI's role in population-level screening but noted it "fails to provide accurate individual patient data."

Overweight patient at doctor

The research team recognized body fat thresholds lack BMI's standardization and that participant age ranges were limited by data constraints. Future studies should prioritize older adult populations, they recommended.

doctor seated with patient

Vogel highlighted the need for affordable, universally applicable body composition assessments: "These findings strengthen calls for new standards to enhance health evaluations." Researchers anticipate BIA could become standard practice when body fat percentage thresholds become formally validated.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: World Has Three Years to Prevent Breaching Critical 1.5C Warming Threshold
fields.summary: Leading climate scientists warn current CO2 emission rates leave only three years before exhausting Earth's carbon budget for limiting warming to 1.5°C, with accelerating sea-level rise and extreme weather underscoring the urgency for immediate emissions reductions to avoid catastrophic impacts.
fields.content:
Current carbon dioxide emission levels leave Earth with just three years before exceeding the critical carbon budget needed to limit global warming to 1.5°C, according to urgent warnings from over 60 leading climate scientists. Nearly 200 countries committed to this target through the 2015 Paris Agreement to prevent severe climate change effects.

Continued record consumption of coal, oil, and gas paired with deforestation has accelerated planetary heating, evidenced by rising sea levels and weather extremes like 2022's record 40°C temperatures in the UK. Professor Piers Forster of Leeds University's Priestley Centre warns changes are 'moving in the wrong direction', with unprecedented warming and sea-level rise acceleration directly linked to high emissions.

The Shrinking Carbon Budget

At the start of 2020, the remaining carbon budget allowing a 50% chance of staying under 1.5°C was 500 billion tonnes of CO2. By 2025, that budget has shrunk to just 130 billion tonnes due to persistent high emissions and refined scientific estimates. With annual emissions at 40 billion tonnes, the budget will be depleted within three years - potentially committing the world to breach the Paris target.

Graph showing rise in global air temperatures since 1850

2024 marked the first year global temperatures surpassed 1.5°C over pre-industrial levels (reaching 1.36°C from human causes), boosted by natural weather patterns. The planet now warms at 0.27°C per decade - faster than any recorded geological period - putting Earth on track for sustained 1.5°C warming around 2030 without rapid emission cuts.

Accelerating Climate Impacts

The climate system now accumulates heat at double the 1970s-1980s rate, creating a 'very worrying' energy imbalance according to the UK Met Office's Dr. Matthew Palmer. Declining air pollution particles has intensified warming, with oceans absorbing 90% of excess heat - disrupting marine ecosystems and expanding seawater volume to raise sea levels.

Global sea-level rise has doubled since the 1990s, dramatically increasing coastal flooding risks worldwide. Melting glaciers further compound sea-level threats to vulnerable communities. The research notes some progress as clean technology deployment slows emission growth, emphasizing that avoiding 1.5°C breach requires immediate 'rapid and stringent' global action.

Waves crash against a sea wall

'Every fraction of warming' matters

While exceeding 1.5°C might be technically reversible through carbon removal technologies, Imperial College London's Professor Joeri Rogelj cautions against reliance on such solutions. Each incremental warming degree dramatically escalates extreme weather severity, ice melt, and sea-level rise with global consequences.

'Reductions this decade can critically change warming rates,' Rogelj stresses, adding that 'every fraction of warming avoided reduces harm to vulnerable populations and societal challenges.' Evidence shows impacts at 2°C warming far exceed those at 1.5°C, making immediate emission reductions vital for planetary stability.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: 1,000-Year-Old Mummy Unearthed During Utility Work in Peru
fields.summary: Utility workers in Lima, Peru, discovered an exceptionally preserved 1,000-year-old female mummy just 20 inches below ground during routine excavation. The pre-Inca remains with intact hair offer new insights into ancient South American cultures that flourished before Spanish colonization.
fields.content:
Utility workers in Peru reportedly found a remarkably preserved 1,000-year-old mummy while digging trenches in Lima, pre-dating the Inca Empire by centuries. The female remains were discovered only 20 inches underground and displayed intact dark brown hair in photographs of the find.

Archaeologists confirmed the individual lived approximately 400 years before the Inca Empire (1400-1533 A.D.), placing the remains in the pre-Hispanic era. Radiocarbon dating suggests links to the Chancay culture, which thrived in coastal Peru from 1000 to 1470 A.D.

Worker next to mummy in ground

Jose Aliaga, an archaeologist with utility company Cálidda, told The Associated Press the discovery was unequivocally pre-Hispanic. "We found remains and evidence that there could be a pre-Hispanic burial," he explained, adding such discoveries remain common across the Peruvian coastline containing tombs and mummified individuals.

Lima, now a metropolis of 10 million people, has sustained human settlement for thousands of years due to its unique geography. The city’s position in a valley nourished by three Andes-fed rivers created habitable conditions for early civilizations despite the coastal desert environment.

Mummy seen through yellow tape, fencing

Pieter Van Dalen, dean of Peru’s College of Archaeologists, noted natural mummification frequently occurs in the region's arid climate, where heat dehydrates skin tissue. He confirmed that Peruvian mummies are often discovered positioned upright with hands covering their faces - a common funerary practice.

The discovery adds to numerous archaeological remains frequently unearthed across Lima, where construction often reveals ancient remains. Archaeologists continue studying such finds for insights into pre-Columbian societies that inhabited western South America before Spanish colonization in 1535.

Spanish signs outside discovery site

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Portland WNBA Team Dismisses President After Just Two Months
fields.summary: Portland's WNBA expansion franchise has reportedly dismissed team president Inky Johnson just two months after hiring her in April. The unexpected move comes as the new team prepares to announce its official name next month, with the WNBA declining immediate comment on the dismissal.
fields.content:
Portland's upcoming WNBA franchise has reportedly dismissed team president Inky Johnson shortly after her April hiring, unexpectedly ending her tenure after just two months. The team is currently counting down to a major announcement on July 15, which is widely believed to reveal the new team's official name.

Exterior view of Moda Center

The WNBA league office declined to provide any immediate comment when contacted about Johnson's reported dismissal. No official reason has been given for the sudden leadership change.

Following her appointment in April, Johnson expressed enthusiasm about the position: 'I am honored to be in a position like this to further the women’s game, and I look forward to creating a winning environment for our future players, our staff and the fans of Portland.'

Cathy Engelbert poses

At the time of Johnson's hiring, ownership executive Christina Whitehead had expressed confidence in her leadership: 'As the very first employee of the organization, Inky will lay the groundwork for our future growth, and we are confident her leadership will drive the franchise to new heights, creating a lasting impact both in Portland and across the WNBA.'

Johnson's responsibilities had included overseeing all business operations for the expansion team, including marketing strategy, ticket sales, sponsorships, community engagement, and financial management as the franchise prepares for its inaugural season.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Texas Instruments Announces Record $60 Billion US Semiconductor Investment
fields.summary: Texas Instruments has committed to investing over $60 billion in US semiconductor manufacturing facilities across Texas and Utah, creating approximately 60,000 jobs. This pledge comes amid ongoing pressure from former President Donald Trump to boost domestic chip production and follows similar announcements from other tech companies.
fields.content:
Semiconductor manufacturer Texas Instruments (TI) plans to inject more than $60 billion (£44.74 billion) into expanding US-based chip production operations. This significant commitment responds to continued calls from former President Donald Trump urging technology companies to establish more manufacturing facilities domestically.

The Dallas-headquartered technology firm will construct or upgrade seven semiconductor plants across sites in Texas and Utah, generating an estimated 60,000 new positions. While TI confirmed the substantial investment amount, it refrained from providing a specific implementation timeline for these expansion projects.

Characterizing the scale of this initiative, the company declared it represents the largest commitment ever made toward foundational semiconductor manufacturing within the United States. This announcement follows another major domestic investment pledge from chipmaker Micron, which recently unveiled plans to invest $200 billion in US operations.

US Secretary of Commerce Howard Lutnick commented on the development, stating: "President Trump has made it a priority to increase semiconductor manufacturing in America." Lutnick added in an official statement, "Our partnership with TI will support US chip manufacturing for decades to come."

According to industry observers, TI's unveiled financial figures incorporate funding previously allocated for building or upgrading manufacturing facilities. Analysts speculate such large-scale spending announcements may partly aim to appease Trump, who has repeatedly threatened to dismantle the $52.7 billion CHIPS and Science Act originated during the Biden administration.

The political backdrop includes a $1.6 billion subsidy that TI secured from the Biden administration last December following its initial commitment to invest $18 billion in constructing three new manufacturing plants. Trump has additionally cautioned about imposing potential tariffs on semiconductor imports.

Unlike specialized artificial intelligence chip producers such as Nvidia, Texas Instruments concentrates on foundational semiconductors used across various electronic devices including smartphones and automobiles. The corporation operates 15 global facilities spanning the US and Asia, supplying technology to prominent clients including Apple, Ford, and SpaceX.

This strategic expansion unfolds as TI encounters intensifying competitive pressure from Chinese manufacturers specializing in comparable entry-level chips. The company's investment highlights the growing emphasis on strengthening domestic semiconductor production capabilities amid global technological rivalries.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Kara Pod: Revolutionary Device Converts Air into Pure Water and Coffee
fields.summary: The Kara Pod appliance creates up to a gallon of mineral-rich drinking water daily by extracting moisture from the air, while also brewing coffee using compostable pods. This innovative device eliminates plastic bottle waste, requires no plumbing, and saves users approximately $1,464 annually on bottled water expenses.
fields.content:
The Kara Pod provides pure hydration without plumbing connections or plastic waste, removing concerns about refills and environmental impact. This countertop gadget generates water and coffee through an entirely self-contained system.

After extracting moisture from the air, the device purifies it and enhances it with essential minerals including calcium, magnesium, and sodium. This process yields premium alkaline water, producing up to 3.2 liters (1 gallon) per day that's stored in an auto-refilling tank.

Kara Pod mineral enrichment visualization

Device brewing coffee with various pods

Compatible with Kara-branded and original Nespresso capsules, the appliance allows users to brew tea or coffee at customized strengths and serving sizes via touchscreen controls. Used pods are designed to be compostable, extending its eco-friendly approach.

Household using Kara Pod appliance

By eliminating bottled water dependence, Kara Pod saves users about $1,464 yearly while dehumidifying spaces and filtering airborne dust. Its plug-and-play operation requires no specialized installation, freeing consumers from purchasing and transporting heavy water containers.

Device in small living space like RV

Ideal for apartments with unreliable pipes, off-grid homes, RVs, or environmentally conscious consumers, Kara Pod also enhances coffee quality by using mineral-balanced water. The pure water optimizes flavor profiles of specialty coffee beans.

Biomimicry inspiration from desert beetle

Its technology mimics the moisture-harvesting behavior of Namibia's Stenocara beetle, employing biomimicry and desiccant processes. While atmospheric water generators have existed industrially, Kara Pod represents a breakthrough in countertop adaptation.

Sustainable hydration future concept

This device spearheads a future combining sustainable hydration with brewing convenience. It addresses water quality anxieties, plastic pollution, and recurring grocery trips through a unified appliance powered by ambient air.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Doechii's Five-Year Plan: From Obscurity to Grammy Winner and Glastonbury Headliner
fields.summary: Grammy-winning artist Doechii boldly predicted her rise to stardom five years ago. Now, fresh from her victory and critical acclaim, she prepares for a headline Glastonbury set, fulfilling her meticulously crafted vision of success.
fields.content:
In 2023, rising musician Doechii declared a strategic five-year blueprint to become one of music's biggest stars. She precisely outlined, "By year five I want to be at my peak," emphasizing aspirations to reach a dominant career phase comparable to Beyoncé's iconic Sasha Fierce persona.

Back then, these ambitions appeared audacious. The Florida-born rapper and singer had garnered niche attention through tracks like Persuasive, which landed on Barack Obama's summer playlist. Yet mainstream chart success remained elusive.

By 2025, Doechii defied expectations entirely. She claimed a Grammy Award for best rap album—making her only the third woman ever to win in the category—and earned Billboard's "Woman of the Year" title. Her journey culminates soon with a coveted slot at Glastonbury Festival.

CBS Doechii on Stephen Colbert's Show

Her breakout moment is debated among fans. Many credit her hypnotic performance on The Late Show with Stephen Colbert last December, featuring intricate choreography for Boiled Peanuts and Denial Is a River. The skit portrayed her seeking therapy after discovering her boyfriend's infidelity.

Others highlight her vibrant Tiny Desk concert released two days later. The 15-minute NPR session showcased jazz-infused versions from her mixtape Alligator Bites Never Heal, radiating both soulfulness and fiery energy.

Getty Images Doechii performs the splits while being held aloft by dancers at the Grammy Awards

Her Grammy acceptance speech empowered marginalized fans: "Don’t allow anybody to project any stereotypes on you—that you can’t be here, that you’re too dark, not smart enough, too dramatic or too loud." She punctuated the victory with an athletic dance tribute to Michael Jackson and Missy Elliott, climaxing in a suspended split.

Jaylah Ji’mya Hickmon grew up in Tampa amid bullying so severe she contemplated suicide. At age 11, she created her Doechii persona as armor. Recalling this transformation, she stated, "Jaylah might’ve been getting bullied, but I decided Doechii wouldn’t stand for that," marking a pivotal identity shift.

Doechii / X Doechii as a child

Attending Howard W. Blake School of the Arts, she explored chorus, ballet, gymnastics, and stagecraft. "Gymnastics taught me to embrace pain as strength," she reflected. The environment also helped her embrace her queer identity—friends there encouraged her music career after initially aiming for classical singing.

Doechii Artwork for Doechii's single Girls

As "iamdoechii," she debuted on SoundCloud in 2016 and self-released Girls in 2018—an early display of rapidfire lyricism and confidence. Yet financial struggles persisted; she once traveled to New York for a gig and slept at McDonald's, unable to afford a return trip.

Reuters Doechii holds her Grammy Award

'Drowning in vices'

After signing with Kendrick Lamar's label Top Dawg Entertainment, Doechii achieved her first Top 40 hit via Kodak Black collaboration What It Is. Success soon stalled—she described herself as "drowning in vices" amid creative blocks and label tensions.

Her 2024 mixtape Alligator Bites Never Heal initially flopped commercially, barely charting at No. 117. However, critical reception dazzled. Rolling Stone praised its "fully-realized brilliance," with Pitchfork noting its urgency against constraints.

Getty Images Doechii wears a custom smoking jacket, crimson cravatte and a cigar, while posing on the red carpet of the 2025 Met Gala

The powerful Colbert and Tiny Desk features revitalized interest, propelling Alligator into the US Top 10. Fan demand also resurrected her 2019 track Anxiety, which soared to No. 3 in the UK and drew recognition from Psychology Today for authentically depicting panic attacks.

Now immersed in her debut album, Doechii prepares for Glastonbury while teasing artistic evolution: "The new project explores how my hip-hop student persona develops." Her 45-minute set promises a triumphant validation of the journey foreseen half a decade ago.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: TypInc: The Roguelike Typing Game That Channels Balatro Energy
fields.summary: TypInc blends frantic keyboard action with deckbuilding strategy, tasking players to accurately type literary passages under time pressure while unlocking Balatro-inspired perk cards for multiplier bonuses.
fields.content:
After countless hours with Balatro, many players are seeking similar roguelike experiences during the wait for its 1.1 update. Enter TypInc—an ingenious fusion of typing challenges and deckbuilding mechanics that channels Balatro's addictive formula into a keyboard-based battleground.

TypInc structures gameplay around typing proficiency as players attempt to survive 30 in-game days. Each day presents paragraphs from public-domain literature like George Orwell's 1984 and Charlotte Perkins Gilman's The Yellow Wallpaper, ranging from straightforward lines to tongue-twisting phrases like "conscientiously" and "black-moustachio'd face." Participants race against a visible timer, correcting red-highlighted errors with frantic backspacing while multiplier chimes reward accuracy.

TypInc perk card selection screen

Successful days earn currency to unlock perk cards that dramatically alter gameplay. These Balatro-inspired modifications include boosting multipliers for short words, adding +3 mult per typed period, and converting error-free streaks into bonus multipliers. Others enhance the point value of specific keyboard keys, turning literary classics into point-scoring opportunities.

Though potentially educational for typing skills with live speed and accuracy feedback, TypInc faces limitations on handheld devices like Steam Deck where on-screen keyboards hinder peak performance. The tension-filled gameplay requires precise typing, with the ticking clock, streak sounds, and error indicators demanding intense focus.

Slated for full release on June 30, a free demo for TypInc is currently available on Steam, offering a taste of this unique Balatro-meets-typing-tutor hybrid.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump's Dramatic NATO Transformation: From Withdrawal Threats to Alliance 'Daddy'
fields.summary: Donald Trump has shifted from threatening to withdraw the U.S. from NATO to embracing the alliance, receiving unexpected praise at the 2025 summit where he was called 'daddy' by officials.
fields.content:
Donald Trump has undergone a remarkable reversal regarding NATO, abandoning former positions threatening U.S. withdrawal in favor of endorsing the alliance. Once a vocal critic, the former president emerged from the 2025 NATO summit in The Hague expressing newfound admiration for member nations.

"I left here differently. I left here saying that these people really love their countries," Trump stated after meetings with allied leaders. This marked a significant departure from his years of protests over defense expenditure deficits.

His renewed support follows prolonged tensions, including heated exchanges with world figures and controversial remarks about alliance functionality. Yet the recent summit displayed noticeably improved relations.

Trump received royal Dutch hospitality and commendations from NATO leadership, including the secretary-general's affectionate "daddy" reference. He told reporters: "It’s not a rip-off, and we’re here to help them."

The transformation appears striking against his historical criticisms. Trump arrived at the summit strengthened by recent U.S. military actions that severely degraded Iran's nuclear facilities, setting back Tehran's atomic ambitions significantly according to intelligence assessments.

These strikes were interpreted as demonstrations of Western deterrence relevant to NATO adversaries Russia and China. "He really came in from this power move," observed Giedrimas Jeglinskas, Lithuania's national security head and former NATO official.

President Donald Trump and NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte speak during a NATO plenary session at the Hague.

Previously, Trump frequently denounced NATO as "obsolete," emphasizing disproportionate U.S. spending burdens. "It’s costing us too much money... We’re paying disproportionately. It’s too much," he declared in March 2016.

He accused the alliance of overlooking terrorism threats, later claiming responsibility when NATO established an intelligence leadership role. His rhetoric partially tempered after assuming office: "We strongly support NATO... We only ask that all members make their full financial contribution."

Despite this, Trump maintained pressure on nations to meet 2% GDP defense commitments by 2024 and privately threatened U.S. withdrawal over funding shortfalls, warning: "Now we are in World War III protecting a country that wasn’t paying its bills."

Post-commitment, he termed NATO a "fine-tuned machine" while accusing Germany of Russian captivity over the Nord Stream pipeline project.

United States President Donald Trump gestures as he speaks to Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer

Further discord emerged when French President Emmanuel Macron called NATO "brain-dead," drawing Trump's rebuke: "I think that’s very insulting." Relations with Canada deteriorated when Trump labeled Prime Minister Justin Trudeau "two-faced" after unflattering behind-scenes footage.

He also ordered 12,000 U.S. troops withdrawn from Germany and faced international backlash for suggesting noncompliant NATO members might face unchecked Russian aggression.

U.S. President Donald Trump with Dutch King Willem-Alexander and Queen Maxima

The 2025 summit unfolded with unusual harmony as Dutch hosts presented red-carpet treatment. "He's the man of the hour," Jeglinskas noted. He credited Trump's unconventional tactics for driving NATO reform: "He's brought tectonic change... by being himself. It’s a gift."

Experts attribute NATO's revival to dual catalysts: Russia's 2022 Ukraine invasion complementing Trump's vigorous funding demands. "Every president since Eisenhower has complained others don’t pay," one analyst noted, adding that Trump uniquely compelled compliance.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Mysterious Blue Spiral Brightens European Skies, Likely From SpaceX Rocket
fields.summary: A dazzling blue spiral illuminated night skies across Europe, with meteorological experts attributing the phenomenon to frozen exhaust from a SpaceX rocket launch reflecting sunlight in the upper atmosphere.
fields.content:
A spectacular spiraling blue light appeared over Europe on Monday night, captivating observers across the region.

Time-lapse footage captured in Croatia around 9 p.m. local time (4 p.m. EST) showed the glowing spiral slowly rotating for approximately six minutes total duration, prompting comparisons to a spiral galaxy on social media.

The Met Office stated via X: "This is likely to be caused by the SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket, launched earlier today. The rocket's frozen exhaust plume appears to be spinning in the atmosphere and reflecting the sunlight, causing it to appear as a spiral in the sky."

A spiraling blue light likely caused by SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket in Croatia.

At high altitudes, the rocket's exhaust fuel instantly freezes, with sunlight reflecting off these ice particles to create the unusual atmospheric display.

SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket

SpaceX has not yet responded to media inquiries about the celestial event.

This report was filed by Michael Dorgan, a correspondent with Fox News Digital and Fox Business.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: How Extreme Heat Impacts Your Brain and Ways to Safeguard Cognitive Health
fields.summary: Neuroscience experts reveal how rising temperatures impair cognitive function and mental well-being, explaining physiological impacts like neuron damage and increased stroke risk, while offering protection strategies for vulnerable individuals during heatwaves.
fields.content:
Neurological Risks of Heat Exposure

Dr. Jace Reed, emergency psychiatry director at Cedars-Sinai Hospital, stresses the brain's heightened vulnerability to extreme heat in professional consultations. This susceptibility can disrupt both social interactions and workplace performance due to impaired cognitive functions. Warning signs like severe confusion may indicate impending heat stroke, requiring urgent medical intervention.

Physiological Impact on Brain Function

Psychology expert Thea Gallagher from NYU Langone Health explains that overheating compromises the body's ability to maintain equilibrium. She notes that elevated temperatures trigger oxidative stress and inflammation in neural tissues, potentially damaging neurons while worsening existing neurological conditions and raising stroke probability. Additionally, heat weakens the blood-brain barrier, exposing neural matter to harmful toxins and pathogens.

woman sits outside in summer heat

Mental Health Implications

Experts observe significant worsening of psychiatric symptoms during heatwaves, including intensified mood disorders and cognitive disturbances. Individuals with pre-existing cognitive impairments face particular danger as they may not recognize early signs of overheating. Depression and irritability commonly escalate, as illustrated by behavioral manifestations observed during high-temperature periods.

depressed woman

woman argues with man outside

Medication-Related Vulnerabilities

Common antidepressants like SSRIs pose dual risks during heat exposure. Gallagher reveals these medications can suppress natural sweating—the body's primary cooling system—increasing hazards of dehydration and heat stroke. Paradoxically, some patients experience excessive sweating from SSRIs, accelerating fluid loss if hydration isn't maintained.

Protection Strategies

Gallagher advocates prioritizing restorative rest as hot weather increases activity levels and daylight hours, intensifying exhaustion. She recommends consciously slowing daily rhythms and implementing cooling measures to mitigate neurological strain. Maintaining hydration and recognizing early cognitive changes prove vital for sustaining mental acuity during temperature extremes.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ohio's $1.6M 'Book House' Features 7,000 Volumes and German-Style Charm
fields.summary: A distinctive Ohio property filled with 7,000 books and designed to resemble a German village cottage is on the market for $1.6 million. The dual-unit luxury rental features floor-to-ceiling shelves across all rooms and potential for substantial rental income.
fields.content:
Nicknamed "The Book House," this Columbus, Ohio property was custom-built to evoke a historic German village cottage, combining vintage aesthetics with modern luxury rental amenities. While its exterior mimics early 20th-century construction, the structure is a contemporary dual-unit complex designed for high-end short-term stays.

Spanning 4,536 square feet, the residence contains two fully equipped living units totaling eight bedrooms and six bathrooms. The layout provides accommodations for up to 24 guests, with rentals projected to generate approximately $273,000 annually according to industry experts.

Developer Guy Marshall amassed around 7,000 hardcover books acquired for just 10 cents each to populate the home's most distinctive feature: floor-to-ceiling bookshelves with library ladders accessible across all rooms. The listing emphasizes these literary installations as central to the property's identity.

Split view showing exterior and interior of Columbus book lover's house

Marshall intentionally selected every element to blend historical authenticity with modern functionality. For the exterior, this included using dyed concrete blocks finished to replicate aged masonry, with specially constructed one-foot-thick walls mirroring early 1900s design principles.

Library-style interior with bookshelves in German cottage-inspired home

Additional vintage touches throughout include antique lighting fixtures, custom ironwork, and reclaimed barn beams. Though construction costs exceeded standard builds, Marshall prioritized uniqueness, stating: "That’s why I designed it to operate as a high-end short-term rental: to increase revenue and share it with guests worldwide."

Authentic-looking exterior resembling German village architecture

The property gained viral attention after appearing on "Zillow Gone Wild," which gushed: "Imagine sleeping surrounded by books. The dreams you will HAVE." Social media reactions ranged from enthusiasm—"I love it so much"—to practical concerns about dust accumulation and difficulty moving thousands of volumes.

Book-filled interior showcasing library ladders and shelves

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Christopher McDonald Praises Travis Kelce's Acting in Upcoming 'Happy Gilmore 2'
fields.summary: Kansas City Chiefs star Travis Kelce has received high praise from co-star Christopher McDonald for his acting in the 'Happy Gilmore' sequel, which will premiere on Netflix this summer.
fields.content:
Kansas City Chiefs tight end Travis Kelce will appear in the upcoming "Happy Gilmore 2" film, earning notable acclaim from his co-star Christopher McDonald for his acting abilities.

Travis Kelce looking on

McDonald, an Emmy-nominated actor who reprises his role as Shooter McGavin, shared enthusiastic feedback about Kelce: "Travis Kelce has been out there, and I just really liked him as a person. He is really funny. Way too handsome, by the way, but really a good actor actually."

Kelce previously described his casting in the sports comedy sequel as "a dream come true," underscoring his excitement about the opportunity.

Speakers onstage during a Netflix event

The sequel to the 1996 cult classic is scheduled for release on July 25 and will stream exclusively on Netflix.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: New York Proposes New Nuclear Plant to Address Energy Challenges
fields.summary: New York Governor Kathy Hochul's proposal for a new nuclear power facility aims to solve the state's energy demands while supporting clean power transition. The plan involves public-private development to keep energy local, though nuclear construction challenges remain unresolved.
fields.content:
New York Governor Kathy Hochul has announced ambitious plans to develop a major nuclear power plant. The proposal seeks to address the state's growing energy demands while advancing clean energy goals. This initiative represents a significant shift in New York's approach to power generation.

The New York Power Authority is currently evaluating potential sites and designs for the facility. State officials plan to collaborate with private companies for construction and operation. A key objective ensures all generated energy remains within New York to benefit local communities and businesses directly.

Nuke plant 2

Beyond meeting energy needs, this project positions nuclear power as crucial to clean energy transitions. Growing corporate demand for zero-emission sources could attract substantial investment to New York. The facility may generate significant job opportunities across the state's energy sector.

nuke plant 3

Nuclear construction faces notable obstacles in the United States. No new large-scale plants have broken ground in over 15 years, with recent projects experiencing severe delays and budget overruns. Promising technologies like small modular reactors offer potential cost savings but remain unproven at commercial scale.

nuke plant 4

Despite challenges, supporters highlight the project's transformative potential. Modernizing New York's energy grid could create thousands of skilled jobs while establishing reliable carbon-free power generation. Bipartisan political support signals nuclear energy's emerging consensus as a practical solution.

nuke plant 5

New York's commitment reflects a determined step toward securing a sustainable energy future. Successful implementation may establish new national benchmarks for clean power infrastructure. As development proceeds, the project could motivate other states to pursue nuclear solutions for their own energy challenges.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Starmer Calls Welfare Reform a 'Moral Imperative' After Labour U-Turn
fields.summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer has labelled the welfare system 'broken' and declared its repair a 'moral imperative', following a partial government reversal on benefit cuts after significant Labour backbench opposition. Revised plans now exclude existing disability claimants from stricter criteria while maintaining inflation-linked increases.
fields.content:
Prime Minister Keir Starmer stated that Britain's benefits system requires urgent repair, emphasizing it's a moral duty during his speech at the Welsh Labour conference in Llandudno. This comes after the government amended welfare reforms due to substantial rebellion from within Labour ranks that threatened parliamentary defeat.

Starmer reassured attendees that the welfare safety net for vulnerable individuals would remain intact, but stressed that benefits must not hinder those capable of working. He described the current system as 'failing people every day', contributing to a 'generation of young people written off' with uncontrolled costs.

The initially proposed reforms targeted Personal Independence Payment (PIP) accessibility for 3.7 million recipients with long-term health conditions. Facing dissent, the government modified its approach—stricter criteria will now apply solely to new PIP claimants rather than existing ones.

Additionally, universal credit's health components will now rise with inflation instead of being frozen. Ministers have committed to reviewing PIP assessments alongside disability organizations and accelerating a £1 billion employment support package to launch before 2029.

Labour MP Diane Abbott wearing a black leather jacket.

Labour MP Diane Abbott expressed reservations about the amended plans, citing potential legislative challenges due to lingering discontent. She highlighted concerns in the party regarding insufficient consultation and advised that creating 'a two-tier benefit system' remained problematic.

However, former Justice Secretary Lord Falconer argued the concessions were significant enough to reduce opposition. MP Debbie Abrahams acknowledged improvements but maintained worries for future claimants despite protections for current recipients.

Unite union escalated criticism by demanding the entire bill be scrapped. General Secretary Sharon Graham condemned the proposals as 'divisive and sinister', asserting that disadvantages facing younger or newly-disabled people would establish an unethical tiered structure within the welfare framework.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Nissan Announces 250 Job Cuts at Sunderland Factory
fields.summary: Nissan has initiated a voluntary redundancy scheme for approximately 250 staff at its Sunderland plant, positioning the cuts as part of a global efficiency drive following declining sales while exempting manufacturing workers from the reductions.
fields.content:
Approximately 250 positions are set to be eliminated at Nissan's Sunderland factory as the automaker implements worldwide restructuring measures in response to declining sales performance. The company confirmed this week a voluntary departure program has been made available to both shop floor and administrative staff at its UK facility.

Manufacturing personnel will be unaffected by the downsizing, with Nissan indicating the move aims to optimize operational efficiency. The Japanese automotive group currently employs about 133,500 people globally, including nearly 6,000 staff at the Sunderland operation.

'More resilient'

The Sunderland job cuts form part of Nissan's broader global workforce reduction strategy. In May, the company revealed plans to eliminate 11,000 positions worldwide and close seven manufacturing plants, bringing total planned layoffs across the last 12 months to approximately 20,000 jobs.

A Nissan spokesperson emphasized that the Sunderland plant continues to play a vital long-term role, stating it remains "at the forefront of our electrification strategy." The spokesperson explained: "To support future competitiveness, we've begun discussions with some Sunderland team members regarding voluntary departure opportunities with company support. This initiative will promote plant efficiency as we transition toward a leaner, more resilient business structure."

This reorganization follows Nissan's June announcement about its next-generation Leaf electric vehicle, which will enter production at the Sunderland facility. The plant currently manufactures the Juke and Qashqai model ranges alongside the existing Leaf version.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Attorney General Dismisses 'Disgusting' Two-Tier Justice Claims
fields.summary: Attorney General Lord Hermer has condemned claims of a two-tier justice system in the UK as 'disgusting' and 'wrong,' defending judicial independence amid criticism of riot prosecutions and his past legal work representing controversial figures.
fields.content:
Rejecting the Two-Tier Narrative

Lord Hermer, the government's chief legal adviser, strongly dismissed accusations of inequality in the UK justice system during his first major interview. He asserted that politicians using the term endanger essential institutions. These claims surfaced after 2024 summer riots, with critics alleging rioters faced disproportionately harsh treatment compared to protesters. The attorney general argued it was invalid to equate demonstrators with rioters who tried to kill police officers, stating: 'They were not producing violence that you could even begin legitimately to compare.' He emphasized such comparisons are 'frankly disgusting' and offensive to police, prosecutors, and courts.

Addressing Criticism of Legal Career

The attorney general addressed Conservative attacks regarding his background as a human rights barrister. Lord Hermer represented controversial clients over three decades, including Irish republican Gerry Adams and Islamic State recruit Shamima Begum. Conservative justice spokesman Robert Jenrick claimed Hermer 'defended those who hate Britain' and urged his removal. Responding to these criticisms, Hermer drew parallels to journalism and medicine, stating: 'Lawyers are professionally obliged to represent those who come to them.' He maintained that refusing clients is indefensible as: 'The whole justice system falls apart if you do that.' Hermer described himself as a 'progressive pragmatist' despite recent portrayals of him as radical.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: The Cortisol Conundrum: Why Social Media's Stress Advice Heightens Anxiety
fields.summary: Widespread social media advice about lowering cortisol levels is paradoxically increasing stress for many, with experts questioning the validity of quick fixes like 'cortisol cocktails' and supplements. Medical professionals emphasize that stress symptoms often have complex causes beyond the hormone alone, urging evidence-based approaches over viral remedies.
fields.content:
The Stress Hormone Dilemma

Social media platforms are saturated with alarming warnings about cortisol's effects—claiming it reshapes faces, expands waistlines, and triggers hair loss. Users encounter relentless promotions for stress-reduction quick fixes: specialized drinks blending orange juice, coconut water, and sea salt; supplements; and lavender balm remedies.

Without knowledge of personal cortisol levels, many feel uncertain whether these measures are needed, though physical changes like facial puffiness or tighter clothing might suggest imbalance. As a vital hormone produced by adrenal glands, cortisol regulates essential functions from morning awakening to nighttime sleep. While indispensable for survival, excessive cortisol creates health complications—prompting urgent searches for solutions.

Ironically, scrolling social media for answers often increases stress, especially when posts advise immediately turning off devices. Oxford endocrinology professor John Wass notes: "With smartphones, you can't get a moment's peace." He questions direct correlations between cortisol and physical changes, stating: "Weight gain or swelling could stem from poor sleep, medications, or diet—it's misleading to blame cortisol alone."

A cortisol cocktail in a large plastic glass - a blend of orange, coconut water and sea salt

Jasleen's Burnout Journey

Jasleen Kaur Carroll experienced cortisol's impacts severely as a tech company director. By her late 20s, her inability to disconnect triggered burnout and exacerbated lupus symptoms: weight loss, joint pain, and breathing difficulties. "I felt like a zombie, but kept pushing," she recalls.

Seeking relief from social media, she tried countless remedies—cortisol cocktails, ashwagandha tablets, and lavender balms—with no improvement. The unchecked stress worsened her autoimmune condition, requiring hospitalization and raising fertility concerns.

Jasleen is wearing all white sat on a sofa with a cup of tea next to her

Jasleen in a hospital bed with a tube inserted into her neck.

During hospital treatment, Jasleen recognized the need to address root causes through therapy and mindfulness rather than superficial fixes. Therapist Neil Shah of the Stress Management Society explained: "Stress hormones are vital for real threats, but our 24/7 society makes us perceive dangers everywhere."

Evidence-Based Approaches

Research indicates mindfulness may regulate cortisol by reshaping brain structures and boosting stress resilience. Skeptical participants in Breathworks sessions—like one featuring raisin-focused sensory exercises—often discover present-moment concentration reduces anxiety. Stress expert David Creswell cites mindfulness, exercise, and cognitive therapy as effective techniques that "train us to sit with discomfort."

Wellbeing authority Cary Cooper warns against social media solutions: "Sudden physical changes warrant medical checks to rule out conditions like Cushing's syndrome." He dismissed cortisol cocktails as harmless but ineffective, stressing: "Treating symptoms without addressing sources—relationships, finances, or trauma—is pointless."

Composite image of Jasleen carrying out stress reducing exercises

Today, with a new job and daughter, Jasleen manages stress through grounding exercises: gentle body tapping, visualization, and dry brushing. Avoiding social media, she focuses on sustainable strategies: "I embrace life's chaos with practical tools, understanding my limits."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Forever Chemical Detected in Nearly All UK Rivers Tested
fields.summary: Trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), a persistent 'forever chemical' potentially harmful to human reproduction, has been found in 98% of UK rivers tested by researchers. River Ness emerged as the only exception, while UK awaits regulatory action.
fields.content:
A substance of significant concern to scientists for its potential effects on human reproduction has been identified in rivers across the United Kingdom.

Researchers from York University detected trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) at 98% of test locations after analyzing samples from 32 rivers spanning all four UK nations. This compound belongs to the "forever chemical" family, meaning it breaks down extremely slowly in nature and accumulates over time.

Widespread Contamination

TFA develops through the partial breakdown of synthetic chemicals found in pesticides and refrigerants. Professor Alistair Boxall from York University emphasized the ubiquity of TFA, stating: "This molecule is everywhere. We'll all be drinking water containing TFA daily, creating lifetime low-level exposure - which is the big concern."

The study, funded by environmental group Fidra, examined 5 Welsh rivers, 3 Northern Irish rivers, 14 Scottish rivers, and 10 in northern England. The highest concentration appeared in Glasgow's River Kelvin. Remarkably, the River Ness remained the only sampled waterway without traces of TFA.

Getty Images The River Ness flows through Inverness. There are two spires on the bank.

Health Concerns Mount

Recent EU studies found TFA in numerous sources including wine, food, human blood, and breast milk. German authorities observed a fourfold increase in drinking water concentrations over two decades. Citing animal studies indicating TFA's impact on rabbit and rat fetuses, Germany's Federal Environment Agency requested the European Chemicals Agency to classify TFA as toxic for reproduction and environmentally harmful.

Andreas Hensel of Germany's Federal Institute for Risk Assessment clarified: "Currently, no adverse health effects are expected from TFA in water or food. This classification prepares measures to ensure future safety."

Regulation Gap in UK

Presently, no UK regulations govern TFA levels in waterways or drinking water. Amid growing concerns, the Drinking Water Inspectorate launched research to assess concentrations and potential risks. A spokesperson stated: "Understanding pesticide degradation is crucial to protect water sources." Water UK, representing water companies, advocates for banning all PFAS chemicals including TFA, demanding manufacturers fund environmental cleanup.

The Drinking Water Inspectorate specifically noted TFA formation from degraded PFAS pesticides, highlighting the importance of tracking chemical pathways to safeguard water supplies.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: The Rising Threat: How 3D-Printed Guns Are Spreading Globally
fields.summary: Untraceable 3D-printed firearms are rapidly emerging as weapons of choice for criminals and extremists worldwide, with social media platforms enabling their spread through illegal sales and accessible blueprints despite policy bans, raising urgent security concerns.
fields.content:
3D-printed firearms could become the preferred weapon for criminals and violent extremists globally, experts warn following investigations into their rapidly expanding online presence. These untraceable DIY guns, often called "ghost guns," have surfaced in multiple criminal cases, including the alleged use of a partially printed weapon in the fatal shooting of United Healthcare CEO Brian Thompson.

Investigations reveal how 3D-printed guns proliferate across social platforms like Telegram, Facebook, and Instagram, alongside websites providing assembly guides. Designed to bypass gun regulations, these weapons use downloadable blueprints and common materials, with newer models capable of firing multiple rounds without structural failure in their plastic components.

Nick Suplina of gun control group Everytown states: "The materials have improved, costs decreased, and blueprint access is at an all-time high." A recent Tech Transparency Project report exposed hundreds of banned gun advertisements on Meta platforms in October 2024, some marketing 3D-printed firearms.

Social Media's Role in Weapons Trafficking

Meta platforms gun ad screenshots

Despite Meta's policies prohibiting weapon sales, investigators found active gun advertisements pushing users to encrypted platforms. Telegram channels openly displayed firearms, with accounts like "Jessy" offering international shipping. When BBC investigators inquired, Jessy agreed to ship prohibited items like Liberator pistols or Glock auto-sears—3D-printed components converting handguns into automatic weapons—to the UK for £160 via Bitcoin.

Messages between investigator and 'Jessy' seller

Though the seller vanished after BBC identification, the investigation revealed security gaps exploited by traffickers. Meta later disabled flagged ads, while Telegram removed Jessy's account but emphasized using AI moderation to block weapons sales.

Blueprints and Global Consequences

Beyond ready-made sales, easily accessible online blueprints like the FGC-9 design enable amateur gunsmithing using household materials. Dr. Rajan Basra at King's College London notes: "It's not like printing paper—but achievable with guides." Advocates like Florida attorney Matthew Larosiere share blueprints freely, arguing information dissemination is protected despite risks.

Myanmar provides the only documented combat use of 3D-printed firearms, where resistance groups produced FGC-9s costing ten times less than black-market guns. However, material shortages and improved access to conventional arms caused rebels to largely abandon printed weapons by 2024.

3D printers inspected by Myanmar personnel

Though limited in warfare, the guns' global spread triggers regulatory actions: Nations are exploring laws against blueprint possession, while some demand printer manufacturers install safeguards similar to currency printing restrictions. The effectiveness of these measures against the expanding DIY arsenal remains uncertain.

Additional reporting from Myanmar by Hnin Mo, BBC Burmese.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: CMAT reveals ongoing online abuse since viral anti-body shaming song
fields.summary: Irish singer CMAT discloses she continues facing severe online harassment after her viral song responding to festival fat-shaming, forcing her to delete TikTok amid daily abuse despite the empowering anthem's success.
fields.content:
Irish singer-songwriter CMAT has spoken out about enduring persistent online abuse following the release of her viral single responding to body-shaming incidents. The 29-year-old artist, born Ciara Mary-Alice Thompson, revealed to reporters at Glastonbury Festival that the harassment remains so severe she removed TikTok from her phone entirely.

Her comments came after a Friday afternoon performance on the Pyramid Stage, where she captivated audiences with powerful vocals and choreography. During the show, CMAT introduced her cathartic single Take A Sexy Picture Of Me by recalling the origins of the song: 'Lots of people would film us. Comments sections filled with nasty remarks about my physical appearance.' The crowd reacted with boos and supportive shouts of 'you’re stunning.'

When questioned about ongoing harassment, CMAT stated emphatically: 'Oh yeah. Oh yeah. Oh yeah. I’m not allowed to really have TikTok on my phone. Daily, people leave terrible comments under my posts with their full faces and names attached.' She noted this behavior stems from collective desensitization, adding: 'We’ve all done it unconsciously, not realizing real people read these comments.'

The viral track addresses appearance pressure through autobiographical lyrics about childhood beauty experiments and the exhausting demand to maintain attractiveness. Contrasting its heavy themes with upbeat melodies, CMAT described the song as deliberately ironic. While glad it resonates, she expressed sadness about its painful relatability: 'It’s a double-edged sword—I don’t know if it’s good that so many recognize this experience.'

‘It’s taken my entire life’

CMAT reflected on her landmark Pyramid Stage appearance, calling the overwhelming response 'shocking' after lifelong dedication: 'It’s taken my entire life [to get here], constantly grafting.' She jokingly admitted pleading with festival organizer Emily Eavis for the opportunity.

The emotional climax came when she walked through the crowd during Stay for Something, as thousands sang the lyrics 'I just can’t do it' back to her. The intimate moment stood out as one of Glastonbury 2025's most memorable highlights. Reflecting on the performance, onlookers felt they'd witnessed a career-defining breakthrough amplified by the iconic stage.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Fatal Run 2089 Revival Blends Burnout-Style Action With Post-Apocalyptic Racing
fields.summary: Atari's reboot of the obscure 1985 post-apocalyptic racer Fatal Run arrives this year as Fatal Run 2089, featuring Burnout-inspired destruction mechanics, branching desert wastelands, and ARC energy deliveries against hostile marauders.
fields.content:
Atari's revival of its 1985 post-apocalyptic racer Fatal Run flew under many radars when announced, largely because the original was an obscure European-only release for the Atari 2600 during the console's decline. Retro Gamer magazine noted in 2016 that the highlight of the primitive original was its cutscenes—faint praise for a largely forgotten title.

However, the trailer for Fatal Run 2089 showcases a compelling blend of vehicular mayhem inspired by Burnout's explosive sequences. Developed by MNSTR Studio, players embark on a cross-country mission to deliver ARCs, clean-energy devices replacing the original's radiation vaccine. Between start and destination lie hordes of hostile racers determined to halt your progress across irradiated landscapes.

Key mechanics involve the degrading ARC unit acting as an arcade-style timer that can only be replenished through skillful driving and destroying opponents across 20 non-linear levels. Hidden shortcuts and branching pathways encourage exploration while seeking tactical advantages during high-speed pursuits.

Environments range from deserts reminiscent of Mad Max battlegrounds to neon-drenched cyberpunk cities and towering gothic castles packed with dynamic hazards like collapsing structures and wrecking balls. Boss battles punctuate these routes with vehicle-to-vehicle combat challenges.

The Burnout influence shines in slow-motion destruction sequences dynamically zooming in on fiery collisions reminiscent of Burnout 3's iconic crash explosions. While lower-budget elements remain visible in character cutscenes, the vehicular physics emphasize aggressive, arcade-style chaos over simulation precision.

Atari's checkered history with legacy titles gives some pause, though recent management changes and successful acquisitions like Nightdive Studios offer hope. Amid a racing genre favoring simulations like Assetto Corsa, Fatal Run 2089 promises pure arcade carnage when it releases later this year.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Convicted Paedophile Staged Fake Disneyland Wedding with Nine-Year-Old
fields.summary: Convicted paedophile Jacky Jhaj organized an elaborate fake wedding ceremony to a nine-year-old at Disneyland Paris, continuing a pattern of concerning stunts involving children despite being on the UK Sex Offenders Register. The event raised questions about offender monitoring and event industry safeguards.
fields.content:
Last weekend, a convicted British paedophile orchestrated a false marriage ceremony with a nine-year-old girl at Disneyland Paris, causing widespread alarm. This disturbing incident appears to be the latest in a series of elaborate productions organised by Jacky Jhaj, a 39-year-old from West London now charged by French authorities.

The BBC's investigation revealed that Jhaj has staged multiple events since his release from prison after a 2016 conviction for sexual activity with two 15-year-olds. These productions consistently featured young performers hired as fake admirers. In 2023, approximately 200 children and young women - some aged just six - were unknowingly recruited through casting agencies to pose as fans during a fraudulent film premiere in London's Leicester Square.

Jacky Jhaj appearing outside dance auditions in 2024

For the Disneyland event, a Ukrainian child was flown to Paris to portray Jhaj's bride at a ceremony costing over €130,000 (£110,000) in venue fees alone. Professional actors received payments as high as £10,000. Videos of Jhaj's productions accumulated over six million YouTube views before eventual removal.

Composite images of Jacky Jhaj holding weapons, unclear if real or fake

What else do we know?

Evidence suggests Jhaj received assistance organising his stunts. A recurring associate acknowledged being Jhaj's friend and his status as a registered sex offender when confronted during an event that involved setting fire to a fake BBC news lorry. At that incident and others, Jhaj used elaborate prosthetics to disguise himself.

The financing of these productions - which included hiring tanks and torching mock police cars - remains mysterious. Despite restrictions under his Sexual Harm Prevention Order that barred unmonitored contact with under-16s, the order didn't explicitly prohibit supervised events involving children. Disneyland Paris reportedly fell victim to deception via a fake Latvian ID during the venue booking.

Associate with fake police car and BBC World News lorry in background

Jhaj wearing facial prosthetics at an event

One police officer to 50 offenders

Questions persist about how effectively high-risk offenders are monitored. Police reportedly manage multiple offender caseloads beyond recommended safety thresholds. National guidelines advise one officer per 50 offenders, yet half of UK forces exceeded this ratio according to recent data, with one averaging 85 cases per officer.

Jhaj naked before burning BBC truck, videographer visible

Safeguarding expert Jonathan Taylor called effectively monitoring 50 offenders impossible, noting systemic gaps. French authorities confirmed the Ukrainian girl suffered no physical harm. The Metropolitan Police have outstanding arrest warrants for Jhaj regarding restriction breaches and potential fraud offenses.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Piccadilly Circus Crash Leaves Young Man Critically Injured
fields.summary: Two young men were hospitalized, one in critical condition, after their car overturned at London's Piccadilly Circus in the early hours of Sunday morning, disrupting one of the capital's busiest intersections.
fields.content:
A 22-year-old man remains in critical condition following a vehicle collision in central London's Piccadilly Circus during the early hours of Sunday.

The black BMW overturned near the Shaftesbury Memorial Fountain, popularly known as Eros, coming to rest on its roof. A second occupant of the vehicle, also 22 years old, sustained non-life-threatening injuries and received hospital treatment.

Authorities confirmed no pedestrians were harmed and no other vehicles appear to have been involved in the incident. The Metropolitan Police stated emergency services responded around 05:30 BST to reports of a car crashing into the landmark and flipping over.

PA Media A black car crashed in Piccadilly Circus

London Ambulance Service dispatched "multiple resources" to handle the situation. A spokesperson confirmed, "We treated two people. We took one patient to a major trauma centre and the other patient to a local hospital."

Police cordoned off the area and implemented road closures around the iconic roundabout. The Metropolitan Police acknowledged resulting disruptions, pledging to reopen roads "at the earliest opportunity, but only when we have carried out the work required to investigate this serious incident."

Piccadilly Circus, one of London's busiest traffic junctions connecting key West End roads, attracts millions of visitors annually to its prominent central location.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Netanyahu's Iran Victory May Not Solve His Political Trust Crisis
fields.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu seeks political gain from Israel's conflict with Iran, but polls reveal deep public distrust over his handling of the Gaza war and corruption charges. While celebrating military success against Iran, Netanyahu faces collapsing public confidence and imminent corruption trial proceedings.
fields.content:
In March, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu reversed a Gaza ceasefire agreement that was producing tangible results—a move some analysts termed political suicide. The original deal, brokered by former U.S. President Donald Trump's envoy ahead of his second-term inauguration, had secured dozens of hostages released by Hamas in exchange for Palestinian prisoners. Further releases and an Israeli military withdrawal from Gaza were anticipated next, offering both Palestinians and Israelis hope for an end to the devastating conflict.

However, Netanyahu abruptly ordered renewed attacks across Gaza, declaring hostilities would continue until Hamas was "completely destroyed." The fate of remaining hostages became secondary, provoking outrage among Israelis—especially families with captive relatives—who accused the prime minister of prioritizing political survival over national welfare and hostage safety.

Three months later, Netanyahu claims victory against Iran after recent hostilities. Despite suggesting possible early elections to extend his record-breaking tenure, opinion polls show only a modest uptick in support. Most Israelis, at 59%, demand an end to the Gaza conflict to secure hostages’ return, while 49% believe Netanyahu prolongs the war for personal political gain, undermining public trust in his leadership.

Trust Deficit

Israel's fractured political landscape complicates Netanyahu's path. The Likud Party lacks majority support and struggles to consolidate alliances with right-wing factions. Professor Tamar Hermann of the Israel Democracy Institute observes Netanyahu as "Israel's most skilled politician" but says trust remains his fundamental challenge. According to new data from the institute, fewer than half of Israelis express "full or partial trust" in him.

The prime minister appropriated the conflict with Iran as a "window of opportunity" to defeat Hamas and pursue broader diplomacy. Yet Hermann argues that calling elections now poses even greater risks amid regional unpredictability. Trust issues rooted in Netanyahu's shifting positions continue eroding his credibility.

Legal Troubles Intensify

Donald Trump and Benjamin Netanyahu meet in diplomatic talks

Netanyahu confronts imminent corruption charges—including bribery and fraud—as his trial commences next week. Attempts to delay proceedings, citing Iran emergency measures, were rejected. The prime minister decries the case as a politicized witch hunt, while opponents insist on accountability. U.S. President Trump called Netanyahu a "great hero" who deserves a pardon, a stance Israeli opposition leader Yair Lapid termed unwelcome interference, stating: "He should not intervene in a legal process of an independent state."

Hermann likened Trump's stance to treating Israel "like a banana republic." Internationally, Netanyahu faces Israel Democracy Institute’s rebuke for harming Israel's global standing by extending the Gaza war unnecessarily—a conflict where over 55,000 people died. The International Criminal Court also targets Netanyahu with warrants for alleged war crimes, accusations he rejects entirely. Analysts acknowledge that elections seem unlikely during ongoing hostilities, though Netanyahu’s unpredictable political maneuvers invite caution against counting him out prematurely.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Bumble to Slash 30% of Workforce Amid Financial Challenges
fields.summary: Dating app Bumble announces major job cuts affecting 240 employees as it faces investor skepticism, revenue challenges, and a sharp drop in share value since its 2021 market debut.
fields.content:
Bumble is reducing its global workforce by nearly 30%, eliminating 240 positions due to sluggish progress and diminishing investor confidence in the dating platform's future. The company plans to redirect approximately $40 million in annual savings from these cuts toward technology development and restructuring efforts.

In a staff memo, Chief Executive Whitney Wolfe Herd described the dating industry reaching an "inflection point" requiring "decisive action." She stressed Bumble must build resilience to thrive over the coming decade, following her return to leadership last March after stepping down in the prior year.

The dating app pioneer, which also operates Badoo, became prominent for its signature feature requiring women to initiate conversations with male matches. While the company relaxed this rule in 2023 aiming for expansion, it now struggles with declining market value. Bumble shares have plunged to under $7 each from its $13 billion valuation during its 2021 stock launch that made Wolfe Herd the world's youngest self-made female billionaire.

Recent performance metrics highlight these challenges. The platform reported 4.1 million paying users by late 2023—an 11% annual uptick. However, Bumble simultaneously posted less than 2% revenue growth alongside net financial losses. The wider dating sector faces similar headwinds, as demonstrated by competitor Match Group implementing 13% staff reductions last month.

Investor reactions were favorable to the cost-cutting strategy, with Bumble's stock price jumping 20% following the restructuring announcement.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Attorney General Affirms International Law as Cornerstone of Starmer's Foreign Policy
fields.summary: Attorney General Richard Hermer declares international law central to Prime Minister Keir Starmer's foreign policy, arguing it strengthens UK credibility for trade deals and global partnerships. Hermer also defends maintaining warm US ties and addresses controversy over his past remarks comparing legal arguments to 1930s Germany.
fields.content:
UK Attorney General Richard Hermer has emphasized that adherence to international law stands at the core of Prime Minister Keir Starmer's foreign policy strategy. In his first broadcast interview since appointment, Lord Hermer asserted that the government intends to proactively champion international legal standards globally, claiming this approach recently facilitated economic agreements with the United States, India, and the European Union.

Hermer also defended Starmer's strategy of cultivating a "warm" relationship with US President Donald Trump, even when it conflicts with "short-term political gain." His comments were recorded prior to recent scrutiny over government legal advice concerning the Israel-Iran conflict.

International Law and National Interest

When questioned whether international law represents a non-negotiable principle for Starmer's foreign policy, Hermer responded: "If you ask me what's Keir's kind of principal overriding interest, it is genuinely to make life better for the people of this country." He elaborated that international law is vital both inherently and instrumentally, as it directly supports this objective.

"By ensuring we comply with all forms of law - domestic and international - we serve the national interest," Hermer stated. He directly linked this compliance to recently secured trade agreements, noting: "No one wants to sign international agreements with a country that's got a government saying, 'we may comply with it, we may not'. We secure trade deals essential for improving lives because our word is our bond."

Approach to US Relations

Addressing the UK's vital relationship with the United States, Hermer endorsed Starmer's focus on maintaining open communication channels despite potential disagreements. He cautioned against succumbing to what he termed the "Love Actually instinct" – referring to a scene in the 2003 film where a British leader publicly confronts a US president – advocating instead for consistent diplomatic engagement.

"Ensuring our relationship remains warm and based on mutual respect is overwhelmingly in this country's interests," Hermer argued.

Controversy Over Comments

The Attorney General acknowledged regret for recent "clumsy" remarks in which he compared arguments urging withdrawal from international legal frameworks to rationales employed by 1930s German legal theorists. Some Conservative politicians interpreted these comments as equating critics with Nazis and called for his dismissal.

A spokesperson clarified Hermer rejected this characterization but regretted the historical reference. Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch subsequently accused Hermer of exceeding his mandate, stating: "The attorney is not there to run foreign policy or call people Nazis," and declared his position "untenable."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Doctor's Failings in Martha Mills Case 'Particularly Grave', Tribunal Rules
fields.summary: A medical tribunal concluded that a consultant's 'grossly negligent' care failures directly contributed to 13-year-old Martha Mills' preventable sepsis death, leading to nationwide healthcare reforms known as Martha's Rule.
fields.content:
A medical tribunal has determined that failings in the care of Martha Mills amounted to "gross negligence" and were "particularly grave." The 13-year-old died from sepsis in 2021 after a cycling accident, with her case subsequently prompting the introduction of Martha's Rule in hundreds of English hospitals to empower families seeking urgent second opinions.

Hospitalization and Deterioration

Martha was admitted to King's College Hospital in London following severe pancreatic injuries sustained when she fell onto bicycle handlebars during a holiday. Despite being at one of the UK's three specialist pediatric centers, she developed sepsis—a life-threatening condition where the body's infection response damages its own organs—several weeks into her month-long hospitalization.

Her mother, Merope Mills, stated: "It was a difficult, tricky injury, but it did not have to be a fatal one." An inquest later confirmed Martha would have survived with proper care.

Critical Failures on August 29

Consultant Prof Richard Thompson, responsible for Martha on August 29, 2021, failed to recognize her critical condition. By 5 PM that day, Martha showed multiple high-risk indicators including rapid breathing, elevated heart rate, fever, and a new rash. Though these signaled sudden deterioration requiring intensive care, Prof Thompson neither examined her personally nor ordered the transfer.

Following an evening phone update about Martha's worsening state, he still chose not to visit the hospital. Thompson later expressed "deep remorse" but defended actions, claiming concern about "distressing her parents" justified keeping Martha on the ward—a rationale the tribunal dismissed.

Judgment and Legacy

The tribunal found Thompson's fitness to practice impaired yet imposed no penalties. Panel chair Robin Ince noted a "stain on his reputation" would endure lifelong. While acknowledging Thompson's remedial efforts, Ince emphasized the ruling validated fundamental care principles and public interests.

Martha's parents welcomed the findings: "It is important to us that allegations denied have been found proved and the gravity of mistakes... recognized." They attributed failures partly to poor relations between consultants and pediatric ICU staff. King's College Hospital reiterated remorse: "We remain deeply sorry that we failed Martha when she needed us most." Martha's Rule—enabling faster clinical second opinions—now operates nationwide.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Could Robots Replace Human Astronauts in Space Exploration?
fields.summary: NASA's Parker Solar Probe recently completed a groundbreaking autonomous flyby of the Sun, reigniting debate about the role of human astronauts versus robotic explorers in space missions. As artificial intelligence advances, scientists and space agencies are divided on whether robots could make human space travel obsolete.
fields.content:
On Christmas Eve, NASA's Parker Solar Probe autonomously navigated past the Sun, setting a record as the closest human-made object to our star—all without any real-time communication with Earth. During its 10-day flyby, the spacecraft endured extreme temperatures of 1000°C while gathering critical data about solar phenomena.

This milestone highlights the capabilities of robotic explorers that have visited every solar system planet over the past six decades, reaching areas deemed too hazardous for humans. UK Astronomer Royal Lord Martin Rees argues: "Robots are developing fast, and the case for sending humans is getting weaker all the time. I don't think taxpayer money should fund human spaceflight."

Artist’s concept of Parker Solar Probe approaching the sun

Physics professor Andrew Coates champions robotic exploration: "For serious space research, robots go much further at lower costs. As AI progresses, their capabilities will continue expanding." Despite robots' advantages, questions remain about their limitations compared to human ingenuity and inspiration.

Rovers versus mankind

While approximately 700 humans have reached space since 1961—mostly to Earth's orbit or the moon—robotic probes have explored vastly more territory. Biological researcher Dr. Kelly Weinersmith notes, "Humans are expensive to keep alive in space, but robots lack humans' versatility and speed." Booker Prize-winning author Samantha Harvey poetically observes that robots "want and ask for nothing," yet their physical limitations remain: Mars rovers crawl at just 0.1mph.

Astronaut on the Moon's surface

Planetary scientist Dr. Ian Crawford questions whether AI can surpass human adaptability: "AI can beat humans at chess, but environmental exploration requires different capabilities we haven't mastered."

AI assistants and humanoid robots

NASA is developing robotic helpers like the 6ft 2in Valkyrie humanoid, designed to perform delicate tasks such as equipment maintenance using specialized hands that can grip tools and flip switches. Dr. Kiri Wagstaff, a former NASA computer scientist, explains current limitations: "Rovers' processors run at one-tenth smartphone speed, unable to support complex AI language models."

NASA's Valkyrie robot performing tasks

NASA's Dexterous Robotics lead Dr. Shaun Azimi envisions collaboration: "Robots secure habitats between human visits, allowing astronauts to focus on discovery." The autonomous Curiosity rover exemplifies this approach, independently selecting Martian rocks for laser analysis during Earth's nighttime.

Life on Mars?

Human space ambitions continue expanding, with NASA planning lunar landings through its Artemis program by 2027 and China preparing its own moon missions. Elon Musk proposes establishing a 1 million-person Martian colony within two decades. However, Dr. Weinersmith cautions about unresolved challenges: "Can humans reproduce in Mars' gravity? These ethical questions require deeper study before colonization."

NASA Artemis astronauts preparing for moon mission

Retired astronaut Leroy Chiao emphasizes the inspirational power of human explorers: "The first human on Mars will captivate the world more than any rover." UK Astronomer Royal Lord Rees speculates about humanity's evolutionary path: "Future Martians may integrate biological enhancements to thrive there."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Revolutionary British Jet Engine Venture Fails in Aerospace 'Valley of Death'
fields.summary: Reaction Engines, a UK aerospace firm developing breakthrough hypersonic engine technology, collapsed in October 2024 after failing to secure vital funding. Former executives recount the emotional journey of the 35-year venture that pioneered revolutionary heat-exchange technology but ultimately succumbed to financial challenges in aviation's notorious 'Valley of Death'.
fields.content:
Richard Varvill, former technology chief at Reaction Engines, remembers the shock when the revolutionary aerospace project collapsed. "It was going great until it fell apart," he reflects on the hypersonic engine venture that began with Britain's 1980s Hotol space plane concept. The firm's breakthrough innovation centered on heat exchange technology capable of cooling 1,000°C hypersonic airflow - a solution to extreme temperatures that melt conventional engines.
