By October 2024, the company was testing systems in UK and US facilities with Ministry of Defence backing for unmanned aircraft research. Rolls-Royce collaboration provided support, but funding remained insufficient. As Varvill explains, "Rolls-Royce had other priorities and the UK military has very little money" - foreshadowing the crisis ahead.

The Funding Crisis and Collapse

Aviation's extended development cycles create a perilous 'Valley of Death', where even promising technologies can fail during the 20-year gestation period. As funding deadlines approached in late 2024, investors hesitated to commit. "The game was played to the very end," Varvill notes, "but crossing the Valley of Death in aerospace is very hard." On October 31, 2024, administrators arrived while 200 staff gathered in the company auditorium.

Employees received devastating news about immediate redundancies. "It was pretty grim," Varvill recalls. "People handed over passes and collected belongings - a bad day at the office with tears and shock." The timing proved particularly galling as the team neared engine improvements: "Just as we were getting close to succeeding, we failed. That's uniquely British."

Richard Varvill Richard Varvill in a blue polo shirt

Former space division head Kathryn Evans shared the emotional turmoil: "I was hopeful to the end despite uncertainty." She described the adrenaline crash when redundancy took immediate effect. Colleagues documented their final moments with Polaroid photos and messages. Evans wrote: "I will miss working with brilliant minds in a kind, supportive culture," maintaining pride in "British engineering at its best." The team later gathered at Varvill's home for a farewell gathering rather than face the loss without acknowledgment.

Legacy and Future Hope

Adam Dissel, president of Reaction Engines' US arm, expressed frustration with major investors Boeing, BAE Systems and Rolls-Royce: "The technology worked consistently and was mature, but strategic investors weren't excited enough." His team shared tearful farewells where they joined hands - Dissel proclaiming, "We still did great, take a bow" to applauding employees. For future ventures, he offers lessons: "You have no choice but to remain optimistic."

Reaction Engines Ltd The chilled helium flowing through the pre-cooler's piping takes away the heat

During company wind-down procedures, servers were backed up to preserve intellectual property. Dissel expects administrators will seek buyers for technological assets, holding hope that the pre-cooler innovations might be revived. His closing reflection honors the ambitious mission: "We were working for the fastest engines and highest temperatures - playing at the very edge of what was possible." Varvill's summary remains starkly practical: "We failed because we ran out of money," marking the fate of this 35-year British aerospace venture.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Anna Wintour Steps Down as US Vogue Editor After 37 Years
fields.summary: Anna Wintour will leave her role as editor-in-chief of American Vogue after a record 37-year tenure, though she maintains global oversight. The fashion icon aims to empower younger talent while continuing influential positions at publisher Conde Nast.
fields.content:
Anna Wintour is stepping back from her position as editor-in-chief of American Vogue after an unprecedented 37-year leadership. The 75-year-old British fashion magnate leaves the role longer than any previous editor but retains senior authority at publisher Conde Nast.

Wintour will continue serving as Vogue's global editorial director and chief content officer for Conde Nast. In her announcement to staff on Thursday, she revealed American Vogue would soon appoint a head of editorial content to oversee daily operations.

The industry pioneer emphasized her commitment to fostering new voices, stating she wanted to help "the next generation of impassioned editors storm the field with their own ideas." She confirmed she would manage many existing responsibilities while declaring she plans to remain "Vogue's tennis and theatre editor in perpetuity."

Raised in London, Wintour edited British Vogue before assuming leadership of its US counterpart in 1988. She revitalized the publication into a fashion powerhouse by featuring emerging models and blending luxury designs with affordable styles. Her leadership made American Vogue one of the world's most influential fashion magazines.

Throughout her career, Wintour became global fashion's most recognizable figure, pioneering the Met Gala fundraiser in 1995. She is renowned for her signature bob hairstyle and dark glasses, which she revealed to the BBC function as both aid and shield: "They help me see and they help me not see."

Her formidable reputation allegedly inspired Miranda Priestly in "The Devil Wears Prada," written by former assistant Lauren Weisberger. Queen Elizabeth II recognized Wintour's achievements by awarding her damehood in 2017, followed by King Charles granting the Companion of Honour title this year. When the king recently asked whether she would retire, Wintour responded, "firmly no."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Spain's PM Sanchez Seeks Re-Election Despite Family Corruption Probes
fields.summary: Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez has announced he will complete his term and seek re-election while his wife and brother face separate corruption investigations involving business irregularities and influence peddling allegations.
fields.content:
Spanish Prime Minister Pedro Sanchez confirmed on June 12 that he will not call early elections, choosing instead to complete his current mandate before standing for re-election. This decision comes amid ongoing legal scrutiny surrounding his family members.

Spain's Socialist PM Sanchez names new party leadership to limit damage from graft probe

Sanchez, one of Europe's longest-serving socialist leaders, faces dual controversies whereby his wife Begona Gomez remains under official investigation for potential business irregularities, while his brother David Sanchez awaits trial over allegations of influence peddling.

A Spanish flag is seen on the street in Krakow, Poland, on March 6, 2025.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Republican Senators Reject Leaked Report on Iran Strike Damage as Politically Motivated
fields.summary: Republican senators have dismissed a leaked intelligence assessment suggesting limited damage to Iran's nuclear facilities as inaccurate and politically driven, highlighting contradictions with Israeli claims of significant destruction amid differing viewpoints following a classified Senate briefing.
fields.content:
Political Motivation Behind Leak

Republican senators have criticized a leaked defense assessment regarding recent U.S. strikes on Iranian nuclear sites, labeling it inaccurate and politically motivated. Responding to why widespread media coverage featured the leaked version, Senator Ted Cruz emphasized to Fox News Digital that "clearly there was a political agenda at play." The disputed report, initially circulated to multiple outlets including CNN, claimed preliminary consensus within the Defense Intelligence Agency determined the strikes on Iranian facilities in Fordow, Natanz, and Isfahan caused minimal critical damage to nuclear infrastructure. None of Iran's stockpile of highly enriched uranium was reportedly destroyed according to these assessments.

Conflicting Damage Assessments

Contradicting these findings, former President Trump presented an alternative account during a press conference in The Hague while concluding his NATO summit activities. Trump cited a letter from the Atomic Energy Commission of Israel, describing its authors as "very serious people." Reading directly from the document, Trump stated: "The devastating U.S. strike on Fordow destroyed the site's critical infrastructure and rendered the enrichment facility totally inoperable." The letter further asserted the military action had "devastated" key locations and "set back Iran's ability to develop nuclear weapons for many years to come." Israeli authorities emphasized this delay could persist indefinitely if Iran remains barred from nuclear materials.

Map showing locations of strikes on Iranian nuclear sites including Fordow, Natanz and Isfahan

Aerial view of Iran's Fordow nuclear facility underground enrichment site

Post-Briefing Divisions Emerge

U.S. senators received a classified intelligence briefing about the strikes from national security officials on Thursday. Democratic Senator Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire expressed general satisfaction, stating: "Most of my questions were answered. I think it was a good briefing." She reiterated that Iran must not obtain nuclear weapons and voiced hope the operation had "set back that program dramatically," potentially forcing Iran toward negotiations. Though certain Democrats previously challenged the constitutionality of these strikes, Shaheen characterized them as "a limited, contained strike" that appeared beneficial if they impeded Tehran's nuclear progress.

Images of Iran's Supreme Leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei and former U.S. President Donald Trump

However, other Democratic senators remained unconvinced during the briefing despite Shaheen's tempered viewpoint, underscoring persistent partisan disagreements about the effectiveness and legality of the military intervention against Iran's nuclear infrastructure. The split reactions highlight ongoing tensions regarding strategic assessments after the strikes.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Orionid Meteor Shower to Illuminate Night Skies Through November
fields.summary: The annual Orionid meteor shower, derived from Halley's Comet debris, brightens night skies through late November. NASA highlights peak visibility conditions and optimal viewing strategies for this celestial display known for its speed and luminosity.
fields.content:
NASA reports the Orionid meteor shower peaks annually in mid-October, known for producing exceptionally bright and swift meteors visible throughout November. Stargazers' prospects depend on cloudless nights, though a bright waning gibbous moon currently outshines fainter meteors, reducing overall visibility.

Meteors in the sky

These shooting stars originate from cosmic debris shed by Halley's Comet, streaking through constellations in Earth's atmosphere. NASA explains: "Halley releases ice and rocky dust during solar approaches. These particles become the Orionids in October and Eta Aquarids in May when colliding with our atmosphere." During Monday's peak, Northern Hemisphere observers spotted up to 15 meteors hourly.

Optimal Viewing Strategies

Successful observation requires dark skies away from city lights beyond just clear conditions. NASA Meteoroid Office lead Bill Cooke advises: "Locate dark areas, bring blankets, and lie flat to maximize sky visibility. Eyes adapt within 30 minutes, revealing more meteors."

Halley's Comet in the sky

The shower commenced its peak on October 21 but remains active through November 22. Halley's Comet, whose tail produces these meteors, completes its solar orbit every 76 years, last seen in 1986 and not returning until 2061 according to NASA calculations.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Study Finds Cannabis Use Elevates Heart Attack and Stroke Risk Exceeding Other Drugs
fields.summary: A major review analyzing over 400 million patient records indicates cannabis consumption significantly increases cardiovascular risks including heart attacks and strokes, particularly among weekly users and young adults. Researchers recommend assessing cannabis use in cardiac evaluations amid growing concerns about unanticipated health impacts.
fields.content:
Researchers examined data from over 400 million patients across 24 previous studies, including cross-sectional analyses and long-term cohort research. One study specifically assessed medical cannabis usage. Findings consistently demonstrated heightened cardiovascular risks, especially among those consuming cannabis at least weekly.

A marijuana joint being hand rolled close up

Multiple studies revealed increased likelihood of acute myocardial infarction (heart attack), with one focusing on adolescents and young adults aged 15 to 22. Another investigation of nearly 15,000 patients between 18 and 54 found cannabis notably elevated risks of acute coronary syndrome (restricted heart blood flow) in the 18-36 subgroup.

Notably, cannabis use substantially raised all-cause mortality and cardiovascular death rates in patients who suffered heart attacks before age 50. The overarching review established "positive associations" between cannabis consumption and major adverse cardiovascular events (MACE), urging healthcare providers to routinely screen for cannabis use in cardiac cases.

Teens smoking

Study limitations included inconsistent reporting of cannabis exposure levels and potential data gaps causing possible bias. Self-reported patient surveys introduced significant inaccuracies in usage and outcome documentation, while overlapping datasets and constrained timeframes presented additional research challenges.

woman stands at the counter of a cannabis retailer

Dr. Siegel highlighted concerning risks of unmonitored regular consumption: "We definitely jumped the gun by not anticipating all the medical risks. Dosage escalation can increase anxiety and confusion, leading to rising ER visits." He specifically expressed alarm regarding elderly users: "It is absolutely an active chemical we need to watch out for."

rolling joint

Citing Colorado's post-legalization data, Siegel warned of severe consequences: "People are going to the ER with psychosis, vomiting disorders, and cannabis-related car accidents. The results are not pretty. We definitely jumped the gun by not anticipating all the medical risks here."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Brooks Koepka smashes tee marker in frustration before withdrawing from LIV Golf event
fields.summary: Professional golfer Brooks Koepka destroyed a tee marker with his driver during a LIV Golf tournament after a poor shot, then withdrew from the event due to illness after struggling at six over par through eight holes.
fields.content:
Five-time major champion Brooks Koepka unleashed frustration during a LIV Golf event by demolishing a tee marker with his driver following a wayward shot. After initially slamming his club, the golfer took direct aim at the marker at his tee box. Koepka had been struggling significantly during the opening round, carding six over par through just eight holes before withdrawing due to illness, according to LIV Golf officials.

Tournament regulations permitted Koepka's potential return over the weekend, though his scores would only count toward his team's total. Reserve player Luis Carrera replaced him for the remainder of the event. Koepka had been scheduled to continue competing in Dallas before the unexpected withdrawal.

Brooks Koepka on the range

The PGA Tour's official records show Koepka earned nearly $44 million from 186 tournaments during his time on the circuit. His career achievements include multiple major championship victories and consistent high-level performances across multiple tours.

Brooks Koepka plays shot

During the previous LIV Golf season, Koepka won two events to become the first golfer with five total victories since the league launched. Meanwhile, Harold Varner III of the 4Aces GC topped the leaderboard at LIV Dallas after the opening round.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: One Critically Injured in Piccadilly Circus Car Crash
fields.summary: A car crash at London's Piccadilly Circus left one man in critical condition and another injured, with emergency services responding to the overturned vehicle near the Eros statue early Sunday morning.
fields.content:
A 22-year-old man remains critically injured after a car accident at Piccadilly Circus in central London early Sunday. His black BMW overturned near the Shaftesbury Memorial Fountain, widely recognized as the Eros statue, landing on its roof.

A second 22-year-old male passenger sustained non-life threatening injuries and was hospitalized. Police confirmed no pedestrians were hurt and no other vehicles appear involved in the incident.

PA Media A black car crashed in Piccadilly Circus

Emergency services received calls around 05:30 BST reporting a vehicle crashing into the tourist area and flipping over. London Ambulance Service deployed multiple medical units to the location.

"We treated two people at the scene. One was transported to a major trauma center while the other went to a local hospital," stated an ambulance service spokesperson.

Police cordoned off the crash site and implemented road closures. Authorities acknowledged resulting disruptions but emphasized the area will only reopen after completing essential investigative procedures for this serious collision.

Piccadilly Circus serves as one of London's busiest traffic circles, linking key West End thoroughfares and attracting millions of visitors yearly.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Life Erased: A Gaza Woman's Struggle Amidst War's Devastation
fields.summary: Hanya Aljamal, a 28-year-old English teacher from Gaza, documents her shattered reality after eight months of war. Once pursuing a master's degree abroad, she now lives crowded in a tiny apartment with her family, witnesses daily trauma, and grapples with the loss of her identity and aspirations amidst widespread destruction.
fields.content:
Hanya Aljamal, 28, spends evenings on the balcony of her cramped apartment in Deir al-Balah, Gaza, seeking solitude from the six family members she now lives with. "I don't think God intended for people in their late 20s to live with their parents," she reflects. Before the war, Hanya taught English in her own apartment while preparing for a US master's program in international development with scholarship prospects. Today, her reality has shifted dramatically.

Each morning, Hanya observes an elderly neighbor tending plants beside a bombed-out building. "It looks like the purest form of resistance," she says. "In the middle of all this horror, he still finds time to grow something." Her school closed when fighting erupted in October 2023, displacing 90% of Gaza's population according to UN estimates. Hanya has relocated five times since.

Destroyed buildings visible from Hanya's balcony with a small garden in foreground

Explosions frequently disrupt the nights. "An explosion really close by jolted me awake at 2am," Hanya describes. Israel launched military operations after Hamas killed approximately 1,200 Israelis and took 251 hostages. Gaza's Hamas-run health ministry reports over 56,000 Palestinians killed so far. Hanya now works with aid organization Action for Humanity, where she witnesses children processing grief. "Someone tells me she lost both parents," she recounts after a therapy session.

Damaged buildings under cloudy skies in Deir al-Balah

Simple moments like seeing children fly kites offer respite. "They're like an active act of hope," Hanya observes. But drones dominate the skies, creating what she calls "psychological torture." Constant buzzing prevents thought: "They remind you they're watching, ready to pounce." Recently, while fasting for Eid al-Adha, malnutrition made her too dizzy to stand. "You cannot control anything - not even your thoughts or who you are," she explains.

Colorful kite flying over Gaza

Her demolished school and shattered aspirations have left Hanya feeling psychologically manipulated. "I feel like I've been gaslit - like my previous life was made up." During Eid, unable to follow tradition of sacrificing an animal due to scarce food supplies, she learned her cousin was killed while seeking aid. The incident highlighted frequent deadly confrontations reported near distribution points.

Hanya distributing aid supplies with children in Gaza

Hanya's teacher colleagues and students feature among at least ten acquaintances she has lost. She recently removed a deceased professor's name from her CV. "It's huge when someone believes in you," she reflects. Processing grief remains difficult: "Grieving is a luxury many of us can't afford." Now, Hanya finds solace in Gaza's dawn skies: "The one thing that gives you colors and beauty when everything else is gray or destroyed."

Sunset over damaged buildings in Gaza

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Council Tax Debt Soars Past £8 Billion as Rises Loom
fields.summary: Households across the UK owe over £8 billion in council tax arrears as financial pressures mount, while authorities plan annual increases potentially up to 5%, prompting calls for reformed collection practices.
fields.content:
Struggling households now face £8 billion in unpaid council tax across England, Scotland, and Wales, despite expectations of further bill increases. Government data reveals £6.6 billion owed to English local authorities alone, with £642 million added to arrears during the last year ending in April.

The Treasury confirmed assumptions of council tax increases of up to 5% annually, as Chief Secretary Darren Jones acknowledged future hikes while speaking to a spending review committee. Local authorities can exceed this cap with voter approval or government permission.

Falling behind

Council tax collection in England during the year ending April reached £41.2 billion—a 7.2% annual increase. However, unpaid debts rose more sharply at 11%, combining with £1.5 billion owed in Scotland and £263 million in Wales.

The collective £8 billion debt surpasses unpaid energy bills by double in these nations. Charity Debt Justice noted most arrears stem from low-income households, criticizing bailiff-led recovery methods. Toby Murray of Debt Justice urged councils to adopt compassionate approaches: "Rather than help, councils are sending in bailiffs - punishing people for struggling with their bills."

The government proposes capping court fees for arrears, relaxing full-year repayment demands after missed payments, pushing 12-month payment schemes, and reviewing enforcement practices.

What to do if you can't pay

Financial charities strongly advise against ignoring council tax notices. Residents facing payment difficulties should contact support organizations immediately for guidance on managing arrears.

The Local Government Association emphasized councils' duty to fund services while acknowledging household struggles. A spokesman cautioned: "It is almost inevitable bills will rise for those least able to pay" without adequate government funding for council tax support systems.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Rape Survivor MP Campaigns to Strip Rapists of Parental Rights
fields.summary: Labour MP Natalie Fleet, who became pregnant after being raped at 15, is leading efforts to amend UK law to prevent rapists from retaining parental rights. She has secured support from Prime Minister Keir Starmer and Queen Camilla for legislation that would block convicted child rapists from making decisions about their biological children.
fields.content:
Natalie Fleet, Labour MP for Bolsover, recalled being told at age 15 that she had "ruined your life, not only for you, but for your unborn daughter" after becoming pregnant through statutory rape. Growing up in Nottinghamshire, she had believed her relationship with an older man was genuine before realizing his true intentions.

"He tells me all the things a young girl wants to hear," Fleet recounted. "But when I told him I was pregnant, it became clear it was about him having as much sex as possible with a girl under 16." Societal attitudes made her accept blame for the situation without questioning why the father's role wasn't examined.

The MP noted that while the previous Labour government addressed teen pregnancy, it failed to ask critical questions about the fathers involved. This gap in approach influenced her current campaign for legal reform regarding parental rights for convicted rapists.

Vintage photograph of young mother holding baby

Fleet initially doubted her fitness for office because of her teenage motherhood experience. Now elected, she feels compelled to share her story despite its difficult nature. She considers herself "really lucky" about how she was raped because she maintains concrete proof: "I have a birth certificate that proves my age, hers, and DNA linking us."

Citing Office for National Statistics data indicating one in four women experience rape or sexual assault, Fleet emphasized: "Ultimately, every woman has either been raped or knows someone who has. Yet nobody's talking about it."

Amendment to bill

Fleet is spearheading an amendment to the Victims and Courts Bill that would suspend parental rights for convicted child rapists. Backed by government ministers, the legislation aims to prevent rapists from accessing children or influencing their lives from prison.

"It means he can't make decisions about medical issues, maintain pre-prison access levels, or interfere with the child's life," Fleet explained. "Children cannot be the only proceeds of crime that criminals retain lifelong access to."

Prime Minister Keir Starmer, previously Director of Public Prosecutions, expressed surprise such laws didn't already exist. "He said, 'I didn't know that was a thing. We can get wording into a bill to stop that'," Fleet revealed. Queen Camilla also offered support during a Buckingham Palace meeting that Fleet called "surreal" and "incredible".

Woman cradling newborn baby

Now a grandmother at 40, Fleet reflects: "Becoming a mum at 15 felt like the worst, but being a Nana at 40 is winning all jackpots combined." She hopes future generations will struggle to believe women stayed silent about rape, seeing her advocacy as starting necessary conversations: "I want my granddaughter to ask why men got away with it so easily."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Food Manufacturers Rush to Simplify Ingredients as Health Concerns Rise
fields.summary: Food companies are rapidly developing products with fewer ingredients in response to growing consumer concerns about ultra-processed foods and allergies, though nutritionists debate the health impact of this trend while shoppers seek cleaner labels.
fields.content:
The Consumer Challenge

For allergy sufferers like Kerry Clayton and her son - who must avoid gluten, dairy, citrus and other ingredients - specialty food shopping demands significant effort. The Kent family visits multiple stores weekly to find safe foods, prepares adaptable meals such as jacket potatoes, and bakes homemade goods, adding hours to their routine. The launch of Marks & Spencer's 'Only' range (featuring products with six or fewer ingredients) thrilled Ms Clayton despite premium pricing, highlighting the trade-off consumers accept for accessibility.

Industry Shift Accelerates

Retailers are experiencing surging demand for simpler ingredient lists, with platform IND!E reporting a 40% increase in retailer inquiries about such products. Founder Matthew Hopkins notes greater orders from Ocado, Selfridges, and John Lewis specifically for minimally processed items. Plant-based brand THIS has responded by introducing a Super Superfoods line using natural ingredients like beans and mushrooms, addressing consumer skepticism about meat alternatives. Similarly, premium cereal brand 3Bears debuted seven-ingredient oat loops priced at £3.99, co-founded with footballer Harry Kane, contrasting sharply with conventional cereals containing over 20 ingredients.

Matthew Hopkins, founder of IND!E, talking about food retail trends

Harry Kane promoting 3Bears cereal with company founders

Nutrition Debate Intensifies

The ultra-processed food (UPF) controversy, amplified by Dr Chris Van Tulleken's 2023 book, fuels the ingredient-reduction trend but draws criticism from nutrition experts. Nutritionist Dr Laura Wyness describes M&S's approach as prioritizing hype over health, voicing concern about omitted fortified nutrients. Food scientist Dr Jibin He argues the UPF classification is misleading, noting that processing ensures food safety and shelf life while nutrition varies independently from ingredient count. He maintains that tofu could be considered ultra-processed yet remain healthier than unprocessed meat, and advises manufacturers to analyze formulas for unnecessary components while exploring advanced processing technologies.

Treat Category Defies Trends

Despite health concerns, the UK's £14.8bn confectionery market continues expanding with its often complex products. Ice cream brand Little Moons, which lists over 30 ingredients in some flavors, now exports globally and faces supermarket copycats. Marketing director Ross Farquhar sees limited need for reformulation, stating certain ingredients remain essential for product stability and taste, adding that minimalist products cater to niche markets rather than mass preferences.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: BBC Admits Error in Broadcasting Anti-IDF Chants at Glastonbury
fields.summary: The BBC has acknowledged it should have cut its live broadcast of Bob Vylan's Glastonbury performance after the band's singer led anti-Israel Defense Forces chants, which the corporation described as 'antisemitic' and 'utterly unacceptable'.
fields.content:
The BBC stated it regrets broadcasting sections of Bob Vylan's performance at Glastonbury Festival, where singer Bobby Vylan initiated chants of 'death, death to the IDF'. In an official response, the broadcaster conceded: 'The team were dealing with a live situation but with hindsight we should have pulled the stream during the performance. We regret this did not happen.' This followed condemnation from broadcast regulator Ofcom and the UK government.

The BBC clarified its stance on Monday, saying: 'We respect freedom of expression but stand firmly against incitement to violence. The antisemitic sentiments expressed by Bob Vylan were utterly unacceptable and have no place on our airwaves.' They further announced plans to review live broadcast guidelines to prevent similar incidents.

Glastonbury organizers earlier described the on-stage comments as having 'crossed a line', stating: 'There is no place at Glastonbury for antisemitism, hate speech or incitement to violence.' The controversy centered on chants including 'free Palestine' and 'from the river to the sea, Palestine will be free' - a phrase interpreted by some as calling for Israel's elimination, though pro-Palestinian activists dispute this characterization.

UK media regulator Ofcom confirmed it was urgently seeking clarification from the BBC, stating: 'We are very concerned about the live stream of this performance, and the BBC clearly has questions to answer.' Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the comments as 'hate speech', while Culture Secretary Lisa Nandy sought an immediate explanation from BBC Director General Tim Davie.

The London-based punk-rap duo Bob Vylan formed in 2017. Their singer posted a statement on Instagram after the incident declaring 'I said what I said', defending artists' rights to political expression. The BBC indicated the performance material would not be available on iPlayer to audiences.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Hundreds Displaced as Israeli Air Strikes Intensify Across Gaza
fields.summary: Israel's intensified air strikes across Gaza have displaced hundreds of families and killed five people amid one of the largest evacuation orders since fighting resumed, escalating pressure on Prime Minister Netanyahu to pursue ceasefire talks.
fields.content:
Israeli air strikes have triggered mass displacement across Gaza, with witnesses reporting hundreds of Palestinian families fleeing bombardment in multiple neighborhoods. Rescue teams recovered five bodies and evacuated dozens of wounded civilians to Al-Ahli Hospital in Gaza City following the attacks.

The military operation represents one of the most extensive evacuation directives issued since hostilities restarted in March. The assaults targeted densely populated eastern sectors of Gaza City, including Shujaiya, Tuffah, and Zeitoun districts.

Social media footage captured chaotic scenes of explosions illuminating night skies, followed by towering flames and smoke plumes. One strike reportedly hit a Zeitoun school sheltering displaced families, while another at Al Shati camp west of Gaza City resulted in the five fatalities.

Despite Israeli military evacuation orders urging civilians south, most displaced residents moved westward within Gaza City's boundaries. Witnesses described receiving automated phone warnings declaring their areas as combat zones requiring immediate departure.

Mother of seven Abeer Talba, who fled Zeitoun, stated: "We had no choice but to leave everything behind. This is the seventh time we've been forced to flee. We're in the streets again, no food, no water. My children are starving. Death feels kinder than this."

The sustained attacks have fueled concerns about an expanded Israeli ground offensive. Concurrently, Israeli media reports suggest military leaders believe Gaza operations may be nearing completion, though former commanders caution prolonged guerrilla warfare could increase casualties among hostages, civilians, and soldiers.

Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu faces mounting domestic and international demands to prioritize ceasefire negotiations, despite his consistent emphasis on continuing military action against Hamas.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Boeing 787 Dreamliner: Safety Record and Whistleblower Concerns
fields.summary: The Boeing 787 Dreamliner carried over a billion passengers without fatal accidents until the 2025 Air India crash, but whistleblowers have repeatedly raised concerns about production flaws and safety risks at Boeing manufacturing facilities.
fields.content:
The Air India disaster in June 2025, which claimed at least 270 lives shortly after takeoff, involved Boeing's innovative 787 Dreamliner. Until this tragedy, the aircraft had been considered exceptionally safe after 14 years of accident-free operation carrying more than a billion passengers, with over 1,100 planes in service globally.

Despite this record, the Dreamliner program has faced persistent quality issues. Multiple whistleblowers who worked on the aircraft allege that production shortcuts and substandard parts created potential safety hazards, though Boeing consistently denies these claims.

The Sonic Cruiser and the 9/11 effect

Boeing began developing the 787 in the early 2000s after abandoning plans for a high-speed Sonic Cruiser jet. Aviation historian Shea Oakley explains that after the 9/11 attacks impacted the airline industry, Boeing shifted focus toward fuel efficiency. The redesigned aircraft could fly smaller planes directly between smaller cities, bypassing busy hub airports.

Attendees watch a Boeing 787 Dreamliner during its first test flight at Paine Field in Everett, Washington, 15 December 2009.

The Dreamliner featured revolutionary carbon composite construction, advanced aerodynamics, and electrical systems replacing heavier pneumatic ones. Boeing claimed it would be 20% more fuel-efficient than previous models and 60% quieter on the ground.

Airbus comparison and technical innovations

Boeing's 787 development strategy contrasted sharply with Airbus's now-discontinued A380 superjumbo program. Aviation analyst Richard Aboulafia notes Boeing correctly predicted airlines preferred direct point-to-point routes over giant hub airports. The fuel-efficient 787 outlasted the A380, which ceased production in 2021.

Airbus workers celebrate during the A380 superjumbo unveiling ceremony.

Early safety incidents and production issues

Shortly after entering service, the 787 faced safety setbacks when lithium-ion batteries caught fire aboard aircraft in Boston and Japan in 2013, leading to a worldwide grounding. Manufacturing defects later emerged, partly attributed to Boeing's new South Carolina assembly plant established away from its Washington headquarters.

John DeLisi of the NTSB updates media on 2013 Boeing 787 battery fire investigation.

Whistleblower disclosures

Former quality manager John Barnett stated before his death in 2024 that workers installed faulty parts from scrap bins to avoid delays. He warned: 'I believe it's just a matter of time before something big happens with a 787.' The FAA substantiated some claims, finding missing parts and metal shavings near wiring.

Supporters of Boeing whistleblower John Barnett protest during Senate testimony by CEO Kelly Ortberg, 2 April 2025.

Engineer Sam Salehpour testified to the US Senate in 2024 that assembly shortcuts created unexpected gaps in fuselage sections, risking 'premature fatigue failure' on over 1,000 aircraft. Boeing maintains these issues were fully investigated and present no safety concerns.

Boeing 787 Dreamliner flying over the Netherlands.

Current safety assessment

While Richard Aboulafia cites the Dreamliner's 'stellar safety record' of 16 years without fatal incidents pre-2025, the Foundation for Aviation Safety notes concerning regulatory reports including water leakage risks near electrical systems.

Firefighters near the crashed Air India Boeing 787 in Ahmedabad, India, on 13 June 2025.

Aviation analyst Scott Hamilton stated regarding the unresolved Air India crash: 'Based on what we know about the plane, I would not hesitate to get on board a 787.' The Air India aircraft involved was 11 years old, and investigations continue.

Protest in India against the government following the Air India plane crash, 16 June 2025.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Government Sets Out Welfare Concessions Ahead of Crucial Vote
fields.summary: The UK government is detailing concessions on welfare reforms to secure Labour support ahead of Tuesday's critical vote after over 120 party MPs threatened to block the legislation. Changes include limiting disability payment cuts to new claimants and maintaining inflation-linked rises for some benefits, reducing projected annual savings from £5bn to £2bn by 2030 despite ongoing opposition concerns about poverty impacts.
fields.content:
The government will release detailed concessions on welfare reforms as ministers strive to address Labour rebellion before a crucial vote. Work and Pensions Secretary Liz Kendall stated officials aim to establish a "fairer, more compassionate" benefits system before the Tuesday decision.

Last week, Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer faced a significant backbench revolt, with over 120 Labour MPs threatening to vote down the proposals. This forced amendments reducing the expected annual savings to £2bn by 2030 - significantly below the original £5bn target.

Revised Welfare Measures

The initial legislation proposed restricting access to personal independence payments and reducing health-related universal credit elements. Following negotiations, revisions will now limit PIP reductions solely to new claimants. Additionally, the government reversed plans to freeze health-related universal credit increases, committing instead to inflation-linked rises for current recipients.

Ministers will establish a PIP assessment review led by Disabilities Minister Sir Stephen Timms, conducted in consultation with disabled individuals. Regulations protecting benefits recipients who attempt work without triggering reassessment will also be introduced in Parliament.

Persistent Opposition

Despite these concessions, dozens of Labour MPs remain opposed to the reforms, potentially voting against the government. Clive Efford, Labour MP for Eltham and Chislehurst, confirmed he will oppose the legislation, stating: "There are still £3.5bn worth of savings required in these measures and we don't yet know the poverty impact they will have."

Efford noted many colleagues await government details to evaluate the impact on vulnerable individuals, calling the vote a "leap in the dark." Weekend negotiations continued as Kendall sought to reassure undecided MPs prior to Tuesday's second reading of the Universal Credit and Personal Independence Payment Bill.

Kendall defended the amended approach: "We must build a welfare system that provides security for those who cannot work and support for those who can. Too often, disabled people feel trapped, worried they might lose essential support if they attempt employment." She emphasized removing barriers for disabled individuals seeking work.

The Liberal Democrats will vote against the legislation. Deputy leader Daisy Cooper stated: "We cannot support measures making life harder for unpaid carers and disabled people dependent on daily assistance to maintain employment or unable to work." Ministers maintain the reforms aim to boost employment while addressing projected £70bn annual disability benefit costs by 2030.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Toilet Discovery: Could Bacteria-Eating Viruses Combat Deadly Infections?
fields.summary: Researchers have discovered a promising bacteria-eating virus in an unlikely place—a toilet sample—that successfully killed a drug-resistant urinary tract infection in laboratory tests, offering potential new weapons against antibiotic-resistant superbugs.
fields.content:
On a mission to find microscopic allies, scientists are seeking viruses that attack bacteria rather than humans. While viruses like COVID-19 and influenza are widely feared, bacteriophages—or phages—prey exclusively on bacterial cells.

These natural predators offer promising alternatives for treating stubborn infections, especially amid rising antibiotic resistance. The straightforward collection process involves gathering contaminated water samples, where diverse bacterial populations host phage activity.

James Gallagher examining a container pond

Investigator James Gallagher sourced samples from ponds, worm-composting bins, and an even less expected location: an unflushed toilet. After careful collection and filtration, these samples were studied at the University of Southampton.

Phage researcher Michelle Lin prepared the filtered samples by combining them with bacteria from a hospital patient suffering recurring urinary tract infections. Astonishingly, one phage from the toilet sample targeted and eradicated this resistant strain.

Scientist Michelle Lin working in a lab

In petri dishes, destroyed bacterial clusters showed where the phage prevailed. Associate professor Dr. Franklin Nobrega confirmed this phage shows high therapeutic potential, indicating it could treat infections directly in wounds, lungs, or urinary tracts. Named Gallagher-phage, its unique structure functions like a microscopic lander: Six-legged invaders attach to bacteria, transform them into replication factories, then burst them open. This targeted approach minimizes collateral damage to healthy cells compared to antibiotics.

Closeup of a petri dish showing phage bacteria destruction

Dr Franklin Nobrega and James Gallagher reviewing phage research

Illustration demonstrating phage therapy mechanism

Phage - the friendly virus

Bacteriophages, first identified in the 1910s by scientists Frederick Twort and Felix d'Hérelle, fueled early therapeutic research. However, the mid-20th century arrival of antibiotics overshadowed phage therapy. Work continued primarily in Georgia while Western research dwindled.

Detailed illustration of a phage structure

Today, antibiotic-resistant infections kill over one million people annually—a figure projected to reach 10 million by 2050. This crisis has revived phage research. Professor Paul Elkington, a lung medicine specialist at Southampton, expressed urgency after repeatedly confronting untreatable infections. He cautioned that while phage shows incredible promise, transitioning from labs to clinics remains challenging.

Microscopic view of clustered phages

Regulatory progress supports clinical testing, with the UK Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency outlining rules for developing phage therapy. Already available in compassionate cases when antibiotics fail, phages could become prescribed alternatives in 15-20 years. Public involvement drives discovery further: groups invite citizen scientists to collect samples using affordable kits.

Researchers from the Phage project team at the University of Southampton

Project representative Esme Brinsden emphasized that bacteriophages represent a tangible way anyone may potentially save lives, especially in an era grappling with escalating antimicrobial resistance.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Westminster Primary Schools Merge Amid Falling Enrollment
fields.summary: Five primary schools in Westminster will merge into two institutions due to declining pupil numbers and financial pressures, despite significant opposition from parents and concerns about educational quality.
fields.content:
Five primary schools in Westminster are consolidating into two institutions following substantial declines in student enrollment and growing financial pressures. The mergers involve Barrow Hill Junior School, Robinsfield Infant School, and George Eliot Primary combining to form St John's Wood Primary School, while Our Lady of Dolours Catholic Primary will integrate into St Mary of the Angels Catholic Primary School.

Parents at both groups of schools actively opposed the plans, with one formal consultation showing 83% disagreement with the mergers. The chairs of governors acknowledged the decision "will bring about some changes and perhaps a level of uncertainty" for the school communities.

Falling birth rate

Governors cited declining birth rates and high housing costs as primary reasons for the mergers in a December 2023 communication to parents. With schools funded per pupil, shrinking enrollment directly impacts finances—Barrow Hill operated at 82% capacity, George Eliot at 85%, and Robinsfield at 75%, while Our Lady of Dolours and St Mary of the Angels were at 54% and 80% capacity respectively in October 2024.

This under-occupancy led to projected deficits of £550,000 for Our Lady of Dolours and £186,000 for St Mary of the Angels this year. Governors moved forward with the merger proposals in spring 2024, submitting them to Westminster City Council for formal consultations.

LDRS Sign showing Barrow Hill Junior School outside the school gates

Some parents questioned the necessity of the mergers, particularly for the Catholic schools. A petition against merging Our Lady of Dolours with St Mary of the Angels warned the move would push the latter to 130% capacity: "The proposed amalgamation would push our school to operate at 130% capacity, leading to crowded classrooms and a likely decrease in the quality of learning."

The petition also highlighted that only half of Our Lady of Dolours pupils practice Catholicism, potentially altering the religious character of the St Mary of the Angels community. Westminster City Council will review the petition, which cites inadequate consideration of alternatives and disregard for community feedback.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Robots vs Astronauts: The Future of Space Exploration
fields.summary: As autonomous spacecraft like NASA's Parker Solar Probe achieve unprecedented feats, a growing debate questions whether human astronauts remain essential for space exploration. Experts analyze the rising capabilities of robots, AI systems, and the irreplaceable roles humans might still hold amid plans for lunar and Martian missions.
fields.content:
On Christmas Eve 2024, an unmanned spacecraft made the closest approach to the Sun ever recorded. During its daring flyby, NASA's Parker Solar Probe autonomously navigated through the star's atmosphere at extreme temperatures near 1,000°C, collecting vital data on solar activity and space weather without any real-time human guidance.

BBC A robot faces an astronaut

This milestone underscores how robotic probes have explored distant frontiers unreachable by humans for over sixty years. Yet with AI advancements accelerating, scientists like Astronomer Royal Lord Martin Rees argue against taxpayer-funded human missions: "Robots are developing fast... I don't think any money should be used to send humans." He cites extreme risks and advocates space travel only for privately funded adventurers.

University College London physicist Andrew Coates supports prioritizing robotics: "They go much further scientifically and cost far less. As AI improves, robots will become increasingly capable." However, this raises questions about whether machines can replicate human ingenuity in unknown environments or inspire public imagination.

NASA A treated image showing artist’s concept of the Parker Solar Probe spacecraft approaching the orange/red sun.

Rovers versus mankind

While robots have visited every solar system planet, humans remain limited to Earth's orbit and the Moon—only about 700 people have entered space since Yuri Gagarin's first flight in 1961. Rice University biologist Dr. Kelly Weinersmith notes prestige still drives human missions: "It shows your political system works." Yet humans face immense challenges—spacesuits, life support, and psychological strain alter missteps into life-or-death scenarios.

Robotic explorers bypass these limitations but move painstakingly slowly—Martian rovers crawl at less than 0.1mph. "AI beats humans at chess, but can it outpace us in exploration?" questions planetary scientist Dr. Ian Crawford. Nevertheless, humans excel at rapid problem-solving; astronauts conduct nuanced research impossible for current AI or distant rovers.

NASA Nasa’s Perseverance Mars rover is seen in a selfie

AI assistants and humanoid robots

Instead of replacement, many envision collaboration. Former NASA researcher Dr. Kiri Wagstaff suggests AI could handle "tedious tasks" during exploration, freeing astronauts for critical work. Humanoid robots like NASA’s Valkyrie—a 300-pound, 6-foot-tall machine—or the tool-wielding Robonaut deployed on the International Space Station demonstrate potential for maintaining habitats and performing delicate operations.

NASA’s Dexterous Robotics lead Dr. Shaun Azimi states: "Robots can secure locations ahead of human crews." Current rovers already make autonomous decisions—Curiosity identifies and studies Martian rocks without Earth's input. However, limited computing hampers complex functions; most systems operate at one-tenth smartphone speeds despite promising experiments like NASA's Valkyrie.

NASA Nasa's Valkyrie humanoid robot

Reuters NASA's humanoid robot Valkyrie opening a bag

Life on Mars?

NASA’s Artemis program aims to return astronauts to the Moon by 2027, while China plans crewed lunar missions. SpaceX’s Elon Musk envisions Martian colonies transporting settlers via Starship rockets. Some scientists question the ethics: "Can babies even develop there?" asks Weinersmith. Others see radical possibilities—Lord Rees imagines genetically modified "cyborgs" adapted for Martian life.

Retired astronaut Leroy Chiao counters robotic arguments with human inspiration: "People relate to people." Coates acknowledges this intangible value, predicting once humans reach Mars, "it will dwarf the Moon landing’s impact." For now, as robotic vanguard blaze trails, human explorers prepare to follow.

Reuters Four Astronauts in blue NASA uniforms, smiling at a press conference

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump claims wealthy group ready to buy TikTok as sale deadline extended
fields.summary: Former President Donald Trump has stated he secured wealthy investors to purchase TikTok after repeatedly delaying U.S. government-enforced sale deadlines over national security issues, expressing confidence in Chinese approval.
fields.content:
Donald Trump revealed he has identified potential buyers for TikTok shortly after extending the deadline for the app's forced divestment. The former president told Fox News a group of 'very wealthy people' stands ready to acquire the platform once Chinese approval is obtained, stating he expects President Xi Jinping 'will probably do it'. This marks Trump's third delay in enforcing the sale mandate.

The new presidential directive requires ByteDance, TikTok's Chinese parent company, to reach a sale agreement by September 17. The extension comes amidst longstanding U.S. security concerns that the social media app could expose American user data to Chinese authorities, which the company has consistently denied. Authorities have formally sought TikTok's response to Trump's buyer announcement.

A previous attempt to sell the platform to American investors failed last April amid U.S.-China trade disagreements. It remains unclear whether Trump's current buyer group involves the same parties from earlier negotiations. Congress originally mandated TikTok's sale in April 2023 over national security worries, with implementation originally scheduled for January 19 before Trump's extensions.

Trump, who previously denounced TikTok during his presidency, now considers the platform strategically important for his election campaign and supports its continued operation in the U.S. His executive actions postponing the congressionally mandated sale have faced criticism for overriding legislative authority. TikTok previously lost a challenge to the sale law in the U.S. Supreme Court after questioning its constitutionality.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Olivia Rodrigo Delivers Triumphant Glastonbury Closing Set
fields.summary: Olivia Rodrigo capped off Glastonbury Festival with a career-defining headline performance on the Pyramid Stage, featuring a surprise duet with The Cure's Robert Smith. The Sunday lineup also saw standout sets from Rod Stewart, Nile Rodgers, Wolf Alice, and others during the festival's closing day.
fields.content:
Glastonbury culminated in a spectacular finale as Olivia Rodrigo delivered a triumphant closing performance on the iconic Pyramid Stage. Following elaborate sets by previous headliners The 1975 and Neil Young, the 22-year-old powered through sharp punk-pop anthems and vulnerable ballads about youthful heartbreak.

Rodrigo charmed English audiences by professing love for Marks and Spencer's Colin the Caterpillar sweets and won festival veterans over by duetting with The Cure's Robert Smith, whom she called "perhaps the best songwriter to come out of England." Beaming to the crowd, she expressed disbelief: "Glastonbury's been my dream festival forever and I can't believe today's the day."

Robert Smith and Olivia Rodrigo performing together

The performance marked a milestone for Rodrigo, whose breakout single "Drivers License" shattered Spotify records just five years ago. Though initially typecast as "the sad piano girl," she dismantled expectations through dynamic rockers channeling influences from Joan Jett to Avril Lavigne.

Dressed in white lace and knee-high boots, Rodrigo kicked off with fierce tracks "Obsessed" and "Diary Of A Homeschooled Girl," screaming to the massive crowd: "I don't think I've ever seen so many people in my life! Are you ready to have some fun?" She balanced raw rock energy, feminist anthems, and heartfelt ballads throughout the night, backed by an all-female band without elaborate staging.

Olivia Rodrigo playing guitar on stage

The emotional peak came during Rodrigo's Cure medley with Smith. As they performed "Friday I'm In Love" and "Just Like Heaven," she glanced at him with visible awe. Smith reciprocated the admiration, watching her entire set from side-stage. "He's the nicest, most wonderful man ever," Rodrigo later gushed. Her genuine connection continued as she introduced "So American," dedicated to inside jokes with an English boyfriend, adding: "I love English boys and M&S sweets—three sticky toffee puddings since arriving!"

Olivia Rodrigo engaging with Glastonbury crowd

England reciprocated fiercely during the encore, erupting for "Brutal," "All American Bitch," "Good 4 U," and "Get Him Back." Rodrigo departed under fireworks as inflatables bounced through the audience—ending the festival's most attended headline show with punk ferocity.

Closing the performance, she demonstrated Glastonbury wisdom beyond her years, summarizing: "Bring the hits. Make it unique. And make it personal." This philosophy echoed advice she'd absorbed from Jarvis Cocker, whom she'd watched on Saturday.

Setlist from Olivia Rodrigo's Glastonbury show

Sunday's Star Performances

Earlier, The Selecter energized the Pyramid Stage opener with sharp ska rhythms. Singer Pauline Black dedicated "Frontline" to NHS colleagues, while the crowd carried her through "On The Radio" when her voice faltered.

Celeste unveiled compelling new grunge-inspired material including "Everyday," reimagining Death In Vegas's "Dirge." Joy Crookes mesmerized in a pink sari, delivering Amy Winehouse-esque soul including the anthemic "Perfect Crime." The Libertines offered nostalgic rock before Rod Stewart took the cherished legends slot.

Joy Crookes performing in pink and green sari

Stewart played lounge-lizard renditions of "Do Ya Think I'm Sexy" and "Maggie May" with Ronnie Wood guesting for a Faces reunion during "Stay With Me." Yet Nile Rodgers and Chic drew larger crowds immediately after with disco classics like "Le Freak," "Let's Dance," and Madonna collaborations. A skywriting plane drew hearts above as they performed.

The Libertines performing at Glastonbury

Nile Rodgers conducting Chic on stage

Elsewhere, AJ Tracey galvanized crowds at Woodsies stage after teasing "the weakest mosh pit"—only for Aitch to burst out for explosive duet "Rain." The Prodigy honored late frontman Keith Flint on The Other Stage, while Jorja Smith offered soothing respite for weary attendees.

Wolf Alice earned massive singalongs for Fleetwood Mac's "Dreams" and friendship anthem "Bros," previewing their upcoming album with angular track "Bloom Baby Bloom." Singer Ellie Rowsell drenched herself mid-set before unleashing punk fury in "Yuk Foo" and "Greatest Hits," cementing their future headliner status.

Wolf Alice's Ellie Rowsell performing on stage

fields.title: Orionid Meteor Shower to Light Up Skies Through November
fields.summary: The annual Orionid meteor shower, created by remnants of Halley's Comet, will illuminate night skies through late November with peak activity occurring in mid-October. Viewers may see up to 15 meteors per hour under ideal dark-sky conditions, though a bright moon may affect visibility.
fields.content:
The Orionid meteor shower reaches its peak every October, famous for producing bright and swift shooting stars that continue appearing through most of November. This year, the celestial event faces challenges from a bright waning gibbous moon that could diminish visibility by overpowering fainter meteors.

These meteors consist of dust and ice particles shed by Halley's Comet. NASA explains: "Each time Halley returns to the inner solar system, its nucleus releases debris that becomes the Orionids when entering Earth's atmosphere each October."

During the peak on October 21, skywatchers could potentially observe up to 15 meteors hourly across the Northern Hemisphere. Optimal viewing requires not just clear skies but minimal light pollution for full visibility.

Meteors in the sky

Bill Cooke of NASA's Meteoroid Environment Office advises: "Find an area far from city lights. Bring a blanket, lie on your back, and absorb as much sky as possible. Your eyes will adjust within 30 minutes, revealing meteors."

Halley's Comet in the sky

Though the Orionids peak on October 21, they remain active until November 22. Halley's Comet completes its solar orbit every 76 years, having last appeared in 1986 and scheduled to return in 2061.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Expert Tips for Better Sleep in Sweltering Summer Heat
fields.summary: A sleep scientist shares practical, evidence-based strategies to overcome heat-related sleep disruptions and improve rest quality during summer nights.
fields.content:
Dr. Michael Gradisar, head of sleep science at Sleep Cycle in Australia, explains that humans naturally release heat through extremities while preparing for sleep. High temperatures hinder this process, making falling and staying asleep challenging. "For those prone to insomnia, heat adds another stressor, increasing nighttime awakenings and morning grogginess," he notes.

Researcher insights on thermoregulation

Gradisar emphasizes that warmth prevents effective heat dissipation from hands, feet, and face—critical to initiating sleep. This physiological challenge causes fragmented sleep cycles during hot nights, significantly reducing sleep quality even in healthy individuals.

Mastering the sleep environment

Gradisar advises opening windows early for cooler air, closing them before bedtime to minimize noise, and maintaining a dark, quiet space. Fans or air conditioning help circulate air to optimize the body's natural heat-release mechanisms and prevent night sweats.

woman lying in front of fan on couch sleeping

Body-cooling techniques

Taking cool showers or evening swims lowers core body temperature for better sleep onset. If overheated under covers, briefly remove your blanket for 30-60 seconds before recovering. Hydration supports internal cooling but combats only part of the problem.

Partner and bedding considerations

Sharing blankets traps body heat between partners—Gradisar recommends separate bedding. Choose breathable pajamas and natural, moisture-wicking fabrics while avoiding gimmicky cooling blankets. "Scientific evidence for cooling blankets is minimal," he cautions.

woman lying in bed late at night awake

Studies indicate alcohol disrupts natural thermoregulation by accelerating heart rate and dilating blood vessels, creating temporary warmth followed by impaired temperature control—further complicating summer sleep.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Real F1 Drivers Analyze Accuracy of 'F1: The Movie'
fields.summary: Formula 1 drivers Pierre Gasly and Franco Colapinto evaluate the realism in Joseph Kosinski's high-speed racing film 'F1: The Movie,' detailing what the Brad Pitt-starring drama captures accurately versus its creative liberties in depicting the sport.
fields.content:
The high-speed racing film 'F1: The Movie,' directed by Joseph Kosinski and starring Brad Pitt, has garnered attention for its authentic on-track sequences. Pitt and co-star Damson Idris personally drove Formula 1 cars during filming, accumulating over 6,000 miles behind the wheel. Real-life F1 champion Lewis Hamilton consulted extensively to ensure technical accuracy, but current Alpine drivers Pierre Gasly and Franco Colapinto offer definitive verdicts on the film's realism.

Gasly and Colapinto attended a special screening ahead of the movie's premiere during the Canadian Grand Prix weekend. They evaluated the depiction of driver experiences, team dynamics, race physics, and regulations.

What F1: The Movie Gets Right

Gasly highlighted the film's accurate portrayal of team responsibilities and pressure: "The stakes of carrying the responsibility of a thousand people working in a team is very well showed. It's a sport where you put it all out there, but you're not always rewarded."

Colapinto emphasized how the film conveys the visceral experience missing from broadcasts: "You can't feel the adrenaline, sound, or vibrations when watching on TV. The movie's camera angles and recreation of scenes capture that unique sensation for fans." Gasly added that the data-driven aspects of F1 were "shown in a very smart way," balancing technical precision with cinematic appeal.

What F1 Gets Less Right

Sonny’s End of Race Participation

Colapinto labeled Brad Pitt's character Sonny racing without practice sessions as "science fiction." Real Formula 1 regulations strictly prohibit drivers from competing without participating in practice or qualifying sessions. While dramatically effective, this storyline element violates official racing protocols.

Race Order

The film's montage placing the Belgian Grand Prix directly after Mexico's race drew criticism. Actual F1 scheduling clusters races regionally to minimize travel, with European races like Belgium occurring mid-season rather than after transatlantic events near the championship's conclusion.

Intense Crash

Gasly called the film's major crash sequence unrealistic: "Hopefully we'll never see that happening on track." Though acknowledging it created tension, he noted real crashes rarely reach such extremes. Colapinto plainly stated: "It's quite unrealistic." Director Kosinski acknowledged inspiration from the 1966 film 'Grand Prix,' and safety measures like the Halo device—implemented after Jules Bianchi's fatal 2014 crash—now prevent such dramatic incidents.

Collateral Damage

Gasly challenged Sonny's strategy of intentionally creating track debris: "I really doubt the FIA will let that happen." Real drivers face severe penalties for deliberate actions, such as Max Verstappen recently earning penalty points for colliding with George Russell. In reality, Sonny's tactics would likely result in race bans or license suspensions rather than heroic outcomes.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Over 130 Charities Demand Closure of US-Israeli Gaza Aid Group
fields.summary: More than 130 humanitarian organizations including Oxfam, Save the Children, and Amnesty International have jointly called for the immediate shutdown of the Gaza Humanitarian Foundation, citing over 500 Palestinian deaths and nearly 4,000 injuries at militarized aid distribution sites.
fields.content:
Humanitarian organizations worldwide are demanding the closure of the controversial Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF), established with Israeli and US backing. The collective statement from over 130 NGOs alleges that over 500 Palestinians have been killed and nearly 4,000 injured since the foundation began aid distribution in late May, following Israel's three-month blockade of Gaza.

According to the coalition, Israeli forces and armed groups consistently open fire on Palestinian civilians attempting to access humanitarian assistance. The organizations detail how GHF operations have centralized food distribution from approximately 400 locations to just four heavily militarized centers in southwestern and central Gaza.

Israel has denied accusations that its soldiers deliberately target aid recipients, defending the GHF model as necessary to circumvent Hamas interference and provide direct assistance. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu dismissed reports from Israeli newspaper Haaretz alleging IDF soldiers were ordered to shoot near aid sites as "malicious falsehoods".

United Nations Secretary-General Antonio Guterres condemned the GHF framework as "inherently unsafe", echoing earlier UN warnings that militarized aid distribution forces perilous journeys through conflict zones. In response to mounting criticism, the IDF announced plans for reorganization of site access including fencing and warning signs.

The charities' joint statement emphasizes the impossible choices facing Palestinians: "Today, Palestinians in Gaza face an impossible choice: starve or risk being shot while trying desperately to reach food to feed their families." The organizations reported orphaned children and caregivers among the casualties, with children harmed in over half of all attacks at distribution sites.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Royal Train Service to End by 2027 in Palace Cost-Cutting Move
fields.summary: Buckingham Palace will decommission the historic royal train service by 2027 as part of cost-saving measures, revealed alongside annual financial reports showing £44,000 costs for a single two-day journey and nearly £5 million in total royal travel expenses.
fields.content:
Buckingham Palace has announced the royal train will be taken out of service by 2027 as a cost-saving measure. This historic transport service has carried monarchs since Queen Victoria's reign but will retire as part of what officials describe as a "drive to ensure value for money".

The decision coincides with the release of royal financial records showing a specific journey on the royal train in February cost over £44,000. The two-day trip covered routes from Gloucestershire to Staffordshire before terminating in London.

While royals will continue traveling on regular train services, the annual report revealed 141 helicopter trips were taken last year at a cost of £475,000. James Chalmers, Keeper of the Privy Purse, acknowledged the decision marks "the fondest of farewells" but maintained that "in moving forwards we must not be bound by the past".

The nine-carriage royal train will tour the UK before retirement, after which it may be displayed publicly. The service dates back to 1869 when Queen Victoria commissioned special coaches for royal travel nationwide.

King Charles exiting the royal train during 2023 engagement

Though extensively used during Queen Elizabeth II's jubilee celebrations, the carriages required no significant updates since the mid-1980s. Recent accounts indicate the train was only used twice during 2024-2025, raising questions about ongoing maintenance costs.

Overall royal travel expenses totaled £4.7 million, representing a £500,000 annual increase. This includes £600,000 for 55 private charter flights, £126,000 for scheduled flights, and £400,000 for the King and Queen's trip to Australia and Samoa.

British royal family on Buckingham Palace balcony during public appearance

The annual Sovereign Grant funding the monarchy remains at £86.3 million for 2024-25 but will temporarily rise to £132.1 million over the next two years to fund Buckingham Palace's £369 million renovation. Adjusted for inflation, this grant has tripled since its 2012 introduction.

Separately, the Duchy of Cornwall reported £22.9 million in profits for Prince William. Officials announced a socially conscious financial strategy, with Will Bax, the duchy's secretary, revealing plans to waive or reduce rents for charities and community groups while emphasizing Prince William's focus on homelessness and climate initiatives.

Anti-monarchy organization Republic criticized royal spending, with CEO Graham Smith calling the funding a "scandalous abuse of public money" given current debates about welfare reductions, noting security costs remain undisclosed in official figures.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Government Urges Supermarkets to Boost Healthy Food Appeal
fields.summary: The UK government has launched a new strategy requiring supermarkets and food manufacturers to make healthy options more appealing through promotions, product reformulation, and store layout changes. Announced ahead of England's 10-year NHS plan, this voluntary partnership aims to tackle rising obesity rates amid criticism of the approach as 'nanny state' intervention.
fields.content:
Government Strategy Against Obesity

Food retailers in England must implement measures to encourage healthier shopping habits under new government plans. Starting Sunday, supermarkets and manufacturers will partner with officials to combat obesity through initiatives like prioritizing healthy product promotions, modifying loyalty program rewards, or redesigning store layouts. Health Secretary Wes Streeting called the strategy "radically different" from previous approaches, shifting from enforcement to collaboration. Retailers will voluntarily report healthy food sales metrics, with targets negotiated between industry and government.

Political Debate Over Personal Choice

Opposition figures immediately criticized the plans as governmental overreach. Shadow Work and Pensions Secretary Helen Whately denounced the "nanny state" mandate, stating: "Telling people what to buy is not up to government. I believe in personal responsibility." She contrasted the focus on supermarket layouts with broader NHS challenges. Streeting countered that reducing average daily calorie intake by just 50 would lift around 300,000 UK children and two million adults from obesity, emphasizing population-wide benefits beyond individual choices.

Health Crisis and Cost Barriers

Data reveals obesity's growing burden: over one-third of children become overweight by middle school in deprived areas, costing the NHS £11 billion annually. A Food Foundation study highlights financial obstacles—1,000 calories of fruits and vegetables cost £8.80 versus £4.30 for processed alternatives like ready meals and processed meats. Streeting noted that a 216-calorie daily reduction—equivalent to a bottle of soda—could halve obesity rates nationwide.

Industry Response and Skepticism

British Retail Consortium's Andrew Opie welcomed the plan but stressed inclusivity: "Engaging all food businesses makes a difference. We consume 25% of calories outside home environments." Katharine Jenner of the Obesity Health Alliance praised its systemic focus on food accessibility rather than individual blame. Past initiatives saw limited success—a 2015-2020 sugar reduction campaign failed to meet its 20% target. Think tank analyst Sarah Woolnough cautioned that without addressing cheaper unhealthy food prices and broader availability, impacts would remain minimal.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Newcastle University Offers Compensation for Strike-Disrupted Classes
fields.summary: Newcastle University will provide financial compensation to students whose studies were interrupted by staff strikes held between March and June. Payments ranging from £100 to £1,200 will be awarded depending on the number of disrupted modules and students' fee status, following guidance from the Office for Students.
fields.content:
University students at Newcastle University will receive compensation following strike action that disrupted classes between March and June. The industrial action was taken by staff in protest of planned job cuts that could have eliminated approximately 300 positions as part of efforts to reduce the university's salary expenditure by £20m.

Compensation amounts will vary based on how many modules were affected and whether students pay home or international fees. Those paying home fees will receive £100 per disrupted module, capped at £600, while international students will get £200 per module up to £1,200. The payouts acknowledge missed teaching that couldn't be rescheduled.

How much compensation?

Eligibility for compensation hinges on module-level disruption rather than individual missed lessons. Under the university's framework, a module qualifies as disrupted only when instruction was canceled due to strikes without substitute sessions. This means compensation remains the same for a module whether students missed one lesson or multiple sessions within that course.

A university spokesperson explained this standardized approach allows efficient compensation consistent with Office for Students (OfS) expectations. The OfS confirmed it doesn't intervene in staffing disputes but mandates that institutions provide appropriate redress for educational interruptions, adding that universities themselves determine fair compensation amounts based on disruption severity.

The strikes concluded when the University and College Union secured assurances that no further job reductions would occur before next year. Over 200 university employees have already accepted voluntary severance packages.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: World's Oldest Boomerang Discovered in Poland, Aged 40,000 Years
fields.summary: A boomerang discovered in a Polish cave has been re-dated to 40,000 years old, revealing it as the world's oldest known example - but this carefully crafted mammoth tusk tool would not return to its thrower. New analysis shows it was likely used for hunting rather than recreational purposes.
fields.content:
The world's oldest known boomerang, discovered in a cave in Poland, has been confirmed to be approximately 40,000 years old, challenging previous estimates about human ingenuity during prehistoric times. This curved tool, meticulously carved from mammoth tusk, displayed sophisticated craftsmanship though it lacked the returning flight capability of modern boomerangs.

Detailed view of the mammoth ivory boomerang with scale showing 75cm length

Unearthed in 1985 at Oblazowa Cave in southern Poland, the artifact was originally thought to be 30,000 years old. Advanced radiocarbon dating of human and animal bones from the same site now establishes its true age at 39,000-42,000 years. Dr. Sahra Talamo of Italy's University of Bologna confirmed its unique status: "It's the oldest boomerang in the world, and the only one of its particular shape discovered in Poland."

Remarkable preservation shows polishing marks and carving patterns suggesting right-handed use. According to Dr. Talamo, this provides a critical insight into how Homo sapiens from this period possessed the technical skill to create effective hunting tools, with possible ritual significance beyond practical application.

Entrance to Oblazowa Cave where the ancient boomerang was discovered

Global Precedents for Boomerang Technology

While boomerangs are most commonly associated with Australian Aboriginal culture, discoveries across multiple continents demonstrate their broader prehistoric use. Australia's oldest physical boomerang dates back 10,500 years, though rock art depicts similar tools as early as 20,000 years ago.

European findings include a 7,000-year-old wooden boomerang from Denmark's Jutland peninsula and 2,000-year-old returne-style oak fragments from the Netherlands, contrasting with the Polish hunting implement. The international research collaboration from six countries detailing this discovery published their findings in PLOS One.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Glastonbury Performances Spark Controversy Over BBC Coverage
fields.summary: The BBC's Glastonbury coverage faces intense scrutiny after performances by Bob Vylan and Kneecap featured politically charged messages, including calls of 'death to the IDF' and contested pro-Palestinian slogans. This led to a police investigation and criticism over the broadcaster's handling of live streams, raising questions about free speech limits at cultural events.
fields.content:
Fresh from winning a Bafta for last year's Glastonbury coverage, the broadcaster now faces criticism regarding this year's event. The focus centers on two afternoon sets at the West Holts stage on Saturday - punk duo Bob Vylan and Belfast rap group Kneecap - though initial attention had centered primarily on Kneecap.

Organizers had defended Kneecap's appearance despite political objections, while the network announced it wouldn't stream their set live. Yet few anticipated the controversy from Bobby Vylan's performance, where the frontman led chants of 'death, death to the IDF' and platformed the 'From the river to the sea' slogan regarding Israel and Palestine.

Getty Images Moglai Bap of Kneecap, a young man with a skin-fade haircut and wearing sunglasses, yells into his microphone as he performs with his back to the crowd, who are close enough to grab his arms.

Police launched a criminal investigation into whether Vylan's statements broke laws, while interpretations of the 'river to the sea' phrase diverged. Critics view these words as calling for Israel's elimination, though pro-Palestinian activists describe them as demands to end occupation and blockade. Meanwhile, Kneecap later expressed political messages critical of British policy during their performance.
