These amounts, exceeding a month's average rainfall, could cause severe flash flooding and major disruptions to transport networks. Additional yellow warnings cover broader areas of England and Scotland, with risks of large hail, frequent lightning strikes, and strong gusty winds.

Regional impacts and flooding threats

A photo of a map showing details of the Amber weather warning

The storms initially developed over central southern and southeastern England and the Midlands late Friday before tracking toward northern England and Scotland on Saturday. Northern Scotland faces an elevated flooding risk on Sunday when rainfall systems may slow significantly. Unsettled low-pressure patterns are forecast to bring more widespread thunderstorms nationwide through Sunday and Monday, exacerbating flood concerns across already saturated regions.

Severely parched soils across England and eastern Wales following consecutive heatwaves will worsen flood risks, as water will run off the hardened ground rather than being absorbed. This mirrors conditions seen during London's August 2022 flash floods after similar heat conditions. The rapid runoff heightens dangers of overwhelmed drainage systems and sudden inundation.

A photo of traffic driving through flooded roads

Little relief for drought-stricken regions

Despite massive rainfall volumes, officials warn the downpours will provide minimal drought relief. Helen Wakeham, Environment Agency Director for Water and National Drought Group chair, confirmed: "This has been the driest start to the year since 1976." Millions remain under hosepipe bans as drought conditions expand across the UK.

The heavy rainfall will mostly become runoff instead of soaking into groundwater reserves due to hardened soils, with growing vegetation absorbing moisture that does permeate the soil. Significant water supply recovery will require consistent precipitation during autumn or winter months. Consequently, existing hosepipe restrictions will likely extend throughout summer and potentially into early autumn.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Defence Firms Predict Job Surge Amid Increased Military Spending
fields.summary: Defence companies across the UK anticipate significant job growth as the government increases military expenditure, with industry leaders expressing confidence in new contracts despite pending procurement decisions.
fields.content:
Hundreds of new jobs are expected across defence supply firms as government spending on military capabilities rises, according to industry leaders. Emma Baker, policy chief at defence trade group ADS, states they "are anticipating a lot more work" from upcoming government contracts.

Over 40,000 people currently work in the defence sector across southwest England, with businesses heavily reliant on Ministry of Defence contracts. Many industry representatives recently gathered at the Royal International Air Tattoo in Gloucestershire, the world's largest military air show.

A military fighter jet, stands on a red runway. Behind it, behind fencing, crowds of people walk past and look on. There are tents behind them.

Highlight attractions included helicopters from Yeovil-based Leonardo Helicopters, which employs over 3,000 people at its Somerset factory. The company awaits final approval on a £1 billion contract to supply the RAF with more than 20 new helicopters which would "create or secure over 3,000 jobs" nationwide. As the sole remaining bidder, Leonardo's contract remains pending amid government defence spending reviews.

Leonardo Helicopters A helicopter flying. It is black. The camera is looking up. Grass on the floor is blowing from the rotors.

Despite delays, Leonardo continues recruiting apprentices and graduate engineers. AJ McKenzie, a 20-year-old apprentice maintaining helicopter gearboxes, described his enthusiasm: "I absolutely love it. Taking things apart, putting them back together, there's a lot of 'why does that not work?' - it's so satisfying."

A woman in a pin stripe blue jacket and a white top, smiles at camera. There is a flight simulator behind her.

Roles extend beyond manual labour to advanced digital engineering. Chrissy Smith, demonstrating a helicopter flight simulator after 36 years at Leonardo, emphasized her pride in developing protective technologies: "I'm proud to be part of something that will protect and secure the nation." Industry leaders remain optimistic about expanding workloads once defence reviews conclude.

Two men in t shirts look at a screen in a factory. One is older. The older man is pointing at the screen.

Smaller suppliers like Bristol-based Broadway Group also anticipate growth opportunities. CEO Seb Greene noted defence contracts sustained them during the pandemic when commercial aviation work collapsed, enabling expansion from 80 to 180 employees. The firm now hires four apprentices annually plus graduates.

A woman in a black top, with black hair, sits at a desk. She is looking into the camera. Her hands are on a keyboard and mouse, and a computer monitor is behind her.

Nanditha Gampala, a business graduate at Broadway, highlighted aerospace career diversity: "There's so much variety. Don't pigeonhole yourself - there's something for everyone." With 130 defence firms employing 44,000 in southwest England, industry executives like Greene remain confident: "These things take time, but contracts will come, allowing us to invest in technology and more people."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Labour's Dilemma: Why Abbott Suspension Was Unavoidable
fields.summary: The Labour Party faced limited options in reinstating its suspension of veteran MP Diane Abbott after she declined to express regret over controversial remarks made in 2023, as leadership sought consistency in enforcing antisemitism policies.
fields.content:
Political parties continually confront difficult decisions, often constrained by the need for consistency in their actions. This principle underlies the current situation involving Diane Abbott and Labour's disciplinary measures.

Diane Abbott holds a significant place in British political history as the first Black woman elected to the House of Commons in 1987, now serving as its longest-tenured female member. The controversy traces back to April 2023 when Abbott wrote a letter to The Observer newspaper.

The Controversial 2023 Letter

In her published remarks, Abbott stated: "Irish, Jewish and Traveller people undoubtedly experience prejudice. This is similar to racism. It is true that many types of white people with points of difference, such as redheads, can experience this prejudice. But they are not all their lives subject to racism." This appeared to equate antisemitism with discrimination against red-haired individuals.

Following widespread criticism, Abbott withdrew her comments and issued an apology. The Labour Party subsequently suspended her parliamentary membership, forcing her to serve as an independent MP until her reinstatement before last year's general election.

Diane Abbott pictured wearing a black jacket and jumper on a BBC set.

Abdication of Regret

A radio interview recorded in May 2025, but broadcast this week, proved pivotal when Abbott was asked if she regretted the letter controversy. She responded: "No, not at all." She elaborated that racism is fundamentally tied to skin color, arguing that antisemitism differs because Jewish identity isn't always visibly apparent.

Although Abbott's language has evolved since 2023 - now classifying antisemitism as racism rather than prejudice - her refusal to regret the original remarks created a decisive challenge. By not disavowing the statements that initially triggered her suspension, she left Labour leadership with little alternative.

Sir Keir Starmer speaking at a podium with Union Jack flags behind him.

Labour's Historical Context

This decision occurs against Labour's troubled history with antisemitism. During Jeremy Corbyn's leadership, the party was found responsible for three breaches of the Equality Act. Current leader Keir Starmer pledged to "tear out this poison by its roots" upon taking office.

Abbott responded to her suspension stating: "It is obvious this Labour leadership wants me out. My comments in the interview were factually correct, as any fair minded person would accept." She now serves as an independent MP amid reports that her political ally Jeremy Corbyn is establishing a new left-wing party.

Diane Abbott speaking at a protest rally.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Reports Birth of Eight Healthy Babies Using Three-Person DNA Technique
fields.summary: Eight babies have been born in the UK using a pioneering reproductive technique that combines genetic material from three people to prevent incurable mitochondrial diseases, with all infants developing normally and free of the hereditary conditions.
fields.content:
British doctors have announced the birth of eight babies through an innovative technique using DNA from three individuals. This approach prevents devastating mitochondrial diseases, often fatal disorders passed from mother to child that cause severe energy deficiency throughout the body.

The method, legal in the UK for a decade but now proven effective, involves combining eggs from the biological mother and a donor, then fertilizing with the father's sperm. Children created through this process retain approximately 99.9% of their parents' DNA while acquiring healthy mitochondria from the donor—about 0.1% of their genetic blueprint.

Overwhelmed with gratitude

Families benefiting from the treatment anonymously expressed profound relief through Newcastle Fertility Centre. "After years of uncertainty this treatment gave us hope - and then it gave us our baby," stated one mother. Another parent shared: "The emotional burden of mitochondrial disease has been lifted, and in its place is hope, joy, and deep gratitude."

Graphic showing embryo DNA transfer process to replace defective mitochondria

Mitochondria act as cellular power generators, converting food into energy. Defective mitochondria can cause organ failure, seizures, blindness, and infant mortality within days of birth, affecting roughly 1 in 5,000 newborns. In the groundbreaking procedure developed by Newcastle University scientists:

• Both parents' eggs and sperm are fertilized alongside a donor's eggs
• The parental DNA structures (pro-nuclei) are transferred to the donor embryo
• The resulting embryo contains healthy mitochondria for normal development

Medical reports confirm all eight children—four boys and four girls including twins—show no signs of mitochondrial disease. One case of temporary epilepsy resolved spontaneously, while another child's treatable heart rhythm issue exists, though neither appears linked to the technique. Residual defective mitochondria were detected in three babies but remain below disease-causing thresholds.

Getty Images Early stage embryo composed of spherical cells

The breakthrough offers hope to families like the Kittos, whose 14-year-old daughter Poppy suffers severe mitochondrial disability. Her sister Lily now has hope for future generations: "It's the future generations like myself that can have that outlook of a normal life." Newcastle specialists anticipate 20-30 such births annually as demand grows.

Only the UK could do this

As the first country to legislate this approach (2015), the UK enabled a permanent genetic change passed through generations. While initially controversial over designer baby concerns, the NHS-backed program has achieved a landmark medical milestone. Professor Sir Doug Turnbull hailed the achievement: "What a wonderful result."

Getty Images Artistic representation of mitochondria

Scientists emphasize continued research to refine the technique, as mitochondrial disease currently lacks a cure. Liz Curtis of the Lily Foundation reflected: "For many affected families, it's the first real hope of breaking the cycle."

BBC/Josh Elgin Kat Kitto with her daughter Lily, feeding their dog

Source: Original Article

fields.title: School hires remote teacher 300 miles away for maths lessons
fields.summary: A Lancashire secondary school will have maths taught remotely by a teacher in Devon from September, sparking opposition from teachers' unions over the digital instruction model for students aged 13-16.
fields.content:
Students at The Valley Leadership Academy in Bacup, Lancashire will soon receive mathematics instruction from a teacher situated 300 miles away in Devon. The remotely delivered lessons will begin in September for high-achieving students in years 9 through 11.

Parents received notification of this "exciting initiative" where specialized virtual instruction will be paired with in-classroom support from a qualified local maths teacher. School administrators described the program as a "carefully considered initiative" addressing staff recruitment difficulties while aiming to improve educational access standards.

The National Education Union (NEU) announced plans to challenge this approach, initially expressing concerns that only teaching assistants might provide classroom support. The school later clarified a qualified teacher would always be present to handle academic, behavioral, and pastoral needs despite the remote teaching setup.

An indicative union ballot showed unanimous support for potential strike action among members, according to the Local Democracy Reporting Service. The academy stated it maintains ongoing collaboration with professional associations regarding the program.

National Education Union members waving flags during a protest

'Dumbing down'

Executive Principal Colette Roberts characterized the virtual teaching approach in parent communications as "an exciting initiative and significant investment" merging edtech benefits with classroom support. Students will reportedly use specialized laptops and headsets during lessons.

Ian Watkinson, Lancashire NEU branch secretary, strongly criticized the initiative as "dystopian," asserting permanent digital instruction deprives students of essential pastoral support. "You just can't dynamically respond as a teacher if you're on a screen in Devon," Watkinson stated.

He further condemned the model as "dumbing down, cutting corners" educationally, adding that employing a qualified support teacher alongside the remote instructor renders the system economically questionable. The academy confirmed the program actually costs more than traditional staffing but represents an intentional investment in educational equity.

'Difficult recruitment'

A school spokesperson explained the strategy targets "exceptional circumstances where recruitment challenges prevent securing high-quality, subject-specific teachers." Educational content will originate from "outstanding, fully qualified teachers" conducting live interactive sessions remotely.

The program aims to expand access to excellent teaching resources for disadvantaged communities while retaining skilled educators who might otherwise leave due to personal circumstances. The academy emphasized this remains a small-scale solution applied selectively when ideal local staffing proves impossible.

Regarding possible strikes, Watkinson clarified that any industrial action would follow a formal union vote and occur only as a "last resort" measure if negotiations prove unsuccessful.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Sycamore Gap tree felling sparks call for UK woodland protection laws
fields.summary: The illegal felling of the famous Sycamore Gap tree has ignited debates about legal protections for UK woodlands, revealing a nation both devoted to trees yet facing severe nature depletion with only 13% forest cover and minimal safeguards for ancient trees.
fields.content:
James Canton observed an 800-year-old oak tree near his Essex home for two years, studying how acorns formed and butterflies landed on its aged trunk. The University of Essex lecturer describes this experience as fostering a profound connection to nature, inspiring his book 'The Oak Papers'.

This reflection comes as Britain confronts its complex relationship with woodlands. Millennia ago, untouched forests covered about 75% of the UK, but today's landscape tells a different story.

The cutting down of the Sycamore Gap tree beside Hadrian's Wall has amplified concerns about tree protection gaps. Two individuals face sentencing for this act of 'mindless destruction' that Canton terms 'symbolic'.

BBC A treated image of the Sycamore Gap Tree

PA Media The Sycamore Gap tree which was illegally felled

Environmentalists argue this incident highlights the urgent need for enhanced tree safeguards. While not ancient or native, the Sycamore Gap tree gained global fame for its striking location, drawing visitors for proposals, memorials, and solace during lockdowns.

Despite apparent public affection for trees, the UK ranks among Earth's most nature-depleted countries. Its woodland covers just 13%, drastically lower than Europe’s 38% average, according to Swansea University's Professor Mary Gagen.

UK's 'odd relationship' with trees

The UK's woodland dynamics appear contradictory. Although recent planting reached 20,700 hectares in 2023-24, it dropped to 15,700 hectares by March 2025 - far below the 30,000-hectare annual target. Alarmingly, only 7% of existing woodland is ecologically healthy.

Professor Gagen observes an 'odd relationship' of 'simultaneously adoring and denuding woodlands'. Andrew Allen from the Woodland Trust warns neglecting existing trees risks serious ecological consequences.

Northumbria Police Handout photos issued by Northumbria Police of Daniel Graham, 39, (left) and Adam Carruthers, 32

Mike Kemp via Getty Images Bucknell Wood ancient woodland in mist and sunlight

'Why would a tree older than Stonehenge go unprotected?'

Most ancient UK trees - vital habitats for hundreds of species - lack automatic protection, unlike heritage trees in Italy and Poland. Tree Preservation Orders and nature reserves cover only one-fifth of veteran trees, reveals Professor Gagen.

Organisations like The Tree Council advocate legislation to protect culturally and ecologically important trees, featuring statutory listing and fines up to £433,000. They argue beloved landmarks like Sycamore Gap demonstrate society's valuation of arboreal heritage.

PA Media The Northern Lights, or Aurora Borealis, shining over the Sycamore Gap

PA Media People gather around the stump of the Sycamore Gap tree in Northumberland National Park

Jon Stokes from The Tree Council questions why yew trees older than Stonehenge remain vulnerable. He stresses: 'We should be looking after them better than we are at the moment.' Government assessment of protective measures is ongoing.

'You can't stop reckless acts'

Legal reforms alone may not prevent incidents like the Sycamore Gap felling, which involved trespass. Sarah Dodd, a tree law specialist, notes: 'You can't stop some people doing reckless acts.'

Instead, she suggests elevating public appreciation of trees' value. Stokes adds that preserving old trees while planting new ones nearby enables biodiversity flow - vital since Woodland Trust reports concerning woodland health.

Dame Judi Dench is presented with a seedling from the Sycamore Gap tree

Difficult choices ahead

Professor Gagen contends conserving woodlands requires society prioritizing nature over housing or transport. Calculating trees' economic contributions - carbon storage, flood prevention, pollination - might shift perspectives.

Canton continues restoring neglected forests and hopes Sycamore Gap's loss leads to legal rights for century-old trees. He believes society is gradually realigning with nature: 'We're happier sat in an oak tree... involved and immersed in that natural world.'

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Video Games Industry Faces Class Diversity Challenge
fields.summary: Industry leaders warn of class barriers limiting social mobility in the UK video games sector, with a new report revealing only 13% of workers come from low-income backgrounds despite substantial talent pipeline from educational programs.
fields.content:
Chris Goodyear, a producer focused on accessibility barriers, voices concern about the future exclusivity of games: "I'm scared for the future of games. It could end up going the way that theatre has, and become a very privileged thing."

The class diversity crisis took center stage at Develop:Brighton, one of the UK's largest game developer conferences, which hosted its inaugural meet-up for working-class and low-income industry professionals this year.

The event was organized by non-profit Into Games, established six years ago by Declan Cassidy to support underrepresented groups. Cassidy explained their focus narrowed to social mobility after recognizing it had no other dedicated advocates in the sector.

A 2024 report from Into Games revealed a troubling pattern: while educational pathways attract high numbers from working-class backgrounds, most fail to secure industry jobs. "They're being failed at the last hurdle," Cassidy stated.

Crowd at Develop:Brighton expo with Indie Showcase banner

The study identified critical barriers including geographical limitations, financial constraints, cultural capital gaps, and lack of professional networks. 59% of surveyed participants reported feeling socially excluded during their career.

Will Luton, founder of Village Studio Games, described experiencing "overt discrimination" and feeling compelled to modify his speech patterns. He emphasized that successful individuals must proactively address systemic issues rather than claim the problem is solved.

Compared to film/TV (29%) and music/visual arts (22%), the games sector has the lowest representation of those from lower socio-economic backgrounds at just 13%. Ukie industry body head Nick Poole noted that while talent exists, opportunities remain limited: "People who are young, gifted and broke need to be able to find their way into the industry."

'Huge' benefits for studios

Despite recent mass layoffs across the global industry, Into Games plans a five-year initiative across six UK regions - Birmingham, Brighton, Dundee, London, Manchester and Tees Valley.

The program includes school outreach, paid internships, and government-subsidized training, with over 100 studios committed to hiring through the scheme during 2025-2026.

Cassidy announced an ambitious target: "By 2030, our aim is to be increasing the number of people from working-class backgrounds in the UK games industry by a factor of 50%." He emphasized that greater diversity offers "huge" advantages for development studios seeking fresh perspectives.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Iconic Citizen Kane 'Rosebud' Sled Sells for Record $14.75 Million at Auction
fields.summary: A legendary prop from Citizen Kane considered one of cinema's most iconic artifacts - the Rosebud sled - has sold for $14.75 million at auction after being rescued from destruction decades ago, becoming the second most valuable piece of movie memorabilia ever sold.
fields.content:
The Legendary Rosebud Sled

The wooden sled featured in the celebrated opening scene of Citizen Kane, considered among cinema's greatest masterpieces, achieved a record $14.75 million (£11m) at auction. Known as "Rosebud," the prop is one of only three surviving examples and was presumed lost until its dramatic rediscovery in 1984.

Director Joe Dante rescued it from destruction when a studio worker presented it to him while clearing storage facilities formerly owned by RKO Radio Pictures, the original producers of Orson Welles' 1941 classic. Dante subsequently incorporated the sled as a hidden tribute in his own films like Gremlins 2: The New Batch.

Getty Images Young Charles Foster Kane (Buddy Swan) shakes hands with Walter Parks Thatcher (George Coulouris) as his parents (Harry Shannon and Agnes Moorehead) watch in Citizen Kane

This sale establishes the sled as the second most expensive piece of movie memorabilia ever sold, surpassed only by the ruby slippers from The Wizard of Oz which fetched $32m in December. Joe Maddalena, Heritage Auctions executive vice president, emphasized its significance: "Along with Dorothy's ruby slippers, the Rosebud sled from Citizen Kane is one of the most iconic objects in Hollywood history."

While other Rosebud sleds exist—including one gifted to the Academy Museum by Steven Spielberg—this particular version had vanished for decades until Dante saved it. The identity of its new owner remains undisclosed following Thursday's record-breaking sale.

Additional Auction Highlights

Silver items including a plate, jug, and three cups, against a dark background.

Michael Baggott's collection of York silver, potentially the most comprehensive assembly ever sold at auction, attracted significant attention among collectors.

A grey-coloured Mars rock sits on podium

A Martian meteorite discovered in Niger during November 2023, noted as being 70% larger than any other known Mars rock on Earth, was offered alongside other rare items.

A painting by Graham Clarke. It shows a number of block-coloured trees next to houses and a path.

Artwork by Graham Clarke valued at approximately £45,700, found abandoned in the basement of Kent's County Hall, went under the hammer during the same auction event.

Graham Greaves is standing to the right of the white lab coat which is on a stand. He is wearing a pink shirt and black trousers. There is a man on the right wearing a light blue shirt.

A historic white laboratory coat purchased by collector Graham Greaves from North Tyneside represented another notable acquisition. Greaves explained his motivation as seeking tangible connections to history.

Martin sitting in front of a shelving unit full of vinyl records. He has a long black beard, arm tattoos and black hair, and is pulling a metal music hand gesture

Martin Hughes noted the renewed market interest in vinyl records during the event, highlighting their enduring appeal among enthusiasts.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Russia Warns of Preemptive Strikes as NATO Accelerates Patriot Missile Deliveries
fields.summary: Russian Security Council Deputy Chairman Dmitry Medvedev warned that Moscow might conduct preemptive strikes against Western targets while NATO prioritizes rushing Patriot missile systems to Ukraine. The threats coincide with Donald Trump's announcement of new tariffs on Russian oil buyers and weapons transfers that Germany claims it hasn't authorized.
fields.content:
Russian Security Council Deputy Chairman Dmitry Medvedev has raised the prospect of preemptive military action against Western nations. "The statements of Western politicians on this topic are complete nonsense," he declared in an interview with state media. "We need to act accordingly... launch preemptive strikes if necessary." These remarks come amid heightened NATO efforts to bolster Ukraine's defenses.

Former U.S. President Donald Trump announced plans for a weapons transfer program where Patriot missiles would be routed to Ukraine through Germany. "They're already being shipped from Germany, replaced by Germany, and the U.S. gets paid back," Trump stated. However, German defense officials contradicted this claim, stating they had "no knowledge" of any such shipments occurring.

Patriot air defense missile system

Switzerland confirmed delays in receiving five U.S.-purchased Patriot systems as Washington prioritizes Ukraine. The Swiss Defense Ministry stated, "The United States Department of Defense will reprioritize delivery to support Ukraine's ground-based air defense." Clarifications about the impact on Switzerland's security arrangements are ongoing.

Medvedev framed the Western response as tantamount to direct warfare: "What's happening is a proxy war, but in essence a full-scale war—with Western missiles, satellite intelligence, sanctions, and militarization." He argued these actions justify Moscow's consideration of preventive military measures against NATO states.

Ukraine defends itself against Russia's deadly assault.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy expressed concern about Trump's proposal giving Russia a 50-day ultimatum for peace negotiations before imposing 100% tariffs on buyers of Russian oil. "Every day is scary. Fifty days means more human losses," Zelenskyy emphasized. He urged faster U.S. action, pledging to provide Washington "more arguments for strong sanctions against Russia." Kremlin officials have remained silent on Trump's sanctions deadline.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: GOP Targets Swing District Democrats Over Ties to NYC Socialist Mayoral Nominee
fields.summary: Republicans are launching ad campaigns linking vulnerable Democratic lawmakers to New York City mayoral nominee Zohran Mamdani, highlighting his socialist policies including fare-free transit and Netanyahu arrest proposals, while Democrats argue the strategy misrepresents ideological differences in swing districts.
fields.content:
The National Republican Congressional Committee unveiled digital advertisements targeting four Democratic representatives, attempting to tie them to Zohran Mamdani, New York City's socialist mayoral nominee. Mamdani recently won the Democratic primary, positioning him to potentially become NYC's first Muslim and millennial mayor.

Republican Campaign Strategy

Ads focus on Democratic Representatives Tom Suozzi, Laura Gillen, and Josh Riley of New York along with New Jersey's Nellie Pou, all representing competitive districts. NRCC spokeswoman Maureen O'Toole stated: "Dangerous Socialist Zohran Mamdani is the new face of Tom Suozzi, Laura Gillen, Josh Riley, and Nellie Pou's Democrat Party." The campaign highlights Mamdani's proposals for eliminating bus fares, tuition-free college, rent controls, and government-run grocery stores.

New York City Democratic Party mayoral nominee Zohran Mamdani is surrounded by supporters after a press conference with union leaders in New York City, on July 2, 2025.

Republicans have amplified viral content including a 2020 photo of Mamdani gesturing at a Christopher Columbus statue, his December statement about arresting Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, and his recent comment: "I have many critiques of capitalism." Suozzi responded he "wholeheartedly" disagrees with parts of Mamdani's agenda, while Gillen called him "too extreme" to lead NYC.

Democratic Response and Wider Impact

Democrats counter that the GOP strategy conflates New York City's overwhelmingly Democratic electorate with suburban swing districts. Tennessee Democrat Steve Cohen noted: "I love New York, but it's a very liberal place, and I don't know that you can necessarily apply that to the rest of the country."

New digital ads by the National Republican Congressional Committee aim to anchor New York City mayoral nominee Zohran Mamdani to Democratic Representatives in swing districts

In New Hampshire's 2026 Senate race, Republican Scott Brown launched ads linking Democratic candidate Chris Pappas to Mamdani and Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. Pappas responded: "People know me. They know the work that I've been doing. I'm one of the most bipartisan members of the House." Riley and Pou have faced criticism for not publicly commenting on Mamdani, with the NRCC accusing Pou of failing to "call out" the nominee.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Glowing Deep-Sea Nudibranch Discovered in Ocean's Midnight Zone
fields.summary: Scientists have identified Bathydevius caudactylus, a groundbreaking bioluminescent sea slug thriving in the ocean's midnight zone up to 13,100 feet deep. This newly classified nudibranch exhibits extraordinary adaptations including transparent camouflage and glowing predator defenses.
fields.content:
A Devious Deep-Sea Discovery

The Monterey Bay Aquarium Research Institute revealed Bathydevius caudactylus, nicknamed the "mystery mollusk" for its unique characteristics distinguishing it from known species. Its genus name references the creature's "devious" nature that long evaded scientific classification. This marks the first nudibranch—a type of sea slug—confirmed to inhabit deep ocean environments.

Life in Extreme Depths

Residing between 1,000 and 4,000 meters (3,300-13,100 feet) in the lightless midnight zone, this gelatinous species features a transparent hood and paddle-like tail. Bioluminescence allows it to glow, a crucial trait for survival in perpetual darkness. MBARI Senior Scientist Bruce Robison noted: "We've invested over 20 years understanding this fascinating species. Our discovery helps unravel Earth's largest habitat."

bathydevius caudactylus

Remarkable Survival Adaptations

The slug employs specialized hunting tactics, using its expansive hood to trap crustaceans "like a Venus flytrap." Its transparent body provides camouflage, though when threatened, it deploys bioluminescent defenses. Researchers observed it detaching "a steadily glowing finger-like projection from the tail" as a decoy to distract predators—an evolutionary response documented in few deep-sea creatures.

bathydevius caudactylus

Reproduction and Research Breakthroughs

Like other nudibranchs, Bathydevius is hermaphroditic, possessing both male and female reproductive organs. It anchors to the seabed with a muscular foot before spawning. Advanced underwater technology enabled this comprehensive study, with Senior Scientist Steven Haddock emphasizing: "A large, unique glowing animal in a previously unknown family underscores the value of new technology for exploring vast deep-sea environments." The findings illuminate how much remains undiscovered in ocean depths exceeding 2,000 meters.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: The 5R Approach: Experts Unveil Comprehensive Gut Health Strategy
fields.summary: Medical experts propose a five-step "5R" methodology to enhance gut health, strengthen immunity, and reduce inflammation. This functional medicine strategy addresses digestive issues through systematic removal of toxins, enzyme replenishment, microbiome restoration, gut lining repair, and lifestyle rebalancing, with reported benefits including improved energy and reduced bloating.
fields.content:
A healthier digestive system may be achieved through a structured five-step plan known as the 5R approach. Developed by the Institute for Functional Medicine, this strategy targets gut restoration to alleviate conditions like irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) and autoimmune disorders while boosting immunity.

Dr. Sydne Ford-Norton, a family medicine specialist and clinic co-founder in Atlanta, reports patients experience reduced bloating, better bowel movements, and increased energy within weeks of starting the regimen. The method addresses how poor diet, medications, and environmental factors disrupt the microbial balance crucial for overall health.

The gut-health connection

Disruptions to the gut microbiome can trigger symptoms ranging from gas and abdominal discomfort to joint pain and chronic inflammation. Physicians explain that damaged gut linings may 'leak' undigested particles into the bloodstream, prompting inflammatory responses.

"The gastrointestinal tract contains approximately 80% of the body's immune tissue and produces about 85% of its neurotransmitters," noted Dr. Alan Weiss, medical director at Annapolis Integrative Medicine. Dr. Joel Evans from the Institute for Functional Medicine added, "Gut issues frequently lead to immune system complications that can progress to autoimmune conditions."

Man holding stomach and chest

Dr. Jesús M. Luévano, gastroenterologist at the American Gastroenterological Association, emphasized diet's critical role: "Nutrition impacts cellular health and microbiome balance. Avoiding inflammatory agents like fried foods, alcohol, and ultraprocessed items is fundamental for gut integrity."

Unpacking the 5R methodology

The systematic approach consists of five consecutive steps to rebuild digestive wellness:

Remove triggers like gluten, dairy, refined sugars, and processed foods through elimination diets or sensitivity testing.

Replace deficient digestive enzymes, vitamins, and minerals. "Many individuals lack essential enzymes for proper nutrient absorption," Ford-Norton explained.

Nutritious meal components

Reinoculate with probiotic cultures and prebiotic fibers. Ford-Norton advocates obtaining these from natural sources like kimchi, sauerkraut, and fiber-rich produce rather than relying solely on supplements.

Individual using probiotic supplement

Repair the intestinal lining using omega-3 fatty acids, L-glutamine amino acids, zinc supplements, and anti-inflammatory agents like aloe vera. Physicians advise consuming omega-3-rich foods such as walnuts and chia seeds, while consulting professionals to prevent supplement interactions.

Dietary supplements for gut health

Rebalance through stress reduction and sleep optimization. "This crucial element is often neglected," Ford-Norton stressed, recommending 7-9 hours of nightly rest plus mindfulness practices like meditation and yoga to regulate the gut-brain axis.

Implementation insights

Ford-Norton warns against skipping any phase: "Incomplete execution, like eliminating foods without reinoculation, yields suboptimal results." Both she and Evans observed symptom improvements and occasional chronic disease reversals in compliant patients.

Patient consulting physician

Experts unanimously advise professional supervision when implementing the framework. Weiss emphasized the necessity of medical evaluation to exclude underlying infections or conditions before beginning gut restoration procedures.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Florida Beach Bans Deep Sand Digging After Near-Fatal Incident
fields.summary: Holmes Beach in Florida has imposed new restrictions banning deep sand holes after a near-tragic incident and rising concerns for beachgoer safety and wildlife protection. The ordinance prohibits holes deeper than one foot and bans metal shovels while allowing children's plastic sand toys.
fields.content:
As summer beach season draws crowds to coastal destinations, one Florida vacation spot is prohibiting an iconic seaside activity. Holmes Beach has introduced a strict rule against digging deep cavities in its sandy shores following a dangerous near-miss incident. City officials formalized the ordinance this summer with a clear directive: "No holes on beach."

According to City Commissioner Carol Whitmore, these measures address critical safety risks. "People aren't listening. They're on vacation, not thinking about consequences," she explained. "We must prioritize the safety of everyone who visits after them and protect our delicate wildlife." The regulation specifically prohibits holes exceeding one foot in depth and bans metal shovels or gardening tools, while plastic children's toys remain permitted.

Uncovered deep hole on a Florida beach

The urgency stems partly from a 2024 tragedy in Lauderdale-by-the-Sea where a young girl died after collapsing sand buried her in a six-foot hole. Nearly 143 million people visited Florida beaches last year, amplifying hazards created by unattended excavations. "We almost had someone fall into a gigantic uncovered hole ourselves," Whitmore emphasized.

Impact Beyond Human Safety

Beyond human dangers, uncovered sand pits threaten sea turtle populations that nest along Florida shores. Deep cavities frequently trap turtles that cannot climb out to survive. "We've documented turtles stuck in 3-6 foot holes left behind," said Whitmore. "They cannot escape when holes remain unfilled."

Children's sand toys on the beach

Beachgoer Waylon Slabach demonstrated responsible practices at Manatee Public Beach, where he brings his daughter. "We love letting her dig and play," he noted. "But we always fill every hole before leaving—it's an easy way to protect turtles." The National Ocean Service concurs, officially advising visitors to fill sand holes to help sea turtles safely nest.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Teen Cyclist Samuele Privitera Killed in Croatian Race Crash
fields.summary: 19-year-old Italian cycling prospect Samuele Privitera died after hitting a speed bump during a descent in the Tour of Valle D'Aosta, sustaining critical head injuries, with the incident prompting tributes from top riders and urgent safety discussions within cycling authorities.
fields.content:
Cycling mourns the loss of Samuele Privitera, a 19-year-old Italian competitor who succumbed to injuries after a devastating crash during the opening stage of the Tour of Valle D'Aosta. The accident occurred on Wednesday approximately 35 kilometers from the finish line in Croatia, where Privitera reportedly struck a speed bump at nearly 70 kilometers per hour, lost control of his bicycle, and hit his head against a barrier, with reports indicating his helmet came off during the impact.

Hagens Berman Jayco team member Privitera was racing on a speedy descent when the collision happened. Race organizers have stated that the exact circumstances remain "still unclear and are being investigated by public safety authorities," raising concerns about event protocols. The team's director, Axel Merckx, released an emotional statement reflecting on the young cyclist's vigorous spirit.

"Samuele was and always will be the life and personality of this team," declared Merckx, honoring his rider. "This team has always been a small family, and moments like this are unimaginable. He was irreplaceable. His joy, his spirit, his kindness was always a bright light to whatever room or race that he was in at that moment. To lose him is devastating beyond words."

Tributes From the Cycling World

The Tour de France riders paused to recognize Privitera during their event, observing a minute-long applause in the 12th stage on Thursday. Tadej Pogačar, a pre-race favorite, expressed his sorrow beforehand: "It’s really sad to lose another young talent today. It’s devastating. It is one of the most dangerous sports in the world, I think, and the risk that we are taking sometimes is too far. But I’m really really really sad for all his family. May he rest in peace."

Racers mourn Samuele Privitera

In response to the incident, the Tour of Valle D'Aosta was temporarily suspended on Thursday, with plans to resume competition on Friday.

Cordiano Dagnoni, President of the Italian Cycling Federation, highlighted the critical need for racing improvements: "This news leaves us shocked and forces us to think even more decisively about how to make our races safer." He referenced an existing safety commission, adding, "We constantly update the regulations every year to ensure such incidents never happen again. We must intensify our efforts in this direction. It is an obligation we owe first and foremost to our young people, to our clubs and to our entire movement." A moment of silence was marked during the event.

Ben O'Connor wears a mourning band

Source: Original Article

fields.title: 8 Top American Skincare Brands to Beat Tariff Price Hikes
fields.summary: As potential tariffs threaten imported skincare prices, a grooming editor recommends eight entirely US-made brands across budget to premium tiers, detailing selection criteria including manufacturing location, specialty focus, and value across price points.
fields.content:
Amid shifting trade policies that could increase costs for imported skincare, opting for entirely US-made products offers price stability. These editor-approved brands manufacture everything domestically, protecting your skincare routine from tariff-related price hikes.

Best American-Made Skincare Brands

Popular skincare lines like Medik8, Horace, and Aesop face potential tariff impacts since they're overseas-based. Though unclear when price increases might occur, switching to US-manufactured alternatives safeguards your budget. Luckily, numerous American brands handle both headquarters and production stateside.

The key distinguisher: brands must manufacture domestically, not just maintain US headquarters. For those needing recommendations, the following list highlights reliable American-made options tested across all skincare categories.

What to Consider

Verifying manufacturing location is crucial—some US-based brands produce overseas. This list confirms each company creates products domestically, even if facilities are in different states.

Brand specialization matters when choosing. Companies excel in specific categories: Baxter of California offers top facial scrubs, while Bravo Sierra dominates deodorants. Focusing on a brand’s expertise typically yields better results in your priority areas.

Budget options provide fundamental benefits without complexity. Examples include Marlowe’s $14 cleanser, effective across skin types but without specialized features. Even basic formulas can deliver reliable performance.

Mid-range products ($25-$50) feature targeted ingredients for specific concerns. Atwater’s $32 Eye Armor combats wrinkles and puffiness, while Brickell’s $40 anti-aging serum outperforms budget alternatives with enhanced formulations for better hydration and skin support.

Premium skincare ($50+) falls into two categories: value-sized essentials or advanced formulas with luxury textures. Products like Dr Dennis Gross’s $70+ wrinkle cream demonstrate clinically-proven ingredients that visibly improve firmness and radiance, making the investment worthwhile for noticeable improvements.

How We Selected

As a grooming editor constantly testing new releases across 50+ brands, selections derive from rigorously evaluated moisturizers, serums, creams, and cleansers. Brands appearing frequently in long-term testing and roundups were prioritized.

Input from fellow writers supplemented the selection. Criteria focused on consistent effectiveness and lasting quality across entire product lines, narrowing down to eight reliable American-made skincare brands.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Serolod Unveils Vibrant Universe in 'Reality is Relative' Exhibition
fields.summary: Greek-born, London-based artist Serolod presents her exhibition 'Reality is Relative' exploring perception through digitally altered paintings, cosmic inspiration, and the interplay of complementary colors at Almine Rech London.
fields.content:
Published on July 14, 2025

Born in Greece and currently based in London, Serolod creates artworks probing perception's fluidity, color dynamics, and the fusion of contemporary with traditional techniques. She begins with digitally manipulated imagery, later transforming it through paint to achieve a balance of control and spontaneity.

"A key aspect of my work is the exploration of duality and interconnectedness. My palette uses 'negative' or complementary colors—opposites of natural hues. By highlighting these overlooked tones, I challenge perception and reality, revealing how subjective our understanding is. This inversion urges viewers to envision beyond the visible, suggesting unseen dimensions of existence," Serolod explains.

Einstein's theory of general relativity inspires Serolod's cosmic vision: her paintings illustrate how microscopic particles and galactic structures interconnect. She portrays reality as a dynamic, living network in flux. Her exhibition "Reality is Relative" remains at Almine Rech London through July 26.

Serolod’s Website: https://www.serolodart.com

Serolod on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/sero.lod

Source: Original Article

fields.title: ADAA Cancels 2025 Art Show, Declaring 'Strategic Pause'
fields.summary: The Art Dealers Association of America has canceled its flagship 2025 Art Show at New York's Park Avenue Armory, marking the first hiatus in decades as leadership cites a strategic reassessment amidst industry-wide instability.
fields.content:
The Art Dealers Association of America has canceled its 2025 flagship fair, The Art Show, ending its decades-long run at New York's Park Avenue Armory. Leadership announced the decision in a member email obtained by sources, describing it as a "strategic pause" following careful review. The fair was slated to begin with a benefit preview on October 28.

"While we understand this news may be disappointing, we believe this pause presents a meaningful opportunity to reimagine The Art Show with long-term sustainability and member value in mind," stated the email. ADAA emphasized the break would allow evaluation of how best to support the arts community amid shifting market conditions.

This cancellation signals broader instability across the art industry. Two prominent dealers - Tim Blum and Adam Lindemann - recently announced gallery closures, while advisors Barbara Guggenheim and Abigail Asher have taken an internal dispute to court. The ADAA's move lends institutional weight to these retrenchments.

Since its 1988 inception, The Art Show served as a key Upper East Side gathering for collectors and dealers. Its gala preview raised over $38 million for social service nonprofit Henry Street Settlement across three decades. Exhibitors who submitted deposits will receive reimbursement information next week.

ADAA confirmed plans to revive the fair in 2026 with a "renewed vision," but the 2025 absence intensifies concerns about the art market's volatility.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ukraine Gamifies Warfare with Points-Based Drone Strike Rewards
fields.summary: Ukraine's military has launched a 'gamified' reward program where frontline units earn points for eliminating Russian soldiers and equipment through drone strikes. The "Army of Drones: Bonus" initiative offers tangible incentives while collecting critical battlefield data, though soldier reactions remain divided on its effectiveness for morale.
fields.content:
Thousands of daily images capture Russian troops and hardware being hunted along Ukraine's extensive front lines. Each encounter is filmed, documented, and systematically counted as part of Ukraine's strategy to maximize advantages against a larger adversary.

The military's "Army of Drones: Bonus" program, known as e-points, allows units to accumulate rewards for every verified elimination. Similar to video game mechanics, points translate to supplies - with higher-value targets yielding greater returns.

"The more strategically important and large-scale the target, the more points a unit receives," explained the Brave 1 defense coordination team. Destroying rocket launchers earns 50 points, tanks 40 points when destroyed (20 if damaged), while individual soldiers yield 6 points each.

Military personnel analyzing drone footage in Ukraine

Digital Transformation Minister Mykhailo Fedorov, architect of the system, stated: "I think, first and foremost, it's about quality data, the mathematics of war, and understanding how to use limited resources more effectively." His office features a massive screen displaying live drone feeds, now allegedly responsible for 70% of Russian casualties.

After 42 months of conflict, Fedorov acknowledges dual purposes: "It's also about motivation. When we change the point values, we can see how motivation changes."

Screen displaying military equipment marketplace interface

Mixed Reactions on the Frontline

Responses from over a dozen units reveal starkly different perspectives. Volodymyr of the 108th Territorial Defence Brigade noted: "This is a way to make up for what we lose while inflicting losses effectively." Soldiers expend drones at rapid rates, requiring constant replenishment.

Jack from the 22nd Mechanised Brigade observed: "Our lads are worn out... but this system helps. The drones are provided, and lads get rewarded."

However, other soldiers question its impact. Fighter "Snake" contended: "The fundamental issue of motivation isn't resolved by points; they won't stop people fleeing." Comrade Dymytro expressed ethical concerns: "This system comes from our twisted habit of turning everything into profit, even our own damned death," citing potential issues like false claims and duplicated strikes.

Weary Ukrainian soldiers resting near military vehicle

Evolving Tactics and Rewards

Analysts in a secure Kyiv facility verify thousands of strikes daily. "We categorize targets as hit or destroyed," explained Volodia, adding capturing soldiers yields far greater points (10x kill value) due to prisoner-exchange potential.

Tactics adapt with Russian battlefield changes. Since Moscow deployed more small reconnaissance units, individual soldiers' point values tripled from 2 to 6. Drone operators carry heightened priority over equipment.

Ukraine's Digital Minister reviewing drone operations

The system links directly to the Brave 1 Market - described as "Amazon for war" - where units exchange accumulated points among 1,600 items. This supplements traditional procurement, offering rapid access to drones, components, and unmanned vehicles for frontline evacuation.

Fedorov confirms 90-95% unit participation, enabling data-driven decisions: "The foundation is always military strategy." Despite ethical concerns, Ukraine prioritizes innovative efficiency in its defense campaign.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump Diagnosed with Vein Condition as White House Explains Hand Bruising
fields.summary: The White House confirmed Donald Trump has chronic venous insufficiency after photos of bruising sparked public concern, explaining the condition causes leg swelling while hand bruises stemmed from frequent handshaking while taking aspirin. Medical experts characterize the vein problem as common and benign for older individuals.
fields.content:
The White House announced Donald Trump suffers from chronic venous insufficiency following scrutiny over photographs revealing bruises on the US president's hand. Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt stated a recent comprehensive vascular examination was conducted after Trump experienced leg swelling.

Oldest US president ever inaugurated

A medical report released by White House physician Sean Barbabella confirmed Trump has no deep vein thrombosis, arterial disease, heart failure or other systemic illnesses. All test results fell within normal parameters despite Trump being the oldest president inaugurated at 78 years and seven months when sworn into his second term this January. Barbabella asserted the president remains in "excellent health."

Concerns emerged after photos from July 13 showed Trump's swollen legs during a soccer match, followed by images revealing bruised hands during a July 16 meeting with Bahrain's leader. A similar bruise had appeared in February during talks with France's president. An April physical had previously declared both cognitive and physical health normal.

What to know about chronic venous insufficiency

Chronic venous insufficiency develops when leg veins struggle to pump blood upward toward the heart, causing pooling and swelling in the lower limbs. Vascular surgeons explain blood must flow upward against gravity through veins with valves that can weaken over time. Dr. Matthew Edwards from Wake Forest University noted 10-35% of seniors develop this condition, which while sometimes linked to serious ailments, typically remains benign.

Besides age, risk factors include obesity, blood clot history and occupations requiring prolonged standing. Physicians recommend medical-grade compression stockings and elevating legs at night. Dr. Meryl Logan of the University of Texas emphasizes daily moisturizing and weight management to alleviate symptoms.

The president's bruised hand

Barbabella clarified the vein condition doesn't explain Trump's bruised hands, attributing the marks to tissue damage from vigorous handshaking while taking aspirin. This medication forms part of Trump's cardiovascular prevention regimen but can exacerbate bruising. Dr. Edwards confirmed this explanation as plausible, noting elderly aspirin users become bruise-prone naturally.

Medical experts stated hand bruises require substantial force to appear. Edwards remarked, "That would be a pretty stiff handshake" to cause such markings. Trump has previously described himself as "the healthiest president that's ever lived" and routinely promotes his physical strength.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: India Emerges as Global French Fry Export Powerhouse
fields.summary: India has transformed into a leading global exporter of french fries, with Gujarat becoming the epicenter of production. Farmers' shift to water-efficient potato farming, competitive pricing, and growing international demand have driven a 45% export surge, though infrastructure challenges remain.
fields.content:
French fries revolutionized the fortunes of farmer Jitesh Patel and his family in Gujarat, northwest India. Previously struggling with water-intensive cotton crops during devastating droughts in 2001-2002, they pivoted to potatoes seeking better returns with less irrigation. Initial attempts with table potatoes yielded marginal improvement until 2007 when they specialized in industrial-grade potatoes for french fry manufacturers.

This strategic shift transformed their prospects. "Since then, no looking back," Mr Patel states, reflecting how this change placed him at the forefront of India's potato boom. The nation now ranks as the world's second-largest potato producer.

HyFun Foods Male and female workers in a potato field in Gujarat

Gujarat has become India's french fry capital, hosting massive processing plants from international giant McCain Foods and domestic leader HyFun Foods. Their output reaches global markets, with Asia—especially the Philippines, Thailand, and Indonesia—as key buyers. Monthly frozen fry exports surpassed 20,000 tonnes for the first time in February 2025.

Annual exports reached 181,773 tonnes by February 2025, marking a 45% annual increase. Competitively priced Indian fries undercut rivals like China in 2024. Haresh Karamchandani, CEO of HyFun Foods, explains: "India has emerged as a significant player through abundant agricultural produce, cost-effective manufacturing, and quality focus." With seven operational plants and two more planned by 2026, HyFun meets surging demand driven by urbanization and rising disposable incomes.

Agricultural Innovation Fuels Growth

Meeting industrial demand required continuous innovation. University-educated farmers like Jitesh Patel implemented drip irrigation in 2003, replacing flood methods to conserve water. Fields now undergo seasonal rest with cow manure fertilization. Patel's group experiments with advanced seed varieties to optimize yields, stating, "We are a well educated bunch of farmers, so we keep trying new methods."

Companies like Jain Irrigation Systems support this through tissue culture techniques—cloning disease-free plantlets in labs. Vice President Vijay Singh notes they're developing potato varieties resistant to sugar-induced browning, addressing industry challenges.

HyFun Foods French fries rolling down a production line

Infrastructure Challenges Persist

Despite growth, the industry faces cold-chain limitations. Only 10-15% of India's cold storage suits frozen foods, concentrated in few states and leaving rural areas underserved, according to Vijay Kumar Nayak of Indo Agri Foods. Specialized refrigerated transport remains scarce, and power outages threaten temperature stability.

Nayak highlights competition from China, Thailand, and Brazil, which boast better infrastructure. Yet farmers like Patel value security from corporate contracts: "Most farmers have become contract farmers which gives us security and good money." As global demand expands, India's potato growers continue adapting to consolidate their newfound superpower status.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Shapps defends secrecy over Afghan data breach as life-saving measure
fields.summary: Former UK Defence Secretary Sir Grant Shapps has defended keeping a major data breach confidential that exposed thousands of Afghans who assisted British forces, claiming secrecy was essential to save lives amid Taliban threats. The leak compromised about 19,000 vulnerable Afghans and over 100 UK officials.
fields.content:
Former defence secretary Sir Grant Shapps has justified withholding information about a data breach that exposed personal details of approximately 19,000 Afghans and over 100 British officials. In his first comments since the incident became public, Shapps emphasized that prioritizing confidentiality was vital to prevent Taliban retaliation against those who supported UK forces during the conflict.

Shapps explained to the BBC that erring on the side of secrecy was "entirely justified" when lives were at stake. He stated his primary focus during the crisis was "sorting out the mess and saving lives" as the Taliban actively sought retribution against collaborators.

The former minister confirmed an injunction blocking media reporting – including a temporary 'super-injunction' that concealed the injunction's existence – was appropriately sought by his predecessor. He noted that if disclosed prematurely, the leaked information could have led to targeted individuals being "pursued, murdered and executed" by Taliban forces.

Though surprised the legal order remained effective until recently, Shapps argued the secrecy allowed time to establish protection measures. He defended not informing the Intelligence and Security Committee, explaining that "even a hint of this getting around... meant the risks were incredibly high." Decisions about disclosure were made through consultations with judges.

The data breach originated in February 2022 when UK Special Forces staff accidentally emailed over 30,000 resettlement applications to unauthorized recipients, mistakenly believing they were sending just 150 files. The compromised information included Afghan applicants for UK relocation and British intelligence and special forces personnel.

Following the discovery of this breach in August 2023 – prompted by partial Facebook leaks by someone in Afghanistan – the government secretly launched the Afghanistan Response Route (ARR). This £850 million resettlement scheme has already brought 4,500 at-risk Afghans and family members to the UK, with 2,400 more expected.

British soldiers in uniform walk across a dusty, desert landscape towards a military helicopter near the Pimon military camp in Nad-e Ali district of Helmand province in March 2010

UK armed forces personnel affected by the leak received additional security guidance, though special forces members already maintained heightened protection protocols. The Ministry of Defence has declined to disclose potential casualty figures related to the breach.

Current Defence Secretary John Healey faces criticism after telling Parliament that to his knowledge, no serving UK forces personnel were endangered by the leak. Downing Street supported his statement, affirming they take personnel security "extremely seriously," while Liberal Democrats accused him of misleading lawmakers.

The Taliban government claimed it hadn't arrested or monitored individuals named in the leak. However, family members of affected Afghans reported increased Taliban efforts to locate individuals identified in the documents. Muhammad Khan, one beneficiary of the ARR scheme, has resettled with his family in southern England.

Muhammad Khan has a dark beard and is wearing a shirt.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK to Build Multi-Billion Pound Pandemic Defence Centre in Essex
fields.summary: A new National Biosecurity Centre under construction in Harlow, Essex will become Europe's largest pandemic response facility, backed by multi-billion pound government investment to research pathogens, accelerate vaccine development, and protect against future health threats.
fields.content:
The UK government is investing billions to establish a new science hub designed to strengthen pandemic defences. The National Biosecurity Centre in Harlow, Essex will consolidate the UK Health Security Agency's existing facilities into Europe's largest biosecurity complex.

Scientists at the centre will focus on studying dangerous pathogens and developing vaccines to combat emerging global health threats. During a site visit, Health Secretary Wes Streeting stated: "Covid-19 taught us how crucial it is to respond quickly to new emerging threats. The new NBC will allow us to do exactly that."

Health Secretary Wes Streeting touring the construction site with officials

Construction will generate approximately 1,600 jobs, with phased openings starting mid-2030s and full operation expected by 2038. Current facilities in Colindale and Porton Down will remain operational during the transition. The government confirmed an initial £250 million investment during this parliamentary term, with total funding to be finalised later.

Streeting emphasised the centre's broader mission: "Harlow will become a scientific hub exploring new ways to treat illnesses and improve health. By backing innovation and life sciences, we'll make the NHS fit for the future." The facility aims to foster partnerships between government scientists and private researchers.

Exterior view of the partially constructed National Biosecurity Centre building

The centre will feature specialised laboratories for investigating dangerous and novel diseases. UKHSA interim chief Dyfed Alsop called the project "fantastic news for the UK" that ensures long-term health protection. The announcement follows a separate £1 billion upgrade for an animal disease research centre in Weybridge, Surrey, while the Porton Down defence laboratory remains unaffected.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: MP Demands Urgent School Road Safety Improvements
fields.summary: Suffolk Coastal MP Jenny Riddell-Carparter launches a petition demanding customized road safety measures at all schools after children expressed fears about dangerous roads during her visits.
fields.content:
An MP has demanded "urgent action" to address road safety hazards near schools, stating children face serious risks daily around educational institutions. Jenny Riddell-Carpenter, Labour MP for Suffolk Coastal, initiated a petition urging the government to require Suffolk County Council to develop tailored road safety plans for every school.

The MP revealed she felt "shocked" and "deeply moved" when children themselves raised safety concerns during her constituency visits. "I was genuinely surprised that students in rural primary schools consistently wanted to discuss road safety," Riddell-Carpenter explained, noting their "genuine anxiety" about unsafe roads surrounding their schools.

Ben Parker/BBC Jenny Riddell-Carpenter smiles at the camera. She has dark blonde hair that is tied back.

Her proposed safety plans include 20mph speed zones, appropriate pedestrian crossings, enhanced enforcement, and safer walking routes. The petition will run through early September before parliamentary submission and forms part of a broader national campaign for stricter school road safety laws planned later this year.

Suffolk County Council confirmed it currently reviews criteria for expanding 20mph limits near schools, with findings expected by December. Meanwhile, Rachael Rudge, head teacher at Bucklesham Primary near Ipswich, described her school's location at a hazardous junction with 30mph and 60mph roads.

"Parents must park on the 60mph road and cross without protective barriers," Rudge stated, reporting dangerous near misses involving adults despite no student accidents thus far.

Vikki Irwin/BBC Rachael Rudge smiles at the camera. She has dark hair which has been tied back and she has a fringe. She stands outside on a sunny day with trees and bushes behind her.

Schools programme

The council emphasized providing individualized support to schools "within available resources" and highlighted its Junior Road Safety Officer scheme. Running for over 20 years, this peer-education program promotes road awareness through student ambassadors.

"It's an effective way to maximize safety education from young people familiar with local conditions," a spokesperson noted, adding that 61 primary schools participated last year.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Animals Detect Plant Distress Sounds, Altering Behavior
fields.summary: Researchers discovered that animals can perceive and react to ultrasonic sounds emitted by distressed plants, as moths were found avoiding egg-laying on tomato plants producing distress signals, suggesting a hidden acoustic ecosystem.
fields.content:
New evidence reveals animals respond to inaudible sounds emitted by plants, suggesting the existence of an invisible acoustic ecosystem. A Tel Aviv University research team found female moths avoided depositing eggs on tomato plants that made specific distress-related sounds, indicating plants’ auditory signals may influence animal decisions.

This discovery builds on prior research showing plants produce ultrasonic vibrations when stressed. These sounds occur beyond human hearing range but are detectable by insects, bats, and small mammals. Before this study, no animal had been experimentally confirmed to behaviorally respond to such plant sounds.

The Moth Response Experiment

Researchers conducted carefully controlled studies isolating sound as the influencing factor. Female moths avoided egg-laying on dehydrated, distressed tomato plants specifically when acoustic emissions were present, ignoring physically identical unaffected plants.

The study focused on moths that typically lay eggs on tomato plants for larval feeding. Researchers hypothesized moths might interpret plant distress sounds as warnings of poor host quality, thereby protecting future offspring survival by seeking healthier environments.

Broader Ecological Implications

Professor Yossi Yovel stated: "This is the first demonstration ever of an animal responding to sounds produced by a plant." He speculated that similar acoustic interactions might influence animal behaviors including pollination, shelter-seeking, or consumption across various species.

Future research will investigate whether different plants emit distinct sounds and whether animals like bees or bats use such cues. Professor Lilach Hadany noted: "If a plant is stressed, organisms most concerned are other nearby plants," suggesting possible plant-to-plant acoustic signaling that could trigger collective responses like water conservation during droughts.

Scientists clarified that such sounds result from physical stress responses rather than plant sentience. Hadany proposed coevolution might have developed mutually beneficial acoustic communication: plants evolving enhanced sound production, while animals refine detection capabilities overtime.

She described this discovery as revealing "an entire world waiting to be discovered." The findings were documented in the eLife journal, opening new pathways for exploring nature's hidden acoustic landscapes.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Samsung Chairman Acquitted in Landmark Fraud Case
fields.summary: South Korea's Supreme Court has upheld the acquittal of Samsung Electronics chairman Lee Jae-yong in a high-profile fraud case, concluding a five-year legal battle over alleged stock manipulation during a controversial 2015 corporate merger.
fields.content:
Samsung's de facto leader Lee Jae-yong has been cleared of all fraud charges by South Korea's highest court, finalizing a prolonged legal dispute concerning a 2015 merger. The Supreme Court in Seoul confirmed Lee's innocence, sustaining previous not-guilty rulings from two lower courts. This case centered on accusations that Lee used fraudulent accounting and stock manipulation to consolidate corporate control during the $8 billion merger between Samsung subsidiaries C&T and Biologics.

The verdict represents the conclusion of a protracted legal saga that had cast scrutiny on South Korea's influential family-run conglomerates, known as chaebols. Prosecutors had argued that Lee and his advisors artificially boosted the valuation of Samsung Biologics to enable his acquisition of a dominant stake in the merged entity, thereby solidifying his leadership succession following his father's 2014 medical incapacitation.

"The Supreme Court has definitively confirmed the legality of the merger and accounting practices after a comprehensive five-year review," declared Lee's legal team, expressing appreciation for the court's decision. This outcome follows Lee's earlier conviction in 2017 for bribing an associate of former President Park Geun-hye, which resulted in prison terms later shortened through presidential pardon in 2021, justified by economic recovery needs during the pandemic.

Throughout this decade-long legal struggle, Samsung has simultaneously faced significant market challenges, including declining electronics sales and intensifying global competition. During proceedings last year, Lee acknowledged these pressures, stating: "The reality facing Samsung is harder than ever, but I will overcome and move forward." Additional challenges include potential U.S. tariff impacts on Samsung's American exports.

South Korea's business community welcomed the final ruling, with the Federation of Korean Industries asserting that the resolution allows Samsung to make prompt leadership decisions during international trade uncertainties. The court's validation of the 2015 merger finally resolves corporate governance questions that have shadowed Asia's largest technology corporation.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Balamory Original Cast Returns for New CBeebies Revival
fields.summary: Original stars of the beloved children's series Balamory will reprise their roles in a new CBeebies revival, blending nostalgia with fresh characters and stories. Filmed partly in the Scottish town of Tobermory that inspired the original, the show will feature returning favorites alongside new faces in 20 episodes across two series.
fields.content:
Original cast members from the cherished children's show Balamory are reuniting for a new series on CBeebies next year. Julie Wilson Nimmo returns as Miss Hoolie alongside Andrew Agnew as PC Plum, Kim Tserkezie as Penny Pocket, and Juliet Cadzow as Edie McCredie.

The revival combines classic characters with new additions including scientist Ava Potts (Danielle Jam), vet Dr. Ollie (Carl Spencer), and harbor master (William Andrews). The BBC promises the series will deliver a celebratory blend of comedy, songs, and adventure rooted in its Scottish heritage.

The members of the new balamory cast gather round pointing to a script that says 'Balamory'

Production will occur both in a Glasgow studio and on location in Tobermory—the colorful Isle of Mull town that originally inspired the show during its 2002-2005 run. BBC Children's Commissioner Kate Morton stated: "It's wonderful to see original cast returning alongside new faces, creating a perfect mix for families. This series will delight both children and grown-ups."

A colourful line up of chacters in tracksuits, kilts and jumpers ahanist a windy island background.

Balamory gained international popularity during its original broadcast, airing across Europe, Australia, Hong Kong, Canada, and South Africa. Lion Television Scotland will produce two new series totaling 20 episodes, continuing the show's tradition of homegrown stories about island community life.

Tobermory School Location Controversy

Campaigners on the Isle of Mull seek a judicial review over Argyll and Bute Council's decision to build a new school near Tobermory rather than a more central island location. Councilors approved the Tobermory site earlier this year despite opposition.

A photo of Tobermory, a town known for it brightly coloured buildings. Visible are blue, yellow and pink buildings with a large church looking building in the middle.

This decision means pupils in southern island areas would still require ferry travel to mainland boarding schools. Local advocacy groups contend the chosen location creates accessibility challenges for some students.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: US-Backed Aid Group Undercuts Hamas Control in Gaza with 76 Million Meals
fields.summary: The US-supported Gaza Humanitarian Foundation has distributed over 76 million meals to Palestinians since May, bypassing Hamas and challenging the militant group's control over aid distribution networks that traditionally sustained its influence in Gaza.
fields.content:
The Gaza Humanitarian Foundation (GHF) is delivering essential aid directly to Palestinians while intentionally sidestepping Hamas involvement, according to conflict analyst Joe Truzman. "The key distinction between GHF and organizations like the U.N. is that GHF undercuts Hamas by preventing them from interfering with aid distribution," explained Truzman, a senior research analyst at the Foundation for Defense of Democracies.

Despite facing criticism and allegations of violence at distribution points, GHF has provided over 76 million meals since late May. Truzman observed Hamas is reacting strongly to this development, as the group cannot control GHF's aid channels - breaking its traditional grip on humanitarian assistance.

According to Truzman, Hamas relies on controlling aid, charities, mosques, and schools to manipulate Gaza's population. "Palestinians depend on these resources to survive, creating leverage for Hamas. By seizing control of aid distribution, Hamas maintained authority over civilians," he stated. GHF's U.S.-backed model disrupts this system, potentially weakening Hamas governance tools.

Hamas militants

The U.S. government specifically funded GHF to prevent Hamas from diverting supplies, providing $30 million in June. "GHF's model ensures aid distribution while preventing Hamas looting," affirmed State Department official Tommy Pigott. Truzman added, "Without GHF, Hamas would regain control of aid flow through terrorist networks - an unresolved challenge until now."

Palestinians getting humanitarian aid

The United Nations remains highly critical of GHF's operations, which Truzman attributes to institutional biases: "The U.N. is unhappy about losing distribution dominance in Gaza." While GHF executive Rev. Johnnie Moore claimed his organization helped reinstate U.N. access to Gaza, U.N. humanitarian officials gave no clear confirmation when contacted for verification, instead emphasizing urgent aid needs for Palestinians.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: NASA Re-establishes Contact with Voyager 1 Using Decades-Old Technology
fields.summary: NASA has restored communication with the interstellar Voyager 1 spacecraft located over 15 billion miles away by utilizing a radio transmitter last employed in 1981, following a complex series of technical challenges involving the probe's fault protection system and signal disruptions in October.
fields.content:
The Voyager Legacy

Launched alongside twin probe Voyager 2 in 1977, Voyager 1 originally embarked on a mission to study the solar system's gas giant planets. Following successful flybys of Jupiter and Saturn, the spacecraft has traveled beyond our planetary neighborhood into interstellar space, becoming humanity's most distant operational spacecraft.

Communication Breakthrough

In November 2023, Voyager 1 ceased transmitting readable data to NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. Mission controllers restored minimal communication in April 2024, but new issues emerged last October.
