International acclaim now blossoms through venues including the 2022 Venice Biennale and simultaneous exhibitions in Aspen and Glasgow. "Time has helped me grow," reflected Pessoa. Her art has physically expanded too - Deliria Deveras (2021–24) fills an Aspen gallery with 20 tons of crystals and silver mined near her Ferros birthplace. Recalling Robert Smithson's land art while diverging through spiritual intent, she described pursuing "the psychology of man’s relationship with an earthly God."

Massive crystal and silver installation covering gallery floor expanse

Roots and Evolution

Growing amidst Minas Gerais' mining culture, Pessoa calls herself a miner of both minerals and meaning. Her farm childhood surrounded by Baroque churches informs her aesthetic; sculptures often reference Saint statues adorned with human hair. Inspiration flows from sources as varied as land artist Smithson and 18th-century Brazilian sculptor Aleijadinho. "These sacks are Baroque," she asserted, "through their folding, verticality, and emotional intensity."

Since the 1990s, her unconventional sculptures - bone circles, hay knots, vegetable fiber masses - made her "a real outlier," according to Wood. She resisted conformity despite backlash, creating visceral works like Lesmalongas – Desterros where performers screamed in agony while wearing sculptures made of lard and dirt. "I like when works take me out of my comfort zone," Pessoa acknowledged.

Detailed rows of burlap sacks filled with organic materials and texts

Recently she has explored durable materials like bronze and soapstone. NIHIL NOVI SUB SOLE (2019–21) features leaf-carved soapstone sculptures that evolve through rainwater interaction, exhibited from Venice to Aspen's rooftop. This shift symbolizes Pessoa's reconciliation with permanence and transience: "I feel the necessity of ephemerality but simultaneously eternalization. These contradictory philosophies are inseparable."

Soapstone sculptures with intricate carvings overlooking mountain landscape

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Lionesses Report Racist Abuse Against Jess Carter to Police
fields.summary: England defender Jess Carter was subjected to racial abuse during Euro 2025, prompting the national team to involve police and discontinue their pre-match anti-racism gesture of taking the knee. Carter announced she would step back from social media following sustained discriminatory attacks.
fields.content:
England's football authorities are collaborating with police after defender Jess Carter reported being targeted by racist abuse during the Euro 2025 tournament. In a Sunday statement, the Lionesses announced they would cease the anti-racism gesture of taking a knee before matches, stating it was evident that football needed alternative methods to combat racism.

Carter confirmed she had endured significant racial harassment throughout the competition, declaring, "From the start of the tournament I have experienced a lot of racial abuse. While I feel every fan is entitled to their opinion on performance and result, I don't agree it's OK to target someone's appearance or race." The 27-year-old defender said she would withdraw from social media platforms, entrusting management of her accounts to a team.

The Football Association emphasized its commitment to pursuing legal action, stating, "We are working with police to ensure those responsible for this hate crime are brought to justice." Teammate Lotte Wubben-Moy subsequently announced she would also step away from social media in solidarity.

UK Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer condemned the abuse, affirming, "There is no place for racism in football or anywhere in society. I stand with Jess, the Lionesses, and any players who have suffered racism." Carter's American club, Gotham FC, expressed being "heartbroken and outraged," praising her as "a world-class player, role model, and leader."

Anti-discrimination charity Kick It Out supported Carter's decision while urging stronger consequences for perpetrators and more urgent action from social media companies. UEFA echoed these sentiments, stating, "Abuse should never be tolerated in football or society, online or offline."

Racial abuse on social media not new to women's football

This incident continues a troubling pattern in women's football, where online racial abuse has persisted despite increased visibility. During the 2023 Women's World Cup, forward Lauren James faced similar attacks after a red card incident. Chelsea condemned racial abuse targeting James again during a 2023 league match against Arsenal.

Manager Sarina Wiegman faces a tactical decision ahead of Tuesday's semi-final against Italy, considering whether to include Carter amid heightened abuse levels. Carter's tournament performances have faced scrutiny despite her defensive versatility, starting at both left-back and center-back. England's defensive unit has shown inconsistencies during the competition, with Carter experiencing particularly challenging moments against Sweden in the quarter-final clash.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Moscow Airports Shut Amid Ukrainian Drone Attacks With Dozens Downed
fields.summary: Drone attacks from Ukraine forced temporary closures at major Moscow airports leading to over 140 flight cancellations, while Russian strikes killed at least three people in Ukraine amid renewed diplomatic efforts to end the conflict.
fields.content:
Key Moscow airports halted operations following a sustained Ukrainian drone assault, causing significant flight disruptions across Russia's capital region. Aviation authorities temporarily shut down four major air hubs serving Moscow, resulting in at least 140 flight cancellations and 130 diversions. Officials confirmed all facilities have now resumed normal operations after repeated airspace closures.

Russia's defense ministry reported intercepting over 230 Ukrainian drones since Saturday morning, with 27 eliminated over Moscow's skies. Kaluga International Airport, southwest of the capital, also ceased operations temporarily when 45 drones targeted the region. Additional unmanned aircraft were shot down in border areas like Rostov and Bryansk, as well as over the Black Sea.

Impact on Aviation and Previous Incidents

Russia's Association of Tour Operators (Ator) revealed Moscow airports experienced ten closures within 24 hours during the attacks. The latest disruption echoes a major incident in May, when Ukraine's aerial offensive stranded 60,000 passengers through 500 drone sorties across Russia within one day, according to Russian military claims.

Meanwhile, Ukraine reported casualties from overnight Russian attacks. Regional officials confirmed at least three fatalities in eastern Ukraine, with two victims in Donetsk and a 78-year-old woman perishing in burning buildings in Sumy. Ukraine's air force claimed success in downing 18 of 57 Russian drones during the offensive, while electronic warfare systems neutralized seven more.

Emergency worker surveys damaged building in Donetsk region

The assaults extended beyond Sumy and Donetsk to front-line regions including Kharkiv, Dnipropetrovsk, and Zaporizhzhia, underscoring the ongoing combat intensity in eastern Ukraine.

Diplomatic Developments

Amid the violence, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov reiterated President Vladimir Putin's willingness to pursue peace settlement talks. Peskov stated in a televised interview while these efforts represent 'a long process, it requires effort, and it is not easy,' the primary objective remains achieving Russian strategic goals first.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky has proposed restarting negotiations with Moscow after discussions stalled last month. Zelensky emphasized the necessity of leader-level engagement, declaring 'A meeting at the leadership level is needed to truly ensure peace.' Previous diplomatic exchanges between nations have yielded prisoner swaps despite ceasefire failures.

Ukraine received reinforcement when the US announced plans to deliver 'top-of-the-line weapons' through NATO partners. The US leader additionally warned of imposing severe tariffs on Russia unless a peace deal emerges within 50 days. Responding to the statements, Peskov dismissed the US official's 'harsh rhetoric' but acknowledged intentions toward peaceful resolution.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: South Essex Railways Return to Public Ownership After Decades
fields.summary: Rail services between south Essex and London have transitioned to public ownership for the first time since the 20th century as operator c2c becomes part of Great British Railways, aiming to reduce costs and improve reliability amid political debate.
fields.content:
Services connecting South Essex and London are now publicly operated after operator c2c formally joined Great British Railways (GBR) this past Sunday, marking the first state-run operation of these routes since the last century.

The government-run GBR now oversees train services spanning England, Wales, and Scotland following the nationalization. Transport Secretary Heidi Alexander cited persistent issues passengers faced under private operations, describing 'spiralling costs, fragmentation, and widespread waste' as key drivers for the change.

c2c train parked at a station platform

Ministerial powers for nationalizing railways were established through the Passenger Railway Services Act passed in November 2024, allowing takeovers as existing contracts expire. c2c represents the sixth operator to enter public hands under this legislation.

Greater Anglia, another eastern England service provider, will transition to state ownership on October 12th. Alexander declared public oversight targets 'deep-rooted problems' and pledged that GBR's unified structure would concentrate resources on service quality.

Policy Benefits and Criticisms

The shift is anticipated to deliver up to £150 million in savings while decreasing delays and cancellations nationwide, according to government projections. David Burton-Sampson, Labour MP for Southend West and Leigh, expressed confidence passengers would witness tangible long-term improvements: 'Commuters should expect better service, consistent ticketing, and enhanced punctuality.'

However, Jerome Mayhew, Conservative shadow rail minister, voiced skepticism about financial outcomes. He cautioned that leasing costs for trains might escalate under government control, characterizing the move as an 'ideological risk' to previously functional operations.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Record UV Levels Forecast for UK: Understanding the Risks
fields.summary: The UK faces unprecedented ultraviolet radiation levels potentially reaching a record-breaking index of nine this week. This article explains the science behind UV measurement, current record conditions including ozone depletion effects, and essential health protection advice.
fields.content:
What is the UV Index?

The UV Index (UVI) is an international measurement scale for solar ultraviolet radiation that penetrates Earth's atmosphere and causes skin damage. It starts at zero and can exceed 10, with higher values indicating greater risk of harm to skin and eyes within shorter exposure times.

UV Index levels graphic: Low (1-2), Moderate (3-5), High (6-7), Very High (8-10), Extremely High (10+)

UV radiation peaks during the four-hour window around solar noon (typically 12:00-14:00). Locations near the equator like Nairobi sustain levels above 10 year-round, while Majorca reaches nine in summer. The Falkland Islands' summer maximum rarely exceeds five.

Current UK UV Situation

UV radiation in Britain typically peaks in late June, but current clear skies could bring record-breaking levels. BBC Weather's Matt Taylor states: "Normally summer readings reach six or seven. Today we could hit nine in southern England and South Wales."

Causes of Heightened Radiation

Multiple factors contribute: the recent summer solstice positions the sun higher in the sky, while exceptional ozone depletion occurred over the northern hemisphere during winter and spring due to natural weather patterns. Reduced pollution levels under lockdown conditions also minimize UV scattering.

Health Dangers

While sunlight provides essential vitamin D, excessive UV exposure causes sunburn, skin cancer, and eye cataracts. Dr. Michaela Hegglin of Reading University advises: "Slip on a shirt, slop on sunscreen, and slap on a hat during peak hours." Temperature doesn't determine UV strength – 20°C days can be as damaging as 30°C. Helen Willetts of BBC Weather warns: "UV penetrates thin clouds, so burning risk persists even when it doesn't feel intensely sunny."

Crowded beach in the UK

Protection Measures

Prevent UV damage by frequently applying high-factor sunscreen (especially for fair skin), avoiding midday sun exposure, and wearing UV-blocking sunglasses. Research confirms direct links between UV exposure and serious eye conditions.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Reddit introduces mandatory age verification for UK users
fields.summary: Reddit has implemented mandatory age verification for UK users to comply with the country's Online Safety Act, using third-party services to confirm users are at least 18 years old before accessing mature content, with potential hefty fines for non-compliance.
fields.content:
Reddit has launched mandatory age verification checks for UK users to restrict under-18s from viewing specific mature content on its platform. This measure responds to new regulations in the UK's Online Safety Act requiring websites with adult material to implement reliable age verification systems.

The social media company stated that while it traditionally avoids gathering extensive user information, confirming whether users are adults or children now supports safety initiatives. External firm Persona will handle the verification process starting July 14, using either government-issued identification documents or selfie analysis.

Reddit emphasized it won't store user photos directly, retaining only verification status and birth dates to avoid repeated checks. Persona commits to deleting photos within seven days and will not access users' platform data. UK communications regulator Ofcom welcomed the move, expecting other companies to follow before enforcement begins on July 25.

Ofcom noted that society traditionally shields children from unsuitable products like alcohol or gambling, and similar protections should apply to inappropriate online content. Penalties for non-compliance could reach £18 million or 10% of a company's global revenue, whichever is higher. In severe cases, Ofcom may seek court orders to disrupt services, including payment blocks or UK-wide site restrictions.

Critics expressed concerns about effectiveness and privacy. Scott Babwah Brennen from New York University warned that determined minors could bypass systems, while David Greene of the Electronic Frontier Foundation called the law a tragedy forcing UK users to provide identification to access the internet. Major adult websites like Pornhub have also announced plans for enhanced age checks, though specific methods remain unclear.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Pilot with 'ideological motive' steals aircraft, shuts down Vancouver airport
fields.summary: A pilot hijacked a small plane with an ideological motive, forcing Vancouver International Airport to temporarily halt operations and divert flights before being safely apprehended by police.
fields.content:
A Cessna 172 aircraft stolen from Victoria International Airport triggered a security alert at Vancouver International Airport (YVR) on July 15, leading to a complete suspension of flight operations. The incident began just before 1:30 p.m. local time, forcing nine incoming flights to divert to alternative airports.

Air traffic controllers issued urgent alerts about the hijacked plane during the crisis. One transmission stated: "We do have an aircraft that has been hijacked and is in the vicinity of the airport... just in case anything starts heading toward [you], you have the ability to move at your discretion." Controllers later confirmed: "They are currently flying overhead. We have the aircraft in visual range—please stand by for further instructions."

After 39 minutes of suspended operations, the plane landed safely around 1:45 p.m. Royal Canadian Mounted Police officers immediately arrested the solo pilot, identified as 39-year-old Shaheer Cassim.

Police arrest suspect who stole plane

Official Responses

Vancouver Airport Authority confirmed no injuries occurred during the incident involving the Victoria Flying Club aircraft. Their statement emphasized: "Safety and security are our top priorities, and we continually review our processes... we debrief on what took place and make recommendations for changes or improvements."

Eyewitness Paul Heeny described seeing the low-flying aircraft: "A few minutes later, the plane made a second pass, circling in a wide clockwise turn."

Vancouver International Airport

Investigation Findings

Police reported Cassim displayed an "ideological motive" aimed at disrupting air traffic and allegedly threatened a flight instructor at Victoria Airport before seizing the aircraft. RCMP Sergeant Tammy Lobb confirmed the investigation remains active, though no injuries were recorded during the incident.

British Columbia's Minister of Public Safety Garry Begg praised responders: "Grateful for the professionalism shown by police, air traffic control, and airport staff. Relieved there were no injuries and that normal operations have resumed." While flights resumed at YVR, officials advised passengers to anticipate minor delays and contact airlines for updates.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: ICE Director Attributes Officer Assaults to Political Rhetoric Criticizing Agency
fields.summary: The acting director of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement has linked an 830% surge in assaults against officers to heightened political rhetoric from elected officials criticizing the agency's enforcement operations.
fields.content:
Acting ICE Director Todd Lyons asserted that inflammatory language from elected officials has directly contributed to a dramatic increase in attacks on immigration officers. During a Sunday interview, Lyons highlighted an 830% rise in assaults compared to 2024, connecting it to public criticism of ICE's enforcement mandate.

Lyons explained that amplified political rhetoric "shaming or speaking out against ICE law enforcement mission" has created hazardous conditions for agents. He added that heightened visibility during expanded deportation operations has further exposed officers to threats, stating: "There is a lot of scrutiny and publicity to it" due to the administration's immigration priorities.

The director confirmed that arrests aren't limited to immigrants with prior criminal convictions, revealing that non-criminal individuals are sometimes detained as "collateral arrests" during operations targeting violent offenders. Nevertheless, Lyons maintained that ICE focuses on capturing "the worst of the worst."

Agents Describe Increasing Hostility

Field officers have expressed deep concern about mounting hostility. Agent Kristian Moreno described the demoralizing experience of being publicly villainized for performing their duties.

"It has been very sad to see how we're villainized, the names used towards us," Moreno shared during a recent interview. He noted the personal risk involved in speaking publicly, saying: "I had to talk to my family about it... We're just enforcing the law. We're not making up the law."

Agents Edgardo Centeno and Chris Sandoval echoed these sentiments. Centeno, a combat veteran, expressed particular distress about national divisions: "It's saddening my heart, especially when you serve in combat and come back and see your country so divided while defending the Constitution through law enforcement."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Florida Reports Four Fatalities from Flesh-Eating Bacteria in Coastal Waters
fields.summary: Florida health officials have confirmed four deaths and 11 infections caused by Vibrio vulnificus bacteria in 2025. Found in warm coastal waters, this potentially deadly pathogen can enter the body through open wounds or raw shellfish consumption.
fields.content:
Florida's Department of Health has confirmed four fatalities and 11 cases of Vibrio vulnificus infection so far in 2025. The naturally occurring bacteria is found in warm coastal waters and poses significant risks for swimmers with open wounds.

Vibrio vulnificus can cause skin infections with symptoms including fever, redness, pain, swelling, and discharge. Those with compromised immune systems or chronic liver disease face heightened vulnerability to severe complications.

When the bacteria enters the bloodstream, it can trigger life-threatening conditions like septic shock and blistering skin lesions—approximately half of such bloodstream infections prove fatal. In extreme cases, it may develop into necrotizing fasciitis, causing tissue death that has led to the "flesh-eating bacteria" designation.

Vibrio vulnificus bacteria

Diagnosis and treatment

Health professionals diagnose infections through laboratory testing of wound, blood, or stool samples. Treatment for mild cases focuses on hydration, while severe infections require antibiotics and possible surgical intervention.

Florida Health stated that "aggressive attention should be given to the wound site" with amputation sometimes necessary to save patients. According to CDC data, the infection has a 20% fatality rate, with some deaths occurring within one to two days of symptom onset.

Man beach bandage

Prevention tips

Officials strongly advise against entering warm saltwater or brackish water with exposed cuts or scrapes. Protective gloves should be worn when handling raw shellfish, and raw oyster consumption should be avoided entirely.

High-risk groups include individuals with liver disease, cancer, diabetes, HIV, thalassemia, or those using immunosuppressive drugs. Prevention is critical as Florida reported 82 cases and 19 deaths in 2024, increasing from 46 cases and 11 deaths the previous year.

oysters on ice

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Caligula's Hidden Botanical Fascination Driven by Assassination Fears, Study Reveals
fields.summary: New research uncovers Roman Emperor Caligula's deep medicinal plant expertise tied to assassination anxieties. Historians reinterpret an ancient account where Caligula referenced poisonous hellebore before executing an ill senator, revealing his complex botanical knowledge within political paranoia.
fields.content:
Historical research suggests Roman Emperor Caligula possessed unexpected expertise in medicinal plants, driven by fears of assassination. The study reexamines an account by ancient historian Suetonius involving Caligula and an ailing senator who sought extended medical leave at Antikyra, Greece, for hellebore treatments.

The Senator and the Poison

When the senator requested prolonged treatment, Caligula ordered his execution with the chilling remark: "necessary, for one whom hellebore had not benefited in all that time." Luke noted Caligula's reputation as a "prolific poisoner" might explain his botanical knowledge: "Murder by poisoning was a common theme in ancient literature about bad rulers."

Aerial view of Antikyra, Greece

Antikyra functioned as an ancient medical destination comparable to the modern Mayo Clinic, offering specialized treatments featuring hellebore blended with local sesamoides plant. Researchers suggest Caligula may have consulted pharmacological texts linked to historical figures like Alexander the Great and Mithradates VI, who also studied botanical toxins.

Bust of Caligula in park

Self-Defense, Not Hobby

When questioned if Caligula should be considered a "plant nerd," study author Luke clarified that self-preservation drove the emperor's botanical interest: "His family members took up the study of poisons and their antidotes... The motive of self-defense is different from just being a nerd." Luke cited suspicious poison-related deaths involving Caligula's relatives as justification.

Close-up of hellebore leaves in field

Luke cautions against taking ancient sources like Suetonius at face value: "Shock does not lead to clear perception of facts. When pursuing the facts behind outrageous stories about Caligula, I often find Suetonius deftly distorted what likely happened." The study emphasizes reevaluating historical narratives through contextual evidence and ancient records.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Scottie Scheffler Dominates at The Open for Second Major Victory of 2025
fields.summary: Scottie Scheffler claimed his first Open Championship title with a commanding performance at Royal Portrush, securing his second major win of 2025 through consistent play across four rounds that saw him finish ahead of challengers Harris English and Chris Gottrup.
fields.content:
Scheffler's Commanding Victory

Scottie Scheffler captured the Open Championship title at Royal Portrush in Northern Ireland with a dominant final-round 68, marking his second major win this year. Despite a modest first-round 68, Scheffler surged ahead with a spectacular second-round 64 featuring eight birdies, followed by a 67 in the third round that positioned him for victory. His Sunday performance included five birdies against a single double bogey, maintaining a steady lead that challengers couldn't overcome.

This victory represents Scheffler's career-best Open finish, significantly improving on his previous best of tied for seventh in 2024. The win adds to his successful 2025 season which includes victories at the PGA Championship, Memorial Tournament, and Byron Nelson, totaling to four tournament wins.

Harris English swings

Harris English secured second place with a 13-under par, delivering an impressive final-round 66 for his best major championship performance. Previously, English hadn't finished better than tied for 15th in majors, achieved back in 2013. Chris Gottrup claimed third place at 12-under par, carding a 66 in his final round despite a difficult 78 in the opening round that nearly saw him miss the cut.

Scottie Scheffler swings

Bryson DeChambeau staged a remarkable comeback after a first-round 78 landed him near the bottom of the leaderboard. His second-round 65 secured his weekend spot, and subsequent rounds of 68 and 64 propelled him up 24 positions to tie for 10th. As golf's final major of 2025 concluded, players from both PGA Tour and LIV Golf now look ahead to September's Ryder Cup.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: 8 Simple Steps to Cut Cable Costs and Switch to Streaming
fields.summary: As cable bills continue rising, discover eight practical strategies to transition to affordable streaming alternatives while maintaining access to essential channels and entertainment.
fields.content:
With cable television costs steadily increasing, consumers like Bob from Plymouth, Massachusetts seek affordable alternatives without sacrificing favorite programs. Cutting the cable cord presents a practical solution with significant savings potential through these eight actionable steps.

1. Verify your internet capability for streaming

Ensure your connection meets streaming requirements: Netflix and YouTube TV recommend at least 25 Mbps download speed for HD content. Higher speeds become necessary when multiple household members stream simultaneously. Test your internet using free online speed tools.

2. Establish an internet-only connection

Contact providers like Verizon to explore unadvertised internet-only packages. Existing customers often qualify for special rates, and switching companies might yield greater savings. Reducing your mobile plan expenses can further lower monthly bills.

3. Acquire a suitable streaming device

Affordable options like Roku, Amazon Fire Stick, or Google Chromecast (typically under $50) transform traditional TVs into streaming hubs. These devices grant access to major platforms through simple HDMI connections.

Various streaming devices displayed

4. Select essential streaming services

Choose budget-friendly subscriptions based on viewing preferences instead of accumulating multiple unnecessary services. Evaluate options like Netflix, Hulu, and Disney+ to create a personalized package.

5. Obtain local channels via HD antenna

An indoor HD antenna provides free access to FOX, ABC, NBC, CBS, and PBS broadcasts without subscription fees. This solution maintains access to news and local programming after cable cancellation.

6. Leverage free streaming platforms

Explore no-cost alternatives offering live TV, movies, and shows—Pluto TV, Tubi, and The Roku Channel provide substantial entertainment libraries without additional expenses. These complement paid subscriptions.

Person using free streaming service

7. Research competitive internet options

Regularly compare providers since pricing and promotional offers frequently change. Shopping around ensures you maintain optimal service at the best available rate for consistent streaming quality.

8. Negotiate discounts before cancellation

When contacting your provider about termination, inquire about retention promotions, loyalty discounts, or budget plans. Customer service representatives often offer bill reductions to retain customers.

The transition to streaming enables significant savings without complexity. Critical steps include securing sufficient internet speed, selecting essential services, and utilizing free content options. Testing your setup beforehand ensures seamless viewing. Implement these changes to unlock both financial relief and viewing flexibility.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: High-Carb Fueling: The New Frontier in Ultrarunning Performance?
fields.summary: Ultrarunner David Roche shattered a 20-year record at the Leadville 100 by consuming up to 140 grams of carbohydrates hourly—a controversial strategy fueling debate about performance limits. His victories and setbacks demonstrate both the promise and pitfalls of extreme carb-loading in endurance sports.
fields.content:
An Audacious Challenge

In 2024, coach and ultrarunner David Roche announced an ambitious goal: breaking the nearly two-decade-old record of 15 hours, 42 minutes at Colorado's legendary Leadville Trail 100 Mile race. This stunned the running community as Roche had never before raced the 100-mile distance. Despite doubts, Roche believed emerging innovations—including carbon-plated shoes and sodium bicarbonate supplementation—combined with a radical high-carb fueling strategy could make the impossible achievable.

His confidence stemmed from a meticulous spreadsheet predicting a 15-minute margin under the record through consuming 120-140 grams of carbohydrates (500+ calories) per hour. This approach originated in elite cycling and was gaining traction among endurance athletes. Roche became one of its chief proponents, preparing to test it under Leadville's grueling conditions.

Unlikely Origins

Roche's path to ultrarunning prominence was unconventional. Growing up as a 200-pound football player in Maryland, he initially believed his athletic limits capped at 800-meter runs. After quitting Columbia University's football team, he discovered trail running while studying environmental law at Duke, where he met his wife Megan, now his coaching partner.

After moving to Boulder, Colorado, the couple built successful coaching careers, but fatherhood in 2022 sparked urgency in Roche. When Megan urged him to "shoot your shot," he entered the 2023 Canyons 100k. A nutrition-related vomiting episode there prompted his carb-loading experiments, culminating in a victory at the McDowell Mountain 50-miler and qualification for Leadville via the Silver Rush 50 win.

Redefining Limits

Roche trained simultaneously for running endurance and caloric intake capacity. "I trained like a competitive eater," he said, practicing with fluids to tolerate up to 56 ounces hourly. Even a training accident—a car collision that broke his wrist—didn't derail preparations.

At Leadville, initial doubts vanished when heart-rate data confirmed he could sustain higher intensity with proper fueling. His rule: run every step, no walking. Pacer Teddy Bross witnessed remarkable consistency, noting Roche looked identical at miles 40 and 60. Despite brief nausea on the Powerline climb, Roche finished in 15:26:34—shattering the record by over 16 minutes.

Scientific Debate

Roche's success ignited discussions about high-carb fueling's validity. Exercise scientist Alex Hutchinson called it "an open question scientifically," citing challenges in testing extremes through ultrarunning trials. Veteran coach Andy Jones-Wilkins labeled it "an incredible marketing opportunity" potentially unsuitable for non-elites.

Experts cautioned that gastrointestinal distress risks increase with age and slower paces. Author Jason Koop noted cycling's peloton has long used such strategies but emphasized few athletes actually need extreme fueling. Coach Tyler Fox advocated "fueling the work," stressing carbohydrate intake must align with sustained effort intensity to avoid digestive issues.

Anna Gibson, a sub-ultra runner coached by Roche, credited 110g/hour carb intake with her 30k course record. Hutchinson summarized: "David weighs the odds and says, 'So you're telling me there's a chance!''

Beyond Leadville

Roche recovered rapidly, attributing his resilience to carb-loading's training and recovery benefits. To test if Leadville was a fluke, he raced Arizona's Javelina Jundred two months later, winning in 12:45:04 despite 100◦F heat. This earned him entry to the Western States 100.

At Western States, Roche initially ran fifth among elites like Kilian Jornet. But after mile 56, electrolyte imbalance and reduced carb intake triggered mental distress. "I didn't nail down the mental side," admitted Roche, who dropped at mile 62. Despite this, he remains committed to refining the approach: "You give me 75 gels and I can give you the world."

Experts urge caution, with Koop warning: "Your average ultrarunner... needs to be cautious." Jones-Wilkins predicts high-carb fueling will settle as an elite-only strategy. Roche's journey illustrates both transformative potential and the fine line between breakthrough and breakdown in endurance sports.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Artist Accuses DHS of Unauthorized Use of Painting in Heritage Campaign
fields.summary: American painter Morgan Weistling alleges the Department of Homeland Security used his frontier-life artwork without permission in a social media post promoting national heritage, sparking copyright concerns and revealing the artist's political connections.
fields.content:
The U.S. Department of Homeland Security recently shared an oil painting on its social media accounts showing a pioneer family inside a covered wagon. The post featured the caption "Remember Your Homeland's Heritage" alongside the artwork depicting a man and woman holding an infant in Old West setting.

This painting was identified as "New Life in A New Land" by Morgan Weistling, an artist specializing in American frontier themes. Weistling transitioned from film and video game illustration to fine art in 1998.

A statement appeared on Weistling's website claiming DHS used his artwork without authorization: "Attention: The recent DHS post on social media using a painting of mine that I painted a few years ago was used without my permission."

The artist initially posted a stronger message calling it "a violation of my copyright on the painting," according to reports. This statement was later deleted from his website and social media. Weistling told the New Republic: "It was a surprise to me and I am trying to gather how this happen and what to do next."

Despite this conflict, Weistling maintains political alignment with Trump-era policies through his partnership with Focus on the Family, a conservative organization opposing abortion rights and LGBTQIA+ protections. His paintings are sold through their online store, including the disputed artwork.

The Focus on the Family listing titles the piece "A Prayer for a New Life," describing it as celebrating family values amid pioneer-era challenges. This marks the second time in weeks that DHS has featured idealized American scenes, having previously shared Thomas Kinkade's mid-century suburban painting "Morning Pledge."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: British woman dies in rafting accident on French Alps river
fields.summary: A British national has died following a white-water rafting accident on the Guisane river in the French Alps. Authorities report she fell from her raft near Briancon and subsequently died in hospital despite rescue efforts.
fields.content:
A British woman has died following an accident during a white-water rafting expedition in France's Alps region. The incident occurred on the Guisane river near Briancon in southeastern France.

According to regional prosecutor Marion Lozac'hmeur, the woman fell from her raft around midday local time (11:00 BST) on Saturday. Emergency services later located her on the riverbank before airlifting her to a nearby hospital in serious condition.

Lozac'hmeur confirmed the victim "unfortunately died yesterday evening". The UK Foreign Office acknowledged a British woman's death in France and stated they are liaising with local authorities.

Local media reports indicated the woman was participating in an organized rafting trip. She fell while navigating a section of the Guisane known as "the wallet". Her identity remains undisclosed by authorities in both countries.

An investigation for involuntary manslaughter has been initiated, with an autopsy ordered to determine the exact cause of death. This tragedy follows another incident last year when a British man drowned during a kayaking expedition on the nearby Durance river.

Both the Guisane and Durance rivers are popular rafting destinations fed by glacial meltwater and spring snowmelt. They contain challenging rapids and are typically navigable only during early summer months according to Briancon's tourism information.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ellen DeGeneres Moves to UK Following Trump Re-election
fields.summary: Ellen DeGeneres revealed during her first UK public appearance that she and her wife Portia de Rossi permanently relocated to England the day after Donald Trump's presidential re-election, citing political concerns, cultural preferences, and ongoing LGBT+ rights challenges in America.
fields.content:
Television icon Ellen DeGeneres declared during an event in Cheltenham, Gloucestershire that she moved to the UK the day after Donald Trump secured re-election as US president. The comedian shared that life feels safer and "just better" in England compared to America, where she believes it remains "scary for people to be who they are."

DeGeneres and her spouse originally planned for a part-time residence but decided to stay permanently following the 2025 election results. She addressed workplace toxicity allegations that ended her long-running talk show in 2022, describing them as "clickbait" while acknowledging she can be "very blunt."

We're staying here

DeGeneres explained that she purchased a Cotswolds home intending to spend several months annually there. Their arrival coincided with Trump's victory. "We got here the day before the election and woke up to lots of texts from our friends with crying emojis," she recalled. "I was like, 'He got in.' And we're like, 'We're staying here.'"

Her social media portrays rural English life with farm animals, though she humorously noted the sheep were sold after constantly escaping. "It's absolutely beautiful," DeGeneres remarked. "The villages and towns, the architecture—everything is charming with a simpler, cleaner way of life. People are polite, animals are treated well. We love it here."

Ellen DeGeneres at a film premiere in 2003

Being gay in Hollywood "is still a problem"

Reflecting on her groundbreaking 1997 coming-out that ended her sitcom, DeGeneres stated that being openly gay in entertainment remains challenging. When asked if her visibility encouraged others, she responded: "I would say no." She observed that many actors still hide their identities due to fear.

The couple is considering remarrying in the UK following efforts by US religious groups and state legislatures to reverse same-sex marriage rights. "They're trying to literally stop it from happening," DeGeneres said, adding that America continues to be intimidating for LGBTQ+ individuals despite progress among younger generations.

Ellen DeGeneres and Portia de Rossi at an awards ceremony in 2006

Does being blunt mean I'm mean?

DeGeneres defended herself against post-talk show allegations of a toxic workplace and "mean" behavior, calling the label disproportionately applied to women. "I'm a direct person, and I'm very blunt," she stated. "It's hurtful because I know I'm an empathetic, compassionate person." The scandal led to three producers being fired and marked an "unpleasant" conclusion to her show.

Would "love" a British talk show

Though missing her program, DeGeneres doubts traditional talk shows work in today's digital landscape. She expressed boredom with farm life and remains open to new projects. "I would love to do that again here, but people aren't really paying attention to televisions," she noted, adding she'll choose her next career move carefully.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Drivers Avoid Steep Fees by Parking in Airport Lay-bys
fields.summary: Travelers at Edinburgh Airport are increasingly using roadside lay-bys to dodge escalating drop-off charges, with drivers coordinating pickups near hotels after passengers exit the terminal. This follows research showing over half of the UK's busiest airports have raised fees in the past year, with costs reaching £7 at major hubs.
fields.content:
A surge of vehicles filled roadside lay-bys near Edinburgh Airport on a busy summer Friday as drivers sought to avoid airport drop-off fees. Positioned within half a mile of the terminal, these motorists waited for messages from arriving passengers before moving to designated pickup spots.

Cars parked in lay-by near Edinburgh Airport roundabout

Recent RAC research revealed over half of the UK's busiest airports increased drop-off tariffs in the past year. Edinburgh Airport currently charges £6 for the first 10 minutes in its official zone, plus £1 per additional minute. Short-stay parking options range from £7 for 15 minutes to £14 for half an hour.

Drivers like Caroline O'Brien strategically wait along Eastfield Road before maneuvering to hotel entrances for quick pickups. Ms. O'Brien explained her £24 experience: "A couple of pounds would be fair when you're just collecting someone quickly." Many drivers note inadequate signage about charges until entering the fee zone.

Entrance to Edinburgh Airport paid pickup zone

Edinburgh Airport drop-off charge sign

Drop-off fees at major UK airports reach £7 at Gatwick, Bristol, Leeds Bradford, Southampton and Stansted. By contrast, nine of the EU's ten busiest airports impose no such fees. Swiss visitor Rontom Tschopp expressed surprise after encountering charges: "In Basel we don't pay - I wouldn't linger for heartfelt goodbyes knowing about this."

Rontom Tschopp reacting to airport fees

While Edinburgh Airport provides a free 30-minute drop-off area half a mile from the terminal, elderly traveler Sheila McPheely considers it impractical for passengers with mobility issues: "The £6 fee is appalling. We're already paying for flights and airport refreshments." Passenger Gavin Marshall noted unprecedentedly high charges: "£6 flat rate seems fair, but £1 per minute later is ridiculous."

Van crashed into fence near airport

Taxi driver Dean Carse emphasized the broader impact: "Every ride becomes £6 costlier - it's passed from customer to driver to airport." Airport authorities highlighted their free drop-off alternatives, as Airports UK confirmed all hubs provide complimentary options away from terminals. Police Scotland indicated they give advice to drivers using unauthorized waiting areas and take action when necessary.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Solar Panels for UK Schools Scheme Sourced from China Despite Labour Concerns
fields.summary: Chinese manufacturers supplied solar panels for the first schools participating in Britain's state-owned Great British Energy scheme, sparking criticism over ethical concerns despite government assurances about compliance with modern slavery laws.
fields.content:
The inaugural phase of Great British Energy solar installations in English schools utilized panels from Chinese companies, according to newly revealed information. Specifically, 11 educational institutions sourced equipment from Aiko and Longi—both headquartered in China—under the government program.

While officials described the project as a landmark initiative "owned by the British people, for the British people", Labour MP Sarah Champion raised objections about ethical sourcing. She urged GB Energy to prioritize British suppliers rather than Chinese firms connected to allegations of forced labor. "We should not be supporting slave labour with taxpayers' money," Champion stated, acknowledging potential short-term cost increases but highlighting alternatives in the UK, Taiwan, and Canada.

Both manufacturers firmly rejected allegations of unethical practices. Longi and Aiko emphasized their strict prohibitions against forced labor within their operations and supply chains. This response comes despite well-documented concerns about Xinjiang region suppliers, where up to half of the globe's polysilicon—a vital solar panel component—originates.

The Xinjiang challenge

China's dominance in solar manufacturing remains substantial, producing over 80% of global solar panel components per International Energy Agency data. UK imports reflect this reliance, with 68% of solar panels coming from Chinese firms in 2024. Mark Candlish of British manufacturer GB-Sol admitted this market reality makes Chinese imports difficult to avoid for affordable low-carbon solutions, despite industry awareness about labor risks in Xinjiang.

A 2023 Sheffield Hallam University report linked multiple solar companies to Xinjiang facilities, though researcher Alan Crawford noted decreased transparency since the study's publication. New legal provisions now prevent GB Energy investments in renewable projects with substantiated modern slavery violations in their supply chains.

'Ethical supply chains'

Launched to accelerate renewable energy deployment, GB Energy represents a state-owned investment vehicle. Its first projects allocate £200 million for solar installations across 200 schools and NHS hospitals. The controversy follows revelations that initial funding covered Chinese-made panels for the initial group of schools.

An aerial artist's impression of the new solar carports showing rows of panels surrounded by a railway line and trees

A GB Energy spokesperson defended the procurement process, stating all contracts adhered to modern slavery legislation and affirming a commitment to "ethical supply chains". They detailed planned initiatives including mandatory anti-slavery obligations for suppliers and enhanced transparency standards. Both Aiko and Longi highlighted participation in the Solar Stewardship Initiative, which promotes responsible sourcing. Longi disputed the Sheffield Hallam report's methodology while reaffirming its zero-tolerance stance on forced labor.

Notably, international bodies have accused China of human rights violations against Uyghurs in Xinjiang, including forced labor tied to polysilicon manufacturing. Beijing denies these allegations.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: NHS England sets waiting time targets with postcode tracking tool
fields.summary: NHS hospitals across England must improve planned treatment waiting times to meet government targets, including ensuring 65% of patients receive care within 18 weeks by March 2026. A new postcode tool allows residents to track local progress toward these goals.
fields.content:
Health authorities have directed all NHS hospitals in England to reduce waiting periods for scheduled medical treatments. Meeting the 18-week referral-to-treatment standard has been designated as a key governmental priority during the current parliamentary term.

By March 2026, officials aim for at least 65% of patients to wait no longer than 18 weeks for planned care. Each NHS trust must achieve either a 60% compliance rate or demonstrate a five-percentage-point improvement from November 2024 data points—whichever target presents greater advancement.

This milestone is an interim step toward the main objective of reaching 92% compliance by July 2029. A specialized tool now enables citizens to input their postcode and assess local hospital waiting list performance.

About the data

The analysis covered NHS trusts in England that reported over 5,000 patients awaiting elective treatment during November 2024. It's important to recognize that announced targets only apply to England and distinct standards exist elsewhere in the UK.

Scotland's healthcare system maintains an 18-week target for 90% of patients, while Wales requires 95% of patients to be treated within 26 weeks. Northern Ireland sets its benchmark at 55% of patients receiving day case or inpatient treatment within 13 weeks.

The interactive assessment tool was developed collaboratively by Alli Shultes, Rebecca French, Daniel Wainwright, Nick Triggle, Ollie Lux Rigby, Chris Kay, Adam Allen, Avi Holden and Rebecca Wedge-Roberts.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Satellite Tech to Monitor Vital Antarctic Krill Populations
fields.summary: Researchers are pioneering satellite technology to track Antarctic krill populations through ocean color analysis, aiming to protect these ecologically vital creatures threatened by climate change and fishing activities.
fields.content:
Scientists have developed a novel approach to monitor Antarctic krill populations from space by detecting subtle variations in seawater color. These tiny crustaceans measure only a few inches yet form a foundational component of the Antarctic ecosystem.

The Critical Role of Krill

Antarctic krill serve as essential nourishment for diverse marine animals including whales, penguins, seals, and seabirds. Conservationists warn these diminutive creatures face significant threats from both climate impacts and commercial fishing, creating an urgent need for improved population monitoring.

Rod Downie, chief polar adviser at WWF-UK, emphasized their importance: "Antarctic krill are the superheroes of the Southern Ocean. They sustain incredible marine life, but climate change and unsustainable fishing are putting them at risk."

Space-Based Surveillance Technology

A research collaboration between the University of Strathclyde, WWF, and the British Antarctic Survey aims to detect krill concentrations through satellites sensitive to light absorption variations in seawater. This innovative method correlates krill density with minute optical changes invisible to the human eye.

WWF A scientist leans over the side of a small boat in Antarctica. The sun is shining and the sea is calm. Icebergs are visible in the background. The scientist is pulling in a sampling net to catch krill for research.

WWF Antarctic krill in a container on board a research vessel. Two small krill swim in turquoise water under laboratory lighting, showing their transparent bodies.

Dr. Cait McCarry from the University of Strathclyde recently conducted fieldwork in Antarctica, where she methodically measured how individual krill alter water's light absorption. Her work involved sequential analysis: "We start with seawater, then add a krill and take measurements. Then we add another krill and measure again." These findings will establish baselines for satellite monitoring.

Ecosystem Impacts and Conservation

Krill form the basis of a critical environmental cycle: they consume microscopic plants within sea ice that absorb atmospheric carbon. These plants regrow through nutrients released from whale excrement after whales consume vast quantities of krill, contributing significantly to carbon sequestration.

Victoria Gill/BBC A humpback whale's tail emerges from Antarctic waters as it hunts krill amidst sea ice.

With rising ocean temperatures disrupting this delicate balance, conservationists advocate stronger protective measures. Downie stressed: "We urgently need better fishery management and marine protected areas for krill habitats. This satellite project offers a new tool to monitor and safeguard this vital species.”

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Paddy Power and Betfair Users Alerted to Spear Phishing Risks After Massive Data Breach
fields.summary: Flutter Entertainment has alerted up to 800,000 Paddy Power and Betfair customers about a data breach compromising email addresses and online activity data, warning users to remain vigilant against sophisticated spear phishing attacks that could exploit the stolen information.
fields.content:
Users of gambling platforms Paddy Power and Betfair have been alerted to security risks following a data breach affecting approximately 800,000 accounts. Parent company Flutter Entertainment confirmed the cybersecurity incident, stating some personal details were compromised.

The compromised information includes users' IP addresses, email addresses, and online activity data. Flutter assured customers that sensitive details like passwords, identification documents, and payment information remained unaffected.

In communications to affected users, the company stated: "There is nothing you need to do in response to this incident, however we recommend you remain vigilant." The breach has reportedly been contained following the discovery.

Cybersecurity specialists warned the stolen data could fuel targeted spear phishing attacks. Harley Morlet, chief marketing officer at Storm Guidance, explained that AI technology enables large-scale automated scams, noting: "It would be very easy to craft messages that look appealing to gamblers, particularly those spending significant sums."

Tim Rawlins from security firm NCC Group advised customers to scrutinize suspicious emails referencing past betting behavior: "If it seems too good to be true, it's probably a fraudster. Watch for requests to re-enter credit card or bank details." He emphasized that AI-generated phishing attempts have become increasingly sophisticated and difficult to distinguish from legitimate communications.

Flutter Entertainment, which also operates Sky Bet and Tombola, serves approximately 4.2 million monthly users across the UK and Ireland.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Man convicted of double murder after dismembering victims, dumping remains in suitcases
fields.summary: Yostin Mosquera has been found guilty of murdering two men in London, dismembering their bodies, and attempting to dispose of the remains in suitcases at Bristol's Clifton Suspension Bridge. The victims, who had been civil partners, were killed in what prosecutors described as a premeditated attack.
fields.content:
Yostin Mosquera has been convicted of murdering two men whose dismembered remains were discovered in suitcases left on Bristol's Clifton Suspension Bridge. The Colombian national killed Paul Longworth, 71, and Albert Alfonso, 62, while staying at their London flat on 8 July 2024.

Police revealed Mosquera decapitated and dismembered both men after the killings. He froze some body parts while transporting others from London to Bristol in suitcases intended to be thrown from the famous landmark. At Woolwich Crown Court, Mr Justice Bennathan described jurors as having witnessed terrible, brutal events during the trial that featured disturbing video footage.

The court heard that Mr Alfonso had engaged in extreme sexual practices and knew Mosquera from online interactions dating back to 2012. Both victims became civil partners in 2023 around the time Mosquera first visited them in London. Though they later separated, the pair remained close friends.

Metropolitan Police Mr Longworth, left, and Mr Alfonso, right, smile at the camera. They are both holding green bottles of Stella and wearing red vest tops with blue and white graphics on them. They are sitting at what appears to be an outdoor bar or restaurant, overlooking a view.

During Mosquera's July return to London, he stabbed Alfonso to death in a filmed sex session. Court evidence showed the defendant singing and dancing afterward. Earlier that day, he fatally attacked Longworth with a hammer, shattering his skull and hiding the body.

Prosecutors said Mosquera meticulously planned the disposal of remains through the bridge dumping, though he abandoned the suitcases there after underestimating the required strength. Mosquera admitted killing Alfonso but claimed manslaughter through loss of control, pleading not guilty to both murders while blaming Alfonso for Longworth's death.

The defendant claimed self-defense, alleging threats against his Colombian family. After the jury delivered guilty verdicts within five hours, the judge delayed sentencing until 24 October pending psychiatric reports, confirming life imprisonment will be imposed. Detective Chief Inspector Ollie Stride called it one of the Met Police's most harrowing cases, describing how the victims were murdered in their home in a brutal and callous manner.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: China Commences World's Largest Dam Project Amid Downstream Fears
fields.summary: China has initiated construction of the world's largest hydropower dam on Tibet's Yarlung Tsangpo river, sparking significant concerns from India and Bangladesh about ecological impacts and water security downstream. The $167 billion project would dramatically exceed the Three Gorges Dam's energy output if completed.
fields.content:
Construction has officially started on what is planned to become the world's largest hydroelectric dam in China's Tibetan region. Premier Li Qiang oversaw the ceremony launching the project along the Yarlung Tsangpo river according to state media reports.

The dam complex, estimated to cost 1.2 trillion yuan ($167 billion), has raised substantial concerns in downstream nations India and Bangladesh due to its potential impact on communities and ecosystems. The river is vital downstream as it flows into India's Arunachal Pradesh and Assam before reaching Bangladesh.

Project Launch and Regional Concerns

Indian officials have expressed serious worries about China's potential ability to control transboundary river flows. Arunachal Pradesh Chief Minister Pema Khandu described the dam as an "existential threat" to local tribes, warning that sudden water releases could act as a "water bomb" devastating communities.

India has formally raised its concerns with Beijing, urging China to protect downstream interests through consultation and transparency. As a countermeasure, India plans its own hydroelectric project on the Siang river to mitigate potential flooding from Chinese water releases.

Engineering the Mega-Dam

Aerial view of Yarlung Tsangpo river bend with surrounding mountains

The dam will exploit one of the planet's steepest river drops through the world's deepest land canyon, where the Yarlung Tsangpo forms a dramatic U-turn encircling Namcha Barwa mountain. Chinese engineers reportedly plan to construct five cascading power stations by drilling lengthy tunnels through mountains and diverting water.

Hydropower generated will primarily supply China's populous eastern regions under President Xi Jinping's "xidiandongsong" policy aimed at transferring western electricity eastward. State media describes the project as both ecologically responsible and economically beneficial for Tibetans.

Environmental and Social Implications

Bangladesh has officially requested project details from Beijing amid concerns about downstream water impacts. Environmentalists warn the scheme threatens biodiversity in one of Asia's most ecologically rich regions and risks catastrophic consequences due to dam construction along active earthquake fault lines.

The project has drawn fierce opposition from Tibetan communities. Last year, Chinese authorities suppressed protests against another regional dam with arrests and violence that left protesters injured according to verified reports.

A previous version of this story misstated the estimated cost as $1.67 billion. The correct figure is $167 billion.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Warns Future Pensioners Face Significant Income Shortfall
fields.summary: The UK government warns that retirees in 2050 face being £800 worse off annually than current pensioners unless retirement savings improve, as almost half of working-age adults contribute nothing to private pensions. A revived Pensions Commission will address savings gaps affecting low earners, women, and minority groups.
fields.content:
Individuals retiring in 2050 could experience an 8% annual income reduction compared to today's pensioners, equating to around £800 less per year, according to new government analysis. The Department for Work and Pensions reports that four in ten people aren't saving adequately for retirement, prompting the reestablishment of the Pensions Commission to tackle the savings crisis.

The state pension age remains on track to reach 68 by 2046, while two new independent reviews examine potential adjustments. Officials highlight concerning trends: 48% of working-age adults save nothing for retirement through private pensions, with participation dropping further among low-income workers, women, self-employed individuals, and ethnic minority groups.

Alarming disparities have been documented, including a 48% gender gap in private pension wealth. Women typically receive just over £100 weekly from private pensions versus men's £200. Only one in four people of Pakistani or Bangladeshi heritage actively contribute to private pensions.

In response, ministers are reviving the Turner Pension Commission that produced landmark reforms including automatic enrolment under the last Labour administration in 2006. Since auto-enrolment's implementation pension participation among eligible workers rose sharply from 55% in 2012 to 88% today.

The rebooted commission will examine obstacles to retirement saving and develop strategies with unions, employers, and experts. Trades Union Congress leader Paul Nowak endorsed this as 'a vital step forward' toward ensuring retirement security.

Income in retirement

Age UK emphasized that while state pensions form most retirees' primary income, private savings play an essential role in preventing hardship. Caroline Abrahams highlighted the urgency of supporting vulnerable groups: 'Particularly disadvantaged groups, including low-paid women and self-employed people on low incomes, need help to save when possible.'

Retirement income benchmarks published by the Pensions and Lifetime Savings Association indicate that a single person requires £13,400 annually for basic needs or £31,700 for moderate comfort. Couples need £21,600 for essentials and £43,900 for moderate living standards.

Catherine Foot of the Standard Life Centre revealed that 17 million people aren't saving sufficiently for their envisioned retirement, cautioning that 'the effects will start to bite' over the next twenty years. Pension firms like Aegon urged the commission to propose substantial auto-enrolment contribution hikes after 2029.

Royal London's Barry O'Dwyer acknowledged that higher pension contributions might impact salaries, stating: 'The money has to come from somewhere. But gradual increases over a decade could minimize the burden.'

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Government Proposes New Law to Target Violence-Obsessed Suspects
fields.summary: The UK government is introducing a new criminal offence to tackle suspected individuals who prepare violent attacks without ideological motivations, closing a legal gap. Home Secretary Yvette Cooper announced the measure following the Southport mass stabbing, allowing police to intervene earlier against non-terrorist plotters.
fields.content:
A powerful new criminal offence will target suspects discovered preparing mass killings without ideological motivations, ensuring their plotting is treated as seriously as terrorism, Home Secretary Yvette Cooper has confirmed. This legislative change addresses violence-obsessed individuals in the wake of last year's Southport attack during a children's dance class.

The current legal framework imposes life sentences on terror suspects taking preparatory steps for attacks, such as target research. However, authorities cannot apply these severe charges against perpetrators lacking ideological motives tied to banned terrorist groups.

Reuters Yvette Cooper in Parliament

Cooper stated authorities will "close the gap" in legislation to detain potential attackers earlier. Axel Rudakubana, who murdered three girls and injured ten others during a Taylor Swift-themed event in Southport, exemplified this vulnerability. Police couldn't have charged him with serious offences had they discovered his target research beforehand due to his lack of ideological motivation.

"There is a gap in the law around the planning of mass attacks that can be just as serious in their implications for communities, their impact, the devastation that they can cause and the seriousness of the crime," Cooper explained. Authorities will now treat such cases with equal severity to terrorism.

Youtube Nicholas Prosper seen wearing a yellow bucket hat.

The proposed offence follows legislation introduced after London's 2005 bombings that addressed terrorist preparations requiring ideological links. The new framework applies more broadly, covering individuals like Nicholas Prosper - who planned a school shooting before murdering his family. Cooper highlighted concerns about adolescents radicalizing themselves online, exposed to "a really distorted and warped online world" leading to non-ideological violence.

This measure forms part of efforts to balance responses between emerging non-ideological threats and traditional extremist dangers. The announcement was made during BBC Radio 4's series examining terrorism responses since the 7/7 attacks twenty years ago.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Martin Frizell Opens Up on Isolation After Fiona Phillips' Alzheimer's Diagnosis
fields.summary: Martin Frizell reveals the profound social isolation experienced since his wife Fiona Phillips was diagnosed with young-onset Alzheimer's, describing how friends withdrew and discussing both personal challenges and systemic shortcomings in dementia support.
fields.content:
Martin Frizell, husband of renowned TV presenter Fiona Phillips, has disclosed the isolating impact of her Alzheimer's diagnosis on their lives. In a candid interview, he described feeling 'almost invisible' as social circles diminished following her illness. Frizell suggested acquaintances might feel uncomfortable or confronted by the disease's visibility.

Phillips, who hosted ITV's GMTV for 15 years, announced her diagnosis in 2023 after recognizing symptoms that began the previous year. At the time of diagnosis, she was 61—considerably younger than typical Alzheimer's patients. She initially attributed her brain fog and anxiety to menopause before medical assessments revealed the neurodegenerative condition.

The couple maintains some close friendships, but Frizell observed societal withdrawal: 'People think, oh gosh, Fiona, maybe she doesn't look the same, or they don't know what to say.' Daily life has transformed significantly, with Phillips abandoning cooking entirely amid changing habits. 'She hasn't cooked in two years,' Frizell noted wistfully.

Personal effects now carry emotional weight—her cookbooks lie unused, while designer clothes remain unworn. 'Part of the heartache is she's got this dressing room full of amazing clothes, but she's content wearing the same T-shirt and trousers daily,' Frizell explained. Phillips is releasing a memoir this week documenting her journey.

Frizell contributed extensively to the memoir after planning brief remarks, ultimately writing 24,000 words detailing his admiration for his wife and frustration with inadequate Alzheimer's support systems. 'As a family we get through it, but there's just nothing really available to help us,' he said. Phillips has deep familial ties to the disease: both parents and an uncle had dementia, and she previously created documentaries about caring for her parents.

Alzheimer's, the UK's leading cause of dementia, involves progressive brain function decline without current cure. The NHS reports approximately one in three UK-born individuals may develop dementia. Addressing broader societal responses, Frizell criticized funding levels: 'Research investment is like trying to fight this disease with the price of a coffee. Society hasn't taken it seriously enough.'

Following her GMTV tenure from 1993-2008, Phillips contributed to Panorama documentaries and wrote for the Mirror—a career now halted by her condition. Frizell previously edited ITV's This Morning and appeared on the show to amplify his call for greater Alzheimer's awareness and resources.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Council Ordered to Pay £2,000 Over Child's Missed Education
fields.summary: Cumberland Council has been ordered to pay £2,000 compensation after failing to provide education for a child with special needs for two school terms. The Local Government Ombudsman ruled the council neglected to update the child's care plan or arrange proper alternative schooling.
fields.content:
Cumberland Council must pay £2,000 compensation after a child with special educational needs missed two terms of education. The Local Government and Social Care Ombudsman upheld a complaint from the child's mother after the council failed to review necessary support provisions.

An official report stated the council did not secure educational support outlined in the child's health and care plan between September 2024 and April 2025. Authorities also failed to arrange suitable alternative provision during this period after the child, referred to as Y, struggled to attend their special school from April 2024 onward.

Though the council organized out-of-school tuition initially, a subsequent draft health and care plan incorrectly continued naming the original school as Y's placement. After family complaints, the council promised changes to the document.

'This was fault'

By October 2024, Y stopped receiving tuition due to engagement difficulties, while council records showed officials requested a review by a specialist teacher. When no final care plan or educational provision materialized by February 2025, the family lodged a formal complaint with the ombudsman.

"There is little evidence of the council reviewing Y's progress or acting on [the mother's] concerns. This was fault," the ombudsman determined. Investigators found that when both the school placement and alternative provision failed, the council neglected required interim reviews, leaving Y with an outdated support plan.

The council has agreed to apologize to the family and revise its interim care plan procedures. Compensation includes £1,800 for the lost education and £200 for the resulting uncertainty.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Record Sewage Spills Threaten England's Waterways and Health
fields.summary: England saw raw sewage spilled into rivers and seas for a record 3.6 million hours in 2024, endangering wildlife and public health according to new data. As regulatory proposals and infrastructure upgrades emerge, concerns grow over water quality across UK regions.
fields.content:
How much sewage is released into the seas and rivers in England?

In 2024, water companies discharged raw sewage into England's lakes, rivers and seas for 3.6 million hours – a slight increase from 2023 but with longer average spill durations despite fewer incidents. Pollution incidents hit record levels this year, including 75 serious cases threatening human and aquatic health, with Thames Water accounting for 33. Industry group Water UK called spills "unacceptable" while outlining infrastructure upgrade plans. Wales saw an 11% decrease in spill hours but pollution incidents reached a 10-year peak. Northern Ireland lacks real-time spill monitoring, while Scotland tracks just 27% of potential overflow sites.

Why is sewage released into the sea and rivers?

Most UK regions rely on combined sewer systems transporting both rainwater and household wastewater through shared pipes. During intense rainfall – especially when dry ground cannot absorb water – treatment plants may be overwhelmed, potentially flooding homes and streets. To prevent this, systems deliberately release excess water and sewage into waterways via combined sewer overflows designed for such emergency discharges.

What is a dry spill?

Dry spills occur when sewage discharges happen without heavy rainfall, violating permit conditions. Regulator Ofwat attributes this to poor wastewater treatment plant management, causing pre-treatment overflows. Investigations revealed approximately 6,000 potential dry spills across England in 2022. Even during rainfall, permits mandate companies treat minimum sewage volumes before release.

Diagram comparing illegal dry spills, normal operations, and rain-triggered legal sewage discharge processes

What is being done to tackle sewage discharges?

Aging infrastructure tops identified causes, prompting regulatory approval for £104bn in water company upgrades across England and Wales over five years, including £20bn targeting sewage spills – termed by Water UK as the "most ambitious modernisation of sewers since the Victorian era". Critics contrast infrastructure investment against rising customer bills and shareholder dividends. The Independent Water Commission proposed 88 reforms featuring stricter monitoring, regulation and penalties, chaired by former Bank of England deputy Sir Jon Cunliffe.

What are the health risks of swimming in polluted water?

Scientists warn mounting public health dangers from human faeces contamination in rivers, potentially exposing swimmers to bacteria like salmonella and E.coli causing gastrointestinal illness, or hepatitis A leading to liver infections. Regular water quality testing was recommended in a 2024 report.

Rowers competing in a scull with significant water splash under sunny conditions

How can I check if the sea near me is clean?

The Environment Agency measures water quality weekly at designated English bathing sites from May-September, issuing daily pollution alerts online. Similar services operate in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. Water UK's National Storm Overflow Hub provides near real-time discharge notifications across England's overflow points, though it excludes data on contamination volumes or pathogens.

How clean are UK waters overall?

Sewage spill records are recent, making historical trends difficult to assess. General water quality monitoring spanning decades also tracks agricultural pollution. In England, only 16% of rivers, lakes, estuaries and coastal waters gained "good" ecological status. Results elsewhere show Scotland leads with 66% good status, followed by Wales (40%) and Northern Ireland (31%).

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Regulator Calls for YouTube Boost to Support Public Broadcasters
fields.summary: UK media regulator Ofcom urges YouTube to prioritize content from public service broadcasters like BBC and ITV, warning that children's preference for the platform poses a "serious threat" to traditional broadcasting. The proposal includes potential legislation to ensure prominence for UK-made news and children's programming.
fields.content:
Media regulator Ofcom has recommended that YouTube should promote videos from UK public service broadcasters to address a critical challenge facing the industry. The call emphasizes the need to better showcase content from channels including the BBC, ITV, Channel 4, and others on the digital platform.

Recent findings reveal children spend considerably more time watching YouTube than all UK public service broadcasters combined. Ofcom's report cautions this trend threatens the future of public service media if younger audiences don't engage with traditional broadcast content as they mature.

The regulator proposed broadcasters should immediately collaborate with YouTube to ensure their programming becomes more visible and accessible to viewers. It further suggested the government might need to introduce legislation to enforce such digital prominence.

Public service broadcasters themselves must intensify efforts to develop compelling content suitable for online platforms, according to Ofcom. The designated public service entities include BBC, ITV, STV, Channel 4, S4C, and Channel 5.

"If children do not turn to PSB content as they get older, the future of public service media is at risk," states Ofcom's comprehensive review. Specifically, YouTube should elevate UK-produced news and children's programming, with data showing only 20% of content viewed on YouTube in the UK is domestically created.

'Proud tradition'

Ofcom highlighted the enduring value of UK public service media, noting it delivers trustworthy impartial news and culturally relevant programming that unites audiences. However, the system now faces unprecedented challenges from expanding viewer choices, severe financial pressures, and fundamental shifts in advertising markets.

These conditions make it increasingly difficult for broadcasters to finance and distribute high-caliber British content nationwide. Ofcom outlined a six-point strategy that includes appealing for government funding support for specialized programming like news and children's content.

Sarah Rose of Channel 5 welcomed Ofcom's recognition of funding challenges for children's programming. The regulator additionally announced plans to modernize television and radio regulations to better fit digital consumption patterns.

Ofcom also sought urgent clarity on whether digital terrestrial television services, currently enabling Freeview, will continue beyond 2034. The Department for Culture, Media and Sport confirmed it would evaluate Ofcom's recommendations.

YouTube hasn't yet responded to the proposal. Channel 4's interim chief Jonathan Allan endorsed Ofcom's call for bold intervention, while ITV emphasized the importance of resolving future distribution models for online TV content.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Russia Launches Intense Strikes on Ukraine Ahead of Key NATO Meeting
fields.summary: Russia launched over 420 drones and 20 missiles across Ukraine overnight, killing two people and injuring 15, as NATO allies prepared to discuss President Trump's plan for expedited weapons transfers to bolster Ukraine's defenses.
fields.content:
Russian forces bombarded Ukrainian cities overnight into Monday with a barrage of over 420 drones and more than 20 missiles, including ballistic weapons.
