The sustained attacks targeted Kyiv, Kharkiv, Ivano-Frankivsk, and surrounding areas, resulting in two deaths and 15 injuries, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy confirmed.

Zelenskyy detailed the destruction to civilian infrastructure: "Russian strikes are always an assault on humanity — in Kyiv, a kindergarten caught fire, along with residential buildings and other civilian infrastructure. Ordinary apartment buildings were damaged. Everyone is receiving assistance. Two people were killed in the attack." The youngest victim was a 12-year-old boy.

The Ukrainian defenses, including mobile fire groups, army aviation, electronic warfare units, and interceptor drones, actively engaged the threats throughout the night and into morning. Zelenskyy stated: "Many targets were shot down — but unfortunately, not all. That is why we must continue scaling up our interceptor capabilities to protect us from massive attacks."

Firefighters work in destroyed building in Ukraine

The attacks coincided with preparations for a key virtual Ukraine Defense Contact Group meeting. NATO Secretary General Mark Rutte was scheduled to participate, following his recent meeting with U.S. President Donald Trump where they announced a major arms transfer initiative. Trump had pledged swift battlefield delivery of weapons purchased by NATO allies for Ukraine.

UK Defense Secretary John Healey expressed strong support for the plan ahead of the meeting: "Last week, President Trump announced a new policy for large scale NATO weapons transfers and committed to getting these 'quickly distributed to the battlefield.' The UK government backs this policy, and we will play our full part in its success to bolster Ukraine’s immediate fight and support wider European security."

Russian drones strike Kyiv, Ukraine

Meanwhile, Russia's Defense Ministry claimed its forces had successfully intercepted 74 Ukrainian drones during the overnight operations, according to The Associated Press.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Democrats Hit Record Low Approval One Year After Biden's 2024 Exit
fields.summary: One year after President Biden's withdrawal from the 2024 presidential race, the Democratic Party faces historically low approval ratings and electoral setbacks. Recent polls by CNN and Quinnipiac University reveal record disapproval of Congressional Democrats amid continued Republican control of Washington.
fields.content:
One year following President Joe Biden's unexpected departure from the 2024 presidential race, the Democratic Party confronts unprecedented public disapproval. After losing the presidency, the Senate, and failing to regain House control during the election, Democrats have seen their political standing significantly diminished.

Then-Vice President Kamala Harris delivers her presidential nomination acceptance speech at the Democratic National Convention, on August 22, 2024 in Chicago, Illinois

Recent polling paints a dire picture for the party. CNN's July survey revealed only 28% of Americans hold favorable views of Democrats—the lowest rating in the network's 30-year polling history. A Quinnipiac University poll confirmed this trend with just 19% voter approval of Democrats in Congress, marking an all-time low since they began tracking congressional approval.

Democratic Discontent

Internal party dissatisfaction is pronounced, with 52% of Democratic voters disapproving of their elected officials' performance according to Quinnipiac's July 10-14 survey. Only 39% expressed approval, while 9% offered no opinion. Analyst Tim Malloy described Democratic approval as "flat out terrible," attributing this to continued losses among Black, Hispanic, and young voters alongside criticisms over insufficient opposition to President Trump.

Schumer, left, next to Jeffries

Republican Challenges

While Republicans fare relatively better, their approval remains problematic. Only 33% of voters nationwide approve of Republican lawmakers' performance, with 62% expressing disapproval. However, the GOP maintains stronger internal support—77% of Republican voters approve of their congressional representatives. In CNN's survey, the Republican Party held a 33% favorability rating.

Trump's Approval Status

President Trump's approval ratings continue to face challenges. His approval stands at 40% with 54% disapproval in the Quinnipiac poll and 44%-56% in CNN's survey. Despite initial positive ratings at his second inauguration, Trump has recorded negative approval in 13 of 17 July polls.

Trump motions during Cabinet meeting

Midterm Motivation

A glimmer of hope for Democrats comes from voter engagement numbers. Seventy-two percent of Democrats and party-aligned independents expressed strong motivation for the 2026 midterms—surpassing Republican enthusiasm by 22 points. This engagement may prove crucial as Republicans defend narrow House and Senate majorities.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Long Island Parishes Bring Sunday Mass to the Beach
fields.summary: Three Catholic parishes on Long Island have held open-air Mass services at local beaches every Sunday since 2014, attracting over 1,000 weekly attendees and nearly 50,000 participants overall. The initiative brings worship beyond church walls, creating community engagement and overcoming barriers to public expressions of faith.
fields.content:
Three Catholic parishes in Long Island, New York, have transformed local beaches into sacred spaces by holding weekly outdoor Mass services since 2014. Known collectively as Beach Catholic, the initiative draws over 1,000 attendees each Sunday to shoreline locations across St. Ignatius Martyr, St. Mary of The Isle, and Our Lady of The Miracul Medal parishes.

Catholic parishioners praying during beach Mass

Father Brian Barr, pastor of Beach Catholic, emphasized that faith should transcend physical buildings. "Many people recall feeling uneasy about expressing faith publicly during childhood—I certainly did," Barr explained. "Bringing the Eucharist, our most important prayer, to shared spaces like beaches directly confronts those fears. Repeated exposure helps overcome discomfort."

The ministry has made a profound impact on regular participants like Tim Murphy, who has attended since its inception. "This gathering transformed my life—my wife and I met here, leading to our son's birth," Murphy said. "Seeing hundreds unite for worship against ocean waves creates a powerful once-in-a-lifetime spiritual encounter."

Attendees celebrating Mass near the shoreline

Parishioner Dee Santos highlighted how these services engage curious beachgoers. Last week, 1,200 people received communion after one passerby inquired about the gathering and stayed to participate. "This natural setting—God's gift—allows us to worship where unexpected visitors might join," Santos noted. "It creates conversations with people who'd never witness our faith within church walls."

Organizers report cumulative attendance exceeding 50,000 over the past decade. The Masses serve as public demonstrations of spirituality while adapting traditional worship to accessible summer settings, where community participation continues to expand each year.

Group worship under beach skies

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump and Ohio Lawmaker Push for Guardians and Commanders to Revert to Former Names
fields.summary: Former President Donald Trump and Ohio State Representative Brian Lorenz are advocating for the Cleveland Guardians and Washington Commanders to revert to their former names, the Indians and Redskins, citing cultural heritage and fan sentiment. Trump has threatened consequences for the Commanders' stadium plans if they refuse to comply.
fields.content:
Ohio State Republican Representative Brian Lorenz has endorsed former President Donald Trump's call for Cleveland's baseball team to change its name back from the Guardians to the Indians. Lorenz emphasized the emotional connection fans have with the former identity in a social media post.

"You don’t mess with Chief Wahoo and expect Cleveland to forget," Lorenz stated. "The Cleveland Indians weren’t just a team — they were summer nights, family memories, heartbreaks, and miracles. We didn’t change because fans asked — we changed because elites told us to. Time to bring back what made us us."

Indians fan in April 2024

Trump initiated the push through social media, asserting widespread demand for both Cleveland and Washington's football team to revert to their previous names. He specifically targeted the Commanders, writing: "The Washington ‘Whatever’s’ should IMMEDIATELY change their name back to the Washington Redskins Football Team. There is a big clamoring for this."

Regarding Cleveland's team, Trump added: "Likewise, the Cleveland Indians, one of the six original baseball teams, with a storied past. Our great Indian people, in massive numbers, want this to happen. Their heritage and prestige is systematically being taken away from them." He concluded with a call to action: "OWNERS, GET IT DONE!!!" Times are different now than they were three or four years ago. We are a Country of passion and common sense.

Josh Harris and Trump in May

Trump later escalated pressure by threatening the Commanders' stadium developments: "I may put a restriction on them that if they don’t change the name back... I won’t make a deal for them to build a Stadium in Washington." He claimed the team would gain value by reverting.

For Cleveland, Trump criticized Guardians minority owner Matt Dolan's political record, stating: "He has lost three Elections in a row because of that ridiculous name change." He coined the phrase "MAKE INDIANS GREAT AGAIN (MIGA)" and asserted that Native Americans were "treated very unfairly" by the name changes.

Historically, Cleveland's baseball team operated as the Indians from 1915 through the 2021 season after previous names including the Naps and Napoleons. Owner Paul Dolan attributed the name change to an "awakening or epiphany" following the death of George Floyd.

Responding to Trump's pressure, Guardians President Chris Antonetti indicated the organization wasn't considering a name reversal. The team declined further comment when approached by media outlets.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: KR1: The Autonomous Humanoid Robot Revolutionizing Warehouse Automation
fields.summary: Kinisi Robotics unveils its autonomous humanoid robot KR1, designed for warehouse efficiency with advanced AI learning, physical strength, precision handling capabilities, and local data processing. Operating without cloud dependency, this wheeled robot promises minimal downtime while tackling repetitive logistics tasks.
fields.content:
Warehouse work involves intense, repetitive, and physically demanding tasks. U.S.-based Kinisi Robotics addresses these challenges with its autonomous humanoid robot, the Kinisi 01 or KR1. Designed specifically for warehouse environments, KR1 moves, lifts, and processes information with human-like capability but enhanced speed and reliability. This robot excels at complex pick-and-place operations, navigating floors to select items from shelves with remarkable precision while handling both heavy boxes and delicate products.

Engineering strength and precision

Kinisi developed KR1 to thrive in industrial settings with 22-pound lifting capacity through dual-arm design. Its sturdy construction and careful engineering enable safe retrieval from high shelves and handling of breakable goods without damage. The robot moves smoothly on wheeled bases across standard warehouse floors—a deliberate alternative to more complex legged systems that ensures stability and simpler setup. Operating up to 8 hours per charge, KR1 features hot-swappable batteries and an auto-docking system for rapid recharging with minimal human oversight, ideal for high-demand fulfillment centers where downtime is costly.

The Kinisi 01, known as KR1, demonstrates its capabilities in a warehouse setting

Intelligent autonomous learning

Beyond physical capabilities, KR1 utilizes built-in AI that learns and adapts in real-time. It recognizes obstacles, adjusts arm movements dynamically, and executes precise trajectories even as warehouse layouts change—reducing the need for reprogramming during workflow shifts. Its most impressive feature is task learning through observation: after a single demonstration by staff, KR1 replicates actions accurately without complex coding. A demonstration showed the robot moving autonomously through a warehouse to select items from shelves, place them in containers, and deliver them to destinations while avoiding obstacles.

Offline functionality advantage

Unlike cloud-dependent robots, KR1 processes data locally, enabling reliable operation in areas with weak internet connectivity. This approach improves response times and enhances data privacy. The local processing allows split-second decision-making during network disruptions—essential for maintaining efficiency in fast-paced logistics operations.

Diverse industrial applications

While optimized for logistics, KR1's design extends to retail stocking, light manufacturing, and maintenance work. Kinisi engineered the robot to integrate seamlessly into existing workflows without requiring costly infrastructure changes. By combining physical strength with learning abilities, it handles accuracy-dependent repetitive tasks—helping companies reduce labor expenses, improve workplace safety, and increase operational flexibility.

KR1's adaptable design enables multi-industry applications beyond warehousing

Subscription-based economic model

At the Automate 2025 event, Kinisi CEO Brennand Pierce announced KR1 costs approximately $4,000 monthly via subscription—likely covering the robot, its AI, and support services. This approach enables small-to-midsize warehouses to adopt automation without major upfront investments or infrastructure overhauls. Though exact inclusions remain unconfirmed, the model offers a scalable, low-risk solution for teams seeking rapid productivity gains.

The autonomous workforce evolution

Kinisi's KR1 embodies the future of industrial work where robots function with human-like dexterity, cognitive ability, and learning speed. Combining rapid deployment advantages, minimal maintenance requirements, and powerful onboard intelligence, it presents a compelling solution for fast-expanding automation demands. This technological shift prompts consideration about the evolving relationship between human workers and intelligent machines in industrial environments.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: The 30-Day Challenge to Reduce Your Sugar Intake
fields.summary: A structured 30-day program offers a gradual approach to reducing sugar consumption, aiming to help individuals overcome cravings while addressing health risks linked to excessive sugar intake like diabetes and inflammation.
fields.content:
A pain-free strategy for cutting back on sweeteners in your daily meals.

When aiming to consume less sugar, people often consider abrupt elimination. However, a gradual 30-day plan presents a more sustainable alternative to reduce intake without severe cravings or deprivation.

Headshot of Karen Ansel, MS, RD

Health Implications of Excess Sugar

Reducing sugar isn't merely about cutting empty calories. Scientific studies indicate that consistent high sugar consumption elevates risks for diabetes, high cholesterol, hypertension, and inflammation. The 30-day program introduces daily manageable adjustments that collectively lead to significant long-term reduction.

Ubiquitous Sugar in Modern Diets

Sugar permeates countless food products beyond obvious sweets. It appears in breakfast staples like bread, savory items including pasta sauces and crackers, and extends through snacks and desserts. This hidden prevalence makes inadvertent overconsumption common.

Members of specialized wellness programs gain access to comprehensive dietary resources including a detailed PDF guide for this sugar-reduction challenge featuring nutrition strategies.

This widespread availability means reducing intake is more achievable than many anticipate, particularly when following a structured 30-day approach that simplifies incremental changes.

Access the complete 30-Day Eat Less Sugar Challenge plan here.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: French NGO Accuses Russia of Systematic Cultural Plundering in Ukraine Before ICC
fields.summary: A French nonprofit has filed a case with the International Criminal Court alleging Russia systematically looted Ukrainian cultural heritage sites during the invasion, seeking arrest warrants for Vladimir Putin and eight officials in what it calls Europe's largest cultural plunder since WWII.
fields.content:
The organization For Ukraine, For Their Freedom and Ours! submitted a formal complaint to the International Criminal Court on July 11, documenting what it describes as Russia's deliberate destruction and theft of Ukrainian cultural properties. The French nonprofit asserts that Moscow orchestrated a state-level campaign to erase Ukraine's cultural identity, demanding arrest warrants for President Vladimir Putin and eight senior officials.

Evidence compiled by UNESCO confirms 501 cultural sites have been damaged since Russia's 2022 invasion, including 262 historically significant buildings, 151 religious sites, 34 museums, and numerous monuments and libraries. The group contends this represents the most extensive pillaging of European cultural heritage during armed conflict since World War II. Christian Castagna, the nonprofit's advocacy manager, expressed confidence in the strength of their legal submission to ICC prosecutors.

This marks the organization's second major ICC initiative, following their 2023 campaign that resulted in arrest warrants for Putin regarding forced deportations of Ukrainian children. While those warrants aided in repatriating nearly 400 of 19,546 abducted minors according to Ukraine's human rights commissioner, Russian authorities maintain they're protecting children from conflict zones. Castagna emphasized similarities between the child deportation case and the cultural looting allegations, noting both involved methodical documentation of systematic crimes.

Earlier in May, Castagna spearheaded demands for the International Council of Museums to expel Russia for violating ethical codes, threatening legal action in France if they refused. He described Russia's cultural erasure of Ukraine as a neo-colonialist project that museums should officially condemn. Despite concerns about mixing politics with cultural work, the group urges cultural institutions to confront Russia's actions, framing the situation as requiring ethical courage.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: WW1 Warship HMS Nottingham Found After 109 Years in North Sea
fields.summary: A diving team has discovered the wreckage of World War One British warship HMS Nottingham, sunk by a German submarine in 1916. The vessel was located at a depth of 82 meters near Scotland, solving a century-long maritime mystery.
fields.content:
Divers have located the remains of the Royal Navy cruiser HMS Nottingham in the North Sea, over a century after it was torpedoed during World War One. The discovery comes 109 years after the warship sank approximately 60 miles off the Scottish coast.

An international diving team from ProjectXplore identified the 457-foot-long vessel during a recent expedition. Research coordinator Steffen Scholz confirmed the identity based on name stamps, ship dimensions, equipment features, and historical records matching the 1916 attack.

HMS Nottingham sank on August 19, 1916, after being struck three times on its port side by a German U-boat. Thirty-eight crew members perished in the attack, though the captain, 20 officers, and 357 sailors were rescued by nearby British destroyers.

A crucial identification clue came from white dinner plates bearing the Royal Navy's blue crown emblem. Divers also found "Nottingham" embossed on the stern, removing any doubt about the wreck's identity.

The German submarine responsible had been spotted earlier that day but was mistaken by a crew member for a small fishing vessel before launching its attack.

Divers illuminating a gun turret on the wreckage of HMS Nottingham.

Divers examining rigging and twisted metal on the sunken warship covered in marine growth.

Previous attempts to find the wreck over the past century proved unsuccessful until ProjectXplore's investigation. Starting in September 2024, researchers examined ships' logs, telegrams, and naval charts to narrow the search area.

The team deployed sonar equipment in April 2025, detecting an unidentified wreck matching HMS Nottingham's size and configuration. Subsequent dives confirmed the discovery, locating the ship at 82 meters depth this month.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: The Cosby Show Star Malcolm-Jamal Warner Dies at 54 in Costa Rica
fields.summary: Actor Malcolm-Jamal Warner, renowned for portraying Theodore Huxtable on The Cosby Show, has died at age 54. Authorities confirm he drowned while swimming during a Costa Rican vacation after strong currents pulled him out to sea.
fields.content:
Malcolm-Jamal Warner, acclaimed for his iconic role as Theodore Huxtable on The Cosby Show, has passed away at 54. Reports confirm he died after drowning during a Costa Rican vacation on Sunday.

According to US media and Costa Rican authorities, Warner died after being swept out by sea currents while swimming at Playa Grande beach in Cocles between 14:00 to 14:30 local time when the incident occurred. Costa Rica's Judicial Investigation Agency provided official confirmation of the fatality.

Warner starred for eight years in the classic American sitcom as the son of Bill Cosby's character. Red Cross responders who rushed to assist found him without vital signs.

Local officials stated, "The victim was assisted by people who were at the beach. However, he was declared without vital signs by the staff of the Costa Rican Red Cross." The incident took place in Limón province on Costa Rica's Caribbean coast.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Water Industry Set for Major Reform After Decades of Underinvestment
fields.summary: A landmark review proposes sweeping reforms for England and Wales' water industry, including replacing regulator Ofwat and addressing decades of underinvestment through new environmental standards and funding structures.
fields.content:
A major review has proposed the most significant reforms to England and Wales' water industry since it was privatized over 30 years ago. Commissioned by the government, the report contains 88 recommendations that could fundamentally reshape how the sector operates.

Major Overhaul for Water Sector

Authored by Sir Jon Cunliffe, the review calls for replacing the current regulator Ofwat while strengthening environmental regulations. This comprehensive overhaul addresses widespread criticism of persistent issues like leaking infrastructure and sewage spills into waterways. If fully implemented, these reforms would represent a substantial shift from the current situation where chronic underinvestment has damaged the industry's reputation.

Campaigners respond to anticipated regulatory changes after Ofwat's abolition

Addressing Underinvestment

The review highlights how systemic underinvestment created the sector's current challenges, noting that water infrastructure requires massive spending to address climate change, population growth, aging systems, and tighter environmental standards. For two decades, bills actually decreased in real terms as Ofwat prioritized keeping prices low over infrastructure improvements.

Now, water companies plan over £100 billion in system upgrades over five years, requiring significant bill increases. Structural problems like excessive debts and shareholder payouts that compromised companies including Thames Water would be tackled through minimum capital requirements and powers to block ownership changes against long-term interests.

Regulatory Transformation

The report recommends abolishing Ofwat and adopting approaches similar to telecoms regulator Ofcom, which successfully encouraged ongoing infrastructure investment. Environment Secretary Steve Reed supports reforms to prevent extreme bill hikes caused by catching up on delayed investments. However, the review acknowledges higher bills remain unavoidable for fixing past underinvestment.

Other proposals include compulsory water metering and involving public health officials in water planning. Implementation requires time, but the government is set to use the review as a foundation for sector transformation.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Warwickshire Council Proposes £190k for Political Assistants Amid Criticism
fields.summary: Warwickshire County Council's interim leader proposes hiring three political assistants for up to £190,000 annually, arguing current staff lack 'imaginative ideas,' despite opposition parties calling it wasteful spending during service cuts.
fields.content:
Warwickshire County Council's interim leader, George Finch, has advanced a plan to hire political assistants at an annual cost of up to £190,000. Each assistant would support one of the three largest council parties: Reform UK, the Liberal Democrats, and the Conservatives.

Finch, leading the minority Reform administration, stated council staff have been "unable to help come up with the imaginative ideas" needed to address key challenges. The Liberal Democrats, Labour, and Green Party oppose the expenditure, with Lib Dem leader Jerry Roodhouse insisting funds should go to "front-line services and not on political assistants."

National legislation permits councils to employ up to three assistants—one per group holding over 10% of seats—to "undertake research and provide administrative support" for council functions. While restricted in some communications, they may engage in activities to boost party support.

Combined salaries would range between £151,000 and £190,000. Finch, 19, will present the proposal at a council meeting on Tuesday alongside a vote confirming his leadership. If appointed, he would oversee a £500 million budget and £1.5 billion in assets, becoming one of England's youngest council leaders.

Disagreement over plans

Finch explained: "For years, the council administration has relied on the corporate policy team to come up with innovative ideas. We've found this team unable to bring about the change we were elected for," advocating for a "fresh, bold approach to policy creation."

Roodhouse countered: "I would rather spend £150,000 on family support workers." Green Party leader Jonathan Chilvers called the move hypocritical, noting Reform pledged to cut "wasteful" spending. Labour's Sarah Feeney deemed it "unnecessary" amid service cuts. Conservatives remain undecided.

Update 18 July: An earlier version misstated that each role could cost £190,000; the figure represents the total for all three positions. Information sourced from the Local Democracy Reporting Service.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: NHS and Doctors' Union Clash Over Strike Staffing Safety Concerns
fields.summary: NHS England faces criticism from the British Medical Association over its decision to maintain most non-urgent services during a five-day junior doctors' strike, with doctors warning the staffing plan could endanger patients.
fields.content:
A dispute has emerged between NHS England leaders and the British Medical Association (BMA) regarding medical coverage plans for an upcoming five-day strike by resident doctors. The conflict centers on patient safety protocols during the industrial action beginning Friday at 07:00 BST.

NHS England directives instruct hospitals to cancel non-urgent procedures like hip and knee replacements only in exceptional cases during the strike period. However, union representatives from the BMA warn this approach dangerously stretches staffing resources by requiring non-striking doctors to simultaneously cover both emergency services and routine elective care.

The work stoppage involves approximately 48,000 resident doctors—representing about two-thirds of junior medical staff nationwide. During previous strikes throughout 2023 and 2024, significant cancellation of non-urgent work enabled senior clinicians to focus on maintaining critical emergency care capacity safely.

The new approach introduced under NHS England chief executive Sir Jim Mackey represents a significant operational shift. Officials supporting the policy emphasize that postponing non-urgent treatments also carries patient health implications that require consideration alongside strike impacts.

Following consultations, BMA leaders Dr. Tom Dolphin and Dr. Emma Runswick formally expressed safety concerns to Sir Jim: "Hospital care must adapt to available staffing levels during strikes. Your directive to maintain scheduled non-urgent care spreads medical personnel too thinly for safe operations."

Negotiations between the government and doctors' union continue as the strike deadline approaches. Junior doctors received an average 5.4% salary increase this year following a total 22% rise over the prior two years, yet the BMA contends real-term wages remain approximately 20% below 2008 levels, necessitating full "pay restoration."

Health Secretary Wes Streeting confirmed no additional funding will address this year's pay demands, though discussions explore alternative measures including student loan relief, examination fees, and work condition reforms. Strike cancellation must occur before Wednesday morning to prevent widespread service disruptions after 11 previous strikes led to hundreds of thousands of postponed appointments.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Girlguiding Launches 72 New Badges Including Fandoms and Laughter Tiers
fields.summary: Girlguiding introduces 72 new activity badges—including ones for 'fandoms,' 'laughter,' and 'booktivism'—marking the organization's most significant update in over a century to better align with modern youth interests like conservation and confidence-building.
fields.content:
Girlguiding members can now earn badges for pursuits like embracing "fandoms," becoming "booktivists," and spreading "guiding sparkle" as part of a historic expansion. The 116-year-old organization unveiled 72 new activity awards, representing its broadest update to the program since 2018.

Amanda Azeez, acting CEO, called the update monumental, emphasizing the importance of staying relevant to members' evolving interests. She said the initiative directly responds to girls' requests to include environmental conservation, confidence-building, and contemporary hobbies.

The new badges are tailored to different age groups within the organization. Rainbows (ages 4-7) can earn distinctions for activities like laughter exercises, grooving to music, showing courage, and practicing bee rescue. One young member described how laughter badge activities involved mimicking animal sounds as a group challenge.

Brownies (7-10) can pursue newfound interests like folklore studies and birdwatching and earn a badge for discovering how to make their voices heard. Guides (10-14) unlock the "thrift" badge by creating new items through upcycling old materials.

For Rangers (14-18), a dedicated "fandoms" badge celebrates enthusiasm for cultural phenomena like Taylor Swift or Harry Potter, while the "booktivism" badge focuses on how reading empowers social change. Additional badges range from codebreaking and engineering to friendship, history, and interior design.

Girlguiding Girls doing an activity involving tiles and paper.

Over 20,000 youth members and volunteers contributed to designing the badges, while 11,000 participants tested the required activities. Girlguiding ambassador and TV host Angellica Bell described the trial experience as a "real blast," highlighting how the organization builds confidence while addressing modern challenges like online harm and sexism.

Since its 1909 founding as the Girl Guide Association by Agnes Baden-Powell, Girlguiding has spanned generations—its alumni include Queen Elizabeth II, who joined in 1937. The latest overhaul follows a badge system that remained largely unchanged for nearly 110 years.

Fatima, an 18-year-old member of the youth steering group, said the new lineup proves the program evolves alongside members. "It's empowering to know our voices help shape what guiding looks like for the future," she stated.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Asteroid Bennu Samples Contain Fundamental Components of Life
fields.summary: Scientific analysis of asteroid Bennu samples returned to Earth has discovered essential organic compounds including amino acids and DNA components, providing crucial evidence that asteroids delivered the ingredients for life to early Earth.
fields.content:
Scientists have made a landmark discovery after analyzing asteroid samples retrieved from Bennu, revealing the presence of compounds that form the basis of life. Rich collections of minerals and thousands of organic compounds, including amino acids that build proteins and nucleobases that compose DNA, were found in the asteroid's grainy dust.

This finding supports the long-standing scientific theory that asteroids transported vital biochemical ingredients to Earth during the solar system's early history. While Bennu itself shows no signs of hosting life, its composition demonstrates how these celestial bodies could have seeded multiple worlds with the building blocks necessary for biological processes.

"What we've learned from it is amazing," stated Prof Sara Russell, a cosmic mineralogist from London's Natural History Museum. "It's telling us about our own origins and enables us to answer big questions about where life began. Everyone wants to know how life started."

These revelations, documented in research papers published in Nature and Nature Astronomy journals, stem from one of NASA's most challenging missions. The Osiris Rex spacecraft completed an audacious operation by capturing samples from the 500m-wide space rock using a robotic arm and returning them to Earth in 2023 through a carefully designed capsule.

NASA capsule containing black dusty sample of asteroid Bennu

The 120 grams of collected material, resembling dark dusty fragments, proved immensely valuable despite modest volume. Approximately one teaspoon of the material went to UK researchers. "Every grain reveals something new about Bennu," emphasized Prof Russell, who studied the samples.

Laboratory analysis detected high concentrations of nitrogen and carbon-rich compounds within the asteroid material. Explicitly identified were 14 types of protein-forming amino acids used in Earth organisms along with all four DNA nucleobases: adenine, guanine, cytosine, and thymine. Additional discoveries included minerals and salts indicating historical water presence and ammonia, which facilitates biochemical reactions.

Scanning electron microscope image showing minerals in Bennu sample

"The diversity is incredible," explained Prof Russell. "We're finding mineral combinations unseen in any meteorite collected on Earth." This research reinforces evidence that asteroids transported water and organic substances throughout the solar system during its turbulent formation phase billions of years ago.

Dr. Ashley King from the Natural History Museum elaborated: "Earth was repeatedly struck by asteroids like Bennu, which delivered carbon and water—ingredients essential for life. While Earth remains the only known life-hosting planet, these ingredients were distributed throughout the solar system."

The findings raise key questions about why life emerged exclusively on Earth despite these universal deliveries, prompting scientists to investigate possible life elsewhere in our cosmic neighborhood. Researchers anticipate decades of further exploration using Bennu materials while planning future studies of similar celestial bodies to unlock more secrets about life's cosmic origins.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Four Arrested Over Cyber-Attacks Targeting UK Retailers M&S and Co-op
fields.summary: Four suspects have been arrested in connection with major cyber-attacks that severely disrupted UK retailers Marks & Spencer and the Co-operative Group, leading to data theft and significant financial losses estimated at £300 million for M&S.
fields.content:
Police have detained four individuals during early morning raids across England in relation to damaging cyber-attacks against retailers Marks & Spencer and the Co-op. The National Crime Agency confirmed arrests took place in Staffordshire, London, and the West Midlands.

A 20-year-old woman was arrested in Staffordshire, while three males aged 17 to 19 were detained elsewhere. All face allegations including breaches of the Computer Misuse Act, blackmail, money laundering, and involvement with an organised crime group. Electronic equipment was seized during the operations.

One suspect is reportedly from Latvia, with others being UK residents. Witnesses described large-scale police operations, including officers wearing balaclavas and forced entry at a Staffordshire property, followed by removal of multiple devices.

Paul Foster, head of the NCA's National Cyber Crime Unit, stated these arrests mark a "significant step" but emphasized the investigation continues with international partners, aiming to bring all responsible parties to justice.

NCA police

These cyber-attacks since mid-April caused extensive disruption: Co-op stores faced prolonged stock shortages while M&S expects system recovery to continue until late July or beyond. The M&S chairman described the hack as feeling like an attempt to destroy the business, with losses estimated near £300 million. Luxury retailer Harrods was also affected but experienced limited impact.

A wave of attacks

M&S was initially compromised, suffering major theft of sensitive customer and staff data. Attackers deployed ransomware that encrypted systems, demanding payment. Evidence revealed offensive ransom demands sent to M&S executives.

Days later, criminals targeted the Co-op, stealing personal information from millions of customers and employees. The company publicly acknowledged the breach after hackers provided evidence contradicting initial damage reports. Protective measures by disconnecting internet-connected systems were later confirmed to have prevented ransomware activation and more severe consequences.

Harrods similarly disconnected critical IT infrastructure after the Co-op attack announcement to mitigate potential damage.

The arrested include a 17-year-old British male from the West Midlands, a 19-year-old British man from London, a 19-year-old Latvian male from the West Midlands, and a 20-year-old British woman from Staffordshire. The operation involved collaboration between the NCA and regional organised crime units.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Rob Brydon Draws from The Traitors for New Game Show Destination X
fields.summary: Comedian Rob Brydon unveils his new BBC game show Destination X, revealing inspiration from The Traitors' approachable hosting style alongside a £100,000 prize competition across Europe. The article also covers recent updates from Love Island's season.
fields.content:
Destination X Gameplay and Inspiration

Rob Brydon has drawn inspiration from the success of The Traitors as he prepares to host the new game show Destination X. The 60-year-old Welsh comedian aims to bring a similar lightness to the BBC program emulating Claudia Winkleman's approachable hosting style on the murder mystery hit. Destination X challenges 13 contestants to deduce a secret European location using only cryptic clues revealed through various challenges.

Participants will travel in a coach with blacked-out windows while sleeping onboard to maintain disorientation. Each episode eliminates the contestant furthest from the actual location with the first player to correctly identify Destination X winning £100,000. Brydon emphasizes blending into the background stating "I wanted to just be the bridge between the viewer and the contestants because they are the stars."

Brydon known for Gavin & Stacey's Uncle Bryn also revealed subtle wardrobe choices provide location hints. "I'm being a little more experimental with my wardrobe than in the past" he noted describing his outfits as containing region-specific "little flourishes".

Rob Brydon holding black box in burgundy suit

Executive producer Dan Adamson highlighted the diverse cast including a crime fiction writer and retired detective sergeant saying "We weren't scared to put good players in. It's rare you get a chance to turn the whole of Europe into a board game." Brydon found the spontaneous storytelling particularly fascinating, adding "The great thing is watching how relationships alter and shift—and how trust is sometimes misplaced between contestants."

The format originated in Belgium with a US version airing earlier this year. Destination X premieres July 30 on BBC One.

Love Island Season Updates

The article also provided developments from the current Love Island season. Four finalist couples are competing for $100,000: Amaya Espinal and Bryan Arenales Chris Seeley and Huda Mustafa Nicolas "Nic" Vansteenberghe and Olandria Carthen and Jose "Pepe" Garcia-Gonzalez and Iris Kendall.

Love Island finalists walking along coastal path

Viewership patterns show more audiences are watching the villa drama on mobile devices than traditional televisions this season. Islander Helena Ford featured prominently in promotional materials reflecting this viewing shift.

Islander Helena Ford looking shocked in pink dress

Former contestant Cierra Ortega issued an apology after past social media posts containing a racial slur surfaced. "I truly regret and am deeply sorry for my ignorance" she stated while also reporting receiving death threats.

Cierra Ortega drinking from cup in villa

Miles Nazaire faced criticism after explaining he had to give up his pet due to time constraints. Meanwhile Ortega's parents described the controversy surrounding their daughter as a "painful" experience for the family following the emergence of offensive posts.

Cierra Ortega in patterned orange dress

Miles Nazaire posing before Dragon statue

fields.title: Iran Enlists China and Russia to Prevent UN Sanctions Ahead of Nuclear Deadline
fields.summary: Iran is pursuing urgent talks with China and Russia to prevent UN snapback sanctions as European powers set an end-of-August deadline for a new nuclear agreement, while security experts warn failure could escalate nuclear threats.
fields.content:
Iran announced high-stakes talks with China and Russia as it seeks to prevent sanctions reactivation by the United Nations Security Council. Foreign Ministry spokesperson Esmail Baghaei emphasized continuous coordination, stating: "We are in constant consultation with these two countries to prevent activation of the snapback or to mitigate its consequences. We have aligned positions and good relations."

European Deadline Approaches

This diplomatic push follows warnings from France, Germany, and the UK that they will trigger snapback sanctions unless Iran agrees to a new nuclear deal by August's end. The E3 alliance will hold separate discussions with Tehran later this week. Details regarding potential agreement terms remain undefined, particularly after the US and Israel conducted strikes against Iranian nuclear facilities last month.

UN Security Council after Iran calls an emergency session

The Snapback Mechanism

The Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action's (JCPOA) snapback clause allows any signatory to reinstate strict UN sanctions if Iran violates nuclear terms. Although the US exited the deal in 2018 and cannot invoke snapback, Secretary of State Marco Rubio has urged European allies to utilize this tool. Behnam Ben Taleblu of the Foundation for Defense of Democracies noted: "Snapback remains the international community’s most powerful political and diplomatic tool against Iran’s nuclear program."

The window for action is narrowing, with security analysts estimating a six-week implementation period. The authority to enforce JCPOA-based sanctions expires on October 18 according to pact terms.

Iran ballistic missile stands next to image of Iran's leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei.

Experts warn that intensified sanctions could provoke broader dangers, potentially leading Iran to abandon international nuclear agreements including the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. Taleblu cautioned that while sanctions could enhance diplomatic pressure, they risk accelerating Tehran's nuclear ambitions.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Jeffries Withholds Endorsement of NYC Mayoral Candidate Mamdani Amid Uganda Trip
fields.summary: House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries announced he will not immediately endorse New York City mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani, citing plans to reconvene with Democratic leaders after Mamdani returns from a trip to Uganda. The self-described socialist nominee faces mounting Republican criticism during his overseas visit celebrating his marriage.
fields.content:
Endorsement Delayed

Democratic leader Hakeem Jeffries stated during a Monday Capitol Hill press conference that he requires more time before endorsing Zohran Mamdani's mayoral bid. Mamdani, confirmed as the Democratic nominee despite Republican attacks for his socialist stance, met with Jeffries in Brooklyn last Friday seeking support.

"We agreed to reconvene with other members of the [New York] delegation and high-level community leaders in Brooklyn upon his return to the country," Jeffries explained. The House Minority Leader emphasized his methodical endorsement approach: "As has been the case with every single high-profile endorsement decision, I have a sit-down conversation first, then proceed."

Overseas Trip Sparks Commentary

Mamdani subsequently traveled to Uganda to celebrate his marriage with extended family. Anticipating media scrutiny, he preemptively mocked the New York Post through social media.

"Since you'll undoubtedly read about this trip on their front page, inshallah [God willing], here are headline suggestions," Mamdani quipped, proposing satirical options including "M.I.A.? Mandani in Africa," "Uganda Miss Me," and "He's Kampala-etely Crazy"—referencing Uganda's capital.

Zohran Mamdani speaking at debate

He closed with "Zo-Running Away?" before footage showed him waving with supporters. Mamdani holds dual U.S.-Ugandan citizenship, having been born in Uganda and raised in South Africa before moving to New York at age 7. Financial disclosures reveal he owns undeveloped land in Jinja, Uganda, valued between $150,000-$250,000.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Canine Scent Detectives Uncover Parkinson's Disease Early, Research Reveals
fields.summary: Specially trained dogs identified Parkinson's disease in human skin swabs with up to 80% accuracy before symptoms appeared, according to UK researchers who found distinctive olfactory markers in patients.
fields.content:
Dogs possess an extraordinary ability to detect Parkinson's disease before clinical symptoms emerge through signature odors in human skin secretions, new scientific research demonstrates. A collaborative UK study proved trained canines could identify volatile markers associated with the condition with remarkable precision.

Research previously established that Parkinson's patients produce heightened levels of sebum, an oily skin substance with a specific musky scent. This study presented two dogs—Bumper the golden retriever and Peanut the black labrador—with skin swabs from 130 Parkinson's patients and 175 healthy individuals. Both had undergone extensive training analyzing over 200 odor samples.

The canines received rewards for correctly flagging Parkinson's specimens while ignoring control swabs. Their diagnostic accuracy proved remarkably high; they detected positive cases with 80% sensitivity and ruled out negatives with 98% specificity, showcasing exceptional skill in distinguishing healthy samples.

Doctor's hand holding the hand of someone with Parkinson's

Published on July 15 in The Journal of Parkinson's Disease, the research emerged from a partnership among the University of Bristol, Medical Detection Dogs, and the University of Manchester. Current diagnostic methods lack early screening options, though warning signs can appear years in advance.

"The dogs achieved high sensitivity and specificity, revealing an olfactory signature unique to Parkinson's patients," explained lead author Nicola Rooney, veterinary professor at Bristol University. "At 70-80% accuracy, dogs might help develop a quick, non-invasive testing approach that's cost-effective too."

golden retriever and black labrador

Claire Guest, chief scientific officer at Medical Detection Dogs U.K., emphasized this confirms dogs "very accurately" detect disease, noting that "timely diagnosis enables treatments that slow progression and reduce symptoms." Perdita Barran, professor at Manchester University, added that skin swabs offer a "faster, accessible method" for early Parkinson's detection.

Future studies will evaluate canines' long-term capability to anticipate diagnoses before symptoms manifest. The Michael J. Fox Foundation and Parkinson's UK funded this research.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Multistory Tower Houses Unearthed in Ancient Egyptian City of Imet
fields.summary: British and Egyptian archaeologists have discovered multistory tower houses and ceremonial structures in the ancient Nile Delta city of Imet, revealing new insights into urban development and religious practices in Ptolemaic-era Egypt.
fields.content:
Archaeologists excavating Tell el-Fara'in—site of the ancient city of Imet or Buto—have revealed multistory structures called 'tower houses' using satellite imagery and remote sensing technology. This discovery reshapes understanding of urban life in the Nile Delta region during antiquity.

Tower Houses and Urban Development

A joint team from the University of Manchester and University of Sadat City found clusters of ancient mudbricks indicating substantial architecture beneath the surface. The excavated tower houses featured exceptionally thick foundation walls designed to support multiple stories, dating from the Late Period through Roman times. Egyptologist Nicky Nielsen explained, 'Their presence shows Imet was a thriving, densely built city with complex urban infrastructure during the Ptolemaic Period starting around 332 B.C.'

Image of multistory building ruins

Religious and Agricultural Structures

Beyond residences, the team uncovered granaries for grain storage and animal enclosures. A ceremonial road linked to the cult of Wadjet—Egypt's cobra goddess—was found beneath a later structure with limestone plaster floors and massive pillars. University officials noted, 'This route fell out of use by the mid-Ptolemaic period, showing shifting religious landscapes.' Smaller artifacts included a funerary figurine, stone slab depicting god Harpocrates, and a bronze rattle honoring Hathor, goddess of music.

Statues unearthed in excavated Egyptian city, Buto

The findings advance knowledge of urban planning, spirituality, and economy in 4th-century BC Nile Delta settlements. Nielsen concluded, 'Imet is emerging as a key site for rethinking Late Period Egyptian archaeology.' Ongoing excavations continue to reveal details about this once-flourishing city swallowed by time.

Split image of stone slab, ancient statue

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Clayton Kershaw Shows Dugout Frustration After Dodgers Fall to Brewers
fields.summary: Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher Clayton Kershaw displayed visible frustration following a tough performance against the Milwaukee Brewers, culminating in a dugout outburst during the team's 6-5 loss as Milwaukee completed a season sweep.
fields.content:
Los Angeles Dodgers star Clayton Kershaw unleashed his frustration with a dugout tantrum after being pulled from Sunday's game against the Milwaukee Brewers. Kershaw allowed three runs (one earned) across 4.1 innings before exiting in the fifth inning with the Brewers having tied the game at 3-3. The Dodgers briefly reclaimed the lead later that inning.

Clayton Kershaw on the mound

After returning to the dugout, the future Hall of Famer violently slammed his glove and hat onto the bench. His outburst preceded Milwaukee's decisive three-run rally in the sixth inning that secured their 6-5 victory. Kershaw remained visibly agitated during postgame interviews, offering minimal commentary: "I don’t make anything of it. They beat us. We need to play better tomorrow," he stated before curtly adding, "I don’t have much to say. I’m going to get myself in trouble, so let’s just call it."

The Dodgers contributed to their own defeat with three fielding errors. Kershaw's season record stands at 4-1 through 11 starts with a 3.27 ERA and 37 strikeouts. The 11-time All-Star was appearing in his first game following the All-Star break.

Clayton Kershaw vs the Brewers

With this loss, the Dodgers fell to 58-42 as they continue their World Series pursuit. The Brewers improved to 59-40 and completed a season sweep against Los Angeles.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Meta Commissions World's Largest AI Superclusters
fields.summary: Meta is investing hundreds of billions to construct unprecedented AI supercomputing clusters, including Prometheus launching in 2026 and Hyperion targeting 5 gigawatt capacity, aiming to dominate next-generation artificial intelligence development.
fields.content:
Mark Zuckerberg recently declared plans to invest "hundreds of billions of dollars" into next-generation AI infrastructure, featuring what may become the world's largest computing clusters. The initiative includes the Prometheus supercluster scheduled for 2026, with the even larger Hyperion project aiming for 5 gigawatts of processing power. Zuckerberg noted these installations will be physically massive, stating: "We're building multiple titan clusters. Just one of these covers a significant part of the footprint of Manhattan."

Why Meta is prioritizing AI infrastructure

Compute power has become AI's most crucial resource as generative models evolve rapidly. Meta's Prometheus cluster is designed to train massively complex AI systems faster than existing alternatives. Industry analysts indicate this could make Meta the first company to operate a supercluster exceeding one gigawatt, positioning it against rivals like OpenAI, Google DeepMind, and Anthropic.

Establishing Meta Superintelligence Labs

Meta launched an elite research division named Meta Superintelligence Labs, led by Alexandr Wang (ex-Scale AI CEO) and Nat Friedman (former GitHub chief). The company invested $14.3 billion in Scale AI while reportedly recruiting top AI specialists from Apple, OpenAI, and Anthropic. "I'm focused on building the most elite and talent-dense team," Zuckerberg emphasized, with compensation packages reaching $100 million for key personnel.

Instagram application interface

The investment signals Meta's resolve to overcome recent challenges, exemplified by the tepid response to its Llama 4 language model. With expanded 2025 capital expenditures of $64-72 billion primarily directed toward AI, the company is making an unprecedented technological commitment to compete in this rapidly advancing field.

Meta brand logo

User impact of AI superclusters

These technological investments will significantly enhance Meta's consumer products. Instagram feeds, Facebook search results, and Meta Quest virtual reality experiences will become more responsive and intuitive. AI assistants will offer more natural interactions, recommendations will grow increasingly accurate, and targeted advertising will become more predictive of user desires even before explicit searches.

Strategic implications

Meta is transforming its approach to artificial intelligence through this high-stakes technological effort. With enormous investments in infrastructure, top-tier talent acquisition, and specialized research centers, the company aims to lead the next phase of AI innovation. The outcome represents a monumental industry gamble – should it succeed, Meta could become the global AI leader; if unsuccessful, it will represent an extraordinary expenditure without achieving dominance.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Demystifying the Clitoris: A Comprehensive Guide for Enhancing Sexual Pleasure

fields.title: Unraveling the Truth Behind Ozzy Osbourne's Bat and Dove Incidents
fields.summary: This article investigates the infamous incidents where rock legend Ozzy Osbourne allegedly bit the heads off animals during concerts and meetings, exploring conflicting accounts to separate fact from rock mythology.
fields.content:
In rock music's history of outrageous behavior, few stories rival Ozzy Osbourne's alleged animal incidents. The "Prince of Darkness," who earned his nickname through dark lyrics and an occult persona, became legendary for a 1982 concert where he supposedly bit off a bat's head.

During his Diary of a Madman tour, Osbourne had developed a habit of tossing animal parts into audiences. On January 20, 1982, at Des Moines' Veterans Memorial Auditorium, a small black object landed on stage. Osbourne believed it was a rubber toy; he popped it into his mouth and bit down.

Tony Iommi and Ozzy Osbourne performing with Black Sabbath

In his autobiography, Osbourne described the horrifying realization: "My mouth was instantly full of this warm, gloopy liquid. Then the head in my mouth twitched." Accounts differ about the bat's condition. While Osbourne often claimed it was alive, he told the BBC in 2006: "It had some string around its neck. I thought it was a joke bat. Sharon signaled it was real."

The individual who reportedly brought the bat, Mark Neal, stated the animal had died days before the show. This aligns with Rolling Stone's ranking of the event as #2 in Rock's Wildest Myths—largely true but embellished. Osbourne himself later acknowledged the bat was likely dead when thrown.

Ozzy Osbourne performing in concert

Doves of peace

Nine months earlier, a similar incident occurred during a Los Angeles meeting with CBS executives. Osbourne arrived with three live doves intended for a symbolic peace gesture. According to biographer Mick Wall, Osbourne—annoyed by a PR representative—abruptly bit one bird's head off to "shut her up," then repeated the act with a second dove.

An alternate version emerged when Osbourne told Sounds magazine the birds were already dead: "The scam is the bird was dead. Rather than waste it, I bit its head off. They all went white." Regardless of accuracy, the executives immediately ejected him from the meeting.

Close-up portrait of Ozzy Osbourne

The ringmaster of rock excess

These incidents reinforced Osbourne's persona as rock's ultimate provocateur. Previously ousted from Black Sabbath for extreme substance abuse, he leveraged these macabre events to amplify his notoriety. While details varied in his retellings, they cemented his reputation for pushing rock's boundaries further than contemporaries.

Osbourne's legacy remains defined by such calculated outrageousness. As rock's self-styled ringmaster of excess, he crafted an enduring mythology through actions others wouldn't contemplate—right until his final days.

Ozzy Osbourne recording with Frank Andrews in 1981

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump's Tariff Tactics Secure Key Trade Deal with Japan
fields.summary: The United States has finalized a trade agreement with Japan in what appears to be a tactical victory for President Trump’s aggressive tariff strategy, avoiding threatened 25% duties while positioning Japan as a model for other trading partners.
fields.content:
Japan has played a pivotal role in the Trump administration's reshaping of global trade dynamics. The recent trade agreement demonstrates how the president's confrontational tariff tactics have achieved concrete outcomes, at least on his terms.

Despite numerous discussions and negotiating teams traveling between the countries, a deal had remained just out of reach until this breakthrough. This represents a narrow victory for the Trump approach, particularly if Japan becomes a model encouraging other nations to comply with U.S. demands.

While Japan now faces a 15% standard tariff on goods entering the U.S., higher than the UK's 10%, this arrangement remains more favorable than alternatives. Japanese negotiators had fiercely resisted during talks, with their frustrations noted by seasoned diplomats given Japan's reputation for politeness.

Tokyo adopted a hardline stance, with its finance minister referring to its $1.1 trillion holdings of U.S. Treasury bonds—the world's largest—as a potential bargaining "card" to deploy. Market jitters emerged when rumors spread about Japanese hedge funds selling U.S. bonds after Trump's April tariff announcements, fueling dollar instability.

The timing of this agreement is significant, coinciding with an EU-Japan summit in Tokyo. It prevents potential coordination between Japan, the EU, and Canada on retaliatory measures. EU nations will likely question why they haven't secured similar arrangements while considering stronger responses targeting U.S. technology corporations.

Japan safeguarded its agricultural market despite agreeing to import more American rice but faces uncertainties over spurring demand for U.S. vehicles. Japanese firms also pledged approximately $500 billion in investments in America. The deal reflects a reluctant acceptance of tariffs once deemed unthinkable between allies, preempting Trump's threatened 25% duty.

Four people drinking beverages with colorful straws in casual setting

Notably, the sugar industry received further protection with Trump applying pressure on companies like Coca-Cola.

Tariff revenue rising for the US

U.S. tariffs have generated over $100 billion this year—5% of federal revenue compared to the typical 2%—without substantial retaliation against American exporters. Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent projects yearly tariff collections will reach $300 billion.

American consumers ultimately bear much of these costs through higher prices. Trump officials expected a rising dollar to offset import expenses, but the currency has instead dropped 10% against global counterparts this year, compounding financial pressure.

Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey highlighted that betting against the dollar is "the most crowded trade" presently, with traditional safe-haven patterns "essentially breaking down." Market participants are reducing dollar exposure through protective hedges. Some analysts suspect dollar depreciation might have been an intentional strategy to restore competitiveness for U.S. manufacturers.

Simultaneously, these trade conflicts have created opportunities for China to position itself as a more stable partner. While the Japan agreement counters narratives suggesting "Trump always chickens out," broader economic consequences—especially with tariff deadlines approaching—remain complex and unclear.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: M&S advertisement banned for showing 'unhealthily thin' model
fields.summary: Marks & Spencer has had an advertisement banned by UK regulators after featuring a model perceived as 'unhealthily thin'. The Advertising Standards Authority ruled the imagery was irresponsible and emphasized the model's slim physique.
fields.content:
UK advertising regulators have banned a Marks & Spencer advertisement featuring a model they deemed "unhealthily thin". The Advertising Standards Authority (ASA) concluded that the model's pose and clothing choices—including large pointed shoes that accentuated her legs' slenderness—made the promotion irresponsible.

The ruling mandates that the ad must not reappear in its current form. M&S must also ensure future images don't portray models as unhealthily thin. Despite disagreeing with the assessment, M&S has withdrawn the advertisement. The retailer stated its women's clothing range promotes inclusivity and "responsibly promoted aspirational fashion".

The contested image, previously displayed on M&S's app, showed a model in an off-shoulder white top, slim trousers, and the criticized shoes. ASA additionally noted the model's head appeared proportionally out of sync with her body, emphasizing her small frame. M&S countered that the pose conveyed confidence and the shoes served stylistic purposes only. While three other M&S advertisements underwent investigation, they weren't banned, though the retailer voluntarily amended them.

M&S stressed its models are chosen based on professional suitability and health, adhering to industry standards to prevent promoting unhealthy body images.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Home Office to Share Asylum Hotel Locations with Food Delivery Firms
fields.summary: The UK Home Office will disclose locations of asylum accommodation hotels to major food delivery platforms like Deliveroo, Just Eat, and Uber Eats to help identify illegal working activities. This initiative is part of broader government efforts to address organized immigration crime, including sanctions against people-smuggling networks.
fields.content:
Delivery Firms to Help Detect Illegal Working

The Home Office has established an agreement with Deliveroo, Just Eat, and Uber Eats to share asylum hotel locations, enabling these companies to detect potential illegal work patterns. Suspicious activity includes delivery accounts consistently operating near asylum accommodations.

This initiative targets account-sharing practices where work-entitled individuals lend profiles to migrants without UK employment rights. Current legislation prohibits asylum seekers from accepting jobs during their first year in the country or while awaiting application decisions.

The collaboration follows concerns about undocumented migrants earning income via delivery apps. Since last month's commitment to strengthen identity checks, platforms have removed thousands of unverified accounts, enhancing enforcement measures.

Home Secretary Yvette Cooper emphasized: "Illegal working undermines honest business, exploits vulnerable individuals and fuels organised immigration crime. By enhancing our data sharing with delivery companies, we are taking decisive action to close loopholes and increase enforcement." The three firms reaffirmed their commitment to these efforts.

Government Sanctions Migration Crime Networks

Simultaneously, the government announced sanctions against 25 individuals and organizations implicated in people-smuggling operations globally. The list includes boat suppliers in Asia, crime leaders from the Balkans and North Africa, fake passport procurers, and smugglers coordinating lorry and small-boat crossings.

Foreign Secretary David Lammy described this action as a "landmark moment," warning trafficking networks: "We know who you are, and we will work with our partners around the world to hold you to account."

However, Dr Madeleine Sumption from Oxford University's Migration Observatory expressed skepticism about the sanctions' impact: "There are so many people involved in the industry that targeting people individually is probably only going to have an impact around the margins. I’d be surprised if this the game changer to end small boat crossings."

Local Immigration Enforcement Updates

Havant Borough Council confirmed an email regarding asylum consultations was mistakenly sent to a former staff member.

Exterior view of Havant Borough Council's Public Service Plaza building

Dorset Police and Immigration Enforcement sought to revoke the license of a venue called Chicken N Beer in May following immigration violations.

Glass of lager on wooden surface with beach backdrop

Braintree District Council alerted that Wethersfield airbase might expand its asylum seeker capacity despite local objections.

Aerial view of asylum accommodation at Wethersfield airbase

A Waitrose employee named Dean Smith appeared in court charged with violent disorder during protests outside asylum hostels.

Police officer beside hotel entrance sign with crowd in background

Meanwhile, over 1,000 people gathered during two separate demonstrations opposing asylum accommodation at an Epping hotel, highlighting rising community tensions.

Police response to unrest involving protest flares in Epping

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Five-Day UK Doctors' Strike Proceeds Amid Pay Dispute
fields.summary: A five-day strike by resident doctors in England will proceed as planned after failed negotiations between the British Medical Association and the government over pay restoration demands. The dispute centers on a 20% real-term wage decline since 2008 despite recent pay increases.
fields.content:
A five-day strike by resident doctors in England will commence on Friday as scheduled, the British Medical Association confirmed after unsuccessful negotiations with the government. Despite five days of talks aimed at resolving the conflict, both sides remain deadlocked primarily over pay concerns.

Health Secretary Wes Streeting had requested the strike's postponement in exchange for continued discussions, but the BMA rejected the proposal citing inadequate governmental concessions. Union representatives stressed that achieving pay restoration remains their core objective, dismissing non-pay offers as insufficient means to address financial losses.

BMA resident doctors committee co-chairs Dr. Melissa Ryan and Dr. Ross Nieuwoudt stated: "We have always said that no doctor wants to strike and all it would take to avoid it is a credible path to pay restoration offered by the government. While we were happy to discuss non-pay issues affecting doctors' finances, this is at its core a pay dispute."

In response, Mr. Streeting criticized the union for "recklessly and needlessly" proceeding with industrial action that demonstrated "complete disdain" for patients. He maintained that resident doctors had received exceptional pay rises over two consecutive years, making further strikes unjustified.

Loan forgiveness

During negotiations, non-pay issues were explored after the government signaled inability to meet salary demands. Discussions included proposals for the government to cover mandatory exam fees exceeding several thousand pounds, grant more location autonomy during early training years, provide longer roster notice periods, and accelerate career progression pathways beyond initial training stages that can span over a decade.

The BMA additionally proposed student loan forgiveness considering doctors' average £100,000 university debts, though this initiative reportedly gained no government traction. Recent pay adjustments awarded resident doctors a 5.4% increase this financial year following 22% cumulative raises over the previous two years, yet the union contends salaries remain approximately 20% below 2008 levels when adjusted for inflation.

Chart showing resident doctor pay rises

Separately, the BMA cautioned that NHS England's strategy to limit non-urgent procedure cancellations during strikes creates patient safety hazards. The new approach, requiring hospitals to maintain routine services unless exceptional circumstances arise, diverges from previous strike protocols where elective care was broadly postponed.

BMA deputy leader Dr. Emma Runswick warned: "Senior doctors cannot physically be in two places at once. We think the vast majority of planned and scheduled care should be shifted. This plan risks last-minute cancellations and potential patient harm." NHS England, now under Chief Executive Sir Jim Mackey, argues that minimizing cancellations also mitigates patient risks from delayed care.

Dr. Runswick defended senior doctors charging over £300 hourly for strike night shifts, explaining such incentives may be necessary when requiring additional coverage beyond normal duties. During prior walkouts in 2023-2024, numerous hospitals cancelled up to 50% of planned care to prioritize emergency services.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: University Pays £1.7m to Students Affected by Staff Strikes
fields.summary: Newcastle University has distributed over £1.7m in compensation to students impacted by faculty strike action between March and June, with payments funded by salary savings from the strike period. Eligible students receive up to £1,200 depending on residency status, as the institution aims to address disruptions caused by protests against job cuts.
fields.content:
Newcastle University has distributed more than £1.7m to students affected by teaching disruptions during staff strikes earlier this year. As of June 30, the institution paid £1.72m to learners who faced canceled classes between March and June due to industrial action protesting job cuts.

Compensation amounts range from £100 to £1,200 per student, following guidelines from the Office for Students. Home fee-paying students receive £100 per impacted module up to £600 maximum, while international students qualify for £200 per module capped at £1,200.

Impact of action

University records showed 12,769 students were eligible for compensation. The institution confirmed the scheme remains open, with final payout figures still pending determination. Funding comes entirely from savings accumulated through unpaid staff salaries during the industrial action period.

University and College Union representative Prof Matt Perry noted the scale of compensation validates their strike impact: "This payment shows the university had resources to avoid compulsory redundancies initially." Industrial action concluded last month after the university assured no further job losses until 2025. Over 200 staff members have already accepted voluntary severance packages.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: SpaceX Starship Test Fails Shortly After Texas Launch
fields.summary: SpaceX's latest Starship test flight ended in failure minutes after liftoff from Texas, though the Super Heavy booster successfully returned as planned. The incident occurred hours after rival Blue Origin achieved its first successful orbital launch.
fields.content:
The most recent flight trial of SpaceX's colossal Starship rocket concluded in failure minutes after Thursday's launch from Boca Chica, Texas. Officials confirmed that the upper stage was lost after encountering issues following liftoff at 17:38 EST (22:38 GMT), marking the company's seventh test mission.

Ground control teams erupted in applause as the Super Heavy booster successfully returned to its launchpad approximately seven minutes after liftoff despite the overall setback. SpaceX publicly acknowledged the incident on social media platform X, stating: "Starship experienced a rapid unscheduled disassembly during its ascent burn." They emphasized that the test's value would come from analyzing data to enhance vehicle reliability.

Unverified social media footage suggested the rocket disintegrated in flames, with additional videos showing orange lights streaking across the skies over Haiti's capital. SpaceX founder Elon Musk framed the situation optimistically on X, declaring: "Success is uncertain, but entertainment is guaranteed!" He suggested an oxygen/fuel leak caused pressure buildup but affirmed plans for another launch within a month using upgraded versions already prepared.

The Federal Aviation Administration confirmed awareness of "an anomaly" during the mission, temporarily diverting aircraft around falling debris zones before normal operations resumed. The test followed two significant aerospace events: a SpaceX Falcon 9 launch on Wednesday that dispatched private lunar landers toward the Moon and rival Blue Origin's successful first orbital flight earlier on Thursday, marking a major breakthrough for Jeff Bezos' space venture.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Microsoft Breached by Chinese Hackers in Corporate Data Theft
fields.summary: Microsoft has confirmed Chinese state-backed hackers breached its on-premises SharePoint servers, targeting business data in a global campaign. Security updates have been issued amid denials from Chinese officials.
fields.content:
Chinese hacking groups with state connections exploited vulnerabilities in Microsoft's on-premises SharePoint servers to target sensitive corporate data, according to the tech giant's disclosure. The breach did not affect cloud-based SharePoint services.

Microsoft identified three distinct groups behind the operation: state-backed Linen Typhoon and Violet Typhoon, along with China-based Storm-2603. The company immediately released security updates and urged all on-premises SharePoint server customers to install them.

China's US embassy spokesperson Liu Pengyu rejected the accusations, stating: "China firmly opposes and combats all forms of cyber attacks and cyber crime. We also firmly oppose smearing others without solid evidence." The statement was shared on social media platform X.

Microsoft warned with "high confidence" that hackers would continue targeting unpatched systems. Investigations revealed intrusions where threat actors sent requests to SharePoint servers enabling cryptographic key theft, compromising data security.

The UK's National Cyber Security Centre confirmed "a limited number" of UK-based SharePoint customers were impacted. Charles Carmakal, CTO at Google Cloud's Mandiant Consulting, observed victims across multiple global sectors: "This was exploited very broadly and opportunistically before patching. Governments and businesses using on-premises SharePoint were primary targets."

Malicious actors used stolen cryptographic material to maintain persistent access to victims' SharePoint environments, Carmakal noted. Their techniques showed parallels with prior campaigns linked to Chinese operations. Microsoft described Linen Typhoon as focused on stealing intellectual property from government, defense, and human rights organizations over 13 years.

Violet Typhoon reportedly conducts espionage against former officials, NGOs, think tanks, and financial institutions across the US, Europe, and East Asia. Storm-2603 was assessed with medium confidence to operate from China. Microsoft indicated it would continue updating its website blog as investigations progress.

A person wearing a hooded jacket and gloves typing at a laptop showing a password field. Background displays European digital maps and code lines, evoking hacking themes.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: 'There will never be another Ozzy': Music World Mourns Heavy Metal Legend
fields.summary: Global music stars and grieving fans are honoring Ozzy Osbourne after the Black Sabbath frontman's death at 76, with bandmates and fellow artists paying tribute to his revolutionary impact on heavy metal and his irreplaceable persona.
fields.content:
Ozzy Osbourne, the iconic frontman of pioneering heavy metal band Black Sabbath, has died at 76, prompting an outpouring of tributes from musicians, bandmates, and fans worldwide. His former band members described him as an irreplaceable brother following their emotional farewell performance in Birmingham just weeks earlier.

Black Sabbath co-founder Tony Iommi reflected on their final concert together: "He loved what he did, and I'm so glad we had the opportunity of getting together again for the farewell show.
