The atmosphere was brilliant for Ozzy – he felt at home there." Bassist Geezer Butler added: "Goodbye dear friend. Thanks for all those years - four kids from Aston, who'd have thought?" while drummer Bill Ward shared heartfelt memories of their bond.

Metallica declared Osbourne's influence "impossible to put into words," calling him "hero, icon, pioneer, and friend." Henry Rollins, former Black Flag vocalist, stated: "If you want to talk about heavy metal, first up it's Ozzy Osbourne and Black Sabbath. Everyone else comes after." Other artists including Aerosmith, AC/DC, and Elton John honored him as a foundational rock figure who "secured his place in the pantheon of rock gods."

'A category of his own'

At Black Sabbath's final Birmingham concert on July 5, supported by Metallica and Guns N' Roses among others, Osbourne delivered a powerful performance despite his failing health. Sammy Hagar of Van Halen noted: "For him to have been that close to death and still perform like he promised puts him in a category of his own." Smashing Pumpkins' Billy Corgan called the event "one of the greatest musical moments of my life."

Ozzy Osbourne performing on screen during Black Sabbath's farewell show

Global tributes emerged as artists performed in his memory. Lady Gaga concluded her San Francisco concert in an Osbourne T-shirt with "Crazy Train" playing, while Coldplay's Chris Martin led thousands in a Nashville rendition of Sabbath's "Changes," announcing: "Wherever you're going, thank you for everything." Kiss frontman Gene Simmons declared: "There was never an Ozzy Osbourne before Ozzy, and there will never be another Ozzy." The musician passed away on Tuesday surrounded by family, who shared: "It is with more sadness than words can convey we report our beloved Ozzy has passed away."

'More than a rock legend'

Fans gathered at the Hollywood Walk of Fame and Birmingham's Black Sabbath landmarks to lay flowers, celebrating what venue producer Ana Martinez called "a cultural icon who reshaped music and defied expectations." Variety's Jem Aswad recalled meeting the "Prince of Darkness" as unexpectedly approachable despite his outrageous image, appearing midday in a gold-adorned bathrobe yet being "perfectly friendly."

Fans laying floral tributes at the Black Sabbath mural in Birmingham

Originally founding Black Sabbath in 1968, Osbourne co-created classics like "Paranoid" and "Iron Man" before launching a massively successful solo career with hits including "Crazy Train." His public persona transformed through MTV's reality show "The Osbournes," which portrayed the heavy metal icon as a relatable family man. Ozzy Osbourne is survived by wife Sharon and six children.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Sweeping Protests Erupt in Ukraine Over Anti-Corruption Bill
fields.summary: Thousands protested across Ukraine against legislation weakening anti-corruption bodies, marking the largest demonstrations since Russia's 2022 invasion. Critics warn the bill would undermine key agencies' independence, drawing concern from European officials.
fields.content:
Large-scale demonstrations have erupted across Ukraine opposing a controversial bill that threatens to weaken the country's anti-corruption institutions. Protesters gathered outside the presidential administration in Kyiv, with additional rallies occurring in cities nationwide. These represent the most significant public outcry in Ukraine since Russia's full-scale invasion began in 2022.

Threats to Anti-Corruption Institutions

Key anti-corruption agencies warn the legislation would critically undermine their autonomy. In a joint statement via Telegram, they asserted that if passed, the law would reduce the head of the Specialized Anti-Corruption Prosecutor's Office (SAPO) to a figurehead role and strip the National Anti-Corruption Bureau (NABU) of independence, making it subordinate to the prosecutor general's office.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy

European Union officials echoed these concerns, with Enlargement Commissioner Maireta Kos cautioning that dismantling safeguards for NABU's independence constituted a severe setback. The international alarm highlights the bill's potential impact on Ukraine's governance reforms.

Government Response

President Volodymyr Zelenskyy addressed the controversy after meeting with leaders from NABU, SAPO, and security agencies. In a social media post, he stated that Ukraine's "anti-corruption infrastructure must be cleared" of what he termed "Russian influence," framing the discussions as part of necessary institutional reform efforts amid the ongoing conflict.

Ukrainians protest

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Coldwater Creek Cancer Risk Linked to WWII Radioactive Contamination
fields.summary: A Harvard study reveals elevated cancer rates among residents near Missouri's Coldwater Creek, contaminated by WWII atomic program waste, with children showing 44% higher cancer risk and new legislation enabling medical compensation.
fields.content:
Coldwater Creek in Missouri, a tributary north of St. Louis, has been recognized as a radioactive waste site since the 1980s due to contamination from nuclear weapons development. Research by Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health examined health data from 4,209 residents near the creek and found significantly higher cancer rates among those living closest to the waterway.

Published in JAMA Network, the study showed proximity to the creek dramatically increased cancer risk. Lead researcher Marc Weisskopf stated in a press release: "Our research indicates that the communities around North St. Louis appear to have had excess cancer from exposure to the contaminated Coldwater Creek."

duck swims in coldwater creek

The findings emerged alongside Congress expanding the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA) as part of President Trump's Big Beautiful Bill, allowing affected residents to seek compensation for radiation-related medical expenses. Contamination originated from uranium processing by Mallinckrodt Chemical Works for the Manhattan Project during WWII.

atomic bomb trinity test new mexico

Radioactive material was improperly stored in uncovered drums near the creek, allowing toxins to seep into soil and water over decades. Researchers noted residents encountered radiation through creek recreation and household activities like gardening where contaminated dust became airborne.

Michael Leung, PhD, Harvard co-author, detailed the impact: "Children from the 1940s-1960s living near the creek experienced a 44% higher cancer risk than those beyond 20 kilometers. The waste from these entities could have huge impacts on people’s health, even at lower levels of exposure."

Girl playing in creek

The study recommends further research while hoping its conclusions advance public health protections and creek remediation. Leung emphasized: "We hope these findings will support public health measures for affected communities."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Drug Emergencies Surge as Tourists Overdose in Spain's Ibiza
fields.summary: The popular Spanish holiday island Ibiza faces overwhelming pressure on its health services due to increasing drug-related emergencies among tourists, with officials demanding nightlife venues fund private medical responses.
fields.content:
Ibiza's reputation as an international party destination has led to critical strains on local health infrastructure due to rising drug overdoses among visitors. Authorities report that 25% of ambulance emergencies are connected to major leisure venues across the Mediterranean hotspot.

Healthcare officials demand nightclubs hire private emergency services

Union leader José Manuel Maroto highlighted the worsening situation: "The situation is entrenched because the population increases, leisure centers increase, and instead of moving forward we go backward." Recent data shows MDMA and cocaine as the predominant substances involved, with overdose deaths steadily climbing annually.

Aerial view of the cliffs and the beach of Cala Vadella, Ibiza, Spain

Longtime party promoter Wayne Anthony expressed doubts about solving the island's drug culture, telling media: "When you have these movements that are driven by music, that are driven by art, that are driven by fashion and drugs are a part of it, whatever you put up, whatever boundaries, whatever laws, I don't think you're going to be able to stop it."

People party at the Pacha Ibiza nightclub in Ibiza, on June 16, 2022. - After being closed for two years because of the Covid-19 pandemic, the Mediterranean island's famous mega-clubs have reopened their doors, drawing throngs of partygoers. The pandemic affected all sectors but the leisure sector -- which employs over 3,000 people directly and indirectly -- was the last to fully after virus restrictions were lifted. (Photo by LLUIS GENE / AFP) (Photo by LLUIS GENE/AFP via Getty Images)

Anthony recalled arriving in 1988 when Ibiza was "this beautiful, hot island, which was visually stunning and we knew you could party there quite legally." The Workers' Union for Healthcare Transport now demands venues employ private ambulance services to handle incidents.

Aerial image of San Antonio Bay on the Island of Ibiza in Spain. 26th April 2024.

Maroto emphasized the financial burden, stating, "We all pay for ambulances to these companies that make billions. It is unaffordable." Officials have been contacted regarding these health system challenges facing the tourism-dependent island.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Mother Questions Preventability of College Football Player's Fatal Heart Condition
fields.summary: The mother of Jeremiah Kelly, an 18-year-old Cincinnati Bearcats football player who died from cardiac hypertrophy, questions whether his death could have been prevented despite his previously clean health record. She urges greater awareness about heart screenings for young athletes.
fields.content:
18-Year-Old Player Died of Cardiac Hypertrophy

The sudden death of Jeremiah Kelly, a Cincinnati Bearcats offensive lineman, has left his mother Chiniqua Kelly questioning whether the tragedy could have been prevented. Jeremiah died at age 18 from cardiac hypertrophy, a condition involving abnormal heart thickening that wasn't detected during his lifetime. Chiniqua told ESPN her son was the "healthiest child" who "never had any issues" medically.

Despite receiving some closure from the coroner's report confirming the cause of death, she is having her two other sons evaluated by a sports cardiologist. "It just makes you want to be more aware, like if there's something that you can possibly save your child from," Chiniqua stated, emphasizing the importance of cardiac awareness.

Cincinnati Bearcats helmets

On the day before his death, Jeremiah was relaxing at home while wearing a heart monitor during physical activity, according to his mother. The Cincinnati football program expressed profound grief in a statement: "The Cincinnati football program and athletics department continue to mourn Jeremiah's passing. He is deeply missed by all of us."

Cincinnati Bearcats helmet

Kelly joined the Bearcats after an outstanding high school career with Ohio's Avon Eagles, helping deliver their first state championship with a perfect 16-0 season in 2024. His senior year honors included first-team all-conference and all-district selections plus Southwestern Conference Lineman of the Year. During his junior season, he contributed to a 14-1 record while playing alongside current Cincinnati running back Jakorion Caffey.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Nexus Supercomputer to Transform America's AI Research Landscape
fields.summary: Georgia Tech is developing the Nexus supercomputer with $20 million in National Science Foundation funding, set to launch in 2026. Designed for groundbreaking AI research, this powerful system combines cutting-edge hardware with unprecedented accessibility
fields.content:
Fueled by a $20 million investment from the National Science Foundation, Georgia Tech is constructing the Nexus supercomputer scheduled for operation in spring 2026. This advanced system aims to redefine artificial intelligence research through extraordinary computing capabilities designed for multiple scientific disciplines.

Unprecedented Processing Power

Nexus will feature massive technical specifications, including 330 terabytes of memory and 10 petabytes of flash storage capacity—equivalent to approximately 10 billion reams of paper. This infrastructure is crucial for training sophisticated AI models running complex simulations and processing massive datasets beyond conventional system limits.

Speed is fundamental to Nexus’s design with optimized data pathways that eliminate bottlenecks between components. Researchers can execute demanding workflows without disruptions from slow file transfers or insufficient memory resources.

Supercomputer infrastructure

Accessible Innovation Platform

Unlike traditional supercomputers focused solely on raw power Nexus prioritizes user accessibility alongside performance. Scientists can operate complex projects through intuitive interfaces without needing deep technical expertise in low-level systems.

The platform supports diverse scientific applications from inception including AI workflows data analysis pipelines simulations and extended research services. This versatility encourages rapid experimentation and collaboration across fields like biology chemistry environmental science and engineering while minimizing technical barriers.

A unique allocation strategy reserves 10% of capacity for Georgia Tech researchers while the NSF manages nationwide access. This hybrid model aims to accelerate innovation at both institutional and national levels powering discoveries across scales.

Advanced computing technology

Transformative Societal Impact

Beyond academic research Nexus will drive innovations that impact daily life across medicine energy management and weather prediction. Breakthroughs developed through its processing power could improve healthcare outcomes with enhanced drug discovery transform urban infrastructure and significantly advance climate forecasting capabilities.

For researchers and developers access to enterprise-level computational resources becomes democratized outside major Silicon Valley laboratories. Complex tasks like protein folding modeling algorithm training and climate system simulations become increasingly accessible across institutions nationwide.

Nexus fundamentally expands opportunities for scientific exploration by removing computational constraints. Researchers across diverse fields can scale experiments pursue larger questions and accelerate cross-disciplinary collaborations previously limited by technical barriers.

Strategic Advantages

Nexus represents both a technological leap and a paradigm shift in research accessibility. By democratizing next-generation computing resources Georgia Tech enables broader participation in innovation helping scientists overcome previously insurmountable challenges and foster transformative discoveries.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Group Fitness Surge: Why Men Are Joining Workout Classes in Record Numbers
fields.summary: Nearly 40% of men now engage in group fitness, according to new research, with offerings spanning strength classes to HYROX training. This guide explores why collective workouts deliver results and how newcomers can maximize benefits.
fields.content:
Group fitness participation among men has reached unprecedented levels, with nearly 40% engaging in structured workout classes last year according to University of California, San Diego research. The trend encompasses diverse offerings like HYROX drills, strength sessions, power Pilates, hybrid yoga, HIIT groups, run crews, and recovery protocols combining cold plunges with sauna therapy.

Despite growing popularity, about 60% of men remain hesitant to join group sessions, citing skepticism about their effectiveness, preference for solitary workouts, social discomfort, or cost concerns. Fitness experts counter that today's science-backed classes provide legitimate muscle-building fundamentals alongside built-in accountability systems and community engagement for sustained motivation.

To navigate this evolving landscape, fitness specialists evaluated countless classes nationwide—ranging from highly effective to unconventional formats—to identify America's top 10 group fitness experiences. Their methodology prioritizes programs that optimize training efficiency while demonstrating how participants can maximize gains through collective exercise environments.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Barnes Foundation’s Digital Platform Expands to Host Penn Museum Classes
fields.summary: Philadelphia's Barnes Foundation will host Penn Museum's educational programs on its interactive Visual Experience Platform (VXP) starting this fall. The expansion marks the first licensing agreement for the digital tool, which enables detailed exploration of artworks and artifacts through zoom features and virtual gallery tours.
fields.content:
Philadelphia's Barnes Foundation is partnering with the Penn Museum to expand its digital learning capabilities. This fall, the Barnes' Visual Experience Platform (VXP) will host the Penn Museum's 'Deep Dig' classes and 'Archaeology in Action' lecture series, bringing archaeological content to the interactive platform for the first time.

The VXP technology allows users to examine artworks and artifacts in extraordinary detail. Participants can zoom into high-resolution images beyond what's visible in person, explore 360-degree museum views, and access a library of past educational sessions. Originally developed by the Barnes for art education, the platform serves both K-12 students and adults.

Since adopting the VXP for online education during the pandemic in 2020, the Barnes has formalized its use with over 110 classes enrolling nearly 4,600 students since January 2023. Among them, 14 percent received scholarships. The platform features on-demand classes containing approximately five interactive videos per session, each around 10 minutes long.

Free multilingual resources remain available for grades 2-10, covering diverse topics like artistic pigments, illustration techniques, and language learning through art. Teachers can also access specialized lessons demonstrating how to integrate museum collections into broader classroom curricula.

'When we shifted online during the pandemic, we realized we needed a purpose-built platform for visual education,' explained Thom Collins, the Barnes's executive director. 'VXP doesn't replace in-person visits but enhances them through capabilities impossible in physical spaces.' Collins noted this marks the institution's first technology licensing partnership.

Starting October and November, Penn Museum becomes the inaugural external institution to license VXP. Cross-institutional benefits include $50 discounts for Barnes members taking Penn Museum classes and reciprocal discounts for Penn Museum members taking Barnes courses.

'We're thrilled to partner with the Barnes to make archaeology and anthropology more accessible,' stated Penn Museum director Christopher Woods. Will Cary, Barnes COO, highlighted the timing: 'This collaboration comes when crucial funding cuts disproportionately impact art and education programs, especially in communities of color.'

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UN Court Rules Nations Can Sue Over Climate Change Damage
fields.summary: The International Court of Justice issued a landmark ruling allowing countries to sue each other for climate change damages, including historical greenhouse gas emissions. This non-binding decision establishes legal pathways for vulnerable nations to seek compensation for climate-related destruction.
fields.content:
A groundbreaking ruling by the United Nations' highest court has determined nations can pursue legal action against each other over climate change impacts and historical greenhouse gas emissions. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) in The Hague acknowledged the complexity of attributing specific climate harm to individual countries but emphasized countries' right to seek legal remedies.

Climate activists gathered outside the Peace Palace holding signs demanding government climate action

This advisory opinion marks a monumental victory for climate-vulnerable nations that initiated the case out of frustration with global inaction. The lawsuit originated in 2019 when law students from threatened Pacific islands conceived the legal strategy. Vanuatu resident Flora Vano said the decision validates frontline communities' suffering: "Tonight I'll sleep easier. The ICJ has recognized what we have lived through."

Compensation Pathways

The court confirmed that developing nations can claim damages for climate-related destruction of infrastructure and property. Where environmental restoration is impossible, compensation becomes viable provided climate change causation can be demonstrated case-by-case. Judge Iwasawa Yuji stated countries failing to implement ambitious climate plans breach their Paris Agreement obligations.

Vanuatu officials attending climate obligations session at ICJ in December 2024

Responsibilities and Challenges

Governments were declared responsible for climate impacts from companies operating within their borders, including fossil fuel subsidies and new drilling approvals. Compensation claims could be substantial—studies show climate change caused $2.8 trillion in global losses between 2000-2019. The Marshall Islands estimates $9 billion is needed for climate adaptation.

Damage from Cyclone Pam in Vanuatu which destroyed homes and wiped out economic output

While wealthy nations argued existing climate agreements sufficed, the ICJ rejected this position. Although rulings can only be enforced against nations accepting the court's jurisdiction like the UK, lawyers note the opinion can be cited globally. Barrister Harj Narulla cautioned that geopolitical influences may impact enforcement as the ICJ lacks direct enforcement powers.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ukraine Faces Protests as Zelensky Weakens Anti-Corruption Agencies
fields.summary: Ukraine confronts widespread public protests and international criticism after President Volodymyr Zelensky signs legislation reducing the independence of two key anti-corruption agencies. The move places oversight under the prosecutor general amid warnings it threatens Ukraine's fight against graft and European Union aspirations.
fields.content:
Ukrainian authorities face mounting public opposition after President Volodymyr Zelensky enacted legislation limiting the autonomy of the National Anti-Corruption Bureau (NABU) and Specialised Anti-Corruption Prosecutor's Office (SAP). The new law transfers oversight of these agencies to the prosecutor general, who holds presidential appointment authority.

Spontaneous demonstrations emerged across multiple Ukrainian cities following Tuesday's approval by parliament, where 263 of 324 lawmakers supported the measure. Additional protests occurred nationwide despite constant threats from Russian aerial attacks, marking the largest anti-government rallies since Russia's 2022 full-scale invasion.

Western allies expressed strong concerns about the legislative change. A spokesperson for European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen confirmed she requested clarifications from Kyiv, emphasizing that adherence to rule of law and anti-corruption standards constitutes essential requirements for EU candidacy. "There cannot be a compromise," the spokesperson stated.

President Zelensky defended the move, asserting that the anti-corruption bodies required intervention due to stagnant criminal proceedings and Russian influence. "They need to be cleansed from Russian influence," Zelensky maintained shortly after ratifying the legislation.

Critics counter that removing independence critically undermines NABU and SAP's effectiveness. These agencies achieved Ukraine's 39-point improvement in Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index since their 2014 establishment under EU and IMF requirements. Prior investigations led to high-profile arrests, including the head of Ukraine's Supreme Court in a $3 million bribery case and searches at the residence of a former defense minister.

Getty Images Young Ukrainians in Kyiv hold placards, including a young woman with a white T-shirt and a blue sash

Ukraine currently ranks 105th globally in corruption perceptions. Protesters fear political allies might evade scrutiny under presidential oversight. "They've destroyed everything that has been worked on for years," one Kyiv demonstrator told Radio Liberty. Placards at rallies carried messages including "Corruption lives – the future dies," reflecting concerns that the measure endangers Ukraine's European integration journey.

EU candidate status, granted in 2022 as Kyiv sought deeper Western ties, now faces new risks according to German and French officials. Germany's foreign policy spokesperson Johann Wadephul called the legislation a barrier to EU accession, while France's European affairs minister Benjamin Haddad urged Ukrainian reversal.

Despite protests, Zelensky doubled down during Wednesday's meeting with agency representatives, promising a joint anti-corruption strategy within two weeks while invoking the need for unity against Russian forces. The anti-corruption bodies jointly countered, stating the changes removed essential operational guarantees and thanking Ukrainians for "principled position, active support and concern."

A close up of Volodymyr Zelensky speaking during a conference in Italy. He's wearing a black suit and is standing in front of a blue backdrop.

Ukrainian media condemned the legislation, with Ukrainska Pravda labeling it a "critical blow to Ukraine's European integration" and Dzerkalo Tyzhnia warning of authoritarian tendencies. War veteran Masi Nayem framed his protest participation as a "duty" to war victims, stating: "I fought for the nation, for the people and the democratic system."

As Russia-Ukraine negotiations resumed in Istanbul, domestic attention remained fixed on the political fallout. A Lviv resident articulated widespread apprehension: "We don't want to have to fight both Russia and our own government."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Heathrow Chief Missed Emergency Calls During Airport Closure Crisis
fields.summary: Heathrow CEO Thomas Woldbye slept through emergency calls during a major fire at a power substation in March, causing airport closure and cancelling 1,300 flights. The outage affected 270,000 passengers and could cost millions, with Heathrow now considering legal action against National Grid over known infrastructure faults.
fields.content:
The Overslept Crisis

Heathrow Airport's Chief Executive Thomas Woldbye described his frustration at sleeping through multiple emergency calls during a critical fire incident in March that forced the airport's closure. The blaze at a nearby electrical substation led to the cancellation of 1,300 flights, disrupting travel for approximately 270,000 passengers.

In his first public remarks since an official report on the incident, Woldbye acknowledged missing two emergency notifications and "several" phone calls because his mobile had switched to silent mode. Although calling the situation uncharacteristic of his normal conduct, he defended his team's response: "It's not how I normally operate but on an operational level all the right things happened," he told media. Woldbye only became aware of the crisis at around 6:45 am, hours after operations halted.

Infrastructure Failures Fallout

An investigation revealed that the substation fire stemmed from a known technical fault that National Grid had identified as early as 2018 but failed to repair. Heathrow, which consumes electricity equivalent to a small city through three grid connections, announced it was considering legal action against National Grid following the National Energy Systems Operator's report citing "clear failings" by the utility company.

The outage occurred amid challenging financial results for Heathrow, where pre-tax profit dropped 37.2% to £203 million in the first six months of 2025 despite a 1.9% revenue increase to £1.7 billion. Woldbye confirmed the March disruption would cost "millions" but declined to specify an exact figure. Heathrow management maintains that National Grid must "take accountability" for the operational and financial impacts on both the airport and airlines.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Cleverly Accuses Prime Minister of Escalating Frustration Over Asylum Housing
fields.summary: Conservative Shadow Housing Secretary Sir James Cleverly has accused Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer of intensifying public frustration by claiming ample housing exists for asylum seekers and homeless people, while many struggle with home purchases and accommodation shortages.
fields.content:
Newly appointed Conservative shadow housing secretary Sir James Cleverly has claimed Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer's recent housing remarks are worsening public frustrations. Cleverly stated on BBC Radio 4's Today program that Starmer amplified tensions by declaring there's "lots of housing available" to accommodate growing numbers of homeless individuals and asylum seekers.

Cleverly emphasized this perceived disconnect is fueling significant public discontent, particularly among aspiring homeowners. He later visited a housing project in Hillingdon with Conservative leader Kemi Badenoch, following his appointment during her Tuesday cabinet reshuffle.

Labour responded by criticizing Conservative housing policies, stating Britain remains burdened by the Tories' "disastrous decision to abolish mandatory housing targets." Reiterating their commitment to build 1.5 million homes, Labour stressed that unlike their efforts to address the crisis, "Conservatives haven't once apologised for the mess they left behind."

Cleverly, who becomes Labour's Angela Rayner's counterpart on housing issues, directly linked Britain's housing challenges and asylum pressures. He contended Starmer's claim before the parliamentary Liaison Committee created disconnect when questioned about accommodation solutions. Starmer had pledged to identify authorities and housing options before committee chairs.

Discussing protests outside hotels temporarily housing asylum seekers, Cleverly acknowledged local frustrations while condemning agitators from "both left and right" trying to escalate tensions. He specifically noted unrest outside the Bell Hotel in Epping after an asylum seeker faced sexual assault charges.

When addressing Conservative leader Badenoch's consideration of leaving the European Convention on Human Rights, Cleverly did not confirm personal support but stated if the review results in new party policy he would abide by it. Badenoch clarified she wouldn't appoint shadow cabinet members who hold opposing stances.

A composite image showing individual headshots of members of the Conservative shadow cabinet, each labelled with their name and position. Roles include Leader (Kemi Badenoch), Chancellor (Mel Stride), Foreign (Dame Priti Patel), Home (Chris Philp), and others across departments such as Defence, Education, Health, Housing, Environment.

Other UK Political Developments

Man with short brown hair and glasses with dark frames. He is wearing a black top with a zip.

Investigators found Albanian nationals concealed within a lorry driver's cab sleeping area during an operation targeting people smuggling.

Near the shore at Wimereux, France, a group of people believed to be migrants, wearing orange life jackets, board an overcrowded inflatable boat. Some are already seated while others are still in the water trying to climb aboard. Waves crash onto the beach in the background.

A newly announced government measure imposes sanctions on 25 suspected criminals and groups involved in smuggling operations.

The entrance of New Red Lantern in Chester-le-Street. The takeaway front is red. New Red Lantern is written in yellow above the windows.

Home Office officials reported being assaulted while conducting an investigation at a Chester-le-Street venue.

An exterior view of Havant Borough Council's main building, the Public Service Plaza. It is a modern-looking building, made with large white brick and has an artistic panelling aorund the exterior made of pale wooden slats. The building has a car park to the left and is surrounded by a patch of grass and some trees.

Council officials acknowledged an email regarding consultations had been mistakenly sent to a former Havant Borough Council employee.

Deliveroo delivery driver rides a bicycle in London, Britain, 12 February 2024 - pictured from behind he is moving through and area crowded with pedestrians with his food delivery bag clearly visible on his back

A recent government agreement aims to establish mechanisms helping businesses identify migrants working unlawfully across the UK.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK government announces 'substantial changes' to infected blood scandal compensation
fields.summary: The UK government has revealed substantial reforms to compensation arrangements for victims of the contaminated blood scandal, addressing criticisms of the payout scheme raised by a public inquiry. The changes include allowing claims from estates of deceased victims and increased payments for chronic hepatitis C sufferers.
fields.content:
The UK government has announced significant modifications to compensation provisions for thousands affected by the infected blood scandal, following heavy criticism from the ongoing public inquiry. Minister Nick Thomas-Symonds informed Parliament that the changes would create fairer access to payouts.

Under the revamped system, estates of deceased victims can now claim compensation they were previously denied. Those suffering from chronic hepatitis C infections will also receive higher payments. Victim support groups cautiously welcomed the adjustments though expressed disappointment that further consultations are still needed on some aspects.

Approximately 30,000 people contracted HIV, hepatitis B, or hepatitis C through contaminated blood products during the 1970s-1990s. A damning inquiry report last year revealed authorities failed to prevent imports of tainted treatments and attempted cover-ups related to the disaster.

Medical professional drawing blood into syringe from vial

Earlier this month, inquiry chair Sir Brian Langstaff described how the compensation scheme caused further harm through delays and insensitive processes. Victims repeatedly contacted his team, prompting a follow-up investigation into payouts.

In response, the government immediately agreed to implement seven of the inquiry's sixteen recommendations while consulting victims on others. The newly established Infected Blood Compensation Authority separately accepted all recommendations under its jurisdiction.

A crucial adjustment enables family members eligible for compensation to pass on claims to their estates if they die before December 31, 2031. Officials will also review compensation recognition for severe interferon treatment side effects and psychological trauma.

Thomas-Symonds confirmed the modifications require an additional £1 billion added to the previously allocated £11.8 billion compensation pool, with exact costs finalized during autumn budget planning.

Andy Evans of victim group Tainted Blood acknowledged improved government engagement but highlighted unresolved concerns regarding hepatitis payment levels: "We must now press forward to ensure this scheme provides real justice, as far as money ever can, for all victims of this scandal."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: AI Tool Aeneas Unlocks Secrets in Ancient Roman Inscriptions
fields.summary: Researchers have created an AI system called Aeneas that can reconstruct missing text from ancient Roman inscriptions while dating and locating them geographically. Though concerns exist about potential errors, historians suggest this technology could revolutionize our understanding of ancient societies by rapidly analyzing fragmentary evidence.
fields.content:
Artificial intelligence systems now show promise in transforming historical research, with a new tool demonstrating the ability to fill gaps in humanity's understanding of ancient civilizations. Named Aeneas after a classical mythological hero, this AI analyzes Roman inscriptions carved on monuments and objects to reconstruct missing text while estimating their dates and origins with unprecedented speed.

Historians caution that AI analysis of texts can sometimes generate errors, potentially distorting historical interpretation. Despite such concerns, Cambridge University historian Dame Mary Beard describes the technology as "transformative" for studying antiquity. She explains that breakthroughs in this complex field traditionally rely on scholars' intuitions and exhaustive database searches, but "Aeneas opens up entirely new horizons" for accelerating discoveries.

The Challenge of Ancient Texts

Roman inscriptions—critical records of ancient societies—often survive in incomplete fragments with uncertain provenance and dates. Historians typically reconstruct them using 'parallels': texts with similar linguistic patterns, cultural contexts, or physical appearances. Since many inscriptions follow standard formulas, experts can logically infer missing content, yet the process remains painstakingly slow.

Dr. Thea Sommerschield, a historian at Nottingham University who co-developed Aeneas, compares the task to solving "a gigantic jigsaw puzzle with tens of thousands of pieces, of which 90 per cent are lost" from centuries of degradation. Traditional analysis can require months or years but yields unparalleled insights about history, language, and vanished ways of life.

Ruined Roman temple structure with collapsed walls

Revolutionizing Research

Aeneas represents a significant advancement beyond previous AI applications, such as digital unwrapping of Roman scrolls from Herculaneum. Developed by Dr. Sommerschield and Google DeepMind AI expert Yannis Assael, the system combines historical expertise with machine learning. Aeneas scans its database of 176,000 Roman inscriptions, images, and metadata to instantly generate historical parallels.

Dr. Assael explains that while historians cannot manually examine tens of thousands of inscriptions in seconds, AI can rapidly highlight relevant patterns: "That is where AI can come in as an assistant." The system supplements scholarly intuition with computational power to uncover connections potentially missed by humans working alone.

Damaged Roman plaque with large missing sections

Validating the Technology

To evaluate Aeneas, researchers tested it on the Res Gestae Divi Augusti—the famed "queen of inscriptions" detailing the achievements of Rome's first emperor, Augustus. This monumental text in Turkey's Temple of Augustus has long puzzled scholars regarding its exact date. Aeneas narrowed the possibilities to two viable ranges: 10-20 CE as most likely and 10-1 BCE as secondary, aligning with historical consensus.

Further testing with 23 historians revealed that human experts working alongside Aeneas produced more accurate interpretations than either could achieve independently. The AI additionally identified patterns scholars had previously overlooked, prompting Dr. Sommerschield to note that the true value lies in doing "things we didn't think to do before."

AI-enhanced visualization of ancient Greek inscription

Addressing concerns about AI reliability, Dr. Assael emphasizes that Aeneas augments rather than replaces historical scholarship: "We acknowledge that AI might not be able to get everything right... it will be down to human historians to weigh up predictions." By accelerating and expanding traditional methods, this collaboration between artificial and human intelligence offers fresh perspectives on our ancient past.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK and OpenAI Forge Partnership to Integrate AI Across Public Services
fields.summary: The UK government has signed a landmark agreement with OpenAI to deploy artificial intelligence across public services including education, defence, and justice systems, aiming to boost productivity and economic growth while raising ethical questions about data usage and commercial interests.
fields.content:
OpenAI, creator of ChatGPT, has agreed to collaborate with the UK government on incorporating artificial intelligence into essential public services. Both parties announced this partnership as a move to enhance administrative efficiency and economic performance.

The deal involves exploring data sharing between OpenAI and UK science departments, potentially allowing the company access to government information. AI systems could be implemented across education, defense, security agencies, and judicial processes.

Technology Secretary Peter Kyle stated that artificial intelligence will fundamentally drive national transformation and economic growth. Digital rights advocacy group Foxglove criticized the agreement as vague and problematic given government's large datasets of significant commercial value to OpenAI.

The non-binding agreement outlines developing safeguards for public protection and democratic values while examining investments in AI infrastructure like data centers. OpenAI will expand its London office, currently employing over 100 staff members.

Sam Altman, OpenAI's CEO, stated the collaboration would deliver widespread prosperity. Dr. Gordon Fletcher from the University of Salford suggested AI could free skilled public servants for complex cases but questioned whether implementation could remain transparent and ethical.

AI Plans

Government transparency records show Peter Kyle dined with Altman multiple times this spring. Kyle later acknowledged engaging with tech giants innovating beyond state capacity in a podcast interview.

This partnership aligns with Prime Minister Keir Starmer's "AI Opportunities Action Plan" for economic revitalization amid forecasts of minimal UK growth. Critics like UKAI's Tim Flagg previously argued such initiatives overly prioritize large tech firms over domestic innovators.

Specific AI tools named "Humphrey" are already being tested to boost civil service productivity. However, the rapid AI adoption faces criticism from groups like musicians concerned about unauthorized content usage in generative AI systems.

The government contends this collaboration could position the UK as a hub for world-changing AI development. Similar agreements exist with Google and Anthropic, though concerns persist about AI-generated misinformation and compliance with copyright regulations.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Fantastic Four Reboot Sees Marvel Regain Its Mojo, Critics Suggest
fields.summary: Marvel's latest reboot 'Fantastic Four: First Steps' earns praise as the studio's best film in years, with critics highlighting its retro charm and strong cast performances despite lingering concerns over humor and tension for the MCU's 37th installment.
fields.content:
Marvel's superhero film series shows renewed vigor with the reboot 'Fantastic Four: First Steps,' according to early critical reviews positioning it as the studio's strongest effort in a decade. The 37th installment in the Marvel Cinematic Universe draws acclaim for its distinctive retro style after the 2015 adaptation of the comic book series underperformed both commercially and critically.

Disney/Marvel Vanessa Kirby as The Invisible Woman

Variety lauded the film as Marvel regaining its mojo with a satisfying retro-styled approach. Reviewer Peter Debrudge emphasized its refreshing departure from convoluted MCU storytelling, noting the gender-swapped Silver Surfer role portrays an intriguing dynamic with the Human Torch. Set in the 1960s, the film stars Pedro Pascal as Reed Richards alongside Vanessa Kirby as Sue Storm, Joseph Quinn as Johnny Storm, and Ebon Moss-Bachrach as Ben Grimm, defending Earth against cosmic entities Galactus and Silver Surfer.

Disney/Marvel The Fantastic Four pictured together

The Telegraph awarded four stars, highlighting the hopeful tone and impressive ensemble chemistry. Robbie Collin described Kirby as "especially good value" and praised the film for placing heroes in relatable human scenarios. Similarly, The Guardian's Peter Bradshaw noted the entertaining spectacle overcame genre fatigue through its self-contained universe and coherent finale based on established storylines.

Embrace wonder again

Other reviews offered tempered praise, with The Independent calling the film a vibrant but risk-averse franchise starter. Critic Clarisse Loughrey highlighted a fascinating ethical quandary resolved predictably, arguing it was pleasant to see the genre re-embrace wonder despite unrealized potential. Director Matt Shakman confirmed the movie exists in its own universe for accessibility, mentioning John Malkovich's scenes as Red Ghost were regrettably cut.

DIsney/Marvel The Thing

Marvel Studios president Kevin Feige revealed an upcoming seven-year plan for the MCU and drew parallels to DC's recent Superman reboot, which he praised for swiftly establishing its world without extensive background knowledge. While BBC Culture critiqued the film for lacking tension, Empire countered with four stars, highlighting the heroes' inspiring sincerity. 'Fantastic Four: First Steps' releases in UK cinemas on Thursday.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Iran Vows to Continue Nuclear Program and Warns of Readiness for War with Israel
fields.summary: Iranian President Pezeshkian has firmly rejected demands to dismantle Iran's nuclear program, asserting that the knowledge behind it resides in scientists' minds rather than physical facilities. He warned that Iran is prepared for military confrontation with Israel, claiming previous Israeli attacks failed to eliminate their nuclear capabilities and expressing doubt about peaceful resolutions.
fields.content:
Iranian President Pezeshkian declared that his country's nuclear capabilities cannot be destroyed because they are rooted in scientific expertise rather than physical infrastructure. "Our nuclear capabilities are in the minds of our scientists and not in the facilities," he stated, rejecting calls to terminate the program.

Pezeshkian acknowledged recent Israeli strikes targeting Iranian nuclear officials but asserted these attacks "completely failed" to dismantle the nuclear program's leadership structure. He simultaneously issued a direct warning of military readiness against Israel.

The president emphasized Iran's preparedness for renewed hostilities, stating: "We are fully prepared for any new Israeli military move, and our armed forces are ready to strike deep inside Israel again." He indicated Tehran's forces retain the capacity to retaliate against Israeli territories.

Fire and smoke rise from an Iranian oil depot

Expressing skepticism about diplomatic solutions, Pezeshkian remarked, "We are not very optimistic about it." He described a cycle of mutual attacks between both nations, claiming: "Israel has harmed us, and we have also harmed it. It has dealt us powerful blows, and we have struck it hard in its depths, but it is concealing its losses."

Iranian, Chinese and Russian officials meet.

The report notes a critical timeframe linked to the 2015 nuclear agreement, formally known as the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA). Member states face an October 18 deadline to trigger snapback sanctions before economic measures outlined in the agreement expire.

While Pezeshkian reiterated Iran's preference for diplomatic solutions, he maintained all negotiations must follow "win-win logic" without external pressure: "We believe in diplomacy, so any future negotiations must be according to a win-win logic, and we will not accept threats and dictates."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Democrats Blame Republicans as Government Shutdown Looms
fields.summary: Democrats led by Chuck Schumer and Hakeem Jeffries are unifying their messaging to blame Republicans for a potential government shutdown ahead of the September 30 funding deadline, while GOP leaders accuse them of deliberately sabotaging negotiations.
fields.content:
Congressional Democrats are reinforcing their position prior to the critical September 30 deadline, openly holding Republican lawmakers responsible for the looming threat of a government shutdown. Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer criticized GOP tactics: "We all want a bipartisan, bicameral appropriations process... but Republicans are making it extremely difficult to achieve."

Democratic leadership recently held meetings near the Senate floor to coordinate messaging strategies across Congress. This effort follows March's political turmoil when Schumer initially clashed with House Democratic Leader Hakeem Jeffries before conceding to pass a last-minute government funding extension.

John Thune

Republicans counter that Schumer blocked all House-passed spending bills during his Senate leadership, halting the constitutional appropriations process that traditionally originates in the House. Senate Republican Whip John Thune emphasized: "Frankly, a lot of us think this standard process is long overdue," referencing the absence of regular appropriations completion since the 1990s.

Rep. Hakeem Jeffries

With most Senate legislation requiring 60 votes to overcome filibusters, bipartisan compromise appears necessary. Democrats reluctantly supported a partisan House GOP funding extension earlier this year but now demand greater involvement. Jeffries warned congressional Democrats would only engage in "bipartisan and bicameral" negotiations, declaring: "House Republicans are marching us toward a shutdown harming Americans."

House Speaker Mike Johnson fired back, asserting Democratic leaders are actively "gaming out how they can shut the government down" rather than seeking solutions. Lawmakers face mounting pressure to resolve budget disagreements or trigger federal service disruptions when funding expires in September.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Experimental Drug Erases Deadly Brain Cancer in Trial Patient
fields.summary: A glioblastoma patient given months to live has remained cancer-free for over two years after receiving an experimental immunotherapy drug called ipilimumab, with this successful case inspiring an expanded clinical trial for the deadly brain cancer treatment.
fields.content:
Ben Trotman was 40 years old when diagnosed with glioblastoma in 2022, considered the most aggressive form of brain cancer. Patients typically survive just 15 months after diagnosis, with only 6.9% living beyond five years.

Referred to University College London Hospitals' National Hospital for Neurology and Neurosurgery, Trotman became the sole participant in a trial for ipilimumab—an immunotherapy treatment. He simultaneously underwent radiation and chemotherapy under oncologist Dr. Paul Mulholland's care.

Over two years later, quarterly medical scans reveal no evidence of the previously fatal brain tumor. "We felt we had a lucky break in an otherwise devastating situation," Trotman stated regarding the outcome.

Just two months after beginning ipilimumab treatment, Trotman married his partner Emily. The couple welcomed their daughter Mabel in April 2025. "Getting this diagnosis was the most traumatic experience—we were grappling with the fact that Ben had gone from being apparently perfectly healthy to having months to live," Emily Trotman recalled.

Ben and Emily Trotman wedding day

She added: "We are focused on rebuilding the life we thought we had lost and enjoying being parents."

Dr Paul Mulholland and Dame Siobhain McDonagh MP

New Trial Launched

Dame Siobhain McDonagh has funded a new trial called Win-Glio, nicknamed "Margaret's Trial" after her sister Margaret who died of glioblastoma in 2023 while under Dr. Mulholland's care. Sixteen patients will participate in the University College London-sponsored research.

The trial will administer ipilimumab at NIHR UCLH’s Clinical Research Facility before participants receive standard treatments like surgery, radiotherapy, or chemotherapy. Dr. Mulholland expressed optimism about extending the experimental therapy to more patients.

Glioblastoma brain tumor medical scan

Trotman voiced strong support for the expanded trial: "I am delighted this treatment advances with the same immunotherapy drug. It will offer newly diagnosed glioblastoma patients genuine hope."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Japanese Police Conduct Bear Attack Drills Following Recent Incidents
fields.summary: Japanese authorities are conducting realistic bear attack simulations using costumed actors after multiple bear encounters injured residents and disrupted school activities, while sharing wildlife safety guidelines.
fields.content:
In Nasushiobara City, a man in his 70s suffered neck and head injuries from a five-foot bear near an elementary school last month, according to national media reports. The wounds were reported as non-life-threatening.

Separately in Hokkaido, an elementary school canceled outdoor classes after bear footprints appeared in its playground, heightening safety concerns in affected communities.

Police with shields facing costumed bear during drill

Police have now initiated training exercises where officers wearing protective helmets and shields confront an actor in a bear costume during realistic attack scenarios. These drills aim to improve response protocols amid rising bear encounters.

The National Park Service (NPS) advises: "Identify yourself by talking calmly so the bear recognizes you as human rather than prey. Remain still; maintain your position while slowly waving your arms."

Officers practicing defensive formations against bear

NPS guidelines clarify that when bears stand upright, it typically indicates curiosity rather than aggression. Authorities emphasize never running or climbing trees during encounters.

“Leave the area or detour whenever possible. If movement isn't feasible, wait for the bear to depart instead. Always provide the animal an escape route," advises the official wildlife safety protocol.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Dolphins Player Bayron Matos Airlifted Following Training Camp Injury
fields.summary: Miami Dolphins offensive lineman Bayron Matos was airlifted to a hospital following an injury during training camp workouts. The team confirmed he remains in stable condition while withholding specifics about his injury status.
fields.content:
Bayron Matos is in stable condition

After sustaining an injury during Wednesday's practice session, Miami Dolphins offensive lineman Bayron Matos required emergency air transport to a nearby medical facility. The Dolphins organization has verified his current status as stable but declined to provide detailed information regarding the nature or severity of his injury.

Matos joined the University of South Florida Bulls football program as a walk-on for the 2022 season. He initially played defensive lineman before transitioning to offensive positions, demonstrating uncommon athletic versatility.

Matos practicing

Born in the Dominican Republic, Matos relocated to America at age 16. Though he grew up playing baseball, his athletic focus shifted primarily to basketball before ultimately transitioning to American football.

His exceptional physical abilities became evident during his pro day workout. At 6-foot-7 and over 300 pounds, Matos recorded a remarkable 4.88-second 40-yard dash time. This performance would have ranked as the fastest among all offensive and defensive linemen at that year's NFL Scouting Combine.

Bayron Matos pregame

Matos is currently participating in the NFL's International Player Pathway Program, an initiative designed to increase opportunities for athletes not raised primarily in the U.S. or Canada. His rapid development made him an intriguing prospect for the Dolphins this offseason.

Following the incident, Wednesday's training camp session was closed to spectators. Team officials have indicated that future practices won't be accessible to fans until Saturday as the team focuses internally.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Revolutionary Bionic Knee Restores Natural Movement for Amputees
fields.summary: MIT researchers have developed a breakthrough bionic knee that anchors directly to the bone and integrates with muscle tissue, enabling above-the-knee amputees to walk, climb stairs, and kick balls with unprecedented natural movement. The system responds to neural signals for intuitive control, transforming prosthetic functionality through osseointegration and advanced robotics.
fields.content:
A revolutionary prosthetic knee developed at MIT allows above-the-knee amputees to perform fluid movements like kicking balls or stair climbing with ease. Unlike traditional socket-based designs, this bionic solution anchors directly to the bone and connects with muscle tissue for faster, smoother motion.

Led by Professor Hugh Herr, the team created technology that responds to user intent, allowing the prosthesis to synchronize with natural body movements. This advanced control achieves seamless integration that redefines artificial limb capabilities.

How the e-OPRA System Functions

The e-OPRA (Enhanced Osseointegrated Prostheses for the Rehabilitation of Amputees) involves surgically implanting a titanium rod into the femur that connects directly to a robotic limb. This establishes an innovative body-machine interface beyond typical prosthetics.

Through the Agonist-Antagonist Myoneural Interface method, muscles are functionally paired to communicate movement signals to the robotic controller. This neural mapping enables knee motions that accurately replicate those of a biological leg.

Natural Motion Achieved in Trials

During testing, two participants demonstrated significantly improved mobility, walking faster and navigating stairs more easily with heightened confidence. Importantly, they reported the prosthetic felt like a natural extension of their body.

One trial subject with minimal residual thigh length fluidly walked, pivoted, and kicked a soccer ball—movements that showcase the system's unprecedented responsiveness for above-knee amputees.

Illustration of a new e-OPRA bionic knee that can help people with above-the-knee amputations.

Advancing Beyond Conventional Prosthetics

Traditional socket designs cause discomfort, instability, and infections while feeling externally attached. This bionic solution eliminates sockets by integrating with bone and muscle, improving load distribution and reducing skin complications while restoring psychological ownership and control.

Development Fueled by Personal Journey

Professor Hugh Herr, who lost both legs below the knee during his teens, returned to mountaineering and dedicated his career to prosthetic innovation at MIT. His biomechatronics lab now pioneers technologies that may transform mobility solutions for amputees worldwide.

A man kicking balls while wearing the e-OPRA bionic knee prosthesis.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Essential Beach Skincare Guide for Sun Protection
fields.summary: A grooming editor shares crucial skincare items beyond basic sunscreen to prevent UV damage during beach trips, including reapplication strategies and specialized product recommendations.
fields.content:
While beach days offer relaxation with sand between your toes and ocean breezes, they pose risks to skin health from intense sun exposure. Basic sunscreen application isn't sufficient for full protection—experts recommend a comprehensive approach. Sand irritation and UV radiation demand an expanded skincare strategy to prevent burns and long-term damage.

Reapplying sunscreen every two hours is critical, especially after swimming or sweating. Skipping reapplication leaves skin vulnerable to burns, premature aging, and heightened cancer risks from UV damage. Sunscreen serves as just the starting point for comprehensive protection during activities like swimming or beach sports.

More of Our Favorite Sun Protection

Key sunscreen categories include reef-safe formulas, options for sensitive skin, convenient stick applications, zinc oxide products, SPF moisturizers, drugstore alternatives, broad-spectrum solutions, and mineral-based options.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Five Essential Books Celebrating Self-Taught Artists
fields.summary: Discover five pivotal books that highlight the extraordinary contributions of self-taught artists, featuring in-depth analysis of their groundbreaking works and the cultural shifts they inspired across American art history.
fields.content:
The Quilts of Gee’s Bend

Collector William Arnett championed the exhibition "The Quilts of Gee’s Bend" and its richly illustrated catalog, documenting social history and biographies. These revolutionary textiles showcase bold blocks of color in rhythmic designs. Their 2002 debut at New York's Whitney Museum became a cultural phenomenon, with critics recognizing the quilts—created by impoverished Black women in rural Alabama—as masterpieces of American abstract art.

Judith Scott: Bound & Unbound

Beginning in her 40s, Judith Scott produced abstract sculptures for over a decade by binding yarn around found objects. The 2014 Brooklyn Museum exhibition catalog marked a turning point in interpretations of self-taught artists. Cocurators Catherine Morris and Matthew Higgs challenged reductive readings of creators with disabilities, positioning Scott's work firmly within contemporary art discourse through illuminating essays.

Darger’s Resources

Michael Moon's revelatory 2012 monograph recontextualizes Henry Darger's visionary works through queer theory and literary studies. The book examines how Darger's epic narratives about the Vivian Girls—juxtaposing idyllic scenes and disturbing violations—drew from 20th-century children's literature, pulp fiction, historical texts, and biblical sources, serving as allegories about slavery and morality.

Horace Pippin, American Modern

Art historian Anne Monahan's 2020 work rescues Horace Pippin from misclassification as a folk artist, restoring his status as the most successful African American artist of his era. Despite being disabled during World War I, Pippin taught himself to paint in the 1930s. Monahan explores his depictions of Black history and life while chronicling how postwar abstractionism unjustly marginalized his legacy.

James Castle: A Retrospective

This 2008 catalog introduced James Castle into mainstream art history through scholarly essays and scientific material analysis. Curator Ann Percy and conservators Nancy Ash and Scott Homolka cataloged thousands of the reclusive artist's undated works, establishing his significance despite his lack of exhibition history. The publication cemented Castle's position among America's most important 20th-century creators.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Gaza Faces Catastrophic Starvation as Aid Organizations Issue Urgent Warning
fields.summary: Over 100 international humanitarian organizations have jointly warned of mass starvation spreading across Gaza, describing populations as 'wasting away' amid Israel's blockade and calling for immediate government action to prevent famine.
fields.content:
The Humanitarian Emergency

More than 100 aid organizations and human rights groups, including Médecins Sans Frontières, Save the Children, and Oxfam, issued a dire warning about catastrophic starvation in Gaza. Their statement described colleagues and beneficiaries as 'wasting away' due to extreme food shortages.

Gaza's health ministry reported 10 Palestinians died from malnutrition in the past 24 hours, bringing the total such deaths to 43 since Sunday. The UN documented people hospitalized with severe exhaustion and others collapsing in streets from hunger.

Israel, which controls all supply entry points, rejected the statement, accusing organizations of 'serving Hamas propaganda.' This rebuttal came amid reports that Israel imposed a near-total aid blockade in early March before partially easing restrictions after global famine warnings.

Mosab al-Debs, 14, who medics say is suffering from malnutrition, lies on a bed at Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City

Humanitarian groups reported record malnutrition levels, especially among children and elderly people, alongside spreading illnesses like acute watery diarrhoea. Psychologists quoted children saying they 'want to go to heaven because at least heaven has food.'

The World Health Organization estimates a quarter of Gaza's population faces famine-like conditions, with nearly 100,000 women and children needing urgent treatment for severe acute malnutrition. Dr. Ahmad al-Farra, a pediatrician in Khan Younis, confirmed no food was available for three days at his hospital, with children dying from starvation complications.

Skyrocketing prices have made essentials unaffordable—"Every day we need 300 shekels just for flour," one resident said. Families now rely on scarce aid deliveries as local markets remain depleted.

A Palestinian girl reacts as she waits to receive food from a charity kitchen in Gaza City

Obstacles to Aid Delivery

Aid groups highlighted that the UN recorded over 1,050 Palestinians killed while attempting to access food since late May, coinciding with US/Israel-backed food distribution efforts. According to UN data, 766 died near aid sites in Israeli military zones, with 288 more killed near convoys.

Israel maintains its forces only fire warning shots near Gaza Humanitarian Foundation sites and denies deliberately targeting civilians. The GHF dismissed UN figures as 'false and misleading.'

Most Gaza residents are confined to under 12% of the territory outside evacuation zones, complicating relief operations. Currently, only about 28 aid trucks reach people daily—far below requirements—while warehouses both inside and outside Gaza hold unused supplies.

While Israel cites 'collection bottlenecks' as the issue, the UN struggles to obtain Israeli authorization for Gaza drivers to collect goods at crossings amid debris-blocked roads, fuel shortages, chaotic security conditions, and armed looting. UN spokesperson Stéphane Dujarric reported civilians being 'under fire at collection points despite assurances.'

International Response

Humanitarian groups urged governments to demand an immediate ceasefire, lift restrictions on aid, open all land crossings, and restore UN-led distribution. They also called for halting weapons transfers to Israel.

Israel's foreign ministry rejected these appeals, stating they 'harm ceasefire chances' and alleging organizations use 'Hamas talking points.' These accusations come amid stalled hostage-release negotiations continuing in Qatar.

The Latin and Greek Orthodox patriarchs of Jerusalem walk together

The conflict began following Hamas's October 7 attack on Israel that killed approximately 1,200 people and took 251 hostages. Gaza's health ministry reports at least 59,219 Palestinians have since been killed. Religious leaders described widespread desperation, noting starving people no longer react to bombings.

The body of Abdul Hamid al-Ghalban, 13, who died of malnutrition, is carried before burial

Women hold bowls and buckets while waiting for food aid in Gaza

The UK government suspended some arms exports to Israel, which Foreign Secretary David Lammy defended while criticizing Israel's rejection of peace initiatives. Lammy stated pressure for a ceasefire aligns with international humanitarian obligations.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Elderly British Couple Held by Taliban Face Deteriorating Health Conditions
fields.summary: The son of British citizens detained by Taliban authorities in Afghanistan warns his elderly parents may die in prison due to rapidly worsening health conditions and inadequate medical care after five months of detention without formal charges.
fields.content:
The son of a British couple held by Taliban authorities in Afghanistan since February voiced concerns they may deteriorate fatally in custody. Jonathan Reynolds fears his parents, Peter Reynolds (80) and Barbie Reynolds (76), could perish without urgent medical intervention despite Taliban assurances.

Arrested on February 1 while returning home to Bamiyan province, the couple face uncertain charges. Jonathan reported their health condition is deteriorating drastically. His father experiences violent convulsions and Parkinson's-like tremors, while his mother shows signs of severe anaemia and malnutrition with blue extremities.

Taliban Foreign Minister Amir Khan Muttaqi asserted the pair receive medical care and maintain "occasional contact" with relatives. "All their human rights are being respected," he declared, adding that release procedures are ongoing but incomplete.

The UN's human rights office contradicted this, urgently warning the couple could die without immediate hospital transfer. Their statement called the detention "inhumane," citing prisoners held in "degrading conditions" with no justification provided. The UN confirmed engaging both Taliban and UK authorities to resolve the crisis.

The Reynolds lived in Afghanistan for 18 years, holding citizenship and operating education initiatives. Their projects included training programs for women and children, operating despite Taliban restrictions on female education and employment above age 12. Jonathan described their imprisonment as traumatic, with his father "chained to murderers and criminals" and both confined for six weeks in a windowless basement.

During their last family contact on June 15, the couple revealed critical health details. Jonathan's father reportedly convulsed uncontrollably for 30 minutes before guards moved him to a mattress on the floor. The couple recently marked birthdays and their 55th wedding anniversary in custody.

UK Foreign Office officials visited the detainees last week, supplying the family photographic confirmation of their wellbeing. Though acknowledging Foreign Office communication, Jonathan expressed frustration at unfulfilled release promises: "Week after week we're told 'just wait two or three more days'... and they're still in prison."

An FCDO spokesperson confirmed support for the family while noting its limited capacity since embassy closure in 2021. The office maintains its "severely limited" advisory against all travel to Afghanistan.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Sugar Industry Emerges Victorious in Coca-Cola's Sweetener Shift
fields.summary: President Trump's intervention has convinced Coca-Cola to introduce a US-made cane sugar version of its flagship soda, delivering a major victory to the sugar industry while worrying corn growers. The policy shift reveals the political clout of sugar producers amid debates about taste, health effects, and economic consequences.
fields.content:
The sugar industry is celebrating after Coca-Cola announced plans to launch a cane sugar version of its iconic soda in the United States following personal lobbying by President Donald Trump. This development represents a significant policy win for sugar producers who enjoy substantial government protections including high import tariffs that keep domestic prices nearly double global rates.

Political Muscle Behind Sweet Policies

Trump's unusual endorsement of cane sugar last week - despite being known for consuming sugar-free Diet Coke - underscores his administration's consistent backing of sugar interests. The sector maintains powerful Washington connections, with former House Speaker John Boehner noting in his memoir, "Don't [expletive] with sugar." Under Trump, policies favoring sugar producers have expanded through import restrictions and higher price guarantees under the "Big Beautiful Bill."

Jordan Hayes prefers Mexican Coca-Cola made with cane sugar

Health Secretary Robert F Kennedy Jr has simultaneously targeted sugar's main competitor, describing corn syrup as "poison." While accounts differ on Coca-Cola's motivation for the change, analysts note the shift could substantially boost sugar demand. "They have the president both championing restrictions that keep out foreign competition and encouraging more use of sugar. This is fantastic for them," observes Colin Grabow, a trade specialist at the Cato Institute.

Corn Growers Voice Opposition

Corn-based sweetener producers face economic headwinds following the announcement. When news broke, corn syrup manufacturer Archer Daniels Midland stocks temporarily plunged over 6%. Corn growers express bewilderment at Trump's position reversal, given his vocal support for American agricultural jobs.

Iowa corn farmer John Maxwell remarks, "He's tooted that horn real hard... so to take a stance was surprising." Bob Hemesath, another Iowa corn farmer, warns "Going away from high fructose corn syrup will hurt jobs here and hurt farmers." Policy analyst Vincent Smith highlights the numerical imbalance between both sectors: approximately 4,000 sugar farmers versus 200,000 corn farmers.

Taste and Health Questions Remain

Debates continue about whether cane sugar actually tastes superior or offers health advantages. Jordan Hayes, 37, contends Mexican Coke's cane sugar creates a "different kind of sweetness" worth its premium price. Studies by nutritional biologist Kimber Stanhope however show no significant health differences: "Both sugars increase all risk factors." She dismisses claims about either sweetener being less processed as "completely quibbling."

Coca-Cola collector Richard Trappasse found no taste difference in blind tests

Coca-Cola memorabilia collector Richard Trappasse, 48, conducted blind taste tests between regular Coke and the cane sugar variety. "The first thing I said was, 'Did you put the same soda in the glass to trick me?' They taste exactly the same," he recalls. Despite this, Trappasse believes Trump's nostalgic pitch for "classic Coca-Cola" will emotionally resonate with supporters. The new cane sugar beverage launches this autumn as Coca-Cola simultaneously expands its low and no-sugar options amid health concerns.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ex-union boss McCluskey took private jet flights arranged by building contractor
fields.summary: A Unite union investigation report found former leader Len McCluskey accepted private jet trips and football tickets arranged by Flanagan Group, the contractor that allegedly overcharged by £30m for a Birmingham hotel project while he overruled internal objections.
fields.content:
An internal Unite union report revealed that former general secretary Len McCluskey received private jet flights and football tickets organized by Flanagan Group, the firm constructing a multi-million pound hotel project for the union. The report found Flanagan Group overcharged Unite by at least £30m for the Birmingham hotel and conference center development.

Evidence showed McCluskey personally "overruled" advice from Unite's staff and legal counsel when approving the construction contract with Flanagan Group. According to the investigation, the flights and match tickets were consistently arranged and funded by the contractor without evidence of reimbursement.

The Eastside Rooms hotel, which was built by Flanagan Group for Unite the Union

As a powerful trade union figure who backed Jeremy Corbyn's Labour leadership, McCluskey championed the hotel as a financial investment for members. After Sharon Graham succeeded him in 2021, she uncovered massive cost discrepancies, launching inquiries that showed £125m spent on a project now valued at £38m. The Serious Fraud Office has opened a separate investigation.

"I was absolutely astounded," said Graham. "It's either rank incompetence, or it's something else." Specialist construction lawyer Martin Bowdery KC was commissioned to investigate, with the report presented to Unite's executive council.

Tickets and flights

McCluskey reportedly used private jets for trips to Liverpool FC's 2018 and 2019 Champions League finals in Kyiv and Madrid. Sources identified one journey on a Falcon 900B jet featuring leather seats and a full-size bed, estimated to cost £40,000-£47,500 round trip. Unite's evidence cited email correspondence about five additional domestic match tickets with hospitality packages.

Getty Images Falcon 900B business jet standing on the tarmac at an airport at night

McCluskey's lawyers stated he paid for all travel and tickets, though he couldn't recall all matches noted in the report. Unite lacked an official gifts policy during his tenure, prompting Graham to implement new financial controls and recovery efforts: "I'm going to do everything to get members' money back."

Ballooning costs

The hotel's estimated £7m budget in 2012 ballooned to £96m paid to Flanagan Group by completion in 2021. Bowdery's report identified £30m in overcharging, including £1.3m billed for £90,000-worth of work and £3.7m paid for weather delays despite contractual ineligibility. The contractor previously cited design changes and unionized labour for cost increases, calling the result "an exceptional asset."

Unionised labour

Despite assertions that using union workers drove overruns, investigators found no financial evidence supporting the claim. Emails from 2017 indicated most laborers weren't covered by union agreements, with Flanagan Group allegedly refusing confirmation of compliance. McCluskey's lawyers asserted he would have addressed any known violations.

Paul Flanagan and Len McCluskey at an artwork unveiling in Liverpool in 2014

Who signed the contract?

The report highlighted a lack of documentation about Flanagan Group's appointment, calling it "remarkable." McCluskey attributed the decision to late finance director Ed Sabisky, though a union official claimed Sabisky opposed the contractor and was overruled. While the report states McCluskey signed the main contract, his lawyers dispute his recollection of doing so. The Flanagan Group did not respond to repeated inquiries.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Volunteering Journey: A Father's Payback for Life-Saving Transport
fields.summary: Willie Hutchinson became a volunteer driver for Northern Ireland Ambulance Service after his three children relied on transport for kidney dialysis, seeing it as payback for the support his family received during their transplants. He is among over 75 volunteers providing vital patient transport across Northern Ireland.
fields.content:
Hospital journeys for serious health treatments become far less daunting when met with compassion from volunteers. Patients facing terminal illnesses or regular dialysis often depend on the kindness of strangers who turn into trusted companions.

The Northern Ireland Ambulance Service's volunteer drivers perform a crucial but often overlooked role, providing free transportation for medical appointments entirely unpaid. "They go above and beyond daily," states Yvonne McMichael of NIAS, highlighting their indispensability.

Willie Hutchinson joined this network after experiencing the service firsthand during his children's kidney dialysis treatments before their transplants.
