"Somebody did it for them, so I'm doing it for somebody else," says the grandfather and former truck driver. In 2023, his dedication earned him the British Empire Medal.

Willie Hutchinson smiling outdoors near a riverbank

His medal nomination came from a long-term passenger who died hours after Hutchinson helped him home on the award day. "His family were thrilled to bits for me," Hutchinson recalls, describing the moment as bittersweet.

'Compassion and calmness'

Drivers earn only a mileage allowance in exchange for transporting patients in personal vehicles. This service significantly cuts NIAS costs compared to taxis or ambulances.

Tommy Nicholl standing beside his car

Tommy Nicholl, undergoing dialysis for seven years, emphasizes drivers offer more than transportation. "They have compassion, they bring calmness when patients like me need that," says the former Mid and East Antrim mayor.

'Not enough ambulances'

Yvonne McMichael credits the volunteers as vital given ambulance shortages. They service seven renal units and two cancer centers across the region.

Yvonne McMichael in ambulance service uniform

Driver Martin Garrity finds meaning in friendships formed during 15 years of volunteering. "They confide in you... sometimes it's tough," he admits. Despite emotional challenges, he hopes to continue for years: "The reward is worth it."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Journalists in Gaza Face Starvation While Reporting Crisis
fields.summary: Major international news agencies warn that journalists in Gaza are starving alongside the population they cover, unable to feed themselves amid Israel's blockade. Local reporters face extreme deprivation while serving as vital news sources due to restrictions on foreign media entry.
fields.content:
Journalists Share Population's Plight

BBC News, Agence France-Presse, Associated Press, and Reuters jointly declared their journalists in Gaza increasingly cannot feed themselves or their families. Those reporting on the conflict endure starvation and "the same dire circumstances as those they are covering," according to the agencies' statement. For months, these local reporters have provided essential coverage since Israel prohibits foreign media from entering Gaza, forcing international outlets to depend entirely on them.

The statement emphasized stark deprivation: "Journalists endure many hardships in warzones. We are deeply alarmed that the threat of starvation is now one of them." Agencies urgently renewed calls for Israeli authorities to permit journalist movement and ensure food reaches civilians.

A woman holds a severely underweight child in a tent in Gaza

Deepening Humanitarian Emergency

Over 100 international aid organizations and human rights groups simultaneously warned of mass starvation gripping Gaza. Médecins Sans Frontières, Save the Children, and Oxfam reported their staff and communities were "wasting away," while Israel accused these charities of "serving the propaganda of Hamas." Gaza's health ministry stated 45 Palestinians died of malnutrition-related causes in recent days.

Israel halted aid deliveries in early March after suspending a ceasefire, only partially resuming supplies later. Acute shortages of food and medicine persist despite controversial aid mechanisms like the internationally supported Gaza Humanitarian Foundation, established with U.S. involvement. WHO director Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus warned: "A quarter of Gaza's population faces famine-like conditions. I don't know what you would call it other than mass starvation, and it's man-made... because of the blockade."

Humanitarian organizations confirmed Israel's siege left supplies "totally depleted," citing desperate scenes including malnourished individuals showing no reaction to nearby bombings.

Four men, two in religious robes, walk along

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Gaza Famine Forces Desperate Residents to Risk Lives for Food
fields.summary: Gaza residents face life-threatening dangers while attempting to secure basic food supplies amidst worsening famine conditions, with medical workers at a southern field hospital reporting daily casualties among aid seekers and international organizations accusing Israel of creating a man-made starvation crisis. Personal testimonies and UN data reveal over 1,000 Palestinians killed near aid distribution points in recent months.
fields.content:
Mohammed al-Qedra, aged 33, lies injured in a Gaza field hospital after being shot while seeking food. "Hunger makes us go there despite everything," he explained, holding his wounded hand. "We know we might get injured or killed at any moment, yet we still go to get a kilo of flour." Al-Qedra was struck in both the hand and leg while attempting to secure provisions for his family at an aid distribution site.

The UK-Med field hospital in al-Mawasi frequently receives casualties like al-Qedra who took extreme risks while seeking basic necessities. "I'm the sole breadwinner. Once I recover, I'll return to these centers regardless of danger," al-Qedra stated, highlighting the impossible choices Gazans face. Medical staff confirm such incidents occur daily as the territory descends into full-scale famine.

Patients awaiting care at Gaza field hospital

Shocking statistics from the UN human rights office reveal over 1,000 Palestinians have died attempting to access food during the past two months. At least 766 deaths occurred near aid distribution centers backed by Israel and the US, with 288 more fatalities reported near UN convoys. Israel disputes these figures, claiming its troops only fire warning shots and accusing Hamas of disrupting aid operations.

British paramedic Sam Sears describes overwhelming conditions at the field hospital: "We see around 2,000 patients monthly—gunshot wounds, shrapnel injuries, amputations, punctured lungs." Dr. Aseel Horabi, a Palestinian medic whose husband was shot at an aid site, calls the journey "a path to death." She added: "We sometimes receive 50 injured daily. Patients are starving, and we're hungry too—potatoes cost $36 per kilogram now."

Medic treating wounded man at Gaza hospital

The WHO's executive director, Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, confirmed "mass starvation" affecting Gaza's 2.1 million residents: "It's man-made. Why else would people risk their lives?" Over 100 international aid organizations recently accused Israel of imposing a deadly siege through strict import restrictions. The WHO estimates a quarter of Gazans face famine conditions, with nearly 100,000 children suffering acute malnutrition.

Israel categorically denies starving Palestinians, with government spokesman David Mencer asserting: "Hamas created these shortages." Mencer stated 4,400 aid trucks recently entered Gaza while blaming the UN for congestion at crossings. UN agencies counter that Israeli restrictions make convoy coordination impossible, leaving families helpless against the escalating famine that is claiming lives daily.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Corbyn Launches New British Political Party to Challenge Wealth Inequality
fields.summary: Former Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn has announced a new political party focused on wealth redistribution and challenging entrenched power structures, positioning it as a grassroots alternative to Labour and Reform UK. Corbyn will co-lead the unnamed party with independent MP Zarah Sultana.
fields.content:
Former Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn has launched a new political movement aiming to "take on the rich and powerful" through wealth redistribution policies. The independent MP for Islington North described the unnamed party as a democratic alternative to what he called Labour's "control freaks" and Reform UK's "dangerously divisive" politics.

In a joint declaration with Zarah Sultana, the Coventry South MP who recently left Labour, Corbyn stated: "It's time for a new kind of political party - one that belongs to you." The movement will combat issues like child poverty and corporate profiteering while opposing military spending at the expense of social programs.

When questioned if this resembled his Labour leadership era, Corbyn emphasized differences: "The Labour Party is very top-down... This will be community-led, grassroots-based and fun." He noted significant early interest with sign-ups reportedly reaching 500 per minute through their "Your Party" recruitment portal – though Sultana clarified this isn't the organization's final name.

A Labour source retorted: "The electorate has twice given its verdict on a Jeremy Corbyn led party." Corbyn dismissed suggestions of a disorganized launch, affirming the strategy as "totally coherent" despite his co-leader's physical absence from the announcement.

The partnership spans political generations – Corbyn with 50 years parliamentary experience against Sultana's six – but both share confidence in the British left's untapped energy. Their autumn inaugural conference will formalize policies positioning the party left of Labour on taxation, nationalization, and Middle East policy, with the explicit mission to "take on the rich and powerful – and win."

Though unlikely to win outright power, analysts warn even modest support could cost Labour seats at the May 2026 local elections, particularly in urban centers. Labour's vulnerability to left-wing challenges was recently exposed when Prime Minister Keir Starmer passed a weakened welfare bill by just 75 votes despite a 165-MP majority.

The party foundation follows months of speculation, accelerated when Sultana quit Labour after suspension for opposing the two-child benefit cap. Corbyn, who was expelled from Labour under Starmer, returns with momentum after successfully retaining his seat as an independent and organizing pro-Gaza MPs.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: NHS England Warns of Patient Harm Ahead of Doctor Strike
fields.summary: England braces for a five-day resident doctor strike as NHS leadership warns of unavoidable patient harm. The industrial action escalates amid conflicting approaches to emergency coverage and unresolved pay disputes involving the government and medical unions.
fields.content:
The upcoming five-day strike by resident doctors in England poses unacceptable risks to patients, according to NHS England national director Professor Tim Briggs. Despite acknowledging doctors' right to strike, he emphasized that patient safety concerns make the action particularly harmful. The walkout is scheduled to begin Friday at 07:00 BST.

Resident doctors – recently rebranded from junior doctors – are entering their 11th strike in a prolonged pay dispute. Hospitals have already canceled over a million appointments during previous strikes. Senior doctors are being recruited for strike coverage, but Professor Briggs expressed worry about impacts on both emergency services and non-urgent treatments.

NHS England aims to continue most non-urgent procedures like knee and hip operations during the strike, differing from earlier actions when such treatments were canceled nationwide. However, the British Medical Association argues this strategy isn't safe. The union contends many elective procedures should be canceled to ensure proper emergency department staffing.

Professor Briggs told the BBC that canceled non-urgent appointments also cause patient harm, noting examples like prolonged waits for hip replacements: "You cannot decouple elective and emergency care, the two go together." He described patients immobilized by pain, relying on strong medication while awaiting delayed surgeries.

BMA negotiation leader Dr Tom Dolphin apologized for the disruptive action: "Striking is something that doctors don't want to have to do." He stated the strikes were preventable had the government shown willingness to address pay erosion issues meaningfully. Dolphin confirmed the union remains open to negotiations.

Talks collapsed on Tuesday after five days of discussion. The BMA requested student debt relief among other concessions, which the government rejected. Health Secretary Wes Streeting had already ruled out revising this year's 5.4% average pay increase for resident doctors. This follows cumulative raises exceeding 20% over the past two years.

A fresh dispute emerged over premium pay rates for senior doctors covering strike shifts. NHS managers allege BMA-endorsed rates – reaching over £300 hourly for overnight shifts – are "simply unaffordable." Consultants could earn triple their standard pay under these terms. The union maintains higher rates must be offered to incentivize doctors to work extra hours.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Lord Chris Smith Elected as Cambridge University Chancellor
fields.summary: Former Culture Secretary Lord Chris Smith has been elected as Chancellor of the University of Cambridge following a competitive selection process involving 10 candidates, including prominent figures like Gina Miller and Sandi Toksvig.
fields.content:
Lord Chris Smith, the former Culture Secretary, has been elected as the next chancellor of the University of Cambridge following a competitive selection process. The election featured 10 candidates including prominent anti-Brexit campaigner Gina Miller and broadcaster Sandi Toksvig.

Lord Smith, who has served as master of Pembroke College since 2015, will occupy the ceremonial position for a 10-year term. Expressing his gratitude, Lord Smith stated: "To be elected as chancellor of the university I love is a huge honour. I'm thrilled."

He further emphasized his commitment: "I look forward to being the best possible ambassador for Cambridge, to being a strong voice for higher education more generally, and to working closely together with the vice-chancellor and her team."

Getty Images long, grey college building with elderly trees in the foreground and a well tended lawn

The chancellor's role is primarily ceremonial, lacking executive responsibilities, though the position involves advising senior university officials, supporting fundraising initiatives, and serving as an institutional ambassador. The position's most vital function remains championing the university's strategic goals.

'Strong relationship'

Approximately 23,000 alumni and staff participated in this historic election, marking the first time voting was conducted online. Lord Smith previously represented the Labour party as Secretary of State for Culture, Media and Sport from 1997 to 2001.

During his campaign, Lord Smith highlighted his commitment to diversity and noted he made history as the "first openly gay Cabinet Minister anywhere in the world". Additionally, he served as chairman of the Environment Agency (2008-2014) and concurrently chaired the Advertising Standards Authority (2007-2017).

In the election results, Dr Mohamed El-Erian from Queens' College secured second place, followed by broadcaster Sandi Toksvig in third position.

Sandi Toksvig is sitting an a BBC Radio 2 studio. In front of her is a black branded microphone and she is wearing headphones. The room is cast in dark orange lights. She is wearing a white shirt, red top and silver necklace. Toksvig has short white and blonde hair and is smiling at someone off camera.

University Vice-Chancellor Prof Deborah Prentice extended congratulations: "On behalf of everyone at the University, I offer my warm congratulations to Chris on his election." She acknowledged Lord Smith's extensive university involvement and "wealth of relevant experience," while praising other candidates' willingness to serve.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Staff Shortages Force Cancellation of Thousands of Water Pollution Tests
fields.summary: The Environment Agency has cancelled 10,000 water quality tests across England since May due to staffing shortages, halting critical pollution monitoring programs. Experts warn the cancellations impair detection of harmful chemicals in rivers and estuaries amid ongoing criticism of regulatory capacity.
fields.content:
Over 10,000 scheduled pollution tests for England's rivers, lakes and estuaries were cancelled between May and July due to staff shortages at the Environment Agency's main laboratory. Internal documents obtained by campaigners reveal seven national testing programmes were completely paused, including initiatives tracking chemical contamination and drought response plans.

The cancelled examinations targeted inorganic pollutants like nitrates and phosphates, which serve as indicators of sewage leaks or agricultural runoff. Although the agency described the changes as optimisation, water quality experts expressed concern about the reduction of vital environmental monitoring.

A man conducts water testing at the Starcross laboratory in Devon.

Impact on Pollution Monitoring

Former Environment Agency specialist Jo Bradley stressed the significance of routine testing: "Inorganic substances like copper and zinc directly poison aquatic life, while excessive nitrogen and phosphorus trigger ecosystem imbalances. Continuous monitoring across hundreds of locations is essential to identify pollution trends and emerging threats."

The Starcross laboratory in Devon, responsible for these analyses, operated at 17.5% reduced capacity during the three-month period, with annual testing expected to drop 15% below targets. Agency officials attributed the shortfall to staffing fluctuations but pledged full operational restoration by October.

Systemic Challenges and Criticism

Staff retention issues have plagued the agency for years, with chairman Alan Lovell acknowledging difficulties during 2023 parliamentary testimony. Leaked internal emails show officials discussing cascading impacts of staff departures, with one senior manager lamenting the situation as "not good news."

Former catchment planner Helen Nightingale described sinking morale among employees facing pay freezes and shifting priorities: "Many joined to make a difference, but frustration grows when you can't accomplish core environmental work." Documents confirm the testing cuts affected investigations into water industry practices and pollution monitoring in ecologically sensitive areas like the River Wye.

Campaign groups highlighted the monitoring gap through alternative programs. The Angling Trust reported collecting 10,000 water samples independently this spring, detecting phosphate breaches in 34% of sites. Vocal critic Feargal Sharkey called the agency "institutionally incompetent" as Sir Jon Cunliffe's landmark review recommended transferring pollution oversight to a new regulatory body. The Environment Agency defended its priorities, citing an extra £8m in funding and maintaining incidents and bathing water testing remained unaffected.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Major EE and BT Network Outage Leaves Thousands Without Service
fields.summary: Thousands of EE and BT customers across the UK are experiencing major service disruptions, with many unable to make or receive calls amid a widespread network outage. The companies have acknowledged the issue and are working to restore services.
fields.content:
Network Outage Impact

Customers of major telecommunications providers EE and BT reported extensive service failures across the UK, preventing thousands from making or receiving calls. The disruption peaked around 1400 BST, with outage tracker Downdetector recording over 2,500 incidents affecting EE services alone.

Numerous users also reported connectivity issues with other networks, though providers Vodafone and Three confirmed their systems were operational without problems. The disruption likely stems from EE connectivity problems affecting calls to BT numbers rather than problems in other networks.

BT Group, owner of EE network, apologized to customers through a spokesperson: "We're currently addressing an issue impacting our services. We’re working urgently to fix this issue and will provide further updates." Social media platforms flooded with complaints about mobile and landline service failures as the problem persisted.

Broader Implications

The financial scale of the disruption is significant given BT Group's 30-million-strong UK customer base and £20.4 billion annual revenue. Several mobile virtual network operators relying on EE infrastructure reported partial disruptions, including 1pMobile who cited issues "affecting a small number of customers" and confirmed engineers were addressing the problem.

The outage coincides with ongoing controversies surrounding BT's infrastructure changes, including plans to remove phone boxes across the UK. North Yorkshire Council has protested against proposed closures of over 90 local phone booths. Additionally, residents in rural Cumbria have expressed concerns about losing analogue phones that function during power outages.

Red K8 telephone box illuminated at night in rural setting

K8 phone boxes like this one have become increasingly rare, with fewer than 50 remaining across the UK.

Traditional red phone box beside busy car park

North Yorkshire Council urges BT to reconsider its plan to eliminate more than 90 local phone boxes.

Alice Bondi sitting in her home

Rural residents such as Alice Bondi in Cumbria rely on analogue phones that function during power cuts and fear losing this service.

Nigel Charlton standing before a modern white phone box

BT's removal plans extend to phonE boxes in locales like Kirton in Lindsey and Barrow upon Humber where this facility may vanish.

Woman in patterned shirt with fair hair

Adding to BT's troubles, a trade union claims 140 positions in Londonderry are at risk without proper staff consultation.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: How Black Sabbath forged heavy metal from industrial Birmingham
fields.summary: The story of how four working-class musicians from Aston transformed blues music into heavy metal through industrial accidents, horror films, and a rejection of flower-power optimism.
fields.content:
Black Sabbath's journey began with a profoundly un-metal moniker: The Polka Tulk Blues Band. During their 1968 debut, they featured a saxophonist and bottleneck guitarist—far removed from their future identity.

Within a year, they reinvented themselves completely, birthing heavy metal and establishing a template for generations. The Birmingham quartet—Ozzy Osbourne, Tony Iommi, Geezer Butler, and Bill Ward—set a precedent for bands from Motörhead to Metallica with their groundbreaking sound.

Getty Images Ozzy Osbourne and Tony Iommi on stage in 1970

Osbourne cited the transformation as a rebellion against the "hippy-dippy" sound dominating post-Summer of Love radio. "Flowers in your hair? Do me a favour," he scoffed. "The only flowers in Aston were for funerals."

The birth of a new sound

Inspiration struck when the band noticed crowds flocking to a cinema opposite their rehearsal space for horror films. Guitarist Tony Iommi proposed: "Why don't we write horror music?" Thus, Black Sabbath was named after a Boris Karloff film.

They intentionally darkened their music: Ward slowed tempos, Iommi amplified distortion, and Osbourne developed his signature unhinged vocal wail. But Iommi's innovative guitar style proved pivotal, born from industrial hardship.

Getty Images Tony Iommi plays guitar

After losing finger tips in a sheet metal accident at age 17, Iommi was told to abandon guitar. Undeterred, he melted a Fairy Liquid bottle to create protective thimbles, loosened his strings, and rewrote guitar technique using his surviving fingers.

Their 1970 debut album—recorded in two days—confounded listeners. Engineer Tom Allan admitted: "I couldn't fathom it." Critics dismissed it, yet its controversial Satanic imagery fueled sales, especially when the title track was revealed to contain the historically forbidden "Devil's Interval."

Getty Images Ozzy Osbourne holds a crystal ball while dressed in a wizard's robes. On the table in front of him is a book of spells and a candleabra encrusted with spiders' webs.

Enduring legacy

Sabbath defied expectations with increasingly sophisticated compositions through albums like "Paranoid" (featuring anti-war anthem War Pigs) and "Vol 4" with its poetic breadth. Ozzy reflected: "The music has held up after 49 years."

Getty Images A black and white photo showing members of Black Sabbath splashing each other in the river in the scenic Wye Valley, 1977.

Metallica's Lars Ulrich summarized their impact at their Rock Hall induction: "If there was no Black Sabbath, heavy metal would be shaped very differently."

Five essential Ozzy Osbourne tracks

1) "Paranoid" - Sabbath's surprise 1970 hit, conceived as filler. "It's a gift," said Osbourne of its unmistakable riff.

2) "Crazy Train" - Launched his solo career with a surprisingly hopeful message undercut by maniacal laughter.

3) "Sabbath Bloody Sabbath" - Showcased melodic prowess alongside Iommi's crushing guitar.

4) "Changes" - A tender piano ballad about heartbreak originally recorded with Sabbath in 1972.

5) "Mr Crowley" - Osbourne's first major solo statement exploring dark imagery alongside guitarist Randy Rhoads.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Intensified Conflict: Russia and Ukraine Exchange Strikes Amid Trump Deadline
fields.summary: Ukrainian authorities report 103 Russian attacks overnight targeting cities including Odesa, while Russian officials confirm a strike hit an oil depot near Sochi. The escalation occurs as former U.S. President Donald Trump issues a 50-day ultimatum to end hostilities.
fields.content:
Ukraine suffered 103 Russian strikes overnight across multiple regions, with simultaneous reports of an oil depot explosion in Russia's Krasnodar Krai territory housing the resort city of Sochi. The extent of damage at the Russian facility remains unverified, while Ukrainian emergency crews responded to extensive destruction in residential zones.

Emergency management officials described severe structural damage to a high-rise apartment building impacted by the attacks, stating: "The residents from the 5th to the 8th floors lost their homes. There is a risk of structural collapse." Rescue teams successfully evacuated 38 individuals, including five who required extraction from trapped positions within the compromised structure.

At least four civilians sustained injuries during the bombardment, according to verified reports. Multiple blazes erupted across urban centers, with fires documented in several cities including Cherkasy. The Ukrainian military noted the onslaught constituted one of Russia's most concentrated aerial assaults in recent weeks.

Odesa endured particularly devastating strikes, with the historically significant Pryvoz market engulfed in flames. Ukraine's Defense Ministry confirmed on social media: "Multiple civilian targets were damaged, including the residential high-rise, a two-story building, a gas station, and a UNESCO-protected architectural monument." Authorities emphasized the purely civilian nature of the affected locations.

Russian strikes on Odessa.

Defense officials condemned the tactical approach as militarily purposeless, asserting: "Once again, Russians target civilian cities – there is zero military gain. Ukraine needs more air defense systems to protect our people from such terror." President Volodymyr Zelenskyy echoed this assessment, describing the assaults as "utterly senseless strikes with no military purpose whatsoever" intended solely to perpetuate violence.

Zelenskyy reiterated Ukraine's urgent defense requirements during his statement: "That is precisely why we need support – strong air defenses, expanded weapons production. All of this will help save lives." His comments followed diplomatic outreach attempting to secure a cessation of hostilities during negotiations in Turkey.

Russian delegation for peace talks in Ukraine.

The Ukrainian leader detailed how proposed peace overtures coincided with intensified attacks: "Yesterday at the meeting in Istanbul, the proposal for an immediate ceasefire was reiterated to Russia. In response, Russian drones struck Odesa's market and residential buildings, Cherkasy apartments, Kharkiv energy infrastructure, and a Zaporizhzhia university gym." Zelenskyy confirmed the deployment of 103 attack drones, predominantly Iranian-produced "Shahed" models, accompanied by four missiles targeting Donetsk, Sumy, and Mykolaiv regions.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Schiff Dismisses Gabbard's Russia Claims as 'Dishonest', Sparks White House Feud
fields.summary: Senator Adam Schiff labeled Tulsi Gabbard's declassified Russia collusion intelligence as 'dishonest', prompting fierce White House retaliation. The exchange revives tensions surrounding investigations into alleged cooperation between Donald Trump's 2016 campaign and Russia, with both sides accusing each other of perpetuating false narratives.
fields.content:
Senator Adam Schiff rejected the validity of Tulsi Gabbard's declassified intelligence about Russia collusion, characterizing it as deceptive during a Capitol Hill interview. "I think what Gabbard and her staff are doing is dishonest and misstated," Schiff stated, escalating tensions around the long-disputed allegations.

White House Retaliation

White House Spokesman Davis Ingle immediately fired back: "Adam 'Shifty' Schiff was one of the chief propagandists behind the Russia collusion hoax. He's now trying to desperately cover his tracks as this entire lie is being exposed to the world." The counterattack referenced Schiff's congressional role during high-profile investigations into alleged coordination between Russia and Donald Trump's 2016 campaign.

Schiff served on the House Intelligence Committee during probes into suspected Russian election interference, rising as a leading Democratic voice accusing Trump's team of illicit cooperation. The new exchange revives deeply rooted political hostilities.

Sen. Adam Schiff

When questioned whether Barack Obama's administration should face accountability for supposedly promoting a disproven collusion theory, Schiff referenced intelligence reports: "They documented Russia's efforts to help denigrate Hillary Clinton, which gave a boost to the Trump campaign." Despite demands for an apology regarding the investigation's conclusions, Schiff maintained, "It's been proven accurate," and nodded affirmatively when asked if his collusion assertions were correct.

Donald Trump speaks at AmericaFest

Donald Trump reignited hostilities via Truth Social, declaring: "Adam 'Shifty' Schiff is in BIG TROUBLE! He falsified Loan Documents." The former president condemned what he termed Schiff's "manufactured" coup attempt against his family while controversially calling for the senator's imprisonment over financial allegations. Schiff previously dismissed similar fraud claims as "baseless political retribution," vowing they wouldn't deter his oversight efforts.

The feud reflects persistent polarization surrounding investigations into Russia's role in the 2016 election, with neither side showing willingness to concede ground as past conflicts resurface.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Cancer Drugs Reverse Alzheimer's Effects in Mice, Study Reveals
fields.summary: University of California researchers found that two FDA-approved cancer drugs, letrozole and irinotecan, reversed Alzheimer's-related brain changes in mice—reducing tau protein clumps and improving memory, with plans for human trials underway.
fields.content:
Scientists at the University of California San Francisco discovered that a combination of two cancer medications, letrozole and irinotecan, significantly reduced toxic tau protein accumulations and improved memory in mice exhibiting Alzheimer's symptoms. The study analyzed how Alzheimer's alters gene expression in brain cells, with the drug combination reversing these damaging patterns.

During testing on mice, the medications successfully countered the genetic shifts triggered by Alzheimer's disease. Co-senior author Marina Sirota explained, "Alzheimer’s disease comes with complex changes to the brain, making it difficult to study, but our computational tools let us address the complexity directly. We're thrilled our approach revealed a promising therapy using existing FDA-approved drugs."

Published on July 21 in the journal Cell, the research received partial funding from the National Institutes of Health and the National Science Foundation. The findings relied on animal models, and the university noted these models may not perfectly replicate human biological responses.

Woman taking pill

Researchers identified a gender-based difference in treatment outcomes, with male mice responding better than females, potentially due to letrozole's hormone-modulating properties. However, they cautioned the small sample size of male subjects limited definitive conclusions.

Over seven million Americans currently live with Alzheimer's, a figure projected to approach 13 million by 2050 according to the Alzheimer's Association. UCSF emphasized that only two FDA-approved disease-modifying treatments exist currently, with others merely addressing symptoms rather than underlying causes.

Amyloid beta

"Developing treatments is challenging because Alzheimer's involves multiple biological pathways rather than a single malfunction," researchers noted regarding the disease's complexity. The team plans to launch clinical trials to evaluate the drug combination in human Alzheimer's patients, expressing optimism: "We're hopeful this can be swiftly translated into a real solution for millions."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Black Death Skeletons Unearthed in Tower of London Excavation
fields.summary: Archaeologists excavating at the Tower of London have uncovered skeletons potentially linked to the Black Death alongside medieval grave goods and architectural remnants, marking the site's most significant dig in 30 years.
fields.content:
Britain's historic fortress has revealed new secrets during excavations ahead of the renovation of St. Peter ad Vincula chapel. As the ritual site for notable figures including queens and Catholic saints, the 15th-century chapel holds untold stories of the Tower's residents.

Skeletons in ground

Standout finds include a mass grave holding 14th-century skeletons suspected to be victims of the Black Death pandemic that devastated medieval Europe. Nearby, archaeologists located even older individual burials in coffins, indicating high-status occupants from earlier periods, bringing the total discovered remains to 20 individuals.

Further excavation revealed exceptionally rare medieval grave goods: two 12th to early 13th-century pots filled with charcoal. Such finds have been documented only once before in England, providing valuable material for scientific analysis according to Historic Royal Palaces.

Split image of medieval tile, building foundation

Tantalizing architectural evidence emerged about the chapel's predecessors. While the current structure dates to 1520, discoveries include remnants from earlier royal commissions. A large-scale burning event marker likely relates to the destruction of Edward I's 1287 chapel, with compacted stone layers potentially tracing back to Henry III's works in 1240. Wall sections and flooring hints may come from Henry I's enigmatic 12th-century chapel.

Split image of building foundation, skeleton

Curator Alfred Hawkins described the dig as a 'generational opportunity' to understand life and death at the fortress. Jane Sidell of Historic England emphasized this is 'just the tip of the iceberg' for insights into England's most evocative monument. Ongoing analysis of both human remains and structures promises to rewrite historical understanding of the Tower's inhabitants across centuries.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Amazon Issues Warning on Prime Impersonation Scams Targeting Customers
fields.summary: Amazon is alerting customers about sophisticated impersonation scams that use fake emails to steal account credentials and financial information, with advice on how to identify fraudulent messages and protect your account.
fields.content:
Understanding Prime impersonation scams

Amazon has notified hundreds of millions of customers about a widespread phishing tactic where scammers send deceptive emails mimicking legitimate communications. These messages often contain alarming notifications about Prime membership renewals at unexpectedly high rates. The fraudulent emails include 'cancel subscription' links that redirect users to counterfeit Amazon login pages designed to harvest account credentials once entered. After obtaining login information, scammers can make unauthorized purchases or exploit the credentials across other platforms where users have reused passwords.

Some fake websites go further by prompting victims for credit card details and personal information, which criminals immediately capture for financial fraud or resale. According to Amazon, these phishing attempts appear convincing because they frequently incorporate genuine personal details likely obtained from previous data breaches. This sophisticated use of previously leaked information makes the scams harder for users to identify as fraudulent.

Amazon app on a phone.

Amazon's countermeasures against phishing operations

The company has actively disrupted tens of thousands of phishing websites and scam phone numbers associated with these attacks. Amazon has implemented a secure email verification system to help customers authenticate legitimate communications from the company. When approached for comment, an Amazon spokesperson clarified that recent customer notifications were primarily educational, highlighting emerging impersonation tactics observed in increasing frequency.

Amazon emphasized it never requests sensitive information like passwords or payment details via email. All authentic account-related messages, including membership renewals, appear exclusively through Amazon's secure Message Centre interface or on the official Amazon website after users log in directly. This distinction will help customers distinguish between genuine communications and fraudulent attempts.

Amazon app on a phone.

Essential steps to protect your account

If you receive unexpected Amazon correspondence containing links or warnings, avoid clicking through. Instead, navigate directly to Amazon's website or official app to verify account status. Carefully inspect website addresses before entering credentials, as fraudulent sites often use slightly altered URLs that mimic the genuine domain. Employ a password manager to generate and store unique, complex passwords rather than reusing credentials across multiple platforms.

Comprehensive antivirus software provides critical protection by detecting phishing attempts, blocking malicious websites, and alerting users to emerging threats before damage occurs. Such programs are especially valuable in preventing malware installations from scam links that could compromise private data. Since scammers often build convincing emails using personal details like names and addresses sourced from data broker sites, using a personal data removal service can reduce your digital footprint and minimize targeting opportunities.

Suspicious messages should be reported through Amazon's self-service reporting tool for verified customers. Others can email reportascam@amazon.com directly. Submitting these reports enables Amazon to investigate and take action against malicious actors, disrupting scams proactively.

Key security insights

Impersonation scams extend beyond Amazon, requiring caution with all email communications. Always scrutinize messages carefully for red flags like unusual domain names, misspellings, or unnatural language patterns. Scammers rely on urgency and panic to provoke hasty responses, so taking a moment to verify communication legitimacy provides critical protection against increasingly sophisticated fraud attempts.

fields.title: The 5 Top-Rated Exercise Bikes for Home Workouts in 2025
fields.summary: Expert trainers recommend top exercise bikes for home gyms, comparing spin versus air bike models while highlighting key buying considerations and fitness benefits.
fields.content:
Home fitness evolves rapidly, yet exercise bikes maintain enduring appeal through their ability to enhance cardiovascular health with minimal joint impact. Recent smart bike innovations have expanded choices significantly, making selection challenging for varied fitness goals.

The Best Exercise Bikes

Spin bikes engage legs intensely, ideal for extended sessions and outdoor cycling supplements, while air bikes incorporate upper body work for high-intensity interval training. We've evaluated diverse models to recommend options across price ranges.

What to Consider

Match bike type to training priorities: air bikes excel in CrossFit-style mixed workouts, while spin bikes suit steady-state cardio. Magnetic resistance in spin models delivers smooth transitions, while air bikes use fan friction systems for intensity.

Prioritize adjustable resistance and essential metrics tracking. High-end spin bikes feature entertainment systems, while subscription-based programs add ongoing costs. Consider equipment dimensions and warranty length when investing over $1,500.

How We Selected

Our recommendations stem from extensive testing by fitness professionals, including Men's Health editors and Brooklyn-based trainer Maillard Howell. Emphasis was placed on real-world application in intense training environments.

Benefits of an Exercise Bike

Aerobic capacity improvements can occur within three months using these machines, particularly when combining cycling with heart-healthy eating according to 2019 research.

University of Nebraska exercise science professor Kate Heelan emphasizes the low-impact advantage: "Cycling minimizes injury risk from misalignment since it's non-load-bearing." Control over terrain intensity makes indoor sessions time-efficient

Indoor Bike Compared to Outdoor Cycling

While both burn calories, MH fitness director Ebenezer Samuel notes key distinctions: "Outdoor cycling challenges balance through spatial movement and constant micro-corrections absent in stationary bikes."

Indoor cycling offers beginner-friendly customization through adjustable resistance. Interactive classes provide motivation through virtual communities and leaderboard competition.

Losing Weight With an Exercise Bike

Intense cycling sessions trigger fat burning, supported by research showing enhanced body composition when combined with dietary changes. Consistent practice and progressive intensity adjustments yield optimal results.

How to Avoid Injury

Though low-impact, maintain proper form during rides to prevent strain. Ensure correct bike fit and posture throughout sessions.

How to Adjust an Exercise Bike

Proper adjustment prevents calf, hip, and knee issues. Ideal settings feature slight elbow bends and curved knees at the pedal's lowest point. Proper alignment maximizes both comfort and power.

More Home Gym Equipment

Enhance home workouts with adjustable dumbbells, weight benches, kettlebells, rowing machines, and recumbent bikes.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UN Reports Severe Child Malnutrition Crisis Engulfing Gaza
fields.summary: One in five children in Gaza suffers from malnutrition with cases escalating daily, according to UNRWA, while over 100 aid groups warn of impending mass starvation. Israel denies imposing a siege and blames Hamas for food shortages, as WHO calls the crisis 'man-made starvation' and Gazans describe desperate searches for sustenance.
fields.content:
A shocking malnutrition emergency grips Gaza with one in five children now malnourished and cases multiplying daily, the UN’s Palestinian refugee agency (UNRWA) reported. Philippe Lazzarini, UNRWA Commissioner-General, quoted a colleague's grim assessment: "People in Gaza are neither dead nor alive, they are walking corpses."

More than 100 international aid groups and human rights organizations issued warnings about mass starvation, urging global intervention. While Israel maintains control over all supplies entering Gaza and denies a siege, blaming Hamas for malnutrition, the UN described current aid levels as "a trickle" in territory facing its most dire hunger crisis.

Lazzarini stated over 100 people, predominantly children, have reportedly died from starvation already. He emphasized, "Most children our teams are seeing are emaciated and at high risk of dying without treatment," imploring Israel to permit unrestricted aid flows.

The World Health Organisation echoed these concerns, with chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus declaring: "I don't know what you'd call it other than mass starvation - and it's man-made."

Daily Struggle for Survival

Hanaa Almadhoun, 40, from northern Gaza described scarce market supplies with exorbitant prices forcing families to sell "gold and belongings" for basic staples like flour. "Every new day brings a challenge to find something edible," she noted, adding, "I've seen children rummaging through garbage for food scraps."

A Palestinian man carries a sack of flour.

During an Israeli troops visit, President Isaac Herzog insisted Israel provides aid "according to international law," while Gaza aid worker Tahani Shehada countered: "People survive hour-by-hour. Cooking or showering became luxuries." She revealed her eight-month-old infant has never tasted fresh fruit.

Tahani Shehada's baby sitting on an armchair holding a toy shovel.

Market seller Abu Alaa stated: "We go to bed hungry nightly. We are dead, pleading for world intervention." Meanwhile, pregnant Walaa Fathi described an "unimaginable catastrophe," hoping her unborn child avoids delivery in such conditions.

Deadly Aid Distribution Efforts

Israel halted aid deliveries in early March after a ceasefire, partially restoring them nearly two months later. The UN lists over 1,000 Palestinians killed seeking food aid in two months—766 near GHF distribution centers (established by Israel and US) and 288 near UN convoys.

Israel blames Hamas for instigating chaos at aid sites, claiming troops fire only warning shots, while GHF dismisses fatality figures as "false." Najah, 19, sheltering in a Gaza hospital, fears approaching distribution points: "I'd get shot. We're finished—no food or water in tents."

Najah, a 19-year-old widow, holding a baby.

UK charity doctor Aseel stated Gaza isn't approaching famine but experiencing it: "My husband got shot seeking aid twice. If we starve, let it be—aid paths are death paths." Reports also indicate local journalists increasingly struggle to feed themselves amid the crisis.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Struggling to Survive: Gaza Journalists Battle Hunger While Covering Conflict
fields.summary: Palestinian journalists in Gaza are enduring extreme hunger while continuing to report on the conflict, with multiple freelancers describing days without food, children begging for meals, and the collapse of their ability to provide basic sustenance for families despite ongoing professional duties.
fields.content:
Freelance Palestinian journalists vital to documenting conditions in Gaza reveal they frequently endure days without eating while struggling to feed their families. These reporters maintain their critical news coverage even after losing loved ones, homes, and during forced displacement from advancing military operations.

One journalist previously injured by Israeli bombing shrapnel states the current crisis represents "the hardest time I have lived through since I was born. It's a huge crisis of suffering and deprivation." While international experts haven't formally declared famine, UN agencies warn of accelerating man-made mass starvation across the territory.

Reuters A displaced Palestinian man carries his possessions following an Israeli military ground operation in Deir al-Balah, central Gaza (22 July 2025)

The reporters remain anonymous for security reasons as they describe heart-wrenching family struggles. One cameraman in Gaza City watches his autistic son hit his stomach to signal hunger, explaining: "He doesn't know we're in a war... he's so hungry." Another journalist supporting parents and siblings in southern Gaza is tormented by his teenage sister's constant requests for food that he cannot provide.

Reuters A girl runs after Israeli air strikes on a school sheltering displaced people in Bureij refugee camp, central Gaza (17 July 2025)

Major news organizations, including international agencies collaborating with these reporters, issued a joint warning about their deteriorating wellbeing. "Desperately concerned" media companies stated that local journalists now face identical threats to those they cover. Their perilous conditions severely impact reporting abilities — a veteran journalist who lost 30kg (66 pounds) says exhaustion causes dizziness and drastically slows his work: "Delirium and fatigue accompanies me."

Reuters Mourners attend the funeral of a Palestinian journalist killed in an Israeli air strike, at al-Shifa hospital, in Gaza City (25 June 2025)

Previously, journalists could sometimes purchase marked-up supplies using externally deposited salaries, but markets are now vacant. One Gaza City father told us his children eat one daily meal from charity kitchens: "I've reached the point of taking food from the charity kitchen." Reported survival tactics include drinking salt water to quell hunger and paying $9 for minimal sustenance. Accessing cash compounds pressures with money merchants charging 45% fees per transaction.

Reuters Palestinians seeking aid supplies from the US-backed Gaza Humanitarian Foundation travel in an animal-drawn cart, near Rafah, in southern Gaza (24 July 2025)

Israel's prohibition on foreign journalists entering the territory, with rare exceptions during military embeds, persists since the conflict's onset in October 2023. This restriction prompted news agencies to "urge the Israeli authorities to allow journalists in and out." Relief organizations warn supplies are gone – over 100 agencies report colleagues wasting away – as 28 nations jointly demand Israel comply with international law and stop "drip feeding" aid. Reporters balance familial duties with documenting catastrophe, described as a "suspended death sentence."

A Palestinian man carries a sack of flour

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK and India Seal Landmark Bilateral Trade Agreement
fields.summary: The UK and India have finalized a comprehensive trade agreement to reduce tariffs and expand market access across key industries. This analysis examines the deal's economic implications and timeline.
fields.content:
The UK and India have formally signed a bilateral trade agreement designed to streamline commerce between the nations. UK Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer and Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi endorsed the pact, with Starmer calling it a landmark achievement for both economies.

What has been agreed?

The agreement reduces taxes on numerous imports. Britain will lower tariffs on Indian products like textiles and agricultural goods. Meanwhile, India cuts duties on UK imports such as automobiles and alcoholic beverages. The deal additionally opens opportunities for British companies to bid on more service contracts within India.

What will be the impact on people in the UK and India?

The agreement will activate within a year. Over time, UK consumers could see expanded choices and lower prices for clothing, jewellery and frozen prawns. British luxury auto manufacturers will gain substantially from falling Indian car tariffs - from over 100% to 10%. Whiskey and gin exports to India benefit from immediate tariff cuts from 150% to 75%, reducing further to 40% within ten years. Indian apparel makers and jewelers gain improved UK market entry with reduced levies.

Getty Images India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi and UK Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer shake hands

If businesses increase profits through exports, it may fuel hiring and domestic investments in both nations.

How important is this for the UK and India?

After three years of negotiations, this becomes Britain's third-largest trade deal after agreements with Australia and Japan. Bilateral trade reached £42 billion last year, with projections suggesting the pact could boost trade by £25.5 billion annually by 2040. It is expected to contribute £4.8 billion to the UK economy. For India - which aims to become the world's third-largest economy - this supports its $1 trillion export growth target by 2030. Meanwhile, India and the EU pursue their own agreement scheduled for conclusion by late 2025.

What does this mean for visas?

Despite India's requests for relaxed immigration rules, no visa concessions were included for students or professionals. However, workers on short-term assignments gain a three-year exemption from UK social security contributions through the Double Contribution Convention, ensuring they only pay social security in India. Business Secretary Jonathan Reynolds emphasized this won't create hiring advantages: Additional visa and NHS fees would actually make Indian workers costlier than UK employees. Similar conventions exist between the UK and 17 other nations.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Boosts Offshore Wind Energy Prices to Meet 2030 Clean Power Target
fields.summary: The UK government has raised maximum prices for offshore wind energy contracts to incentivize renewable projects and achieve its 2030 fossil-fuel-free electricity grid goal. While critics call the increase 'eye-watering', officials expect competitive bidding to lower actual consumer costs.
fields.content:
The UK government will pay higher maximum prices for electricity generated by new wind farms as part of its strategy to reduce household bills and achieve a nearly fossil-fuel-free grid by 2030. The Department for Energy Security and Net Zero unveiled these adjustments prior to its upcoming auction for subsidized renewable energy contracts.

Set to begin in August, this auction represents one of the final opportunities to commission projects that can become operational in time for the 2030 clean power deadline. Conservative officials criticized the move, calling the new guaranteed rates for offshore wind "eye-watering" and excessively high.

The maximum price for offshore wind has risen to £113 per megawatt-hour from £102, with floating offshore wind (a newer technology) set at £271, a £26 increase. Onshore wind prices saw a smaller hike to £92, while solar energy rates decreased to £75 from £85 per megawatt-hour.

Conservative Shadow Energy Secretary Claire Coutinho stated: "These are eye-watering prices - the highest in a decade and way above the average cost of electricity last year. This doesn't even include grid, storage, or wasted wind costs that add to bills." She accused Energy Secretary Ed Miliband of prioritizing "net zero zealotry above the economy or cost of living."

A government spokesperson countered that competitive auctions typically yield lower prices than the set maximums, with Miliband's office noting: "The auction will reveal the true price, just like last year when it cleared significantly lower." Officials contend that shifting to renewables will ultimately reduce bills by minimizing exposure to volatile fossil fuel markets.

Energy transitions advisor Johnny Gowdy explained the auction mechanics, noting that higher bid prices could limit the number of projects secured: "There's a trade-off between volume and price. Competitive bids usually bring down actual costs below administrative caps, despite recent industry cost increases."

The changes follow a 2023 auction failure where zero offshore wind developers participated, claiming prices were unviable. To prevent a repeat, the government now allows projects without full planning permission to bid, extends contract durations from 15 to 20 years, and grants the Energy Secretary visibility into bids before setting budgets.

A government representative defended the strategy, asserting that reforms will "enable a competitive auction securing both cleaner energy and optimal prices to end our fossil fuel dependence."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: University Mental Health Support: Students Feel Let Down Amid Rising Challenges
fields.summary: Students struggling with mental health issues report inadequate support from universities, with cases nearly quadrupling in a decade. Experts debate whether institutions should handle complex mental healthcare or focus on academic roles, as services face funding pressures, high demand, and concerns about students slipping through gaps despite increased spending.
fields.content:
When a student named Imogen arrived at the University of Nottingham in 2022 with a formal letter explaining her history of anxiety and self-harm, she expected ongoing support from wellbeing services. Three years later, after being diagnosed with ADHD and autism, she feels abandoned by fragmented university counseling. Her account echoes others, including Leacsaidh at Nottingham, who received only website referrals when seeking help for OCD-related self-harm.

Illustration showing a student knocking at doors while a therapist sits inside

Similar issues emerge at King's College London, where Jana, an international student, faced clerical errors delaying anxiety-related adjustments. While universities like Nottingham emphasize their services supplement rather than replace NHS clinical care, advocates question their capacity to address surging demand.

'Prime conditions' for problems

Student mental health crises gained attention after 11 suicides at the University of Bristol between 2016-2018. Data reveals UK students reporting mental health conditions soared from 33,500 in 2014-15 to 122,430 in 2023-24. Psychology expert Dr Sandi Mann identifies late adolescence (ages 18-21) as peak vulnerability for conditions like OCD and depression.

Bar graph showing rise in student mental health issues over ten years

University pressures—academic demands, independent living, and part-time work—create 'prime conditions' for problems. While societal openness reduced stigma, Dr Sarah Sweeney of Amosshe argues for clearer distinctions between mental health challenges and clinical illness. The pandemic also hindered social development for current undergraduates.

'We're not trained for this'

Personal tutors—academics who are students' first contact—often feel ill-equipped. A Manchester University lecturer anonymously noted they receive minimal training despite encountering crises. 'It's a problem we're not trained for,' they stated. Universities nationwide have increased mental health spending by 73% in five years, yet staffing gaps remain amid financial deficits.

Students socializing outdoors at a UK university

Services involve tiers: wellbeing teams teach stress management, then escalate complex cases to specialists. Dr Mann warns fragmented systems risk students 'slipping through gaps', while Dr Sweeney acknowledges that without proper resources, 'streamlined' services may falter.

What role should universities play?

Opinions diverge on responsibilities. While one Manchester academic insists 'students are adults', Dr Sweeney clarifies universities aren't treatment centers but stresses collaboration with NHS services like Manchester's mental health initiative could help. Student Natasha Abrahart's father Bob, however, demands stronger institutional accountability.

Person sitting in airplane cockpit

The duty of care debate

After 20-year-old Natasha Abrahart died by suicide before an oral presentation in 2018, courts ruled Bristol University breached equality laws by failing to accommodate her social anxiety. Though data suggests lower suicide rates among students than the general population, experts recommend mandatory staff mental health training.

Parents holding photo of their daughter Natasha

Abrahart's parents campaign for statutory university 'duty of care', which the Department for Education opposes, stating existing legal obligations suffice. Universities UK argues a statutory duty imposes 'unrealistic expectations'. Amid these tensions, universities balance support with boundaries. Dr Mann suggests teaching resilience: 'We need to teach them to rescue themselves.' As Imogen reflects on her experience at Nottingham, she concludes, 'I wish I could say everything was great... but I can't.'

Source: Original Article

fields.title: University Cuts NHS Mental Health Courses Amid Financial Pressures
fields.summary: The University of East Anglia has announced discontinuation of three NHS mental health training programs, citing financial unviability and reduced NHS commissions, while unions warn this undermines critical regional healthcare needs during a mental health crisis.
fields.content:
A union has accused the University of East Anglia (UEA) of abandoning essential training amid regional shortages after the institution confirmed cuts to its High Intensity Therapy programme, Psychological Wellbeing Practitioner programme, and Clinical Associate in Psychology Masters Apprenticeship (CAPs). The decision includes eliminating 10.9 full-time equivalent roles.

A university spokesperson explained that running the courses is no longer financially sustainable, as enrollment is limited to NHS personnel and unavailable to self-funded students. External factors such as NHS England restructuring, declining commissions for therapy programs, and reduced apprenticeship opportunities contributed to the decision.

The CAPs apprenticeship will end entirely in January 2026. Current students will receive support to finish their degrees, though the nearest alternative provider is in Essex, creating accessibility challenges. Staff consultations have begun, with compulsory redundancies described as a last resort.

Criticism Over Training Reduction

The University College Union (UCU) contends that eliminating these programs directly conflicts with NHS expansion goals for psychological services. A spokesperson highlighted that the East of England requires 150 new psychological wellbeing practitioners and 150 cognitive behavioral therapists in the coming year alone.

"By closing these programmes during a regional and national mental health crisis, UEA is turning its back on the area and shirking its duty to train urgently needed mental health workers," the union stated, attributing the decision to poor university financial management. This follows last year's announcement of 170 job cuts to save £11m.

An NHS representative responded: "While supporting record numbers with mental health issues, we remain committed to workforce development through various channels and are collaborating with partners to maintain access to specialized training."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Robots vs Humans: The Future of Space Exploration
fields.summary: NASA's record-breaking Parker Solar Probe mission showcases advances in autonomous space exploration, reigniting debate on whether robots could replace human astronauts as AI and robotics evolve to perform increasingly complex extraterrestrial tasks.
fields.content:
On Christmas Eve, NASA's Parker Solar Probe made history by autonomously navigating closer to the Sun than any previous spacecraft. During its mission to study solar activity and space weather effects, the probe endured temperatures reaching 1000°C without real-time communication with Earth, executing pre-programmed tasks during its atmospheric passage.

NASA A treated image showing artist’s concept of the Parker Solar Probe spacecraft approaching the orange/red sun.

This milestone highlights how unmanned spacecraft continue exploring destinations inaccessible to people. Over 60 years, robotic probes have surveyed every planet in our solar system, while human astronauts have only reached Earth's orbit and the Moon.

BBC A robot faces an astronaut

These advancements prompt critical questions about human roles in future space endeavors. Lord Martin Rees, the UK's Astronomer Royal, argues against publicly funded human missions: "Robots are developing fast, and the case for sending humans is getting weaker all the time," emphasizing significant risks. Andrew Coates from University College London added: "For serious space exploration, I much prefer robotics - they go much further and do more things" while being cost-efficient.

Rovers versus mankind

NASA An astronaut on the surface of the Moon

Robotic craft perform well in hostile environments but lack human versatility. Since Yuri Gagarin's first spaceflight in 1961, about 700 people have experienced space, primarily in orbit. Dr. Kelly Weinersmith notes prestige remains a key motivation: "It shows your political system is effective." Though humans conduct vital research, Dr. Weinersmith observes: "Humans get stuff done faster but are expensive to keep alive," while author Samantha Harvey poetically describes robots requiring "nothing."

NASA An image of the Earth from space

Current Mars rovers crawl at 0.1 mph, highlighting limitations. "AI can win chess, but can it outperform humans in exploration? We just don't know," says planetary scientist Ian Crawford, acknowledging potential efficiency improvements.

AI assistants and humanoid robots

NASA Nasa's Valkyrie humanoid robot

Future missions might feature AI handling tedious tasks, as Dr. Kiri Wagstaff notes machines don't tire. However, existing rover processors operate at one-tenth smartphone capacity, insufficient for large language models. Humanoid designs like NASA's Valkyrie and Robonaut demonstrate growing capabilities - Robonaut successfully performed ISS maintenance in 2011 using specialized hands to manipulate tools.

Reuters NASA's humanoid robot Valkyrie opening a bag

NASA's Shaun Azimi envisions robots securing habitats when humans are absent. While rovers like Curiosity autonomously analyze Martian rocks, Dr. Wagstaff acknowledges their slow progress. Leroy Chiao, a retired astronaut, emphasizes humans' unparalleled inspirational impact: "The first Mars landing would eclipse the Moon mission."

NASA Nasa’s Perseverance Mars rover is seen in a selfie that it took

Life on Mars?

Human deep-space exploration paused after 1972's Moon missions, though NASA's Artemis program plans lunar flybys in 2026 and landings by 2027. China aims for crewed Moon missions, while Elon Musk's SpaceX wants to establish Mars colonies, transporting 100 people per Starship flight to achieve one million residents within 20 years.

Reuters Four Astronauts in blue NASA uniforms, smiling at a press conference

Dr. Weinersmith questions Mars settlement feasibility: "Maybe babies can't develop there - we need to slow down." Lord Rees speculates about genetic modifications enabling humans to thrive off-world, potentially creating "a new species happy on Mars." Until then, human space exploration continues following paths pioneered by robots.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Implements Strict Age Verification for Pornography Websites
fields.summary: New UK regulations require pornography websites to implement robust age verification systems instead of simple tick-box confirmations. The measures aim to prevent underage access but raise privacy concerns about users sharing identification data and potential workarounds like VPNs.
fields.content:
Tick-box age confirmations for accessing pornography are now obsolete under UK law. Starting this Friday, all adult-content platforms operating in Britain must implement stringent age verification checks for users.

Adults viewing explicit material will experience significant changes to their online habits. Websites failing to comply face penalties up to £18 million or 10% of their global revenue.

British regulator Ofcom, noting that approximately 14 million UK residents access online pornography, states these measures will substantially reduce children's exposure to harmful content. However, questions arise about the system's effectiveness and possible circumvention techniques.

Verification methods and requirements

Ofcom has approved multiple verification techniques, including credit card validation, photo ID matching, and AI-powered age estimation via selfies. Thousands of websites have reportedly committed to implementing these systems.

All verification methods must demonstrate technical accuracy, reliability, and fairness. Platforms must also implement measures preventing access through workaround methods.

VPN dilemma for users and platforms

Many users express reluctance to share sensitive personal data. One typical response highlights the dilemma: provide information to verification companies or simply use VPN technology.

Virtual private networks (VPNs) legally reroute internet connections, enabling users to bypass location-based restrictions. Under the Online Safety Act, platforms must prohibit content encouraging VPN use to evade age checks.

Ofcom warns parents that children utilizing VPNs won't benefit from the new protections, urging families to block such tools. Katie Freeman-Tayler of Internet Matters anticipates increased VPN adoption as rules take effect. Aylo, parent company of Pornhub, officially states: "We certainly do not recommend that anyone uses technology to bypass the law."

Infographic explaining how a VPN functions

Effectiveness and privacy concerns

Woman taking selfie to demonstrate facial age estimation method

Cybersecurity expert Chelsea Jarvie acknowledges that approved verification methods effectively prove age while incorporating circumvention safeguards. However, she warns that determined users will seek anonymous alternatives.

Persistent concerns remain about sharing personal information, particularly following high-profile cyberattacks. Andy Lulham of Verifymy cautions: "It is possible that an adult could complete an age check on behalf of a child... comparable to buying a pornographic magazine for them."

Participating platforms

Every UK-based pornographic platform must deploy "highly effective" age checks effective July 25th. Major sites including Pornhub have confirmed implementation. Reddit has already introduced age gates restricting under-18 access to mature content.

Pornhub mobile application logo display on smartphone

Social platforms X (using AI facial estimation) and Grindr have committed to compliance. Discord offers UK users face scanning or ID verification, while Bluesky provides multiple verification options.

User reactions

Tom, a regular porn viewer in his 20s, worries about data leaks: "It's not if something will leak, but when." He highlights particular risks for users whose undisclosed sexual orientation could be revealed through viewing habits. Verification firms reassure they don't retain user data.

Daily user Shea, also in his 20s, dismisses uploading scans of identification: "No thank you." He believes verification hurdles will simply redirect users rather than stop consumption: "It's pushing people into fringe extremes while failing to prevent porn access."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Wrestling Legend Hulk Hogan Passes Away at Age 71
fields.summary: Wrestling icon Hulk Hogan, one of America's most recognizable sports entertainers, has died at age 71. World Wrestling Entertainment confirmed his passing at his Florida home on Thursday, though the cause remains unknown following his recent heart surgery.
fields.content:
Hulk Hogan, one of America's most iconic wrestling superstars, has died at 71 according to an official confirmation from World Wrestling Entertainment (WWE). The legendary performer, born Terry Gene Bollea, passed away on Thursday at his residence in Florida.

Beginning his professional wrestling career in 1977, Hogan rocketed to global fame after joining the World Wrestling Federation (WWF, now WWE) in 1983. He became synonymous with wrestling's cultural explosion during the 1980s and 1990s era.

Beyond wrestling, Hogan gained household recognition through his reality television series "Hogan Knows Best," which documented his family life on VH1 from 2005 to 2007. More recently, he was known as a vocal supporter of former US President Donald Trump.

His cause of death hasn't been publicly confirmed. Hogan underwent heart surgery in June 2024.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Israel Recalls Gaza Ceasefire Negotiators Amid Hamas 'Hardened' Stance
fields.summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has recalled negotiation teams from Qatar after Hamas presented new demands deemed unacceptable, stalling ceasefire talks. The development comes amid warnings of a worsening humanitarian crisis in Gaza and international diplomatic pressure.
fields.content:
Israel has called back its negotiation team from Qatar following Hamas' latest proposal, which officials describe as a hardened stance undermining ceasefire efforts. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's office stated: "In light of the response Hamas delivered this morning, it has been decided to recall the negotiating team for further consultations in Israel." The statement acknowledged mediation efforts by Qatar, Egypt, and U.S. envoy Steve Witkoff.

Witkoff announced his team's return from Doha on social media, stating: "Hamas' response clearly shows a lack of desire to reach a ceasefire in Gaza." He further accused Hamas of failing to act "in good faith," adding: "We will now consider alternative options to bring the hostages home and try to create a more stable environment for the people of Gaza. It's a shame Hamas has acted in this selfish way."

A senior Israeli official confirmed the negotiation pause isn't a complete breakdown but noted "significant gaps across all core issues." Another official relayed that Hamas' updated prisoner exchange terms were deemed "unacceptable," complicating diplomatic efforts. A joint condemnation of Israel's Gaza operations by 25 countries has also impacted talks, prompting Israel's Foreign Ministry to criticize the move as "disconnected from reality" and counterproductive during sensitive negotiations.

Hamas terrorists

Hamas insists on Israeli forces withdrawing to positions held before March 2—when the previous ceasefire collapsed—and demands reopening Rafah crossing from Gaza to Egypt. The group also opposes the U.S.-backed Gaza Humanitarian Fund, advocating for a return to the previous UN-supervised aid distribution system.

hostage appeal

A Hamas official told Reuters they seek binding guarantees preventing Israel from restarting military operations after a proposed 60-day truce, even without a full agreement. This demand comes amidst severe humanitarian conditions in Gaza, where the UN reports hundreds of thousands face food insecurity. Reports indicate northern Gazans resort to eating animal feed while aid distributions in the south become disorderly and deadly.

LTG Eyal Zamir

Israeli authorities said over 800 aid trucks remain uncollected at Gaza crossings despite COGAT reporting more than 150 were secured for distribution. As discussions stall and military activities continue, officials warn the opportunity for a deal is diminishing. An Israeli source stressed: "There are still significant gaps. The negotiations are not over—but time is running out."

Steve Witkoff and Benjamin Netanyahu

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Do You Really Need Three Meals Daily? Experts Challenge Tradition
fields.summary: Nutrition experts debate the necessity of eating three daily meals, suggesting cultural habits rather than biological needs dictate this pattern and recommending personalized approaches to meal timing.
fields.content:
For centuries, breakfast, lunch and dinner formed the cornerstone of dietary routines—but modern nutrition science questions whether three daily meals are truly essential for health. Serena Poon, a Los Angeles-based certified nutritionist and longevity advisor, contends this structure is primarily a cultural convention rather than biological necessity.

"There's no universal magic in 'three meals a day,'" Poon noted. "What proves vital is food quality, meal timing consistency, and alignment with an individual's biology and lifestyle." She emphasized that metabolic health hinges more on food choices than fixed eating schedules.

senior couple enjoying pasta salad for lunch

Research supports flexible approaches: A recent Nature Medicine study demonstrated overweight adults restricting eating to eight-hour windows reduced visceral fat and cardiometabolic risks as effectively as conventional meal patterns.

USF College of Public Health nutrition professor Lauri Wright concurs the three-meal model stems from industrial-era work schedules and social customs more than science. "People vary significantly,” Wright explained. “Some thrive on three balanced meals while others prefer frequent smaller meals—what matters is fulfilling daily nutritional needs consistently."

hungry woman looking at her watch in a kitchen

Poon advocates customized eating frequencies, observing most healthy adults benefit from 8–12 hour daily feeding periods starting soon after waking and concluding hours before sleep. Early risers might prioritize larger breakfasts and lunches while shift workers need adjusted schedules.

She recommends tuning into body cues—stomach growling, concentration dips, or mild irritability—as guides to genuine hunger. Ending meals at "comfortable satiety" prevents overconsumption. Such mindfulness maintains consistent energy and avoids impulsive, less-nutritious choices according to Poon.

Couple eating breakfast

Experts urge prioritizing whole foods, nutrient density, and macronutrient balance regardless of eating rhythm. Poon concluded: "Consistency remains paramount—find a pattern that supports your circadian rhythm, accommodates social interactions, and advances your health objectives."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Algeria Beach Town Reverses Ban on Men's Shorts After Modesty Debate
fields.summary: A coastal town in Algeria ignited controversy by prohibiting men from wearing short swim trunks, citing violation of moral values, then reversed the ban days later amid tensions between Islamic traditions and tourism.
fields.content:
Controversy highlights tension between Islamic modesty and tourism in Algeria

Chetaïbi mayor Layachi Allaoua issued a decree banning men from wearing Bermuda-style shorts in public areas of the Algerian coastal town. He stated the attire clashed with community standards and upset locals during summer months.

"These summer outfits disturb the population. They go against our society’s moral values and sense of decency," Allaoua explained to The Associated Press. He emphasized that residents objected to seeing foreigners in "indecent clothing" around town.

New Masculinity: Group of male friends, interacting playfully on the beach. Friendship and body positivity concepts.

Officials from the nearby city of Annaba pressured the mayor to rescind the ban. Within two days, Allaoua reversed his decision claiming he sought to maintain "peace and tranquility" for residents and tourists, while denying influence from Islamist groups.

beach algeria

Islamic modesty standards remain prevalent in Algeria, where the CIA World Factbook shows 99% identify as Sunni Muslims. The Algerian Civil War (1991–2002) contributed to increasingly visible religious practices in daily life.
