Traditional Islamic principles, as explained in cultural studies, define "awara" as body areas requiring cover for dignity preservation—mandating coverage from navel to knees for men, and full-body covering except hands and face for women.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Charley Hull Reveals Scary Collapse During Golf Tournament
fields.summary: British golfer Charley Hull shares details of her frightening collapse during a major tournament, describing symptoms leading to the incident and her ongoing recovery process after being forced to withdraw.
fields.content:
Professional golfer Charley Hull has opened up about her frightening collapse during the opening round of a major tournament. The 29-year-old British athlete was carted off near the fourth tee on Thursday after losing consciousness, ultimately withdrawing from the competition. Hull revealed she began feeling ill several days prior to the incident.

"I played the pro-am and I soldiered through because I didn’t want to let my team down, but I felt really rough," Hull explained about her deteriorating condition earlier in the week. "All my bones were aching." Despite feeling increasingly unwell, she attempted to compete in the tournament.

Charley Hull tee shot

On tournament day, Hull woke with severe symptoms. "I felt really dizzy, had cold sweats, and no energy," she recalled. Remarkably, she persevered through approximately 12 holes while playing "really solid golf" before collapsing. The medical incident occurred on her 12th hole after teeing off on the back nine.

Hull described losing consciousness during her shot sequence: "In the bunker hitting a fairway shot, I had to sit down because my eyesight went and my hearing went muffled." After managing to nearly sink a birdie from the bunker, she walked to the next tee and called medics. "Before hitting my tee shot, my knees gave way. My caddie said my eyes rolled back and I was out over a minute, caught just before hitting concrete."

Charley Hull playing a pitch shot

The golfer shared disorienting details of regaining consciousness: "I came out of what felt like a deep sleep, feeling good until I saw birds above me and people staring." Her recovery has involved mandated rest periods, which Hull admits are challenging for her active lifestyle. "I hate sitting still—drives me bonkers not going to the gym," she said, though she continues limited golf practice while recuperating.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: New Wearable Sensor Monitors Hydration Levels in Real-Time
fields.summary: Researchers at the University of Texas have developed a breakthrough wearable hydration sensor using bioimpedance technology to continuously monitor fluid levels. This non-invasive device detects dehydration before symptoms appear, benefiting athletes, workers in high-heat environments, and patients requiring precise hydration management.
fields.content:
New wearable hydration tech could change how we stay safe, healthy, and hydrated

Hydration is crucial for health, yet most people don't effectively track their water intake. Warning signs like dizziness or fatigue often emerge before individuals recognize they're dehydrated. At the point of feeling thirsty, the body is already experiencing fluid deficit. The innovative wearable hydration sensor solves this problem by delivering real-time data, empowering users to proactively maintain hydration rather than react to symptoms after they occur.

How the wearable hydration sensor works

Engineered at the University of Texas at Austin, this sensor detects early dehydration using bioimpedance technology. It transmits a painless, low-level electrical current through the bicep and measures how efficiently it travels through tissue. Well-hydrated tissues conduct electricity easily, while dehydrated ones create resistance. The device wirelessly connects to a smartphone app, providing immediate hydration updates without disrupting daily activities or requiring clinical tests.

Wearable hydration sensor benefits for workouts, jobs, and health

This technology offers practical advantages across multiple scenarios. Athletes can use it to prevent fatigue and cramping during intense training in hot conditions. Firefighters and police officers wearing heavy gear in high temperatures gain critical safety monitoring. Even office workers missing water breaks during long meetings receive timely reminders. For patients managing kidney or cardiovascular conditions requiring precise hydration balance, the device offers a non-invasive alternative to current clinical methods.

The science behind the hydration sensor

Researchers validated the sensor's accuracy through controlled experiments where participants took diuretics to simulate dehydration. Continuous readings from the sensor matched urine analysis results that measured biochemical hydration markers. This demonstrated the technology's reliability during normal activities like walking or working. Co-author Matija Jankovic confirmed that arm bioimpedance measurements accurately reflected whole-body hydration changes, establishing it as a dependable monitoring method.

Rigid PCB and commercial gel electrode system.

Traditional hydration tests fall short

Conventional hydration checks like urine analysis or blood tests are impractical for daily use due to their time-consuming nature and need for laboratory processing. Existing commercial monitors are often bulky and restrict movement. This sensor overcomes these limitations with its portable, lightweight design that operates continuously during exercise, work, or routine life without requiring users to remain stationary.

What's next for hydration tracking

The current model measures relative hydration shifts, but researchers plan to collect population-wide data to establish baseline measurements for absolute hydration levels. They're also developing enhanced designs including breathable electronic tattoos and sweat-resistant sensors for extended comfort. Future versions might monitor other body areas like forearms or thighs. Lead researcher Nanshu Lu envisions making seamless, real-time hydration tracking universally accessible across all lifestyles and professions.

A woman sweating during a workout.

What this means for you

This technology simplifies hydration management by replacing guesswork with precise data. Whether pushing through demanding physical activity, enduring high-stress work conditions, or navigating busy routines, the sensor provides instant hydration status updates to optimize performance and health.

Kurt's key takeaways

Dehydration often develops unnoticed yet can rapidly become serious. This wearable sensor empowers individuals through accurate, non-invasive hydration monitoring suitable for daily use. From elite athletes to professionals needing sustained focus, real-time hydration awareness represents a fundamental health advancement with broad applications.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Exploring Non-Medication Strategies for ADHD Management
fields.summary: Amid medication misinformation and shortages, ADHD patients are increasingly turning to alternative treatments. This article examines validated non-pharmaceutical approaches that can complement or reduce reliance on stimulants, offering practical solutions for symptom management.
fields.content:
Navigating ADHD treatment has become increasingly complex. Research reveals that about half of popular ADHD content on social media contains misinformation, ranging from medication fears to unproven remedies. Simultaneously, prescription shortages and governmental scrutiny of ADHD drugs create additional challenges. Psychiatrist Dr. Javier Quintero explains that drug-free interventions are gaining recognition for enhancing organizational skills, emotional control, and stress management: "They can reduce medication dosage while improving daily functioning and quality of life." Below are science-backed strategies for those seeking alternatives or complementary approaches.

Double-Check Your Diagnosis

Accurate identification of ADHD is essential before pursuing treatment. Dr. Gregory Scott Brown highlights that many adults assume they have ADHD without proper diagnosis. True ADHD symptoms emerge before age 12, though they may remain undiagnosed for years. He cautions that concentration problems often stem from burnout, depression, or anxiety instead of ADHD. Professional evaluation helps differentiate these conditions.

Ask About New Meds

If standard stimulants cause side effects or prove ineffective, consider newer alternatives. Beyond traditional options, the FDA recently approved viloxazine (Qelbree), a non-stimulant medication targeting brain chemicals associated with ADHD. Additional treatments are under investigation, including centanafadine. Dr. Quintero notes that this triple reuptake inhibitor shows comparable efficacy to stimulants in clinical trials while affecting serotonin, norepinephrine, and dopamine pathways.

Commit to Therapy

Therapy begins by identifying ADHD's specific impact on daily life to establish targeted goals. Cognitive behavioral therapy (CBT) demonstrates strong effectiveness by modifying unhelpful thought patterns and improving organization and emotional regulation. For instance, replacing thoughts like "I can't do anything right" with situation-specific analysis reduces shame and boosts productivity. Alternatively, ADHD coaches provide practical organization strategies. Though unlicensed, reputable coaches hold certifications from bodies like the Professional Association for ADHD Coaches requiring training and testing.

Double Down on Wellness

Mindfulness practices enhance concentration and emotional control despite being challenging for ADHD patients. Structured options like meditation apps or workshops aid implementation. Technology-based interventions such as EndeavorOTC show promise—an FDA-authorized app using game-like tasks improved focus for 83% of users in clinical trials. Physical activity also offers significant benefits; cycling particularly strengthens inhibitory control. Just 20 minutes of daily aerobic exercise can augment attention, memory, and mood regulation.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ancient 5,000-Year-Old Cairn in Yorkshire Dales Gains Protected Status
fields.summary: England has granted legal protection to Dudderhouse Hill long cairn, a 5,000-year-old Neolithic structure in the Yorkshire Dales National Park that predates Stonehenge, safeguarding the nationally important archaeological site from damage and raising public awareness about its cultural significance.
fields.content:
Dudderhouse Hill long cairn, a prehistoric stone structure dating back approximately 5,000 years, has been designated as a protected monument by English heritage authorities. Located in the Yorkshire Dales National Park, this ancient marker pre-exists Stonehenge and ranks among the oldest human-built structures in the country.

Cairns traditionally consist of human-made stone piles functioning as burial sites or territorial markers. The Dudderhouse Hill example represents a rare Neolithic construction built by early farming communities between 3400 and 2400 BCE.

Though originally featuring structured chambers, the cairn now appears as an oval mound partially covered with turf. Measuring 75 feet long, 39 feet wide, and three feet tall, it provides archaeologists with valuable insights into ancient funeral rites, spiritual beliefs, and community practices from England's earliest agricultural societies.

Paul Jeffery, Historic England’s national listings manager, explained the preservation challenges: "It doesn’t look particularly impressive and that’s one of the problems. Unfortunately, because they don’t realize that this is such an important site, some people walking past pick up stones from what they think is just this pile and then add them to the other cairn and obviously that causes harm."

Officially recorded only in 2008, the site gained Scheduled Monument status which provides legal safeguard against unauthorized alterations. This designation followed an incident in 2023 when stones were removed to enhance a nearby walking trail cairn.

Myra Tolan-Smith, Historic England's listing adviser, highlighted the importance: "We hope its new status as a prehistoric funerary monument of national importance will raise awareness among the wider public of both the importance and the vulnerability of this significant part of our shared cultural heritage." Tolan-Smith added this protection enables planning for comprehensive repairs to address recent damage.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: NHS Braces for Critical Days as Junior Doctors' Strike Intensifies
fields.summary: The NHS confronts significant challenges during a five-day strike by junior doctors in England, with Health Secretary Wes Streeting warning of service disruptions while pledging minimal impact. The government and British Medical Association remain deadlocked over pay disputes, as hospitals attempt to maintain non-urgent services despite warnings about stretched staff resources.
fields.content:
Health Secretary Wes Streeting has issued warnings about the National Health Service facing extreme pressure during an ongoing five-day strike by junior doctors across England. Senior doctors are covering emergency and routine services during the walkout that began on Friday, with efforts focused on minimizing care disruptions.

The British Medical Association permitted a doctor to leave picket lines over the weekend to assist at Nottingham City Hospital's neonatal intensive care unit. This marks only the sixth temporary exemption granted during the prolonged dispute centered on pay disputes. Prime Minister Keir Starmer previously urged doctors to reconsider strike action, stating it risks reversing NHS progress.

Previous junior doctor walkouts led to over one million canceled appointments and surgeries earlier this year. Though current cancellation numbers remain unconfirmed, some hospitals report maintaining over 80% of non-urgent services during this industrial action.

Graph showing resident doctors' salaries

The strike follows collapsed negotiations between the government and BMA. While discussions touched on non-pay issues like exam fees and career progression, Health Secretary Streeting maintained that pay discussions were off the table. Junior doctors reject the current 5.4% average pay raise this year, asserting their salaries remain 20% lower than 2008 levels when adjusted for inflation.

First-year junior doctors currently earn £38,831 annually for approximately 48 hours weekly, rising to £44,439 in the second year. Doctors supplement this with additional income for nightshifts and weekends, typically raising earnings by over 25%. "Restoring pay remains the simplest and most effective route toward improving our working lives," stated BMA junior doctor leaders Dr. Melissa Ryan and Dr. Ross Nieuwoudt.

NHS junior doctors protest outside Royal Victoria Infirmary in Newcastle with placards and orange BMA hats

With junior doctors comprising nearly half of England's medical workforce, the strike impacts hospitals, GP clinics, and community services. Patients have experienced disruptions, exemplified by Hassnain Shahid from Bradford, whose three-year-old daughter's lung surgery was canceled despite her high-risk condition.

The BMA cautioned NHS England that staff attempting to maintain non-urgent services could become dangerously overstretched. However, NHS Providers deputy chief executive Saffron Cordery emphasized hospitals operate within rigorous safety protocols, noting the challenge of unpredictable attendance among non-striking doctors.

Political reactions intensified as Liberal Democrats urged an emergency plan utilizing private hospitals for elective treatments, while Conservative shadow health secretary Stuart Andrew accused the government of "spineless surrender" to union demands. Strikes remain exclusive to England, with Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland unaffected.

NHS England advises the public to attend appointments unless canceled and confirms GP practices and emergency services remain available throughout the strike period. Negotiation timelines remain uncertain following this fifth walkout in the ongoing dispute.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Thailand Warns Border Clashes with Cambodia Could Escalate to War
fields.summary: Thailand's acting prime minister warned that deadly border clashes with Cambodia could escalate into war, with fighting involving heavy weapons at 12 locations. The conflict has killed at least 16 people and displaced tens of thousands, as both nations accuse each other of aggression while rejecting international mediation.
fields.content:
Acting Thai Prime Minister Phumtham Wechayachai has issued a grave warning that border clashes with Cambodia could 'move towards war.' Intensified fighting with heavy weapons has expanded to 12 locations along the disputed frontier, resulting in at least 16 fatalities and mass displacements of civilians in both nations.

Thailand claims Cambodian forces fired rockets into its civilian areas, forcing the evacuation of villages within rocket range. Conversely, Cambodia accuses Thailand of deploying banned cluster munitions - weapons condemned globally for their indiscriminate impact on civilians. Thailand hasn't formally responded to these allegations.

A Thai soldier stands guard at the disputed ancient Khmer temple Prasat Ta Muen Thom, at a disputed area on the Thai-Cambodian border

Thailand rejected offers of third-party mediation despite international appeals for peace. Foreign Ministry spokesman Nikorndej Balankura stated there's 'no need' for external intervention, insisting Cambodia must halt offensive actions first. This stance came despite Malaysian Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, chair of ASEAN, offering to facilitate talks.

Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Manet has urgently requested United Nations Security Council intervention to 'stop Thailand's aggression,' with the Council scheduled to deliberate on the crisis. The U.S., China, EU, Australia, and France have all voiced deep concern and called for an immediate ceasefire. U.S. State Department spokesman Tommy Pigott expressed being 'gravely concerned' and 'deeply saddened' by civilian casualties.

The violence began after competing accusations about who triggered hostilities. Thailand asserts Cambodia initiated conflict by sending surveillance drones over its border troops, while Cambodia contends Thai soldiers violated agreements by advancing toward the sacred Khmer-Hindu temple Prasat Ta Muen Thom. This dispute stems from century-old border disagreements dating back to French colonial rule, with tensions escalating significantly last May when a Cambodian soldier died in a skirmish.

In Thailand's Surin province, thousands of civilians have been evacuated to converted sports centers. Elderly evacuees who survived Cambodia's 1980s civil war described these as the worst bombardments they've witnessed. Villager Joi Phasuwan recounted fleeing with her grandchildren after prolonged rocket attacks. Near the border, groups of men remain to guard homes and livestock despite artillery fire, taking cover in concrete-pipe shelters fortified with sandbags and tires.

Military vehicles now roam empty roads linking deserted villages as the conflict paralyzes daily life across the border region, with historical temples and forested territories at the heart of the deadly confrontation.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: River Island's Restructuring Battle to Save High Street Chain
fields.summary: Iconic British fashion retailer River Island faces a decisive court judgment on its restructuring strategy, proposing 33 UK store closures and rent reductions at 71 locations. The High Street staple cites online shopping shifts and rising operational costs after reporting £33.2m losses, with creditors voting on the plan in early August.
fields.content:
The survival of fashion chain River Island hinges on an upcoming High Court decision regarding its restructuring strategy. The British retailer announced plans in June to shut 33 UK stores, threatening hundreds of jobs, while seeking rent reductions at an additional 71 outlets.

Citing heavy financial losses driven by consumer shifts to online shopping and escalating operational expenses, the company reported a £33.2m deficit with sales dropping 19%. Though reports suggest potential collapse if the plan fails, executives express confidence in its approval.

Rihanna posing in front of River Island collaboration signage

Retail analyst Catherine Shuttleworth attributes the struggles to an outdated store portfolio in declining locations and unsustainable overhead costs. "River Island maintained expensive stores as footfall decreased and expenses rose," she noted, pointing to underperforming locations that lost prominence over decades.

Founded as Lewis and Chelsea Girl in 1948 and rebranded in 1988, the family-owned business operates 230 stores with 5,500 employees. Despite pioneering online retail in the late 1990s, CEO Ben Lewis highlighted how rising business costs and competition from fast-fashion giants like Shein, Temu and Boohoo intensified financial pressures.

Creditors will vote on the restructuring proposal on August 4, with the High Court ruling due three days later. While the company describes the plan as a "proactive measure" to ensure stability, Label Sessions' Nick Sherrard observed eroding stakeholder confidence: "No one believes in River Island enough to do it favors." He added that the brand struggles with customer loyalty despite market recognition.

Celebrities at a 2009 River Island charity event in London

Can it make a comeback?

According to Sherrard, leadership may underestimate the urgency required for recovery: "You have less time than you think before market changes permanently impact businesses." Fashion editor Remy Farrell suggested successful rebranding is essential, emphasizing the need for timeless pieces over trend-driven collections. She noted uncertainty about River Island's target demographic while highlighting industry anticipation for Topshop's revival as a nostalgia benchmark in affordable fashion.

Additional reporting by Connie Bowker

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Government Considers Shift to Annual Borrowing Assessments
fields.summary: The UK Treasury is reviewing a potential move to yearly official assessments of public finances after the International Monetary Fund warned that the current twice-annual reviews lead to frequent policy reversals. This consideration follows controversial welfare cuts announced and later withdrawn this year due to changing borrowing forecasts.
fields.content:
The government is examining whether to reduce formal evaluations of public borrowing from twice a year to once annually. This reconsideration comes after the International Monetary Fund suggested the current approach causes "overly frequent" policy shifts in response to fluctuating economic forecasts.

Current System Challenges

At present, the Office for Budget Responsibility assesses whether ministers meet borrowing thresholds biannually. Earlier this year, increasing global and domestic interest rates prompted OBR forecasts that led Chancellor Rachel Reeves to announce £5 billion in health-linked welfare reductions. These proposed cuts were quickly reversed after opposition from within the governing Labour Party.

The IMF argued in its annual UK economic review that reducing assessment frequency would grant the government more operational flexibility. Its report stated authorities need "greater room for manoeuvre around its fiscal rules, so that small changes in the outlook do not compromise assessments of rule compliance." Fiscal rules are voluntary constraints most developed nations implement to maintain credibility with international lenders.

Potential Economic Impacts

Adopting the IMF's advice could lead to higher-than-expected tax increases in the upcoming Autumn Budget as Treasury officials build larger financial buffers against worldwide economic instability. While maintaining their commitment to "non-negotiable fiscal rules," Treasury representatives indicated they would consider the IMF's stability recommendations.

Meanwhile, the Institute for Fiscal Studies recommended reducing policy sensitivity by relaxing borrowing targets during Spring Statements to avoid constant tax and spending modifications.

Beyond the assessment proposals, the IMF recommended measures like potentially replacing the state pension triple lock, extending VAT coverage, boosting means-tested benefits, and implementing NHS co-payments for wealthier patients should economic shocks occur. Despite concerns over borrowing assessments, the IMF generally praised the UK's economic direction and described its medium-term fiscal strategy as "credible."

Chancellor Reeves welcomed the report, stating it confirmed her government's decisions had initiated Britain's economic recovery. "Our fiscal rules allow us to confront those challenges by investing in Britain's renewal," she affirmed.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Reanalysis Reveals Potential for Life on Uranus' Moons
fields.summary: New research indicates Uranus and its largest moons might host subsurface oceans capable of supporting life, challenging decades-old assumptions based on Voyager 2 data collected during an unusual solar event.
fields.content:
A fresh study reveals that Uranus and its five major moons are likely far more dynamic than previously believed, potentially featuring liquid oceans beneath their icy exteriors that could harbor life. This dramatic reassessment stems from new interpretations of data collected by NASA's Voyager 2 spacecraft in 1986, which originally suggested these distant worlds were geologically inert.

The original perception emerged after Voyager 2 detected no gases or materials around Uranus—key indicators of active subsurface oceans or geological processes. The planet's magnetic field appeared unusually distorted, squeezed away from the Sun without clear explanation.

Graphic showing positions of Uranus's magnetic field based on Voyager data versus the new analysis indicating gases and possible oceans

Researchers now attribute these anomalies to powerful solar winds that coincided with Voyager 2's flyby. The cosmic storm may have temporarily swept away trapped gases and warped the magnetic environment, giving a false impression of inactivity. Uranus, the solar system's coldest planet with its extreme axial tilt, has long fascinated astronomers for its unique characteristics.

Image of Uranus captured by Voyager 2 during its 1986 flyby

"These results suggest the Uranian system could be vastly more exciting than we imagined," explained Dr. William Dunn of University College London. "Certain moons might possess conditions necessary for life—oceans beneath their surfaces teeming with organisms."

Black and white image of Miranda, one of Uranus's largest moons

The findings, published in Nature Astronomy, have reignited enthusiasm among scientists. Linda Spilker, Voyager's project scientist, stated: "I’m thrilled about the potential for life. It’s astonishing that fresh discoveries continue emerging from data gathered 40 years ago."

Dr. Affelia Wibisono of the Dublin Institute for Advanced Studies described the work as transformative: "Reexamining old data can reveal hidden insights, guiding next-generation missions."

NASA technicians testing the Voyager 2 spacecraft before launch

NASA plans to send the Uranus Orbiter and Probe in the 2030s for detailed investigation, leveraging this research in instrument design. Project scientist Dr. Jamie Jasinski emphasized: "We’re adapting our approach to capture essential science about these active environments." Expected to arrive by 2045, the mission aims to confirm whether Uranus’ enigmatic moons could support extraterrestrial life.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Mandates Age Verification on Adult Sites as New Online Safety Rules Begin
fields.summary: Approximately 6,000 adult content platforms in the UK began implementing mandatory age verification checks today under new online safety regulations. Media regulator Ofcom confirmed participation from major platforms including X, Reddit, and Pornhub, though concerns persist about enforcement effectiveness and privacy implications.
fields.content:
Around 6,000 websites hosting adult content in the UK started verifying visitors' ages on Friday as new online safety rules took effect. Media regulator Ofcom confirmed that platforms including Elon Musk's X, Discord, Bluesky, Grindr, and leading adult site Pornhub have committed to implement age verification systems.

Ofcom chief executive Dame Melanie Dawes stated that the regulations demonstrate concrete action by technology companies to protect children online, remarking that no other country has enacted similar measures with such widespread platform cooperation. However, the BBC learned at least one major UK adult site failed to implement checks by the Friday deadline.

The UK's Technology Secretary Peter Kyle defended the policy as common sense, comparing online age checks to existing verifications for purchasing energy drinks. He noted the discrepancy in requiring age proof for buying a can of Monster but not for accessing explicit content online.

Chris Sherwood of children's charity NSPCC welcomed the move, stating platforms can no longer evade child protection responsibilities. Prof Elena Martellozzo from the University of Edinburgh added the regulations send a clear message that child safety cannot be compromised for business convenience.

'More to be done'

Critics argue the regulations fall short on enforcement. The Molly Rose Foundation, established after 14-year-old Molly Russell's suicide following exposure to harmful content, believes Ofcom prioritizes corporate interests over child safety. Foundation head Andy Burrows contends larger companies face insufficient pressure to overhaul systems effectively.

Privacy concerns have also surfaced, particularly regarding LGBTQ+ individuals who may avoid ID verification due to safety fears. Sex educator Reed Amber Thomas-Litman warned that pushing users toward unregulated platforms could expose them to more extreme content, while collected identification data might be mishandled by third parties. She advocated for improved sex education to help youth contextualize adult content.

Despite these concerns, Derek Ray-Hill of the Internet Watch Foundation acknowledged progress while emphasizing the need for continuous improvement. He urged platforms to integrate safety measures into their fundamental design to create a more secure internet.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Parents of American Terror Victim Push U.S. to Secure Hamas Bomber's Extradition
fields.summary: The parents of an American victim killed in a 2001 Hamas bombing in Jerusalem have urged top U.S. prosecutor Jeanine Pirro to push Jordan for the extradition of confessed terrorist Ahlam al-Tamimi, who masterminded the attack that murdered 16 people including three Americans.
fields.content:
Parents of an American victim murdered in a Jerusalem terrorist attack urged U.S. prosecutor Jeanine Pirro to pressure Jordan into extraditing self-confessed Hamas bomber Ahlam Aref Ahmad al-Tamimi. The 2001 pizzeria explosion killed 16 victims, half of them children, including three Americans as the 24th anniversary approaches next month.

Parents Advocate for Justice

Arnold Roth implored Pirro during their meeting: "You have the capacity to push for her extradition, to ensure the 1995 treaty is honored, and show Jordan that harboring terrorists has consequences." The family emphasized that the discussions focused on concrete steps to advance al-Tamimi's long-delayed extradition from Jordan.

FBI Most Wanted Terrorist Ahlam al-Tamimi

Arnold Roth stressed: "Jordan needs to know the U.S. cannot tolerate protecting a murderer of American citizens. U.S. justice needs respect from the world and America's own officials." Frimet Roth added emotionally: "We cannot carry this fight alone. Be the voice for Malki and other victims. Act for the integrity of American law."

Jerusalem Terror attack at Sbarro

Government Response Questioned

Arnold Roth revealed ongoing frustration with U.S. officials: "No senior State figure ever spoke with us despite promises this was a 'foremost priority.' They ignored every follow-up after Biden and Blinken's initial assurances." Jordan, a major recipient of U.S. military financing, faces scrutiny over sheltering the terrorist.

President Trump meets with Jordanian King Abdullah

The State Department redirected queries about al-Tamimi's U.S. criminal case to the Justice Department, where Pirro's office didn't immediately respond to press inquiries. Jordan's government also remained silent despite multiple requests regarding the extradition standoff.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: GOP Launches Effort to Draft Second Major Bill Advancing Trump Agenda
fields.summary: House Republicans have initiated efforts to draft a second budget reconciliation bill advancing Donald Trump's priorities, forming a working group through their main policy think tank. Building on their recent legislative success, GOP leaders aim to further reduce living costs and implement conservative policies following their initial broad legislative package.
fields.content:
Working Group for a Second Bill

The Republican Study Committee (RSC), representing 189 members and functioning as the House GOP's primary policy forum, has formed a working group to outline proposals for a second budget reconciliation bill. This marks the most substantial organized initiative by congressional Republicans to achieve leaders' goals for another significant agenda bill following their recent legislative victory.

"We must capitalize on the momentum we’ve generated in the first 6 months of a Republican trifecta in Washington," stated RSC Chairman August Pfluger of Texas. "To fulfill our promises, conservatives must lay groundwork for the second reconciliation bill to drive down living costs and restore America's promise." Pfluger instructed group members to consult colleagues, conservative senators, and GOP organizations regarding potential policy inclusions in the new legislation.

The group aims to develop a framework for what supporters term the second "big, beautiful bill" and present these recommendations to Republican leadership.

Trump signs the Big Beautiful Bill

Building on Previous Success

The first reconciliation bill enacted sweeping legislation advancing Trump's priorities on taxes, border security, immigration, defense, and energy policy. Key provisions included making most of the 2017 Tax Cuts and Jobs Act permanent while imposing new work requirements for Medicaid and food assistance programs.

Republicans notably achieved their July 4 deadline for passing this legislation—a timeline widely considered unrealistic previously. The reconciliation process allows the party controlling Congress and the White House to implement major policy overhauls with simple majority votes, bypassing the 60-vote threshold typically required in the Senate. However, such bills must exclusively address fiscal matters under strict legislative guidelines.

House Speaker Mike Johnson

Future Legislative Plans

House Speaker Mike Johnson confirmed plans for additional reconciliation bills during a recent television appearance. "With President Trump back, we must fix every policy area damaged over the last four years," Johnson explained. "The big beautiful bill was the opening step. We anticipate at least two, possibly three reconciliation bills—one this fall and another next spring."

Elizabeth Elkind is a politics reporter focusing on congressional affairs, having previously contributed to major news outlets including CBS News.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Lifestyle factors under scrutiny in Ozzy Osbourne's Parkinson's diagnosis
fields.summary: Rock legend Ozzy Osbourne's rare Parkinson's diagnosis prompts expert analysis on how environmental exposures and rock star lifestyle factors may have influenced his condition's progression, alongside explanations of the disease's mechanisms and emerging treatments.
fields.content:
Ozzy Osbourne publicly revealed his Parkinson's diagnosis in 2019 during an interview, citing his inability to keep it private any longer. The Black Sabbath vocalist connected his condition to a serious fall that required neck surgery and caused nerve damage, stating, 'I'm running out of excuses.' Medical experts note his case involves a rare genetic variant potentially accelerated by lifestyle influences.

What causes Parkinson’s?

Parkinson's disease is a neurodegenerative disorder affecting dopamine production in the midbrain. Dopamine regulates movement coordination and cognitive functions. Neurologists highlight that physical slowing and tremors—typically starting in hands—are common initial symptoms. As dopamine pathways degrade, patients often experience diminished executive function and cognitive decline alongside motor impairments.

Man with Parkinson's disease holds his own hand

Clinical neurologist Dr. Nathan Crawford emphasized Parkinson's pervasive impact: 'This disease affects every aspect of life beyond tremors or slowed movement,' noting the dopamine deficiency disrupts both physical mobility and mental clarity.

Disease management

Parkinson's treatment focuses on symptom management, though medications often provide fluctuating relief. Crawford explained, 'Patients experience brief periods of improved function before symptoms rapidly return as drugs wear off.' Sharon Osbourne described her husband's unpredictable condition where good days abruptly shift to severe episodes.

A photo of Ozzy and Sharon Osbourne

The family reported significant improvement following stem cell therapy, with daughter Kelly Osbourne noting enhanced mobility, speech, and muscle strength after one treatment. Current research explores stem cells' potential to regenerate dopamine neurons, with the FDA approving a Phase 1 trial in March.

Environmental factors

Crawford suggested Osbourne's rock star lifestyle may have contributed to his condition's progression. Disrupted circadian rhythms from nighttime performances, loud music exposure, chronic inflammation and substance use likely played roles. The neurologist noted that repetitive head trauma from stage movements like headbanging resembles mild brain injuries.

Jake E. Lee and Ozzy osbourne

Long-term environmental exposures to heavy metals like mercury and lead in poorly ventilated venues could elevate Parkinson's risk. Crawford concluded, 'These cumulative lifestyle elements potentially accelerate neurodegeneration in genetically susceptible individuals.'

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Amateur Detectorist Unearths Major Roman Settlement in UK Countryside
fields.summary: An amateur metal detectorist with a hunch led archaeologists to uncover a 2,000-year-old Roman settlement in England's Cotswolds region, revealing a villa, limestone structures, Iron Age ditches, and rare cavalry swords that offer new insights into ancient British history.
fields.content:
A remarkable Roman-era settlement dating back 2,000 years has been discovered in Gloucestershire, England, after an amateur detectorist's intuition prompted archaeological investigations. The excavation near Willersey revealed a Roman villa, limestone structures, and at least three Iron Age ring ditches, with the site inhabited between the 1st and 2nd centuries AD.

Cotswold Archaeology and Historic England conducted the joint excavation, unearthing Roman building materials including ceramic roofing tiles, painted wall plaster, and specialized box flue tiles. Historic England now awaits the final report before potentially recommending the site become a protected scheduled monument through the Department for Culture, Media and Sport.

Initial investigations began after local metal detectorist Glenn Manning discovered two iron Roman cavalry swords at the location in March 2023 despite minimal experience. Analysis showed one sword featured intricate pattern welding – indicating higher status and greater expense – while the other was plainer in design.

Ancient Roman sword

These 2nd-century swords likely belonged to cavalrymen active during the villa's occupation, though their presence remains unexplained. Archaeologists also uncovered a human burial site featuring an iron armband and a horse skull, though determining their connection to the Roman settlement requires further study.

Fragments of Roman plaster

Project officer Peter Busby expressed pride in how "a plowed field, the swords, and geophysical anomalies" revealed centuries of settlement history. Manning, calling the find "amazing" on just his second detecting trip, remains eager for more discoveries. The Romans occupied Britain from 43 AD until 410 AD, with new artifacts still emerging across the country today.

Split image of archaeologists digging next to metal detectorist

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Valerie Chiang Returns to Photography with Still Lifes and Portraits
fields.summary: New York-based photographer and filmmaker Valerie Chiang showcases her recently renewed artistic practice after a three-year hiatus, presenting striking still lifes and intimate portraits.
fields.content:
New York City artist Valerie Chiang displays recent photographic works following a pause from the medium. Previously featured by this platform, Chiang initially studied piano performance at Oberlin Conservatory before transferring to the University of Southern California. She graduated in 2015 with a degree in Film & TV Production.

After a three-year break from photography, Chiang has embarked on a new project centered on still lifes and portraits. Her renewed practice demonstrates a fresh perspective on everyday subjects and human connections through carefully composed imagery.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: The Artistic Revolution Behind Seurat's 'A Sunday on La Grande Jatte'
fields.summary: Georges Seurat's 1884-1886 masterpiece 'A Sunday on La Grande Jatte' transformed modern art through pioneering pointillism techniques, scientific color theory, and profound social commentary, cementing its status as a foundational work of Post-Impressionism.
fields.content:
The Pointillist Technique and Its Sources

Georges Seurat's 'A Sunday on La Grande Jatte' revolutionized painting through pointillism—a technique he termed 'divisionism' or 'optical painting.' This Post-Impressionist masterpiece captures Parisian leisure-seekers at a Seine riverside park, creating an arresting paradox: modern spontaneity frozen into chromatic permanence. Seurat merged classical influences from his École des Beaux-Arts training under Henri Lehmann, a disciple of neoclassicist Jean Auguste Dominique Ingres, with radical color science from Michel Eugène Chevreul's 1839 treatise on simultaneous color contrasts. "Some say they see poetry in my paintings," Seurat remarked. "I see only science."

Setting and Social Contrasts

The Île de la Grande Jatte—named for its bowl-like depression—became a fashionable retreat after 19th-century urban renovations. Seurat depicted this locale as a deliberate counterpart to his earlier 'Bathers at Asnières', which portrayed working-class men just across the Seine. Both paintings share geographic elements like a railway bridge while creating a sociological diptych: 'Bathers' faces leftward with proletarian informality while 'La Grande Jatte's bourgeois figures face right in structured promenades. Seurat executed over 70 studies transitioning from crosshatched brushwork to precise dots during 1884-1886.

Symbolism and Lasting Influence

The painting encodes subtle commentary through symbols like a woman fishing (suggesting solicitation) and a monkey on a leash—'singesse' being French slang for prostitute. Exhibited at the 1886 Impressionist show, it initially faced derision; critic Joris-Karl Huysmans dismissed it: "Strip his figures of the colored fleas... underneath there is nothing." Undeterred, Seurat expanded pointillism, later adding border-dot frames that intensified optical engagement. His sudden death at 31 curtailed his career but solidified 'La Grande Jatte' as an enduring landmark that relies equally on viewer perception and artist intention for its effects.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Coroner Rules Jay Slater's Death as Accidental After Tenerife Ravine Fall
fields.summary: A coroner has ruled 19-year-old Jay Slater from Oswaldtwistle died accidentally after falling in a ravine during a holiday in Tenerife. The inquest revealed he suffered fatal injuries while attempting a long walk after consuming drugs and alcohol.
fields.content:
Jay Slater's death resulted from an accidental fall in Tenerife with no third-party involvement, Preston Coroner's Court concluded. The 19-year-old from Lancashire disappeared on June 17, 2024, sparking an extensive search before his body was discovered in the Rural de Teno national park near Masca on July 15.

Coroner Dr James Adeley determined Slater had sustained catastrophic skull fractures and brain trauma from a fall of up to 25 meters (82 feet) in a hazardous ravine. Evidence indicated death was instantaneous, with additional pelvic fractures and contributing factors including drug consumption, inadequate clothing, sleep deprivation, and lack of mountain experience.

'Particularly dangerous area'

Slater's mother Debbie Duncan described her son as having a "wonderful life" and being a "joy to be around," emphasizing his loving nature and devastated family. "He was very loved and our hearts are broken," she testified during the inquest, which resumed after being adjourned to locate witnesses.

Dr Adeley confirmed the location represented an extremely hazardous terrain and expressed hope that the knowledge Slater wouldn't have suffered provided some solace. Witness accounts revealed Slater had taken ecstasy, ketamine, cocaine, and alcohol before disappearing. His last phone call to friend Lucy Law described being stranded "in the middle of the mountains" with dwindling battery.

Reuters Flowers left by family of Jay Slater, near the site where his body was found, in Masca, on the island of Tenerife, Spain.

Friend Bradley Geoghegan recounted that Slater appeared disoriented but not fearful during a final video call while attempting a 14-hour walk back to his accommodation. Geoghegan had urged him to take a taxi instead. The coroner noted friends demonstrated genuine concern for Slater's welfare throughout the incident. Toxicology reports indicated multiple substances in his system when he undertook the ill-fated journey.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Philippines Supreme Court Halts Impeachment Bid Against VP Sara Duterte
fields.summary: The Philippine Supreme Court has suspended impeachment proceedings against Vice President Sara Duterte, ruling that the lower house violated constitutional restrictions on multiple impeachments. The decision spares her from immediate removal and preserves her eligibility for a potential presidential run.
fields.content:
The Philippine Supreme Court has halted an impeachment trial targeting Vice President Sara Duterte, delivering her a significant legal victory. The ruling comes after the lower parliamentary chamber voted in February to impeach her over allegations of public fund misuse and threats against President Ferdinand Marcos Jr.

Court representatives clarified that Friday's decision stems from a constitutional violation—specifically the prohibition against initiating multiple impeachment processes within a single year. While the judgment doesn't dismiss the allegations against Duterte, it prevents any possible removal from office until at least February 2026.

This legal reprieve grants Duterte crucial time to mobilize support ahead of potential presidential bids, as she would have been barred from candidacy if convicted. Her political fortunes contrast sharply with former ally President Marcos. Once partners in the dominant "Uniteam" alliance that won the 2022 election, their relationship deteriorated into open hostility.

Tensions reached a critical point last November when Duterte declared on Facebook that she had instructed "a person" to ensure Marcos's death if she were killed. This post triggered the impeachment proceedings. The feud grew more personal after her father, Rodrigo Duterte, was extradited to The Hague to face crimes against humanity charges related to his deadly drug war campaign.

Political analysts note the Supreme Court's composition—dominated by appointees of Duterte's father—contributed to the outcome. Since democracy's 1986 restoration, only one impeachment conviction has succeeded nationwide. In 2012, Chief Justice Renato Corona was ousted for concealing assets, while President Joseph Estrada's 2001 impeachment trial was interrupted by mass protests that forced his removal.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Hot Weather Drives UK Retail Sales Growth in June
fields.summary: UK retail sales rebounded by 0.9% in June as record-breaking heat drove increased spending on summer clothing, drinks, and fuel, partially recovering from an unexpectedly large 2.8% decline in May according to ONS data.
fields.content:
UK retail sales experienced a 0.9% volume increase in June according to the Office for National Statistics (ONS), marking a partial revival from May's revised 2.8% slump. The warmth and sunshine prompted consumers to buy more summer clothes, drinks, and filling stations experienced a 2.8% sales boost as people traveled during the sunny weather.

Despite the improvement following May's deeper-than-expected contraction, the recovery fell below economists' projections. Ruth Gregory, deputy chief UK economist at Capital Economics, characterized June's sales performance as "disappointingly small." Overall retail spending momentum has weakened significantly, registering only a 0.2% rise during April-June compared to the preceding three months.

These monthly fluctuations partly resulted from weather conditions and Easter's timing this year. Supporting this modest quarterly growth picture, a separate Gfk survey suggested consumer confidence remains lower than last year. This aligns with economists' forecasts for sluggish economic expansion during the second quarter.

Bar chart showing retail sales volume changes from June 2023 to June 2025

Food stores registered a 0.7% expansion in June. ONS senior statistician Hannah Finselbach highlighted how hot weather helped boost supermarket trade, particularly drink purchases, while sunshine encouraged travel and vehicle refueling. England witnessed its hottest recorded June, with the UK experiencing its second-warmest.

Non-food stores displayed mixed results – clothing sales increased through promotions and weather, while household goods like furniture declined. PwC UK's Jacqueline Windsor attributed supermarket and fashion rebounds to home entertaining and wardrobe updates but noted warm weather reduced high street footfall and elevated online sales.

The retail numbers emerged amidst other concerning economic updates: higher-than-anticipated government borrowing in June, unexpected economic contraction in May, and a recent inflation rise to 3.6%.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Pressure Mounts on UK After France's Palestine Statehood Pledge
fields.summary: French President Emmanuel Macron's commitment to recognize Palestinian statehood at the UN General Assembly in September has intensified diplomatic pressure on UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer to align with this position, amid domestic political challenges and growing humanitarian concerns in Gaza.
fields.content:
President Emmanuel Macron's declared intention to recognize Palestinian statehood places significant pressure on UK leader Keir Starmer to take similar action. France had postponed this move earlier following strikes on Iranian nuclear facilities by Israel and the United States.

Macron plans formal recognition during September's UN General Assembly, hoping to build diplomatic momentum and encourage broader international support. A senior French diplomat emphasized that joint UK-France action would demonstrate serious intent at the UN Security Council.

Traditionally, the UK has reserved recognition as leverage for final peace negotiations, fearing symbolic gestures might undermine the diplomatic process. Officials privately questioned the tangible impact of Macron's decision beyond its diplomatic optics.

UK Foreign Secretary David Lammy reiterated that statehood recognition remains a sovereign choice but cautioned it represents a symbolic step rather than a solution. Starmer stressed the necessity of a ceasefire as prerequisite for progress, stating recognition must follow sustainable peace efforts.

Domestic pressure is intensifying within the UK, with MPs across parties demanding recognition and cabinet ministers like Health Secretary Wes Streeting advocating timely action. Political analysts warn of potential Labour backbench revolts if Starmer resists alignment with France.

Over 140 nations have already recognized Palestine, though recent additions like Ireland and Spain saw minimal impact. Questions persist about whether diplomatic recognition alters dire conditions in Gaza, where food shortages cause widespread malnutrition.

All week, reports have highlighted severe humanitarian conditions affecting Gaza's population. This includes vulnerable groups facing starvation due to restricted supplies.

People in Gaza holding bowls, waiting for food

Plaid Cymru leaders demanded urgent sanctions against Israel over the Gaza crisis while Keir Starmer called the situation a humanitarian catastrophe during emergency talks with European counterparts.

A woman holds a severely underweight child in a tent in Gaza

Prime Minister Keir Starmer during a joint press conference, with a union jack flag in the background

Freelance journalists covering Gaza endure the same desperate conditions as those they report on, with food distributions becoming critical survival mechanisms.

Palestinians carrying pans gather to receive hot meals from a charity kitchen in Gaza City, northern Gaza (23 July 2025)

Source: Original Article

fields.title: 7,000 Daily Steps Can Lower Health Risks as Effectively as 10,000
fields.summary: Walking just 7,000 steps daily substantially reduces risks of serious health conditions including cancer, dementia and heart disease, according to a major Lancet Public Health study that challenges the traditional 10,000-step benchmark as unscientific.
fields.content:
New research indicates achieving approximately 7,000 steps each day could effectively enhance cognitive function and guard against multiple chronic diseases. This figure presents a more attainable goal than the frequently promoted target of 10,000 steps.

The comprehensive study, published in The Lancet Public Health, analyzed health and activity data from over 160,000 adults globally. Findings reveal this step count correlates with dramatically lower risks of developing cancer, dementia, and cardiovascular conditions compared to inactive individuals taking only 2,000 steps.

Lead researcher Dr. Melody Ding notes the evidence challenges common perceptions: "We have this perception we should be doing 10,000 steps per day, but it's not evidence based." The 10,000-step standard originated from a 1960s Japanese pedometer marketing campaign before the Tokyo Olympics.

While benefits generally plateau around 7,000 steps, the research identified that additional walking continues improving heart health specifically. Overall, even moderate activity levels of 4,000 daily steps showed substantial advantages over minimal movement.

Person checking fitness app on smartphone while wearing smartwatch

'It's about getting out and about'

Jon Stride, 64, who regularly surpasses 16,000 daily steps since recovering from a heart attack in 2022, emphasizes that health benefits extend beyond numbers: "It's about getting out and about, and the benefits for our mental wellbeing that are tangible but not as easy to quantify."

Exercise guidelines typically focus on time-based recommendations—like the World Health Organization's 150 weekly minutes of moderate activity—rather than step counts. Specialists explain step targets could complement existing advice, especially benefiting those unable to engage in other physical activities.

Dr. Daniel Bailey from Brunel University London calls the findings a challenge to the "myth" of 10,000-step necessity, suggesting 5,000-7,000 steps may be a "more realistic and achievable target" for many people. Healthcare professionals note that even household activities like gardening contribute meaningfully to daily movement goals.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Public Divided Over AI Use in Student Coursework
fields.summary: A recent UK survey reveals polarized public opinions on students using artificial intelligence for schoolwork, showing 89% opposition to general AI use but near-even splits on educational applications, while education leaders call for national AI strategies.
fields.content:
A YouGov survey commissioned by Cambridge University Press and Assessment found significant divisions among UK adults regarding student use of artificial intelligence. One in six respondents believed reducing or removing coursework assignments would best prevent AI misuse in education.

While 89% considered it unacceptable for students to use AI broadly for coursework, nearly half (46%) approved its use specifically for improving punctuation and grammar. Conversely, 44% opposed even this limited application.

These findings follow exam board OCR CEO Jill Duffy's call for a coordinated national AI strategy. "The public is clear that coursework is too important to lose, even in the age of AI," Duffy stated, emphasizing that AI has become an unavoidable presence in schools.

Risk to fairness

Duffy's appeal responded to concerns raised in an independent curriculum review about AI's potential threats to assessment fairness. An interim report published in March highlighted risks to educational standards posed by AI-enabled coursework.

Education expert Becky Francis chairs the review, which is considering reducing GCSE exam volume and will issue final recommendations this autumn. Duffy framed this as a challenge to "adapt coursework so it is fit for the AI century" through national coordination and targeted funding.

"AI enables us to test different skills and reduce the intense volume of exams taken at 16," Duffy argued. June's survey also revealed over 60% of adults oppose teachers using AI for grading coursework, though 27% support such applications.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: South Park Secures $1.5 Billion Paramount+ Streaming Deal
fields.summary: South Park creators have finalized a $1.5 billion agreement to move their animated series exclusively to Paramount+, concluding a competitive bidding war and bringing 26 existing seasons plus 50 new episodes to the platform.
fields.content:
The creators of South Park, Trey Parker and Matt Stone, have finalized a landmark five-year deal to bring their long-running satirical series to Paramount+. The agreement, reportedly worth $1.5 billion according to the Los Angeles Times, guarantees streamers will have access to all 26 existing seasons of the animated show along with 50 new episodes starting this week.

Paramount+ emerged victorious after months of intense negotiations and a bidding war among major streaming platforms. All new South Park episodes will premiere first on Paramount-owned Comedy Central before transitioning to streaming, marking a change from the show's previous home on HBO Max.

South Park creators Matt Stone and Trey Parker speaking in a public appearance

This transition faced delays as contract talks pushed back the newest season originally scheduled for July 9 release. The animated series debuted back in 1997 and became renowned for its provocative comedy and boundary-pushing humor that consistently generated controversy.

Parker and Stone, who also co-created the acclaimed musical The Book of Mormon, developed South Park into a cultural institution. The show has frequently encountered criticism including a clash with President Donald Trump, whose administration dismissed a Trump-themed episode as "a desperate attempt for attention".

Paramount faced separate scrutiny recently when canceling The Late Show after over three decades, citing financial pressures. However, some observers questioned whether this related to a $16 million lawsuit settlement between the company and former President Donald Trump over allegedly deceptive editing during a CBS News interview with Kamala Harris.

Paramount headquarters building in California

Paramount clarified the settlement funds were allocated to Trump's future presidential library rather than personally to him and included no admission of wrongdoing or apology. The company noted the Federal Communications Commission approved the arrangement amid ongoing controversies surrounding other corporate decisions.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Dame Cleo Laine, Legendary Jazz Vocalist, Dies at 97
fields.summary: Renowned British jazz singer Dame Cleo Laine, known for her extraordinary four-octave vocal range and collaborations with music legends like Frank Sinatra, has died at age 97. The Grammy-winning artist co-founded the Stables theatre and revolutionized jazz performance while maintaining an active career into her 90s.
fields.content:
Celebrated jazz vocalist Dame Cleo Laine, famed for her unparalleled vocal range and genre-spanning repertoire, has passed away at 97. The British icon made history as the first UK singer to win a Grammy Award in jazz and performed alongside greats including Ray Charles and Frank Sinatra during her illustrious career.

Getty Images Dame Cleo Laine and her husband Sir John Dankworth at the piano

Her most significant artistic partnership was with husband John Dankworth, the composer and musician she wed in 1958. Together they established Buckinghamshire's Stables arts center, which confirmed her passing in a statement expressing profound sadness. David Meadowcroft, chairman of The Stables, praised her as a "remarkable performer" committed to music education.

Rise to Fame

Born Clementina Dinah Hitching in Southall on October 28, 1927, to a Jamaican WWI veteran father and English mother who faced family disapproval for their interracial marriage, she began singing at community events aged three. Post-war hardships saw her leave school at 14, working various jobs including hairdressing and pawnbroking before marrying roofer George Langridge in 1947.

Cleo Laine in 1945

Her breakthrough came in 1951 when she auditioned for Johnny Dankworth's jazz ensemble. Dankworth declared "she's got something," and she joined for £7 weekly. When posters required a shorter name, 'Cleo' and 'Laine' were drawn from a hat. With distinctive corkscrew hair and husky contralto voice spanning four octaves, she mastered scat singing techniques.

Getty Images Cleo Laine and John Dankworth photographed in the 1950s; he is playing a saxophone and she is singing

Artistic Triumphs

Following divorce from Langridge and marriage to Dankworth, Laine pursued acting. Her Royal Court Theatre debut in 1958's Jamaican-set play "Flesh To A Tiger" earned critical acclaim. She simultaneously maintained musical success with 1961's top-10 hit "You'll Answer Me" and the landmark 1964 album "Shakespeare and All That Jazz."

International recognition arrived when Duke Ellington invited her to the US in 1973. After conquering Carnegie Hall, the New York Times remarked Britain had been "hoarding a national treasure." This launched annual American tours that garnered multiple Grammy nominations before her 1983 win for a Carnegie Hall recording. She remains the only artist with simultaneous pop and classical Grammy nominations.

Getty Images Cleo Laine performing on stage

Enduring Legacy

Honored with an OBE in 1979 and damehood in 1997, Laine established The Stables theatre with Dankworth to demystify musical genres. When Dankworth died in February 2010, Laine performed their scheduled concert hours later, announcing his death afterward. She continued singing with children Jacqui and Alec Dankworth well into her 90s, saying: "Singing is the one thing that keeps me going."

Getty Images John Dankworth and Cleo Laine pose for the cameras in 1970

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump Visits Scotland Amid Security Boost for Trade Talks and Golf
fields.summary: President Donald Trump travels to Scotland for discussions on trade, politics, and golf at his properties. The trip features enhanced security measures and highlights UK-US trade agreements ahead of a formal state visit in September.
fields.content:
President Donald Trump's visit to Scotland centers on diplomatic discussions, trade relations, and a round of golf at his own properties. Authorities have implemented heightened security, deploying forces nationwide for safety during the stay.

Trade Deal Advancements

Mendoza told Fox News Digital that further specifics on trade agreements are anticipated, noting, "Now we expect to see more detail to be hammered out and specific rates on various industries to be specified." The British government emphasized their exclusive tariff agreement with the U.S., stating: "The U.K. is the only country to have secured this deal with the U.S., reducing car export tariffs from 27.5% to 10%, saving manufacturers hundreds of millions each year and protecting hundreds of thousands of jobs." Aerospace sector benefits were also highlighted, with 10% tariffs eliminated on engines and aircraft parts to boost companies like Rolls-Royce.

Diplomatic Relations

British leader Starmer previously underscored the importance of his relationship with Trump in a BBC interview, calling it "in the national interest" for them to maintain cooperation. "We are different people, and we’ve got different political backgrounds and leanings, but we do have a good relationship and that comes from a number of places," Starmer remarked on the "Political Thinking" podcast. Earlier this month, Starmer met with Trump and Vance at the Oval Office.

Starmer meets Trump during Oval Office visit

The British government declined to confirm whether Starmer will join Trump for golf during the Scotland trip, recalling the president's 2018 visit to Turnberry resort.

Scottish Heritage and Security

Trump holds personal ties to Scotland through his mother, Mary Anne MacLeod Trump, who was born there before moving to New York. He honored her by naming an 18-hole course the MacLeod Course at his Aberdeen club. Trump is seen alongside ceremonial bagpipers during his Scottish stops.

Trump with bagpipers in Scotland

Police Scotland mobilized substantial security resources, with Assistant Chief Constable Emma Bond stating: "A policing plan will be in place to maintain public safety, balance rights to peaceful protest and minimize disruption." The operation involves national resources and mutual aid from other UK police forces. Bond added, "The visit will require a significant police operation," acknowledging anticipated protests.

Police presence during Trump's visit

Trump will return to the UK in September for an official state visit to meet King Charles III at Windsor Castle—marking the first time a US president receives a second UK state invitation.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ashley Moody Secures Trump Endorsement for 2026 Florida Senate Race
fields.summary: Florida Senator Ashley Moody received former President Donald Trump's endorsement for the 2026 special election after demonstrating alignment through legislative support. Moody was appointed by Governor Ron DeSantis to replace Marco Rubio and recently backed Trump-endorsed legislation.
fields.content:
Senator Ashley Moody, appointed by Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, earned a significant endorsement from former President Donald Trump ahead of the 2026 special election. Trump praised Moody's performance, characterizing her work as a 'tremendous job'.

Moody assumed the Senate seat earlier this year after Marco Rubio departed to serve as Secretary of State during the Trump administration. This gubernatorial appointment positioned her to complete the current Senate term.

In a recent display of political alignment, Moody voted alongside most congressional Republicans to pass the Trump-backed One Big Beautiful Bill Act. Following Trump's endorsement, Moody publicly expressed gratitude for his support.

A special election will take place next year allowing Florida residents to elect their representative for the remainder of the Senate term. This contest will determine if Moody continues representing the state beyond her interim appointment.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Alleged Ambien use raises concerns for high-stress occupations
fields.summary: Concerns about sleep medication safety have emerged following claims about Joe Biden's alleged Ambien use, with experts warning that certain professions strictly prohibit its use due to risks of grogginess, impaired judgment, and dementia.
fields.content:
Recent claims regarding Joe Biden's alleged use of the sleep medication Ambien have prompted discussions about occupational restrictions for the drug. In a recent interview, Hunter Biden suggested the prescription medication might have affected his father's performance during the 2024 presidential debate.

"He's 81 years old. He's tired as s---. They give him Ambien to be able to sleep," Hunter Biden stated, adding that grogginess might have contributed to perceived cognitive difficulties onstage. These remarks raised questions about the appropriateness of such medication for high-responsibility roles.

Ambien medication bottle displayed adjacent to President Joe Biden

Political commentator Salena Zito responded to the assertions during a television appearance, expressing doubt about the suitability for a president to use such medications. "For the guy who’s supposed to answer the 3 a.m. phone calls—it’s bewildering," Zito remarked.

Occupational restrictions for Ambien

Prescribing guidelines warn that Ambien can impair mental alertness for critical tasks like operating machinery or driving, with effects potentially lasting until the next day. The Federal Aviation Administration prohibits pilots and aircrew from flying within 24 hours of taking sleep aids.

A tired pilot shown rubbing his eyes in a cockpit

Studies reveal Ambien increases dementia risk in adults over 55 and may contribute to next-day drowsiness and abnormal thinking. Heavy machinery operators are advised against equipment use for eight hours after consumption, while commercial truck drivers must undergo medical evaluation if prescribed sleep aids to ensure safe vehicle operation.

A fatigued truck driver leaning against his vehicle

Medical expert Dr. Marc Siegel emphasized that physicians should consider job requirements when prescribing sleep aids. Meanwhile, the Department of Defense mandates seven hours of nightly sleep for military personnel to maintain operational readiness.

Requests for comment from President Biden's representatives and Ambien manufacturer Cosette Pharmaceuticals reportedly received no immediate response.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Deadly Rip Currents Claim Lives: Experts Share Survival Tactics During Beach Season
fields.summary: Multiple fatalities from rip currents, including actor Malcolm-Jamal Warner, have occurred this summer, with safety experts outlining crucial survival measures to prevent drownings at beaches.
fields.content:
A series of tragic deaths has been reported due to rip currents as beach season peaks, with experts emphasizing lifesaving tips to counter these hazards. Among the victims is Malcolm-Jamal Warner, known for his role on The Cosby Show, who was swept away while on vacation in Costa Rica on July 20.

Rescuers attempted to save Warner but could not revive him. Similarly, Chase Childers perished after diving in to help stranded swimmers, only to be overtaken by strong waters. Another incident involved U.S. Border Patrol Agent Eric Cespedes, who rescued his children from a current near South Padre Island, Texas on July 11 but then himself drowned.

No swim sign

According to Chris Brewster of the United States Lifesaving Association, untrained rescuers frequently succumb to rip currents while aiding others. He advises always bringing a floatation device like a life jacket when attempting rescue and stresses that the term 'rip currents'—not 'riptides'—correctly describes these dangerous patterns.

Brewster explained that rip currents form as surf pushes water ashore, with gravity pulling it seaward. He co-authored a study which reveals rip currents cause 81.9% of rescues on surf beaches and potentially over 100 fatal drownings annually in the U.S.

lifeguard at lido beach, long island

Rip currents can be spotted as narrow, calmer gaps between breaking waves, often indicating seaward movement of foam or debris. When caught, victims typically panic after realizing they cannot swim back to shore, exhausting themselves.

Experts like Greg Leonard recommend staying calm and swimming parallel to the shore until escaping the current before heading in at an angle. Brewster echoes this: Don’t fight the rip—relax, float, and swim sideways.

People on beach

CDC data shows 4,500 unintentional drownings occur yearly, with half happening in natural waters like oceans. Brewster urges beachgoers to swim near lifeguards, while Leonard suggests assigning a watcher, especially for children, to avoid distractions.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: USA Volleyball Implements Ban on Transgender Athletes in Women's Competition
fields.summary: USA Volleyball has enacted an immediate policy prohibiting transgender athletes from competing in women's divisions, requiring participation based on birth certificate gender designation. This change follows guidance from the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee emphasizing federal compliance and competitive fairness in women's sports.
fields.content:
Immediate Policy Change

USA Volleyball (USAV) announced an immediate policy shift requiring all members to compete according to their gender assigned at birth in sanctioned events. This decision effectively excludes transgender athletes from girls' and women's competitions. The organization stated the measure responds to guidance from the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee (USOPC) mandating alignment with federal expectations.

USOPC leadership emphasized compliance obligations in an official communication. "As a federally chartered organization, we have an obligation to comply with federal expectations," stated CEO Sarah Hirshland and President Gene Sykes. "Our revised policy emphasizes ensuring fair and safe competition environments for women. All National Governing Bodies must update policies accordingly."

The back of Jordan Thompson's jacket

Previous Regulations

Before this policy revision, USAV's 2024-2025 gender eligibility rules allowed transgender athletes to compete under specific conditions. The framework permitted participation opposite birth gender following a notification process at least six weeks before events. Athletes needed to submit a personal statement plus documentation from a treating physician including medical records and lab results.

For athletes assigned male at birth competing in women's divisions, testosterone levels could not exceed the upper female reference range for their age group. Adults over 18 faced stricter requirements, needing sustained testosterone levels below 10 nmol/L for at least one year prior to competition.

Volleyballs spread out on court

This new nationwide regulation removes all previous accommodations, limiting participation exclusively to birth-certificate-designated categories. The change occurs alongside widespread policy adjustments throughout sports organizations. The University of Pennsylvania recently modified their athletics policies following extensive review, while at least 24 states have enacted legislation prohibiting transgender athletes from female scholastic sports.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: The Hidden Risks in Your Home Wi-Fi Network and How to Secure It
fields.summary: Many people assume password-protected home Wi-Fi networks are secure, but experts reveal how outdated routers, smart devices, and insufficient protection measures create vulnerabilities. Learn why traditional antivirus software isn't enough and how VPNs can provide essential encryption.
fields.content:
The false sense of Wi-Fi security

Most individuals operate under the mistaken belief that a password alone guarantees their home network's safety. As remote work expands and homes fill with smart devices like speakers and connected appliances, network vulnerabilities multiply. Despite increased dependence on these connections, few users regularly check their security settings or update protective measures.

Router vulnerabilities and risks

Standard-issue home routers frequently contain exploitable weaknesses out of the box. For example, a sophisticated 2025 attack compromising millions of routers globally suggested nation-state involvement. Security specialists emphasize critical steps: replacing default credentials regularly updating device firmware, and disabling remote administration features.

router on table

These adjustments can transform shallow security into robust protection against unauthorized access.

Limitations of conventional security tools

While antivirus software blocks known malware threats and firewalls manage network traffic, neither shields your internet connection itself. This gap leaves personal data exposed during transmission. Neither tool prevents Internet Service Providers from monitoring browsing activity nor protects against exploits targeting unsecured connections between devices and online services.

hacker

VPN protection explained

Virtual Private Networks create encrypted tunnels between devices and websites, hiding online activities from ISPs and hackers. The encryption prevents external monitoring of web browsing banking details or personal communications. It's important to note VPNs supplement rather than replace antivirus software and cannot prevent phishing scams or malware introduced through user error.

Selecting the right VPN service

Free VPN services often compromise privacy through data logging and selling user information. For genuine security choose VPNs with proven no-log policies, military-grade encryption and high-speed servers. Providers should support multiple devices under one account and operate under jurisdictions with strong privacy laws to prevent data leakage.

Essential security layering

Comprehensive protection requires combining VPN encryption with antivirus software, strong unique passwords and regularly updated firmware. Unsecured routers, ISP tracking and flawed IoT devices collectively jeopardize personal data. Implementing multiple defensive layers creates robust security where single solutions fall short.
