fields.title: Trump Golf Visit to Scotland Under Tight Security Amid Protests
fields.summary: Former US President Donald Trump's private golf outing at his Scottish resort has prompted heightened security operations and public protests. His visit includes meetings with UK leaders and coincides with a controversial government grant for his Aberdeenshire golf course.
fields.content:
Heightened security has enveloped South Ayrshire as former US President Donald Trump played golf at his Turnberry resort on the opening day of a private UK visit. Trump arrived at Prestwick Airport Friday evening before teeing off around 10:00 Saturday under a major protection operation.

While the golf outing proceeded without disruption, hundreds of demonstrators gathered in Edinburgh and Aberdeen condemning Trump's political positions. Protest signs referenced climate change concerns, the Gaza conflict, and an expletive slogan popularized by Scottish comedian Janey Godley.

Several hundred anti-Trump protesters with placards in Aberdeen - journalists at the right of the frame point cameras at the crowd

Anita Bhadani of the Stop Trump Coalition described Edinburgh's demonstration: "We are really excited... It's kind of like a carnival of resistance." Aberdeen protester Nicola Seal criticized the taxpayer-funded security costs: "We shouldn't be hosting him... It's costing vast amounts of taxpayers' money."

Trump will meet UK Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer and Scottish First Minister John Swinney in coming days while also opening a new golf course at his Aberdeenshire property. He praised Scottish leaders, saying it was "great to be in Scotland," though police unions expressed concern about resource strain from the security operation.

Journalists and spectators observed Trump's Friday arrival via a 25-vehicle motorcade following airport greetings from Scottish Secretary Ian Murray and US Ambassador Warren Stephens. Police sealed roads around Turnberry while military personnel conducted sweeps, with the resort remaining operational despite checkpoint installation.

PA Media Donald Trump, wearing a blue jumper and trousers and a white USA cap, takes a golf swing on the fairway as other group members watch next to golf buggies

EPA A number of people, mostly men, on a golf course with a number of golf buggies. President Donald Trump and his son Eric are in the centre of the shot

PA Media Donald Trump waves to onlookers from his golf buggy

PA Media Donald Trump leading a convoy of 15 other golf buggies

Trump played with his son Eric, Ambassador Stephens, and Stephens' son—a group trailed by 15 golf buggies. Despite £1,000 peak-season green fees, no protesters appeared on the course as Trump waved to photographers at the fourth tee. Donald Trump Jr also joined the family visit.

During Trump's round, the Scottish government announced £180,000 public funding for next month's 2025 Nexo Championship at his Aberdeenshire course. First Minister Swinney stated this support demonstrates Scotland's commitment to golf, but Scottish Greens co-leader Patrick Harvie likened it to "handing some pocket money to the school bully."

Reuters Journalists and photographers on a grassy hill at Turnberry

Trump meets European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen Sunday before talks with Swinney and Starmer Monday ahead of his Tuesday departure. At Prestwick, Trump urged Europe to "get your act together" on migration and "stop the windmills"—referencing his failed 2019 lawsuit against an offshore wind farm visible from his Aberdeenshire course.

PA Media Three men from left to right - Warren Stephens, US Ambassador to the UK, Scottish Secretary Ian Murray and US President Donald Trump. They are at an airport with what is likely Air Force One blurry in the background. All three are wearing suits.

Swinney will raise Gaza concerns during Monday's meeting while encouraging lawful protests. Incumbent US presidential visits remain rare in Scotland, with previous trips by Dwight Eisenhower in 1957, George W. Bush in 2005, and Joe Biden in 2021. Trump will return for an official state visit hosted by King Charles at Windsor Castle in September.

Reuters A line of military personnel and police sweep a stretch of grass outside the luxury Turnberry resort

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Thais and Cambodians Clash Online Amid Escalating Border Tensions
fields.summary: Deadly border skirmishes between Thailand and Cambodia have sparked intense online confrontations among citizens, with social media users trading accusations over territorial disputes, cultural heritage, and political rivalries, further inflaming tensions after more than a dozen fatalities last week.
fields.content:
Recent border clashes claimed over a dozen lives along the Thai-Cambodian frontier as governments struggled to avert a full-scale military confrontation. Nationalists from both nations quickly escalated hostilities on social media platforms, reigniting arguments about temple ownership, territories, and the origins of traditional dances, costumes, food, and sports.

Comment sections transformed into digital battlegrounds, with Thai and Cambodian users defending their governments' narratives. On TikTok, one Cambodian demanded "Justice for Cambodia," alleging Thai forces fired first. A Thai user retaliated by referencing Cambodia's reputation for scam operations: "[Who's] gonna trust [what] the largest scammer country said?" Similarly, Thai activists promoted the hashtag #CambodiaOpenedFire, while Cambodians countered with "Thailand opened fire."

Smoke rises from a structure, amid the clashes between Thailand and Cambodia, in Kantharalak district, Sisaket province, Thailand. Black smoke rises up into the blue sky. Other smaller structures can be seen in the foreground of the picture, which is a still from a video. A tarmac road runs alongside one side of the picture.

Border tensions flared in May after a skirmish killed one Cambodian soldier, prompting mutual travel bans and troop buildups. Journalists' associations from both countries issued a joint warning in May, criticizing users for circulating unverified information that "caused confusion" and urging restraint. Online hostility has spilled offline—a viral video showed a Thai man demanding Cambodian workers speak Khmer before physically assaulting one. Journalism professor Wilaiwan Jongwilaikasaem labeled the ensuing animosity a "war of hate," cautioning that violence was spreading beyond the conflict zones.

Getty Images Tourists posing for photos at Preah Vihear temple

Long cultural rivalry

Historical rivalries date back to border demarcations after French colonial rule and have intensified over cultural symbols. In 2008, Cambodia listed the Preah Vihear temple as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, sparking Thai protests. Similar conflicts arose this week over Cambodia's claims that Thai troops blocked access to the Ta Moan temple complex.

Map of Southeast Asia highlighting Thailand and Cambodia. Major cities of Bangkok and Phnom Penh are marked and three Thai provinces on the border with Cambodia - Sisaket, Surin and Ubon Ratchathani - are highlighted

Competing claims extend to sports, cuisine, and attire. Thai nationalists decry "Claimbodia" for cultural theft, while Cambodians dismiss them as "Siamese thieves." Disputes include Thai kickboxers boycotting Cambodia's 2023 Southeast Asian Games over naming conflicts and Cambodian UNESCO bids for Khmer wedding traditions this month, which Thai users accused of appropriating Thai designs.

A Thai soldier stands guard at the disputed ancient Khmer temple Prasat Ta Muen Thom, at a disputed area on the Thai-Cambodian border

Politicians' war on X

The feud worsened after the breakdown of a friendship between Cambodia's ex-leader Hun Sen and Thailand's former Prime Minister Thaksin Shinawatra. Thaksin stated on X: "I asked for some time because I have to let the Thai military teach Hun Sen a lesson for his cunningness." Hun Sen retorted: "I am not surprised by Thaksin's attitude... he is resorting to war, the ultimate consequence of which will be the suffering of the people."

Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra is surrounded by journalists after a cabinet meeting at Government House in Bangkok, Thailand, 01 July 2025. She wears a green suit, and the journalists are holding microphones, cameras and phones toward her.

The rift stems from Hun Sen leaking a private call with Thaksin's daughter, Paetongtarn Shinawatra, who referred to him as "uncle" and criticized a Thai military commander. This resulted in her suspension as prime minister and potential dismissal by Thailand's Constitutional Court. Despite Cambodia's ceasefire calls, social media battles persist, with one Thai user suggesting Hun Sen provoked conflict to consolidate political power in Cambodia.

Paweena Ninbut contributed to this report.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Salon Owner Braces for Key L'Oréal Trademark Clash
fields.summary: Leicester entrepreneur Rebecca Dowdeswell prepares for a decisive Intellectual Property Office hearing against cosmetics giant L'Oréal, which opposes her renewed 'nkd' trademark over potential confusion with Urban Decay's 'Naked' products, following a three-year dispute that has already cost £30,000.
fields.content:
Rebecca Dowdeswell declares she's "ready to fight again" as her prolonged trademark battle against global beauty conglomerate L'Oréal reaches a critical stage with a hearing finally scheduled this year. The Leicester-based salon owner faces opposition from the French corporation over her attempt to renew the 'nkd' trademark for her business.

L'Oréal officially challenged Dowdeswell's trademark renewal application in 2022, asserting its ownership of the 'Naked' brand under the Urban Decay line. The cosmetics firm contends that similarity between 'nkd' and 'Naked' could mislead consumers searching for its eye shadow palettes.

Dowdeswell, 49, maintains confidence as November's Intellectual Property Office hearing approaches. "I'm in a much stronger position now," she stated. The mother of two originally secured the 'nkd' trademark in 2009 but inadvertently let it lapse in 2019 during pandemic-related disruptions.

"That six-month renewal window collided with the start of Covid chaos, causing me to miss the deadline," Dowdeswell explained. Under trademark rules, this required beginning a new registration rather than extending the original. When she sought fresh registration post-lockdown, L'Oréal's opposition began.

Dowdeswell highlighted that in 15 years operating her Radcliffe-on-Trent business, "no customer ever asked if we are affiliated with Naked by Urban Decay," rejecting claims of marketplace confusion. Her staunch defense has cost over £30,000 across three years of proceedings.

nkd body scrub tube next to Urban Decay's Naked Reloaded eye shadow

The Intellectual Property Office postponed earlier hearing dates due to overwhelming caseloads exacerbated by Brexit. Following Britain's EU departure, approximately 1.4 million formerly EU-held trademarks transferred to the IPO registry, creating what officials termed "very significant" administrative pressures.

Despite the weight of legal proceedings, Dowdeswell welcomed a reprieve during the delay: "I've enjoyed metaphorically packing this case away for a while. Now I realize how heavy an emotional and professional toll it took on my family, children and business."

Rebecca Dowdeswell outside her nkd branded salon

L'Oréal responded via spokesperson: "We're committed to resolving any misunderstanding with Ms. Dowdeswell. From our initial communications with her legal counsel, we've proposed solutions supporting her business while upholding our trademark rights, and anticipate mutual resolution."

With the IPO confirming a concrete November 5 hearing date and decisions typically requiring nine months post-proceedings, Dowdeswell remains resolute. "I think L'Oréal assumes I'll withdraw," she observed. "They're wrong."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Condemns Hong Kong Cash Rewards for Activist Arrests
fields.summary: The United Kingdom has denounced Hong Kong authorities for offering cash bounties targeting pro-democracy activists residing in Britain, with senior UK ministers describing the initiative as "transnational repression" amid rising diplomatic tensions.
fields.content:
The UK government strongly criticized Hong Kong authorities for providing financial incentives to facilitate the arrest of pro-democracy activists living in Britain. Rewards ranging from $25,000 to $125,000 are offered for information leading to the capture of 19 individuals abroad.

Foreign Secretary David Lammy and Home Secretary Yvette Cooper jointly condemned the bounty system, labeling it "another example of transnational repression" in an official statement. China dismissed international criticism of its initiative as "interference," noting similar appeals had been issued three times before.

All individuals targeted face accusations of violating Beijing's national security law implemented in 2020 following widespread anti-government protests. Bounty amounts vary per activist, with Hong Kong police identifying Choi Ming-da and Fok Ka-chi—operators of the "Tuesdayroad" social media channel—among those with the highest rewards.

Former Hong Kong legislator Nathan Law and activist commentator Yuan Gong-Yi also appear on the wanted list. Previous bounty announcements in July and December 2023 targeted Law—who reported heightened danger to the BBC after being listed—and Simon Cheng, a former UK consulate employee detained in a 2019 case. A third wave focused on six activists in Britain and Canada including Tony Chung, ex-leader of a pro-independence group.

Approximately 150,000 Hong Kong residents have relocated to the UK since 2021 through the British National (Overseas) visa scheme, according to Home Office statistics. The pathway offers BNO passport holders and their dependents accelerated access to UK citizenship.

Originally created before Hong Kong's 1997 handover to China, the BNO status provided limited travel benefits without citizenship rights. Current visa holders become eligible for UK settlement after five years and citizenship following an additional year.

This development follows November's controversial Hong Kong court sentencing of dozens of pro-democracy figures for subversion. Responding to the bounty program, Cooper and Lammy affirmed: "This government will continue to stand with the people of Hong Kong, including those who have made the UK their home. We take the protection of their rights, freedoms, and safety very seriously."

They further stated: "The UK is committed to human rights, the rule of law, and the safety of all individuals in the UK. That's why we have removed Hong Kong from the Extradition Act 2003."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Medication Side Effects: Parkinson's Drugs Linked to Sexual Urges and Spying
fields.summary: A family shares how dopamine agonist medication prescribed for Parkinson's triggered extreme sexual urges and compulsive spying in their elderly father, with similar cases revealing broader concerns about inadequate patient warnings for these widely used drugs.
fields.content:
James's Hidden Obsession

When Sarah explored her father's attic during the COVID-19 pandemic, she uncovered disturbing evidence of his secret life. Her father, James, a retired Parkinson's patient, had filled the space with handwritten journals and recording devices monitoring his wife's every move. The previously modest man had become convinced she was having an affair, documenting innocent household sounds and compulsively using chat lines and porn sites. Sarah later learned her mother endured sexual coercion from James, whose personality transformed after years on Ropinirole medication.

During a medical appointment, a specialist nurse remarked: "Oh, he's gone down the randy route, has he?" acknowledging the drug's known side effects. The family now lives separately due to safety concerns, with James reportedly assaulting staff at his care facility. Sarah, who holds power of attorney for both parents, states: "This medication has torn my family apart."

Eight recording devices including phones and tablets.

Pattern of Dangerous Behavior

The BBC documented 50 similar cases involving dopamine agonists—drugs prescribed for Parkinson's and restless leg syndrome—where patients developed extreme compulsive behaviors. Reported incidents include a former headteacher accumulating indecent images of children, a detention officer soliciting sex workers while on duty, and a bus driver propositioning female colleagues. Notably, all subjects had no previous history of such actions before medication.

Some men intentionally continue treatment despite recognizing the drugs' effects, crediting the medication with enabling newly discovered consensual interests. Married patients pursued online relationships with strangers through chat lines, while others explored previously unexpressed sexuality or cross-dressing. Data shows withdrawal attempts proved difficult without compromising their underlying medical conditions.

Systemic Warnings Failure

Despite pharmaceutical company GSK discovering Ropinirole's links to "deviant" sexual behavior in 2003—including pedophilia—clear warnings didn't appear in medication leaflets until 2007. Current cautions about "altered" sexual interest and "increased" libido remain vague. Acting chair of the Health Select Committee Paulette Hamilton argues: "What does it mean by altered sexual interest? I haven't got a clue." She advocates for explicit safety notifications rather than relying on written inserts that few read.

Labour MP Paulette Hamilton wearing glasses and a black blazer.

Medication leaflet listing side effects including altered sexual behavior.

Broader Impact and Regulatory Stance

Dopamine agonists imitate dopamine's effects—regulating both movement and pleasure responses—but can overstimulate reward pathways and erode self-control. Ironically, they may worsen the conditions they treat via "augmentation," forcing dosage increases that intensify side effects. Controversy surrounds research on rival drug Rotigotine after claims of pharmaceutical company interference and conflicted authorship in studies minimizing its risks.

Nearly 1.5 million dopamine agonist prescriptions were issued in England last year alone, with 1.7 million more for the impulse-control-risking Aripiprazole (a partial dopamine agonist). Despite reports including compulsive gambling and indecent exposure, the UK's Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency maintains current warnings suffice. The Royal College of GPs will soon update training guidelines to include monitoring for these behavioral side effects, estimated to affect 6-17% of certain patients.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Record Mediterranean Heatwave Threatens Marine Ecosystems
fields.summary: An exceptionally early and intense marine heatwave gripping the Mediterranean Sea has alarmed scientists, with temperatures exceeding 30°C in late June – far above average and earlier than ever recorded. While holidaymakers might enjoy warmer water, this extreme event threatens marine life and may bring devastating consequences for fisheries and coastal communities.
fields.content:
Warmer Mediterranean waters might seem appealing for summer vacations, but an unprecedented marine heatwave has scientists warning of severe threats to ocean ecosystems. Late June saw sea temperatures surpass 30°C around Majorca and other areas, climbing six to seven degrees higher than normal seasonal averages.

Map displaying Mediterranean sea temperatures on July 6 with dark red zones marking areas over 30°C near Majorca and Italy, plus buoy data showing record June highs

Climate Change Connection

Temperatures above 30°C have previously occurred in late summer Mediterranean waters, but the early June arrival this year broke all recorded patterns. Marta Marcos, professor at Spain's University of the Balearic Islands, emphasized: "What is different this year is that 30°C sea temperatures have arrived much earlier, meaning a more intense and longer summer." Researchers link this trend to human-driven climate change, as ocean heatwaves globally have tripled in frequency over 80 years.

Map of marine heatwave intensity across Europe on July 6 showing severe conditions in western Mediterranean

Temperature anomaly map illustrating Mediterranean waters up to 6°C above average on June 30 with corresponding regional graph showing unprecedented warming

Environmental Vulnerability

The Mediterranean's enclosed geography makes it exceptionally sensitive to warming. Karina von Schuckmann of Mercator Ocean International noted that the basin functions as a "climate change hotspot," its limited water exchange causing rapid surface heating under calm conditions. While winds recently lowered peak temperatures slightly, researchers worry about prolonged thermal stress on marine species beyond their survival thresholds.

Ecological Consequences

Marine life faces multiple threats, including mass die-offs. Emma Cebrian, ecologist at Spain's Centre for Advanced Studies of Blanes, recalled finding "skeletons of many populations" after previous heatwaves. Critical ecosystems like carbon-storing seagrasses struggle under sustained heat, while fish may forgo reproduction to conserve energy. Dan Smale of the Marine Biological Association warned this could mean "losses of fisheries" affecting human communities.

Fish swimming over deep green seagrass meadow in Mediterranean waters

Extreme Weather Risks

The heatwave carries secondary dangers including intensified rainfall from increased evaporation, potentially causing devastating floods like those witnessed recently in Libya and Spain. Furthermore, reduced cooling effects from sea breezes may worsen future heatwaves on land. Marta Marcos cautioned: "I'm pretty sure that's going to be horrible," forecasting broader climatic impacts across the region due to ongoing marine temperature extremes.

Flood destruction scene with rubble, recovery vehicles, and workers cleaning up in high-visibility clothing

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Users Wrongly Accused by Instagram of Child Exploitation Violations
fields.summary: Multiple Instagram users report being falsely accused by Meta's AI systems of violating child exploitation policies, leading to account bans that caused significant emotional and financial distress before subsequent reversals following media intervention.
fields.content:
Instagram users have expressed experiencing "extreme stress" after receiving wrongful accusations of breaking child sexual exploitation rules, resulting in abrupt account suspensions. Three individuals confirmed to reporters that Meta permanently disabled their accounts only to reinstate them after journalistic inquiries. One affected user described the ordeal as horrible, citing lost sleep and isolation due to the serious nature of the accusations.

Over 100 individuals claim similar wrongful bans by Meta, with reports indicating financial losses for business account holders and irreversible deletion of personal memories. A petition criticizing Meta's AI-powered moderation system and flawed appeals process has gathered over 27,000 signatures, while thousands more discuss the issue on Reddit forums.

'Outrageous and vile'

David, a user from Scotland, had his Instagram, Facebook, and Messenger accounts suspended on June 4 for alleged child exploitation violations. After discovering a Reddit community of similarly affected users, he condemned Meta's automated responses as "an embarrassment" and highlighted the impact of losing over a decade of digital memories. His accounts were restored hours after journalists contacted Meta in July.

London-based student Faisal faced instant permanent suspension on June 6 while building a creative arts business through Instagram commissions. He emphasized the emotional toll and concerns about false accusations appearing in background checks. Faisal's accounts were reinstated five hours following media outreach, though he expressed lingering distress about the incident.

Another user, Salim, reported identical false accusations and criticized Meta's appeal process, noting accounts were reactivated nearly a week after his ban. All three individuals received standardized apologies from Meta acknowledging their wrongful suspensions.

What's gone wrong?

Meta declined to address specific cases or confirm systemic issues with child exploitation accusations despite evidence of similar wrongful bans in South Korea, where lawmakers confirm the company acknowledged potential errors. Researcher Dr. Carolina Are suggests unclear policy changes and ineffective appeal mechanisms may contribute to the problem, noting Meta's lack of transparency about algorithmic triggers.

Meta states it combines human oversight with technology to enforce policies, reporting detected content to US authorities. The company denies increased erroneous suspensions and maintains that child exploitation policies cover both real and non-real depictions, including AI-generated or fictional material. Meta also recently confirmed using technology to flag suspicious adult behaviors, such as repeated searches for harmful terms.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Gregg Wallace Denies Being a 'Groper' After MasterChef Exit
fields.summary: Former MasterChef host Gregg Wallace has apologized for offending people but denies being a 'groper, sex pest or flasher' after his dismissal from the show. Wallace and co-host John Torode were sacked following an investigation into misconduct allegations involving inappropriate behavior and racist remarks.
fields.content:
Television presenter Gregg Wallace has expressed remorse but strongly refuted allegations of sexual misconduct following his dismissal from MasterChef. In an interview, the former host insisted, "I'm not a groper, a sex pest or a flasher" while offering a general apology to anyone he hurt during his tenure on the popular cooking show.

Both Wallace and co-host John Torode were removed earlier this month after an independent investigation upheld multiple misconduct claims. The probe, ordered by production company Banijay, substantiated 45 allegations against Wallace including unwanted physical contact and inappropriate undress incidents. For Torode, one claim regarding the use of an "extremely offensive racist term" was confirmed.

Wallace acknowledged that his language had sometimes offended people, attributing it to his background as a greengrocer from Peckham where environments were "jovial and crude." He specifically addressed the widely reported incident of appearing semi-naked with a sock covering his genitals, explaining it occurred near friends without contestants present and caused no distress.

John Torode and Gregg Wallace on MasterChef

Autism defence and Torode controversy

Wallace's previous attempt to link his behavior to his autism diagnosis drew criticism from disability charities who stressed autism isn't a justification for misconduct. Speaking about his diagnosis, Wallace stated, "I know I struggle to read people. I know people find me weird. Autism is a disability," citing sensory hypersensitivity regarding his habit of not wearing underwear.

Addressing Torode's dismissal, Wallace defended his former colleague saying, "I've known John for 30 years and he is not a racist," pointing to the diversity of MasterChef winners as evidence. Despite this, Wallace admitted the pair never got along well, revealing he had unfollowed Torode and his wife on social media.

The BBC announced it will broadcast the upcoming MasterChef series recorded before the dismissals despite objections from some women who made allegations against Wallace. One claimant criticized the decision as showing a "blatant disregard for the people who have come forward." The broadcaster stated they made the choice after consultation with contestants and have not yet decided on airing completed celebrity editions.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Landmark FTC Firing Case Challenges Presidential Authority and Agency Independence
fields.summary: A legal battle over President Trump's dismissal of FTC commissioners may overturn a 90-year-old Supreme Court precedent limiting presidential removal power, with constitutional experts predicting the landmark Humphrey's Executor ruling could be reversed as the case advances toward the Supreme Court.
fields.content:
A significant legal confrontation is unfolding as FTC Commissioner Rebecca Slaughter contests her dismissal by President Trump, setting the stage for a potential Supreme Court review that could redefine presidential authority over independent agencies. The case directly questions the validity of the Humphrey's Executor ruling from 1935, which restricted a president's power to remove regulatory commissioners without cause. Biden-appointed Slaughter asserts her termination violated this established precedent.

John Shu, a constitutional law expert who served in both Bush administrations, predicts the Supreme Court will likely overturn or substantially weaken the Humphrey's Executor decision. He explained to media sources, "I think it's unlikely that Humphrey’s Executor survives the Supreme Court, at least in its current form," noting the FTC's powers have dramatically expanded since the 1930s ruling. Today's commission holds executive, quasi-legislative, and quasi-judicial authority including investigation powers and financial penalty imposition.

The Landmark Precedent Under Threat

The Humphrey's Executor case originated when President Franklin D. Roosevelt dismissed an FTC commissioner for political differences. The Supreme Court ruled this unlawful, establishing that presidents couldn't remove commissioners before their seven-year terms ended except for reasons like malfeasance. Shu emphasized, "The Federal Trade Commission of 1935 is a lot different than the Federal Trade Commission today," pointing to its broadened scope combating anticompetitive practices.

Supreme Court Chief Justice John Roberts

Recent signals suggest the high court is re-evaluating Humphrey's Executor. A previous 6-3 Supreme Court ruling emphasized that presidents "may remove without cause executive officers" who wield considerable power, though it didn't explicitly address the 1935 decision. Legal observers view these developments as incremental steps toward potentially reversing the long-standing limitation on presidential removal authority.

Ongoing Legal Conflict

The current lawsuit stems from Trump dismissing Slaughter and fellow Democratic appointee Alvaro Bedoya in March without stated cause. Their termination letter closely resembled Roosevelt's note from nine decades prior. Though Bedoya has since resigned, Slaughter continues her legal challenge, maintaining that independent agencies exist to ensure "transparency and accountability" insulated from presidential politics. She recently stated she'll "continue to fight my illegal firing" to preserve this institutional independence.

FTC Commissioner Rebecca Slaughter testifying

In a preliminary ruling, U.S. District Judge Loren AliKhan found Slaughter's case nearly identical to Humphrey's situation, declaring courts shouldn't question Supreme Court decisions regardless of their age. Following an appeal from Trump's administration, an appellate court paused this ruling. A three-judge panel—comprising two Obama appointees and one Trump appointee—is now reviewing whether to extend the pause, with filings submitted by late July potentially leading to a decisive ruling shortly afterward.

This legal battle represents the most direct confrontation with the Humphrey's Executor precedent to date, and its outcome could fundamentally reshape the relationship between presidential authority and independent federal agencies in the U.S. government structure.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Hulk Hogan's 25 Surgeries Preceded Cardiac Arrest Death at 71
fields.summary: WWE legend Hulk Hogan underwent 25 surgeries in his final decade before dying at 71 from cardiac arrest, stemming partly from decades of wrestling's physical toll. The pop culture icon had back procedures, joint replacements, and spinal fusion surgery, with cardiologists explaining how these factors increase cardiac risks.
fields.content:
In a September 2024 interview on the "IMPAULSIVE" podcast, wrestling superstar Hulk Hogan revealed he'd undergone 25 surgical procedures over the preceding decade. These included 10 back operations, multiple shoulder surgeries, and knee and hip replacements on both sides.

Hogan blamed part of his chronic pain on wrestling rings from the 1970s era, describing them as hazardous 22-foot structures with "lumps" and "boards sticking up" that damaged his body. "It was horrible," he stated. "Jumping up and dropping the damn leg for 40 years—with the largest arms in the world—I should’ve been using ‘The Sleeper.’ I probably should’ve quit earlier, but I just loved doing it—and the money was just crazy."

hulk hogan flexes his muscles

Earlier in July 2025, Hogan's wife Sky Daily denied online rumors about the wrestler being in a coma. She clarified he was actually recovering from a "major four-level anterior cervical discectomy and fusion (ACDF)," describing it as complex with a lengthy healing process.

Years of physical strain

Medical experts connected Hogan's extensive surgeries to his ultimate cause of death—cardiac arrest. Physicians noted his health struggles included admitted steroid use during the 1990s, multiple joint replacements, back surgeries, and spinal fusions. This culminated in a fatal cardiac event.

A University of East Michigan study highlights wrestlers aged 45-54 as three times more likely than the general population to die prematurely. Dr. Marc Siegel noted this risk significantly increases with age, adding "Many of these men didn’t even make it to their 70s." Hogan testified under oath in 1994 during then-WWF Chairman Vince McMahon's trial that he used steroids "for over a decade."

Hulk Hogan and Karl Malone

What happens during cardiac arrest?

Cardiologists explained Hogan reportedly showed good health before collapsing suddenly. Dr. Brittany Serwer identified this as characteristic of "heart attack with sudden cardiac arrest," typically caused by oxygen-deprivation to the heart muscle.

"Ischemic heart disease causes muscle death, making the heart vulnerable to dangerous rhythms like ventricular fibrillation," she stated. Vfib involves erratic electrical signals that trigger ineffective quivering instead of pumping. Serwer emphasized that cardiac arrests outside hospitals have a survival rate around 10% without treatment.

Man holding chest

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ancient Hawaiian Petroglyphs Reappear on Oahu Beach After Years
fields.summary: Ancient Hawaiian petroglyphs known as kiʻi pōhaku have resurfaced on Oahu's shoreline after years of being hidden, with seasonal ocean swells and shifting sands revealing 500-year-old carvings of human figures, canoes, and turtles for tourists and locals to witness.
fields.content:
Ancient Carvings Reemerge

Seasonal ocean patterns have uncovered 500-year-old petroglyphs along Oahu's beaches for the first time in years, making the ancient Hawaiian carvings visible again. Tourists and residents can now observe these historic rock engravings, locally called kiʻi pōhaku, which had remained hidden beneath sand and water.

Ancient Hawaiian petroglyphs on a beach are visible again with changing tides and shifting sands

While researchers haven't confirmed the exact meaning of the etchings, theories suggest they may document births or commemorate significant events. The carvings feature distinctive stick-like human forms alongside images of canoes, turtles, and various symbolic objects.

Ancient Hawaiian petroglyphs on a beach are visible again with changing tides and shifting sands

These petroglyphs appear at multiple locations across Hawaii's islands. Oahu, where the carvings have resurfaced, hosts the state capital Honolulu and ranks as Hawaii's third-largest and most populated island.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Historic MLB Showdown: Braves vs. Reds at Transformed Bristol Speedway
fields.summary: Bristol Motor Speedway prepares to host an unprecedented MLB game between the Atlanta Braves and Cincinnati Reds on August 2, with the iconic racing venue transformed into a baseball stadium expected to break attendance records and offer unique fan experiences.
fields.content:
Record-Breaking Anticipation at Bristol

The transformation of Bristol Motor Speedway into a baseball stadium promises to astonish attendees, as previewed during site tours. For years in the making, this Major League Baseball event represents a landmark collaboration between speedway officials and MLB organizers, showcasing extraordinary construction achievements. Though Bristol previously hosted the famed 'Battle at Bristol' football clash, the current baseball configuration pushes creative boundaries further.

Meticulous preparation ensures excellent sightlines throughout the venue, with crews working tirelessly to perfect the playing field. The innovative setup features indoor batting cages, an outdoor bullpen, and imaginative spectator zones, marking one of the most ambitious sports events in recent history. Speedway president Jerry Caldwell spearheaded the project after MLB expressed interest following Bristol's successful college football experiment.

Bristol Motor Speedway prepares to host first National League game on August 2.

With turf installation complete and temporary seating nearing readiness, officials anticipate historic attendance numbers, though exact figures remain undisclosed.

Unparalleled Fan Experience

Beyond the diamond action, August 2 offers diverse activities including tailgate festivities outside the venue before gates open. Infield concerts begin at 6 PM alongside team warm-ups, creating a festival atmosphere. Outfield spectators gain unique opportunities to catch home run balls, as the unconventional layout eliminates traditional outfield fencing. Significant investment created expansive clubhouses and practice facilities for players.

Broadcast partner FOX will incorporate special production elements for television viewers, details of which remain confidential. Fans can follow real-time updates through OutKick platforms during this groundbreaking sporting spectacle.

fields.title: Beware: How Fake Microsoft Alerts Lure You Into Phishing Traps
fields.summary: Deceptive emails impersonating Microsoft security alerts are tricking users into revealing login credentials through sophisticated phishing schemes that exploit trusted platforms.
fields.content:
Fake Microsoft security alerts delivered via email manipulate recipients into surrendering account passwords, posing significant risks to personal data. Understanding these scams is essential for protecting digital identities from compromise.

How the fake Microsoft alert scam works

Attackers embed fraudulent links in emails that initially lead to legitimate platforms like Google Docs or SharePoint before secretly redirecting to counterfeit Microsoft login pages. This multi-step deception makes the scam particularly convincing, especially when combined with manipulated support contact information that directs victims to scam call centers.

malicious redirection diagram

Key warning signs of a fake Microsoft alert

Phishing attempts can appear strikingly authentic, but identifiable red flags include unexpected security warnings demanding immediate action, mismatched sender addresses, and suspicious URLs in email links. Vigilance remains critical when reviewing unsolicited communications.

phishing indicators illustration

The sophisticated design of fake Microsoft alerts necessitates constant caution. Users should verify messages through official channels, avoid clicking questionable links, and report suspicious activity immediately. These security practices can effectively safeguard accounts against credential theft.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Controversial Auction of Tutankhamun-Era Artifact Raises Provenance Concerns
fields.summary: Apollo Art Auctions in London plans to sell a 3,000-year-old grasshopper-shaped artifact allegedly linked to Tutankhamun's tomb despite expert claims it was illicitly removed by archaeologist Howard Carter. The ivory-and-wood cosmetic vessel, valued at £300,000-£500,000, has sparked debates about ethical ownership and artifact repatriation to Egypt.
fields.content:
A carved grasshopper artifact from ancient Egypt's Tutankhamun era is slated for auction in London, stirring controversy among Egyptologists who suspect it was stolen from the pharaoh's tomb. Apollo Art Auctions intends to sell the ivory-and-wood cosmetic container on July with estimates reaching £300,000-£500,000 ($400,000-$675,000).

Contested History

Experts contend British archaeologist Howard Carter, who discovered Tutankhamun's tomb in 1922, may have illicitly appropriated the artifact. Carter spent years cataloging thousands of tomb artifacts, with allegations indicating some entered his personal collection. The auction house asserts the piece underwent Art Loss Register verification and includes provenance documentation.

Object Details and Ownership Trail

Dubbed the 'Guennol Grasshopper', the artifact features ivory upper wings with checkerboard patterns, wooden lower wings, and black inset eyes. Its cavity was designed for kohl or perfume storage. Auction records note previous ownership by collector Joseph Brummer, the Guennol Collection, and the Merrin Gallery since 2007, with exhibition history at Brooklyn Museum (1948-2002) and Met (1969). The Guennol Collection held by philanthropists Alastair and Edith Martin yielded a record-breaking $57.1 million sale for a 5,000-year-old lioness sculpture in 2007.

Expert Disputes and Legal Ambiguity

Christian Loeben, curator at Germany's Museum August Kestner, argues stylistic elements and pristine condition indicate origins in Tutankhamun's sealed tomb: "I'm quite convinced... it existed in exactly the period of the pharaoh's reign." Apollo counters that "no documented evidence" ties it to the tomb, noting its absence from excavation inventories. Art Loss Register's James Ratcliffe acknowledged the artifact occupies "an awkward area" since Egypt hasn't officially claimed it.

Repatriation Debates

Former Met director Thomas Hoving linked the piece to Tutankhamun's tomb in his 1978 book. This sale follows patterns of reparation, including Carter's posthumously returned artifacts and the Met's 2010 return of 19 tomb-originating items. Loeben insists on ethical restitution: "It's a moral question." Egypt has yet to file a formal claim for the grasshopper despite expert appeals.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: England's Lionesses and Their Unseen Supporters: The Team Behind the Team
fields.summary: As England's women's football team competes in the Euro 2025 final, family and friends share emotional insights about their vital off-field support during the tournament's rollercoaster journey in Switzerland.
fields.content:
The inner circle of England's women's football team recently gathered in Switzerland for a group outing, demonstrating the powerful bonds formed among players' families and friends throughout the Euro 2025 tournament.

While supporters witnessed England's dramatic progression through five matches over three weeks, the experience proved even more intense for loved ones in the stands who lived every heart-stopping moment. As the Lionesses prepare for their championship match against Spain, family members reflect on their emotional journeys and offer heartfelt messages to the players.

'Every goal she scores, he's watching over her'

Ella Toone and Michelle Agyemang

The tournament held profound significance for forwards Ella Toone and Beth Mead, both competing following heartbreaking family losses. Toone's father passed away in September 2024 after battling prostate cancer, while Mead's mother died of ovarian cancer in January 2023.

"Nick would've loved this," shared Toone's partner Joe Bunney, speaking about her late father. "The inspiration Nick gave us to support Ella was incredible. Every goal, every match - he's watching over her. Having Beth nearby helps tremendously as they support each other through similar experiences."

Bunney described unforgettable celebrations like the pandemonium following Michelle Agyemang's 96th-minute equalizer against Italy. His message to Toone: "I know your dad watches proudly as we cheer you on. Bring that trophy home."

'Our job is to give them that normality'

Lucy Bronze with her niece and nephew

Defender Lucy Bronze, competing in her seventh major tournament for England, engaged in late-night hide-and-seek with her young niece and nephew after crucial matches. Her brother Jorge described the emotional rollercoaster families endured: "Brilliant but exhausting - trauma after trauma after trauma."

He noted Coach Sarina Wiegman has deliberately involved the extended support network: "Our role is to provide normality. Whether sharing a half-eaten cheese sandwich or smashing her at Mario Kart - we help her unwind." His message to Bronze emphasized her winning legacy: "You're already England's most decorated player. Now cap it with a championship."

'I'm not used to this as a fan'

Alessia Russo

Striker Alessia Russo's brother Giorgio joined supporters after appearing on reality television. He admitted adapting to tournament intensity proved challenging: "Watching family compete triggers completely different emotions than being a regular fan."

He shared scenes from tense moments: "Our mums couldn't even look during penalty shootouts." His heartfelt message read: "Keep making us proud every single day. I love you."

'We tried to just keep it normal and keep it real'

Georgia Stanway

Midfielder Georgia Stanway's brother John-Paul helped organize gatherings among the extended network. His primary mission: maintaining players' emotional equilibrium amid tournament pressure. Following England's semi-final victory, family members took players for a low-key Chinese meal to decompress.

"Our job was providing calmness and normality," he emphasized. His tribute to Stanway expressed gratitude: "Thank you for the memories and back-to-back finals. Less heart attacks next time though!"

The squad faces Spain in the Euro 2025 championship on Sunday, 27 July at Basel's St Jakob-Park stadium.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Israel Unveils Gaza Aid Measures Amid Starvation Criticisms
fields.summary: Israel has implemented new humanitarian measures including aid airdrops and tactical military pauses in Gaza following intense international criticism over starvation in the territory. The moves came after Britain, France and Germany jointly demanded immediate aid access, though questions remain about their effectiveness as casualties continue during aid distribution.
fields.content:
Under mounting global pressure regarding starvation conditions in Gaza, Israel's military has unveiled humanitarian measures including approved aid airdrops and temporary halts in combat operations. The Israel Defence Forces announced these steps would 'improve the humanitarian response' and counter accusations of causing deliberate starvation.

While Israel permitted its first aid drop alongside an Emirati mission, Hamas dismissed the measures as deceptive 'whitewashing'. Shortly after Israel's announcement of tactical pauses, an airstrike killed Wafaa Harara and her four children—Sara, Areej, Judy, and Iyad—near an aid distribution point.

European allies and UN agencies continue rejecting Israel's claims it bears no responsibility for Gaza's famine conditions. The measures appear partially aimed at addressing stern criticisms like the joint July 25 statement from Britain, France and Germany demanding Israel 'immediately lift restrictions on aid flow' to prevent starvation.

Since replacing Gaza's UN aid network with its 'Gaza Humanitarian Foundation' system, Israel alleges Hamas diverted relief supplies—charges the UN says remain unproven. Aid groups refuse to cooperate with what they call an 'inhumane and militarised' distribution model where over 1,000 Palestinians have reportedly been shot while seeking food. A retired US colonel claims he witnessed GHF and Israeli forces firing on civilians.

Mary Sheikh al-Eid's family comforted after her body arrived at Nasser Hospital in southern Gaza

Palestinians scramble for flour bags from an aid truck in northern Gaza

UN humanitarian coordinator Jonathan Whittall—who faces visa revocation after condemning 'weaponised hunger' in Gaza—described the current crisis as the worst ever. He insisted effective aid requires faster truck processing, safer movement corridors, and guarantees civilians won't be fired upon when approaching distribution sites.

The International Criminal Court maintains arrest warrants against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and former defense minister Yoav Gallant for alleged starvation tactics and crimes against humanity, accusations both deny.

Israeli footage showed nighttime air drops delivering flour, sugar and canned goods—an approach humanitarian professionals consider high-risk and inefficient. Each aircraft holds less than a small truck convoy, with pallets often missing targets or sparking deadly scrambles among desperate civilians.

An Israeli soldier standing by aid parcels in Gaza

Two women seeking food at a charity kitchen in Nuseirat refugee camp

Risks of Desperate Measures

Historical precedents reveal the dangers of aerial aid delivery. During Iraq's 1991 humanitarian crisis, parachuted supplies landed in minefields, causing deaths among those retrieving them, while in besieged Bosnia heavy pallets crushed shelters after smashing through roofs.

Experts emphasize airdrops only when all land access fails—unlike Gaza where alternatives exist via nearby Ashdod port or Jordanian routes. With two million Gazans now compressed into just 17% of the territory—roughly Philadelphia's footprint—in densely packed tent camps, parachute landings carry severe injury risks and enable profiteering amid chaos.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Why Many Workers Are Opting Out of Pension Savings
fields.summary: Nearly half of working-age UK adults aren't contributing to private or workplace pensions, with self-employed individuals, low earners, women, and ethnic minorities most affected. This report explores the daily financial realities forcing people to prioritize immediate needs over retirement savings.
fields.content:
Recent government data shows almost 50% of UK working-age adults have no private or workplace pension. The self-employed, low-income workers, women, and individuals of Pakistani or Bangladeshi descent show particularly low participation rates, with only one in four from these backgrounds having pension plans.

Mohaimen, 29, exemplifies this trend. The London-based hospitality worker previously stopped paying into an auto-enrolled pension during university, explaining: "I'm more worried about surviving day-to-day than the future." Originally from Bangladesh, he stated: "Even with a good job, I'd prioritize saving £30-50k for a house deposit over pension contributions. That feels more urgent right now."

'I need to cover daily expenses first'

Self-employed stylist Saira Amir, 46, struggles to balance costs for her Norfolk household with three children. She receives universal credit, which barely covers groceries and bus fares to client appointments. "Being self-employed is risky," she admits while aspiring to open her own salon. Although previous generations in her Pakistani family relied on children for retirement support, Saira doesn't expect this: "I don't know my children's mindset."

Saira Amir wearing gold earrings, Indian clothing, pink lipstick and looking at the camera. She is standing at street level, outside, with houses and one car behind her.

State pension realities

Those without private plans often depend solely on the state pension, requiring 35 qualifying National Insurance years. The 2025/26 state pension provides £230.25 weekly (£11,973/year), but the Pensions and Lifetime Savings Association estimates a single retiree needs £13,400 annually for minimum living standards, £31,700 for moderate comfort, and £43,900 for a comfortable lifestyle.

How auto-enrolment works

UK employers must enroll eligible workers (aged 22-66 earning £10,000+ annually) into workplace pensions. Employees contribute 5% of earnings above £6,240 yearly, with employers adding 3%. Since its 2012 introduction, the scheme has seen low opt-out rates. Participants receive tax relief - basic rate taxpayers get 20% relief (£100 pension contribution costs £80), while higher-rate taxpayers receive 40% relief (£100 costs £60).

'I wish I'd started sooner'

Victoria Olsena, 38, represents the minority who do prioritize pensions. The AI marketing consultant earning £50,000 annually contributes to both a pension and ISA, stating: "People should realize the future will be terrible without preparation." Helen Morrissey of Hargreaves Lansdown emphasizes the power of early contributions: "That long-term drip-feed builds value. Starting late makes catching up extremely difficult - retirement seems distant, but early action is crucial."

Victoria Olsena looking straight at the camera in business attire of a bright peach blazer, with dark shoulder length hair, wearing red lipstick and a gold chain.

Additional reporting by Connie Bowker and Kevin Peachey.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump Arrives in Scotland for Four-Day Visit Focused on Golf and Diplomacy
fields.summary: Donald Trump has landed in Scotland for a private four-day stay where he will visit his golf resorts, meet UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer and Scottish First Minister John Swinney, and participate in transatlantic discussions while criticizing European renewable energy policies.
fields.content:
Former US President Donald Trump declared it 'great to be in Scotland' upon landing at Prestwick Airport to begin a four-day private visit. His arrival just before 8:30 pm was met by Scottish Secretary Ian Murray and US Ambassador Warren Stephens.

Crowd observing Air Force One landing at Prestwick Airport

Trump expressed admiration for UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer, calling him a 'good man' who secured a crucial trade deal delayed for over a decade. He also spoke highly of Scottish First Minister John Swinney, whom he will meet during the visit. Swinney has pledged to represent Scottish interests during their conversation.

Following arrival, a motorcade of two dozen vehicles transported Trump to his Turnberry resort in South Ayrshire, passing a small protest group. The former president plans to golf at Turnberry before traveling to Aberdeenshire to inaugurate a new golf course at his Menie estate. Trump credited late actor Sean Connery for helping secure permits: 'If it weren't for Sean Connery, we wouldn't have those great courses.'

Presidential motorcade traveling with police escort

Trump playing golf at Turnberry during previous visit

Trump will meet with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen on Sunday to discuss transatlantic trade, and hold separate talks with Starmer and Swinney on Monday before departing Tuesday. His itinerary included criticism of European policies, stating: 'Stop the windmills – they're ruining your countries and killing your birds. On illegal migration, you'd better get your act together or you're not going to have Europe anymore.' This referenced his failed 2019 legal effort to block a North Sea wind farm near his Aberdeenshire course.

Map of Trump's Scottish golf courses at Turnberry and Menie

Trump further characterized undocumented migration as an 'invasion killing Europe' while avoiding questions about Jeffrey Epstein documents, calling media coverage overblown. Solid security measures include road closures around Turnberry, police checkpoints and reinforcements from UK-wide forces through mutual aid.

Police checkpoint near Turnberry resort

Mounted officers patrolling near Turnberry

Scheduled protests in Edinburgh and Aberdeen highlight the unusual nature of the trip – only Eisenhower (1957), George W. Bush (2005), and Biden (2021) previously visited Scotland while serving as US presidents. Trump's Scottish connections include his late Gaelic-speaking mother Mary Anne MacLeod, born on the Isle of Lewis, who immigrated to America during the Great Depression.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Assessing Radiation Risks from Bombing Iran's Nuclear Sites
fields.summary: Following airstrikes on Iran's key nuclear facilities at Fordo, Natanz, and Isfahan, experts analyze potential radiation hazards. While initial reports show no increased off-site radioactivity, scientists warn of localized contamination risks from dispersed uranium particles and chemical threats.
fields.content:
US military aircraft targeted three critical nuclear installations in Iran, duplicating previous Israeli strikes during ongoing regional tensions. The strikes focused on the deep-underground Fordo enrichment site plus critical plants at Natanz and Isfahan, all vital to Iran's nuclear program. Damage assessments remain underway, but the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) confirmed no detectable radiation increase outside facility boundaries so far.

The United Nations nuclear watchdog labeled the attacks "deeply concerning," with Director General Rafael Grossi warning that military escalation heightens the potential for dangerous radiological releases affecting people and the environment. Enrichment facilities produce concentrated uranium-235 isotopes essential for nuclear reactions.

A satellite-style map shows a mountainous area with labeled features including 'Entrances to underground complex,' 'Security checkpoint,' and a red box noting Fordo's depth as 262-295 feet below ground. An inset map marks its location in Iran.

Burst of energy

Uranium enrichment increases concentrations of fissile uranium-235 by spinning gaseous uranium in centrifuges. Since uranium-238 is heavier, repeated separation cycles boost enrichment levels. Nuclear reactors need just 3-5% enrichment for energy production. Weapons-grade material requires 90% uranium-235 to create massive energy bursts when atoms split.

Graphic explaining uranium enrichment levels: 60% for potential weapons use; 20% for research reactors; 3-5% for power plants.

IAEA reported Iran achieved 60% enrichment - progressing toward weapons-capable thresholds. Experts differ from nuclear reactor disasters like Chernobyl. Professor Jim Smith clarified that striking uranium stockpiles won't cause catastrophic fission-chain reactions. The main hazard comes from dispersal. "Enriched uranium is three times more radioactive than natural uranium, but neither poses major contamination issues compared to fission products," Smith stated.

Localised threat

IAEA verified unchanged off-site radiation levels after latest explosions. IAEA identified localized radioactive contamination at Natanz from previous attacks but found normal background radiation elsewhere. Professor Claire Corkhill explained dispersed uranium particles could harm nearby residents: "Breathing or ingesting uranium lodges particles that decay inside the body, causing cellular damage."

Map noting key Iranian nuclear sites including Fordo, Natanz, Isfahan, uranium mines and power reactors.

Additional dangers exist from uranium hexafluoride gas in centrifuges. Professor Simon Middleburgh warned: "Contact with moisture converts it into a strong acid - causing severe chemical incidents, though impacts remain extremely localized." IAEA's emergency teams continue monitoring radiation levels while analyzing ongoing risks.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: EE fixes network outage amid customer frustration and broader telecom concerns
fields.summary: EE has resolved a technical fault that disrupted voice services for customers across multiple days, with some users still reporting issues despite overnight repairs. The outage prevented call connections on both mobile and landline services, causing significant inconvenience and highlighting broader concerns over telecom infrastructure changes including phone box removals and job insecurity.
fields.content:
EE implemented overnight maintenance to resolve a technical fault that prevented customers from making or receiving calls. This followed hundreds of service disruption reports over 24 hours, compounding earlier network issues earlier in the week that affected thousands of landline and mobile users.

On Saturday, a spokesperson for BT—EE's parent company—stated the network was "running as normal" but confirmed continued monitoring. However, customers continued reporting unresolved problems. One 84-year-old user described being unable to make "vital" daily family calls, while an Essex resident called three days without service "unacceptable," criticizing the "deafening" lack of information.

An Exeter-based estate agent confirmed multiple business offices faced ongoing call-making difficulties. The outage earlier prevented emergency 999 calls, with BT apologizing on Thursday for the "technical fault impacting voice services." EE's Saturday statement added: "We continue to conduct enhanced monitoring to prevent recurrence."

Broader infrastructure challenges

A fading red telephone box at night with the light on. It illuminates the grassy hill and trees behind slightly. The kiosk has large panes of glass on three sides rather than the usual smaller panes

Rare K8 phone boxes, with fewer than 50 remaining across the UK, are part of broader telecom shifts sparking local concerns.

A traditional red phone box next to a busy car park with cars, vans, a motorhome and a coach.

BT faces opposition to its plan to close over 90 phone boxes in North Yorkshire, where the council rejected the proposal.

Alice Bondi is sitting on an ornately carved chair wearing glasses with black strings. She is wearing a beige top and jacket and has grey hair.

Rural Cumbria communities worry about analogue landline removal despite the technology's reliability during power cuts.

66-year-old Nigel Charlton in front of a white phone box, with cash machine stickers on it. Nigel has rosy cheeks and is looking into the camera, wearing thin-framed grey glasses with clear lenses, a purple t-shirt and a white panama hat with a black ribbon around it. His right arm is raised.

BT also proposes eliminating phone facilities in Kirton in Lindsey and Barrow upon Humber.

Shows a woman with fair hair in a white flowery short-sleeved shirt

Separately, a trade union alleged BT failed to consult staff before placing 140 Londonderry jobs at risk.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Drake Postpones Manchester Gig Citing Travel Logistics
fields.summary: Rapper Drake has canceled his scheduled Manchester performance at Co-op Live arena due to unforeseen travel complications, rescheduling the show for August 5. Ticket holders expressed frustration over the last-minute change while organizers confirmed existing tickets remain valid.
fields.content:
Drake's Monday concert in Manchester has been abruptly postponed because of unexpected travel disruptions, according to an announcement from Co-op Live arena organizers. The Canadian artist's performance is now slated for August 5 at the same venue.

All tickets purchased for the original date remain valid for the rescheduled event. The rapper successfully completed two Manchester shows earlier this weekend and is still scheduled to perform there on August 4 as part of his global tour.

In an official statement posted online, the venue explained: "Due to unforeseen ferry schedule and travel logistics, tomorrow's performance in Manchester on July 28th has been rescheduled." The message continued optimistically: "Drake will now perform in Manchester on Tuesday, August 5th, and it's set to be an unforgettable night."

Fan Disappointment

News of the postponement triggered widespread disappointment among ticket holders who criticized the short notice. One supporter tweeted: "Extended my unpaid leave in Dubai to stay in Manchester so I could see Drake on 28th July just for him to cancel last minute."

Another concert-goer dismissed the explanation as a "lame excuse of travel logistics," reflecting growing frustration among the audience. The cancellation follows Drake's recent release of his single "Which One" featuring UK rapper Central Cee, premiered last Thursday during his Iceman livestream filmed across Manchester.

This tour marks Drake's first European concert series in six years, including multiple UK dates scheduled throughout summer.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Wildfires Ravage Turkey: 1,700 Evacuated, Firefighter Dead Amid Record Heat
fields.summary: Turkey battles unprecedented wildfires as 1,700 people are evacuated and a firefighter dies amid record temperatures reaching 122.9°F. Over 84 blazes rage nationwide, spreading to neighboring countries and prompting international firefighting assistance.
fields.content:
Turkey is facing a devastating wildfire crisis with 84 separate blazes recorded across the country on Saturday alone, as announced by Forestry Minister Ibrahim Yumakli. The northwest region remains at highest risk, including the Karabuk area where fires have been burning since Tuesday.

The General Directorate of Meteorology confirmed Turkey reached its highest-ever recorded temperature of 122.9 degrees Fahrenheit (50.5°C) in Sirnak province on Friday. This extreme heat has fueled the rapid spread of flames nationwide.

Fourteen people have perished in recent fire-related incidents, including ten rescue volunteers and forestry workers killed during a firefighting operation in Eskisehir last Wednesday. The death toll includes frontline responders battling the infernos.

Funeral services for victims

Justice Minister Yilmaz Tunc revealed investigations have been launched into fires across 33 provinces since June 26. Prosecutors have taken legal action against 97 suspects in connection with the blazes, though specific charges weren't detailed.

Mourners at funeral

The fires have grown so intense they now threaten to cross international borders into Greece and Bulgaria. Bulgarian authorities led by National Fire Service chief Alexander Djartov have requested emergency assistance from European Union partners.

Aircraft from five nations – the Czech Republic, Slovakia, France, Hungary, and Sweden – are expected to arrive Sunday to bolster firefighting efforts. This multinational response highlights the cross-border nature of the escalating disaster.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: White House Orders Pentagon to Halt Leak Investigation Polygraphs
fields.summary: The White House intervened to stop Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth's administration of polygraph tests to Pentagon staff suspected of leaking classified information, following an adviser's warning about impending examinations.
fields.content:
The White House instructed Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth to halt polygraph examinations targeting Pentagon personnel under suspicion of leaking sensitive information. This directive came after presidential adviser Patrick Weaver informed senior officials he faced imminent polygraph testing, prompting immediate White House intervention.

The use of polygraphs to identify leakers became apparent in March

Joe Kasper, then serving as Hegseth's chief of staff, launched the Department of Defense leak probe through a late March memorandum. Kasper's March 21 memo cited "recent unauthorized disclosures of national security information involving sensitive communications" as demanding urgent investigation.

"The use of polygraphs in the execution of this investigation will be in accordance with applicable law and policy," Kasper explicitly stated. Neither the Pentagon nor White House provided comments to media inquiries when approached.

Pentagon

This revelation follows the Pentagon's earlier 'Signalgate' controversy, where confidential military strategy discussions involving Hegseth and senior officials were leaked despite occurring on encrypted messaging platforms. Then-national security advisor Michael Waltz claimed "full responsibility" for accidentally including Atlantic editor Jeffrey Goldberg in a Signal chat with Vice President JD Vance, Secretary of State Marco Rubio, CIA Director John Ratcliffe, and Hegseth.

The breach exposed planned U.S. missile strikes against Houthi targets in Yemen. Former President Donald Trump maintained strong public support for Hegseth in the aftermath of this security lapse.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Japanese Walking Trend May Boost Lifespan by 7 Years, Experts Reveal
fields.summary: A Japanese fitness technique involving alternating walking speeds for 30 minutes could extend life expectancy by up to seven years, according to health experts. The method combines brisk strolling with recovery periods to combat age-related health risks.
fields.content:
The Japanese walking trend, an exercise method gaining global attention, alternates between three minutes of fast walking and three minutes of slower recovery walking during a 30-minute session. Dr. Alexa Mieses Malchuk, a primary care physician from North Carolina, compared this approach to high-intensity interval training (HIIT) for its efficiency.

The Longevity Connection

Research indicates regular walking significantly impacts longevity, with fitness expert Jillian Michaels noting that 150 minutes weekly can extend lifespan by up to seven years. Performing Japanese walking for 30 minutes five days weekly meets this target.

Senior couple walking in park on path with trees in the background.

Scientific Basis and Applications

This technique, also known as Interval Walking Training (IWT), operates similarly to zone-based training by regulating the body's energy expenditure. Studies confirm its effectiveness against age-related health issues, though benefits for other diseases require further investigation.

Couple power-walking

Physical activity choices should prioritize safety and personal comfort according to fitness levels. "It doesn’t matter if you prefer HIIT, Japanese walking or something else — choose exercise that is appropriate for your level of fitness, and is comfortable and safe," researchers advise.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Giant Elon Musk Sculpture Sparks Debate Across US National Parks
fields.summary: An anonymous creator has revealed why they commissioned a 12-foot tall sculpture of Elon Musk touring US national parks with the slogan 'Make America Wait Again', intended to highlight staffing challenges and spark nonpartisan dialogue about park conservation.
fields.content:
An anonymous individual has come forward to explain the motivations behind a traveling art installation featuring a 12-foot sculpture of Elon Musk's head. The surreal artwork has been appearing across US national parks bearing a sign that reads "Make America Wait Again" - a playful reference to a well-known political slogan.

Describing himself as a private citizen with no organizational affiliations, the creator stated: "No organizations, no parties — just me and a few people who care." The project aims to draw attention to staffing reductions affecting park services.

Elon Musk statue in front of Arches National Park rock formations

National parks were specifically chosen because they represent "one of the few truly nonpartisan joys we have in this country," the creator emphasized. Mt. Rainier was selected due to its severe overcrowding during peak season, where parking shortages create significant delays.

Visitor reactions have varied dramatically at display sites. "People crowded around it, took photos, laughed, flipped it off, gave it thumbs-up," the creator noted, describing the polarized responses as "a good cross-section of America."

Elon Musk statue draws crowds at Yosemite National Park

Commissioned from a Michigan-based artist, the hyperrealistic sculpture was designed to be visually striking and easily shareable. Its signature feature is Musk's "very self-satisfied" smirk. Though bearing a politically inspired slogan, the creator asserts its purpose is conversation rather than partisanship.

Remaining anonymous allows the message to remain central, according to the backer. "Major things happen in our country... and we forget them because the news cycle spins so fast," they observed. "This is a loud, silly way to not forget."

Yosemite National Park welcome sign in California

Park rangers and staff were highlighted as symbolic of the issue. "Becoming a park ranger is something you do for the love, not for the money," the creator noted, stressing that staffing issues affect shared national treasures. When questioned about personal politics, the individual declined categorization into either major party.

Mount Rainier

Future installations will continue at undisclosed locations, with the mystery element preserved deliberately. "I can't tell you where next, but I'm happy to keep telling you in the right moment," the creator concluded, underscoring the ongoing nature of the campaign.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Cowboys QB Joe Milton Takes Subtle Jab at Patriots After Trade to Dallas
fields.summary: Quarterback Joe Milton made a subtle criticism of his former New England Patriots team while expressing enthusiasm for his offseason trade to the Dallas Cowboys, where he's expected to back up Dak Prescott.
fields.content:
Dallas Cowboys quarterback Joe Milton took a subtle swipe at his former New England Patriots teammates while embracing his offseason move to Texas, stating he "preferred" a fresh start with a new franchise. The quarterback transfer to Dallas occurred earlier this offseason.

Joe Milton looks on

Milton revealed he actively sought the transition. "That was something me and my team put together," he explained. "They were able to get it done, I really didn’t have to do much or say much. So just shout out to my agent, that’s pretty much it." The quarterback saw limited opportunities in New England, appearing in just one game throughout the entire 2024 season.

Joe Milton with the Patriots

Milton enters training camp projected as Prescott's primary backup, with Will Grier currently positioned as the third-string quarterback. Prescott's health remains a focal point for Dallas after the starter missed significant time last year, appearing in only eight games during the 2024 campaign.

Source: Original Article

Deidre from New York expresses a common frustration: "I donate to these charities every other month, yet I still get three to four mailings monthly. Despite my requests to stop, nothing changes." This situation demonstrates how good intentions like supporting causes or registering to vote can trigger relentless waves of unsolicited communications. fields.title: Summer Outdoor Gear Sale: Major Amazon Discounts After Prime Day
fields.summary: Significant outdoor gear discounts of up to 50% remain available on Amazon post-Prime Day, featuring deals on premium brands like Yeti, Coleman, Columbia, and Marmot for camping, hiking, and outdoor essentials.
fields.content:
Summer is now in full swing, providing opportunities for outdoor adventures. Despite Prime Day ending earlier this month, Amazon continues offering substantial discounts of nearly 50% on camping, hiking, and essential outdoor equipment from premium brands including Yeti, Gerber, Coleman, and Columbia.

Amazon may not be the foremost destination for all outdoor needs, yet the platform currently features remarkable price reductions on quality gear. Significant savings are visible across coolers, durable water bottles, dependable power stations, and versatile tents. Interested buyers need to act swiftly as these post-Prime Day discounts won't last much longer.

Amazon Outdoor Gear Deals

For backpacking enthusiasts, the Osprey Farpoint 40L Men's Travel Backpack maintains its Prime Day discount at 25% off. This durable, versatile backpack includes adjustable torso fit and exterior gear loops, available for under $150 temporarily. Yeti products also feature prominently, including the M15 Soft Cooler at 20% off and the acclaimed Yonder Water Bottle for $24—a lightweight, durable option previously named best overall water bottle.

These deals represent rare opportunities to acquire premium gear at near-Prime Day pricing as summer outdoor season peaks.

More Great Summer Sales

Additional seasonal promotions extend beyond Amazon, with noteworthy sales occurring at Huckberry, Filson, Amazon Warehouse, Lululemon, and Nordstrom during their Anniversary Sale event.

fields.title: Anish Kapoor Lists Tribeca Penthouse for $17.75 Million
fields.summary: Acclaimed artist Anish Kapoor has listed his Tribeca apartment at a sculptural Manhattan landmark for $17.75 million, featuring architectural distinction and luxury amenities designed by Herzog & de Meuron.
fields.content:
Renowned artist Anish Kapoor has placed his New York City penthouse in Tribeca on the market for $17.75 million, residing in the 57-story tower where his smaller Cloud Gate sculpture installation is featured at the building's base. This reflective piece echoes his iconic bean-shaped Cloud Gate sculpture in Chicago's Millennium Park.

Luxury Features

The 3,576-square-foot apartment occupies the 47th floor at 56 Leonard Street, configured with four bedrooms and four-and-a-half bathrooms. Highlights encompass 12-foot ceilings throughout, expansive windows, and a primary bedroom suite featuring a travertine marble bathroom with heated floors and a walk-in closet. Additional features include a private elevator entry, three outdoor terraces, a fireplace, and a chef's kitchen.

Building amenities available to residents encompass an indoor lap pool, sun deck, fitness center, private movie theater, communal lounge, dining room, and children's play area. The distinctive Jenga-inspired skyscraper, sculpted by Pritzker Prize-winning architects Herzog & de Meuron, stands as Tribeca's tallest structure.

Property History

This marks Kapoor's second attempt to sell this apartment; it was previously listed for approximately $18 million last year under a different brokerage. Records show the artist acquired the unit from the building's sponsor for $14 million in 2016. Serhant agents Krista Nickols and Martin Garcia currently handle the listing, though Kapoor's motivation for selling remains undisclosed.

This Tribeca listing follows Kapoor's sale of his London residence, one of that city's largest private homes, marketed for $26 million in 2021. That same year, the artist purchased an 18th-century Venetian palazzo to convert into a dedicated exhibition venue for his artworks.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Greece and Turkey Battle Raging Wildfires Amid Record Heat
fields.summary: Greece and Turkey are confronting severe wildfires during an unprecedented heatwave, with Greece fighting five major blazes amid temperatures expected to hit 44°C (111°F). Turkey recorded its highest-ever temperature of 50.5°C and faces fatalities and evacuations across multiple regions while requesting EU firefighting assistance.
