fields.content:
Greece is combating five major wildfires during an extreme heatwave, with temperatures forecast to reach 44°C on Sunday. Firefighters are focusing on significant blazes on the islands of Kythira and Evia after battling fires throughout the night. Fire brigade spokesman Vasilios Vathrakoyannis warned that Sunday remains "extremely dangerous" for potential new ignitions despite improving conditions.

Neighboring Turkey registered its hottest temperature ever when meteorologists recorded 50.5°C in the southeastern city of Silopi on Saturday. This surpassed the previous national high of 49.5°C. Forestry Minister Ibrahim Yumakli described affected areas as undergoing "risky times," estimating several more days before flames are contained.

Ten people perished battling a fire in Turkey's Eskisehir province earlier this week. Firefighters entered their fourth day of operations against a blaze in Karabuk province, with water restrictions imposed in western coastal resorts like Cesme. Greece has formally requested six firefighting aircraft from the EU Civil Protection Mechanism.

Greek Climate Crisis Minister Giannis Kefalogiannis reported injured firefighters, endangered lives, and widespread property and forest destruction. On Kythira, fires in Pitsinades village have affected approximately 20% of the island. New evacuations were ordered Sunday as helicopters and water-bombing planes supported ground crews through flare-ups at dawn.

On Evia island, an uncontrolled blaze near Pissona sent six firefighters to the hospital with burns and smoke inhalation while cutting power to villages. Strong winds still threaten reignition despite some improvement. A third fire erupted in Messinia's Polithea area, causing severe damage to homes and farmland.

Near Athens in Attica, a fire rapidly spread through Drosopigi, Kryoneri, and Agios Stefanos. Residents evacuated as smoke reached central Athens. Although the main firefront is contained, isolated hot spots persist. Crete's Chania region battles an active 20km wildfire front that destroyed beehives, crops, and livestock. Southwesterly winds blocked containment as several villages lost power.

Greece experienced earlier large-scale wildfires last month when Chios island lost 4,700 hectares of land. In July, Crete evacuated 5,000 tourists due to a separate blaze. Simultaneously, New York state authorities issued air quality alerts declaring conditions "unhealthy for sensitive groups" due to Canadian wildfire smoke over the weekend.

Smoke-shrouded sun rising over Manhattan skyline

In Cyprus, local authorities confirmed an elderly couple died during wildfires in Malia village, Limassol district. Search crews found their bodies in a burned home missing windows and roof, surrounded by debris. Details surrounding their deaths remain under investigation.

Destroyed home with debris after wildfire

Turkey's Eskisehir province experienced a fatal incident where shifting winds trapped forestry workers and rescuers amid flames earlier in the week. Dense plumes enveloped the forest region during rescue attempts, contributing to the casualties.

Thick smoke engulfing Turkish forest fire zone

Spain recorded wildfire destruction with Toledo authorities estimating damage to 2,500 hectares of land. Fire crews battled large-scale flames amid a challenging firefighting landscape.

Firefighting operations in Spain’s Toledo region

North American officials deployed ground and air resources across California and eastern Canada to contain numerous wildfires. Coastal views revealed vast smoke blankets rising over forested areas as crews intensified operations.

Forest fire smoke looming over coastline

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Aid Operations Intensify in Gaza Amid Israel's Humanitarian Pauses
fields.summary: Jordan and the UAE conducted humanitarian airdrops into Gaza as Israel initiated daily tactical pauses in military operations to address the territory's worsening crisis. Despite these measures, violence persisted near aid routes with casualties reported, while international organizations highlighted severe starvation risks among Gaza's population.
fields.content:
Jordan and the United Arab Emirates delivered critical aid to Gaza through coordinated airdrops on Sunday. Working together, their forces successfully parachuted 25 tonnes of essential supplies across three separate operations. Additional humanitarian convoys entered Gaza via Egypt, with another expected soon from Jordan.

EPA Humanitarian aid airdropped by the Royal Jordanian Army lands in the northern Gaza Strip. Silvery parachutes can be seen descending near several damaged buildings.

Israel announced a daily operational halt lasting 10 hours in specific Gaza areas to establish secure aid delivery corridors. The Israel Defense Forces stated these "tactical pauses" aimed to counteract allegations of intentionally restricting humanitarian access. The designated safe zones include Al-Mawasi, Deir al-Balah, and Gaza City, with pauses active between 10:00 and 20:00 local time until further notice.

Fresh reports of violence emerged despite the pause. Medical personnel confirmed nine fatalities and 54 injuries from Israeli gunfire near Salah al-Din Street in central Gaza. Crowds had gathered there anticipating United Nations aid convoys. Later, an airstrike struck Gaza City's Al-Rimal district shortly after the pause commenced. The IDF denied awareness of casualties or conducting strikes in verified locations.

Desperate scenes unfolded as Palestinians swarmed aid trucks distributing flour in northern Gaza. Humanitarian groups report Gaza faces catastrophic food shortages, with the UN World Food Programme stating one-third of residents endure days without eating. The Hamas-run health ministry documented over 100 malnutrition deaths recently, alongside hundreds killed at aid distribution points.

The Times front page shows the headline 'Gaza's suffering must stop, PM to tell Trump' as well as photographs of the British Lionesses, who are preparing for a match, and the Lions, who just beat Australia. The Observer's front page is devoted to a picture of Lionesses player Michelle Agyemang. She wears a black jacket with purple insignia, and listens to headphones. A bag is slung over one shoulder.

UK Foreign Secretary David Lammy emphasized that airdrops alone wouldn't resolve the crisis, stating: "Land routes remain the only viable solution for sustainable aid. These measures must be fully implemented with further barriers removed—the world is watching." UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk urged intensified international pressure to stop the fighting, citing "daily dehumanization of Palestinians."

Gaza residents expressed mixed reactions. Rasha Al-Sheikh Khalil, a mother in Gaza City, shared cautious hope but worried about future starvation. Neveen Saleh, another resident, reported her family hasn't consumed fresh produce in months. Journalist Imad Kudaya raised concerns that many airdrops land in high-risk demilitarized zones controlled by Israeli forces.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu pledged to continue military operations until achieving "complete victory," accusing the UN of misrepresenting aid constraints. Meanwhile, Sir Keir Starmer and former US President Donald Trump are scheduled to discuss Gaza during a meeting in Scotland. Concurrently, the Freedom Flotilla Coalition reported Israeli interception of its aid vessel bound for Gaza.

Mary Sheikh al-Eid's family is comforted after her body is brought to Nasser Hospital in Khan Younis, southern Gaza (24 July 2025)

The humanitarian crisis in Gaza follows Israel's military campaign launched after Hamas attacked southern Israel on October 7, 2023, which left approximately 1,200 Israelis dead. According to Gaza's health authorities, over 59,000 Palestinians have since been killed. Aid organizations repeatedly warn that aerial delivery methods endanger civilians in populated areas.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: FCC Approves $8 Billion Merger of Paramount and Skydance Media
fields.summary: The US Federal Communications Commission has approved Paramount Global's $8 billion merger with Skydance Media, clearing the final regulatory hurdle. The decision follows Paramount's $16 million settlement with former President Trump over a CBS interview and includes commitments to overhaul journalism standards at the combined company.
fields.content:
US regulators have approved Paramount Global's $8 billion (£5.9bn) merger with Skydance Media, marking the consolidation of one of Hollywood's oldest studios with an influential independent production company. The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) greenlit the deal after Paramount settled legal disputes involving former President Donald Trump.

Originally announced in 2024, the merger cleared its last major hurdle weeks after Paramount agreed to pay $16 million (£13.5m) to resolve Trump's lawsuit regarding a CBS interview with then-Vice President Kamala Harris. The settlement did not include any admission of wrongdoing or apology from Paramount.

FCC Chair Brendan Carr, a Trump appointee, announced the approval while stating that Skydance promised significant reforms for CBS journalism. Carr noted a widespread mistrust in national media, declaring: "Americans no longer trust the legacy national news media to report fully, accurately, and fairly. It is time for a change."

The merger includes Skydance's commitment to appoint an ombudsman to address bias complaints and eliminate diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives - mirroring Trump administration priorities. FCC commissioners approved broadcast license transfers for 28 CBS stations in a 2-1 vote, with Democrat Anna Gomez dissenting over concerns about political influence.

Gomez criticized Paramount's settlement approach, stating: "After months of cowardly capitulation to this administration, Paramount finally got what it wanted. Unfortunately, it is the American public who will ultimately pay the price for its actions."

The merger is scheduled to close on August 7, combining Paramount's century-old film library and networks including CBS, MTV and Nickelodeon with David Ellison's Skydance Media. Paramount has struggled financially in recent years despite owning franchises like Mission: Impossible and Star Trek.

Reports indicate the Trump settlement - with funds directed to a future presidential library rather than Trump personally - aimed to prevent White House interference in FCC merger review. Trump had alleged CBS intentionally misrepresented a Harris interview to influence elections.

The merger finalization follows CBS's recent announcement ending The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, though the network insists this financially motivated decision was unrelated to Colbert's Trump criticism.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UN Human Rights Chief Condemns UK Ban on Palestine Action
fields.summary: The UN Human Rights Chief has criticized the UK government's ban on Palestine Action as a misuse of counter-terrorism legislation, calling it disproportionate and in violation of international law. Volker Turk urged Britain to lift the ban, which carries penalties of up to 14 years in prison and has led to over 170 arrests.
fields.content:
UN Condemns Terrorism Law Application

The United Nations human rights chief has characterized the UK's ban on Palestine Action as a worrying misuse of counter-terrorism legislation. Volker Turk specifically urged authorities to revoke the measure, stating it appears disproportionate and unnecessary.

Earlier in July, the UK government formally designated Palestine Action as a terrorist organization under the Terrorism Act 2000. This decision followed activists claiming responsibility for spraying red paint on two military aircraft, causing an estimated £7 million in damages. The ban is currently under legal challenge in the High Court, with a ruling expected soon.

Membership or support for Palestine Action now constitutes a criminal offence carrying up to 14 years imprisonment. Over 170 individuals have been arrested using terrorism laws since the ban took effect.

Human Rights and Terrorism Definition

Turk emphasized that the prohibition unfairly limits rights like freedom of expression and peaceful assembly for those supporting Palestine Action without engaging in criminal acts. He asserted this violates the UK's obligations under international human rights law.

An aerial view of a Royal Air Force plane which has had red paint sprayed onto it.

The ban specifically targets activities like the RAF Brize Norton incident last month, where activists spray-painted military aircraft used for Israeli support missions. Security Minister Dan Jarvis clarified that while Palestinian solidarity protests remain legal, Palestine Action faces proscription due to criminal campaigns against defense infrastructure.

Turk also criticized the UK's broad terrorism definition covering serious property damage. He noted international standards confine terrorism to acts causing death, injury, or hostage-taking intended to intimidate populations or coerce governments.

Multiple prosecutions regarding Palestine Action activities are currently before courts. Four people charged in the Brize Norton case face trial next year.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Immunotherapy Trial Extends Life for Penile Cancer Patients
fields.summary: A groundbreaking clinical trial combining immunotherapy with chemotherapy has significantly extended the lives of advanced penile cancer patients, with the first participant crediting it for giving him two extra years. The UK-based EPIC study showed promising results for over 60% of participants.
fields.content:
An 83-year-old man who pioneered a clinical trial for penile cancer treatment believes the innovative approach gave him two additional years of life. Eddie Baker from South Gloucestershire underwent immunotherapy alongside standard chemotherapy as part of the EPIC study, conducted by University Hospitals Bristol and Weston NHS Foundation Trust.

Baker acknowledged that delayed medical attention impacted his prognosis after noticing symptoms for over a year. Recognizable signs include unusual bleeding, lumps, skin discoloration, or rashes. "The swelling grew progressively worse but I hesitated to seek help until it was too late," he explained, resulting in surgical amputation and incurable disease.

More than 60% of patients in the trial experienced significant clinical benefits despite having advanced cancer. Survival time extended to approximately 15 months on average among these patients—a meaningful advancement for the aggressive illness.

Consultant oncologist Professor Amit Bahl, leading the EPIC study, emphasized how social stigma causes critical treatment delays. "Unlike cervical or vaginal cancers, penile cancer remains taboo. Many patients aren't even aware it exists, so symptoms get ignored," he observed.

Professor Amit Bahl, UHBW consultant oncologist and chief investigator of the EPIC study

While immunotherapy—a relatively modern cancer treatment—isn't currently available on the NHS for this condition, Professor Bahl is seeking special funding access. Given the trial's success, researchers will soon test introducing the immunotherapy earlier in the illness to potentially increase cure rates. "Our purpose is improving management of this rare disease," Bahl noted, "and we've now shown we can offer affected men more time."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: New Footage Reveals Sound of Titan Sub Immersible Implosion
fields.summary: Newly revealed footage from Titan submersible's support ship captures the sound of its catastrophic implosion during a Titanic wreck dive, as US Coast Guard investigators disclose evidence the carbon-fiber hull began failing a year before the disaster.
fields.content:
The moment OceanGate's Titan submersible violently imploded has been captured in footage recorded aboard its support ship. The catastrophic failure occurred approximately 90 minutes into a June 2023 descent to explore the Titanic wreck site, roughly 3,800 meters beneath the Atlantic's surface, claiming the lives of all five people onboard.

Passengers included OceanGate CEO Stockton Rush, British explorer Hamish Harding, veteran French diver Paul Henri Nargeolet, and British-Pakistani businessman Shahzada Dawood with his 19-year-old son Suleman. A documentary team investigating the disaster gained unprecedented access to the US Coast Guard's investigation materials.

The footage shows Wendy Rush, CEO Stockton Rush's wife and an OceanGate director, reacting to what sounded like a loud bang when the submersible reached about 3,300 meters depth. She is recorded asking crew members, "What was that bang?" while monitoring communications from the submersible.

Moments after the noise, Mrs. Rush received a text message indicating the vessel had jettisoned ballast weights. Investigators confirmed the sound was actually the Titan imploding, while the delayed text message had been dispatched moments before structural failure. According to the US Coast Guard, all occupants died instantly.

US Coastguard Wreck of submersible on seabed showing carbon fibre layers exposed

Investigation data revealed the carbon-fiber composite hull had started failing during a dive one year prior to the disaster. On that earlier expedition, passengers reported hearing a loud bang during ascent that Rush allegedly dismissed as the sub shifting. The US Coast Guard confirmed this noise signified the beginning of delamination—layers of carbon fiber separating—compromising the structure's integrity.

Lieutenant Commander Katie Williams stated, "Delamination at dive 80 was the beginning of the end. Everyone that stepped onboard the Titan after dive 80 was risking their life." Despite this damage, the submersible performed three subsequent dives in 2022 before its June 2023 failure.

Businessman Oisin Fanning, who made two dives before the disaster, stated he wouldn't have participated knowing the true risks: "Very intelligent people who lost their lives, who, had they had all the facts, would not have made that journey." Deep-sea expert Victor Vescovo publicly warned OceanGate years earlier, telling Rush directly that operating under such conditions was like "playing Russian roulette."

Supplied via Reuters / AFP Stockton Rush, Hamish Harding, Paul-Henri Nargeolet, Shahzada Dawood and his son Suleman

The wreckage recovery yielded debris including Rush's clothing, business cards, and Titanic memorabilia. Christine Dawood, who lost husband Shahzada and son Suleman, described permanent life alteration: "I don't think that anybody who goes through loss and such a trauma can ever be the same."

OceanGate ceased operations following the incident, telling media they offered "deepest condolences" and deferred further comment until investigations concluded. The US Coast Guard will release its final report later this year to establish causes and prevent future tragedies. Legal action including civil lawsuits and potential criminal charges remain under consideration.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Nvidia Achieves Historic $4 Trillion Market Valuation Milestone
fields.summary: Nvidia has become the first company worldwide to reach a $4 trillion market valuation, with shares hitting $164 amid surging demand for its artificial intelligence chips. The milestone reflects the company's meteoric growth fueled by the AI revolution.
fields.content:
Nvidia has made financial history by surpassing a $4 trillion market capitalization, becoming the first company ever to reach this valuation milestone. On Wednesday, the chip manufacturer's shares rose 2.4% to $164, driven by intensifying demand for its artificial intelligence technology components.

This achievement builds on Nvidia's previous milestone of reaching a $1 trillion valuation in June 2023. Analyst Dan Ives from Wedbush Securities described the moment as historic, stating that Nvidia remains the foundational company powering AI advancement: "They are the only game in town with their chips the new gold and oil," he emphasized.

The company experienced significant share price volatility in April amid market turbulence caused by former President Donald Trump's tariff policies. Despite these ongoing trade concerns, Nvidia recovered strongly through spring to reach its current valuation, representing astronomical growth from eight years ago when shares were valued at less than 1% of today's price.

Originally known for competing with AMD in graphics card development, Nvidia's recent growth stems from surging demand for processors that power generative AI systems like ChatGPT. CEO Jensen Huang has gained celebrity status throughout this expansion, with Meta's Mark Zuckerberg dubbing him "the Taylor Swift of tech," particularly noting his rockstar reception in Taiwan.

Wall Street's confidence in AI growth, despite economic uncertainties, continues to drive Nvidia's value. The company reported a first-quarter revenue of $44.1 billion, a 69% year-over-year increase, with earnings of 81 cents per share.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump-Inspired Japanese Populist Sohei Kamiya Shakes Up National Politics
fields.summary: Populist leader Sohei Kamiya has made a stunning entry into Japanese politics with his Sanseitō party winning 14 Upper House seats, challenging establishment norms on immigration, cultural identity, and economic self-sufficiency while drawing inspiration from Donald Trump's movement.
fields.content:
Political newcomer Sohei Kamiya has upended Japan's established order after his Sanseitō party secured 14 seats in the nation's Upper House elections. The 47-year-old former supermarket manager and English teacher has drawn comparisons to Donald Trump while promoting "Japanese first" policies that resonate with younger voters.

Gordon Chang, senior fellow at the Gatestone Institute, described the breakthrough as populism hitting Japan "like a tsunami." Despite holding only 15 out of 248 Upper House seats currently preventing legislative proposals, polling reveals significant youth support with over 20% of voters aged 18-40 backing Sanseitō.

Sohei Kamiya campaigning in Japan

Immigration and Identity Debate

Kamiya has faced criticism for his immigration stance after responding forcefully to former U.S. President Joe Biden's 2024 comment labeling Japan "xenophobic" for limiting immigration. "It’s not that we’re xenophobic, we are being cautious after seeing your failures," Kamiya stated on social media, adding, "You are meddling too much in our internal affairs."

Chang refuted xenophobia claims, noting Japan's unique cultural synthesis: "The country has one of the most astonishing cultures in history, formed by adopting Western culture and enriching it to create a completely unique culture with tremendous global appeal."

Economic Vision and Challenges

Key elements of Kamiya's platform include lowering taxes, reinforcing traditional values, and boosting Japan's food self-sufficiency rate from its current OECD-low 38%. However, his proposal to convert farmers into public sector employees faces resistance. Chang cautioned that "the agriculture bloc is one of the most powerful in the dominant Liberal Democratic Party," questioning farmer receptiveness.

Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba and former President Donald Trump

While Kamiya reportedly rejects coalition-building, Chang predicts Sanseitō's influence will grow as Japan turns inward: "Societies globally have had enough of large foreign populations that do not assimilate. Change occurs slowly in Japan until it happens all at once. Japan is now on the verge of an all-at-once moment."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Unprecedented July Surge of West Nile Mosquitoes Alarms Health Officials
fields.summary: Health authorities report an alarming spike in West Nile virus-infected mosquitoes across two major U.S. cities during July, with infection rates matching late-summer levels and prompting urgent precautions.
fields.content:
Health authorities are sounding alarms over an exceptional surge in West Nile virus-infected mosquitoes detected across two major cities this July. Current infection rates rank among the highest ever recorded for this month, mirroring levels typically seen in late August when mosquito activity normally subsides.

Officials Urge Dawn and Dusk Precautions

Public health experts are coordinating insect control measures while advising residents near affected regions to avoid outdoor activities during dawn and dusk when mosquitoes are most active. Officials emphasize eliminating standing water sources which serve as breeding grounds for mosquito populations.

West Nile virus

Virus Origins and Health Risks

Originating from mosquito-bird transmission cycles in Africa and Europe, West Nile virus first emerged in the U.S. during a 1999 New York outbreak. That incident hospitalized nearly 60 people within two months, with most patients showing clinical signs of brain inflammation and seven fatalities recorded according to National Institutes of Health documentation.

While older individuals and those with muscle weakness face heightened risks of severe outcomes like brain swelling, officials note that most infected people experience either mild symptoms such as fever or no symptoms at all following mosquito bites.

mosquitoes

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Man Travels the World by Throwing Darts at a Map
fields.summary: A Romanian entrepreneur has visited over 60 countries through a unique method: blindfolded dart throws at a world map. Sorin Mihailovici's spontaneous approach evolved into a travel show, taking him from Iceland to Iraq while ignoring conventional travel planning.
fields.content:
Sorin Mihailovici, a 48-year-old entrepreneur, launched his unusual travel journey in 2012 after casually telling a friend about his desire to "wake up one morning and throw a dart at a map and go there." Instead of detailed itineraries, Mihailovici relies on chance, blindfolding himself before throwing darts at a world map.

When the dart lands on large countries, he travels there directly, but for smaller nations like Uruguay, he starts in the capital for practicality. This method has taken him to over 60 destinations across six continents, including remote locations like Antarctica and Easter Island.

Among his favorite experiences are trips to Iceland, Argentina, and Thailand, while Madagascar proved disappointing due to mismatched expectations from an animated movie and challenging local encounters. He noted that Scandinavian countries and luxury destinations like Switzerland and the Maldives often strained his budget.

Sorin Mihailovici throwing a dart in Iceland. A man has travelled to over 60 countries by throwing a dart a world map and visiting where ever it lands.

His adventures spawned the travel show "Travel by Dart," which features self-edited footage from his journeys. Mihailovici hires local videographers during his trips and has produced content for YouTube and Amazon Prime. He explained: "While we were at home, I started editing all those materials from every country and created a season of 13 episodes."

Despite the potentially risky destinations selected through his method, Mihailovici embraces uncertainty. He recently visited Iraq despite safety concerns, later reporting positive experiences including daily camel meals. His ultimate goal remains visiting every country through the dart method, acknowledging that smaller nations become challenging targets when blindfolded.

Sorin Mihailovici throwing a dart in Iraq. A man has travelled to over 60 countries by throwing a dart a world map and visiting where ever it lands.

Having already covered geographically large nations, Mihailovici now aims for harder-to-hit destinations like Australia and Spain, with another dart-throwing session scheduled for August. His traveled nations include Indonesia, Bermuda, Portugal, Cuba, Colombia, Vietnam, and Yemen.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: 12-Year-Old Chinese Swimming Star Makes World Championship Debut
fields.summary: Chinese swimming sensation Yu Zidi, aged just 12, has made her international championship debut following a near-selection for last year's Olympics. Competing in the 200m butterfly and 400m medley, the young prodigy advanced to semifinals while expressing ambitions for future world-class competitions.
fields.content:
Yu Zidi, a Chinese swimming prodigy, has made her world championship debut at just 12 years old, having nearly represented China at last year's Olympic Games. She is currently competing in both the 400-meter individual medley and 200-meter butterfly events.

In her initial performance, Yu completed the 200m individual medley in 2 minutes, 11.90 seconds. This time qualified her for the semifinals as the 15th fastest among 16 advancing swimmers.

Yu Zidi in Singapore

Yu began swimming at age six after a chance encounter at a water park. She recalled, "The summer was too hot, and my dad took me to the water park. I enjoyed the coolness of the water and spent a lot of time in different small pools for kids. One day, a coach approached me and asked if I wanted to swim faster." Born in October 2012, she now views her young age as an advantage for development.

Yu Zidi on her back

The young athlete expressed her aspirations: "My age is currently an advantage. I hope to grow and develop more strength in the future. I really want to experience the world-class competition," she said.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Faraday Future FX Super One: AI-Powered EV with Emotional Intelligence
fields.summary: Faraday Future introduces its groundbreaking FX Super One electric MPV featuring an AI-powered facial recognition system called F.A.C.E. that creates emotional connections with owners through responsive expressions and adaptive learning.
fields.content:
The FX Super One brings a digital face and emotional AI to electric vehicles

Previously seen only in science fiction, Faraday Future's new electric vehicle recognizes its owner, displays digital expressions, and responds to voice commands. The car lights up with personalized animations when approached, creating an immediate emotional interaction.

Inside the Faraday Future FX Super One electric MPV

Seating configurations range from practical to luxurious, with a premium GOAT model offering four seats that include zero-gravity recliners in the rear. This version comes with a panoramic display, integrated refrigerator, smart lighting systems, and high-end materials throughout. Other configurations can accommodate up to seven passengers.

Interior of FX Super One showing premium seating and display

How the F.A.C.E. AI grille works on the FX Super One

Differing from standard illuminated grilles, Faraday's Advanced Character Expression (F.A.C.E.) system employs AI to detect nearby individuals and respond with dynamic displays. Integrated with the Embodied Intelligence Agent, it shows emotions and delivers information through animations while responding to voice commands.

The system activates when parked, creating connections between driver and machine. Using cameras, voice recognition, and adaptive learning algorithms, it tailors responses over time—displaying calming visuals after difficult days or playful animations during morning greetings.

AI technology and smart features in the FX Super One

Close-up of F.A.C.E. AI grille technology

What's next for Faraday Future and the FX Super One

With over 10,000 pre-orders secured, Faraday Future plans to begin production in late 2025 at its Hanford, California facility. This accelerated timeline marks the company's commitment to competing in the EV market by prioritizing human connection alongside traditional metrics like speed and range.

Pricing and availability

Anticipated to cost under $100,000, the FX Super One is now available for reservation with a $100 refundable deposit through Faraday Future's official website.

Exterior view of Faraday Future FX Super One

Final impressions

Moving beyond conventional EV expectations, the FX Super One introduces personality through its interactive grille, responsive AI, and adaptive interior. By remembering interaction patterns and developing emotional connections, Faraday Future pioneers a relationship-driven approach to mobility that adds novelty to the electric vehicle space.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Marvel's Complete Upcoming Movie and TV Lineup: Every Known MCU Project
fields.summary: A comprehensive guide to all announced Marvel Cinematic Universe films and television series, including Spider-Man 4, Avengers installments, Blade, and Disney+ shows, with release dates and production updates for Phase 6 projects.
fields.content:
Following the debut of "The Fantastic Four: First Steps," Marvel Studios continues advancing its cinematic universe narrative. The current Phase 6 introduces multiverse concepts while maintaining Kevin Feige's meticulous planning. Although projects like the anticipated X-Men film remain officially unannounced, Marvel has revealed numerous titles currently in development.

Film Releases

Spider-Man: Brand New Day arrives July 31, 2026, directed by Destin Daniel Cretton. Tom Holland returns as Peter Parker navigating street-level challenges, with Jon Bernthal as Punisher joining the cast alongside Sadie Sink, Liza Colón-Zayas, Zendaya, and Jacob Batalon.

Avengers: Doomsday lands December 18, 2026, with the Russo brothers directing. Robert Downey Jr. makes a surprise return playing Doctor Doom in this multiverse epic confirmed to feature The Fantastic Four.

Avengers: Secret Wars releases May 7, 2027, adapted from major comic runs. The Russo-helmed project builds on multiverse themes and includes Fantastic Four characters.

X-Men enters development with Jake Schreier attached to direct following his work on Thunderbolts*, though no release window is set.

Blade remains in pre-production after directorial and scripting changes. Mahershala Ali stars as the vampire hunter, with Mia Goth expected to co-star in what's planned as an R-rated feature. Michael Green currently writes the screenplay.

Armor Wars transitions to a feature film format starring Don Cheadle as War Machine, though the release schedule remains unconfirmed.

Television Series

Daredevil: Born Again Season 2 debuts in 2026, continuing Matt Murdock and Wilson Fisk's stories. Following production restructures, Charlie Cox and Vincent D'Onofrio return alongside Jon Bernthal's Punisher.

Eyes of Wakanda premieres August 1, 2025. Ryan Coogler produces this animated series expanding the Black Panther universe.

Wonder Man stars Yahya Abdul-Mateen II in December 2025. James Ponsoldt directs the series featuring Ben Kingsley's return as Trevor Slattery, with potential connections to WandaVision characters.

The Punisher Special Presentation targets 2026 release. Jon Bernthal headlines this hour-long standalone project currently filming.

Vision Quest explores White Vision's journey in a WandaVision spinoff. Paul Bettany reprises his role, potentially connecting to Agatha All Along narrative threads.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Court Rejects Icelandic Artist's Appeal in 'Fishrot' Art Controversy
fields.summary: The UK High Court has dismissed Icelandic artist Oddur Eysteinn Friðriksson's final appeal over his controversial artwork featuring a fake apology website for fishing conglomerate Samherji regarding the 'Fishrot' bribery scandal. The court ruled the work constituted fraud rather than protected artistic expression.
fields.content:
The Controversial Artwork and Fishrot Scandal

Icelandic artist Oddur Eysteinn Friðriksson, known as ODEE, created a conceptual artwork in 2023 titled "We're Sorry," consisting of a duplicate UK-registered website mimicking the official site of Samherji, Iceland's largest fishing company. The artwork prominently displayed an apology statement related to the company's alleged involvement in the "Fishrot" scandal. This controversy emerged from over 30,000 documents leaked by a former employee in Namibia and published by Wikileaks in 2019, suggesting Samherji paid millions in bribes to Namibian officials for fishing quotas.

Samherji has consistently denied all bribery allegations, while ten accused Namibian officials remain detained proclaiming their innocence. Namibia's high court took up the case in late 2023, and Icelandic prosecutors recently concluded an inquiry without yet filing charges. The company pursued legal action against ODEE for trademark infringement and malicious falsehood.

Court Ruling Against Artistic Defense

UK High Court Judge Anthony Mann recently rejected ODEE's final appeal, upholding an earlier order requiring the artist to relinquish control of the website domain. While acknowledging ODEE hadn't sought commercial profit, Mann ruled the website constituted fraud rather than legally protected parody. The judge further determined the work couldn't claim free expression protections under Article 10 of the Human Rights Act, declaring it "an instrument of fraud."

In response, ODEE stated to ARTnews that the ruling paradoxically enhanced the artwork's value: "Here, Samherji has bared its teeth for the world to see." He contended that accepting the verdict could criminalize works by artists like Andy Warhol and Banksy. Together with legal representatives from the International Lawyers Project (ILP), he is preparing an appeal to the European Court of Human Rights.

Ongoing Legal Battle and Reactions

ILP's senior programmes director Ewa van Der Merwe accused Samherji of deliberately using UK courts to "suppress his artwork and exposure of their leadership's involvement" in the corruption scandal. This follows a November 2023 ruling where a UK judge sided with Samherji after the company sued ODEE for intellectual property violations.

During earlier hearings, ODEE characterized his practice as "culture jamming" – activist art subverting corporate messaging – while Samherji argued it didn't meet standard definitions of art. Following the initial verdict, then-CEO Thorsteinn Már Baldvinsson expressed satisfaction, stating the company needed to protect its trademark against violations "under the guise of artistic expression." Baldvinsson stepped down in May 2024, succeeded by his son.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Police officers accused of abusing victims in Rotherham grooming scandal
fields.summary: Five women abused by grooming gangs in Rotherham have alleged they were also sexually assaulted by South Yorkshire Police officers during their exploitation between 1997-2013, with detailed testimonies revealing patterns of threats, coercion, and institutional failures.
fields.content:
Warning: This story contains descriptions of sexual violence.

Five women previously victimized by grooming gangs in Rotherham have reported experiencing sexual abuse by South Yorkshire Police (SYP) officers during their exploitation. One survivor described being raped from age 12 in marked police vehicles by an SYP officer who threatened to return her to abusers if she resisted.

"In a world where you were being abused so much, being raped once by a police officer was a lot easier than multiple rapes by the gang," the former victim told investigators. Documentation reveals accounts from these five women plus 25 additional victims of grooming gangs, with accusations suggesting police collusion or deliberate non-action regarding exploitation.

The Jay Report confirmed at least 1,400 girls endured abuse by predominantly Pakistani-heritage gangs in Rotherham between 1997 and 2013. SYP's major crime unit has now launched a fresh criminal probe into officer involvement, supervised by policing watchdogs.

Professor Alexis Jay, head investigator of Rotherham abuse inquiry

Professor Alexis Jay, who led Rotherham's landmark investigation, expressed shock that SYP is investigating its former personnel, urging assignment to an independent body instead. "Victims were totally failed," she stated, emphasizing protections must precede institutional reputations.

SYP Assistant Chief Constable Hayley Barnett responded that despite historical failures, current efforts center victims' welfare. Original testimonies include disturbing patterns where officers exploited vulnerable children:

Aerial view of Rotherham neighborhoods

"Willow" (pseudonym) reported abuse by hundreds and specific targeting by two officers over three years, including assaults in patrol cars followed by threats if she refused. Another officer she identified subsequently destroyed her formal statement when she reported the grooming gang.

Accountability failures

While 30 testimonies were collected by Switalskis Solicitors for potential civil claims, just 17 were submitted to police. Many victims withdrew due to system mistrust. Amy Clowrey of Switalskis stated: "It's beyond belief - authorities prioritized reputation over safeguarding children, creating lasting distrust."

Amy Clowrey, solicitor collecting survivor testimonies

"Emma" detailed how officers deliberately targeted care-home runaways: "He knew we wouldn't report it - we were disposable." SYP referenced an ongoing watchdog-monitored investigation.

Former Independent Office for Police Conduct investigator Garry Harper derided SYP's prior Operation Linden inquiry as "an abject failure." His report documented systemic negligence regarding abuse claims, resulting in no prosecutions despite substantiated complaints against over a dozen officers.

Former police investigator Garry Harper

Specific officer identified

Redacted reports conceal officers' identities, though three former SYP members have been arrested since December 2024 regarding historic sex offenses while on duty. Willow specifically identified deceased PC Hassan Ali, who allegedly raped her while insisting "you do it for me like the others." He died while under misconduct investigation in 2015.

Late officer PC Hassan Ali named in allegations

Harper revealed awareness of Ali's suspected drug distribution and organized crime links during earlier probes. SYP confirmed complaints against Ali involved relationship-seeking and misconduct, not narcotics or rape. The force maintains all officers now under scrutiny were not implicated for rape before retirement.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Deadly Russian Strikes Hit Ukrainian Prison, Hospital and Aid Queue
fields.summary: At least 25 people died in overnight Russian strikes targeting Ukrainian civil infrastructure, including a prison where 16 inmates were killed and over 50 injured. Further attacks hit a hospital in Dnipropetrovsk region and a humanitarian aid queue in Kharkiv, as President Zelensky called for immediate sanctions to halt what Ukraine terms Russian war crimes.
fields.content:
Mass Casualties Across Multiple Regions

Russian aerial attacks during the night and early morning resulted in at least 25 deaths nationwide. The most devastating strike destroyed parts of the Bilenke penitentiary in Zaporizhzhia, southern Ukraine, killing 16 detainees and injuring over 50 people. Four precision glide bombs demolished the facility's dining area, administration buildings, and quarantine section, according to Ukraine's justice ministry. Officials initially reported 17 fatalities but later revised the number downward.

Separate assaults included a rocket strike killing five civilians waiting for humanitarian aid near a shop in Novoplatonivka, Kharkiv region. Meanwhile, in Dnipropetrovsk, a hospital in Kamianske suffered a direct hit, claiming three lives including 23-year-old pregnant woman Diana. Ukraine's human rights ombudsman emphasized that attacking prisons constitutes a war crime under international humanitarian law.

Leadership Responses and Ceasefire Demands

President Volodymyr Zelensky condemned the bombings, declaring Russia 'must be forced to stop the killings and make peace' through impactful sanctions. He called the attacks evidence that Moscow is 'wasting the world's time' while continuing aggression. Zelensky specifically welcomed remarks by U.S. President Donald Trump, who threatened severe sanctions against Russia unless it agrees to a ceasefire 'within 10 or 12 days'. Trump reiterated he would announce measures imminent y after his warning a month earlier had not halted hostilities.

Military Developments and Insider Reports

Russian authorities stated their troops recently captured Maliivka village in western Dnipropetrovsk, though Ukrainian officials denied territorial losses. Meanwhile, Ukrainian drones launched retaliatory attacks on the Russian border regions of Rostov and Belgorod, leaving one civilian dead in Salsk and another fatality at Belgorod. A BBC investigation confirmed numerous 18-year-old Russians died in Ukraine despite Moscow's pledge against deploying conscripts. An image illustrated the human cost, showing portraits of two young casualties.

Portraits of two young Ukrainian casualties

Domestic Protests Over Legislation

Ukraine saw significant anti-government demonstrations following legislation that critics believe eroded anti-corruption bodies' independence. Images documented rallies nationwide, including Lviv where protesters held banners demanding justice remain 'independent'. Further protests occurred in Kyiv against new rules viewed by Western partners as undermining oversight institutions.

Protester holding 'Justice must be independent' sign in Lviv

Kyiv protest against corruption legislation

Anti-corruption protest in Kyiv on July 22, 2025

One image depicted nighttime destruction at Odesa's market after deadly exchanges erupted along the Ukrainian-Russian frontier hours following trilateral ceasefire negotiations in Turkey. The controversial bill attracted the largest protests witnessed since Russia's full-scale invasion began in 2022, with Western allies expressing concern over governance reforms.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Maternity Services Report Reveals Serious Safety Failings at NHS Trust
fields.summary: A damning NHS England report has exposed critical safety and quality failures in maternity services at Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust, citing staffing shortages, poor workplace culture, and a failure to learn from past incidents. The review followed complaints from 67 families about avoidable injuries and deaths, prompting urgent calls for accountability and systemic reforms.
fields.content:
A recent inspection by NHS England has identified alarming deficiencies in the maternity services provided by Leeds Teaching Hospitals NHS Trust. The report uncovered "significant" safety concerns, highlighting widespread staffing issues, a "challenging" organizational culture, and consistent failure to implement lessons from previous incidents.

Following their March visit, inspectors issued 101 recommendations to safeguard expectant mothers and newborn infants. These proposals aim to urgently improve care standards and address systemic shortcomings throughout the trust's maternity units.

Trust representatives acknowledged the findings, stating remedial action is now their "priority". This comes after numerous families came forward with disturbing accounts of care failures. Over the past half-year, 67 families reported negligent care resulting in preventable infant injuries and deaths, supported by testimony from five whistleblowers raising safety alarms.

Just two months after these revelations emerged, NHS England escalated oversight by placing the trust under its specialized Maternity Safety Support Programme. This intensive intervention targets services exhibiting serious operational deficiencies.

According to one whistleblower highlighted in the document, critical concerns raised in previous safety meetings remained unresolved months later. Medical staff expressed frustration that preliminary versions of the improvement directives had reached trust management as early as May, yet substantial progress lagged.

Fiona Winser-Ramm portrait

Bereaved families described the published findings as "truly shocking and horrifying", criticizing the trust's "culture of denial" and absence of accountability for tragedies. Their statement emphasized that the report validates years of complaints about unaddressed failures.

Published just weeks after the Care Quality Commission downgraded Leeds' maternity units from "good" to "inadequate", the NHS England review intensifies scrutiny of the troubled services. Fiona Winser-Ramm, whose newborn daughter Aliona died in 2020 due to documented "gross failures", joined dozens of affected families demanding an independent inquiry.

The controversy deepened when Chief Executive Phil Wood unexpectedly announced his upcoming retirement shortly before the report's release. Having held leadership roles including Chief Medical Officer since 2020, his departure timing raised concerns about accountability continuity during the crisis.

Rabina Tindale, the trust's Chief Nurse, issued a public apology stating: "I would like to apologise to all families who received maternity care falling short of our standards." She promised that implementing the recommendations was her immediate focus, committing to "safe, high quality and compassionate care".

Leeds General Infirmary building

In his statement, Mr. Wood attributed his decision to retire to "national NHS changes", while pledging to complete ongoing maternity safety reforms before stepping down. He confirmed cooperation with an impending nationwide investigation into maternity and neonatal failures across England.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Teacher Banned for Life After Grooming Student
fields.summary: A teacher who groomed and manipulated a schoolgirl into performing a sex act has received a lifetime prohibition order from the Teaching Regulation Agency, after a panel found he abused his position despite being previously acquitted in court.
fields.content:
A secondary school teacher has been permanently banned from the profession after an investigation found he groomed a student into sexual activity. Jason Harrison committed misconduct while teaching at Notre Dame High School in Sheffield.

The Teaching Regulation Agency (TRA) panel determined Harrison touched the female pupil's legs and buttocks, exposed himself, and coerced her into performing a sex act during a lunchtime meeting in his classroom. The victim stated she suffered through "four years of hell" following the incident.

Now recognizing she was groomed, the former student described in a written statement: "I realise that I had been groomed and manipulated and can see that I should not have been worrying about protecting Mr Harrison." She added she remains fearful of encountering him publicly.

Legal aftermath

The abuse came to light after the student's friends reported concerns. Though the victim initially told school authorities she was joking about the incident, she later confided the truth to her mother. Harrison was subsequently arrested and interviewed but later acquitted in a 2021 criminal trial after resigning from Notre Dame in 2019.

The TRA panel nevertheless concluded the misconduct allegations were proven on the balance of probabilities. They stated Harrison abused his position, violated pupil rights, and caused irreparable damage to the teaching profession's reputation.

In their decision, panel members noted Harrison demonstrated "a complete lack of insight and remorse" and failed to acknowledge the "devastating impact" on the victim. The lifetime prohibition order bars him from working in any school, college, youth facility, or children's home, without possibility of reinstatement.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Fossil Evidence Reveals Terror Bird Attacked by Reptile 13 Million Years Ago
fields.summary: Paleontologists have discovered 13-million-year-old bite marks on a terror bird's fossilized leg bone that match an extinct caiman species, suggesting a deadly prehistoric encounter between two apex predators in ancient South American swamps.
fields.content:
Distinctive teeth patterns found on a terror bird fossil indicate the formidable avian predator may have been killed by a large reptile approximately 13 million years ago, according to new research. These birds dominated prehistoric South American ecosystems as top predators, taller than humans with lethal legs and razor-sharp beaks for ripping flesh.

Colombian scientists carefully analyzed puncture wounds on a fossilized leg bone and identified them as matching an extinct species of caiman, a crocodilian predator. Using 3D digital scanning technology, researchers reconstructed what appears to have been a fatal confrontation. The study detailing these findings has been published in the journal Biology Letters, offering rare documentation of violent interactions between extinct apex predators.

Link et al/Biology Letters The image shows the digital scan of a crocodile skull biting into a small leg bone. The bone that is being bitten into is based on a 3D scan of the 13 million year old fossilised bone from a terror bird.

The fossil was originally discovered over 15 years ago in Colombia's Tatacoa Desert. During the Middle Miocene epoch when this terror bird roamed, the region featured humid swamps where river sediments effectively preserved animal remains. The bird stood around 2.5 meters tall and used its powerful legs to immobilize prey while tearing into them with its beak.

Researchers note they cannot definitively determine if the caiman delivered the killing blow or scavenged the bird. According to lead researcher Dr. Andres Link from Universidad de Los Andes in Bogotá, there's a key clue: "There is no sign of healing in the bite marks on the bone. So if it wasn't already dead, it died in the attack. That was the last day that bird was on this planet – then a piece of its leg bone was found 13 million years later."

Andres Link The image shows a chunk of fossilised bone from a terror bird's leg. There are two holes visible in the bone - puncture marks left by the teeth of a predatory reptile.

The fossil was initially identified by César Augusto Perdomo, a local collector whose discoveries formed the basis of a paleontological museum collection. Terror bird fossils remain exceptionally rare, making this find particularly valuable. During examination of the museum collection, scientists recognized both the bone's significance and the fascinating puncture damage.

Analysis confirmed the bite marks most closely match Purussaurus neivensis, an extinct caiman species measuring up to five meters long. As Dr. Link explained, "I would imagine it was waiting for prey to be nearby," describing an ambush strategy similar to modern crocodiles. This evidence demonstrates terror birds weren't invulnerable, despite their apex predator status.

Andres Link The image shows a fossil collector at a dusty site in Colombia. The man wears a red shirt and a wide-brimmed hat to protect him from the sun. His feet are bare and he is examining the ground carefully for fossils.

The fossil provides critical insights into ancient ecosystems, revealing predator-prey dynamics and environmental conditions. Dr. Link emphasized the significance of such discoveries, stating, "Every piece of a body helps us to understand so much about life on the planet in the past. That's something that amazes me – how one tiny bone can complete the story."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: EE Introduces Age-Restricted Mobile Plans for Teen Internet Safety
fields.summary: EE is launching specialized SIM-only phone plans with tiered internet restrictions for teenagers, featuring age-based content filtering and scam protections, though limitations exist for Wi-Fi usage.
fields.content:
EE will introduce new mobile phone plans next month that restrict internet access for teenagers, though limitations apply when connecting via Wi-Fi. The SIM-only packages will feature three tiers of age-specific web filtering, reduced internet speeds for younger teens to limit video streaming, and protections against scam calls.

Controls only affect content accessed through EE's mobile data network and cannot filter Wi-Fi connections, which operate independently. With 25 million customers, EE claims to be the first major UK mobile operator offering dedicated smartphone plans for under-18s.

Current UK regulations require mobile networks to block adult content for minors on their networks based on British Board of Film Classification standards. Typically, accessing restricted sites via 4G/5G triggers blocks that require age verification through credit card checks or account settings adjustments.

What Are the Plans?

Despite Wi-Fi limitations, EE maintains the plans provide valuable safeguards. Starting at £7 monthly upon August launch, the offerings include three protection levels: "Protected" with strict controls for pre-teens, plus "Guided" and "Trusted" with moderate filters for older teens, all featuring scam call blocking.

Claire Gillies, head of BT's consumer division (EE's parent company), stated: "As the UK's best network for families, we understand smartphones offer benefits but pose real risks for young people. As a parent, I've had to balance these challenges when giving children their first phone."

Parental Challenges and Tech Overwhelm

The plans join existing app, website, and device safety features that often overwhelm parents. EE ambassador Konnie Huq compared the experience to "her mum in the old days" struggling with technology. Meta reports low adoption of its parental tools, while analyst Paolo Pescatore called EE's approach "a huge step" but noted implementation difficulties: "Users without reliable signals depend on Wi-Fi, making technology-agnostic solutions essential."

In-Store Support and Advice

EE will offer in-store appointments for family safety guidance and resources for parent-child phone discussions. Carolyn Bunting of Internet Matters charity welcomed the initiative: "Many parents feel overwhelmed about online safety. These positive steps support families better than outright bans, which remove pressure on tech firms to create safer spaces." The launch coincides with new UK regulations requiring age verification on websites.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ozzy Osbourne's Final Birmingham Procession Set for Wednesday
fields.summary: Birmingham will host a public procession for Ozzy Osbourne on Wednesday, allowing fans to pay final respects to the Black Sabbath legend. The cortege will pass key city landmarks including the dedicated Black Sabbath Bridge, where thousands have left tributes. Authorities have arranged road closures and encouraged early attendance.
fields.content:
Fans in Birmingham will gather to honor late heavy metal icon Ozzy Osbourne as his funeral cortege travels through the city center. The procession will begin at 13:00 BST on Wednesday along Broad Street, passing significant landmarks including the Black Sabbath Bridge and memorial bench – sites covered in tributes since the singer's passing.

The route announcement by BBC WM presenter Ed James gives supporters a chance to say farewell to the 76-year-old Black Sabbath frontman, who died on 22 July. Lord Mayor Zafar Iqbal declared Birmingham would pay "last respects to one of the greatest living legends," emphasizing that Osbourne "put Birmingham and Aston on the map."

Flowers and notes fill the majority of the image, with some reaching the top of tall black railings. Five people are by the tributes. Buildings are in the background at the top of the photo.

Osbourne's death came just weeks after he joined former bandmates for Black Sabbath's farewell concert at Villa Park, featuring performances by Metallica and Aerosmith members. The Wednesday procession precedes a private family funeral and includes accompaniment by local group Bostin' Brass.

Road closures will affect Broad Street from 07:00 BST, with tram and bus services rerouted all day. Lord Mayor Iqbal noted he witnessed "immense" public affection while signing a condolence book, adding the family funded all event expenses as the city hosted "at pace."

Getty Images A picture of a younger Ozzy Osbourne singing into a microphone, with long brown curly hair and tattoos visible on his arm and fingers, and wearing a black waistcoat and holding a microphone.

Global admirers from Mexico, the United States, and Poland have visited Birmingham to leave tributes. A letter from Greece praised Osbourne as "the king of metal" and "a light in the darkness," reflecting how his music shaped identities worldwide.

For those unable to attend, the city will provide a live stream of the Black Sabbath bench gathering. Additional memorial opportunities include signing condolence books at Birmingham Museum's Ozzy Osbourne Working Class Hero exhibition, opened recently by his wife Sharon.

PA Media A man stood surrounded by flowers and notes and a sign saying Black Sabbath Bench

Lasting City Memorials

Birmingham's enduring tributes include the Black Sabbath Mural on Navigation Street, the Ozzy the Bull sculpture at New Street Station, and The Crown pub – recognized as heavy metal's birthplace after hosting Black Sabbath's 1968 debut.

Ali Zaman, occupant of Osbourne's childhood home on Lodge Road, created a dedicated email collecting fan messages. He plans to publish them online, noting his family encountered pilgrimages to the property for decades.

Over 46,000 people signed a petition urging Birmingham Airport's renaming to Ozzy Osbourne International. Airport officials confirmed plans to commemorate his regional legacy. The city previously honored Black Sabbath with Freedom of the City status in June.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: US-Backed Gaza Humanitarian Foundation Delivers 97 Million Meals with Zero Diversion
fields.summary: The US funded Gaza Humanitarian Foundation has distributed 97 million meals in Gaza since late May without diverting resources to Hamas, employing armed security and innovative methods to overcome distribution challenges.
fields.content:
GHF has delivered over 97M meals with zero diversion to Hamas since May

The United States recently contributed $60 million to Gaza humanitarian efforts, with a spokesperson noting this represented the largest national donation while urging other countries to increase support. $30 million of this funding was channeled through the US and Israeli-backed Gaza Humanitarian Foundation.

Since beginning operations on May 27, GHF has partnered with Palestinian aid groups to deliver 97 million meals across Gaza. The organization operates four distribution sites providing boxes containing 2,400 daily calories sufficient for 5.5 people over 3.5 days, currently delivering approximately 2 million total meals daily.

Hamas terrorists

GHF coordinator Fay described successful implementation of a potato pilot program that has brought "hundreds of tons of potatoes" into Gaza. Despite media reports of violence at aid sites, Fay stated GHF operations run orderly, directly countering common perceptions of chaos.

Cardboard box with Gaza Humanitarian Foundation logo

Although the United Nations and NGOs oppose GHF's use of armed security personnel, UN data cited by Reuters shows only 8% of UN aid reached destinations unlooted over ten weeks. Fay offered GHF's security approach to assist UN operations, declaring, "We need to stop pretending that there’s only one way to get aid into Gaza."

Trucks of aid for Palestinians in Gaza

GHF continually adapts methods, including implementing a red-light/green-light system for distribution points and adding shelf-stable onions to aid packages based on recipient suggestions. Workers also reserve portions specifically for women and children, resulting in observable positive responses from female recipients.

A Palestinian boy carries an aid box provided by UNRWA, amid a ceasefire between Hamas and Israel, in Gaza City, Feb. 3, 2025.

The organization anticipates delivering its 100 millionth meal later this week as distributions become progressively smoother in what Fay describes as a "dynamic environment."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Michigan Democrats Propose Prosecution of Masked ICE Agents
fields.summary: Michigan Democrats have introduced legislation to prosecute ICE agents who wear masks during operations, comparing the practice to 'authoritarian secret police.' The proposal follows the state's COVID-era mask mandates and has drawn sharp criticism from Republicans and federal officials who cite safety concerns.
fields.content:
Democrats Target Masked Enforcement Tactics

Michigan Democrats propose state prosecution of Immigration and Customs Enforcement agents conducting operations while wearing identity-concealing masks. The legislation follows Michigan's COVID-19 mask mandates that were also enforced in states like Pennsylvania, New York and California. State Representative Betsy Coffia, the bill's sponsor from Traverse City, condemns ICE operations where agents obscure their identities, stating: "It mirrors the tactics of secret police in authoritarian regimes and strays from the norms that define legitimate local law enforcement."

Coffia emphasized that masked operations "confuse and frighten communities," adding: "Those who protect and serve our community should not do so behind a concealed identity." Co-sponsor State Representative Noah Arbit of West Bloomfield asserted that unclear identification during apprehensions "shreds the rule of law," claiming the tactic makes the Trump administration and Republican Party "the most pro-crime administration and political party that we have ever seen."

Attorney General Dana Nessel joined the effort, having previously urged Congress for similar federal legislation. Nessel referenced Michigan's own strict mask requirements during the pandemic, which mandated face coverings in crowded outdoor spaces and allowed businesses to deny service to uncovered individuals. She advocated focusing on public health rather than legal disputes, stating: "It’s time for us all to focus on the health and safety of the people in this state rather than fighting against each other in unnecessary legal battles in our courts." Nessel also supported an amicus brief against ICE's raid tactics in Los Angeles.

Republican and Federal Pushback

Michigan House Speaker Matt Hall dismissed the legislation as an "attack on law enforcement," declaring it "dead on arrival" and unlikely to reach Governor Gretchen Whitmer's desk. "The people want these dangerous criminal aliens off our street," Hall stated, adding that Republicans aim to partner with the Trump administration against illegal immigration while accusing Democrats of prioritizing criminals over victims.

Department of Homeland Security Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin criticized the bill as politically motivated, saying "power-hungry politicians" push "disgusting smears against our brave officers." McLaughlin clarified that ICE agents verbally identify themselves, wear labeled vests, and operate near marked vehicles, arguing masks protect officers from gangs like Tren de Aragua and MS-13. "These arguments are getting a little desperate," McLaughlin concluded regarding the proposed legislation.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Key Lyme Disease Symptoms to Watch as Tick Season Intensifies Across US
fields.summary: Medical experts warn of rising Lyme disease cases as tick season peaks, detailing critical symptoms like distinctive rashes and neurological effects, while explaining testing protocols, prevention methods, and treatment options.
fields.content:
Lyme disease infections are increasing across the United States during peak tick season, with heightened transmission occurring in the Northeast, mid-Atlantic, and upper-Midwest regions, though cases are expanding to new areas. The illness is caused by Borrelia burgdorferi bacteria transmitted through bites from black-legged deer ticks, potentially leading to severe muscle and joint pain, Lyme arthritis, cardiac complications, and neurological conditions if untreated.

How to identify Lyme disease infection

Between 60% and 80% of infected individuals develop a distinctive rash, often resembling a bull's-eye pattern following a tick bite. Symptoms typically emerge two weeks after exposure and can worsen without treatment. Early treatment during the rash phase is crucial to prevent severe complications.

If left untreated, patients may later develop serious conditions including Bell's palsy causing facial paralysis, Lyme meningitis with severe headaches and neck stiffness, or carditis involving heart tissue inflammation.

Woman experiencing joint pain symptoms

Additional indicators include fever, cognitive difficulties described as brain fog, dizziness, heart palpitations, and nerve pain. Medical professionals emphasize the importance of monitoring for these signs following potential tick exposure.

Diagnosis methods and treatment protocols

Blood tests for Lyme disease detect antibodies produced in response to the infection, though testing too early within the first 3-4 weeks after a bite can yield false negative results. Epidemiologists recommend post-exposure prophylaxis with a 200-mg dose of doxycycline antibiotic taken within 72 hours of a high-risk tick bite.

While this preventative approach proves effective in most cases, some physicians advocate for more extensive treatment. One specialist commented, "I don't feel comfortable with a single dose if I really want to avoid Lyme," suggesting longer antibiotic courses and follow-up assessments after one month to screen for co-infections.

Close-up view of a deer tick

For confirmed Lyme disease cases, treatment typically involves antibiotics like doxycycline, amoxicillin or cefuroxime prescribed for 10 days to six weeks depending on severity. Most patients respond well to these regimens when administered promptly.

Distinguishing persistent symptoms and co-infections

Some patients experience ongoing symptoms labeled as chronic Lyme disease, which medical experts often attribute to Post-Treatment Lyme Disease Syndrome (PTLDS). As one doctor explained, "The bacteria is dead and gone. It's the immune system's lingering response to the infection that you had in the past." Management typically focuses on symptom relief rather than prolonged antibiotics.

Man displaying facial pain symptoms

Warning sign about tick dangers

Physicians urge consideration of babesiosis for patients with unresolved symptoms, the second-most common tick-borne illness in the Northeast. Caused by Babesia microti parasites carried by the same ticks that transmit Lyme, this infection doesn't respond to standard Lyme antibiotics. A specialist noted, "You'll never get control of Babesia until you take some anti-parasite medicine," highlighting the need for targeted treatment.

Effective tick bite prevention strategies

Avoiding tick bites remains the most effective defensive approach. Experts recommend wearing protective clothing in grassy or wooded areas, using insect repellents containing DEET, and conducting thorough body checks after outdoor activities. The CDC estimates approximately 476,000 people receive Lyme disease diagnoses annually in the U.S.

Person applying insect repellent spray

When ticks are found attached, proper removal technique includes using fine-tipped tweezers to grasp near the mouthparts and pull upward steadily without twisting. Seek medical consultation promptly after removal for bite risk assessment.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Air Travel's Golden Age: A Look Back at Steak Dinners and Formal Skies
fields.summary: Discussions about modern air travel have sparked nostalgia for aviation's golden age, when flying featured fine dining on china, spacious cabins, formal attire, and was considered a luxury experience primarily for the wealthy before deregulation transformed the industry.
fields.content:
Contemporary conversations about air travel frequently evoke nostalgic comparisons to what many call aviation's golden age. A recent online discussion in an aviation forum questioned whether legendary carriers like Pan Am operated at major losses during this celebrated era.

Pan Am, which operated for 64 years until 1991, became a symbol of this luxurious period with its spacious seating, gourmet meals served on proper dinnerware, and highly respected flight crews commanding premium salaries.

BOAC stewardesses during Jumbo Jet 747 training in 1971

Forum participants highlighted how passengers during the 1950s-1970s dressed formally for flights. Tickets were exceptionally expensive, making air travel primarily accessible to the wealthy. One contributor noted Scandinavian airlines would carve whole hams mid-flight, while carriers frequently hosted themed culinary experiences.

Former flight attendant Jacqueline Whitmore, now a Florida-based etiquette expert, confirmed flying was once considered the height of luxury. Crews served hot meals on china plates with metal cutlery, contrasting sharply with today's experiences where many passengers disregard courtesy policies and airlines charge extra for amenities.

1950s plane cabin service

Modern reductions in legroom and seat dimensions have created increasingly uncomfortable conditions, Whitmore observed. Passengers must now pay additional fees for basic comforts like extra space.

The Deregulation Shift

Texas-based travel industry expert Gary Leff noted that people often romanticize early air travel through rose-colored glasses. He acknowledged modern technological advances in personal entertainment systems, but attributed fundamental changes to policy shifts.

Vintage commercial airplanes midair

Forum contributors and Leff pinpointed the 1978 Airline Deregulation Act as the turning point that ended the golden age. This legislation eliminated federal control over routes and fares, making air travel affordable for ordinary travelers though diminishing its luxury elements. Leff clarified that pre-deregulation regulations were designed to guarantee airline profitability rather than passenger comfort.

Contemporary airplane seating

The travel expert emphasized that airline bankruptcies didn't compromise safety standards despite the profitability focus. Modern aviation maintains strong safety records even amid economic volatility.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: AI Scam Alerts Now Active on Venmo and PayPal
fields.summary: PayPal and Venmo have deployed AI-powered scam detection systems for Friends and Family payments, using real-time risk analysis to intercept suspicious transactions and offer tailored warnings.
fields.content:
PayPal and Venmo have introduced significant updates: advanced scam prevention alerts for Friends and Family transfers. The feature specifically addresses concerns about users unintentionally sending funds to fraudsters.

These new notifications represent a substantial improvement over previous warnings. Unlike uniform pop-ups that consistently reminded users about scams, these alerts dynamically assess each transaction's specific risk level in real time. Understanding this technology provides crucial protection.

How do AI-powered scam alerts work?

The system relies on continuously improving machine learning models that scrutinize billions of data points. Using artificial intelligence, it identifies new fraudulent patterns, including those never previously encountered. Suspicious transactions trigger customized alerts that escalate in urgency according to the fraud probability. The company can autonomously block payments deemed extremely high-risk.

This represents a shift from conventional alerts that shared generic warnings regardless of context.

Why PayPal and Venmo built this AI feature

PayPal app on a smartphone.

Fraud tactics continue shifting rapidly, particularly through social media. Scammers routinely pressure victims toward Friends and Family payments that lack refund options. By inserting warnings before funds transfer, PayPal empowers immediate user intervention. The company emphasizes that this real-time risk assessment enables better decision-making.

Dynamic alerts vs. static warnings

Traditional methods employed standardized messaging, while this AI-driven approach generates contextualized responses tailored to transaction risks. This targeted methodology enhances both security and customer experience.

Global rollout and future plans for the AI scam alerts

PayPal app on a smartphone.

The alert system operates across all PayPal markets globally and fully within Venmo's U.S. operations. Self-learning algorithms will progressively refine detection as scam techniques advance.

Tips to stay safe beyond the AI-powered scam alerts

Complementing the technology, adopting secure practices adds significant protection.

Employ unique passwords for every account, avoiding easy-to-guess combinations. Consider using password management tools to generate and store complex passwords effectively.

Regularly review credit reports and monitor alerts for unusual account activities. Address anomalies promptly.

Exercise caution with unsolicited links and attachments, particularly high-pressure messages demanding quick action. Reliable antivirus software offers critical defense against malware and phishing schemes.

Prioritize secure payment platforms for transactions. Never send Friends and Family payments to unfamiliar parties since these lack refund protections.

Kurt's key takeaways

While online scams persist, AI-driven alerts from PayPal and Venmo substantially disrupt fraudsters. Combining rapid threat identification with adaptive warnings helps prevent losses before they happen. Integrating these alerts with proactive personal habits powerfully safeguards digital transactions.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Chief Justice Roberts Blocks Trump's Push to Fire Portrait Gallery Director
fields.summary: Chief Justice John Roberts intervened to prevent the dismissal of National Portrait Gallery Director Kim Sajet following President Trump's public firing declaration, asserting the Smithsonian board's exclusive authority over personnel decisions amid political tensions.
fields.content:
New information reveals Chief Justice John Roberts Jr. played a pivotal role in safeguarding National Portrait Gallery Director Kim Sajet's position after President Donald Trump announced her dismissal on social media. Sajet continued working until her voluntary resignation despite Trump's proclamation, which prompted scrutiny over presidential authority in Smithsonian staffing matters.

Roberts, serving as Smithsonian chancellor, reportedly halted board discussions about complying with Trump's demand during an internal meeting. When Florida Representative Carlos Gimenez urged the board to act on Trump's order, Roberts countered by stating, "We already have a motion on the floor," effectively ending consideration of the demand.

The board subsequently passed a resolution affirming its exclusive right to terminate museum directors. It further committed to providing directors "reasonable time to make any needed changes to ensure unbiased content" and to report back on personnel adjustments based on compliance progress.
