This resolution followed Trump's executive order accusing the Smithsonian of adopting "a divisive, race-centered ideology." In his social media post claiming Sajet's removal, Trump labeled her "a highly partisan person, and a strong supporter of DEI [Diversity, Equity, Inclusion]."

Separately, artist Amy Sherald recently withdrew her planned exhibition from the gallery after reportedly being asked to remove a portrait of a transgender woman depicted as the Statue of Liberty, illustrating ongoing tensions surrounding artistic expression at the institution.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UN Experts Warn Famine Now Occurring Across Gaza Strip
fields.summary: A UN-backed food security initiative reports that famine has reached Gaza City while catastrophic food insecurity affects most areas, citing evidence of widespread starvation and malnutrition driving hunger-related deaths among 2.1 million Palestinians amid Israel's prolonged blockade.
fields.content:
Global food security experts supported by the United Nations confirm famine thresholds have been surpassed across much of the Gaza Strip. The Integrated Food Security Phase Classification (IPC) alert states widespread starvation, malnutrition and disease are accelerating hunger-related fatalities among the territory's 2.1 million residents.

"The worst-case scenario of famine is currently playing out in Gaza," the report declares, adding clear evidence shows famine thresholds for food consumption have been exceeded in most areas with acute malnutrition reaching famine levels in Gaza City. UN agencies have documented at least 63 malnutrition-related deaths this month alone.

UN Secretary-General António Guterres characterized the situation as "a humanitarian catastrophe of epic proportions," emphasizing the immediacy: "This is not a warning. It is a reality unfolding before our eyes." He demanded that humanitarian access transition from "a trickle to an ocean" of supplies.

Israel enforced a complete blockade on Gaza in early March, partially eased after 11 weeks under international pressure, though aid workers report deteriorating conditions. Israeli officials deny creating food shortages, stating "there is no starvation," while recently implementing daily military pauses to facilitate aid distribution.

Odeh Hathaleen is pictured with a beard and curly hair, wearing a backwards baseball cap and a t-shirt, outside

The IPC indicates malnutrition levels rose alarmingly in early July as intensified Israeli operations devastated civilian infrastructure. Nutrition Cluster data reveals 20,000 children required treatment for acute malnutrition between April and mid-July, including 3,000 severe cases. At least 16 children under five died of hunger-related causes since July 17.

Gaza's Hamas-run health ministry reported 147 malnutrition deaths since war began, including 88 children. World Food Programme chief Cindy McCain warned: "Waiting for official famine confirmation while people already die is unconscionable," demanding an immediate flood of assistance.

UN agencies state merely "a trickle" of Gaza's required aid arrives monthly, needing 62,000 tonnes to sustain basic needs. Despite Israeli claims of delivering 5,000 lorries over two months, residents report widespread scarcity. Gaza City nurse Bakr Salah described his children going unfed for days: "We keep hearing about aid coming in, but we never see any."

Keir Starmer standing at a lectern in downing street

A Palestinian man carries a bag with aid supplies that entered Gaza, in Beit Lahia, northern Gaza (27 July 2025)

Aid delivery challenges include widespread looting, with Khan Younis resident Bilal Atallah paying $35 for black-market flour stolen from aid lorries. While Israel claims Hamas systematically diverts supplies, US analyses cited by Reuters and the New York Times found no evidence supporting systematic theft.

The crisis follows Israel's military campaign responding to Hamas' October 7 attack that killed 1,200 Israelis and took 251 hostages. Gaza's health ministry reports 60,034 Palestinian deaths during the ensuing conflict, including documentary filmmaker Odeh Hathaleen.

Jeremy Bowen wearing a blue denim shirt, holding a black microphone

Israeli human rights groups B'Tselem and Physicians for Human Rights-Israel hold a news conference in occupied East Jerusalem to release reports accusing Israel of genocide in Gaza (28 July 2025)

The IPC stressed famine conditions cannot be reversed without a ceasefire and unimpeded large-scale aid. While not yet formally declaring famine pending analysis, experts emphasized thresholds have been met for catastrophic food insecurity affecting over 470,000 Gazans since May.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: New York Shooter Targeted NFL Offices But Went To Wrong Floor, Mayor Says
fields.summary: An assailant who killed four people at a New York office building left a note blaming the NFL for brain injuries before committing suicide after the attack, according to authorities. The gunman went to the wrong floor in a building housing NFL offices during the assault that caused chaos in Midtown Manhattan.
fields.content:
The Attack and Motive

Mayor Eric Adams revealed that the gunman who opened fire at a New York City skyscraper Monday evening, resulting in four fatalities, had left a note holding the NFL responsible for a brain injury he suffered. The assailant, identified as 27-year-old Shane Tamura from Las Vegas, entered 345 Park Avenue where the NFL maintains headquarters but mistakenly went to a different section after taking an incorrect elevator.

Tamura reportedly carried a note attributing his mental health struggles to chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), a degenerative brain disease linked to repeated head trauma, while specifically blaming the football league. A senior official informed ABC News that the message stated "study my brain please" and concluded with "I'm sorry."

Though Tamura played high school football in California as a talented running back, former teammates confirmed to US media he never competed at the professional NFL level, while former coaches remembered him as hard-working and humorous.

Victims and Aftermath

Among those killed was New York Police Officer Didarul Islam, 36, who was providing security at the building. The Bangladesh native—a father of two with a third child expected—was described by Police Commissioner Jennifer Tisch as "a hero" who "made the ultimate sacrifice." Islam had previously mentored young men within his Bangladeshi community after moving to America.

Wesley LePatner, an employee of financial giant Blackstone, also died in the attack. Her company memorialized her as "brilliant, passionate, warm, and deeply respected." Two unidentified male civilians were killed as well, while an NFL staff member suffered serious injuries according to Commissioner Roger Goodell.

The shooting caused panic throughout Midtown Manhattan as bystanders described scenes resembling a "warzone." Witness Nekeisha Lewis reported seeing a wounded man fleeing the building and hearing multiple gunshots. Law enforcement closed off the area and conducted a floor-by-floor sweep lasting several hours.

President Donald Trump, on vacation in Scotland at the time, released a statement condemning the violence after being briefed about the incident and expressing confidence in investigators to determine the motivations behind this "senseless act" of violence.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Novo Nordisk Warns of Slowing Profits as Wegovy Competition Intensifies
fields.summary: Novo Nordisk, the maker of popular weight-loss drugs Wegovy and Ozempic, has reduced its financial outlook citing increased competition from rival medications and slower-than-expected US market growth. The Danish pharmaceutical company's shares fell sharply as it announced new leadership and lowered profit forecasts amidst claims of 'unsafe knock-off' drugs entering the market.
fields.content:
The manufacturer of Wegovy and Ozempic has issued a warning that its annual sales and profits will grow more slowly than previously projected due to the emergence of competitor weight-loss medications described as "knock-off" drugs. Novo Nordisk revealed this during its trading update while naming Maziar Mike Doustdar as its new chief executive, replacing Lars Fruergaard Jørgensen who is departing unexpectedly.

Novo Nordisk's shares plummeted over 20% following the announcement of its revised outlook and leadership transition. Doustdar, currently serving as vice president of the company's international operations, will assume the CEO role starting August 7.

The revised projections reflect weaker performance in key markets, including slower adoption of Wegovy in the US obesity treatment sector and reduced Ozempic sales for diabetes patients in America. This downturn coincides with increased competition as rival weight-loss treatments gain market presence.

Novo Nordisk specifically noted a rise in what it termed "unsafe and unlawful" semaglutide-based drugs since May. The company stated it's actively pursuing legal actions and other measures to combat these copycat medications falsely marketed as its patented treatments.

Semaglutide injections like Ozempic were originally developed for diabetes management but surged in popularity as weight-loss solutions, particularly following COVID-19 lockdowns. While Novo Nordisk attributes its financial downgrade partly to competitor drugs and restrained expansion efforts, analysts suggest the company underestimated potential revenue from consumers willing to pay directly for obesity treatments.

Markus Manns, portfolio manager at Novo Nordisk shareholder Union Investment, characterized the company's challenges as "much deeper" than just US Wegovy sales, extending to global markets. "Novo has underestimated the self-pay market in obesity and only recently began focusing on this key patient segment," he remarked. Manns described the reduced profit outlook as "a shocker," with full-year profit growth now forecast at 10-16% versus May's 16-24% projection.

Sales expectations were similarly revised downward to 8-14% growth compared to the previous 13-21% estimate. Meanwhile, analyst Benjamin Jackson from Jeffries questioned Novo Nordisk's decision to appoint Doustdar—who joined the company in 1992—to the top position, noting surprise that an external candidate wasn't selected despite the company's assertion of conducting a comprehensive search.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Sets Conditions for Palestinian State Recognition Amid Gaza Crisis
fields.summary: The UK government will officially recognize a Palestinian state at September's UN General Assembly unless Israel takes substantial action to address the humanitarian crisis in Gaza, Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer announced. The conditions include a ceasefire, full aid access, and Hamas releasing all hostages while relinquishing governing ambitions in Gaza.
fields.content:
Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer declared the UK will recognize Palestinian statehood at the September UN General Assembly unless Israel implements concrete measures to resolve the devastating situation in Gaza. Required steps include agreeing to a ceasefire, allowing unrestricted UN aid distribution, and taking substantial actions to improve humanitarian conditions in the territory.

Conditions and Political Context

This policy shift comes amid mounting domestic pressure on Starmer and follows France's announcement supporting Palestinian state recognition. Previously, the British government maintained recognition should occur during peace negotiations for maximum impact. The Prime Minister justified the timing, emphasizing the urgent need to preserve the possibility of a two-state solution given Gaza's deteriorating humanitarian situation.

Israel's Foreign Ministry criticized the UK's stance as rewarding Hamas and undermining ceasefire negotiations. Simultaneously, Starmer called on Hamas to immediately release all hostages, commit to a permanent ceasefire, disarm, and abandon governance aspirations in Gaza. Liberal Democrats welcomed the announcement but advocate immediate recognition, while Conservatives denounced it as counterproductive.

Humanitarian Crisis and International Responses

UN agencies describe Gaza's situation as man-made mass starvation, accusing Israel of restricting essential supplies—a claim Israel denies, insisting no food shortages exist. Palestinian authorities reported 112 deaths within 24 hours, including 22 fatalities during aid distribution efforts.

Palestinian women react during funeral for people killed in Israeli strikes in Gaza City

Aid organizations warn recent Israeli measures remain insufficient amid reports of people killed while seeking supplies. The UK conducted an emergency aid airdrop while advocating for land-based deliveries. Germany declined to join France and the UK in supporting statehood recognition, calling it a final-step measure.

Palestinians climbing onto aid trucks in Beit Lahia, northern Gaza Strip

Palestinians waiting for food at a Gaza City charity kitchen

Over 250 British parliamentarians demanded immediate recognition, despite skepticism that symbolic recognition alone resolves sovereignty disputes. With 139 nations already recognizing Palestine, Spain, Ireland, and Norway joined France in endorsing statehood, contrasting with U.S. and German positions linking recognition to permanent conflict resolution.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Launches Study to Test Pet Waste for Antibiotic Resistance
fields.summary: UK authorities will collect dog and cat feces from owners nationwide to analyze antibiotic-resistant bacteria in household pets, investigating transmission risks to humans amid global superbug concerns.
fields.content:
The United Kingdom is initiating a nationwide study requesting dog and cat owners to submit their pets' waste for laboratory analysis. Health experts are concerned household animals may harbor antibiotic-resistant superbugs that could transfer to humans.

This pioneering research will monitor healthy pets, not just sick animals, to identify dangerous bacteria strains. Studies indicate these pathogens can spread through close interactions like petting or kissing animals, as well as handling waste.

While frequently harmless, resistant bacteria may cause severe illnesses including sepsis and blood infections. The Veterinary Medicines Directorate highlights that over half of UK adults share living spaces with pets, creating environments where bacteria easily transmit between species.

Poo samples

Previous research confirms humans and pets can exchange pathogens like MRSA. Scotland's Rural College will conduct this four-year study, collaborating with veterinarians and pet owners on collection methods.

"This initiative is critical for understanding how antimicrobial resistance transmits and persists in pets," stated Prof. John Berezowski among the research team.

The World Health Organization identifies antibiotic resistance as a top global health threat, causing over 1.2 million deaths annually. Without intervention, annual fatalities could reach 10 million by 2050.

Researchers recommend owners practice strict hygiene—handwashing after contact with pets or waste. Isolating ill animals and thorough cleaning may reduce bacteria spread.

Antimicrobial resistance develops when bacteria evolve to withstand treatments, potentially making common medical procedures like cesarean sections dangerously risky.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Nottingham Attack Victims Awarded Posthumous Degrees
fields.summary: The University of Nottingham has awarded posthumous degrees to students Grace O'Malley-Kumar and Barnaby Webber, both 19, who died during the city's attacks in June 2023. Their families accepted the honors in emotional ceremonies, highlighting the victims' academic legacies and expressing gratitude for community support.
fields.content:
The University of Nottingham has posthumously awarded degrees to two students killed during violent attacks that shocked the city in 2023. Grace O'Malley-Kumar and Barnaby Webber, both aged 19, lost their lives after being stabbed on 13 June. A third victim, school caretaker Ian Coates, also died during the series of attacks.

During separate ceremonies, family members accepted honors on behalf of the young victims. Barnaby's brother Charlie Webber, 17, collected a degree in history on Monday, while Grace's medical science degree was awarded on Thursday. Charlie described the occasion as emotionally significant for their family.

"We know how much he would have been so chuffed to have gotten his degree this time if he was still here," Charlie stated before the event. "It means a lot to come up here, and I feel honored to be able to collect my brother's degree for him." He extended thanks to both the university and the people of Nottingham for their solidarity and compassion.

Charlie spoke warmly about his brother's deep connection to the city, recalling: "He loved it - from the social life to his academics to his sport up here, he was obsessed with Nottingham." He highlighted how local residents had embraced the grieving family despite never having met them personally.

At Barnaby's ceremony on Monday, friends gathered to pay tribute. Abi Brant, who knew Barnaby since their schooldays in Somerset, recently graduated with a geography degree herself. She called the event "bittersweet," explaining: "We're here to support Charlie and the family. It's tough but lovely to celebrate Barney's graduation - it's great that the university honored him."

Proud moment

Fellow graduate Ollie Chaplin, 22, met Barnaby through the university cricket team. He acknowledged the significance of the posthumous award as "a great gesture" demonstrating his friend's lasting influence.

"It's a sign that he's not forgotten, not just by his friends, but by the institutions he engaged with," Chaplin reflected. "This stands as a proud moment for both family and friends - while he can't join us physically, today provides meaningful recognition of his memory."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Five Key Takeaways from the Landmark Water Sector Review
fields.summary: An independent review led by Sir Jon Cunliffe highlights critical reforms for the water sector in England and Wales, recommending regulatory overhaul, better pollution monitoring, controls on company ownership, and potential bill increases to address sewage spills and public concerns.
fields.content:
The independent Water Commission has published its major review of the water industry in England and Wales, responding to widespread worries over sewage pollution and customer bills.

All sides to blame but Ofwat gets the boot

Commission chair Sir Jon Cunliffe asserted that multiple parties are at fault for sector failures, stating: "The underlying fact is we have not managed this well, and no one comes out of this with very much glory - not government, not the water companies and not the regulators." Most notably, the review advises replacing the fragmented oversight system with one unified regulator for each country, meaning the abolition of economic regulator Ofwat. This key suggestion has been confirmed for implementation by the government.

Water companies need to stop marking their own homework

Addressing criticism of operator self-monitoring, the report proposes enhanced surveillance including automated systems and independent checks to prevent firms from reporting pollution incidents without adequate oversight. Sir Jon emphasized utilizing technology like AI to improve measurement of sewage spill impacts and supplement existing efforts beyond just timing monitors. The review also urges better tracking of pollution from sources such as agriculture and chemicals to rebuild public trust.

More controls over company owners but no nationalisation

The commission recommends greater say for regulators in choosing water company ownership and holding executives directly accountable, alongside attracting long-term investors. Opposing calls for public ownership, Sir Jon recalled pre-privatization issues and argued that a well-regulated private system could work, provided performance aligns with pay. Critics like Surfers Against Sewage, however, condemned the review for failing to place public benefit above profits.

PA Media Five swimmers in black wet suits and coloured swim caps in water behind a sandy beach. There are trees in the background.

Our bills may have to rise

Bill pressures are likely to continue as the review identified past underinvestment due to low-rate policies from 2009 to 2024, compounded by climate change and population growth. Following last year's 26% bill hike approval, Sir Jon suggested gradual cost increases to avoid sharp burdens, advising consultations on social tariffs for low-income households and compulsory smart meters to reduce water demand. He stated: "Over time I think we are going to see the cost of producing water rise - that's inevitable, but we need to manage the impact carefully."

There are no quick fixes

The report stresses that transformation will be slow, with Sir Jon noting: "There is no single, simple change... that will reset the water sector" and "it takes years to build new infrastructure." Out of 88 recommendations, only abolishing Ofwat plus four others have immediate government backing, leaving many proposals pending. Improvements in river quality or bill reductions won't be rapid, and final decisions rest with lawmakers.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Google Introduces AI-Powered Search in UK, Sparking Traffic Concerns
fields.summary: Google has launched its AI-powered 'AI Mode' search feature across the UK, offering summarized answers instead of traditional link lists. While designed for complex queries, concerns mount among publishers over potentially devastating traffic drops from reduced click-through rates as major organizations warn of revenue impacts.
fields.content:
Google has initiated the rollout of its "AI Mode" feature in the UK, dramatically transforming how users interact with the world's dominant search engine. This artificial intelligence-powered alternative generates conversational answers instead of conventional blue links when activated, shifting search results to condensed summaries containing far fewer website referrals.

The option — currently experimental — complements rather than replaces traditional search, allowing users to choose between formats through a dedicated tab or search box. Hema Budaraju, Google's search product manager, emphasized the feature addresses modern complex queries like "I spilled coffee on my Berber carpet, I'm looking for a cleaner that is pet friendly" — searches unnatural for keyword-based approaches.

Getty Images A hand holding a mobile phone. On the screen is displayed Google across the top and then in the centre 'Meet AI Mode'. Below that there is text explaining that this tool will provide AI-powered responses and allow the user to ask follow up questions. Below that are example queries: How do migrating birds know where to go, and Houseplants that improve air quality and don't need much light.

Despite Google's assertion that AI Mode enables new information-seeking behaviors, businesses and online publishers express alarm. Organizations relying on search traffic — including retail sites and news outlets that generate ad revenue through clicks — fear dramatic consequences. The Daily Mail reported links from Google searches to its site have plunged by approximately 50% on desktop and mobile since "AI Overview" summaries appeared.

What is Google AI Mode?

Responding to user migration to chatbots like ChatGPT, Google employs its Gemini AI platform for responses in an accessible conversational format. Following launches in the US and India, UK implementation started recently. Google provided an example where a strawberry-picking query for families yielded broad geographic results with business links buried deeper compared to standard search.

Budaraju confirmed the company hasn't finalized an advertising model for AI Mode, leaving uncertainty about whether firms can pay for inclusion. Many organizations worry users won't visit their websites if answers appear fully synthesized. Budaraju counters this perspective: "People are going to use these technologies to unlock newer information-seeking journeys... you made it really possible for people to express anything a lot more naturally."

News model

Research by the Pew Center suggests only 1 in 100 searches result in a clicked link when AI summaries appear. Google disputes this methodology. Rosa Curling from campaign group Foxglove warns news outlets face existential threats, observing users often don't verify AI summary accuracy or access source material. "What the AI summary now does is makes sure that the readers' eyes stay on the Google web page," Curling noted, adding that news sites' advertising revenue is "massively impacted."

Google currently delivers over two billion daily AI overviews in over 40 languages, absent in the EU due to regulatory restrictions. Environmental concerns also accompany this expansion, as AI computations require massive energy and water resources at data centers. Budaraju stated Google continues exploring sustainable methods to serve growing technological demands.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: TV Presenters Cat Deeley and Patrick Kielty Announce Separation
fields.summary: Television personalities Cat Deeley and Patrick Kielty have publicly announced the end of their marriage, confirming their separation in a joint statement while emphasizing their continued commitment as co-parents to their two children.
fields.content:
Popular television hosts Cat Deeley and Patrick Kielty have declared their separation after over a decade together. The couple, aged 48 and 54 respectively, are parents to two young children.

In an official joint communiqué, they stated: "We have taken the decision to end our marriage and are now separated. There is no other party involved." They stressed their ongoing devotion as parents, adding, "We will continue to be united as loving parents to our children and would therefore kindly ask for our family privacy to be respected. There will be no further comment."

The pair exchanged vows in a wedding ceremony held in Rome during September 2012.

Career Background

Deeley currently co-presents ITV's flagship daytime program This Morning alongside Ben Shephard. Her prominence began on youth shows SM:TV and CD:UK before achieving international recognition as host of the popular American competition series So You Think You Can Dance.

Additionally, Deeley fronted the BBC's singing contest Fame Academy and later hosted ITV's celebrity impersonation program Stars In Their Eyes.

Kielty, a multi-faceted entertainer from Northern Ireland, assumed hosting responsibilities for BBC Radio 5 Live and RTÉ's prestigious Late Late Show in 2023. His documentary portfolio includes acclaimed BBC productions exploring the Troubles, notably My Dad, The Peace Deal And Me—an intensely personal film examining his father's murder by paramilitary forces.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Threatens Palestine Recognition Unless Israel Agrees to Gaza Ceasefire
fields.summary: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer declared the UK will formally recognize Palestine at the UN General Assembly in September unless Israel agrees to an immediate ceasefire in Gaza, ends the humanitarian crisis, and commits to a two-state solution. Starmer also demanded Hamas disarm and release hostages.
fields.content:
United Kingdom Prime Minister Keir Starmer announced on Tuesday that Britain will formally recognize a Palestinian state during September's UN General Assembly session, but only if Israel fails to agree to a ceasefire and take concrete steps toward peace in Gaza. Starmer issued a clear ultimatum to Israel to end the "appalling situation" in Gaza through substantive actions.

"I can confirm that the UK will recognize the State of Palestine by the United Nations General Assembly in September, unless the Israeli government take substantive steps to end the appalling situation in Gaza, agree to a ceasefire and commit to a long-term sustainable peace," Starmer stated. He specifically demanded Israel permit UN aid resumption and cease West Bank annexations.

The prime minister simultaneously delivered a stern warning to Hamas: "They must immediately release all the hostages. Sign up to a ceasefire, disarm and accept that they will play no part in the government of Gaza." This announcement followed Starmer's recent meeting with Donald Trump.

International Reactions Emerge

Former US President Donald Trump declined to endorse Starmer's position when questioned aboard Air Force One, noting the UK and France were adopting similar approaches. "Essentially, they're saying the same thing and that's okay. But you know it doesn't mean I have to agree," Trump commented.

Donald Trump shaking hands with Keir Starmer

Israel's foreign ministry swiftly condemned Starmer's announcement, stating it "constitutes a reward for Hamas and harms efforts to achieve a ceasefire in Gaza and a framework for the release of hostages." Starmer countered that his government would closely monitor developments before the UN session to evaluate both Israeli and Hamas actions before finalizing the recognition decision.

Debate Over Gaza Aid Intensifies

Trump contradicted Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's claims about sufficient aid reaching Gaza, remarking: "Based on television, I would say not particularly, because those children look very hungry. That’s real starvation stuff." He highlighted American efforts, noting the U.S. directed $60 million toward Gaza food assistance without receiving acknowledgment.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu speaking at event

Trump expressed frustration about the lack of gratitude: "We gave $60 million... and nobody acknowledged it. It would be nice to have at least a thank you." Amid international criticism over hunger in Gaza, Israel recently began conducting aid drops after months of restrictions, having previously contended that Hamas diverted significant portions of aid shipments.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Socialist Candidate Challenges Minneapolis Mayor in High-Stakes Race
fields.summary: Democratic socialist Omar Fateh challenges Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey in a November election showdown after winning party endorsement. The race features a progressive agenda mirroring New York City's Zohran Mamdani, with widening Democratic Party divisions.
fields.content:
Omar Fateh, a democratic socialist state senator, has secured the Democratic Party endorsement to challenge Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey in November's mayoral election. At 35, Fateh—a Somali American and Minnesota's first Somali-American state senator—represents a generational and ideological shift for the city.

Fateh won the endorsement over two-term incumbent Frey, who remains on the ballot seeking a third term. Minneapolis, like New York City, will use ranked-choice voting to determine its next mayor. Fateh declared his endorsement reflects public frustration: "a mandate to build a city that works for all of us," indirectly criticizing Frey's leadership.

Minneapolis Mayor Jacob Frey, a moderate Democrat, is running in 2025 for a third term steering Minnesota's largest city

Progressive Policy Agenda

Fateh's platform mirrors New York City mayoral candidate Zohran Mamdani's far-left proposals. Fateh advocates for raising Minneapolis' minimum wage, increasing affordable housing, and reducing police responsibilities through community alternatives. He also supports issuing legal IDs to undocumented immigrants.

Mamdani similarly pushes for free city bus fares, tuition-free City University of New York, rent freezes on municipal housing, free childcare up to age 5, and government-run grocery stores in NYC.

Zohran Mamdani, a democratic socialist who won New York City's Democratic Party mayoral primary, took a big step towards becoming the city's first Muslim mayor.

Democratic Divides and Republican Attacks

University of Minnesota professor Larry Jacobs notes similarities between Fateh and Mamdani but highlights a key difference: Frey remains the favorite to win. Jacobs points to a "genuine division" within the Democratic Party between younger socialists and moderates advocating gradual change.

Republicans have targeted both progressive candidates, using Mamdani's platform to criticize national Democrats. While Fateh hasn't received comparable media attention, conservatives have intensified attacks against his proposals as November's election approaches.

Mayor Frey responded to the endorsement outcome: "This election should be decided by our entire city, not by a handful of delegates. I look forward to a full debate about our records and visions for Minneapolis's future.”

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Health officials warn of dangerous kratom-derived substance sold nationwide
fields.summary: U.S. health officials have issued urgent warnings about 7-OH, an opioid compound derived from kratom plants that's being sold in vape stores nationwide. FDA Commissioner Dr. Marty Makary and HHS Secretary RFK Jr. cautioned that without immediate regulation and public education, this substance could trigger a new opioid epidemic, citing parallels to earlier prescription painkiller crises and sharing personal addiction experiences.
fields.content:
U.S. health leaders are sounding alarms about the widespread availability of 7-OH, a potent substance extracted from kratom plants being sold in stores across America. Health and Human Services Secretary RFK Jr. and Food and Drug Administration Commissioner Dr. Marty Makary stress the critical need to prevent another addiction crisis before it escalates nationwide.

Dr. Makary drew direct comparisons between 7-OH distribution and the initial phase of the opioid epidemic, when prescription painkillers flooded communities. "Vape stores are popping up in every neighborhood in America, and many are selling addictive products like concentrated 7-OH," Makary stated in an FDA release. "After the last wave of the opioid epidemic, we cannot get caught flat-footed again. 7-OH is an opioid that can be more potent than morphine. We need regulation and public education to prevent another wave."

Exterior of a New York cannabis dispensary

During a Tuesday news briefing, Makary questioned whether public health experts sufficiently understand the grassroots spread of such substances. He observed a "disconnect between the ivory towers and the streets" and asked if professionals had visited vape stores to witness distribution channels firsthand, noting the real-world impact reflects in medical settings.

Personal addiction battles highlighted

Secretary Kennedy revealed his personal struggle with heroin addiction during the conference, recounting how his perceived "iron willpower" proved useless against the drug's grip. "I felt that I could do anything with my willpower, but this compulsion was absolutely impervious to my will," Kennedy admitted. "Part of the problem was just the availability. It was too easy to get this drug for me."

The HHS secretary also referenced the Trump family's experiences with addiction, noting that while President Donald Trump remained abstinent throughout his life, his brother Fred Trump Jr. battled alcoholism until his death at age 43. Trump once recalled his brother's warnings: "I had a brother, Fred, great guy. But he had a problem with alcohol. He would tell me, 'Don't drink. Don't drink.'"

Kratom capsules in a bottle

Senator Markwayne Mullin expressed strong support for regulatory action, noting his family's direct experience with addiction's devastation. "It’s an addiction that is ruining lives," the Oklahoma Republican stated. Mullin publicly thanked Kennedy for addressing the threat on behalf of families nationwide affected by substance abuse.

Scientific background reveals that 7-hydroxymitragynine (7-OH) is derived from kratom, a tropical Southeast Asian tree. The FDA emphasized that while kratom is often used to self-treat pain, anxiety, and depression, no approved prescription or over-the-counter medications contain kratom or its primary compounds—mitragynine and 7-OH. Federal health authorities urge public vigilance regarding these unregulated substances entering consumer markets.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: French Beach Resort Bans Swimwear in Town With $175 Fines
fields.summary: The popular French resort Les Sables-d'Olonne has banned tourists from wearing swimwear in town areas, with municipal police authorized to issue fines up to $175 for violations. This dress code enforcement reflects growing tensions in tourist destinations, mirroring similar restrictions recently implemented in Algeria.
fields.content:
Another vacation hotspot is tightening regulations on tourist attire, with the French coastal town Les Sables-d'Olonne prohibiting swimwear beyond beach areas as destinations address overtourism challenges.

Municipal authorities have empowered local police to impose fines of €165 ($175) on visitors wandering through town in swimsuits. A town spokesperson emphasized this addresses community sensibilities, stating: "It's a question of respect for locals who don't want people wandering around their town half-naked."

Fashionable Young Women Wearing Bikinis While Taking Selfie In City During Sunny Day

Located on France's Atlantic coast, Les Sables-d'Olonne ranks among Europe's largest seaside destinations, attracting thousands of beachgoers annually. Officials cite preserving community decorum as the primary motivation behind the swimwear restrictions.

Algeria Implements Similar Dress Restrictions

This follows dress code enforcement in Chétaïbi, Algeria, where authorities banned men's Bermuda shorts last month. Mayor Layachi Allaoua explained the decision, stating: "These summer outfits disturb the population. They go against our society’s moral values and sense of decency," and adding, "The population can no longer tolerate seeing foreigners wandering the streets in indecent clothing."

Officials in Annaba, another Algerian coastal city, subsequently called for rescinding Chétaïbi's ban, highlighting differing regional perspectives on tourist clothing regulations.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Sophie Cunningham Attracts Wrestling Promotion After Fiery WNBA Defense
fields.summary: WNBA star Sophie Cunningham has caught the attention of wrestling promotion WOW following her physical defense of teammate Caitlin Clark during a heated court incident, with co-owners praising her competitive spirit.
fields.content:
Professional wrestling promotion WOW has shown keen interest in WNBA athlete Sophie Cunningham after her intense on-court protective actions drew widespread notice. Co-owner Jeanie Buss commended Cunningham's abilities, labeling the basketball player as "talented, dedicated, and a fierce competitor" whose combat skills have translated impressively to the court.

Dave McLane, a fellow WOW executive, echoed this enthusiasm during a recent Comic Con appearance in San Diego, revealing he witnessed Cunningham's aggressive play firsthand in Las Vegas. He stated, "I would love to have Sophie Cunningham in WOW because she takes down the competition and ensures Caitlin Clark's safety on the basketball floor. We'd love to have Sophie in WOW."

Sophie Cunningham and Jacy Sheldon

This wrestling interest emerged following a contentious WNBA matchup last month where Cunningham intervened after teammate Caitlin Clark suffered multiple fouls. Clark had already endured an eye poke from Jacy Sheldon and a hard shove to the floor by Marina Mabrey earlier in the game.

During the fourth quarter, Cunningham retaliated by wrapping up Sheldon under the basket with a flagrant foul, triggering a massive on-court scrum that resulted in both players being ejected. The incident polarized fans, with some criticizing Cunningham while others applauded her protective stance.

Sophie Cunningham mixes it up

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Electric Dolly System Reinvents Diesel Trucking with Hybrid Power
fields.summary: California startup Revoy introduces an electric dolly that attaches to existing diesel trucks, creating hybrid rigs that cut emissions and fuel costs without replacing vehicles. The removable device features battery swapping, smart driving aids, and a pay-per-mile model to overcome traditional EV trucking barriers.
fields.content:
Big rigs go electric without abandoning diesel

Heavy-duty trucks dominate transportation emissions in the U.S., surpassing passenger vehicles for the first time. Yet full electrification faces hurdles: expensive new vehicles, limited range, slow charging, and thin profit margins among trucking firms. Revoy's solution enables instant electric conversion through an innovative dolly placed between cabs and trailers, cutting emissions while preserving familiar diesel operations.

A big rig using a high-tech electric dolly with its own motor and a battery pack.

How the electric dolly transforms trucks instantly

The dolly houses a 575-kilowatt-hour battery comparable to full EV semis. Its powered axle propels the truck forward, easing diesel engine strain. Connecting via existing fifth-wheel hitches and air lines requires no vehicle modifications, with installation completed tool-free in minutes. This creates a functional hybrid system without infrastructure overhaul.

Illustration of how the Revoy dolly connects to the truck's fifth-wheel hitch.

Smart driving enhancements

Integrated sensors and cameras monitor blind zones, feeding data to drivers via smartphone apps while improving lane control and crosswind correction. Regenerative braking recaptures energy, and automated reversing simplifies tricky maneuvers. These features activate without driver retraining or dashboard adjustments.

Battery swap stations for rapid refueling

Instead of charging pauses lasting 30+ minutes, drivers exchange depleted dollies for fully charged units in about five minutes at Revoy stations. Current facilities in Texas and Arkansas support expanding networks. For routes without swap access, trucks disconnect dollies and run purely on diesel.

Illustration of a Revoy swap station.

Cost-efficient operation model

Fleets avoid capital expenses by leasing dollies per-mile rather than purchasing them. The system saves over $5,000 yearly per truck through fuel reductions, with some fleets achieving 3–5 times better efficiency. Since 60% of truckloads are volume-bound rather than weight-limited, the dolly's mass rarely impacts operations.

Global scalability potential

Designed for U.S. single-trailer configurations, the technology suits sun-rich regions like Australia and promises adaptation for Canada's double-trailer rigs. Solar power could fuel remote dolly swap stations, turning lengthy charging sessions into quick exchanges worldwide.

A big rig on the road using a high-tech electric dolly.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Understanding CTE: The Brain Disease Linked to Football and Violence
fields.summary: Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE), a degenerative brain condition tied to repetitive head injuries in contact sports, resurfaces in public discussion following a deadly Manhattan shooting where the gunman claimed to suffer from CTE in a suicide note. This article explains the condition's symptoms, latest research findings, and prevention efforts in sports.
fields.content:
The brain disorder Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy (CTE) has returned to public attention after a tragic shooting in Manhattan. The gunman, Shane Tamura, a former high school football player, left a note claiming he had CTE and alleging the NFL concealed the condition's risks before killing four people and himself via chest wound suicide—a method more common among CTE sufferers who die this way.

Tamura's note read: "Study my brain please. I'm sorry," highlighting CTE's recurring emergence during catastrophic events. Research into the devastating illness continues alongside preventative measures.

CTE is a devastating and deadly condition.

CTE involves progressive brain damage resembling Alzheimer's, resulting from repeated head trauma—particularly in contact sports. The condition permanently destroys brain nerve cells, potentially causing behavioral shifts, memory issues, suicidal thoughts, personality changes, and tremors, according to health authorities.

"It is currently a diagnosis made only by examining the brain tissue of persons who have died," states Dr. John Leddy, medical director at the University at Buffalo Concussion Management Clinic. CTE cannot yet be diagnosed in living individuals.

There is ongoing research into CTE.

A 2023 study in JAMA Neurology examined 152 donated brains of athletes under 30 with head impact histories. Over 40% showed CTE symptoms—mostly mild stages—with suicide being the leading cause of death. Football accounted for 75% of CTE cases among amateur athletes.

Disturbingly, a 2024 survey found 34% of ex-NFL players believed they had CTE, reporting health issues and suicidal thoughts. A 2017 analysis revealed 99% (110 of 111) of studied ex-NFL players had CTE postmortem.

The NFL has taken some steps to lower the risk of CTE.

Facing mounting public pressure over CTE risks and player testimonials—like ex-Eagles center Jason Kelce stating he "virtually guarantees" having it—the NFL reports concussion rates recently reached "historic lows," dropping 17% in 2024. Measures include optional helmet Guardian Caps. However, initial research questioned their effectiveness, showing no impact reduction among college players.

Leddy emphasizes treating coexisting conditions rather than assuming CTE causes symptoms: "Persons experiencing distress should seek medical help... to identify and treat possible conditions." League responses include rule changes and concussion protocols—removing players immediately and requiring medical clearance before return. The NFL hasn't commented on the Manhattan shooting.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: George Lucas Debuts at Comic-Con to Preview Narrative Art Museum
fields.summary: George Lucas made his first Comic-Con appearance to reveal details about the upcoming Lucas Museum of Narrative Art, emphasizing its mission to showcase storytelling through diverse artworks while sharing his personal philosophy as an unconventional collector.
fields.content:
George Lucas made his Comic-Con debut during a landmark Hall H panel that attracted 6,500 attendees. Instead of discussing Star Wars or Indiana Jones, Lucas focused on the Lucas Museum of Narrative Art, slated to open in Los Angeles next year. Academy Award-winning director Guillermo del Toro, museum board member, and designer Doug Chiang joined him, with Queen Latifah moderating. This marked Lucas's first public museum appearance since leadership changes and staff layoffs earlier in 2025.

Cofounded with his wife Mellody Hobson, the museum defines narrative art as imagery that conveys stories to shape societal beliefs and communities. The design features a 300,000-square-foot structure by architect Ma Yansong, described by del Toro as embodying artistic flow. Both he and Lucas emphasized treating artworks as cultural stewardships rather than possessions.

Exterior view of Lucas Museum building

The Vision Behind the Collection

Located in Exposition Park, the museum campus offers 11 acres of green space designed by Studio-MLA and includes galleries, theaters, and public facilities. Lucas revealed his connection to narrative art began in college, with the founding collection featuring over 40,000 personally curated works. He noted, "I love all art, but I could afford comic art back then – it was underground." Rejecting investment-focused collecting, Lucas emphasized emotional connections: "I’m not typical – I couldn’t sell art later for profit."

He highlighted Norman Rockwell's 1943 painting "Freedom from Want" as exemplifying narrative art’s power to reinforce communal values like family bonds. "Society cannot exist without common belief systems," Lucas stated, citing illustrations as vital for visualizing shared principles.

Frida Kahlo's 1940 self-portrait 'Dedicated to Dr. Leo Eloesser'

The collection will display works ranging from Frida Kahlo and Kadir Nelson to seminal pop culture items like the first Flash Gordon sketch and early Peanuts comics. Chiang praised the museum for elevating historically overlooked genres: "It celebrates art forms that haven't been properly highlighted before." Lucas concluded his presentation by framing the institution as "a temple to people’s art," dedicated to how stories build communities through illustrated narratives.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump's Scottish Visit: Triumphs in Golf, Trade, and an Unwanted Distraction
fields.summary: Donald Trump's trip to Scotland blended personal indulgence and high-stakes diplomacy, yielding a favorable EU trade deal, promoting his golf resorts, and extensive play time, while the Jeffrey Epstein scandal cast a shadow he couldn't outrun.
fields.content:
Donald Trump's Scottish getaway indulged his passions for golf, self-promotion, and trade deals perfectly, delivering victories that left him visibly pleased during what was described as a "private visit." His most significant win involved securing an unprecedented agreement with the European Union, the largest in history and skewed advantageously toward the US economy.

Major Trade Deal Secured

The EU pledged to spend hundreds of billions purchasing American energy and military hardware while investing further in US industries; in return, American tariffs on European exports dropped to 15% against a possible 30%. Although this didn't fulfill Trump's ambitious promise of "90 deals in 90 days," it became a key point of pride for his administration.

Hosting Britain's Prime Minister Sir Keir and Lady Starmer at his Turnberry golf resort provided another highlight, even if it blurred diplomatic lines by having the PM hosted as a guest in his homeland. Starmer capitalized on the unusual amount of face time, building rapport that Trump values greatly in shaping foreign policy.

Diplomatic Talks with Keir Starmer

Their discussions centered heavily on Gaza, with Starmer urging Trump to pressure Israel for more food aid to Palestinians, resulting in Trump vowing to collaborate with the UK and European allies to establish food centers. He also publicly gave Starmer leeway to recognize Palestine, stating, "I'm not going to take a position, I don't mind him taking a position," while clarifying that the US wouldn't follow suit.

Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer and his wife ascending the steps of a golf club where Trump greets them

Trump reevaluated his stance on Ukraine, shortening Putin's deadline for a ceasefire from 50 days to just 10-12 days during a lengthy press conference where he freely discussed wind power, immigration, and commented on figures like King Charles and London's mayor, Sadiq Khan. One topic he couldn't sidestep was Jeffrey Epstein, as criticism over withheld government documents trailed him to Scotland with a van displaying their shared past picture.

Epstein Scandal Surfaces

For the first time, Trump explained their falling out, claiming Epstein poached staff from his Mar-a-Lago estate and insisting he ceased communication afterward. He also denied ever sending sexually suggestive drawings to Epstein, asserting he only sketches buildings. Despite the intrusion, little dampened his mood—few scattered protests were peaceful, while adoring fans hailed him at airports and golf clubs.

Seizing opportunities to flaunt his properties, Trump hosted Starmer and EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen in Turnberry's newly renovated ballroom, bragging about opulent ceilings during talks on Gaza. He dazzled Starmer with aerial views of his courses aboard Marine One and had Scottish First Minister John Swinney help open the Trump International Golf Links in Balmedie.

Donald Trump and Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer arriving at a Trump estate in Aberdeenshire

It was extraordinarily bold for a sitting US president to so brazenly use official engagements to advertise his businesses, but Trump clearly relished it, complementing nearly daily rounds of golf that capped off a successful diplomatic, personal, and commercial venture.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Beijing Floods Claim 30 Lives Amid Northern China's Extreme Weather Crisis
fields.summary: Severe flooding has killed at least 30 people in Beijing and forced 80,000 evacuations amid northern China's ongoing extreme weather crisis, with President Xi Jinping calling for all-out rescue operations while landslides claim additional lives.
fields.content:
Torrential rains in Beijing have led to devastating floods, claiming at least 30 lives and triggering mass evacuations of over 80,000 residents across northern China. Rescue operations are underway in severely affected suburban districts including Miyun and Huairou.

A separate landslide in Chengde city, located northeast of Beijing, killed eight people on Monday. The disaster comes during a summer marked by extreme weather patterns across China, following recent record heatwaves in eastern regions and destructive flooding in the southwest.

President Xi Jinping has urged comprehensive emergency efforts, emphasizing preparation for worst-case scenarios. Authorities have allocated 200 million yuan ($28 million) for infrastructure repairs and recovery.

Flooding has collapsed roads and cut power to over 130 villages, with rescuers seen navigating chest-high waters to reach stranded residents. Helicopters and drones are delivering essential supplies to isolated areas.

Getty Images A bulldozer and truck beside a collapsed section of a road. Brown water is flowing in a canal beside the road.

Affected residents shared harrowing accounts of the floods' rapid onset. Zhuang Zhelin, a shop owner near Beijing, described how waters inundated his town within moments, while neighbors reported sheltering upstairs awaiting rescue.

Family members expressed distress over disconnected communications. Yang, a Hebei province resident, publicly appealed for help after losing contact with her elderly relatives and pets in the flood-hit Miyun district.

This disaster recalls Beijing's deadly July 2012 floods, which killed 79 residents after 190mm of rainfall. Recent weeks saw Typhoon Wipha kill two people in Shandong while leaving 10 missing, and a landslide claim three lives in Ya'an.

Experts highlight climate connections to intensifying weather extremes threatening China's population and agriculture. First-half natural disasters caused 54.11 billion yuan ($7.5 billion) in damage nationwide, with floods responsible for 90% of losses according to emergency authorities.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Meat and Tea Prices Fuel Six-Month High in Food Inflation
fields.summary: Food price inflation accelerated to 4% annually in July amid tightening global supplies of meat and tea, marking the sixth consecutive monthly increase with grocery bills projected to rise by £275 this year.
fields.content:
Food price inflation hit 4% in the year to July, up from 3.7% in June, as meat and tea costs surged due to constrained global supplies. The British Retail Consortium's latest data shows this marks half a year of steadily increasing prices that are straining household budgets.

Helen Dickinson, Chief Executive of the British Retail Consortium, highlighted that staples like meat and tea faced the sharpest increases. "Tighter global supplies have hit wholesale prices hard," she noted, adding that consumers would notice these higher food expenses.

Fresh food inflation remained steady at 3.2%, but cupboard goods like tea bags surged to 5.1%. Separate research indicates average annual grocery bills will jump by £275 due to these ongoing pressures.

Andrew Keeble of Heck Sausages described a "perfect storm" for meat costs: chicken prices doubled to £5.50 per kilo over two years due to reduced stock density and avian flu. He acknowledged producers and retailers were resisting price hikes but warned, "it gets to the point where this is now actually coming through."

Rising food prices contributed to broader inflation hitting 3.6% in June, driven by 4.5% annual growth in food and drink expenditures – the fastest rise since February 2024. Mike Watkins of NIQ cautioned that retailers face challenges retaining shoppers amid such pressures.

Despite the grim outlook, Dickinson noted "bright spots" with discounts available in fashion and furniture. Overall shop price inflation climbed to 0.7%, outpacing June's 0.4% increase. A separate study confirmed food costs jumped 5.2% year-on-year, with chocolate, butter, and fresh meat leading the surge.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Police Seek Tommy Robinson for Questioning Over Station Incident
fields.summary: Authorities are attempting to locate far-right activist Tommy Robinson regarding an alleged assault at London's St Pancras railway station where a man suffered serious injuries, with video evidence emerging on social media showing Robinson near the victim.
fields.content:
Police are attempting to question prominent far-right activist Tommy Robinson following an alleged physical altercation at St Pancras railway station in London. Social media footage circulated widely showed Robinson in close proximity to an unconscious man lying on the station floor, although the clip revealed no details about how the man sustained injuries.

British Transport Police confirmed discovering a man with serious, non-life-threatening injuries at the station on Monday evening. Investigators revealed a 42-year-old male suspect boarded an international flight early Tuesday morning after the incident. The force identified the suspect as being from Bedfordshire without disclosing his name.

When approached by a female reporter seeking comment, Robinson—whose legal name is Stephen Yaxley-Lennon—responded with a message calling the journalist a "slag." Detectives confirmed they are continuing their inquiry with the intention of locating and detaining the suspect for formal questioning.

The viral footage shows Robinson pacing near the motionless man lying face-down adjacent to the stairs for the northbound Thameslink line. In the video, an unidentified commuter attempts to block Robinson's movements while calling station staff for assistance.

As two station personnel attend to the injured individual, Robinson retreats down a staircase shouting: "He's come at me, bruv." Moments later, Robinson returns toward the commuter who had requested help before the footage abruptly concludes.

Additional videos surfaced on Robinson's social media accounts showing him at the same station wearing identical clothing to that seen in the incident footage. Police did not directly reference the viral material in their official statements.

After authorities released their statement, Robinson reposted several expressions of support on social media but offered no personal commentary about the station incident. Police urged anyone with information to contact them via text message at 61016, referencing case number 655 for 28 July.

London Ambulance Service reported receiving a call regarding an assault at St Pancras at exactly 20:40 on Monday. Crews dispatched to the scene treated one male victim before transporting him to a major trauma center for further care.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Do We Really Need to Stick to Daily Health Guidance?
fields.summary: Recent studies suggest some health recommendations might be more flexible than we thought. Experts weigh in on whether we need to follow common guidelines like 10,000 steps, eight glasses of water, and 7-9 hours of sleep, revealing where flexibility exists and where strict adherence matters.
fields.content:
Many celebrated when research challenged the long-standing goal of walking 10,000 daily steps, indicating that just 7,000 could offer significant benefits. This revelation sparks the question: What about other common health benchmarks? Experts examine if we need to strictly follow standards like hydration targets, sleep recommendations, exercise duration, and mindfulness practices.

Water (6-8 glasses a day)

Getty Images Eight glasses of water arranged in a triangle pattern

While the NHS recommends drinking 1.5-2 liters of water daily for adults, kidney specialist Professor Neil Turner argues trust in natural mechanisms suffices. "Our bodies tell us to eat when hungry and drink when thirsty," he notes, citing humans' millennia of existence without measuring intake. Dark urine signals kidneys conserving water before we feel thirst. Nutritionist Dr. Linia Patel counters that dehydration symptoms—fatigue, brain fog, cravings—commonly affect women, making recommended targets useful.

Sleep (7-9 hours a night)

Getty Images Woman resting face-down on a neat bed

Sleep disorders expert Professor Ama Johal stresses strict adherence to 7-9 hours nightly. He cites studies linking less than five hours' sleep to higher obesity, diabetes, depression, and early mortality risks, including one involving 10,000 British civil servants. Catnapping? "Our bodies react differently to daytime naps," Johal clarifies, though research suggests brief naps can counter poor nighttime sleep. He advocates prioritizing quality sleep several nights weekly.

Emily and Lucy friends hiking in a wooded area

Manchester residents Emily and Lucy, committed walkers, battle anxiety-related sleep difficulties but aim toward the seven-hour target.

Exercise (150 mins a week)

Emily and Lucy's hiking group has improved their mental health and social connections. Though they prioritize 7,000 daily steps and weekend walks, fitness benchmarks like the NHS-recommended 150 weekly exercise minutes aren't rigidly managed. Sports nutritionist Dr. Sinead Roberts agrees: "Adapt recommendations to your life." She considers strength training vital for injury prevention but applauds any exercise, likening health habits to a highway—"going off course sometimes" is manageable.

Mindfulness (10 mins a day)

Getty Images Woman meditating cross-legged with earbuds

The NHS suggests 10 daily minutes of mindfulness to enhance mental focus. Psychologist Natasha Tiwari explains the duration helps "give the mind time to settle" but emphasizes that even brief pauses offer benefits. She advises incorporating mindful awareness into daily routines instead of stressing about time quotas. Experts concur benchmarks serve as useful guides, but a holistic approach—not rigid rule-following—optimizes wellbeing. As Emily and Lucy note, "Five minutes of meditation beats none."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Why Wasp Numbers Are Booming Across the UK This Summer
fields.summary: Pest controllers report unusually high wasp activity across the UK this summer, linked to the warm, dry weather conditions. Experts explain their ecological importance and provide tips for safe coexistence as numbers surge.
fields.content:
Pest control expert John Horsley experienced wasps firsthand while gardening when one crawled down his shirt and stung him multiple times. He states such encounters have become more common after recent years of reduced wasp activity.

Horsley, representing the British Pest Control Association, reports a significant increase in callouts related to wasps this season. Issues include larger nests appearing earlier than usual and heightened nuisance in public spaces. These insects are currently raising offspring but will soon seek sugary foods as summer peaks before dying off.

"It's been a very good year for them," Horsley observes, linking the population surge to weather conditions that included the warmest spring in over 50 years. Last summer had been the UK's coolest in nearly a decade.

Wasp on a yellow flower against blue sky

Professor Seirian Sumner, a leading wasp expert at University College London, notes scientific data won't be available immediately but confirms weather patterns suggest "it's going to be a good year for wasps." The UK hosts about 9,000 wasp species, mostly solitary and harmless to humans.

Social wasps like the common yellowjacket rank as Britain's second most disliked insect after spiders. However, these species serve as crucial ecosystem regulators. "They're apex predators and natural pest controllers," Professor Sumner explains. Their absence would trigger domino effects throughout agricultural and natural landscapes.

Close-up of wasp on green leaf

While global insect populations decline due to pesticides and climate change, common wasps maintain stable numbers. The European hornet is expanding northward in the UK amid warming temperatures, and Asian hornet sightings are increasing. Butterflies and ladybirds also appear more abundant this summer compared to last year's low point.

Living alongside wasps - without being stung

Nikki Banfield of conservation group Buglife emphasizes respecting wasps' ecological role: "They have a really valid purpose in the natural world." She suggests leaving small amounts of jam or fruit juice away from human activity areas to distract them.

Detailed view of common wasp wings, abdomen and stinger

Experts strongly advise against swatting or panicking around wasps, as this provokes aggression. Horsley warns that stings can cause severe allergic reactions and urges seeking professional help for nest removal. "Don't disturb them and stay away where possible," he cautions.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Women's Safety App Hacked Exposing Dating User Images and Data
fields.summary: A popular US dating safety app designed to help women vet potential partners suffered a security breach exposing 72,000 user images—including verification photos—along with thousands of posts and private messages, prompting concerns about privacy violations.
fields.content:
A dating safety application intended to help women screen potential romantic partners has been compromised by hackers, resulting in the exposure of sensitive user data. The platform called Tea Dating Advice reported unauthorized access to 72,000 images uploaded by its 1.6 million members, including verification photos showing women with identification documents. According to the company's privacy policy, such verification images should be "deleted immediately" after authentication.

The Scope of the Breach

Tea Dating Advice confirmed the breach impacted users who registered before February 2024. The company stated it responded quickly and is collaborating with cybersecurity specialists to address the incident. Beyond the personal images, hackers accessed an additional 59,000 files spanning posts, comments, and direct messages dating back over two years. Tea maintains the breached photos "can in no way be linked to posts within" the app and highlights screenshot blocking features designed to prevent content leakage.

Founded in November 2022 by software engineer Sean Cook, Tea saw rapid growth amid controversy over its functions. Cook claimed inspiration came from witnessing his mother’s unsafe online dating encounters, stating he was "shocked by how easy it was for catfish, scammers and criminals to take advantage of women."

App Functionality and Criticisms

The app enables background checks on men including marital status, sex offender registry lookups, and reverse image searches to combat fake profiles. Its most debated feature lets women anonymously share "red flag" warnings or positive "green flag" endorsements about dates. Despite intended safety benefits, critics denounced Tea as anti-male and warned it risks enabling defamation and privacy invasions against men.

Past legal challenges targeted similar platforms, including a dismissed lawsuit against Facebook’s parent company Meta over comments made in groups like "Are We Dating the Same Guy." Tea has faced heightened scrutiny alongside its increasing popularity, promising members it’s "taking every step to protect this community—now and always" in response to the data breach.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: England's Euro 2025 Victory Becomes Year's Most-Watched TV Moment
fields.summary: England women's dramatic penalty shootout victory against Spain in the Euro 2025 final set viewing records, becoming 2025's highest-rated TV moment with 12.2 million peak viewers on BBC platforms and 16.2 million combined across broadcasters, cementing the Lionesses' historic title defense.
fields.content:
England clinched their second consecutive European Championship by defeating world champions Spain in a gripping Euro 2025 final, triumphing in a penalty shootout after a 1-1 draw in Basel. The dramatic match became the year's most-watched television event, attracting a peak live audience of 12.2 million viewers across BBC platforms.

Chloe Kelly sealed England's victory with the decisive penalty, replicating her extra-time heroics from the Euro 2022 final against Germany. Goalkeeper Hannah Hampton emerged as another hero by saving two Spanish penalties during the shootout that followed regular time.

Broadcast figures reveal unprecedented viewer engagement: BBC One alone achieved an 11.6 million peak audience, capturing 59% of all UK television viewers during the match's climax. Combined coverage across BBC and ITV reached a 16.2 million peak, while averaging 12 million viewers throughout the entire broadcast.

Digital platforms recorded massive traffic with 4.2 million streams on BBC iPlayer and the BBC Sport website and app. The BBC Sport live page generated 11.4 million page views during the final. Overall, the broadcaster's tournament coverage reached 22.1 million people on television and 231 million views across BBC Sport social media channels.

Alex Kay-Jelski, BBC Director of Sport, described the event as a landmark moment: "The kind of moment people will remember exactly where they were. The incredible Lionesses took millions on an emotional rollercoaster, with younger audiences engaging in huge numbers through our digital platforms."

A graphic that reads 'Follow our women's football TikTok' with a picture of a mobile phone

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Alleged Serial Gang Member Arrested in Michigan After Previous Release
fields.summary: U.S. Customs and Border Protection arrested an alleged Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang member in Michigan after he was previously released into the country. Manuel Zavala-Lopez faces multiple violent criminal charges across several states following a traffic stop that revealed his illegal status and gang affiliation.
fields.content:
Customs and Border Protection officers detained Manuel Zavala-Lopez, an alleged Tren de Aragua gang member, during a traffic stop near Detroit on Wednesday. The Venezuelan national had entered the United States in May 2023 under the current administration and was subsequently released before this recent apprehension.

The arrest in Shelby Township occurred after officers discovered a counterfeit license plate on a vehicle. All three occupants were determined to be unlawfully present in the U.S., with Zavala-Lopez identified as a suspected member of the Venezuelan criminal organization.

Department of Homeland Security Assistant Secretary Tricia McLaughlin stated: "Zavala-Lopez is a serial criminal who's traveled across the U.S. committing violent crimes. He has an outstanding warrant for failure to appear on a felony assault charge in Denver, Colorado. He has also been charged with robbery resulting in physical injury, criminal possession of weapon intent to use, assault, possession of stolen property and petty larceny in New York."

Detroit Sector Chief Patrol Agent John R. Morris emphasized: "This arrest removes another dangerous criminal illegal alien from our country and enhances public safety. This marks the second arrest of a gang member from a foreign terrorist organization this month, underscoring the value of interagency cooperation."

Detained Tren de Aragua gang members

Lt. Mark Benedettini of the Shelby Township Police Department affirmed local authorities' commitment: "This gang member, who had no business being in our country, let alone roaming our streets, represents our department's dedication to community safety and removing dangerous individuals."

This incident follows the arrest of two unlawfully present Salvadoran nationals by Detroit CBP in early July. Those arrests occurred after Border Patrol agents responded to an altercation at a Sterling Heights motel.

Members of Venezuelan Tren de Aragua gang

Commenting on the previous arrests, Detroit Sector Acting Chief Patrol Agent Javier Geronimo Jr. declared: "This operation exemplifies how our agents and law enforcement partners protect communities by removing violent criminals from our country."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: 7,000 Daily Steps Offer Nearly Same Health Benefits as 10,000, Study Finds
fields.summary: Walking just 7,000 steps daily provides nearly identical health advantages to 10,000 steps, including a 47% lower mortality risk, according to a comprehensive review of global research. Even modest increases from sedentary levels yield significant benefits.
fields.content:
New research challenges the traditional 10,000-step target, revealing that 7,000 daily steps provide nearly identical health advantages. A University of Sydney analysis of 57 studies across more than 10 countries tracked participants' steps and health outcomes, finding that 7,000 steps daily improved eight critical health areas including heart disease, dementia and depressive symptoms.

"Any increase in daily steps, even modest ones like 4,000 steps, delivers health benefits compared to very low activity levels," stated lead researcher Dr. Ding. "Significant health improvements occur when people increase from 2,000 to anywhere between 5,000 and 7,000 steps daily."

The Lancet Public Health-published research indicates that while exceeding 7,000 steps offers additional benefits, the rate of improvement slows beyond this threshold. Regular 10,000-step achievers should maintain their routines rather than reducing activity.

Mortality Risk Reduction

The study revealed walking 7,000 steps daily reduces mortality risk by 47% - nearly matching the 10,000-step benchmark. Researchers observed substantial health gains when individuals progressed from sedentary levels of around 2,000 steps to the 4,000-7,000 step range.

Step count

For those struggling to reach 7,000 steps, Ding emphasized that gradual increases matter: "Even small incremental boosts like moving from 2,000 to 4,000 steps daily provide measurable health improvements."

Practical Application

Incorporating movement into daily routines proves most sustainable, according to researchers. "Everyday activities count - like exiting public transport one stop early or choosing stairs over elevators," Ding advised. "These small, incidental movements accumulate significantly toward health benefits."

Woman fitness walking

The team acknowledged study limitations including sample size constraints for certain health outcomes. While walking offers substantial benefits, researchers noted it shouldn't replace comprehensive fitness regimes. Future work will focus on updating physical activity guidelines based on these findings.

"Our research shifts focus from perfection to progress," said Ding. "Meaningful health improvements occur with even modest increases in daily movement patterns."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Turnberry: Scotland's Iconic Golf Resort and Trump Renovation Story
fields.summary: Discover Turnberry, Scotland's legendary golf resort transformed by Donald Trump through a $100 million renovation. This coastal property features world-class courses with volcanic island views, a historic lighthouse, castle ruins, and hosted the iconic 1977 'Duel in the Sun' British Open match.
fields.content:
Trump's Transformation

President Trump detailed extensive renovations at Turnberry after purchasing the financially struggling property, investing approximately $100 million to restore its grandeur. During his Scotland visit, he noted extensive damage from weather, stating windows required replacement after enduring 125 storms. Improved facilities now showcase higher quality, with Trump emphasizing: If you take a look at the windows in the various dining rooms, they're magnificent, and they're new, and they're much better looking than what was that same exact look — other than a much higher quality. Restoration employed local craftspeople and included rebuilding the deteriorated ceiling structure.

Donald Trump golfing at Turnberry

The Ailsa Course, named after the volcanic island Ailsa Craig visible across the Irish Sea, ranks among Golf Digest's global top 10 courses. Trump played a round here during his July visit, having acquired the property in 2014 when it was renamed Trump Turnberry.

Historical Landmarks and Legacy

The resort originated in 1901 as Turnberry Station Hotel, reflecting its proximity to a railway line according to Historic Environment Scotland records. On the coastline stands the 1873-built Turnberry Lighthouse, towering nearly 80 feet with 76 steps to its peak. Nearby lie the ruins of Turnberry Castle, adding medieval heritage to the landscape.

Aerial view of Trump Turnberry golf course

Turnberry cemented its golf legacy by hosting the legendary 1977 British Open duel between Tom Watson and Jack Nicklaus, dubbed Duel in the Sun after Watson won by one stroke. Commemorating this event, the resort's 19th-hole restaurant carries the same historic name.

Scenic view of Turnberry golf course

Trump driving golf cart at Turnberry

Shoreline at Turnberry golf resort

Personal Ties to Scotland

Trump participated in a ribbon-cutting ceremony for Aberdeen's new MacLeod Course alongside son Eric Trump. He credited Scottish actor Sean Connery for permitting assistance, saying: Sean Connery helped get me the permits. If it weren't for Sean Connery, we wouldn't have those great courses. The property holds familial significance, with the MacLeod name honoring Trump's mother Mary MacLeod.

Donald Trump and his mother Mary MacLeod

Source: Original Article

fields.title: NFL Host Expresses Anguish Over Deadly Shooting Near League's NYC Headquarters
fields.summary: An NFL host expressed profound grief after a fatal shooting occurred in the New York City building housing the league's headquarters, leaving one law enforcement officer dead and an NFL employee seriously injured. The gunman reportedly blamed the NFL and intended to target the organization but entered the wrong elevator bay.
fields.content:
NFL Network host Kyle Brandt shared his devastation following a deadly shooting incident at 345 Park Avenue – the location of the National Football League's New York headquarters. Though personally unharmed as he works at a different downtown location, Brandt emphasized the tragedy occurring during what should be a celebratory period for the league.

"Heartbreaking news," Brandt stated solemnly. "This is a time of great excitement, joy, hope and rebirth for the company, and some of that was taken yesterday. It's horrible news. Terribly sad to hear it. We at 'Good Morning Football' deeply share our support for the victims' loved ones."
