Scene outside NFL building where the mass shooting took place in NYC

NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell confirmed in an internal memo that one league employee sustained serious injuries during the attack but is currently in stable condition. The memo expressed gratitude to responding officers, specifically honoring Officer Islam who lost his life during the incident.

"We are deeply grateful to the law enforcement officers who responded to this threat quickly and decisively and to Officer Islam, who gave his life to protect others," Goodell wrote in the message shared with employees.

Ambulance at 345 Park

New York City Mayor Eric Adams identified the shooter as Shane Tamura and revealed the attack was deliberately aimed at the NFL. Addressing the media, Adams explained Tamura erroneously selected the wrong elevator bank while attempting to reach the league's offices.

"He seemed to have blamed the NFL," Mayor Adams stated, noting the gunman alluded to suffering from chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE) and held grievances against the organization. "The NFL headquarters was located in the building, and he mistakenly went up the wrong elevator bank."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Elliptical vs. Treadmill: Choosing Your Ideal Cardio Machine
fields.summary: Comparing elliptical machines and treadmills for fitness goals, this analysis explores differences in impact, calorie burn, injury considerations and functionality. Featuring expert insights from personal trainer Chris Parnell, we break down which machine suits various workout needs.
fields.content:
Two of the most popular gym fixtures deliver cardiovascular benefits but have distinct differences in functionality. Both treadmills and ellipticals elevate your heart rate and provide adjustable speed, incline and resistance. Their mechanisms, however, significantly impact how they support fitness journeys.

According to personal trainer Chris Parnell, treadmills offer movement specificity aligning with natural human locomotion. With a motorized belt allowing running in place, they excel for structured training regardless of weather conditions. The machines facilitate interval work through customizable speed adjustments and incline challenges targeting posterior muscles.

Key Elliptical Advantages

Ellipticals feature dual pedals and handles creating an elliptical motion that mimics walking and running without impact. "This low-impact quality proves particularly valuable for joint protection," notes Parnell. The fixed-path design prevents foot-strike vibrations while supporting balanced movement patterns, making ellipticals optimal for users with weighty builds or existing lower-body concerns.

The machine's stability enables relaxed, extended workouts. Its reduced coordination demands allow distractions like reading or viewing entertainment without safety risks, easing lengthy sessions.

Calorie Burn Comparison

Both machines effectively contribute to calorie expenditure through consistent training, though treadmill running typically yields higher rates. The Compendium of Physical Activities indicates vigorous treadmill running at 7 mph burns approximatlely 11 METs versus 9 METs for hard elliptical work. For a 180-pound individual, calculated expenditure reaches 15.5 calories per minute on treadmills versus 12.7 on ellipticals.

Decision Factors

Selecting equipment involves weighing factors like impact tolerance, weight considerations, injury background and training preferences rather than definitive superiority. Treadmills excel in run-specific training progression and interval versatility, while ellipticals prioritize sustainability and joint protection. Both grant substantial cardiovascular benefits when integrated thoughtfully into fitness routines.

For home gyms, numerous reputable models suit different needs on both sides of this cardio equipment spectrum.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Artlogic and ArtCloud Merge to Transform Art Market Technology
fields.summary: Leading art-tech companies Artlogic and ArtCloud have merged to create a combined platform serving over 6,000 galleries and collectors worldwide, aiming to reshape the digital infrastructure of the art market amid a broader industry consolidation trend.
fields.content:
In a significant consolidation within the art technology sector, inventory management leader Artlogic and gallery software provider ArtCloud have merged to redefine the digital foundations of the global art marketplace. This strategic partnership connects two complementary technology portfolios used widely across the industry.

A Strategic Combination

The merger integrates Artlogic's established inventory systems and website solutions—currently serving over 5,500 clients across 70 countries—with ArtCloud's advanced tools for collector engagement, AI-driven analytics, and integrated payment solutions. The combined entity now supports more than 6,000 galleries, artists, and collectors while managing 15 million artworks globally.

Artlogic CEO Mike Profit characterized the move as forward-looking infrastructure development. "We are not merging to compete in a momentary race," Profit explained. "We’re building durable, flexible technology that will empower galleries, collectors, and institutions well into the future."

Alex West, ArtCloud's CEO who becomes Chief Innovation Officer of the merged company, emphasized efficiency benefits. "While we can't lower gallery rents," West noted, "we're creating systems to maximize their operational impact through smarter digital infrastructure."

Industry-Wide Transformation

The merger arrives during concentrated consolidation across the art market. Beowolff Capital recently offered to acquire digital marketplace Artnet, potentially uniting it with Artsy under one umbrella. Beowolff aims to delist Artnet from the Frankfurt Stock Exchange to develop a private, AI-enhanced art ecosystem.

This month also featured Winston Art Group joining with blockchain analytics firm Artory to establish the Winston Artory Group, blending traditional appraisal with data verification technology. Additionally, prominent art veterans including Brett Gorvy and Philip Hoffman launched New Perspectives Art Partners, an invitation-only consultancy targeting complex industry challenges.

Artlogic and ArtCloud will continue separate operations temporarily while integrating technologies internally.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Man Convicted for Airport Attack on Police Officers
fields.summary: A man has been found guilty of assaulting two police officers during a violent disturbance at Manchester Airport in July last year. The attack, captured on video, left one officer with a broken nose and emotional trauma.
fields.content:
Mohammed Fahir Amaaz, 20, has been convicted of assaulting two Greater Manchester Police officers during a violent altercation at Manchester Airport on July 23, 2023. Video footage of the incident circulated widely on social media.

After a three-week trial at Liverpool Crown Court, Amaaz was found guilty of causing actual bodily harm to PC Lydia Ward and assaulting PC Ellie Cook, who is classified as an emergency worker. Additionally, he was convicted of assaulting a member of the public, Abdulkareem Ismaeil, at a Starbucks cafe in the airport's arrivals area earlier that same day.

The jury could not reach verdicts regarding accusations that Amaaz and his 26-year-old brother Muhammad Ahmed assaulted PC Zachary Marsden causing actual bodily harm during the same incident.

Officers entered the airport parking pay station area after receiving reports of a man matching Amaaz's description headbutting a civilian. Prosecutors explained that Amaaz resisted when grabbed from behind at a ticket machine, sparking the violence.

CCTV footage presented as evidence revealed PC Ward sustaining a broken nose from an extremely forceful blow to her face. She later testified: "Everything went black. I could feel blood pouring out of my nose. I was terrified and had never experienced that level of violence before in my life."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Fukushima Nuclear Plant Evacuated Following Tsunami Alert
fields.summary: Thousands of workers were evacuated from Japan's Fukushima nuclear plant after tsunami alerts sounded across the country. The warnings followed an 8.7 magnitude earthquake off Russia's far eastern coast, reviving traumatic memories of the 2011 nuclear disaster. While no abnormalities were reported at the plant, the incident highlights ongoing safety concerns at the facility where hundreds of tons of radioactive material remain.
fields.content:
Workers at Japan's Fukushima nuclear plant evacuated on Wednesday following tsunami warnings triggered by a powerful offshore earthquake. Plant operator Tepco confirmed all 4,000 employees left the facility after alerts sounded nationwide, stating no abnormalities were detected. The evacuation occurred after an 8.7 magnitude earthquake struck near Russia's far eastern coast, prompting tsunami alerts across Pacific regions.

The warnings brought back painful memories of the 2011 Fukushima disaster for local residents. In March of that year, a 9.0-magnitude earthquake and subsequent tsunami killed over 18,000 people and caused multiple meltdowns at the nuclear plant after floodwaters disabled emergency generators. Fourteen years later, hundreds of tons of highly radioactive material remain at the site, posing ongoing cleanup challenges.

What happened at the Fukushima nuclear site?

On March 11, 2011, the Great East Japan Earthquake struck just 97km north of Fukushima at 14:46 local time. The earthquake and resulting tsunami caused hydrogen explosions in reactor buildings while knocking out cooling systems, ultimately leading to three nuclear meltdowns. Additional chemical explosions severely damaged facilities and released radioactive materials into the atmosphere and Pacific Ocean.

Japanese authorities declared a 30km exclusion zone around the plant, forcing more than 150,000 residents to evacuate due to radiation concerns. Today, significant portions of the area remain restricted with abandoned homes and empty towns serving as reminders of the catastrophe.

Abandoned house on main street in Fukushima prefecture

Why is it so hard to clean up the nuclear waste?

Approximately 880 metric tons of extremely hazardous material—a mixture of melted nuclear fuel and reactor debris—remain inside the Fukushima plant. Removing this radioactive waste represents the greatest challenge in decommissioning the facility safely. The cleanup process is estimated to require tens of thousands of workers over 30-40 years at a projected cost of 21.5 trillion yen ($145 billion).

Tepco recently announced a delay in full-scale debris removal until 2037 or later—pushing back preparations by at least 12-15 years. This marks another setback to the government's goal of completing decommissioning by 2051. Shunji Matsuoka, environmental economics professor at Waseda University, expressed doubt: "Who really believes all 880 tons of debris can be removed in 14 years between 2037 and 2051? Maintaining an unrealistic goal is not good when considering Fukushima's recovery."

Additionally, over one million tons of treated radioactive water stored in more than 1,000 tanks pose ongoing challenges. To free land for new decommissioning facilities, Japan began releasing treated water into the ocean in 2023 despite controversy, though UN atomic regulators deemed the environmental impact "negligible."

Is Japan shifting back to nuclear power?

Japan initially moved away from nuclear energy after Fukushima but has gradually reversed course. An energy plan released this year called for "maximizing" nuclear power to meet growing demand from sectors like artificial intelligence and semiconductors. This week, utility company Kansai Electric Power announced it would explore building a new reactor—a project suspended since 2011. However, local opposition persists, and Wednesday's tsunami alert may heighten safety concerns.

Japanese meteorological officials confirmed tsunami waves had reached parts of the coast including Fukushima, with possible heights up to 3 meters (9 feet). Thousands received evacuation orders.

Woman watches television broadcast of tsunami warning in Japan

Why do so many earthquakes happen in Japan?

Japan experiences about 1,500 earthquakes annually due to its position on the Pacific "Ring of Fire." Considered among the most earthquake-prepared nations, Japanese citizens train through drills from primary school, and buildings feature earthquake-resistant designs. Despite these measures, experts warn of a 70-80% chance of a magnitude 8 or 9 earthquake occurring along Japan's Nankai Trough within 30 years. Such an event could generate tsunamis up to 30 meters (100 feet) and potentially claim 300,000 lives along the Pacific coastline.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: US Economy Rebounds as Import Drop Sparks Trump Fed Criticism
fields.summary: A significant decline in imports helped drive an unexpected 3% economic rebound in the second quarter, prompting President Trump to renew his criticism of Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell ahead of an interest rate decision.
fields.content:
A sharp reduction in imports linked to President Trump's tariff policies contributed to strong US economic growth between April and June, according to new Commerce Department data. The world's largest economy expanded at a 3% annual rate during this period, rebounding from a contraction in the previous quarter.

Analysts stress this growth primarily reflected sudden trade fluctuations as businesses rushed goods into the country ahead of new tariffs, rather than underlying economic strength. The Commerce Department report showed the decline in imports outpaced US export reductions, leading to a temporary growth surge.

Seizing on the positive data, President Trump criticized Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell ahead of a key interest rate announcement. Using his "Mr Too Late" nickname for Powell, Trump wrote on social media: "WAY BETTER THAN EXPECTED! 'Too Late' MUST NOW LOWER THE RATE. No Inflation! Let people buy, and refinance, their homes!"

The Federal Reserve typically cuts interest rates during economic weakness and raises them when inflation accelerates. Officials have maintained rates this year due to uncertainty about tariffs and tax policies, despite inflation easing to 2.1% in the second quarter from 3.7% earlier in the year.

Some analysts believe the growth rebound supports the Fed's cautious approach. Bernard Yaros, lead US economist at Oxford Economics, noted: "The economy's resilience will allow the Federal Reserve to hold still and assess the unfolding tariff impact on consumer prices before pivoting to interest rate cuts in December."

Other data in the report suggested cooling economic momentum. Consumer spending grew just 1.4% in the second quarter compared to the previous three months, and a key measure tracking spending and investment slowed to 1.2%. Federal spending declined as non-defense expenditures dropped, while business investment weakened.

Jim Thorne, chief market strategist for Wellington-Altus Private Wealth, cautioned: "Forget about the headline number. The underlying data suggests an economy that is losing momentum, though price pressures are starting to alleviate." These mixed signals leave the Fed navigating complex economic conditions as it weighs future rate decisions.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Health Minister Calls Junior Doctors for Crucial Pay Talks
fields.summary: UK Health Secretary Wes Streeting has invited junior doctors' union leaders for renewed negotiations next week to resolve a prolonged pay dispute, despite warning that their recent strike action damaged government goodwill.
fields.content:
Health Secretary Wes Streeting has summoned junior doctors' representatives for fresh discussions next week to address an ongoing pay conflict. This follows a formal request for talks submitted by the British Medical Association (BMA) on Tuesday evening.

Streeting responded that while pay terms remain non-negotiable, he would reopen dialogue on working conditions. These negotiations will focus on career advancement pathways, examination fees, and working schedules — topics previously discussed before talks collapsed last week.

The minister explicitly cautioned that the union exhausted government goodwill through its latest five-day walkout, which concluded Wednesday. He noted this was the 12th strike by junior doctors since spring 2023 and the first under the new Labour administration.

Though the BMA has yet to publicly address the invitation, sources indicate their earlier letter specifically demanded pay discussions. Streeting called this appeal "ironic" since he stated negotiations were still open while planning the recent walkout.

'Squandered goodwill'

Following Labour's election victory, Streeting previously brokered a pause in strikes that secured junior doctors a 22% salary increase over two years, supplemented by another 5.4% average raise this year. The BMA renewed strikes arguing current pay remains 20% below 2008 levels when adjusted for inflation.

In his Wednesday letter, Streeting branded the latest strike "deeply disappointing" and "entirely unnecessary," asserting that continued negotiations could have delivered tangible workplace improvements. He emphasized the walkout's disruptive impact on patient care.

"Your action has also been self-defeating because you have squandered the considerable goodwill you had with me and this government," Streeting wrote. Despite this, he confirmed willingness to meet next week to resume discussions.

NHS authorities reported reduced disruption compared to previous strikes, with many hospitals maintaining over 80% of normal non-urgent procedures like joint replacements — a significant improvement from earlier 50% capacity levels during walkouts.

Junior doctors, composing nearly half of the medical workforce, include physicians ranging from recent graduates to those with up to ten years of clinical experience.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Specialist School for Autistic Children Approved in Kirklees
fields.summary: Kirklees Council has granted planning permission for a new purpose-built facility accommodating up to 180 autistic students, relocating Woodley School from Huddersfield to Almondbury as part of broader special educational needs improvements.
fields.content:
Approval has been granted for a specialized educational facility designed to serve up to 180 autistic students aged five to 19. Woodley School and College will relocate from its current Dog Kennel Bank location in Huddersfield to Fernside Avenue in Almondbury.

The council emphasized the new custom-built environment will significantly enhance support systems for neurodiverse learners while providing localized access to specialist education. Kirklees Council's cabinet member for education Jane Rylah stated: "The new school will provide a tailored environment where pupils can thrive and reach their full potential."

Preparatory site clearance commenced in May, with construction now advancing. Rylah described the planning consent as "a significant milestone," adding: "Woodley School delivers excellent education and support, and this purpose-built facility will extend that offer to more children and young people." She further expressed anticipation for the project's positive community impact.

Expanding Special Educational Support

This initiative aligns with Kirklees Council's broader strategy to transform Special Educational Needs and Disabilities (SEND) provisions across the district. Parallel projects include rebuilding and relocating Joseph Norton Academy, which serves students with social, emotional and mental health requirements. Additional SEND placements are being created in other local schools to expand capacity throughout the region.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Record Sewage Spills Pollute England's Waterways for 3.6 Million Hours
fields.summary: England experienced 3.6 million hours of sewage spills in 2024 – a record amount – as aging infrastructure and insufficient monitoring contributed to pollution in rivers and seas, posing significant risks to public health and wildlife according to Environment Agency data.
fields.content:
Water companies released raw sewage into England's waterways for a record 3.6 million hours during 2024, according to Environment Agency statistics. While limited discharges are permitted during heavy rainfall to prevent system overload, environmental groups warn current spill levels threaten wildlife and swimmers' safety.

A major report by the Independent Water Commission has recommended overhauling sewage spill regulations, improving monitoring systems, and implementing stricter penalties for violations.

How much sewage is released into the seas and rivers in England?

The 2024 sewage spill duration represented a slight increase from 2023, though the total number of individual spills decreased - indicating longer average discharge duration. Additional Environment Agency figures revealed record-high pollution incidents from sewage and other contaminants in 2024.

Among these incidents, 75 were classified as serious threats to human health and aquatic ecosystems. Thames Water accounted for 33 of these severe cases. Water UK described spills as "unacceptable" but outlined comprehensive infrastructure upgrades intended to eliminate sewage discharges.

Wales registered an 11% decrease in spill duration but saw pollution incidents reach a 10-year peak. Northern Ireland lacks real-time spill monitoring, while Scotland collects data from just 27% of overflow points.

Why is sewage released into the sea and rivers?

Most UK regions operate combined sewer systems channeling both rainwater and household wastewater through shared pipes. During heavy rainfall exceeding ground absorption capacity, overloaded treatment plants risk flooding neighborhoods. To prevent this, systems intentionally discharge excess flow into waterways through overflow outlets.

What is a dry spill?

Dry spills occur when companies release untreated sewage without significant rainfall, violating permit conditions. Industry regulator Ofwat attributes these to poor wastewater facility management. Investigations uncovered approximately 6,000 potential illegal dry spills during 2022.

Even during wet weather, permits require partial sewage treatment before release.

A diagram showing the process of sewage being spilled into waterways. The top image shows an illegal spill in dry weather where household wastewater comes from pipes on the right and partly drops down into the pipes to the treatment plant and some is spilt out into the rivers/sea. The second image is normal operation where there is no spilling, and the third diagram shows a legal spill where rainwater is entering in a separate pipe from the top and both wastewater and water are spilled into waterways.

What is being done to tackle sewage discharges?

Outdated infrastructure remains a key contributor to spills. Regulator Ofwat has approved £104 billion for water company upgrades across England and Wales through 2028, including £20 billion specifically targeting sewage reduction. Water UK terms this the largest sewer modernization since Victorian times.

Critics highlight substantial customer bill increases while firms continue shareholder dividend payments. The Water Commission, chaired by former Bank of England deputy governor Sir Jon Cunliffe, has proposed 88 regulatory reforms.

What are the health risks of swimming in polluted water?

Leading scientists warned in May 2024 about growing health dangers from river faecal contamination, pushing for enhanced water testing. Exposure introduces bacteria like salmonella and E.coli which cause gastrointestinal illness, and viruses such as hepatitis A potentially triggering liver infections.

Getty Images Seven male rowers can be seen in white bibs and sunglasses in a yellow scull. There is significant splash from the river being sprayed around the rowers, and the sunlight is reflecting off the water.

How can I check if the sea near me is clean?

Between May and September, the Environment Agency regularly tests water quality at English bathing spots, issuing daily pollution forecasts for some areas. Location-specific data is available via agency websites, with similar systems operating in Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland.

Water UK's National Storm Overflow Hub provides near real-time discharge notifications across England, though it excludes volume measurements or faecal pathogen data.

How clean are UK waters overall?

While consistent sewage monitoring remains relatively new, broader water quality tracking has continued for decades. Only 16% of England's assessed surface waters achieved "good" ecological status in 2023. Performance was better elsewhere: roughly 66% met standards in Scotland, compared to 40% in Wales and 31% in Northern Ireland.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: EE fixes mobile network outage following recurring technical faults
fields.summary: EE has resolved a technical failure that disrupted voice services for customers over consecutive days, with the company confirming overnight repairs and ongoing monitoring after similar outages earlier this week affected emergency and business communications.
fields.content:
EE mobile network users experienced renewed service disruptions leaving many unable to make or receive calls, marking the second such incident within days. Hundreds reported the latest connectivity issues occurring within the last 24 hours, following a larger outage earlier in the week that impacted both mobile and landline services.

A spokesperson for BT Group, EE's parent company, stated the network resumed normal operation after overnight maintenance work. However, they acknowledged continued vigilance, saying teams were "monitoring" stability throughout Saturday as new problem reports emerged.

Affected customers detailed significant inconveniences, including an 84-year-old user unable to place daily calls to family members she described as "vital." One frustrated Essex resident reported entering a third consecutive day without service, criticizing the "deafening" lack of communication from the provider.

Business operations also suffered, with an Exeter-based estate agent confirming multiple offices experienced call failures. "This is still an ongoing issue," he emphasized, highlighting the problem's persistence beyond EE's initial resolution timeline.

This disruption follows a previous outage where users couldn't connect to emergency services, including 999 calls. BT previously apologized for that incident on Thursday, attributing it to a technical fault in voice services infrastructure.

Responding to the recurring failures, EE announced enhanced monitoring measures to prevent future occurrences while extending apologies: "We sincerely apologise for any inconvenience this issue has caused."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ozzy Osbourne Given Emotional Send-Off in Birmingham Procession
fields.summary: Thousands gathered in Birmingham as Ozzy Osbourne's family accompanied the music legend's coffin on a final journey through his hometown. Sharon Osbourne laid roses among fan tributes while crowds chanted his name to the sounds of Black Sabbath songs.
fields.content:
Family members joined fans in Birmingham to bid farewell to rock legend Ozzy Osbourne during an emotional procession guided by brass versions of Black Sabbath anthems. Sharon Osbourne, visibly tearful, placed a pink rose amid colorful floral tributes with support from children Kelly and Jack, as crowds rhythmically chanted "Ozzy! Ozzy! Ozzy!".

The procession featured a hearse carrying Osbourne's coffin topped with a purple floral cross, moving through streets that witnessed historic moments of his career. This tribute came one week after the musician's death at 76 and just a month following his final concert for 40,000 fans at Villa Park stadium.

On the route past Villa Park and into Broad Street, supporters wearing Black Sabbath merchandise spontaneously sang and threw flowers. The procession paused at Black Sabbath Bridge—a location transformed into a shrine with messages, beer bottles, and symbolic bat-shaped balloons referencing Ozzy's infamous 1982 on-stage bat bite incident.

A picture of the back of the hearse showing an Ozzy floral tribute alongside the coffin, with crowds behind it

Sharon, supported by Kelly and Jack as well as Ozzy's other children Aimee and Louis, added her tribute to the memorial. Slipknot DJ Sid Wilson joined the emotional gathering, where family members embraced while absorbing heartfelt chants from the crowd.

Supporters shouted expressions like "We love you Ozzy!" and "Sharon we love you!". Sharon responded by raising her hands in a peace gesture before the procession continued through the mourner-filled streets.

A crowd of Ozzy fans standing in front of an advertising screen showing the words Ozzy forever

Attendee Pete Coles from Nuneaton noted the celebratory yet respectful mood, stating that being there let him "embrace the atmosphere that's here, with all the emotions and people just here to sing the praises of this legend in music."

Eddie Hayes, who traveled four hours from Newcastle, called Ozzy "purely an individual" with no equal in music history. Fellow fan Will Brain described the procession as "poetic," adding: "Seeing the family and how upset they were, that was quite hard to see."

A Black Sabbath Bridge sign with numerous tributes stuck to the railings, a bat ballon above them, and the heads of the crowd in the foreground

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump Signals Ukrainians Likely to Remain in US Following Policy Confusion
fields.summary: Former President Trump has indicated Ukrainians already in the United States will likely be permitted to stay, as the Department of Homeland Security reversed an order that blocked new arrivals. Trump also issued a warning to Russian President Putin regarding peace talks with Ukraine.
fields.content:
Policy Uncertainty Resolved

Trump addressed the status of Ukrainian refugees during recent remarks, stating: "We have a lot of people that came in from Ukraine, and we're working with them." This follows eight months of confusion after the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) paused a U.S. admission program for Ukrainians on January 28.

When questioned about DHS actions prohibiting further Ukrainian arrivals, Trump responded: "We’re certainly not looking to hurt them. I’m looking at that, and there were some people that think that’s appropriate, and some people don’t, and I’ll be making a decision pretty soon." DHS later clarified the suspension notice was issued erroneously, though the error prolonged uncertainty for Ukrainians affected by Russia's invasion.

Ukrainians flee Russia's war

Peace Ultimatum to Russia

In parallel developments, Trump delivered a stern warning to Russian leader Vladimir Putin on Tuesday, giving him ten days to negotiate a peace agreement with Ukraine. Failure to comply would trigger secondary sanctions targeting Russia's primary export—oil. This move intensifies pressure amid ongoing conflict.

War in Ukraine

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Sensitive Trump-Russia Probe Documents Found Hidden in FBI Burn Bags
fields.summary: Thousands of classified documents from the Trump-Russia investigation were discovered inside ‘burn bags’ within a previously undisclosed room at FBI headquarters, including the classified annex to the Durham report that will soon be made public.
fields.content:
Thousands of documents related to the Trump-Russia investigation were found inside sealed "burn bags" within a hidden sensitive compartmented information facility at FBI headquarters. Sources indicated that multiple bags contained classified materials including the classified annex to former special counsel John Durham's final report, which details underlying intelligence reviewed during his probe.

One source familiar with the annex's contents revealed that the intelligence it contains, while unclear at the time of collection, later predicted the FBI's actions with "alarming specificity." The source added, "The release of the classified annex will lend more credibility to the assertion that there was a coordinated plan inside the U.S. government to help the Clinton campaign stir up controversy connecting Trump to Russia."

FBI Director Kash Patel and his team uncovered the documents while responding to a request from Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley. Patel previously described discovering "a room full of documents and computer hard drives that no one had ever seen or heard of," allegedly hidden during former Director James Comey's tenure.

Patel sworn in to testify before the Senate

Grassley's office confirmed it is now reviewing the documents, which will result in a declassified version of Durham's annex being released to the public. The collection includes materials from the FBI's original Trump-Russia investigation known as Crossfire Hurricane, which began in July 2016.

Chuck Grassley in a dark suit, red tie, reaching out right hand on table, left hand on chair

CROSSFIRE HURRICANE

Patel, who previously led the House Intelligence Committee's probe into alleged Russia collusion, has been central to exposing issues with the investigation. His work contributed to discoveries that led the Justice Department to appoint special counsels Robert Mueller – who found no collusion – and John Durham, who determined the original probe was unfounded.

Robert Mueller served as the FBI's sixth director.

The Crossfire Hurricane investigation began based partly on the Steele dossier, funded by Hillary Clinton's campaign and the Democratic National Committee. Former Carter Page adviser Carter Page praised Patel's role: "While most members of Congress were ready to ignore the unprecedented civil rights abuses against the Trump campaign and myself, Kash Patel’s training made him the perfect advocate for exposing one of the greatest election interference scandals of all time."

One-time advisor to then-President-elect Donald Trump, Carter Page, addresses the audience during a presentation in Moscow on Dec. 12, 2016.

Patel co-authored the February 2018 Nunes memo, which revealed that the FBI used the dossier to obtain Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act warrants against Page without disclosing its Democratic funding origins. Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe testified that "no surveillance warrant would have been sought" without the dossier.

Former FBI Director James Comey, left, and current FBI Director Kash Patel.

Devin Nunes, who chaired the House Intelligence Committee during the investigation, stated: "Kash was instrumental in unraveling the Russia collusion hoax and finding evidence of government malfeasance despite constant stonewalling." The Justice Department's inspector general later validated the memo's central claims.

Andrew McCabe at hearing

Patel has since opened criminal investigations into former CIA Director John Brennan and former FBI Director James Comey. Meanwhile, Grassley's forthcoming release of Durham's annex is expected to provide unprecedented insight into the intelligence underpinning the controversial investigation.

John Durham

CIA Director John Ratcliffe testifies

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Experts Warn of Health Risks in Viral Watermelon Diet Trend
fields.summary: Health professionals caution about the viral watermelon diet, which promotes rapid weight loss through fruit-only consumption, highlighting risks including muscle loss and nutrient deficiencies despite potential hydration benefits.
fields.content:
The watermelon diet has surged in popularity as a rapid weight-loss method requiring individuals to consume primarily watermelon for three to seven consecutive days. While watermelon provides excellent hydration, healthcare experts warn this extreme approach deprives the body of essential nutrients needed for balanced functioning.

hand cutting watermelon

Dr. Mark Hyman, a functional medicine specialist, explained that although watermelon complements a nutrient-rich diet, exclusive consumption becomes problematic through nutritional imbalance. The human body naturally detoxifies itself without extreme diets, emphasizing that whole foods provide sustainable support for wellness and weight management. On social media's influence, Hyman noted it can be beneficial yet hazardous: "Health is personal, and your body isn’t an experiment. I encourage people to be curious, but also cautious."

Woman eating fresh salad, avocado, beans and vegetables.

Registered dietitian Ilana Muhlstein highlighted watermelon's beneficial compounds like l-citrulline and potassium, which aid detoxification, blood flow, and sodium flushing. However, she stressed that resulting weight reduction is temporary, primarily from water and muscle loss: "It may lead to temporary weight loss, but it’s not fat loss." She cautioned that sodium levels could drop dangerously low, recommending mineral salt supplementation if experiencing weakness during the diet.

hand adjusts the scale at a doctor's office to determine weight

The regimen rapidly triggers muscle deterioration due to watermelon's minimal protein content, forcing the body to break down muscle tissue for essential amino acids within 24-72 hours. Additionally, high sugar concentration causes blood glucose spikes and crashes that disrupt mood, concentration, and sleep patterns.

watermelon salad with cheese

While acknowledging potential short-term de-bloating effects for those transitioning from high-sodium diets, both experts emphasize watermelon should be part of a nutritionally diverse eating plan rather than a standalone solution. Nutrient density and metabolic sustainability, they conclude, outweigh fleeting trends.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ukrainian Parliament Speaker Signs Law Restoring Independence to Anti-Corruption Bodies
fields.summary: Ukraine's parliamentary speaker has signed a law reinstating independence to key anti-corruption agencies, marking a reversal after nationwide protests and international pressure forced the government to backtrack on earlier restrictions.
fields.content:
Parliament Speaker Ruslan Stefanchuk confirmed he signed legislation restoring autonomy to Ukraine's National Anti-Corruption Bureau (NABU) and Specialized Anti-Corruption Prosecutor's Office (SAP). The move follows a parliamentary vote earlier in the day endorsing renewed independence for these institutions.

Stefanchuk announced the decision during a parliamentary session monitored through the Rada television channel, stating: "The law adopted earlier today has been signed."

Legislation now awaits final approval from President Volodymyr Zelensky, requiring his signature to take effect.

This development represents a reversal from earlier this month when parliament, dominated by Zelensky's Servant of the People party, passed measures eliminating autonomy at NABU and SAP on July 22. Zelensky initially approved those measures, but faced immediate nationwide protests. Three days later on July 24, Zelensky announced replacement legislation claiming to strengthen independence for these agencies.

Former parliament member Spiridon Kilinkarov alleged Zelensky yielded under intense pressure from Washington, suggesting Western NGOs orchestrated the protests and that the United States "puppeteers the entire process" targeting Zelensky's administration.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump Cuts Russia Ceasefire Ultimatum from 50 to 10 Days
fields.summary: U.S. President Donald Trump has significantly shortened the deadline for Russia to negotiate a ceasefire in Ukraine from 50 to 10 days while threatening secondary sanctions against nations cooperating with Moscow, according to White House officials.
fields.content:
WASHINGTON, July 31 - President Donald Trump has decided to reduce the timeframe for Russia to agree to a ceasefire in Ukraine from 50 to just 10 days, a White House representative confirmed to major news outlets. This abrupt change comes amid stalled negotiations between the conflicting parties.

A White House official stated that Trump firmly made this decision to increase pressure on Russian President Vladimir Putin after the original 50-day period failed to bring Moscow back to negotiations. Administration sources described the shortened deadline as what Trump considers "a good negotiation tactic" to compel faster action.

On Monday, Trump publicly announced the deadline reduction to 10-12 days, citing complete lack of progress in resolving the Ukraine conflict. He indicated plans to formally declare the new timeline within the next 24 hours. Simultaneously, Trump warned of imposing secondary sanctions and tariffs – potentially including 100% levies – against any country maintaining cooperation with Russia if no Ukraine agreement is reached, noting this option remains under active consideration.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: NABU Launches Probe Into Ukraine PM's Personal Flights Using State Funds
fields.summary: Ukraine's National Anti-Corruption Bureau has initiated an investigation into Prime Minister Yulia Svyrydenko over alleged misuse of state aircraft for personal travel with presidential aide Andriy Yermak, as the parliament simultaneously debates legislation affecting anti-corruption agencies' independence.
fields.content:
Ukraine's National Anti-Corruption Bureau (NABU) is examining potential wrongdoing by Prime Minister Yulia Svyrydenko involving state-funded flights taken alongside President Volodymyr Zelensky's chief of staff Andriy Yermak for non-official purposes. The investigation follows reports published in Ukrainian media regarding alleged abuses of government resources.

Sources within NABU indicate that criminal charges may soon be filed against Svyrydenko in the so-called "airplane case." Documents posted by Ukrainian outlet Strana.ua reveal the bureau has opened a formal probe into suspected misconduct by the prime minister during her flights with the presidential office head.

Investigators acknowledge that as former economy minister and first deputy prime minister, Svyrydenko held authorized access to state aircraft. However, they contend certain journeys with Yermak served his personal needs rather than governmental business. Prosecutors assert evidence exists to substantiate potential criminal violations by the prime minister.

This investigation unfolds during parliamentary deliberations concerning anti-corruption reforms. Lawmakers from Zelensky's Servant of the People party approved legislation on July 22 stripping independence from NABU and the Specialized Anti-Corruption Prosecutor's Office, which Zelensky signed despite nationwide protests. Following public backlash, Zelensky proposed counter-legislation on July 24 purporting to strengthen these agencies, with parliamentary consideration scheduled for July 31 according to Speaker Ruslan Stefanchuk.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Kazakh Court Orders Compensation for Girl Burned While Sleeping
fields.summary: A court in Kazakhstan has ordered parents to pay 1 million tenge compensation after their children burned a sleeping girl with a hot metal spatula, causing injuries and psychological trauma.
fields.content:
A court in Kazakhstan's Kostanay region has mandated compensation payments following a disturbing incident where two minors burned a sleeping girl using a heated metal spatula. The Lisakovsk City Court heard how the perpetrators implemented their act in April 2025 while the victim was asleep in a Lisakovsk apartment.

According to the judicial findings reported by the Kostanay Regional Court, the juveniles deliberately heated the cooking utensil on a gas stove before applying it to multiple parts of the girl's body. This resulted in burns on her left cheek, right leg, and left hand, causing both physical injuries and emotional distress.

The parents of the offenders faced administrative charges for neglecting their parental responsibilities, with their sanctions finalized through earlier court proceedings. During the civil case focusing on compensation, medical examinations verified that the victim sustained injuries resulting in minor physical impairment.

While partially approving the moral damages claim, the court ordered the defendants to jointly pay 1 million tenge (approximately $2,100 USD), split equally between the two families. The ruling explicitly noted that the victim retains future rights to claim medical expenses for subsequent cosmetic treatments relating to the injuries.

This verdict remains subject to appeal as it hasn't taken legal effect. The case emerges amid growing concern about minor safety in Kazakhstan following other recent incidents - including a 9-year-old's severe hand injury at an Aktobe children's center and a mother's allegations that an Almaty amusement park caused her daughter grave injuries without accountability.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Kairat Nurtas' Pregnant Wife Addresses Baby Gender Questions Amid Reveal Plans
fields.summary: Zhuldyz Abdukarimova, pregnant actress and wife of Kazakh singer Kairat Nurtas, responded to public curiosity about their fifth child's gender, reaffirming plans for a reveal party once her daughter Alau returns.
fields.content:
Kazakh actress Zhuldyz Abdukarimova, spouse of renowned singer Kairat Nurtas, has addressed social media questions regarding the gender of her unborn fifth child. Currently expecting, Abdukarimova had previously committed to hosting a gender reveal event but has yet to schedule it.

Followers recently reignited the inquiry, directly asking: "Has the gender party happened? Boy or girl?" Abdukarimova responded by sharing a tender photograph featuring herself surrounded by pink and blue balloons without confirming details. She stated: "I don't even know myself. We will hold the gender party, God willing. Let my Alauka come first," referencing the couple's middle daughter.

Сторис Жулдыз Абдукаримовой

Meanwhile, the actress confirmed she has officially begun maternity leave. Abdukarimova is known for starring in films like "When Angels Sleep" and "Azhirasam" while managing her growing family with Nurtas.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Woman Assaults Husband with Poker at 16th Anniversary Celebration
fields.summary: A woman in Kazakhstan's Abai region was sentenced after striking her husband with a poker during an alcohol-fueled argument at their 16th wedding anniversary celebration. Her prison term was suspended due to having two young children.
fields.content:
In Abai region, Kazakhstan, a 36-year-old woman received a suspended sentence for grievously assaulting her husband during festivities commemorating their 16th wedding anniversary. According to law enforcement reports, the incident escalated after both spouses consumed alcohol.

During a heated argument, the woman seized a fireplace poker and struck her spouse on the head and body, resulting in injuries requiring hospitalization. The Semey City Court initially sentenced her to three years imprisonment.

However, judges suspended the penalty because she cares for two minor children. The woman entered probation with support from Zatonsky District authorities, who helped her secure employment at a local business.

"We explained the terms of her suspended sentence and facilitated job placement with an individual entrepreneur," confirmed Erlan Kydyrmannov, head of the district's probation service.

The convict later expressed remorse: "I deeply regret my actions. I didn't realize I could lose my freedom and be separated from my children. My husband and I reconciled and agreed to celebrate future occasions without alcohol."

Related Incidents

In Kyzylorda region, another woman faced criminal charges for assaulting a canteen proprietor who asked her to lower her voice during a dispute. She pleaded guilty and apologized for her conduct.

Separately, Kyzylorda authorities released a man from punishment after he reconciled with his wife, whom he had beaten while causing bodily harm. Court records confirmed he struck her face, pulled her hair, and verbally abused a child during the altercation.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Elderly man arrested after children poisoned at summer camp
fields.summary: A 76-year-old man was arrested on suspicion of administering poison following the hospitalization of eight children from a Leicestershire summer camp. Police have launched a major investigation while an independent watchdog examines their handling of the incident.
fields.content:
A 76-year-old man is in custody after children became ill at a summer camp in Stathern, Leicestershire. Eight children from Stathern Lodge camp required hospital treatment on Sunday but have since been discharged.

Police and ambulance services responded to Canal Lane following reports of children feeling unwell. Authorities arrested the suspect on charges of administering poison or a noxious substance with intent to injure, aggrieve, or annoy.

Leicestershire Police transferred the investigation to the East Midlands Special Operations Unit's major incident team for a thorough inquiry. Officers remain in Stathern conducting investigations and supporting affected families.

'Conduct referral'

The Independent Office for Police Conduct confirmed it received a conduct referral regarding police handling of child welfare concerns. An IOPC spokesperson stated: "Our assessment team concluded the matter should be independently investigated."

The investigation will examine whether professional conduct breaches, specifically failures in duties and responsibilities, caused delays in polices response to what became a critical incident.

Google Google shot from above of Stathern Lodge

Senior investigating officer Det Insp Neil Holden assured the public: "We understand the concern this caused. We're contacting all parents and providing full safeguarding with partner agencies." He described the case as a complex and sensitive investigation, promising updates as developments occur.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Flight Chaos Continues After Air Traffic Control Failure
fields.summary: Thousands of British travelers face ongoing disruptions after a nationwide air traffic control failure grounded flights, with airlines scrambling to manage cancellations and passenger rights groups warning of extended travel chaos across UK airports.
fields.content:
Passengers traveling through UK airports are advised to verify flight statuses as disruption continues following a critical air traffic control system failure. The issue initially suspended all outbound flights nationwide on Wednesday, causing widespread cancellations and delays.

Over 150 flights were scrapped during the peak disruption, with industry experts predicting travel chaos could persist for days. Air traffic provider NATS reported resolving the radar-related failure within 20 minutes through backup systems, with full operations restored within an hour.

Transport Secretary Heidi Alexander acknowledged passenger frustration during a briefing with NATS chief Martin Rolfe. She later stated on social media the incident showed no evidence of malicious activity and urged travelers to consult airlines before departing.

Major airports including Heathrow, Gatwick, Stansted, and Manchester confirmed operations were stabilizing Thursday, though cancellations continued. Heathrow reported 10 cancelled flights in the morning session, while Manchester recorded six cancellations absorbed within schedules.

'I don't want it to affect our kids'

Vicki Sluce and husband David stranded in Turkey with their children

Vicki Sluce described the family's ordeal after being stranded in Antalya, Turkey. "I'm stressed out," she explained. "My daughter spent three hours crying and has thrown up from stress thinking she's stuck." EasyJet informed them of no available return flights until Saturday.

Aviation analyst Simon Calder warned that thousands of travelers remain unexpectedly displaced, with system capacity stretched thin during peak holiday season. "Very few spare seats exist to accommodate passengers whose flights were cancelled in the hundreds yesterday," he noted.

According to aviation data firm Cirium, Wednesday saw 84 departures (3% of total) and 71 arrivals (2%) cancelled UK-wide. Ryanair executives demanded NATS leadership resign over what they termed "incompetence," highlighting that last August's similar failure impacted over 700,000 passengers.

While airlines must arrange meals, accommodation, and alternative flights for affected passengers under UK law, exemptions apply for "extraordinary circumstances" like technical failures. NATS confirmed the issue wasn't cyber-related but stemmed from radar equipment malfunction.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Top Lawyers Challenge UK's Plan to Recognize Palestinian State
fields.summary: Prominent British legal experts warn that the UK government's proposal to recognize Palestinian statehood may contravene international law, arguing Palestine doesn't meet criteria for statehood. The challenge follows Prime Minister Starmer's conditional offer of recognition linked to Israeli concessions.
fields.content:
Distinguished UK legal authorities have cautioned the government that recognizing Palestine as a state would violate international law. This warning targets Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer's recent pledge to advance recognition unless Israel agrees to specific conditions.

Starmer's conditions include establishing a ceasefire, reviving the two-state solution process, halting West Bank annexations, and ensuring greater aid access to Gaza. Opponents cite the 1933 Montevideo Convention, which requires defined territory, permanent population, effective government, and diplomatic capacity for statehood—criteria they argue Palestine currently fails to meet.

Business Minister Gareth Thomas contested this position, noting that the UK never ratified the Montevideo Convention and that 147 of the UN's 193 member states already formally recognize Palestine. The legal critique comes alongside assertions from over 800 lawyers alleging Israeli violations of the Geneva Convention in Gaza.

A coalition of 43 peers, including eminent jurists like former Supreme Court judge Lord Collins and barrister Lord Pannick, detailed their objections in a letter to Attorney General Lord Hermer. They stated: "It is clear that there is no certainty over the borders of Palestine," while highlighting governance deficiencies citing Fatah and Hamas divisions.

These signatories—comprising 27 Conservatives, 10 crossbenchers, and 4 Labour peers—warned that abandoning the Montevideo framework during "fragile" times for international law risks its disintegration. They urged Lord Hermer, who has emphasized law's centrality to foreign policy, to publicly oppose recognition as legally unsound.

Israeli figures condemned the UK initiative, with ex-hostage Emily Damari calling it historically misguided and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu denouncing it as "rewarding terrorism." Meanwhile, Canada announced parallel plans for September recognition, prompting Thomas to emphasize UK requirements: Palestinian Authority reforms, exclusion of Hamas from governance, and adherence to 1967 borders with Jerusalem as a shared capital.

The UK's position remains contingent on Israel meeting Starmer's terms before a planned UN summit in September. Thomas noted, "The prime minister was in talks this week with a series of countries, including Canada," which recently decided on recognition following Gaza's "catastrophe."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Nurses Demand Pay Reform in England Amid Strike Warning
fields.summary: Nursing leaders have issued a stark ultimatum to the English government, demanding pay reforms to prevent potential strike action this autumn. Over 170,000 Royal College of Nursing members overwhelmingly rejected this year's 3.6% pay increase as inadequate, with union leaders calling the offer 'grotesque' and warning about systemic pay structure issues in the NHS that trap nurses in low salary bands.
fields.content:
Nursing union representatives are warning the English government that failure to address pay concerns could result in strike action. A recent survey of Royal College of Nursing members revealed that 91% consider the current 3.6% pay increase insufficient, particularly when compared with higher settlements for doctors.

The union described the pay award as 'grotesque' and seeks urgent talks about reforming the NHS Agenda for Change contract. They highlight structural problems where approximately half of nurses remain stuck at the entry-level band five, starting at £31,000 annually and topping out at £38,000 even after the recent pay rise.

With more than 170,000 participating nurses—representing over half the eligible membership—the survey indicated widespread dissatisfaction with current compensation systems. The RCN is formally threatening to initiate an industrial action ballot this autumn unless government officials address their demands during summer negotiations.

The union proposes automatically advancing nurses from salary band five to band six after completing an 18-month introductory program. This change could potentially resolve career stagnation issues by recognizing nurses' expertise beyond entry-level positions.

Union sources indicate they aren't demanding revisions to this year's increase, acknowledging the government's position following its standoff with junior doctors. Similar discontent exists among nursing staff in Wales and Northern Ireland, showing the pay dispute spans multiple UK nations.

RCN General Secretary Professor Nicola Ranger stated, "My profession feels deeply undervalued. Record numbers are telling the government to wake up and do what's right for both nurses and patients. We face a broken system that holds back nursing pay and careers while hampering NHS operations."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ancient Siberian Mummy's Intricate Tattoos Revealed Through Advanced Imaging
fields.summary: Advanced imaging techniques have uncovered remarkably intricate tattoos on a 2,500-year-old Siberian ice mummy, revealing detailed depictions of leopards, stags, a rooster, and mythical creatures that provide new insights into the ancient Pazyryk warrior culture and their sophisticated tattooing practices.
fields.content:
High-resolution analysis of tattoos preserved on a 2,500-year-old Siberian ice mummy has revealed astonishingly complex designs that would challenge modern tattoo artists, according to research findings. The remarkably intact decorations include leopards, a stag, a rooster, and a mythical half-lion, half-eagle creature called a griffin.

Daniel Riday A black line drawing illustration of the tattoos on the woman's right forearm. It shows three leopards encircling a stag with horns and what look like wings.

The scanning technology revealed "intricate crisp and uniform" tattooing invisible to the naked eye. The tattooed woman, approximately 50 years old, belonged to the nomadic Pazyryk people who once roamed the vast steppe between Europe and China, according to researchers who used near-infrared digital photography at the Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg.

On her right forearm appeared an image of three leopards surrounding a stag's head, while her left forearm featured a griffin attacking another stag. A distinctive rooster adorned her thumb, showing what researchers described as "an intriguing style with certain uniqueness" compared to the more typical animal battle scenes.

Daniel Riday A black line drawing of the tattoo on the woman's left forearm. It shows a large stag with horns, and a half-lion and half-eagle creature appearing to attack the stag.

Archaeologists collaborated with Daniel Riday, who recreates ancient tattoos using historical methods on his own body. His insights revealed craftsmanship differences between tattoos on the woman's two arms, suggesting either multiple artists or occasional mistakes during the lengthy tattooing process.

Daniel Riday A photograph showing some bare skin with tattoed arrows in blue and black ink. Some are filled in. Two hands with latex gloves are on the top of the skin. In one hand there is a tattooing needle poised above the skin.

A 'solid commitment'

Riday estimates tattooing the lower right arm would have taken about four and a half hours plus another five hours for the upper section. He described this as "a solid commitment from the person," especially considering the windy steppe conditions where the tattooing likely occurred.

He emphasized the procedure would require knowledge of health safety practices to manage infection risks from skin punctures. Analysis of skin markings suggests designs were stenciled first before application with probable multi-pointed tools made from horn or bone and single needles, using pigment from burnt plant matter or soot.

A table of three images from the high-resolution scan of the woman's body, with a purple hue. The three images show parts of the skin and tattoo of the woman with lines across the skin that are the tattoo. They show different marks made by different tools.

Evidence showed tattoos were damaged during burial preparations, indicating they served the living rather than the afterlife. Lead researcher Dr. Gino Caspari remarked that the sophistication of Pazyryk tattooing demonstrated "people put a lot of time and effort and practice into creating these images" as a significant cultural practice that parallels modern appreciation for body art.

Daniel Riday A black line drawing illustration of the tattos on the woman's thumb and fingers. One image is a rooster, with a feathered tail and an outstreched neck and beak. There are two other images underneath with rounded ends, similar to arrows.

The findings are published in the journal Antiquity and represent rare insights into personal identity within ancient nomadic cultures. The tattoos survived in remarkable condition due to the mummification process in the icy Altai Mountains.

M Vavulin Two 3D images of the ice mummy. They show a skeleton with its hand crossed and feet stretched out.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Ofcom Investigates 34 Adult Sites Over Age Verification Compliance
fields.summary: UK regulator Ofcom has launched investigations into 34 adult websites operated by four companies to determine if they're complying with new age verification requirements designed to prevent children from accessing harmful online content.
fields.content:
Ofcom is examining four firms operating dozens of adult websites for potential failures in implementing new age verification rules. More than 6,000 platforms hosting pornography and potentially harmful content must now deploy "highly effective" measures to confirm users are at least 18 years old following Friday's regulatory changes.

The targeted companies—8579 LLC, AVS Group Ltd, Kick Online Entertainment S.A., and Trendio Ltd—collectively attract over nine million monthly visits across their 34 sites. Ofcom stated the probes were initiated because these services pose particular risks: "These companies have been prioritised based on the risk of harm posed by the services they operate and their user numbers."

This enforcement follows earlier investigations into platforms such as online forum 4chan, First Time Videos LLC, a suicide discussion site, file-sharing services, and a "nudifying" website. The regulator indicated additional enforcement actions will follow in coming weeks.

Technology Secretary Peter Kyle defended the measures: "These laws have nothing to do with censorship or policing adults seeking to access legal content. Those who suggest otherwise are playing politics with child safety," emphasizing that unprotected exposure to explicit material could cause "lasting, even fatal, damage."

Age checks online

Since enforcement began, UK users accessing adult content on platforms like Reddit and X now encounter age verification prompts. Spotify confirmed similar checks may activate for 18+ rated music videos not only in the UK but also in Australia and other regions.

A petition demanding repeal of the underlying Online Safety Act has gained over 400,000 signatures, reflecting concerns about privacy and regulatory overreach. The government rejected the appeal, confirming it has "no plans to withdraw the law."

Critics also note the rules might be undermined by virtual private networks (VPNs), which permit users to mask their locations. VPN applications surged to the top of Apple's App Store download charts immediately after the rules took effect.

Ofcom acknowledged imperfect protections, describing the measures as no "silver bullet," but maintained they would reduce chances of children accidentally encountering explicit content online.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Jenna Ortega Reflects on Overwhelming 'Wednesday' Fame and Season Two Family Dynamics
fields.summary: Jenna Ortega reveals the staggering fame from Netflix's 'Wednesday' felt overwhelming after the show became the platform's most popular English-language series. The star discusses the second season's increased focus on family dynamics and shared thoughts on relatable themes of identity and community.
fields.content:
Jenna Ortega has described the whirlwind fame sparked by her starring role in Netflix's Wednesday as profoundly overwhelming. The first season launched in 2022 as the streamer's most-watched English-language series ever, thrusting the 22-year-old actress into unprecedented recognition.

Ortega expressed deep gratitude for the show's resonance with viewers but admitted she felt unprepared for the sudden exposure. When asked if she anticipated the attention, she stated: "Is anyone? No, I wasn't. I wouldn't want to know someone who is. I don't think that should ever be like a normal experience." She emphasized, "We didn't know anyone would watch it... it was very overwhelming."

The upcoming second season brings Wednesday Addams back to Nevermore Academy under new principal Barry Dort, played by Steve Buscemi. Notably, parents Gomez and Morticia gain expanded roles, creating what Netflix calls "a rare new form of torture" for the independent sleuth as family dynamics deepen.

Ortega highlighted the Addams family's relatable contradictions: "They're a cohesive unit but very different—they shouldn't fit together but they do." She specifically mentioned the evolving mother-daughter tension between Wednesday and Catherine Zeta-Jones's Morticia, calling the actress a "delicious, divine presence" and noting: "The daughter wants her own space, while the mother wants to protect from past hardships—it mirrors my teenage experience."

Catherine Zeta-Jones as Morticia, Isaac Ordonez as Pugsley, and Luis Guzmán as Gomez Addams in Wednesday season two

The California-born actress, known for roles in Scream and Beetlejuice Beetlejuice, expands her contribution this season as executive producer. Ortega called it "a great education" and cited the production delay allowed "the dust and debris to settle." She added: "Audiences were patient... we want to please them in new exciting ways."

Jenna Ortega with Winona Ryder at Venice Film Festival 2024, promoting Beetlejuice Beetlejuice

Catherine Zeta-Jones welcomed the increased focus after season one's "grassroots" feel, saying the development created "a lovely arc" exploring Morticia and Wednesday's bond. She affirmed: "We embrace our idiosyncrasies—it's the ultimate modern family."

Catherine Zeta-Jones at Netflix®'s "Wednesday" photo event in Hollywood, April 2023

"Online communities can be isolating"

Ortega suggested the show's resonance stems partly from exploring community in the digital age. Contrasting past neighborhood connections with current smartphone reliance, she observed: "People find community online, which can be isolating. Young people struggle to discover what makes their voice unique."

Zeta-Jones echoed this perspective: "It's OK to be different... we encourage it." Ortega agreed viewers find comfort in characters who are "so obviously themselves," stressing its relevance for youth: "It prevents being swept up in sheep mentality.” The season releases in two parts—four episodes on August 6, followed by the remaining four on September 3.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: 49 Christians Killed in DR Congo Church Massacre by Islamist Militants
fields.summary: Islamist militants killed 49 Christians, including 9 beheaded children, during a church service in DR Congo and kidnapped others. Eyewitnesses describe attackers hacking worshippers with machetes as international groups warn of escalating religious violence.
fields.content:
Forty-nine Christian worshippers, including nine children who were decapitated, were murdered during a church attack in Komanda village, Democratic Republic of Congo. Several other children were abducted by the attackers identified as members of the Islamist Allied Democratic Forces (ADF), a sanctioned rebel group.

Eyewitness Account

A church worker connected with Open Doors UK, a global Christian charity advocating for persecuted believers, arrived at the scene hours later. Eyewitness testimonies revealed attackers entered the church during Silver Jubilee celebrations and began hacking people with machetes. Those inside the sanctuary were killed immediately, while others were chased into the compound and roads before being slaughtered.

One local shopkeeper whose business was burned survived by hiding. A church worker under the pseudonym Judith reported: "People were crying for their children who had been kidnapped. One woman cried for the man she was shortly due to marry."

Burned vehicle at attack site in Komanda

Mass Burial and Grief

The UN's MONUSCO mission provided earth-moving machines to dig a mass grave for the victims who were buried in simple coffins. Judith described the funeral scene: "There was sadness everywhere. Everything they had is lost—they have nothing now." Some victims had previously fled violence elsewhere seeking refuge in Komanda.

Villagers walking to burial site

Villagers praying for attack victims

Calls for Global Action

Henrietta Blyth, CEO of Open Doors UK, described the situation as "a crisis of biblical proportions," noting that displaced Christians are "sleeping in the jungle at risk of wild animals" to avoid attacks. Over 80 Christians were reportedly killed in separate attacks during July across the region.

Open Doors' Sub-Sahara specialist Jo Newhouse urgently appealed: "We need the U.S. to pay attention and use your influence. Do not be blind to what is happening here." International concern surged as villagers reported militants remain nearby, raising fears of further attacks.

Displaced Christians in DR Congo

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump Warns Russia's Medvedev: 'Watch His Words' Amid Trade Tariff Dispute
fields.summary: Former US President Donald Trump escalated tensions with Russian official Dmitry Medvedev, dismissing India and Russia as 'dead economies' while imposing 25% tariffs on Indian imports and warning Medvedev about 'dangerous territory.' Medvedev responded by referencing Russia's Cold War-era 'Dead Hand' nuclear retaliation system.
fields.content:
Former U.S. President Donald Trump issued strong criticism targeting both India and Russia through a midnight social media post, declaring indifference to their economic partnership. "I don’t care what India does with Russia. They can take their dead economies down together," Trump wrote, simultaneously announcing new 25% tariffs on Indian imports effective August 1st while branding Russia and America as virtually non-trading partners. Trump specifically warned former Russian president Dmitry Medvedev to "watch his words," asserting he was entering "very dangerous territory."

Medvedev responded promptly via Telegram, referencing the Soviet-era "Dead Hand" automated nuclear retaliation system - designed to launch missiles if leadership is destroyed - suggesting Trump's reaction validated Russia's policies. "If a few words from a former Russian president provoke such a nervous reaction... then clearly Russia is in the right," Medvedev stated, likening economic discussions to "zombie movies" while emphasizing the system's danger.

A Russian Cold War relic, the "Dead Hand" mechanism guarantees massive nuclear retaliation even if Moscow's command structure is eliminated, representing one of history's most extreme deterrence strategies. Trump justified the steep tariffs against India—a major Russian oil consumer—by criticizing the country's "strenuous and obnoxious" trade barriers and military dependence on Moscow, adding: "everyone wants Russia to STOP THE KILLING IN UKRAINE."

Trump denounced India's membership in the BRICS coalition as an "attack on the dollar," declaring: "We're not going to let anybody attack the dollar." His new trade penalties coincide with reciprocal tariff arrangements established during recent European talks, which Medvedev subsequently criticized.

Medvedev during Moscow meeting

Trump consistently links foreign trade agreements to alignment with U.S. geopolitical stances. On Thursday, he enthusiastically endorsed tariffs as economic salvation: "Tariffs are making America GREAT & RICH Again," claiming they reversed decades of disadvantage. "ONE YEAR AGO, AMERICA WAS A DEAD COUNTRY, NOW IT IS THE ‘HOTTEST’ COUNTRY ANYWHERE IN THE WORLD," he proclaimed.

Putin during meeting with bank leader in Moscow

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Heart Age Assessment Highlights Disease Risk Disparities
fields.summary: A new study reveals that your heart may be biologically older than your chronological age, with this gap predicting heightened cardiovascular disease risk. Researchers found significant disparities across gender, racial, and socioeconomic groups, introducing a novel prediction tool to make risk assessment more accessible.
fields.content:
Understanding Heart Age

According to new research, your heart's biological age often exceeds your actual age, serving as a significant predictor for heart disease. This 'heart age' concept, clinically termed PREVENT age, translates complex 10-year cardiovascular risk projections into an intuitive metric comparable to chronological age. Senior researcher Dr. Sadiya Khan, who developed the PREVENT equations at Northwestern University, explained that this approach helps patients and clinicians better grasp cardiovascular risks.

"It translates complex information about the risk of heart attack, stroke or heart failure over the next 10 years into a number that is easier to understand," Khan noted. The tool could potentially improve prevention strategies since many who require medication to reduce cardiovascular risks aren't receiving treatment.

Research Findings and Disparities

The study analyzed over 14,100 U.S. adults aged 30-79 with no prior heart disease history using National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey data. Findings revealed significant gaps between chronological and heart age across demographic groups. Women had an average heart age of 55.4 years against an actual age of 51.3, while men showed a larger discrepancy with 56.7 heart age versus 49.7 chronological age.

Man holding chest

Notably, 22% of women and 33% of men with high-school education or less exhibited heart ages exceeding their chronological age by more than 10 years. The gap was also significantly wider among Black and Hispanic individuals and those with lower income levels.

Implications and Limitations

Published in JAMA Cardiology, the research aims to improve preventive approaches for heart disease—the leading cause of U.S. deaths for over a century. "We hope this new heart age calculator will help support discussions about prevention," said Khan, adding it's especially useful for younger adults who may underestimate their risks. The calculator isn't meant to replace physician assessments.

heart health

Researchers acknowledged one key limitation: "The definition of optimal risk may influence the calculation of PREVENT risk age." Khan emphasized the tool requires broader testing to determine its practical effectiveness. The findings underscore demographic disparities in cardiovascular health while offering a novel approach to risk communication.

Heart clock

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Roman Legionary's Monthly Pay Unearthed in Pristine Coin Hoard in UK
fields.summary: Archaeologists revealed a cache of Roman silver coins unearthed in a UK field that likely represents a soldier's monthly salary. The 25 pristine denarii from various emperors were found scattered in Norfolk farmland.
fields.content:
A discovery in the countryside has revealed what appears to be an ancient Roman soldier's monthly salary. Officials announced the unearthing of 25 silver denarii in exceptional condition this month, corresponding precisely to a legionary's standard payment.

The Norfolk Field Discovery

Found by a metal detecting enthusiast, the coins were spread throughout a Norfolk field due to centuries of agricultural activity. Numismatist Adrian Marsden confirmed the coins were handed to authorities and noted similar finds in the region. "We had a few hoards like this over the years, scattered by the plow and often of a similar size," Marsden said.

Stock image of field in Norfolk with grain, windmill

Imperial Portraits on Denarii

Exceptional preservation suggests minimal circulation before burial, with only light wear visible. The collection features seven coins depicting Emperor Hadrian, alongside Emperor Vespasian and Trajan. Two denarii show Marcus Aurelius – one during his time as heir apparent and another from his reign as emperor. A notable piece commemorates Rome’s conquest of Judaea with a "Judaea Capta" coin minted after Jerusalem’s destruction.

Array of Roman coins

Array of ancient Roman coins

Roman Legacy in Norfolk

Marsden explained such discoveries remain frequent in this historically wealthy agricultural region: "There are plenty of Roman discoveries in the area, including occasional small hoards. This was a wealthy agricultural area in the Roman period." Romans occupied Britain for nearly four centuries before withdrawing in 410 A.D., leaving behind ongoing archaeological evidence of their settlement.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Mariners Strike Deal to Acquire Slugger Eugenio Suárez from Diamondbacks
fields.summary: The Seattle Mariners are finalizing a trade to acquire power hitter Eugenio Suárez from the Arizona Diamondbacks ahead of the deadline, adding a two-time All-Star who leads MLB in RBIs to bolster their postseason push.
fields.content:
The Seattle Mariners are nearing a deal to obtain power hitter Eugenio Suárez from the Arizona Diamondbacks ahead of Thursday's trade deadline, according to reports. Considered one of the most coveted players on the market, the two-time All-Star leads Major League Baseball with 87 RBIs this season while smashing 36 home runs with a .248 batting average and .898 OPS across 105 games.

Eugenio Suarez vs Astros
