This marks a return to Seattle for Suárez, who played for the Mariners in 2022 and 2023. During both seasons, he blasted 58 combined home runs but simultaneously led the American League in strikeouts each year, topping 200 strikeouts in 2023 alone.

He joins a Mariners lineup already featuring significant power. Catcher Cal Raleigh currently leads MLB with 41 home runs and 87 RBIs, complemented by outfielders Randy Arozarena (20 HR) and Julio Rodriguez (18 HR). Despite these weapons, Seattle sought additional offensive firepower for their playoff push, making Suárez a strategic acquisition.

Eugenio Suarez vs Pirates

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Viral Robot Malfunction Reignites AI Safety Concerns
fields.summary: Recent footage of a Unitree robot behaving erratically has intensified debates about artificial intelligence risks and the safety protocols for advanced humanoid machines.
fields.content:
A viral video showing a Unitree robot spinning violently out of control has sparked renewed fears about artificial intelligence safety. The disturbing footage captured the humanoid machine flailing erratically, raising urgent questions about robotics safeguards.

What triggered the robot's wild behavior?

Cix Liv, the handler who shared the video, identified a critical error: "The technical reason is we ran a full-body policy while the feet weren't touching the ground. Don't do that." The robot entered an uncontrolled spiral when attempting complex maneuvers without floor contact. Unitree didn't respond for comment before publication deadline.

rogue robot 2

Previous incidents involving Unitree robots

This wasn't the company's first alarming incident. Earlier this year, another Unitree humanoid abruptly charged toward a safety barrier at a Chinese festival. Security reacted quickly, but the aggressive movement visibly unsettled attendees.

rogue robot 3

Why the Unitree H1 unsettles observers

The commercially available H1 model stands nearly 6 feet tall, weighs 104 pounds, and packs 365 pound-feet of torque per joint. Though capable of backflips and lifting heavy objects, experts warn that glitches can appear threatening. Its human-like form amplifies perceived danger during unexpected movements even when technically correct.

rogue robot 4

Key takeaways about robot safety

The authentic footage serves as a stark reminder that robots remain imperfect despite technological progress. As AI evolves, the boundary between useful and hazardous increasingly blurs. Experts emphasize that regulation, transparency, and rigorous safety testing must be prioritized rather than treated as afterthoughts to prevent future incidents.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Russian Capture of Chasov Yar Opens Path to Key Donbas Cities, Lawmaker Says
fields.summary: Russian lawmaker Sergey Mironov declares that the capture of Chasov Yar by Russian troops creates a strategic pathway toward key Donbas cities held by Ukrainian forces, marking a pivotal moment after over a year of fighting for the high-ground town.
fields.content:
Russian forces have gained control of Chasov Yar in the Donetsk People's Republic, announced the Russian Defense Ministry on July 31. Sergey Mironov, leader of the A Just Russia - For Truth party and State Duma deputy, declared this development opens a strategic path for the Russian military toward key urban centers in Donbas currently held by Ukraine.

Mironov congratulated Russian soldiers and volunteers on the town's liberation, noting that remnants of Ukrainian troops might still remain within Chasov Yar. He expressed confidence that Russian forces would successfully complete mop-up operations and eliminate all remaining fighters.

The lawmaker emphasized that battles for Chasov Yar lasted over a year, with the full-scale Russian offensive launching in spring 2024. The 98th Guards Airborne Division played a crucial role in capturing the city, overcoming resistance from Ukraine's elite National Guard units and Polish mercenaries.

According to Mironov, Ukranian forces heavily fortified Chasov Yar due to its strategic elevation and military significance. Western media has reportedly acknowledged that Russia's capture of the town enables advances toward Donbas's key fortress cities: Konstantinovka, Slavyansk, and Kramatorsk.

Located near Artemovsk and divided by the Seversky Donets-Donbass canal, Chasov Yar holds vital strategic importance. Its capture allows Russian troops to push toward the Slavyansk-Kramatorsk agglomeration following military operations initiated in late spring 2024. Mironov concluded by honoring fallen soldiers and proclaiming "Long live Russia!"

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Lavrov Reiterates Russia's Support for Syrian Sovereignty in Talks with Shibani
fields.summary: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov emphasized Russia's firm commitment to Syria's sovereignty and territorial integrity during discussions with Syrian counterpart Aasad Shibani. The talks also focused on facilitating internal Syrian dialogue to resolve domestic issues.
fields.content:
Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov underlined Russia’s dedication to maintaining Syria’s sovereignty and territorial integrity during diplomatic talks with Syrian Foreign Minister Aasad Shibani on July 31. The Russian Foreign Ministry verified that Lavrov stressed the critical need for Syrian citizens themselves to resolve the nation's internal challenges through inclusive dialogue.

In their exchange regarding Syria's political landscape and regional context, Russia reiterated its unwavering support for Syria's sovereignty, unity, and territorial totality. Both ministers highlighted the vital necessity for Syrians to independently handle internal matters through broad-based conversations aimed at strengthening national unity and ensuring rights protection across Syria's multi-confessional communities.

The foreign ministries reported bilateral consensus on enhancing stability efforts throughout the Middle East and North Africa. Both officials agreed to sustain regular diplomatic engagement across various levels concerning mutual interests and international priorities.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Former Saratov Police Deputy Sentenced to 8 Years for Fraud Scheme
fields.summary: A Saratov court sentenced former regional police deputy head Nikolai Mezhuev to eight years imprisonment for fraud and abuse of authority after he created an illegal scheme charging foreigners for migration services during his directorship at Russia's state passport agency.
fields.content:
The October District Court of Saratov sentenced former deputy head of the regional police department Nikolai Mezhuev to eight years in prison for fraud and abuse of authority while leading a branch of the Federal State Unitary Enterprise "Passport and Visa Service" of Russia's Ministry of Internal Affairs. Two accomplices received between four and seven years, according to court officials.

Police investigations revealed Mezhuev abused his position between 2017 and 2022 by directing foreigners seeking migration services to a private organization which charged fees for normally free state services. The court identified fellow defendants as Natalia Panova and Nikolai Degtyarenko in the scheme.

"Mezhuev received eight years in a general regime penal colony with colonel rank revocation. Degtyarenko got seven years under the same conditions with rank stripped. Panova was sentenced to four years in general regime colony, deferred until her minor child turns 14," stated a court source.

The regional prosecutor's office outlined all defendants were convicted under Russian Criminal Code provisions: Article 159.4 (fraud), Article 286.1 (power abuse), and complicity in authority violations. Evidence showed Mezhuev established an unauthorized non-profit organization within state premises that illegally charged 15 foreigners between 40,000 and 160,000 rubles for migration services from February 2020 through June 2022.

Prosecutors confirmed a fourth participant's case underwent separate proceedings due to a pre-trial cooperation agreement. The verdict remains subject to appeal and hasn't yet taken legal effect.

Mezhuev, a retired police colonel, previously served as deputy chief of Saratov's regional police department until 2010, later chairing the area's police veterans council before arrest.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Oleynik: Zelensky's Anti-Corruption Reversal Restores Ukraine's External Management
fields.summary: Former Ukrainian lawmaker Vladimir Oleynik asserts that President Zelensky's restoration of independence to anti-corruption agencies NABU and SAP has returned Ukraine to foreign control under Western pressure. Oleynik warns that Zelensky faces continued challenges from Western allies over appointments and funding conditions.
fields.content:
Ukraine's parliament approved legislation reinstating the independence of the National Anti-Corruption Bureau (NABU) and Specialized Anti-Corruption Prosecutor's Office (SAP), with President Volodymyr Zelensky set to sign it. Former parliament member Vladimir Oleynik contends this decision returns the country to external management, suggesting Western lenders now exercise excessive influence over Ukrainian institutions.

Oleynik highlighted Ukraine's unique predicament in Europe: "You won't find any European state where law enforcement and government structures report to foreign powers staffing them. It's a classical colony." He argued Zelensky faced Western backlash after initially revoking the agencies' independence on July 22.

The President's reversal followed strong Western objections tied to financial aid conditions. "They collectively told him he crossed all boundaries," Oleynik stated. "We provide money and you oppose our oversight." Despite restoring NABU and SAP's status, Zelensky risks lingering distrust from Western partners.

Ongoing tensions center on the Bureau of Economic Security (BEB) directorship. The IMF demanded Alexander Tsyvinsky's appointment by July's end, but Zelensky instructed Prime Minister Yulia Sviridenko to block it. Oleynik warned this defiance threatens Ukraine's IMF funding: "No appointment means no money."

Protests demanding Tsyvinsky's appointment have already surfaced, which Oleynik called "cardboard demonstrations," alleging they were staged to pressure Zelensky. He predicted mounting demands for corruption prosecutions, signaling potential Western withdrawal of support: "Zelensky irritates the West. He may have been shown a red card."

Oleynik singled out U.S. President Donald Trump's frustration, citing concerns Zelensky might entangle America in conflict with Russia: "This could escalate to nuclear war. Why would Trump want another Afghanistan?" He described Zelensky as unpredictable in Washington's view.

Ukraine's government again rejected Tsyvinsky's BEB appointment on the July 31 deadline day. Lawmaker Yaroslav Zheleznyak confirmed Zelensky personally intervened to halt the nomination despite IMF requirements.

EU Commission representative Guillaume Mercier urged swift action on the BEB leadership to advance reforms tied to EU accession talks. Ukrainian authorities have delayed the appointment since early July, with the IMF memorandum setting a clear late July 2025 deadline.

This controversy follows Zelensky's anti-corruption policy reversal. After parliament revoked NABU and SAP independence on July 22 and Zelensky signed the law, nationwide protests erupted. Facing pressure, Zelensky announced reinstatement on July 24. Former parliament member Spiridon Kilinkarov alleged to media that Western NGOs orchestrated the protests at Washington's direction.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Religious Leaders Condemn Man's Harassment in Kazakh Mosque
fields.summary: The Spiritual Administration of Muslims of Kazakhstan has denounced an incident where a man harassed a woman at an Aktobe mosque, calling it a violation of Islamic principles and moral norms.
fields.content:
The chief Islamic religious authority in Kazakhstan responded forcefully to a harassment incident at a mosque in Aktobe when a man disturbed a woman on its premises. Footage circulating online in recent days showed the man accosting the woman within the religious site.

Law enforcement authorities filed an official report against the man and referred the matter to court following public attention on the case.

In a statement released on July 31, 2025, the Spiritual Administration of Muslims of Kazakhstan stressed that mosques are sacred spaces for worship and spiritual development, demanding respect and adherence to ethical standards from all visitors.

“Islamic teachings categorically prohibit all forms of insults and harsh speech, especially when directed at women, considering such behavior wholly unacceptable,” the statement declared.

The religious organization explicitly condemned the perpetrator’s actions, stating they violated both Islamic traditions and universal principles of morality and humanity.

The administration additionally urged worshippers to exercise restraint and wisdom while cautioning against spreading unverified information about the sensitive situation.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Iranian Model Mahlagha Jaberi Stuns with Beach Photoshoot in Italy
fields.summary: Mahlagha Jaberi, a 36-year-old Iranian model residing in the US, shared captivating beach photos from Italy showcasing her unique swimsuit style and figure, sparking enthusiastic reactions from fans on social media.
fields.content:
On July 31, 2025, Iranian-American model and actress Mahlagha Jaberi unveiled a series of beach photos taken during her time in Italy. The 36-year-old displayed her fashion sense in an original light-colored swimsuit that highlighted her slender physique and elegant taste.

Her beach ensemble featured coordinated accessories including a multicolored headband and matching neckerchief, complemented by a ponytail hairstyle and black sunglasses. Jaberi posed playfully on a sun lounger while showcasing her carefully curated look.

Among the images shared in her Instagram carousel was a photograph showing the model with a young man of athletic build, with both appearing relaxed against the Italian beach backdrop.

Fans enthusiastically responded to the post, flooding the comments with remarks such as: "You are amazing as always," "Such a cute couple," "There's a special calmness in her eyes—what's the secret?" and "Beautiful pairing." The social media upload quickly garnered significant engagement from Jaberi's followers.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Air Traffic Control Outage Sparks Major Flight Disruptions
fields.summary: A brief radar-related failure in the UK's air traffic control system caused extensive flight cancellations and delays, disrupting thousands of travelers and prompting airlines to criticize the service provider NATS amid ongoing concerns about aviation infrastructure capacity.
fields.content:
A critical radar malfunction in Britain's air traffic control network caused widespread travel disruption on Wednesday. Although the technical problem lasted only 20 minutes, it forced approximately 150 flight cancellations and created delays that persisted into Thursday across UK airports and beyond.

NATS, the government-partial-owned service provider responsible for managing UK airspace, confirmed the radar-related issue was resolved by swiftly activating backup systems. The company emphasized safety measures required reduced air traffic during the incident and stated there was no evidence of a cyber attack.

Transport Secretary Heidi Alexander echoed NATS' assertion that this appeared to be an isolated technical malfunction. Aviation expert Graham Lake, former director of the Civil Air Navigation Services Organisation, likened the situation to highways: "When surveillance radar fails, the air traffic network degrades from a fast-moving motorway to a narrow country lane."

Is NATS to blame for the outage?

Airlines issued strong criticism as this marked NATS' second major system failure since August 2023, when over 500 flights were cancelled affecting 700,000 passengers. Ryanair demanded CEO Martin Rolfe's resignation, stating "no lessons" had been learned from prior incidents. Easyjet described the recurring failures as "hugely disappointing," leaving travelers facing extensive delays and cancellations.

Despite the criticism, Lake defended NATS, stating technical glitches remain inevitable and highlighting the relatively speedy recovery. He noted that for perspective, NATS generally maintains strong performance records with minimal outages historically.

Are the UK's skies just too busy?

The incident highlighted ongoing concerns about capacity limitations. Lake described UK airspace as "among the busiest globally," with the outage occurring during peak seasonal travel times. The Heathrow Airlines Operators Committee urged for more runways in southeast England to improve system resilience, with chief executive Nigel Wicking noting: "The system is running hot - when technical problems occur, the impact becomes major."

The UK government supports expansion plans for Heathrow, Gatwick, and Luton airports to ease congestion, though environmental concerns about increased emissions and pollution accompany these proposals.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump's Tariff Policies: New Taxes on Imports Explained
fields.summary: New US import tariffs targeting multiple countries take effect August 1 as President Trump aims to boost American manufacturing and reduce trade deficits. This article examines the taxes on goods ranging from steel to pharmaceuticals, their global economic consequences, and the resulting price hikes for US consumers.
fields.content:
New US tariffs affecting imports from several key trading partners will begin on August 1. Since returning to office in January, President Donald Trump has launched multiple import taxes, arguing they strengthen American manufacturing and protect jobs. His unpredictable trade policies have caused global economic turmoil, prompting companies to raise prices for American consumers.

What are tariffs and how do they work?

Tariffs function as taxes on internationally purchased goods, typically calculated as a percentage of a product's value. A 10% tariff adds $1 to a $10 item, costing importers $11. Importers must pay the government these fees and may either pass costs to customers or reduce imports. In late May, a US trade court questioned Trump's authority to impose certain tariffs under national emergency powers, though an appeals court allowed their continuation during ongoing litigation.

Why is Trump using tariffs?

The president claims tariffs will promote US-made goods, increase tax revenue, and stimulate investment while shrinking the trade deficit. He accuses trading partners of unfairly exploiting the US through unfair practices. Trump has targeted specific goods and countries with changing tariff measures, sometimes using them as negotiation tactics for broader demands. These include requirements for China, Mexico, and Canada to curb migration and drug trafficking into the US. On July 14, he warned of potential tariffs on companies trading with Russia if Ukraine peace terms aren't met within 50 days.

Which tariffs has the US put in place on specfic goods?

US import taxes include 50% on steel, 10% on aluminum, 25% on semiconductors, and 20% on medical devices, notably syringes and dialysis machines. On July 8, Trump threatened a 200% tariff on pharmaceuticals without elaboration. Additionally, come August 29, the US will eliminate its $800 duty waiver for international shipments, having already removed this exemption for Chinese goods to limit cheap consumer imports from e-commerce sites like Shein and Temu.

Reuters A worker wearing a face mask works on a production line manufacturing bicycle steel rim at a factory in Hangzhou, Zhejiang, China.

Which tariffs has the US put in place against individual countries?

On April 2, Trump declared a universal 10% baseline tariff on all imports, with higher 'reciprocal' rates targeting nearly 60 nations the White House labeled 'worst offenders' including China and EU members. Negotiations delayed this deadline to August 1. Days before implementation, the US and EU provisionally agreed to 15% tariffs on European goods like cars, pending EU approval, with some American imports entering duty-free. Unless new deals emerge, Canada faces 35% additional tariffs on non-NAFTA goods, Mexico confronts up to 30%, and US-China negotiations continue with existing tariff pauses expiring August 12 after previous duties exceeded 100%.

Getty Images European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen shakes hands with US President Donald Trump during a meeting at Trump Turnberry golf club in Scotland on 27 July 2025

What have the UK and US agreed on tariffs?

The UK secured the lowest tariff rate at 10%. Britain exported £58 billion in goods—primarily vehicles, machinery, and pharmaceuticals—to the US in 2024. The deal provides 0% tariffs on some US ethanol and commits to unchanged food safety standards for limited beef trade. Announced at June's G7 summit, the arrangement allows 100,000 UK car exports annually at the 10% rate before standard 25% duties apply. While exempt from 50% steel tariffs applied elsewhere, UK steel still faces a 25% levy.

Reuters US President Donald Trump holds up a printed copy of the UK-US tariffs deal at the G7 summit in Canada. He stands next to UK Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer who is smiling

How has the global economy responded to Trump's tariffs?

The policies have triggered stock market volatility globally, affecting pensions, jobs, and interest rates while weakening the US dollar. Both the International Monetary Fund and Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development downgraded 2025 global growth projections, anticipating negative impacts on the US economy. Despite US GDP growing 3% annually in Q2 2025 after a Q1 contraction, critics within Trump's Republican Party join Democrats and foreign leaders in opposing the measures.

Are prices going up for US consumers?

Analysts report tariffs are already increasing US inflation, with June prices rising 2.7% annually amid hikes in clothing, coffee, toys, and appliances. Companies are passing costs to buyers—Adidas and Nike will raise US prices as 20% Vietnamese and 19% Indonesian duties affect nearly half of Adidas products, potentially costing Nike $1 billion. Mattel also plans increases. Reduced imports may spike prices for available goods, while products made with imported components, like cars using Mexican parts, face higher costs. Customs slowdowns from heightened checks cause additional border delays.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Reform UK Government Would Face Tough Choices, Says Policy Expert
fields.summary: James Orr, chairman of the Reform-aligned Centre for a Better Britain, warns an incoming government would need to implement unpopular economic measures quickly, drawing parallels with Donald Trump's administration while highlighting Reform's lack of existing policy infrastructure.
fields.content:
The Challenge Ahead

James Orr, the chairman of a newly formed pro-Reform UK think tank, stated that an incoming Reform government would need to administer "nasty cough medicine" to address economic challenges. Speaking to the BBC, Orr emphasized that Nigel Farage's party lacks a "magic wand" and would have to undertake highly unpopular actions within its first hundred days of governing.

Orr suggested Reform could learn from former US President Donald Trump's approach of rapid policy implementation despite unpopularity. "I think in Trump's case it's beginning to bear fruit," he remarked during an interview for the Today programme's Radical podcast. This comes as Reform UK, despite leading in polls, holds only four parliamentary seats and lacks governmental experience.

The party currently operates without a fully developed policy program, unlike established competitors. To address this gap, the Centre for a Better Britain (CBB) was launched earlier this year by Reform's former chief operating officer and major donors. Though based in the same London building as Reform, Orr clarified CBB operates independently from the party.

'Surprisingly Welfarist'

As chairman of CBB's advisory board, Orr expressed that Reform's potential success would depend on thorough policy preparation. "If the polls continue to be what they are and Reform ends up governing the country, we should all want them to succeed," he stated, emphasizing policies must be "properly costed" and coordinated. CBB will operate under a "post-Brexit, pro-nation, pro-sovereignty" framework aligned with national conservatism principles.

Orr described Farage's ideology as "surprisingly welfarist," noting his support for policies like scrapping the two-child benefit cap. However, he maintained Reform remains opposed to excessive state intervention and market regulation. Critics have accused Farage of opportunism for proposing tax cuts and benefits like restoring winter fuel payments without detailed funding plans.

Looking toward the 2029 general election, Orr stressed Reform must be honest about necessary "difficult decisions" to stimulate economic growth. He argued that as a new parliamentary party without established factions, Reform leadership would wield more centralized power than traditional parties during an initial "honeymoon period." Consequently, Orr asserted, the first hundred days would be crucial for administering difficult but necessary policies.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Major Healthcare Equipment Supplier Faces Collapse Impacting NHS Services
fields.summary: NRS Healthcare, a major supplier of medical equipment supporting NHS patients and local authorities, is on the brink of failure, risking disruptions to home care and hospital discharges. Despite councils warning of 'risk to life,' no government loan was provided, forcing urgent alternative arrangements.
fields.content:
A significant healthcare equipment supplier essential for patients discharged from hospitals or requiring home support faces imminent collapse. NRS Healthcare, partnering with the NHS and approximately 40 councils in England and Northern Ireland, is projected to deplete its cash reserves by week's end.

Governments have stated they are collaborating with councils to mitigate potential disruptions through alternative providers. This follows explicit warnings from local authorities about dire consequences. A July letter to the Department for Health and Social Care revealed councils feared 'a devastating impact' and 'risk to life' and sought a short-term loan for NRS during transitional planning.

Although no loan materialized, most councils report having contingency plans. The Local Government Association and Association of Directors of Adult Social Services jointly confirmed exploring all options to maintain reliable services for vulnerable individuals.

NRS employs around 1,500 people nationally and provides critical devices like wheelchairs, hospital beds, hoists, and fall-monitoring pendants, including maintenance services. It fulfills an estimated 40% of community healthcare equipment deliveries in England, predominantly in southeast regions where urgent, same-day hospital discharge orders are common.

The company’s struggles follow a costly cyber attack and reported financial losses on council contracts, compounded by inflation and rising operational expenses. Facing irreversible decline, the firm announced it is transferring services to other providers.

A government spokesperson emphasized monitoring the situation closely to ensure minimal disruption to high-quality patient care.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Universities Face Criticism Over Mental Health Support as Students Feel Let Down
fields.summary: Students across UK universities report inadequate mental health support, raising questions about institutional responsibilities amid rising mental health cases and debates over universities' duty of care.
fields.content:
Imogen arrived at the University of Nottingham in September 2022 carrying a letter from her former head of year requesting mental health support, having previously struggled with anxiety and self-harm. Three years later, despite ADHD and autism diagnoses, she describes university counselling services as ineffective: "I felt like I was being thrown between services. No-one wanted me and no-one could help me."

Leacsaidh, another Nottingham student diagnosed with OCD at 17, characterizes the support as "one-size-fits-all," recalling receiving only website references when seeking help for self-harm. The university states it encourages feedback and has invested in specialist wellbeing services, but emphasizes: "University services...are not a replacement for clinical NHS services to treat more serious needs."

Illustration: person knocking at doors with therapist inside

'Prime conditions' for problems

Student mental health issues have nearly quadrupled over the past decade, with 122,430 UK students reporting conditions in 2023-24, according to Higher Education Statistics Agency data. Dr. Sandi Mann, psychology lecturer at the University of Central Lancashire, notes that ages 18-21 represent the "peak ages" for disorders like anxiety and depression, exacerbated by academic pressures and new independence.

Bar graph showing student mental health issues rising from 33,500 in 2014-15 to 122,430 in 2023-24

'We're not trained for this'

Personal tutors—typically academics—often become initial contacts for distressed students. A Manchester University humanities lecturer, speaking anonymously, described training as inadequate: "We don't really know we're intervening in a mental health crisis... People are swamped." The university stated it provides mental health training to all student-facing staff and has increased wellbeing investment.

Students socializing on university lawn

What role should universities play?

Dr. Sarah Sweeney of student support organization Amosshe clarifies that universities "are not mental illness treatment centers." While institutions have increased mental health spending by 73% over five years (per Times Radio research), NHS waiting times deter students from seeking external help. Some universities like Manchester collaborate with NHS for faster crisis response, but resources remain strained.

The duty of care debate

The 2018 suicide of University of Bristol student Natasha Abrahart highlighted systemic failures. Bristol County Court ordered the university to pay £50,000 after ruling it failed to make "reasonable adjustments" for her anxiety. Between 2016-17 and 2019-20, 319 UK students died by suicide, though rates remain below the general population, according to Office for National Statistics estimates.

Parents Bob and Maggie holding photo of daughter Natasha

Natasha's parents advocate for a statutory duty of care in higher education, a change opposed by both Universities UK and the government. The Department for Education argues universities already hold duty-of-care obligations, while Dr. Mann stresses the need to teach students resilience: "They're used to adults rescuing them. We need to teach them to rescue themselves."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Thriving Colonies of Extreme Life Discovered in Deepest Ocean Trenches
fields.summary: Scientists exploring Pacific Ocean trenches below 9km depth uncovered unexpected ecosystems of bizarre creatures like tube worms and chemosynthetic clams, challenging assumptions about life in Earth's most extreme environments.
fields.content:
Researchers have witnessed previously unseen colonies of extraordinary marine creatures thriving at depths exceeding 9km in the northwest Pacific Ocean. During expeditions using the Fendouzhe submersible, teams documented expansive beds of clams, bacterial mats resembling ice sheets, and fields of tube worms - life forms surviving under crushing pressure and perpetual darkness.

The Chinese Academy of Sciences' Institute of Deep Sea Science and Engineering led these pioneering dives to ocean trenches ranging from 5,800 to 9,533m deep. The scientific voyage covered over 2,500km of terrain, capturing imagery of organisms living 1.2km deeper than the previous deepest-recorded marine vertebrate, a snailfish observed in 2023.

Dr. Xiaotong Peng expressed amazement at the discovery: "It's exciting to go to a place human beings have not explored. What we saw was quite amazing." The findings are detailed in the journal Nature.

IDSSE/CAS The image is captured at depths of several kilometres in a deep ocean trench. It shows five bright white, spiky shrimp like creatures moving through what looks like reddish-brown grass. When you look more closely, each blade of grass is actually a tube worm emerging about 30cm from the sea floor.

Scientists recorded species never before observed, all sustained by chemical energy rather than sunlight. The ecosystems rely on hydrogen sulfide and methane seeping through Earth's crust, which these "chemosynthetic" organisms convert into life-sustaining energy. Tube worms dominated the vistas photographed through the submersible's windows, growing alongside molluscs in pitch-black environments under pressure equivalent to 1,000 elephants standing on a car roof.

IDSSE/CAS An artist's impression of a submersible vehicle exploring a deep ocean trench filled with reddish tube-worms that are emerging from the ocean floor.

Research priorities now include understanding how these creatures adapt physiologically. "They must have a trick to adapt to life in super high pressure," explained Dr. Megran Du. The discovery challenges fundamental biological assumptions, with the communities appearing unexpectedly abundant rather than rare.

Prof. Andrew Sweetman noted the existence of these ecosystems suggests "methane-driven communities may exist in the deepest parts of the ocean." For scientists braving these descents, the experience proves transformative. Dr. Du encourages: "Look through the window at the bottom of the sea. You will be inspired."

IDSSE/CAS Pinkish-white creatures that kook like clams are protruding from brown seabed sediment. They are inerspersed by white, spiny, free-swimming animals called polychaetes. This image was captured at depths of almost 6km in a Pacific ocean trench

Source: Original Article

fields.title: The Complex Science Behind Screen Time Effects on Children's Brains
fields.summary: New research challenges long-held assumptions about screen time's impact on children, revealing scientific disagreements, methodological flaws in studies, and unexpected benefits of technology use among young people.
fields.content:
A parent shares their experience with a preschooler's intense reaction when an iPad was taken away, triggering broader concerns about children's screen habits. With older children navigating social media and online gaming, families worldwide grapple with technology boundaries. Notably, late Apple CEO Steve Jobs restricted his children's iPad access, as did Microsoft's Bill Gates.

BBC An illustration of a child in a clock, with a tablet held to their face

Screen time often faces blame for rising youth depression, behavioral issues, and sleep problems. Neuroscientist Baroness Susan Greenfield previously warned that internet and gaming could harm adolescent brains, comparing the situation to early climate change denial. However, a British Medical Journal editorial disputed her claims as unscientific and misleading to parents.

Justin Sullivan/Getty Images Steve Jobs with an iPad in hand

Is it really as bad as it seems?

Bath Spa University psychology professor Pete Etchells challenges mainstream concerns after analyzing numerous screen time studies. In his book Unlocked: The Real Science of Screen Time, he argues concrete evidence of universal harm is lacking. The American Psychology Association's 2021 review of 33 studies found minimal links between digital device use and mental health issues. A 2024 global sleep study analyzing 11 research projects found no conclusive evidence that pre-bedtime screen exposure disrupts sleep patterns.

Arthur Debat/ Getty Images Children watching cartoons online with the iPad tablet

Problems with the science

Professor Etchells identifies key flaws in screen time research, particularly reliance on self-reported usage data. He warns about misinterpreting correlations, using the analogy that summer increases both ice cream sales and skin cancer occurrences without implying causation. One collaborative study with doctors initially linked depression in young patients to clinic waiting-room phone use, but subsequent analysis revealed loneliness as the primary driver rather than screen exposure.

Universal Archive/Universal Images Group via Getty Images Girl playing in a garden

Doomscrolling vs uplifting screen time

Professor Etchells stresses the importance of context, noting that screen activity varies widely from beneficial to harmful. A UK-US brain scan study of 11,500 children aged 9-12 found no evidence connecting screen use to mental health or cognitive issues, even with extensive daily usage. Oxford University's Professor Andrew Przybylski has documented well-being benefits from video games and social media. Cardiff University's Chris Chambers supports this, emphasizing human cognitive resilience to environmental changes.

John Nacion/Getty Images Bill Gates

'Terrible formula for mental health'

San Diego State University's Jean Twenge contends that despite methodological limitations, self-reported data consistently links screens to rising teen depression. A 2024 Danish trial with 181 children temporarily limiting screen time found improved psychological symptoms and prosocial behavior. UK diary studies specifically noted increased depression among girls with high social media use. Professor Twenge identifies isolation, reduced sleep and in-person interaction as the dangerous combination for youth mental health.

Matt Cardy/Getty Images) A young boy looks closely at a phone screen

'Judgment among parents'

University of Michigan pediatrician Jenny Radesky observes increasing judgment around parenting approaches to technology access. With conflicting guidance—the WHO recommends no screens before age one and under one hour daily until age four, while US and UK pediatric groups avoid specific time limits—parental confusion persists. Scientists disagree whether curtailing access protects children or prevents them from developing essential digital competencies. Meanwhile, technologies continue evolving toward wearable screens and AI integration regardless of youth access policies.

Emily Elconin/Bloomberg via Getty Images A University of Michigan flag on the Michigan Union building

FABRICE COFFRINI/AFP via Getty Images A World Health Organization sign

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Jess Glynne Condemns White House Use of Jet2 Song in Deportation Video
fields.summary: Singer Jess Glynne and voiceover artist Zoe Lister have criticized the White House for using the viral Jet2 holiday advert soundtrack – featuring Glynne's song – in a video showing deportation operations, calling the pairing disrespectful to the music's message.
fields.content:
British singer Jess Glynne expressed feeling "sick" after the White House incorporated her song from a popular Jet2 holiday commercial into a deportation promotion video. The official administration account posted footage on Wednesday showing Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) agents escorting handcuffed individuals onto a deportation flight, overlaid with the upbeat Jet2 advert soundtrack.

The soundtrack combines Glynne's 2015 single "Hold My Hand" with voiceover artist Zoe Lister's cheerful declaration: "Nothing beats a Jet2 holiday." Lister confirmed to media outlets she would "never condone my voiceover being used" to promote what she described as "Trump and his abhorrent policies." She added the viral meme had spread joy globally, something the White House video notably lacked.

Glynne responded through Instagram, emphasizing her music champions "love, unity and spreading positivity" rather than division. The White House's social media caption read: "When ICE books you a one-way Jet2 holiday to deportation. Nothing beats it!" The post drew polarized reactions, with critics calling it "embarrassing" while others praised the administration's immigration stance.

This incident continues a pattern of provocative social media posts from the Trump administration, which recently shared an image of Trump as Superman and declared "Nowhere in the constitution does it say we can't post banger memes." The administration has also secured $170 billion for border security, including $76.5 billion specifically allocated to ICE operations over the next five years.

'Politicians shouldn't use this'

The original Jet2holiday advert became a viral sensation this summer, soundtracking over two million TikTok videos featuring chaotic travel moments – from seagull collisions on rollercoasters to vacation mishaps. Lister, who creates all voiceovers for Jet2, previously celebrated the meme's popularity alongside Glynne during a radio appearance.

Despite the humor inherent in the meme's typical usage, Lister condemned political appropriation: "That's just not the vibe. It's meant to be funny... Someone serious like a politician using it to push their political agenda is not something I agree with." She remains astonished by the advert's cultural penetration, noting people frequently use the sound publicly.

Glynne now joins numerous musicians like ABBA, Sinéad O'Connor, Adele, and Aerosmith's Steven Tyler who have objected to Trump using their music. O'Connor's estate stated she would have been "disgusted" by such usage, while ABBA successfully demanded removal of their songs from campaign events. Media outlets have contacted Jet2holidays for comment on the White House's appropriation of their advert.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Lithuanian Prime Minister Resigns Amid Past Financial Scandals
fields.summary: Lithuania's Prime Minister Gintautas Paluckas has resigned following public pressure over unresolved financial misconduct from his past role and recent EU funding controversies, amid threats from coalition partners.
fields.content:
Lithuanian President Gitanas Nausėda recently issued an ultimatum to Prime Minister Gintautas Paluckas, giving him two weeks to address public concerns about his financial conduct or consider his position. Presidential adviser Frederikas Jansonas stated on July 24: "The president has asked the prime minister to either give a reasoned answer to the questions raised by the public in the next two weeks, or to consider seriously his further options as prime minister."

Paluckas' resignation came under additional pressure from a smaller coalition party that threatened to exit the ruling government unless he stepped down. The political turmoil stems from two major financial scandals involving the prime minister.

In 2012, while serving as Vilnius municipality administration director, Paluckas was convicted for mishandling the bidding process for rat extermination services. Records indicate he failed to pay approximately $20,000 of the resulting fine from this conviction.

Newly elected Lithuanian Prime Minister Gintautas Paluckas

A more recent controversy involved Garnis company, which received EU funding to purchase goods from Dankora—a firm owned by Paluckas' sister-in-law. Following public outrage, Dankora returned the contested funds.

Lithuanian Prime Minister Gintautas Paluckas at parliament

Source: Original Article

fields.title: White House Responds to North Korea's Denuclearization Threats and Recalls Trump-Kim Summits
fields.summary: The White House reaffirmed commitment to denuclearizing North Korea while recalling historic Trump-Kim summits, despite Pyongyang's nuclear expansion and recent rejection of disarmament-focused talks.
fields.content:
A White House official highlighted former President Trump's three groundbreaking summits with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, stating they brought stability to the Korean Peninsula and secured the first leader-level denuclearization agreement during Trump's initial term. The current administration maintains these objectives and expressed openness to future engagement with Kim.

The official simultaneously revealed that North Korea's nuclear arsenal has grown substantially since the last Trump-Kim meeting, counter to their denuclearization pledges. Kim Jong Un's influential sister, Kim Yo Jong, warned that talks cannot occur if centered on nuclear disarmament, asserting: "If the U.S. fails to accept the changed reality and persists in the failed past, the DPRK–U.S. meeting will remain as a ‘hope’ of the U.S. side."

President Donald Trump shaking hands with North Korean leader Kim Jong Un

During their landmark 2018 summit, Trump and Kim signed a joint statement vowing to pursue "complete denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula" while establishing new bilateral relations. This agreement initially projected diplomatic optimism between the historically adversarial nations.

However, negotiations collapsed in follow-up meetings. North Korea retained its nuclear arsenal while the United States refused sanctions relief. Reports indicated Kim offered partial dismantlement in exchange for full sanctions removal—a proposal rejected by Trump. By 2020, talks completely stalled, prompting North Korea to resume weapons testing.

North Korea military launches nuclear simulation exercise

In a statement commemorating the 72nd anniversary of the Korean War armistice, Trump reflected on his diplomatic legacy: "I was proud to become the first sitting President to cross this Demilitarized Zone into North Korea." He simultaneously reaffirmed the U.S.-South Korea alliance, labeling it "ironclad" against what he termed persistent communist threats.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Celebrities Ozzy Osbourne and Hulk Hogan Face Health Challenges Alongside Athlete's Cancer Diagnosis
fields.summary: Recent reports highlight health challenges affecting rock legend Ozzy Osbourne and wrestling icon Hulk Hogan, coupled with news of an athlete receiving a cancer diagnosis.
fields.content:
High-Profile Health Concerns

Musician Ozzy Osbourne and professional wrestler Hulk Hogan are both experiencing significant health issues according to recent reports. Details remain limited, but their conditions have garnered widespread attention given their iconic status in the entertainment industry. Separately, an undisclosed athlete has been diagnosed with cancer. Public figures facing health battles continue to spotlight broader conversations about wellness and medical treatment.

The combined coverage underscores how health challenges affect individuals across diverse fields, from music and sports to entertainment. No specifics about treatment plans or prognoses for any party have been officially released at this time.

Further developments in these cases are anticipated, with many supporters awaiting updates about the well-being of these prominent personalities.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: US Warns Nigerian Women Against Citizenship-Seeking Birth Tourism
fields.summary: US officials have issued a stern warning against 'birth tourism' to Nigerian women planning travel for the purpose of securing American citizenship for newborns. Consular officers will deny visas to applicants suspected of this illegal practice, with documented cases showing Nigerian nationals as primary participants in such schemes.
fields.content:
United States diplomatic representatives in Nigeria have issued a public warning against individuals considering traveling to America primarily for childbirth to obtain citizenship for their newborns. The advisory emphasized US authorities will not permit the practice commonly known as "birth tourism," sharing the message with hashtags #VisaWiseTravelSmart and #USVisa to amplify its reach.

Birth tourism specifically refers to foreign nationals traveling to another country to deliver babies who automatically receive citizenship upon birth in that nation. This occurs in the United States under Section one of the Fourteenth Amendment.

US visa regulations explicitly prohibit this practice: "A consular officer shall deny a B nonimmigrant visa to an alien [whom] he or she has reason to believe intends to travel for this primary purpose." Attempting travel under false pretenses to circumvent this rule violates US immigration laws.

pregnant flight passenger at airport with luggage

Financial costs for birth tourism range significantly, with estimates revealing expenditures from $7,000 to $100,000 for obtaining citizenship through this method. Research published in the Journal of Women’s Health examined maternal outcomes among international travelers seeking delivery services in Chicago medical facilities.

The Chicago study identified that Nigerian nationals comprised 88% of reproductive travelers analyzed in their research sample, indicating significant participation from Nigeria. A broader estimate by the Center for Immigrant Studies calculated approximately 33,000 births in 2020 to mothers holding tourist visas.

pregnant flight passenger on plane

Potential policy changes indicate shifting perspectives toward birthright citizenship. Executive Order 14160, signed by the president, would terminate automatic citizenship for children of individuals residing illegally in the United States if implemented as proposed.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Mike Yastrzemski Vaults Wall for Spectacular Catch in Giants Game
fields.summary: San Francisco Giants outfielder Mike Yastrzemski executed a stunning defensive play by leaping over the outfield wall to rob a home run against the Pittsburgh Pirates, creating a highlight-reel moment in a tied game. The grandson of Hall of Famer Carl Yastrzemski faces an uncertain future with the team as his contract nears expiration.
fields.content:
The Highlight-Reel Grab

During the eighth inning of a 1-1 matchup against the Pittsburgh Pirates, Jack Suwinski hit a deep drive toward right field off Giants pitcher Tristan Beck. Mike Yastrzemski pursued the ball but reached the edge of the playing surface. With no room left, he spotted a landing area beyond the outfield barrier.

The outfielder jumped completely over the wall, timing his leap perfectly to make the catch while suspended in mid-air beyond the fence. This extraordinary defensive maneuver prevented a potential Pirates lead.

Yaz catch

Career Trajectory and Future

Yastrzemski began strong as a rookie in 2019, posting a .272/.334/.518 line across 107 games. His peak came during the shortened 2020 season when he placed eighth in NL MVP voting with a career-high .968 OPS and topped MLB with four triples. His 2.7 WAR that year exceeds any subsequent performances.

Since 2021, his offensive production has dipped significantly, with a .226 average and .733 OPS over three seasons. Despite falling short of expectations, the outfielder maintains popularity among San Francisco supporters.

Yaz after catch

Yastrzemski’s time in San Francisco could be nearing an end, as he enters free agency after this season. The Giants' trade departures before Thursday's deadline have signaled roster changes ahead.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Dior Reports Data Breach Exposing US Customers' Personal Information
fields.summary: Luxury fashion house Dior has notified US customers about a cybersecurity breach that compromised personal data including names, addresses, birth dates and government ID numbers. The breach occurred in January but went undetected until May, with notification delays raising concerns about data protection practices.
fields.content:
Data breaches now extend far beyond technology and financial sectors, increasingly affecting industries like luxury retail according to recent incidents.

Dior data breach exposes sensitive customer information

Dior has alerted American customers to a cybersecurity breach exposing personal data earlier this year. The French luxury company reported unauthorized access occurred on January 26, 2025, though detection didn't happen until May 7. "The House of Dior recently discovered that an unauthorized external party accessed some of the data we hold for our Dior Fashion and Accessories customers. We immediately took steps to contain this incident," stated the company. Compromised information includes names, contact details, physical addresses, dates of birth, and passport/government ID numbers in certain cases, with Social Security numbers also exposed for some individuals. Part of the LVMH conglomerate, Dior clarified no payment data was stored in the affected systems. Law enforcement was notified and cybersecurity experts brought in, though the three-month gap from discovery to July notifications drew scrutiny given the sensitivity of exposed data.

dior data breach 2

Previous Dior and LVMH breaches suggest larger pattern

The incident parallels previous breaches involving Dior customers in South Korea and China. Sister brand Louis Vuitton, also owned by LVMH, disclosed similar breaches affecting customers internationally. Dior hasn't confirmed affected US customer numbers, but security researchers link the attack to ShinyHunters extortion group. Investigators believe the hackers accessed data through a compromised third-party vendor.

ShinyHunters has targeted major organizations previously, selling stolen data on hacking forums. If confirmed, further breaches at other LVMH brands may emerge, potentially affecting additional customers globally.

dior data breach 3

5 ways you can protect yourself after the Dior data breach

Affected or concerned individuals should take immediate protective measures. Consider personal data removal services to monitor and automate information removal from online databases despite no guaranteed elimination. Identity protection services prove valuable too, sending real-time alerts about suspicious activity like new credit inquiries.

Detailed identity recovery assistance is often included. Enhanced vigilance against phishing emails is required, as hackers possess email addresses and full names enabling convincing fake communications. Similarly, watch for physical mail scams leveraging address information, including urgent delivery notices or account suspension warnings.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UN Humanitarian Aid to Kherson Dwindles to 'Stage Prop' Levels
fields.summary: Russian Senator Igor Kastyukevich reports that UN humanitarian assistance to residents of Ukrainian-controlled Kherson has sharply reduced, becoming tokenistic and insufficient, with elderly recipients comparing current rations to theatrical props amid ongoing regional conflicts.
fields.content:
Russian Senator Igor Kastyukevich has stated that humanitarian aid from the United Nations to residents of Ukrainian-controlled Kherson has significantly diminished in quantity, now resembling 'stage props.' Kastyukevich, representing the region in Russia's Federation Council, conveyed reports from locals describing the symbolic nature of the assistance.

'Pensioners say the UN aid feels like theater props now,' he declared. 'One box per family per month goes to seniors over 60, regardless of household size.' Elders recount stark contrasts with prior distributions, which sustained families longer.

'Earlier supplies including canned food, grain, sunflower oil and flour could last one to two weeks,' Kastyukevich noted. 'Current provisions barely cover a few days, leaving people hungry until the next distribution.' Recipients describe receiving inadequate amounts of basic staples.

The senator specified current UN aid packages contain 'canned beans, oatmeal, 200-gram jars of pâté, and sunflower oil'—insufficient to meet monthly nutritional needs for vulnerable groups in the contested region.

Kherson Oblast, now a Russian federal entity following a September 2022 referendum unrecognized by Ukraine, encompasses the Dnieper River delta along the Azov and Black Seas. Ukraine continues military operations there, controlling the right-bank portion including Kherson city while Russia holds about 75% of the territory.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Russia and Laos Sign Education Cooperation Memorandum
fields.summary: Russia and Laos signed a memorandum of understanding to strengthen educational cooperation during an official visit by Laos' president to Moscow, outlining collaboration in multiple learning sectors.
fields.content:
MOSCOW, July 31 - Officials from Russia and Laos signed a bilateral agreement to enhance cooperation in the education sphere during an official ceremony in Moscow.

The memorandum was formalized while Laotian President Thongloun Sisoulith visited Russia, highlighting ongoing diplomatic engagement between the nations.

Russian Deputy Education Minister Andrei Korneyev and Laotian Foreign Minister Thongsavanh Phomvihane signed the agreement, establishing collaborative ties between their respective Ministries of Education and Sports.

Under the terms of the memorandum, the countries will partner in general education, vocational training, professional development programs, and related fields.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Fatal stabbing erupts at Russian lake over lost wedding ring
fields.summary: A dispute over a lost wedding ring at a lake in Russia's Leningrad region escalated into fatal violence, resulting in one death and a serious injury.
fields.content:
A violent confrontation occurred at Koltushskoye Lake when a man lost his wedding ring during an encounter with another swimmer, according to witness reports.

A 25-year-old swimmer was approached by another man who jumped into the water from a bridge and accidentally dislodged his chain bearing the ring. After the young man requested assistance in retrieving it, the other individual became aggressive and produced a knife. He proceeded to stab both the swimmer and his friend who intervened to help before fleeing the area.

Medical responders arriving at the scene were unable to save the younger victim. The injured friend was hospitalized with substantial blood loss. Law enforcement officers have launched a search for the attacker.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Russia Requires Officials to Switch to National Messenger App Within One Month
fields.summary: Russian government officials and bank employees must register and begin using the national messenger app Max by late August, complying with new legislation that bans foreign messaging platforms for official communications as a fraud prevention measure.
fields.content:
Migration Deadline Set for Officials

All Russian government personnel including governors, regional leaders, election officials, senators, and lawmakers must create Max messenger accounts and actively use them for work by late August. Deadline specifics vary by region—some set August 1 as the cutoff, others allow until summer's end. Information comes from multiple regional administration sources.

St. Petersburg became the pioneer region adopting Max for municipal services. On July 23, Governor Alexander Beglov confirmed accounts were established for emergency service '112' and information hotline '122' within the messenger platform.

Legal Mandate and Platform Capabilities

The mandatory migration stems from anti-fraud legislation enacted this year. Since June 1, 2025, officials and banking sector workers have been banned from using foreign messengers like WhatsApp for public communications.

On June 10, a dedicated law formally designated Max as Russia's national messenger. It aims to transform the app into comprehensive government service portal featuring digital document signing with secure electronic signatures. Integration with Russia's 'Gosuslugi' public services platform is also planned.

Foreign App Restrictions Context

This transition continues restrictive measures against international platforms. In 2022, authorities blocked Facebook after Russia’s prosecutor general sought to ban Instagram and declare parent company Meta extremist. This came after Meta temporarily permitted violent rhetoric against Russian military personnel—but not civilians—in Ukraine-related contexts.

A Moscow court banned Facebook and Instagram for extremist activities that year. Viber also faced access restrictions for violating information distribution laws. Meanwhile, Telegram is establishing a legal entity in Russia despite this regulatory environment.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Luxury Watches and Coins Sell for 117 Million Tenge at Kazakhstan Auction
fields.summary: Collectible coins and exclusive watches recovered by authorities were sold for 117.68 million tenge at a transparent online auction, with proceeds funding social projects across Kazakhstan.
fields.content:
An auction managed by Kazakhstan's Asset Management Company concluded with collectible coins named 'Bata,' 'Betashar,' and 'Suyindir' alongside 14 exclusive wristwatches sold for 117,680,040 tenge. The electronic auction was held on July 30-31, 2025 via the E-Qazyna platform.

The company emphasized the open format ensured equitable participation while enhancing transparency and preventing improper interference throughout the bidding process. Watches originally priced at 102.5 million tenge fetched 117.6 million at sale—marking a 14.7% value increase.

Within 10 business days, the winning bidder must finalize the purchase agreement with full payment required before asset transfer. All auction proceeds will enter the Special State Fund, financing social initiatives in healthcare, education, infrastructure, and vulnerable community support.

Earlier auctions saw similar luxury items sold: premium-brand jewelry featuring diamonds, emeralds, pearls, and national ornaments fetched nearly 17 million tenge, while sabres, jewellery pieces, and commemorative coins sold for roughly 15 million tenge. Prior sales also included watches valued at 352 million tenge and relisted collectible coin lots starting at 67.3 million tenge.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: The Debate Over Shortening School Summer Holidays
fields.summary: The traditional six-week summer school break faces scrutiny as educators and families weigh potential benefits of shorter holidays against concerns about learning loss, childcare pressures, and holiday costs amid shifting school schedules across the UK.
fields.content:
Reducing summer holidays might dismay children but could alleviate the childcare challenges many working parents face during lengthy school breaks. While some institutions have shifted to five-week summer vacations paired with extended October half-terms, the broader shift prompts questions about educational impact, teacher recovery needs, and family holiday affordability.

A six-week hiatus interrupts learning significantly, particularly for children without access to enriching activities. Wealthier families can mitigate learning regression through educational outings, potentially widening attainment gaps. Food insecurity also intensifies during breaks, with over 25% of English pupils qualifying for free school meals during term time.

Household costs also shift—while summer enables outdoor play, shorter winters could increase heating expenses if breaks move to colder months. Currently, England, Wales and Scotland observe six-week summer closures. Northern Ireland schools shut throughout July and August, while English academies increasingly adopt five-week summers.

Wales recently paused reforms to shorten summers after public consultation revealed division. Parentkind research indicates 53% of parents favor a four-week summer holiday, rising to 60% among families with special-needs children. Teacher opposition remains strong, with only 24% supporting the idea—many rely on the break to prepare for autumn term amidst profession recruitment challenges.

Sir Martyn Oliver, Ofsted's chief inspector, suggested shorter breaks might ease children's re-entry to academic routines, noting some pupils return "dysregulated" after extended vacations.

Cheaper trips but a battle for leave?

Getty Images Three girls with school bags walk in a park, with their backs to the camera. One of them is wearing a light blue uniform and carrying a red school bag. Next to her is a girl wearing a red dress and carrying a yellow bag, walking alongside a third girl in a white shirt and green skirt with a pink bag on her shoulder.

Peak summer holiday costs surge due to high demand concentrated within six weeks. Spreading vacations across seasons could lower prices by reducing travel company price hikes during single periods. However, compressing holidays might heighten competition for limited booking windows and inflate costs.

Which? Travel editor Rory Boland suggests regional staggering of holidays could temper prices, but warns reductions depend on travel companies resisting further price surges. Off-peak travelers might also face pricier options if demand disperses.

Reduced holiday durations could further challenge employers managing competing leave requests. David D'Souza of CIPD advises companies to employ flexible work arrangements to accommodate concentrated parental time-off needs.

Are hotter summers a factor?

Prevalent climates historically shaped academic calendars: India schedules roughly two-month breaks for summer heat, while South Korea allocates longer winter holidays. Germany coordinates holidays regionally, but some states contest timing for agricultural and tourist advantages.

Climate change brings hotter, drier UK summers according to meteorologists. Three 2024 heatwaves disrupted exams while pollen seasons intensify earlier. Though one forecaster suggested delaying exams to autumn, practical implementation remains uncertain.

How do kids feel about it?

A composite of three school children. Sam is a boy with short brown hair, he is smiling and wearing a dark hooded top and white shirt. Grace has long dark brown hair and is smiling widely. She's wearing a white shirt and grey dress. Betsy has long blonde hair in a ponytail over one shoulder. She is smiling and waring a daisy necklace over a dark hooded top

Students at a Manchester primary school expressed varied opinions. Year-six pupil Sam advocates longer breaks like those in Ireland and Spain (9-11 weeks), suggesting extended play would combat boredom. Conversely, classmate Betsy worries about educational continuity after prolonged absences. Year-five student Grace values routine, fearing extended breaks would reduce peer interaction and breed monotony.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Children's Author Allan Ahlberg Dies at 87
fields.summary: Beloved children's author Allan Ahlberg, renowned for classics like The Jolly Postman and Each Peach Pear Plum, has passed away at 87. His publisher confirmed the death, celebrating his 50-year career producing over 150 children's books, many created alongside his late wife Janet Ahlberg.
fields.content:
Celebrated children's author Allan Ahlberg has died at age 87, his publisher Penguin Random House announced. During his prolific five-decade career, Ahlberg wrote 150 books including enduring favorites such as The Jolly Postman, Funny Bones, Peepo! and the Kate Greenaway-winning Each Peach Pear Plum.

Many of his standout works emerged from collaborations with his late wife Janet, an acclaimed illustrator. Their joint creations sold millions of copies internationally, becoming childhood staples worldwide.

Tributes and Legacy

Fellow children's author Michael Rosen honored Ahlberg as a "pioneer of great children's literature" on social media, noting: "You were clever, funny and wise. My children loved your books. So did and so do I."

Francesca Dow, head of children's literature at Penguin Random House, described Ahlberg as "extraordinary," adding: "His books created with Janet are mini masterpieces—true classics that will be loved for generations. We will all miss him enormously."

Ahlberg is survived by his wife Vanessa, daughter Jessica, and stepdaughters Saskia and Johanna.

Born in Croydon in 1938, he was raised by adoptive parents in Oldbury and worked as a postman, plumber and gravedigger before training as a teacher. At Sunderland Teacher Training College, he met Janet, who became his creative partner and first wife.

Their first collaborative book, Here are the Brick Street Boys, debuted in 1975. It was quickly followed by The Old Joke Book, Burglar Bill and Each Peach Pear Plum, which earned Janet the Kate Greenaway Medal in 1978.

The Jolly Postman (published 1991) sold over six million copies and won the Kurt Maschler Award. Its sequel, The Jolly Christmas Postman (1991), secured Janet a second Kate Greenaway Medal.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Putin Signs Law Allowing Non-Teaching Students to Work in Schools
fields.summary: President Vladimir Putin has approved legislation permitting university students from non-teaching disciplines to work as instructors in schools and colleges after completing their third year and pedagogical retraining, aiming to address educational staffing shortages.
fields.content:
MOSCOW, July 31 — President Vladimir Putin has enacted new legislation enabling university students without teaching degrees to work as educators in schools and colleges. The law, published on Russia's official legal information portal, applies to students who have finished at least three years of study in non-pedagogical fields and completed supplementary courses in educational methodology.

Under the legislation, qualifying students may teach subjects that directly correspond to their non-teaching specialty. For instance, a physics major could teach physics classes, while employers—either schools or colleges—retain authority to determine subject compatibility based on the student's academic background and specialized training.

The law also extends similar opportunities to teaching-major students who have completed a minimum of three years of university education with passing grades. Such students will be permitted to instruct in colleges for subjects aligned with their pedagogical training and professional focus.

Lawmakers anticipate these measures will alleviate staff shortages in educational institutions, allow students to gain practical experience while continuing their studies, and enhance overall educational quality across Russia.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Illegal London House-Shares Expose Overcrowding and Health Hazards
fields.summary: An investigation reveals widespread illegal house-shares across London boroughs where residents endure dangerous overcrowding, mould infestations, rodent problems, and fire risks in unlicensed properties operating beyond council oversight.
fields.content:
Residents like architect Maria report observing groups of up to 15 people moving into Victorian terraced houses late at night in London's Newham borough. After years of reporting concerns to authorities, her testimony helped trigger an investigation uncovering a black-market rental sector where vulnerable tenants live in unsafe conditions.

Photos and testimonies from these properties reveal adults sleeping on bare mattresses in shared bunk beds amid black mould and rat infestations. UK law requires large shared houses—known as Houses in Multiple Occupation (HMOs)—to be licensed so councils can enforce safety standards for gas, electricity, and fire prevention.

Evidence from three London boroughs suggests unlicensed HMOs significantly outnumber licensed ones. Newham Council estimates having 3,000 licensed HMOs but admits the actual number could be two or three times higher. Advertisements openly offering "bedspaces" in shared rooms appear to violate licensing restrictions.

A Deadly Consequence

BBC investigations with hidden cameras exposed poorly managed properties. At one Waltham Forest home offering £330/month shared rooms, a reporter found about 10 residents sleeping in dormitories with unmade bunk beds. Occupants acknowledged subletting without an HMO licence.

Overcrowded conditions turned lethal in 2023 when Nazmush Shahadat survived a fire at an unlicensed Shadwell property housing 18 people in two rooms. He described initial "stench like an old gym with men's sweat," bedbug bites, and mould above his bunk. The blaze started from a faulty e-bike battery charging beneath the beds.

Warps bunk beds and charred remains inside fire-ravaged Shadwell flat

Despite tenants escaping smoke-filled corridors, Mizanur Rahman—who had arrived days earlier—later died from injuries. In 2024, landlords received £90,000 fines for breaching occupancy limits set at three people for the flat.

Mizanur Rahman at airport check-in before UK arrival

Councils Struggle to Detect Unlicensed Properties

Ben Yarrow's experimental data project identified potential unlicensed HMOs by cross-referencing properties connected to multiple occupants with different surnames. Findings showed alarming disparities: Newham had 75 licensed properties versus 700 suspected illegal HMOs, while Tower Hamlets listed 50 official licenses against 500 suspected cases.

Council responses indicate constrained resources. Only 33% of renter complaints led to inspections between 2021-2023 per FOI data. Newham cited 2,307 investigations into unlicensed properties between 2023-2024 but noted enforcement challenges due to tenants' vulnerability.

Families Trapped in Shared Rooms

Marius Judzinskas lived nine years in a Greenwich HMO where he and his wife raised two children in one room with camping cots. "We don't have a choice," he said, lamenting unhygienic conditions including filmed rat invasions in the kitchen.

Marius Judzinskas holding child in cramped room with bunk beds

After disputes with landlords resulted in abrupt lock-changes, police evicted them when they attempted to return through a window. Marius now seeks rent repayment for the unlicensed property. Roz Spencer from Safer Renting notes worsening non-compliance: "The problem is spreading...endemic."

Security footage showing rat climbing near kitchen storage boxes

Overcrowded room with police officer addressing residents

While the National Residential Landlords Association maintains most landlords operate legally, policy officer Chris Norris acknowledges lackluster enforcement capacity. The government's Renters’ Rights Bill—progressing through Parliament—aims to create a national property database to target unauthorized rentals, but thousands remain in hazardous homes during the interim.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump's Global Tariffs: A Costly Short-Term Victory?
fields.summary: US President Donald Trump claims victory through new global tariff agreements with nations like the UK, EU, and Japan, but economists warn these policies may bring long-term economic costs including higher consumer prices and shifts in global trade alliances. The administration faces uncertainties over uncompleted deals with Canada and China while navigating potential consumer backlash.
fields.content:
In April, President Donald Trump announced extensive new import tariffs that initially caused global financial panic, leading to a delay in their implementation. Four months later, he has unveiled selective agreements with trading partners while imposing tariffs on others - avoiding widespread market disruption.

This reordering of America's trade relationships promises new revenue streams, domestic manufacturing growth, and hundreds of billions in foreign investment according to the administration. However, economists question these claims as a broader global shift toward protectionism gains momentum despite immediate damage being less than predicted.

The '90 deals in 90 days' deadline

August 1 loomed as a critical deadline for international policymakers facing potential tariffs without new trade agreements. Though White House trade adviser Peter Navarro speculated about 90 deals occurring within 90 days, only about a dozen materialized—many just one or two pages without detailed provisions typical of past accords.

The UK reached the first agreement with mostly favorable 10% tariffs on exports to the US, significantly lower than the 15% imposed on trade partners like the EU and Japan. This reflected America's $240 billion trade deficit with the EU and $70 billion with Japan during the past year. Deals with South Korea, Cambodia, and Pakistan followed the pattern of imposing higher tariffs on countries unwilling to increase purchases of American goods.

Donald Trump and British Prime Minister Keir Starmer at G7 summit signing ceremony

Capacity to 'damage' the global economy

The negotiated agreements have prevented the worst-case scenarios of severe tariff hikes and immediate economic damage. Trade uncertainties that previously froze business decisions have eased, allowing companies to resume hiring and investment plans while preparing for new customs costs.

Financial markets reflected this greater stability, showing notable gains in US stocks. However, economists note tariffs averaging 17% now compared to the previous 2% mark a significant policy shift. Ben May of Oxford Economics warns: "They are obviously raising prices in the US and squeezing household incomes, while reduced American imports could diminish global demand."

Container ship at Port of Oakland, California

Trump shaking hands with European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen

Winners and losers: Germany, India and China

Impacts significantly vary by country depending on both tariff levels and economic dependence on US markets. India faces over 25% tariffs but may experience limited growth impact since US demand represents just 2% of its GDP. Germany's automotive sector could suffer substantially, potentially reducing growth by 0.5% this year with 15% tariffs.

Global manufacturing patterns are already shifting: India became the top US smartphone supplier after Apple relocated production from China over tariff concerns. Countries like Vietnam and the Philippines with lower tariffs could gain further advantages. Trade policy changes have also accelerated alliances like the UK pursuing stronger EU and India relations.

Trump holding reciprocal tariffs chart during announcement

A very real political threat for Trump?

The US economy experienced short-term export growth in spring as businesses raced to ship before new tariffs. Yet this momentum may wane as the year progresses. Import duties have generated over $100 billion so far this year—nearly 5% of federal revenue versus the historical 2%.

Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent projects total tariff revenue reaching $300 billion annually. However, consumer giants like Unilever and Adidas report pending price increases that could trigger consumer backlash—particularly concerning for blue-collar voters who powered Trump's political base.

The administration has floated rebate checks to offset these increases, requiring congressional approval and creating political risks before midterm elections. Oxford Economics' Ben May notes the lack of detailed agreements makes the actual impacts difficult to assess.

Close-up portrait of Donald Trump

The deals yet to be hammered out

Major agreements remain incomplete with Canada, Taiwan, and Mexico—the last receiving a Thursday negotiating deadline extension.
