Critical sectors including pharmaceuticals and steel await tariff decisions. The most significant unresolved issue is how to approach China under a separate negotiation timeline.

Many announced deals lack binding commitments: some depend on verbal agreements and unspecified investment amounts. Foreign leaders have occasionally contradicted the president's claims regarding agreements. If the new tariffs trigger a large-scale trade alliance realignment bypassing the US, long-term consequences may not favor American priorities.

History suggests Trump's goal of relocating jobs to America may see minimal success, while short-term impacts may include reduced consumer choice and slower economic growth.

Trump meeting with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Supreme Court Paves Way for Millions in Car Finance Compensation
fields.summary: A landmark ruling by the UK's Supreme Court could enable millions of motorists to claim compensation for mis-sold car finance deals. The decision addresses hidden commissions paid to car dealers and may result in billions in payouts, with potential impacts on lending markets across the country.
fields.content:
The UK's Supreme Court is poised to make a decisive ruling that could allow millions of drivers to seek compensation over alleged motor finance mis-selling. This judgment will determine whether to uphold a prior ruling declaring undisclosed commissions paid to car dealers unlawful.

Nearly 90% of new vehicles were purchased using finance agreements during the affected period. A verdict against lenders might trigger billions in compensation claims dating back years, paralleling the payment protection insurance scandal in scale. Major institutions like Lloyds Bank have already allocated substantial sums in anticipation.

How cars were bought

Most new and used car transactions relied on finance deals where customers placed deposits and borrowed the balance. Dealers often received commissions from lenders for arranging these agreements. Some operated discretionary commission arrangements (DCAs), earning higher payments by securing elevated interest rates for consumers, a practice banned by regulators in 2021.

Jemma Caffrey

The Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) may establish a central compensation scheme for affected borrowers. Individuals like Jemma Caffrey from Blackburn, who purchased a car in 2009 while caring for her medically vulnerable newborn, hope for larger settlements through courts. "I feel I was taken advantage of as a vulnerable new mum," said Caffrey after discovering her high-interest Corsa loan.

Marcus Johnson sitting at home

The Supreme Court is examining whether nearly all hidden commissions—not just DCAs—breached legal standards. Test cases include Marcus Johnson from Torfaen, who unknowingly financed a Suzuki Swift in 2017. Solicitors argue such payments constituted bribes under common law, with courts previously ruling brokers failed their duty to act in borrowers' best interests.

Economic fallout

Motor finance firms maintain they operated within known regulatory boundaries. The Finance and Leasing Association seeks definitive legal clarity from the court. The Treasury worries massive redress payments might destabilize markets, compromising UK competitiveness, while Liberal Democrat parliamentarian Bobby Dean counters that consumer protection bolsters economic confidence.

The FCA will announce compensation procedures within six weeks of the ruling. Analysts fear lenders could increase credit costs across products—from car loans to mortgages—to recoup losses. "Good regulation can protect consumers and support the economy simultaneously," Dean stated.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Government restricts civil service internships to working class students
fields.summary: The UK government will exclusively reserve civil service internships for students from lower socio-economic backgrounds in a bid to make Whitehall more representative. Critics condemn the move as 'leftist social engineering' while supporters argue it addresses class imbalances in public service.
fields.content:
The UK government has announced a major shift in civil service recruitment, restricting internships exclusively to students from poorer family backgrounds. This policy aims to increase working-class representation across Whitehall departments.

Eligibility for the primary internship program will depend on parental occupation when applicants were 14 years old. Successful candidates will later receive priority entry to the Fast Stream graduate recruitment scheme.

Conservative shadow Cabinet Office minister Mike Wood expressed strong opposition, stating: "No young person should be told they're not welcome based solely on leftist social engineering."

The reform spearheaded by Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster Pat McFadden emphasizes inclusivity. McFadden told the BBC: "We need to get more working class young people into the civil service so it harnesses the broadest range of talent and truly reflects the country. Government makes better decisions when it represents and understands the people we serve."

Currently, students from lower socio-economic backgrounds comprise roughly 25% of higher education enrollments but constituted only 12% of successful Fast Stream applicants in 2024. Some Labour ministers reportedly believe parts of the civil service remain dominated by privileged backgrounds.

The existing summer internship program pays undergraduates £430 weekly during 6-8 weeks of work. Under new rules effective October 2025, approximately 200 annual placements will exclusively accept candidates from disadvantaged backgrounds.

Participants gain experience through organizing events, drafting ministerial briefings, shadowing officials, and policy research. High performers receive accelerated access to Fast Stream final selection stages if they pursue civil service careers post-graduation.

A 2024 YouGov survey indicates 56% of Britons self-identify as working class compared to 36% as middle class. The Social Mobility Commission considers parental occupation the most reliable class indicator.

Additional reforms will create more senior career paths outside London, with half of Fast Stream placements to be located beyond the capital by 2030. Labour ministers have previously criticized civil service culture, with Prime Minister Keir Starmer claiming last December that many in Whitehall were "comfortable in the tepid bath of managed decline."

Wood reiterated Conservative objections: "UK public services deserve talent chosen on ability. This scheme sends the message that unless you fit a particular social profile, you're no longer welcome."

FDA union leader Dave Penman welcomed the initiative, noting that "only 18% of senior civil servants are from working-class backgrounds," though he cautioned that barriers persist for advancement. Social Mobility Foundation head Sarah Atkinson praised the policy, saying: "It's encouraging to see the government leading by example."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Teen Caffeine Pouch Trend Raises Health Concerns Among Experts
fields.summary: Health experts are alarmed by a rising trend of US teenagers using dissolvable caffeine pouches for quick energy boosts, warning the practice could spread to the UK and pose significant overdose risks due to high caffeine content equivalent to multiple coffees.
fields.content:
An increasing number of American teenagers are turning to caffeine pouches to obtain rapid energy spikes, with health specialists expressing concern that this behavior may soon emerge in the UK. The teabag-like sachets are positioned between the lip and gum, delivering caffeine directly into the bloodstream. Digital influencers promote these products to both gym enthusiasts for performance enhancement and students preparing for exams.

Dr. Rob van Dam from George Washington University notes widespread availability through platforms like TikTok Shop, which offers flavored varieties designed to attract young consumers. However, he cautions that a single pouch can contain the caffeine equivalent of two standard cups of coffee, significantly increasing the risk of overdose symptoms.

Discreet usage—making detection difficult for parents and teachers—compounds the issue, with some users boasting online about "buzzing" sensations when doubling pouches. Rapid absorption means effects appear within minutes and persist for hours, potentially leading to uncontrollably high caffeine levels. Dr. van Dam warns that youth might have lower caffeine tolerance: "Young people may have less tolerance to caffeine and could end up in the emergency room if they have too much."

Why caffeine and what happens if you have too much?

Caffeine stimulates alertness by affecting the brain and nervous system. Lewis James of Loughborough University confirms its efficacy as a performance aid, explaining that it blocks adenosine receptors that cause fatigue through exercise. This mechanism has made it popular among athletes.

Pouring milk into a coffee cup

However, caffeine also impacts the cardiovascular system, causing risks like abnormal heart rhythms, rapid pulse, and seizures at elevated levels. While deaths from overdose are rare, they are documented. Sensitivity varies—some individuals experience nausea and anxiety with minimal intake.

Safety thresholds include 400mg daily for healthy adults (approximately four instant coffees) and five cups of tea. Pregnant women should halve that intake at 200mg. Young people face greater risks, leading EU regulations to mandate warnings on energy drinks with over 150mg: "High caffeine content. Not recommended for children or pregnant or breast-feeding women."

Watch for other drinks or food that contain caffeine

Dr. van Dam highlights accidental overconsumption risks given caffeine's presence in beverages and foods. "It's harder to overdose on coffee, but easier with these pouches—especially if combined with energy drinks," he states. He adds that lab tests reveal misrepresented caffeine amounts on certain product labels.

A woman biting into a chocolate bar

Dental professionals warn persistent use irritates gums, as with nicotine pouches. Experts fear caffeine pouches could act as gateways to nicotine alternatives. Bini Suresh of the Cleveland Clinic cautions this usage normalizes stimulants, creating dependency patterns: "While caffeine provides temporary alertness, it disrupts sleep and worsens fatigue long-term, especially in youth."

Health authorities advise strict moderation for teenagers, with European guidelines recommending under 3mg per kilogram of body weight daily—meaning 90mg for a 30kg child. Suresh emphasizes hydration, consistent meals, and iron-rich foods with slow-releasing carbohydrates as healthier energy solutions.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: University Fees Rise to £9,535 Amid Financial Strain for Students
fields.summary: Undergraduate tuition fees in England and Wales have increased to £9,535 annually, marking the first rise since 2017. Maintenance loans have also increased to cover living expenses, while universities report financial strains potentially leading to course cuts. The article examines how fees vary across the UK, accommodation costs, loan mechanisms, and long-term earnings prospects for graduates.
fields.content:
Tuition fees for undergraduate degrees in England and Wales have risen to £9,535 per year, while maintenance loans have increased to help students manage living expenses. This represents the first tuition fee adjustment since 2017, following sustained appeals from universities concerning financial viability. The government stated it will introduce extended funding strategies later.

How much have tuition fees gone up by in England and Wales?

Annual fees rose by £285, reflecting a 3% upturn alongside greater borrowing allowances for living costs. Students from England living away from home outside London can now access a maximum maintenance loan of £10,544 per academic year, an increase from £10,227. These adjustments were announced by the Department for Education in November 2024, aligning with inflation measures.

Why have tuition fees gone up?

The fee freeze in place since 2017 ended as universities highlighted intensifying financial challenges. England's regulator, the Office for Students, projected over 40% of universities would encounter deficits by summer 2025. Reduced real-term fee value due to high inflation and a decline in international student enrollment compounded these pressures. Students face possible reductions in staffing and course availability as a consequence.

How much are university fees in Northern Ireland and Scotland?

Higher education pricing varies across UK regions. Northern Ireland sets maximum undergraduate fees at £4,855 annually for local students, with other UK students paying £9,535. Scottish students generally attend university free of charge, while students from other UK nations pay £9,535 per year.

What does student accommodation cost across the UK?

Accommodation costs have surged according to the Higher Education Policy Institute and Unipol. Average yearly rent in ten university towns and cities (excluding London and Edinburgh) escalated from £6,520 in 2021-22 to £7,475 in 2023-24. Cities like Nottingham (£8,427) and Bristol (£9,200) reported notably higher rates. London's purpose-built student accommodation averaged £13,595 annually for 2024-25.

Chart showing how rents increased in 10 British towns and cities between 2021-22 and 2023-24 - with the average annual rent for a student room in Bournemouth rising from £6,649 in 2021-22 to £7,396 in 2023-24, Bristol £8,444 to £9,200, Cardiff £5,970 to £6,632, Exeter £7,372 to £8,558, Glasgow £6,271 to £7,548, Leeds £6,648 to £7,627, Liverpool £6,063 to £6,467, Nottingham £7,294 to £8,427, Portsmouth £6,563 to £7,183 and Sheffield £5,855 to £6,451

Hepi cautioned that maintenance loans in England scarcely cover average rent, potentially leaving students without funds for other essentials without family aid or work. Their 2025 survey revealed 68% of undergraduates engaged in term-time employment, rising from 45% in 2022. Additional monthly expenses like food, transportation, and study materials averaged £564 beyond rent.

How do student loans work?

Most UK students qualify for tuition loans and means-tested maintenance loans that accumulate interest immediately. Repayment stipulations differ nationally. England's amended 2023 repayment rules lengthen payment periods, potentially costing lower and middle earners thousands extra, according to MoneySavingExpert.com. New repayments beginning April 2025 carried an average debt of £53,000 per Student Loans Company data.

What extra financial help can students get?

Wales and Northern Ireland provide non-repayable maintenance grants. Welsh students receive at least £1,000, rising to £10,124 for low-income students in London. Northern Ireland allows up to £3,475 in grants. Scotland offers aid for specific circumstances such as student parents, with hardship funding accessible UK-wide through universities and charities.

Will I earn more money with a degree?

Graduates typically out-earn non-graduates, though this advantage has diminished. The Higher Education Statistics Agency's 2021 graduate cohort reported average earnings of £29,699 fifteen months after graduation. Fields like creative arts showed minimal lifetime earnings impact (even declining for male graduates), while subjects like medicine and economics yielded substantial financial returns - exceeding £250,000 extra for women and £500,000 for men.

Chart showing how subject choice impacts lifetime earnings for men and women across their lifetime.

Graphic showing that an earnings gap persists between graduates from different backgrounds. It shows that 46% of the graduates in the top fifth of earners at age 30 had attended private school, while 22% of graduates in that earning category had been eligible for free school meals.

The Sutton Trust highlighted inequality among graduates, with only 20% of former free-school-meal recipients in the top 20% of earners by 30, compared with 46% of privately educated graduates. Russell Group universities offered the greatest social mobility potential according to their analysis.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Unsung Ocean Heroes: How Fat Zooplankton Combat Climate Change
fields.summary: New research reveals how tiny Antarctic zooplankton migrate deep into the ocean while storing fat, effectively locking away carbon equivalent to 55 million cars' annual emissions. These overlooked creatures play a surprisingly large role in mitigating global warming through their unique life cycle.
fields.content:
Obscure marine animals often sold as aquarium food are silently protecting the planet from climate change through an extraordinary annual migration, according to new scientific findings.

Zooplankton, termed "unsung heroes" by researchers, consume vast amounts of phytoplankton during Antarctic spring, storing the carbon as fat. They then descend hundreds of meters into the ocean depths to slowly metabolize this fat during winter.

Prof Daniel J Mayor @oceanplankton Female copepods (Calanus simillimus) displaying variable quantities of lipid (fat) reserves – the clear cigar shaped ‘bubble’ within their bodies. Body length approximately 4mm.

This process annually sequesters approximately 65 million tonnes of carbon deep underwater—equivalent to the emissions from 55 million petrol cars—preventing it from warming the atmosphere. Dr. Guang Yang from the Chinese Academy of Sciences calls the findings "remarkable," noting they fundamentally change understanding of carbon storage in the Southern Ocean.

Despite their crucial role, these millimeter-sized creatures remain largely unknown compared to iconic Antarctic species like whales and penguins. Most people encounter them only as packaged fish food.

Nature's Carbon Batteries

Copepods, a crab-related zooplankton species measuring 1-10mm, spend most of their lives dormant in ocean depths between 500m and 2km. Microscopic images reveal cigar-shaped fat deposits within their transparent bodies.

Prof Daniel J Mayor @oceanplankton The Southern Ocean copepod, Calanoides acutus, with their green pigmented guts and lipid sacs clearly visible inside its transparent body. Body length approximately 4mm.

Daniel Mayor from the University of Exeter explains: "Their fat acts like a battery pack. When wintering deep below, they slowly burn this carbon-rich fat, releasing CO₂ at depths where it takes centuries to resurface." This biological mechanism contributes significantly to the Southern Ocean's role in absorbing 40% of all oceanic heat from human-caused climate change.

The research team analyzed data stretching back to the 1920s, quantifying the seasonal migration of copepods, krill and salps. Copepods emerged as the most significant carbon transporters, followed by krill and salps.

Prof Daniel J Mayor @oceanplankton A close-up of Antarctic krill, Euphausia superba, showing its specialised front limbs (the ‘feeding basket’) that help them harvest microscopic phytoplankton (algae) from the water. Its green gut demonstrates their effectiveness. It has orange patches in his body and front legs, with a large black eye at the top of its body.

Gathering Threats in Warming Seas

As scientists uncover this vital service, emerging threats endanger zooplankton populations. Angus Atkinson from Plymouth Marine Laboratory warns that climate change-induced ocean warming, disrupted water layers and extreme weather jeopardize these carbon-storing creatures.

Commercial fishing compounds the problem—nearly 500,000 tonnes of krill were harvested from Antarctic waters in 2020, authorized internationally but criticized by conservationists. Reduced zooplankton numbers would significantly impair the ocean's carbon sequestration capacity.

Prof Daniel J Mayor @oceanplankton A collection of Antarctic krill, Euphausia superba. The guts of many of these specimens are green, indicating that they have recently been feeding on microscopic algae (phytoplankton). Body lengths approximately 50-60mm.

Researchers emphasize the urgent need to incorporate these findings into climate models. Atkinson states: "Without this biological pump, atmospheric CO₂ levels would be nearly double. The oceans perform vital work absorbing and isolating carbon."

Investigations continue through expeditions like the recent two-month voyage aboard the Sir David Attenborough research ship. Scientists there worked under red light in near-freezing conditions, collecting specimens near South Orkney and South Georgia to unravel more mysteries of this carbon-capturing migration.

Prof Daniel J Mayor @oceanplankton Five scientists wearing high-vis orange jackets and dark trousers on board the Sir David Attenborough polar ship. They are working with a fishing net equipped with 9 closing nets and has a 1 × 1 m mouth. There is a large yellow crane above them.

Jennifer Freer Dr Jennifer Freer stands on deck of the Sir David Attenborough polar ship wearing orange high-vis safety clothing, a red hat and sunglasses. She is holding on to the rope railing next to the ocean. Close to the ship is the tip of an iceberg visible at the water surface. The sky is blue with some clouds.

The study appears in the journal Limnology and Oceanography, highlighting how these miniature deep-sea migrants substantially contribute to Earth's climate regulation.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Social Media Age Checks Restrict War and Political Content
fields.summary: Social media platforms like X and Reddit are restricting access to news about conflicts in Gaza and Ukraine, parliamentary debates about serious crimes, and historical artworks as they implement the UK's new Online Safety Act aimed at protecting children from harmful material.
fields.content:
Social media companies have begun blocking broad categories of online material in response to Britain's newly implemented Online Safety Act. The legislation, effective since last Friday, mandates platforms to prevent under-18s from accessing pornography, self-harm promotion, and other harmful content, with fines up to £18 million or 10% of global revenue for non-compliance.

Restrictions on Public Interest Content

BBC Verify analysis identified significant restrictions on war-related posts, including a Gaza footage showing a man searching rubble for family remains without graphic content, and Ukrainian battlefield clips featuring destroyed drones. Reddit communities discussing both the Ukraine conflict and Israel-Gaza war now require age verification when accessed via search engines.

X platform age verification prompt stating content restricted until age confirmation

UK parliamentary material has also been affected: Conservative MP Katie Lam's speech detailing child sexual exploitation by grooming gangs was accessible on official parliamentary streams but restricted on X. Lam criticized this on social platforms, stating the state protects adults from hearing about crimes instead of protecting children from them.

Conservative MPs Katie Lam and Robert Jenrick walking in Parliament corridor

Even Francisco de Goya's historical painting 'Saturn Devouring His Son' was restricted on X under the new framework, despite its artistic significance.

Implementation Concerns

Experts warn companies are over-applying restrictions, potentially suppressing legitimate discourse. Sandra Wachter of Oxford Internet Institute noted the Act wasn't intended 'to suppress facts of public interest, even if uncomfortable'. Data shows 37% of X users and 59% of Reddit visitors access platforms without logging in, meaning these unverified users experience the same restrictions as children.

Elon Musk, owner of X, strongly opposes the legislation, claiming it facilitates 'suppression of the people' while amplifying criticisms from far-right figures. Yet the Act successfully limited exposure to graphic violent and pornographic content during testing.

Regulatory Ambiguity

The UK government stated platforms determine implementation methods, but emphasized the law mustn't 'censor political debate'. Regulator Ofcom warned fines could apply both for child safety failures and freedom-of-speech violations. Professor Sonia Livingstone suggested companies might improve distinctions between harmful and public interest material over time, though many have reduced moderation teams despite needing 'nuanced' assessments.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Lindsay Lohan on motherhood, acting return and Freaky Friday sequel
fields.summary: Lindsay Lohan discusses her Hollywood comeback, personal journey into motherhood, and reuniting with Jamie Lee Curtis for the Freaky Friday sequel after more than two decades since the original film became a global hit.
fields.content:
Over two decades have passed since the mother-daughter body-swap comedy Freaky Friday captured audiences worldwide with its relatable family dynamics. Now, Jamie Lee Curtis and Lindsay Lohan reunite for Freakier Friday, a sequel exploring similar themes through a new generational lens.

The film features Lohan's character Anna as a mother navigating challenges with her biological daughter and stepdaughter. The family dynamics take an unexpected turn when four characters experience a complex body-swapping scenario. At the London premiere, Lohan expressed her enthusiasm for revisiting the beloved franchise: "Every part of me wanted to make this sequel because fans show such strong loyalty. We make people happy, and with everything happening globally, it's wonderful to offer joyous entertainment."

This project marks Lohan's continued return to Hollywood after being largely absent during the 2010s. Following her 2022 comeback film Falling for Christmas, this represents her first Disney collaboration in over a decade. The actress revealed she felt no nerves about returning, stating: "I love acting, and that passion always shows in my work." Her personal life has transformed significantly since the original film, having married financier Bader Shammas in 2022 and welcoming their son in 2023.

Becoming a parent provided Lohan with fresh perspective on the film's core themes: "Motherhood completely reshapes your life. Balancing career and parenting remains an ongoing learning process that definitely deepened my connection to this story." Reflecting on her turbulent twenties, which included several arrests and rehab stints, Lohan shared advice for her younger self: "Slow down and breathe — everything will come in time."

Getty Images Lindsay Lohan and Jamie Lee Curtis

Curtis, who won a 2023 Oscar for Everything Everywhere All at Once and reprises her role as Lohan's mother, described their reunion as natural: "This didn't feel like reconnecting because we've always remained united. I've consistently felt responsible for providing friendship and support since her teenage years." She recently met Lohan's baby in Los Angeles and emphasized the film's timely message: "Understanding is scarce globally, but experiencing each other's lives builds common ground."

The Great Depression-themed sequel carries emotional depth alongside humor according to Curtis: "Beyond the silliness, we touch on universal experiences like loss to foster empathy." The actor initiated the project after two decades, explaining the delayed timing: "We needed Lindsay to authentically portray a mother of a teenager." Original actor Chad Michael Murray returns alongside newcomer Julia Butters as Lohan's on-screen daughter.

Freakier Friday joins a wave of nostalgic sequels including the recently announced Bend It Like Beckham follow-up and the anticipated Devil Wears Prada continuation. The film premieres globally on August 8.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Allied Nations Condemn Iran Over Assassination and Kidnapping Plots Abroad
fields.summary: The United States, United Kingdom, and over a dozen other nations have jointly condemned Iran for orchestrating assassination, kidnapping, and harassment operations against citizens in Europe and North America, calling the actions unacceptable violations of sovereignty.
fields.content:
The United States and United Kingdom, backed by Canada, Germany, France, Albania, Austria, Belgium, Czechia, Denmark, Finland, the Netherlands, Spain, and Sweden, issued a formal condemnation of Iranian intelligence operations targeting individuals abroad. In a collective statement, they declared: "We are united in our opposition to the attempts of Iranian intelligence services to kill, kidnap, and harass people in Europe and North America in clear violation of our sovereignty."

The nations emphasized that such attacks constitute breaches of national sovereignty regardless of their targets. Posted by the U.S. Virtual Embassy of Iran, the statement demanded Tehran halt these activities immediately, adding: "We are committed to working together to prevent these actions from happening and we call on the Iranian authorities to put an end to such illegal activities in our respective territories."

A map shows nuclear sites in Iran that were struck by the United States during Operation Midnight Hammer.

Intelligence assessments indicate escalating Iranian covert operations targeting foreign citizens, with the U.K. reporting more than 20 documented incidents since 2022 of Iran-linked kidnap or assassination plots on British soil—many targeting Iranian dissidents.

Masih Alinejad greets friends and supporters outside the federal courthouse

Despite the international accusations, Tehran has consistently denied involvement in these alleged murder-for-hire and abduction schemes.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Mamdani's Police Defunding Reversal Criticized as Political Opportunism
fields.summary: New York State Assemblyman Zohran Mamdani faces accusations of political opportunism for reversing his stance on defunding police after an NYPD officer's death, with critics calling his change 'damage control' and 'political theatre' amid his mayoral campaign.
fields.content:
Assemblyman Zohran Mamdani has long criticized the New York Police Department, previously labeling it as "racist" and calling for its defunding in 2020. He publicly advocated dismantling the NYPD's Strategic Response Group and once posted "nature is healing" in response to an image showing an officer crying in his car.

However, following a fatal shooting in midtown Manhattan that claimed the life of NYPD Officer Didarul Islam, Mamdani stated his past calls to defund police stemmed from "frustration" over George Floyd's murder. This reversal prompted skepticism about his sincerity among community members and political opponents.

Rafael Mangual, senior fellow at the Manhattan Institute for Policy Research, characterized Mamdani's recent statements as cynical damage control after the tragedy. Mangual noted Mamdani appeared defensive during a press conference and reiterated criticism regarding the police unit involved in responding to the shooting.

Mangual remarked, "It’s going to take more than a short press conference to undo the anti-cop image Mamdani has cultivated for years." Republican State Assemblywoman Inna Vernikov added, "He spent years bashing the NYPD and pushing a radical agenda... Nobody with half a brain is buying it."

Republican colleague Jake Blumencranz described Mamdani's press conference as "political theatre," noting, "While a police officer and innocent New Yorkers were being murdered, Mamdani was in Uganda, not New York. Now he’s playing pro-police for the cameras?" Blumencranz highlighted Mamdani's past description of the NYPD as "wicked and corrupt" and his demands to "dismantle it" amid calls to disband the unit deployed to the mass shooting.

Zohran Mamdani visits Washington, D.C.

Blumencranz concluded this wasn't genuine growth but "opportunism dressed up as evolution." Mamdani later attended Officer Islam's funeral alongside Republican mayoral candidate Curtis Sliwa, former Governor Andrew Cuomo, and current Mayor Eric Adams. At the funeral, Mamdani praised the fallen officer and distanced himself from his previous positions.

Sliwa funeral

"I am not running to defund the police," Mamdani stated during his press conference, framing himself as "a candidate who learns and leads" who must sometimes admit past missteps. His campaign has not responded to inquiries regarding these criticisms.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Scientific Study Identifies Age 50 as Critical Turning Point in Human Aging
fields.summary: Chinese researchers have discovered a major acceleration in biological aging starting around age 50, with blood vessels showing particular vulnerability. The study examined seven bodily systems and identified significant protein changes during midlife that increase susceptibility to aging-related decline.
fields.content:
Scientists in China have determined that human tissues and organs undergo accelerated aging beginning around age 50. Their research reveals a sharp increase in aging processes around this milestone, with blood vessels demonstrating particular sensitivity to deterioration.

younger person holding hands of older person

The comprehensive study examined samples from seven bodily systems: cardiovascular, digestive, immune, endocrine, respiratory, integumentary (skin), and musculoskeletal, supplemented by blood samples. Analysis showed that between ages 45 and 55, substantial protein restructuring occurs across multiple tissues.

A table indicating where researchers noted sensitivity to aging in the human body per age.

The aorta emerges as especially vulnerable during this period of "substantial proteomic remodeling" that heightens aging susceptibility. Study co-author Guanghui Liu from the Beijing Institute for Stem Cell and Regenerative Medicine explained that while aging involves multi-organ decline, they investigated whether different organs age at consistent rates.

Blood vessels appear to act as early indicators of aging, releasing proteins that influence body-wide deterioration. Liu identified "senokines"—substances in blood that function as biological timekeepers—as key drivers that both track and accelerate the aging process.

"Together, our findings lay the groundwork for a systems-level understanding of human aging through the lens of proteins," the researchers concluded. They propose that aging is not an organ-specific process but rather a whole-body phenomenon with ripple effects across biological systems.

The discovery suggests potential for non-invasive aging assessments through blood tests, enabling researchers to evaluate aging rates by connecting tissue profiles with plasma indicators.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Accidental Discovery in Murky River Reveals Civil War-Era Shipwreck
fields.summary: Marine archaeologists exploring Wisconsin's Fox River unexpectedly discovered the preserved hull of a historic vessel believed to be the 19th-century steamboat L.W. Crane. The accidental find reveals new insights into regional maritime history despite challenging underwater conditions.
fields.content:
The Wisconsin Underwater Archaeology Association confirmed a significant discovery during operations near Oshkosh: the remarkably intact hull of a nineteenth-century vessel resting in the Fox River. Historians believe the sunken wreck represents the L.W. Crane, constructed in 1865 and lost in 1880.

"We knew the Crane was in this vicinity, and finding her remains remained a possibility," said WUAA president Brendon Baillod. "However, we assumed she'd be completely buried beneath river sediment." Visibility challenges make diving difficult along the sediment-heavy Fox River.

To their surprise, the team found the entire hull structure clearly visible below. The Wisconsin Historical Society later highlighted the discovery through social media posts. Their maritime archaeologist Jordan Ciesielczyk described the event as "a happy accident, and completely unexpected."

Researchers on Fox River trip

Initially focused on documenting another historic wreck—the 1856 steamboat Berlin City that sank in 1870—archaeologists spotted the unexpected signature while scanning between survey areas. "We were moving upriver when this wreckage suddenly appeared on our screen," Ciesielczyk recalled. "It was very exciting!"

Evidence strongly suggests the vessel is the Crane due to contextual clues matching historical records. Measuring 90 feet long and 20 feet wide, dimensions align with the known specifications of the L.W. Crane. Historical accounts confirm the barge caught fire in 1880, was set adrift, burned, and sank near railroad bridge infrastructure—just 100 yards from recently documented stone bridge caissons.

Researchers smiling after trip

No artifacts have yet been identified, though further research may reveal hidden items despite adverse conditions. "Diving here is incredibly challenging due to powerful currents and visibility so poor you can't see your hands," Ciesielczyk explained, referencing prior Fox River dive experiences. Exploration remains complicated by these environmental factors.

Sonar image of ship on bottom of river

This finding represents part of a series of recent historical shipwreck identifications throughout the Midwest, including the J.C. Ames—a former lumber vessel deliberately destroyed in 1923.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Preseason Opener: Chargers Beat Lions as Trey Lance Stars in Hall of Fame Game
fields.summary: In the NFL's Hall of Fame Game preseason opener, the Los Angeles Chargers defeated the Detroit Lions 27-7, led by quarterback Trey Lance's two touchdown passes. The annual game in Canton, Ohio showcased Lance's potential as he guided scoring drives after Lions turnovers.
fields.content:
The NFL preseason kicked off with the Hall of Fame Game in Canton, Ohio, featuring the Los Angeles Chargers and Detroit Lions. Quarterback Trey Lance, the third overall pick in the 2021 draft now with the Chargers, seized the spotlight with a strong opening performance.

After a Lions fumble on the opening kickoff, Lance needed only five plays to capitalize, finding Will Dissly for a 4th-and-2 touchdown pass that capped a 28-yard drive. The catch gave the Chargers the first points of the preseason.

Lance struck again in the first half with a precise slant pass to rookie receiver KeAndre Lambert-Smith. The fifth-round draft pick from Auburn outraced defenders to the end zone, extending the Chargers' lead to 21-7.

KeAndre Lambert-Smith making touchdown catch

Chargers rookie KeAndre Lambert-Smith

Lance continued into the second half, orchestrating two scoring drives that resulted in field goals. He completed 12 of 20 passes for 120 yards with two touchdowns during his playing time.

Detroit backup quarterback Hendon Allen struggled in his preseason debut, completing 9 of 14 attempts for 91 yards with two interceptions. Running back Craig Reynolds provided a bright spot for the Lions, scoring on one of his ten carries. Rookie receiver Isaac TeSlaa caught two passes for 46 yards.

Special teams miscues plagued the Lions, including a muffed punt by Jakobie Keeney-James that gave the Chargers possession at Detroit's five-yard line. Detroit's defense prevented a subsequent touchdown. Despite preseason mistakes, both teams gained valuable experience as training camp progresses.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Secret Messaging Trick Using iPhone's Notes App
fields.summary: Learn how to transform your iPhone Notes app into a private messaging tool with this easy step-by-step guide, enabling real-time conversations that can be completely erased afterward.
fields.content:
How to Use Notes as a Secret Messaging App

Before starting, ensure both you and the person you're messaging have updated iPhones, as this feature doesn't support Android devices.

To set up your private chat, open the Notes app to create a new note. Add your contact as a collaborator to establish the shared messaging space.

iphone notes 2

iphone notes 3

Once your contact opens the note, type messages directly into the document. Text appears instantly without needing a send button. Swipe right on any text to see the name of who wrote it.

iphone notes 4

Securing the Conversation

When your private discussion ends, stop sharing the note to immediately remove it from the other person's device. Finally, delete it from your own Notes app to erase all traces.

iphone notes 5

iphone notes 6

What This Means for You

This technique is perfect for sharing sensitive information or coordinating plans discreetly in public spaces. Messages synchronize instantly with color-coded attribution showing different contributors.

For complete privacy, stopping the note share makes it vanish from the other device immediately. Deletion afterward ensures no records remain, all managed through Apple's native tools.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Russian Businessman Accused of $3 Million Tax Evasion
fields.summary: Authorities in Russia's Tula region have completed an investigation into a local metal industry entrepreneur accused of evading over 260 million rubles ($3M) in taxes through falsified documents.
fields.content:
A businessman from Tula region faces criminal prosecution for allegedly evading tax payments exceeding 260 million rubles (approx $3 million), announced the regional Investigative Committee of Russia. The entrepreneur operates in metal processing and sales, according to official sources.

Investigators determined the individual filed fraudulent tax returns to avoid paying value-added tax, income taxes, and mandatory insurance contributions. Documentation showed false information led to unremitted payments totaling over 260 million rubles between various tax categories.

The completed investigation targets the businessman under Part 2 of Article 199 of Russia's Criminal Code, addressing large-scale tax evasion. Authorities confirmed the accused voluntarily repaid the full damage amount during the investigation proceedings.

Prosecutors will reportedly transfer the criminal case materials to court soon for review. The regional Investigative Department stated key evidence has been compiled for the judicial process.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Russia Accuses Estonia of Politically Motivated Persecution Against Citizens
fields.summary: Russia's embassy in Tallinn has accused Estonian authorities of ongoing politically motivated persecution against Russian citizens, citing a recent 6.5-year prison sentence for a Russian national convicted of espionage.
fields.content:
MOSCOW, August 1 - The Russian Embassy in Estonia has declared that Tallinn persists in targeting Russian citizens for political reasons, as announced amidst a recent court verdict involving a Russian national.

Earlier in July, Estonian public broadcaster ERR reported that the country's court sentenced a Russian citizen residing in Narva to 6.5 years imprisonment. The conviction was based on allegations he transferred information having "significance for Estonia's security" to Russia.

"Law enforcement agencies of Estonia continue to persecute our compatriots on political grounds," stated the embassy. "These fabricated espionage charges aim to intimidate residents of Estonia and distance them from Russia, which remains the historical homeland for many."

The diplomatic mission further criticized Estonia's approach as short-sighted, asserting it exposes the government's anti-Russian sentiments.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: US Dollar Regains Strength Against Kazakhstani Tenge
fields.summary: The US dollar is appreciating against the Kazakhstani tenge following temporary stabilization efforts by the National Bank, with markets testing the central bank's tolerance levels amid calmer trading conditions.
fields.content:
The US dollar is strengthening again against Kazakhstan's national currency after a brief decline caused by the National Bank's interventions. As of August 1, 2025, the currency appreciation is progressing gradually, contrasting with previous volatility.

Foreign exchange trading on the Kazakhstan Stock Exchange (KASE) remained relatively stable despite the dollar's rise. By 15:30 local time, minor exchange rate adjustments were observed in currency markets nearing week's end.

Eldar Shamsutdinov, an economist and Telegram channel analyst, noted the market is positioned for further tenge weakening. Traders appear to be gauging the National Bank's response threshold without recent intervention activity detected.

Exchange Office Rates

Currency exchange points tracked by Kurs.kz have adjusted dollar purchase prices as of 15:30 on August 1. Euro exchange rates have similarly shifted at retail currency outlets across Kazakhstan.

The National Bank earlier reported that throughout July, the tenge had depreciated by 4% against major foreign currencies. This preceded their intervention actions to counter rapid dollar and euro appreciation. Economic analysts have examined which sectors might benefit from the ongoing currency depreciation.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Rare Tornado Strikes Pavlodar, Kazakhstan: Residents Capture Stunning Footage
fields.summary: Residents of Pavlodar, Kazakhstan observed a rare tornado on August 1, 2025, capturing dramatic footage of the rotating funnel cloud that shocked local citizens and prompted weather-related safety discussions.
fields.content:
On August 1, 2025, residents of Pavlodar, Kazakhstan, witnessed a rare meteorological event as a tornado formed over their city. Numerous citizens documented the phenomenon, sharing photos and videos across social media platforms showing the rotating column of air descending toward the ground.

One local resident, Andrius Sarapinas, filmed the tornado while mushroom hunting outside city limits. He reported: "Today we went for mushrooms, but a tornado started. Yes, you heard right—a tornado in Pavlodar. I don't know how to react. It just kept getting larger."

Another resident, Vladimir Kirichenko, captured the tornado within city boundaries. "I honestly see this for the first time. Is this really a tornado in Pavlodar?" he remarked in his footage. Additional videos appeared on social media accounts, including one shot by local children.

The tornado appeared alongside lightning strikes and thunderclaps, with some residents reporting hailstorms. Witnesses identified it as a tornado due to its distinctive funnel cloud formation. A warning was issued that some circulating videos contained explicit language.

Defining Severe Weather Phenomena

Such events prompt clarification about severe weather terminology. A hurricane constitutes a powerful atmospheric vortex with wind speeds reaching 120 km/h at altitude and up to 200 km/h near ground level.

A storm features prolonged, intense winds exceeding 20 m/s, typically occurring during cyclones alongside destructive land impacts and turbulent seas.

A tornado—also called a twister—forms within thunderclouds before extending downward as a funnel-shaped column, generally measuring between tens and hundreds of meters wide. This phenomenon remains relatively brief and moves together with its parent cloud system.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: BBC Under Pressure to Axe MasterChef After Host Controversies
fields.summary: The BBC faces growing demands to cancel the new MasterChef series following the dismissal of presenters Gregg Wallace and John Torode after multiple misconduct complaints. Broadcast unions and women's rights groups argue airing the show disrespects victims and rewards inappropriate behavior, despite claims of contestant support.
fields.content:
The BBC confronts intensifying pressure to scrap this year's MasterChef season after firing hosts Gregg Wallace and John Torode over upheld complaints. Broadcast union Bectu declared misconduct "should not be rewarded with prime-time coverage," while a leading women's rights organization cautioned many would feel "deeply uncomfortable" watching the show.

Demands escalated after contestant Sarah Shafi disclosed she was edited out for requesting the series not air. The BBC acknowledged this was "not an easy decision," but cited "widespread support" among chefs.

Controversy erupted last year with misconduct allegations against Wallace. An inquiry by production company Banijay later validated over 40 complaint settlements involving him, including unwelcome physical contact and inappropriate undress. It also substantiated claims Torode used a "severely offensive racist term" in 2018.

The BBC proceeded with the pre-recorded series after "careful consultation" with contestants, though workers alleging misconduct weren't consulted. Bectu head Philippa Childs warned broadcasting would "trigger" complainants: "When serious findings are upheld, broadcasters should not reward bad behavior with prime-time coverage."

Women who accused Wallace echoed this sentiment. One stated airing shows "blatant disregard for people who came forward," asking, "How can you be fired when your work stays public?" Another called it "profoundly disrespectful," adding it suggests such conduct gets overlooked.

Gregg Wallace and John Torode portrait

Fawcett Society CEO Penny East expressed concern: "Seeing Gregg Wallace will deeply discomfort many, especially the women who spoke out. Men who harass shouldn't retain platforms and power." She suggested editing out hosts altogether may have been preferable despite contestants' hard work.

"Ideally, it would've been axed"

Contestant Sarah Shafi, removed during editing for opposing broadcast, said ideally the show would be cancelled. "This sends the message that [the BBC] don't support victims or condemn enabling environments," she said. Shafi felt pressured into approving airing and called her erasure silencing women "yet again."

Banijay countered they reviewed footage after Shafi’s formal complaint and found no evidence supporting her claims of inappropriate behavior by Wallace during filming. She also described the show as "a boys' game" where she felt uncomfortably "eyed up and ogled."

"Not an easy decision"

The BBC defended airing: "We know not everyone agrees, but it recognizes contestants' dedication and offers audience choice." They stressed broadcasting "doesn't diminish the complaints' seriousness" and acknowledged standards expectations.

Wallace denied the "most serious allegations" among 83 complaints but admitted inappropriate humor and language, offering unreserved apology. Torode said he couldn't recall the racist term incident but called such language "wholly unacceptable."

Source: Original Article

fields.title: US Raises Tariffs on Canada to 35%, Sparking Trade Dispute
fields.summary: US President Donald Trump has escalated trade tensions by raising tariffs on Canadian goods to 35%, citing insufficient cooperation on drug control. Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney expressed disappointment, defending Canada's enforcement efforts. While most Canadian exports avoid tariffs under the USMCA agreement, this move follows broader trade levies imposed on dozens of nations.
fields.content:
Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney voiced disappointment as the United States increased tariffs on select Canadian exports from 25% to 35%. US President Donald Trump announced the move, asserting that Canada had not adequately cooperated in preventing fentanyl and other drugs from crossing the border. Canadian officials highlighted ongoing actions against drug trafficking networks.

The United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) protects roughly 90% of Canadian products from the tariffs, exempting fresh produce, energy exports, and most industrial goods. However, items like dairy, wood, and leather could still face charges depending on forthcoming discussions.

Trump simultaneously imposed tariffs ranging from 10% to 50% on numerous other nations. Economists caution these measures may raise costs for US consumers and businesses, a concern dismissed by White House Press Secretary Karoline Leavitt, who claimed Trump was revitalizing America's economy.

Most nations received a seven-day grace period before the tariffs took effect. Shipments dispatched by August 7 and arriving before October 5 remain unaffected. The Canadian tariff increase became effective at 00:01 Eastern Time on Friday.

Mexicotemporarily avoided a planned tariff hike to 35%, maintaining its current 25% rate for an additional 90 days. White House officials attributed the differing treatments to Canada's perceived lack of constructive engagement in negotiations.

Broader Global Impact

Tariffs severely affected multiple Asian economies. India faces a 25% levy, while Taiwan contends with 20%. Taiwanese President Lai Ching-te termed the measure temporary and pledged swift negotiations with Washington.

Laos received the second-highest rate at 40%, trailing Syria's 41%. Even smaller economies like Vanuatu and Papua New Guinea encountered 15% duties. Countries not explicitly listed face a baseline 10% tariff.

South Korea secured a 15% tariff through a deal involving US investment commitments. Immediately following this announcement, protests emerged near the US embassy in Seoul.

Getty Images A member of a civic group wearing a mask of US President Donald Trump stands during a protest against Trump's tariff policy near the US embassy on July 30, 2025 in Seoul, South Korea

Negotiations and Responses

Trump's tariff expansion originated in April with "reciprocal" duties designed to reduce the US trade deficit. Initial market turbulence led him to postpone the harshest measures, opening negotiations. Over 200 countries contacted the administration, resulting in framework agreements with major partners including the UK, China, Japan, and the EU.

Indiareportedly faced an unresolved negotiation outcome. Trump mentioned an unspecified additional penalty linked to India's relations with Russia. Switzerland encountered a 39% tariff after President Karin Keller-Sutter's last-minute call with Trump failed to secure a deal.

Canada emphasized pursuing diversified trade beyond the US. Former Trade Minister Mary Ng noted the deeply integrated supply chains but affirmed efforts to decrease reliance on American markets, stating opportunities exist worldwide.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Labour MP Tulip Siddiq Faces Corruption Trial in Bangladesh
fields.summary: British Labour MP Tulip Siddiq will stand trial in Bangladesh on August 11 over corruption allegations involving land acquisition during her aunt's administration. She denies all charges as politically motivated.
fields.content:
British Labour politician Tulip Siddiq is scheduled for trial in Bangladesh later this month regarding corruption accusations tied to her family. The Hampstead and Highgate MP faces charges involving allegedly illegal land acquisition during the leadership of her aunt, former Bangladeshi Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina.

The country's Anti-Corruption Commission confirmed Siddiq will be tried alongside over 20 others—including Hasina and family members—on August 11. The hearing will proceed in her absence if she fails to attend. The cases involve accusations that Siddiq influenced her aunt's government to secure a plot in Dhaka's Purbachal area for her mother, brother, and sister.

Siddiq's legal representatives have rejected the allegations as "politically motivated," stating she owns no land in Purbachal. They note Bangladesh never formally communicated court details to Siddiq and criticized investigators for ignoring legal correspondence while conducting media briefings. Bangladeshi authorities issued an arrest warrant for Siddiq earlier this year after she missed multiple court summonses.

Separately, Siddiq is under investigation for alleged embezzlement tied to Bangladesh's $3.9 billion Russian-funded nuclear power plant deal from 2013. Authorities claim around $234 billion was illicitly moved from Bangladesh during Hasina's tenure. Siddiq denies involvement in the energy contract, which opposition figure Bobby Hajjaj brought to light.

The MP resigned as a treasury minister in January, citing potential "distraction" from her duties despite maintaining her innocence. An inquiry by the UK prime minister's standards adviser found no evidence of wrongdoing but noted Siddiq should have been more aware of "reputational risks" from her family ties. Bangladesh's interim leader recently declined Siddiq's request to discuss the allegations, calling it a legal matter.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Liberal Democrats Propose 8% Profit Cap on SEND Schools
fields.summary: The Liberal Democrats have called for an 8% profit cap on private providers of special educational needs schools, citing research showing some firms make over 20% margins while local councils face financial strain. The proposal aims to redirect funds from shareholders to support disabled children.
fields.content:
The Liberal Democrats demand profit limitations for private special educational needs and disabilities (SEND) schooling providers, condemning what they term "shameless profiteering." Party-commissioned research reveals some companies generate tens of millions annually with profit margins surpassing 20%.

House of Commons Library analysis identified several leading SEND education firms—including those backed by offshore private equity—experiencing substantial profit growth. One provider reportedly earned £44 million in profit from £208 million turnover, marking a 60% two-year surge. Another recorded £20.9 million profit on £194.2 million revenue, a 10.8% margin.

Education spokesperson Munira Wilson contends these profits come "off the backs of disabled children" as local authorities face budget pressures. Describing the situation as "an absolute scandal," she accused private equity firms of exploiting SEND provision shortages, stating: "Children with special educational needs deserve the best possible support, and should not be viewed as cash cows for vulture firms."

The proposed 8% profit cap would parallel similar measures considered for children's homes. Companies exceeding the limit could face sanctions including repaying excess profits to local authorities. The policy would coincide with expanding state-run provision, supporting councils to build schools and accelerating 66 planned special free schools.

A government spokesperson acknowledged: "The system we've inherited has been failing families of children with SEND for far too long, and it's appalling that some companies are capitalising on this crisis." Officials are reviewing a major SEND system overhaul to be detailed in a forthcoming Schools White Paper, while emphasizing plans require schools to prioritize "improving children's outcomes—not excessive profit-making."

This follows December's £740 million funding announcement for SEND pupils and alternative education, aimed at increasing specialist places in mainstream schools.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: DNA Bone Test Suggests New Origins for Ancient Egyptian Civilization
fields.summary: Analysis of 4,500-year-old skeletal DNA reveals unprecedented links between Ancient Egyptian and Mesopotamian populations, suggesting these civilizations exchanged ideas and people during a pivotal transformation period.
fields.content:
Genetic analysis of a 4,500-year-old skeleton from the Nile Valley has provided new evidence about the emergence of Ancient Egyptian civilization. The man was around 60 years old when he died and possibly worked as a potter.

Remarkably, 20% of his DNA originated from ancestors in Mesopotamia—modern Iraq—situated 1,500 kilometers away. This marks the first biological proof of connections between these two great contemporary civilizations.

Liverpool John Moores University. Nature A stark, white human skull is depicted against a black Backround

The findings support theories that Egypt's evolution from scattered farming communities into a dominant civilization was influenced by exchanges with Mesopotamia. They may explain how writing and agriculture spread through migration and shared innovations.

Professor Pontus Skoglund of London's Francis Crick Institute noted that analyzing ancient DNA reveals overlooked details about ordinary people's lives. He stated: "Putting DNA evidence alongside archaeological and written records promises exciting historical insights."

Researchers extracted DNA from the inner ear bone of remains buried in Nuwayrat, 265km south of Cairo. The man lived between 4,500-4,800 years ago during both civilizations' transformation eras. While archaeological evidence indicated possible contacts dating back 10,000 years, this study offers direct biological confirmation.

Liverpool John Moores University/Nature Nearly full skeleton missing his right lower arm as well as fingers and toes on each hand and foot appearing against a black background

According to researcher Adeline Morez Jacobs, this provides definitive evidence that people and ideas moved between these centers: "Both regions pioneered early writing systems—and now we know they were connected." Future sampling may reveal migration timing and scale from West Asia.

The individual was buried before artificial mummification became common, aiding DNA preservation. His burial involved placement in a ceramic pot within a hillside tomb. Chemical analysis of his teeth indicated he was likely raised in Egypt.

Garstang Museum/Liverpool University/Nature A black and white picture showing a colleaction of bones including the person's skill in a vircular vessel

Professor Joel Irish reconstructed the man's life through bone analysis. Standing at 5ft 2in and aged 45-65 with arthritis, bone structure indicated a labor-intensive life as a potter. Spinal and arm adaptations pointed to long hours sitting while lifting heavy materials and looking downward.

The Metropolitan Museum of Art At the top are eight crudely drawn bowls below which is a seated potter on the right using his left hand to turn a potters wheel on whihc sits a vessel they are creating. On the left is another figure bending over about to lift a bowl

Dr. Linus Girdland Flink highlighted the specimen's extraordinary survival. Excavated in 1902 and preserved despite wartime destruction in Liverpool, it revealed unexpected ancestry ties from the Fertile Crescent. The research has been published in Nature.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: UK Government Signs AI Partnership Deal With OpenAI
fields.summary: The UK government has announced a strategic partnership with OpenAI to integrate artificial intelligence across public services. The agreement aims to enhance productivity and economic growth while facing criticism over privacy transparency and commercial use of public data.
fields.content:
The UK government revealed a strategic agreement with OpenAI, creator of ChatGPT, to implement artificial intelligence in public services for increased productivity.

This non-binding deal involves potential OpenAI access to UK government data, with applications planned across education, defence, security, and the justice system.

Technology Secretary Peter Kyle asserted: "AI will be fundamental in driving change in the UK and driving economic growth." He emphasized the technology's role in addressing national challenges.

Digital rights advocates criticized the arrangement, with the Foxglove organization calling it "hopelessly vague." Activists accused the government of taking a "credulous approach to big tech's increasingly dodgy sales pitch."

According to the agreement terms, both parties may create an "information sharing programme" while developing safeguards to "protect the public and uphold democratic values."

Collaboration could include infrastructure investments like expanding data centers needed for AI operations. OpenAI concurrently announced plans to grow its London office, which already employs over 100 staff.

OpenAI CEO Sam Altman predicted the partnership would "deliver prosperity for all," while University of Salford researcher Dr. Gordon Fletcher noted AI could free public servants to handle "difficult one-in-a-million situations."

Fletcher cautioned about ethical concerns, questioning whether implementation could happen "transparently and ethically, with minimal data drawn from the public."

Foxglove's Martha Dark warned government data represented a "treasure trove" with "enormous commercial value" for training future AI models, directly benefiting OpenAI.

Dark criticized policymakers: "Peter Kyle seems bizarrely determined to put the big tech fox in charge of the henhouse when it comes to UK sovereignty."

AI plans

Government records show Technology Secretary Kyle dined with Sam Altman twice this spring, signaling ongoing dialogue preceding the agreement.

Kyle explained the government must collaborate with "global companies which are innovating on a scale the British state cannot match" in a recent podcast interview.

The move comes as the UK confronts economic stagnation, with projections indicating just 0.1%-0.2% growth for April-June.

Prime Minister Keir Starmer unveiled an "AI Opportunities Action Plan" in January, seeking tech-driven growth solutions supported by industry leaders.

UK tech representatives like UKAI's Tim Flagg previously argued such initiatives focus too narrowly on large corporations rather than domestic innovation.

The government finalized similar arrangements with Google and Anthropic earlier this year, reinforcing its invitation for major US AI investments.

Officials stated the OpenAI collaboration "could mean that world-changing AI tech is developed in the UK, driving discoveries that will deliver growth."

UK civil servants already use OpenAI models through the Humphrey toolset, designed for productivity enhancement.

This AI adoption has attracted criticism, including protests from musicians objecting to unlicensed training data usage.

Generative systems like ChatGPT generate content using books, media, and copyrighted materials, raising infringement concerns when trained without authorization.

The technology additionally faces scrutiny for tendencies to propagate false information or inadequate guidance through prompt responses.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Steven Knight Announced as Writer for Next James Bond Film
fields.summary: Acclaimed screenwriter Steven Knight, creator of Peaky Blinders, has been confirmed to write the upcoming James Bond film directed by Denis Villeneuve. The announcement marks a significant shift as long-time series producers Barbara Broccoli and Michael G. Wilson step aside.
fields.content:
Peaky Blinders creator Steven Knight will pen the next installment of the James Bond franchise, according to Amazon MGM Studios. The film is being developed under new leadership following the departure of longtime series producers Barbara Broccoli and Michael G. Wilson earlier this year.

Knight expressed his enthusiasm about the project, telling media outlets: "It has always been on my bucket list and it's fantastic to be invited to do it – I can't wait to get started." The BAFTA-winning writer added that he hopes to draw from his lifelong appreciation of the series to create something that feels both authentic and innovative.

However, Knight declined to reveal who might replace Daniel Craig as Agent 007. Craig bowed out after 2021's No Time To Die, and rumors have circulated about possible successors including British actors Aaron Taylor-Johnson and James Norton, as well as Ireland's Paul Mescal.

Daniel Craig in a tuxedo

Knight brings considerable prestige to the project, having created the hit BBC series Peaky Blinders and earned an Oscar nomination for Dirty Pretty Things. His recent works include the BBC drama This Town and Princess Diana biopic Spencer, which garnered Kristen Stewart an Academy Award nod.

Director Denis Villeneuve, known for Dune, is set to helm the project. Knight recalled being surprised by the offer during a meeting with producer Amy Pascal: "Very quickly discovered what it was about and became very, very excited." He acknowledged the high-pressure nature of the assignment but emphasized his commitment to deliver bold work.

Denis Villeneuve in a black shirt and smart jacket

Produced by Pascal and David Heyman, the next Bond film might debut around 2028 according to industry reports. This follows No Time To Die, which featured writing contributions from Neal Purvis, Robert Wade, Cary Joji Fukunaga, and Phoebe Waller-Bridge.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Trump Urges Hamas to Surrender for Swift End to Gaza Conflict
fields.summary: Former President Donald Trump has declared that Hamas should surrender and release hostages as the fastest resolution to the Gaza conflict, marking a shift in his messaging. The article details the collapse of ceasefire talks and reactions to an international declaration calling for Palestinian governance changes.
fields.content:
Former President Donald Trump asserted that Hamas ending hostilities and freeing hostages represents the swiftest path to peace in Gaza. "The fastest way to end the humanitarian crises in Gaza is for Hamas to SURRENDER AND RELEASE THE HOSTAGES!!!" Trump stated publicly, signaling a notable adjustment from his previous positions on the conflict.

This stance diverges from Trump's recent acknowledgments of Israel's role in Gaza's humanitarian situation. He had previously recognized "real starvation in Gaza," creating distance from Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's perspective. The shift occurs amid stalled diplomatic efforts to pause fighting.

Steve Witkoff, Benjamin Netanyahu

Recent ceasefire negotiations in Qatar collapsed, prompting U.S. and Israeli withdrawal from talks. Officials cited Hamas as obstructing progress through bad-faith engagement. Steve Witkoff condemned the militant group, stating on social media platform X, "It is a shame that Hamas has acted in this selfish way."

A declaration obtained by The Times of Israel outlined key demands for postwar governance. It called for unifying Gaza and the West Bank under Palestinian Authority control while demanding dismantlement of Hamas' military capabilities. The document commended mediation attempts by the U.S., Egypt, and Qatar.

Saudi Arabia and France co-chair UN conference

Critics expressed skepticism about the document despite its peace rhetoric. Anne Bayefsky characterized the declaration as undermining U.S. policy and ignoring historical Jewish connections to the region. "There is zero reference to a Jewish state, to Jews, or Jewish history – or to antisemitism," she emphasized.

Bayefsky further noted plans for a September meeting coinciding with the U.N. General Assembly, anticipating confrontation. Israel formally rejected the declaration while the U.S. dismissed it as "unproductive and ill-timed." Ambassador Danny Danon warned against appeasing terrorist forces.

Israeli UN Ambassador Danny Danon

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Linda McMahon Details Trump Plan to Shift Education Control to States
fields.summary: Education Secretary Linda McMahon revealed the Trump administration's efforts to transfer education oversight to state governments, calling it a nonpartisan priority during an interview at the National Governors Association summer meeting.
fields.content:
Education Secretary Linda McMahon emphasized education's bipartisan nature while discussing plans to reduce federal oversight at the National Governors Association summer meeting. "I'm not getting push back because it's many states from both sides of the aisle," McMahon said, noting educational challenges affect both Democratic and Republican states equally.

During the Colorado Springs gathering, McMahon secured agreements to release $6.8 billion in previously frozen K-12 funding before participating in a panel discussion with Colorado Governor Jared Polis. She stressed that coordinating with governors is essential for the administration's plan to shift educational authority. "It's just incredibly important that if we are going to return education to the states, we have to talk to the governors," McMahon stated.

Gov. Jared Polis and Secretary Linda McMahon on stage

The former WWE CEO explained that returning educational control "means giving states back the part handled by the federal government," adding they're "anxious for it." McMahon has conducted extensive visits to charter and public schools nationwide to understand regional differences. "Every state has different needs," she observed, but highlighted literacy as a universal priority across both parties.

Education Secretary Linda McMahon

Despite concerning results from the Nation's Report Card showing the U.S. lagging internationally, McMahon expressed confidence in improvements under Trump. "The president is keen on making sure the United States takes its rightful place as an educational leader," she said. McMahon also endorsed empowering teachers through reduced bureaucracy, noting governors support fair pay and classroom innovation. "Let's let teachers teach. This is all good," she concluded.

The article was authored by a political affairs writer.

Source: Original Article

fields.title: Powassan Virus Case in Maine: Risks and Prevention Strategies
fields.summary: A Maine resident has been diagnosed with Powassan virus, a rare tick-borne disease causing neurological symptoms with a 10-15% fatality rate in severe cases. Health experts warn of its rapid transmission time and emphasize prevention.
fields.content:
Health officials report a Maine resident has contracted Powassan virus, a potentially dangerous tick-borne illness that has raised concerns as tick season approaches its peak across the United States. According to medical advisors, while less common than Lyme disease, this virus presents significant dangers due to its ability to trigger severe neurological complications.

Dr. Jorge P. Parada, a medical advisor to the National Pest Management Association, highlighted the virus's uniquely rapid transmission: "Powassan can be transmitted in as little as 15 minutes after an infected tick bites, whereas Lyme disease typically requires 36 to 48 hours of attachment." This swift transmission window, combined with an incubation period of one to four weeks, makes early detection challenging.

Transmission and Symptoms

Active primarily from late spring through mid-fall, Powassan virus carries alarming severity—approximately 10% to 15% of severe infections prove fatal according to health agencies. Initial symptoms mirror common viral illnesses: fever, headache, vomiting and fatigue, with many infected individuals showing no signs at all.

However, in critical cases, neurological issues emerge including difficulty speaking, confusion, coordination loss and seizures. Dr. Marc Siegel, a senior medical analyst, confirmed these risks, noting survivors of severe cases frequently suffer lasting complications like chronic headaches, memory impairment and muscle weakness.

Powassan virus

Prevention and Management

With no specific treatment or vaccine available, managing symptoms remains the sole approach for Powassan virus infections. "Prevention is critical," stressed Parada, advising that protective measures against Lyme disease apply equally here. Recommendations include immediate tick checks after outdoor activities and using EPA-approved insect repellents.

Environmental precautions are equally vital: keeping grass trimmed short and installing wood chip or gravel barriers between lawns and wooded areas to create a 'tick moat.' These methods help minimize tick migration into residential spaces during peak season from late spring to mid-fall.

Close up photo of adult female deer tick crawling on piece of straw
